# 黄帝内经素问补注释文

**The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: *Suwen* with Supplementary Commentary**

Title: *The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: *Suwen* with Supplementary Commentary*

*The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: *Suwen*** is a work from the pre-Qin era, its author unknown. Commentary was added by Tang-dynasty scholar Wang Bing (王冰), and later corrected by Song-dynasty scholars Lin Yi (林亿) and others. It comprises fifty volumes.

Base text source: *The Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Dynasty* (《正统道藏》), **Taoist Mysteries Section** (太玄部).

Collation texts: The Ming-dynasty edition by Gu Congde (顾从德), modeled after the Song-dynasty printing, abbreviated as *Gu* text.

**Overview of *The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: *Suwen***:**
Your servant has heard that those who remember safety must not forget peril, and those who cherish life must not forget death—this was the foremost concern of the ancient sages. Those who seek to remedy the people’s afflictions and alleviate their suffering—this is the profound benevolence of the sovereign.

In ancient times, when the Yellow Emperor ruled, he used the principles of the Dao to govern his body and the remaining teachings to bring order to the world. Seated in the Hall of Enlightenment, he surveyed the eight extremes, examined the establishment of the five constants.

He declared: "Human life begins by drawing in **Yin** while embracing **Yang**, nourished by flavors and shaped by colors. From without, there are the opposing forces of cold and heat; from within, the conflicting emotions of joy and anger. Sudden death and lingering illness alternate in succession, affecting the state."

When he wished to enumerate the five blessings of the times and bestow them upon the common people, he questioned **Qìbó** (岐伯) extensively—from the highest celestial patterns to the deepest terrestrial principles, from distant phenomena of the cosmos to nearby observations of the human body. Together they deliberated, refined the teachings, and transmitted them to benefit future generations.

Thus, the lineage of **Léigōng** (雷公) and others received the doctrine and passed it down, and *The Inner Canon* was composed. Across the ages, it has been treasured without loss.

When the **Zhōu** (周) dynasty flourished, **Qín Hé** (秦和) expounded the theories of the six **qi** (气), which were recorded in the *Left Classic*.

Later, the **Yuè** (越) people obtained fragments of these teachings and expanded upon them to create *The Canon of Difficulties*.

In the Western Han dynasty, **Cāng Gōng** (仓公) transmitted the ancient doctrines, and in the Eastern Han, **Zhōngjīng** (仲景) compiled the remaining theories. During the Jin dynasty, **Huángfù Mì** (皇甫谧) followed with *The Canon of A and B*, and in the Sui dynasty, **Yáng Shàngshàn** (杨上善) compiled it as *The Grand Essentials*.

Later, **Quán Yuánqǐ** (全元起) was the first to write *The Explanatory Commentary*, though he omitted the seventh and eleventh chapters.

By the time of the Tang dynasty’s **Bǎoyìng** (宝应) era, **Wáng Bīng** (王冰), the Grand Steward, deeply cherished this work. He obtained the original scrolls from his predecessors and meticulously annotated them, preserving the ancient texts of the Three Sovereigns in their pristine splendor.

Alas, in the Tang dynasty, this work was relegated to the hands of mere practitioners, and scholars of high standing rarely cultivated it. Distant from the sages, its principles grew obscured, leading to conflicting annotations and convoluted interpretations.

The remnants of the *Three Primordial Classics*, the lofty aspirations of sovereigns, the deeds of sages—when **Emperor Yao** ordained the four seasons, **Emperor Shun** harmonized the seven celestial movements, **Divine Yu** cultivated the Six Palaces to achieve imperial glory, **King Wen** expounded the Six Children to align with the *coalescent qi*, **I Yin** regulated the Five Flavors to serve the sovereign, and **Ji Zi** expounded the Five Phases to aid the world—all these pursuits share a singular aim.

Yet how could the most refined and subtle **Dao** be entrusted to the most vulgar and shallow of people? That it was not abandoned is already a fortunate thing.

During the **Jiayou** era, the **Ren Zong** emperor, mindful of the legacy of his august ancestor, feared its loss to oblivion. He thus commissioned scholars to study and rectify it. We, as humble officials entrusted with editorial duties, reflected deeply for a decade.

We then scoured both court and private collections, gathering myriad versions, gradually discerning their meanings, and correcting errors. We recovered three or four out of ten, though the rest remain incomplete. We deemed this insufficient to honor the imperial edict or fulfill the sage’s intent. Additionally, we consulted the *Han* and *Tang* dynastic records of ancient medical classics still extant, obtaining several dozen works to cross-examine and verify.

We wove together disparate strands, synthesizing their insights—sometimes tracing roots to understand branches, other times ascending currents to uncover sources. We established what could be known, arranged it under the old chapter headings, corrected over six thousand erroneous characters, and added over two thousand explanatory annotations. Every judgment of inclusion or exclusion was meticulously verified, and ambiguities were clarified. Thus, for personal cultivation, one may preempt ailments before they manifest; for governance, one may extend life indefinitely.

With reverence, we consider the emperor’s reign—unifying the great harmony, embracing boundless blessings—continuing the ancestral vision to perfect what was begun, reviving neglected learning to ensure its perpetuity. Then, the harmonious *qi* may be summoned, calamities averted, and all under heaven elevated to the realm of longevity.

**Guo Zi** Scholar **Gao Bao Jie**, **Guanglu Grandee and Secretariat Attendant** **Lin Yi**, and others, humbly submit:

**Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: *Su Wen* Supplementary Commentary, Volume One**
**Tang Grand Steward and Master of the Mystic Play** **Wang Bing’s** Annotations
**Song Guanglu Grandee and Secretariat Attendant** **Lin Yi’s** Editorial Corrections
**Song Guard of the Ministry of War and Field Officer** **Sun Zhao’s** Emendations of Errors
**Newly Corrected Version:**

It is noted that **Wang Bing** did not explain the origin of the title *Su Wen* or the dynasty in which it first appeared. According to the *Sui Book of Libraries*, the title *Su Wen* first appears there. In the preface to the *Jia-Yi Canon*, **Huangfu Mi** of the Jin dynasty already refers to *Su Wen* as a precise discourse on illness. **Wu Chuhui**, a Western Jin scholar, compiled the *Pulse Canon*, stating it derived from *Su Wen* and the *Acupuncture Canon*. **Zhang Zhongjing** of the Han dynasty, in his *Treatise on Sudden and Chronic Febrile Diseases*, stated he composed it using *Su Wen*. Thus, the title *Su Wen* was recorded in the *Sui* and attested in the Han dynasty. Before **Zhang Zhongjing**, no written evidence survives, and its origins remain unknown. Based on extant texts today, the title *Su Wen* emerged in the Han dynasty.

As for the meaning behind the title *Su Wen*, **Quan Yuanqi** offered an explanation: *"Su"* means "origin," and *"Wen"* refers to the dialogue between the **Yellow Emperor** and **Qi Bo**. Since it expounds the fundamental nature of human constitution and the Five Phases, it is called *Su Wen*. Though **Quan Yuanqi** provided this interpretation, its meaning remains unclear.

According to the *Qian Zao Du*, "What has form arises from the formless. Thus, there is **Tai Yi** (Great Simplicity), **Tai Chu** (Great Commencement), **Tai Shi** (Great Beginning), and **Tai Su** (Great Primordial). **Tai Yi** is the state before *qi* manifests. **Tai Chu** is the origin of *qi*. **Tai Shi** is the origin of form. **Tai Su** is the origin of substance. When *qi*, form, and substance are complete, diseases and remedies emerge. Thus, the **Yellow Emperor** inquired into this **Tai Su**—the origin of substance. Perhaps the title *Su Wen* derives from this."

---
**Chapter on the Primordial Truth of the Upper Antiquity**
In ancient times, the **Yellow Emperor** was born with divine insight, spoke as an infant, and as a child, he was swift and sincere, matured with wisdom, and ultimately ascended to heaven. His father was the ruler of the **Xiong** clan, **Shao Dian**, of the **Gong Sun** lineage. *"Swift"* here means *"urgent."* *"Sincere"* means *"trustworthy."* *"Wise"* means *"enlightened."* He mastered warfare, subduing those who refused tribute, pacifying the world, and exterminating **Chi You**. Ruling with the virtue of **Earth**, he established his capital on the **Xuan Yuan** mound, hence his title **Xuan Yuan Huang Di**. Later, he cast the tripod on **Dinghu Mountain**; upon its completion, the sun ascended in daylight. His ministers buried his robes and crown on **Qiao Mountain**, where his tomb still stands today. *"Swift"* is pronounced *"Xu Rùn."*

He then inquired of the **Celestial Master** (Qi Bo): *"I have heard that in the Upper Antiquity, men lived to a hundred autumns and springtimes without decline in vigor. Now, people in my time reach half a century and already show signs of decay. Is this due to the changing times, or have people lost the way?"*

The **Celestial Master** replied: *"In the Upper Antiquity, those who understood the Dao aligned with yin and yang, harmonizing with techniques and calculations. The Upper Antiquity refers to the **Xuan Ancient** era. To understand the Dao means to know the methods of cultivation. Yin and yang are the eternal principles of heaven and earth; techniques and calculations are the great fundamentals of preserving life. Thus, cultivators must prioritize these above all else. The *Laozi* states: ‘All things carry yin within and embrace yang without, and their harmonious *qi* forms unity.’ The *Great Treatise on Harmonizing the Four Seasons with the Spirit* states: ‘Yin and yang, the four seasons—these are the beginning and end of all things, the source of life and death. To defy them brings calamity; to follow them prevents illness. This is called attaining the Dao.’ This is what is meant.

Let food and drink be moderate, let rising and resting be regular, avoid excessive labor, and..."

To nourish the Dao, one must regulate food and drink as the means to replenish the void, and maintain proper rising and resting as the principles of movement and repose. Thus, cultivators must practice moderation in all actions.

The *Treatise on Stagnation* states: ‘When food and drink are doubled in excess, the intestines and stomach are injured.’ The *Treatise on the Movement of Vital Qi Through the Heavens* states: ‘If rising and resting are as erratic as a startled man, the spirit and *qi* become agitated.’ This is the evil of reckless movement. The *Master Guangcheng* says: ‘Be still and clear, do not labor your body, do not disturb your essence—only then can you attain longevity.’ Hence, the Sage prioritizes these teachings.

**Newly corrected annotation reads:** According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s annotated version: ‘Food and drink have fixed moderation and regularity; rising and resting have fixed measures—neither excessive nor deficient.’ The *Treatise on the Great Purity* agrees. Yáng Shàngshàn says: ‘In moderation, one enjoys sounds, colors, fragrant scents, and flavors; this means not indulging in sight or hearing.’ One acts in accordance with principle, not for extraneous matters. Thus, they preserve both form and spirit, departing from the body and attaining their full natural lifespan. To reach one hundred years with form and spirit intact is to fulfill one’s allotted span of life. Those who excel in cultivation thus serve their true nature, attaining their full natural lifespan.

**Departure** refers to leaving behind the physical frame. The *Spiritual Pivot Classic* states: ‘At one hundred years, the five *zàng* organs are all depleted; the spirit and *qi* have departed, and the physical frame remains alone until death.’ Because of their understanding of the Dao, they extend their years and prolong their life. **Reaching one hundred years** refers to attaining one hundred and twenty years. The *Book of Documents: Hong Fan* says: ‘A full lifespan is one hundred and twenty years.’ But people of our age do not follow this. They act recklessly, approaching death’s domain, straying from the Dao.

Now they take wine as their drink, indulge in falsehood as their norm, and enter the bedchamber inebriated—
**Wine as drink** betrays their drowning in intoxication.
**Falsehood as norm** betrays their scarcity of sincerity.
**Drunken bedchamber entry** betrays their excess in lust.

They exhaust their essence through desire, dissipate their true nature through reckless indulgence.
**Delighting in lust** daily drains their essence—
**Light use** is called dissipation;
**Delighting in lust without restraint** exhausts their essence,
**Reckless indulgence without cease** scatters their true nature.
Thus, the Sage cherishes essence and moderates action,
Filling the marrow, strengthening the bones.
**Laozi** says:
*"Weaken the will, fortify the bones."*
**He Shangong** says:
*"Those who indulge in desire lose their body."*
**The Rites of Zhou** says:
*"Desire must not be indulged."*

**New Annotation:** According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*, "dissipation" should read *"good"* (i.e., "good use").

Not preserving fullness, not timing the governance of spirit—
This speaks of reckless indulgence and unrestrained desire.
**Laozi** says:
*"To grasp and fill it to the brim is not as good as stopping in time."*
This means cherishing essence and preserving spirit,
Like holding a vessel brimming to the edge—
If careless in motion, it will spill and drain one’s true nature.
**The True Revelations** says:
*"Those who cannot always be cautious in their affairs bring upon themselves a hundred ailments—
How can they blame the divine for their misfortune?"*
This is what is meant.

**New Annotation:** According to another text, *"timing"* should read *"dissolving."*

To indulge the heart’s fleeting pleasures,
To act against the harmony of life’s natural joys—
When the heart delights in desire’s gratification,
It reverses the path of nurturing life’s true bliss.

**Laozi** says:
*"Excessive love and greed bring great depletion."*
This is of the same kind.

To love excessively yet fail to preserve,
To speak of the Dao while dismissing its reality—
This is the great sigh of life’s undoing.

Without measure in rest and motion,
One weakens by half a century’s age.
This too stems from dissipation and waste.

The Dao cannot be abandoned, not for an instant—
If one strays from the Dao, life’s full span cannot reach its natural end.

**Laozi** says:
*"When things flourish, they grow old—
This is called not aligning with the Dao.
Not aligning with the Dao brings early decay."*
This is what is meant by straying from the Dao.

The teachings of the ancient sages to those beneath them
All spoke of *xūxié zéifēng*—evil winds that prey on emptiness.
Avoiding them had its proper times:
When *xū* (emptiness) allows evil to enter—this is *xūxié*.
When *xié* (evil) disrupts *zhōnghé* (central harmony)—this is *zéifēng*.
Avoiding them at their appointed times:
The eight seasonal nodes,
And when *Tài-Yī* enters and aligns with the *zhōngguān* (central palace),
On the days when the eight winds are received in court.

*The Ling Shu* says:
*"Evil qi cannot harm unless it finds emptiness in the person."*
Meaning: Only when the person is empty does evil overcome.

---
**Annotation:** According to *Quán Yuánqǐ*’s commentary:
*"The ancient sages’ teachings—all beneath them followed."*
*The Tàisù* and *Qiān Jīn* agree.
*Yáng Shàngshàn* says:
*"The ancient sages led by example,
Their silent teachings surpassing spoken ones—
Thus, the common folk imitated them in great numbers,
Hence, ‘all beneath them followed.’"*
The meaning of *Tài-Yī* entering and aligning with *zhōngguān*,
And receiving the eight winds in court, is fully explained in *Tiān Yuàn Yù Cè*.

With tranquility and emptiness,
True qi follows naturally;
With spirit inwardly guarded,
Where then do diseases arise?

Tranquility, stillness, emptiness—this is *qi*.
Following the Dao’s pure stillness,
With vital essence held within,
Thus, *xūxié zéifēng* cannot take root.

Therefore, with a mind at ease and few desires,
The heart at peace and without fear,
The body laboring yet unwearied—
Because inner mechanisms rest, desires are few;
External distractions stilled, the heart finds ease.
Yet when both emotions and calculations fade,
Judgment becomes unified,
Rest and motion both harmonious—
Thus, no weariness arises.

Qi flows in accordance with nature,
Each follows its own desires,
All find what they seek.
Because the will is unburdened,
All desires align naturally;
The heart easily finds contentment,
All wishes are fulfilled—
Seeking nothing beyond what is natural,
Thus, nothing is difficult to obtain.

**Laozi** says:
*"Knowing sufficiency brings no disgrace,
Knowing when to stop brings no peril—
Thus, one may endure forever."*

Therefore, one delights in their food,
Wears their garments with ease,
Finds joy in their customs—
Delighting in food means accepting both coarse and refined;
Wearing garments with ease means adapting to good and bad;
Finding joy in customs means abandoning envy and emulation.

---
**Annotation:** According to another text, *"delights"* reads *"sweet."*

High and low do not envy one another,
Thus, their people are called *pǔ* (uncorrupted).
Reaching the state of *wúqiú* (no seeking),
This is what is called *"the heart’s sufficiency."*

**Laozi** says:
*"No misfortune greater than not knowing sufficiency,
No fault greater than coveting what one lacks—
Thus, he who knows sufficiency is always sufficient."*
It is not that the things themselves are sufficient,
But that the heart is sufficient—
Not indulging in desire,
Thus, simplicity is preserved.
Hence, the sage says:
*"I have no desires, yet the people naturally become simple."*

---
**Annotation:** According to another text, *"day"* reads *"sun."*

Thus, lust cannot weary the eyes,
Licentiousness cannot confuse the heart—
The eyes do not gaze wantonly,
So lust cannot weary them;
The heart aligns with the *Xuán* (Mysterious),
So licentiousness cannot confuse it.

**Laozi** says:
*"Seeing no desirable things,
The heart remains undisturbed."*
And again:
*"The sage acts for the belly, not for the eyes."*

Foolish and wise, virtuous and base—
None fear external things,
Thus, they align with the Dao.
With both emotions and calculations extinguished,
No scheming mind remains;
With the heart in silent observation,
Victory and defeat are both abandoned—
Thus, the heart and will are preserved in safety,
In perfect harmony with the Dao.

*The Gēngsāng Chú* says:
*"Nurture your form,
Embrace your life,
Do not let your thoughts labor ceaselessly."*

---
**Annotation:** According to *Quán Yuánqǐ*’s commentary:
*"Aligning with the Dao’s principles."*

Thus, those who could all surpass a hundred years
Yet move without decay—
Because their *dé* (virtue/power) remains whole and unthreatened.
Not venturing into danger,
Thus, their *dé* remains whole.

*Zhuāngzi* says:
*"Those who grasp the Dao have complete virtue,
Complete virtue preserves the form—
This is the sage’s way."*
And again:
*"Without action, life and essence cannot be fully preserved."*

The Emperor asked:
*"Why do some grow old without children?
Is it because their strength is exhausted,
Or is it the natural course of heaven?"*
*Cūn* refers to the sturdy trunk—
That which can support life.

*Qí Bó* replied:
*"At seven years of age, the girl’s kidney qi flourishes,
Her teeth change and grow longer.
The *lǎo yáng* (old yang) reaches its peak at nine,
The *shào yáng* (young yang) follows at seven.
Women embody *shào yīn* (young yin) qi,
Thus, it is paired with the *shào yáng* number—
This shows that when yin and yang harmonize,
Only then can they form and perfect the body.
Thus, at seven, kidney qi flourishes,
And teeth change and grow longer.

At fourteen, *tiān guǐ* arrives,
The *rèn* (conception) vessel opens,
The *tài chōng* (supreme surge) vessel thrives,
And menstruation descends in its proper time—
Thus, she can conceive.

*Guǐ* refers to *rén guǐ* (the water stem *rén* and *guǐ*),
Named for the northern direction’s water stem.
The *rèn* and *chōng* vessels are both extraordinary meridians.
When kidney qi is at its fullest,
And the *chōng* and *rèn* flow freely,
The menstrual blood gradually fills,
Descending at its appointed time—
The *tiān zhēn* (heavenly true) qi descends to assist,
Thus, it is called *tiān guǐ*.

Yet the *chōng* is the sea of blood,
The *rèn* governs the fetus—
The two support each other,
Thus, conception is possible.

This is why it is called *yuè shì* (monthly affair):
When *zhōnghé* (central harmony) prevails,
It appears regularly every thirty days.
Thus, missing a period is called *bìng* (disease)."

**Annotation:** According to *Quán Yuánqǐ*’s commentary and *Tàisù*, *Jiǎ-Yì Jīng*—
All read *"fú chōng"* (concealed surge).
The same below for *tài chōng*.

The *guǐ* (three-seven) marks the balance of kidney qi,
Thus, the **true teeth** emerge and grow to their utmost.

The **true teeth** refer to the last teeth to develop.
When kidney qi is balanced, the **true teeth** grow—
This shows that teeth are the remnants of bone.

At *sì qī* (four-seven),
Tendons and bones harden, hair reaches its fullest growth,
And the body is at its peak of strength and vigor.

For women, the count of *tiān guǐ* (heavenly true) qi concludes at *qī qī* (seven-seven).
At *sì qī*, half of their vitality remains,
Thus, the body is strong and hair reaches its fullest length here.

At *wǔ qī* (five-seven),
The **Yángmíng** meridian’s qi declines,
The face begins to wither, and hair starts to fall.

The **Yángmíng** meridian’s qi nourishes the face,
Thus, when it declines, hair falls and the face withers.

The *Língshū Jīng* (Spirit Pivot Classic) states:
"The **foot Yángmíng** meridian begins at the nose,
Crosses the forehead,
Descends along the outer nose,
Enters the upper teeth,
Returns to emerge beside the mouth, encircling the lips,
Descends to meet **Chéngjiāng** (receiving saliva),
Then ascends behind the jaw to **Kāng** (cheek),
Exits at **Dàyíng** (great welcome),
Follows **Jiáchē** (cheek cart),
Ascends to the front of the ear,
Passes **Kèzhǔrén** (guest master),
Traces the hairline,
And reaches the forehead and cranium."

The **hand Yángmíng** meridian ascends the neck and pierces the cheek,
Enters the lower teeth’s gaps,
Returns to emerge beside the mouth,
Thus, when its qi declines, the face withers and hair falls.

**Lèi** (类, *lèi yú gé qiè*)
**Xiá** (侠, *xiá yú hú jiá qiè*)
**Pō** (颇, *pō yú luò hú qiè*)

At *liù qī* (six-seven),
The three **Yáng** meridians decline from above,
The face withers entirely, and hair begins to turn white.

The three **Yáng** meridians all ascend to the head,
Thus, when they decline, the face withers and hair turns white.
The reason for their decline is that women’s life force
Has excess **qi** yet deficient blood,
Due to their monthly discharge of blood.

At *qī qī* (seven-seven),
The **Rèn** meridian weakens,
The **Tài chōng** meridian declines and diminishes,
*Tiān guǐ* is exhausted,
The **earthly channel** is blocked—
Thus, the body decays and childbearing ceases.

The cessation of menstrual flow is called **earthly channel blockage**.
When the **chōng** and **rèn** meridians weaken,
It is said the body decays and no children can be conceived.

For men, at eight years,
Kidney qi solidifies, hair grows, and teeth are renewed.
The count of **Lǎoyīn** (old yin) reaches ten,
While **Shàoyīn** (young yin) follows at eight;
Men embody **Shàoyáng** (young yang) qi,
Thus, their count aligns with **Shàoyīn**.

The *Yì Xìjì* (Systematic Words of the *Yì*) says:
*"Heaven nine, earth ten."*
This is their count.

At *èr bā* (two-eight),
Kidney qi flourishes, *tiān guǐ* arrives,
Essence and **qi** overflow and manifest,
Yin and yang harmonize—
Thus, they can conceive.

Men and women differ in yin-yang constitution,
Yet *tiān guǐ* marks their divergence in essence and blood:
Women, in stillness, accumulate fullness and then discharge blood,
Men, in movement, respond and emit semen;
When the two harmonize in flow,
Thus, conception is possible.

The *Yì Xìjì* says:
*"Men and women combine their essence,
And all things transform and generate."*
This is what is meant.

At **three-eight** (twenty-four), kidney qi is balanced, tendons and bones are strong and resilient—thus true teeth emerge and reach their full growth. This is because their use is frequent.

At **four-eight** (thirty-two), tendons and bones are at their peak, muscles full and robust. The **tian gui** of men terminates at **eight-eight** (sixty-four), yet at **four-eight**, they have already reached half their lifespan.

At **five-eight** (forty), kidney qi declines, hair falls out, and teeth wither. The kidney governs bones, and teeth are the remnants of bone. Since kidney qi weakens and lacks nourishment, hair falls and teeth dry up.

At **six-eight** (forty-eight), yang qi declines above, causing the face to wither and hair at the temples to turn white. This yang qi is also the **Yangming** meridian’s flow. The *Língshū Jīng* states:
*"The foot Yangming channel begins at the nose, crosses the philtrum, descends below the lip along the outer nose, enters the upper teeth, then exits beside them. It encircles the lips, descends to meet the chin’s depression, then follows the jaw’s posterior edge, exits at *Dàyíng*, ascends along *Jiáché*, reaches the ear’s front, passes *Kèzhǔrén*, follows the hairline to the forehead and crown. Thus, when yang declines above, the face withers and temple hair turns white."*

At **seven-eight** (forty-nine), liver qi weakens, tendons lose mobility, **tian gui** is exhausted, essence dwindles, and the kidney’s storage declines—all bodily functions reach their extremes. The liver nourishes tendons; its decline causes immobility. The kidney nourishes bones; its decline causes bodily decay. With **tian gui** spent, essence is scarce. Not only does physical vigor decline, but this is the natural course of heaven’s measure.

At **eight-eight** (sixty-four), teeth and hair fall out. Yang qi is exhausted, essence weakens, so teeth and hair lose firmness—like a withered chicken’s frame. *"Go"* means to fall. The kidney governs water, receiving and storing the essence of the five *zàng* and six *fǔ*. Thus, when the five *zàng* flourish, only then can overflow occur. The five *zàng* and six *fǔ*’s excess essence seeps into the kidney, which then stores it. How do we know this? The *Língshū Jīng* says:
*"The five *zàng* govern storing essence; what stores essence must not be harmed."* Thus, each *zàng* has its own essence, which, when used, flows into the kidney—making it the central nexus, not a single *zàng* possessing essence alone. Hence, it is said that only when the five *zàng* flourish can overflow occur. Now, with all five *zàng* declining, tendons and bones slacken, **tian gui** is exhausted. Thus, temple hair turns white, the body grows heavy, gait becomes unsteady, and childbearing ceases. This is what is meant by *"things flourish then age—this is the Way of Heaven."*

The Emperor asked: *"Are there those who, though aged, still bear children? This seems contrary to the measure of **tian gui**."*

Qíbó replied: *"These are those whose natural lifespan exceeds the norm, whose vital pathways remain unobstructed, and whose kidney qi is abundant. Their inherent true *qi* was originally excessive. Though they bear children, men do not surpass **eight-eight**, nor women **seven-seven**, yet the essence of Heaven and Earth is already exhausted. Even if the aged conceive, their offspring’s lifespan cannot exceed the **tian gui** measure."*

The Emperor asked: *"Those who practice the Dao—do they, though aged, still bear children?"*

Qíbó replied: *"Those who practice the Dao can reverse aging and preserve their form. Though their years are long, they can still conceive. These are the true *zhēnrén* (perfected ones). The signs of Dao’s fulfillment appear as in the following chapter."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"I have heard that in antiquity, there were *zhēnrén* who upheld Heaven and Earth, grasped yin and yang. The *zhēnrén*—those who have attained the Dao—are elusive, their presence unseen. In their smallness, they enter the boundless; in their vastness, they pervade the void. Their transformations move between Heaven and Earth, unseen within or without. Following the utmost truth, they embody the proof of Dao’s completion. Thus, they can uphold Heaven and Earth, grasp yin and yang. They breathe in refined *qi*, stand alone in guarding the spirit, their flesh unified as one. Their bodies, like ice and snow, graceful as a maiden."*

*(New annotation: The *Quán Yuánqǐ* commentary reads: *"The *zhēnrén*’s flesh and essence are unified."* The *Tàisù* agrees. Yáng Shàngshàn says: *"The *zhēnrén*’s body aligns with the Supreme Ultimate’s essence, hence ‘unified.’"* Thus, they endure beyond Heaven and Earth, with no end. *"Dé"* (exhaust) is pronounced *bì-sì*, meaning ‘to complete.’ This is the Dao’s generation. Only the utmost Dao can achieve such perfection.*

In the mid-ancient era, there were *zhìrén* (accomplished ones) who preserved pure virtue and fulfilled the Dao. *"Full"* refers to perfecting the utmost Dao, hence *zhìrén*. Yet the *zhìrén*, through this pure and unadorned virtue, master the subtle applications of the Dao."*

*(New annotation: As Yáng Shàngshàn elaborates: *"Accumulating essence and preserving spirit, they attain virtue, hence ‘accomplished.’"* They harmonize with yin and yang, align with the four seasons—*"harmonize"* meaning to conform, *"adjust"* meaning to suit—so their movements, whether still or active, align with the seasons’ growth, contraction, and storage, resonating with yin and yang’s ascent and descent. Detached from the world, they accumulate essence and preserve spirit, wandering between Heaven and Earth, perceiving beyond the eight extremes. This is because their spirit is complete. The *Gēngsāng Chú* says: *"The fully spirited do not deliberate yet understand; they do not plan yet act rightly. Their essence illuminates all, their will encompasses the cosmos—like Heaven and Earth. Again: ‘The body aligns with the heart, the heart with *qi*, *qi* with spirit, spirit with the void. Their presence is distinct, their sound resonant—though distant as the eight farthest reaches or near as the eyelashes, those who approach me, I know them all.’"*

The thusly complete in spirit, hence their power is manifest. *Jié* (睫), pronounced *jiē* (接).

These are those who prolong life and strengthen vitality, also returning to the True Person. All converge in the Dao.

Next are the Sage-Persons, dwelling in Heaven and Earth’s harmony, following the principles of the Eight Winds, harmonizing virtue with Heaven and Earth, luminosity with Sun and Moon, sequence with the Four Seasons, and fortune with spirits and ghosts—hence they are called Sage-Persons. Their dwelling in Heaven and Earth’s pure harmony and conforming to the Eight Winds’ true principles is to nourish the true and avoid the false and malevolent. They moderate desires within worldly affairs, harboring no resentment in their hearts. The Sage-Person’s resolve is deep in the Dao, thus their desires are moderated; their heart is whole and love expansive, so they do not suffer true harm. Hence, their virtue never departs, and their body remains unharmed.

Their conduct does not wish to separate from the world—*being clad in ritual adornment* [omitted, as per annotation]. Their actions do not seek display among the vulgar. Though the Sage-Person’s deeds and movements often dwell within the world’s affairs, their conduct differs from the common. How so? They value the Dao’s purity and stillness.

The *Laozi* says: *"I alone differ from others, cherishing the Mother. Mother—this is the Dao."* Externally, they do not weary the body in labor; internally, they suffer no torment of thought. The Sage-Person practices *wuwei*, acting without action, thus internally free from thought, externally unburdened by form. They take tranquility and contentment as their pursuit, self-fulfillment as their merit. Tranquility is stillness; contentment is joy. Following the Dao’s purity and stillness, they move in accordance with nature, hence they attain self-fulfillment. Their form remains unspent, their spirit undispersed—thus they may reach a hundred years. Externally unburdened, internally free from thought, their form remains unspent; their spirit preserved, their essence unbroken—thus their years extend to a hundred. All these are the governance of preserving nature.

The *Gēngsāng Chú* says: *"The Sage-Person, regarding sounds, colors, flavors—if they benefit nature, they take them; if they harm nature, they abandon them. This is the way of preserving nature."*

Next are the Virtuous Persons, modeling Heaven and Earth, resembling Sun and Moon. Inferior to the Sage-Person, yet they strive unceasingly, their insight penetrating a hundred matters, understanding without deliberation, their plans always correct. Their resolve aligns with Heaven and Earth; their heart illuminates the deepest mysteries. Thus they are said to model Heaven and Earth, resemble Sun and Moon. They arrange the stars, follow yin and yang, distinguish the Four Seasons. Stars—all stars. *Chén* (辰)—the North Star. *Biànliè* (辩列)—determining the positions of celestial officials and constellations in the heavens, the gradations of the 365 degrees in distance. Following yin and yang—using the *liùjiǎ* (六甲) and similar methods, counting forward and backward to prognosticate auspicious and inauspicious omens. The *Yīnyáng Shū* says: *"Human *jiǎzǐ* (甲子), beginning with *jiǎzǐ*, proceeding in sequence with *yǐchǒu* (乙丑). Earthly *jiǎzǐ*, beginning with *jiǎxū* (甲戌), proceeding backward with *guǐyǒu* (癸酉). This is called following yin and yang."* Distinguishing the Four Seasons—dividing their *qi* sequences: Spring’s warmth, Summer’s scorching heat, Autumn’s chill, Winter’s piercing cold—these are the Four Seasons’ *qi* sequences. If they follow the ancient ways, aligning with the Dao, they too may prolong life to its limit.

Following the ancient ways and aligning with the Dao—meaning those ancient who knew the Dao. Conforming to yin and yang, harmonizing with the *yǎnshù* (衍数), moderating food and drink, regulating rest and activity, avoiding reckless labor. The ancients who knew the Dao lived a hundred years before departing—thus they may prolong life to its limit.
