*End of the Huangdi Neijing Suwen* (黄帝内经素问补注释文卷之三竟)
#1 *静*: Originally written as **"序"** (Preface).
#2 *曰*: Then (则) was omitted in the original; added from the *Gù* (顾) edition.
#3 *人*: The original had **"火"** (fire), changed to **"人"** (people) based on the *Gù* (顾) edition.
#4 *缓*: The *Gù* (顾) edition has **"绥"** (soothe).
#5 *然*: The *Xiǎn* (显) edition has **"为"** (to be).
#6 *若*: Omitted in the original; added from the *Lú* (颅) edition.
#7 *都*: Omitted in the original; added from the *Gù* (顾) edition.
#8 *愈*: The *Gù* (顾) edition has **"瘦"** (emaciated).
#9 *圣*: Omitted in the original; added from the *Pī* (颇) edition.
#10 *肝*: The original had **"汗"** (sweat), changed to **"肝"** (liver) based on the *Gù* (顾) edition.
#11 *神*: The *Gù* (顾) edition has **"藏"** (Zang).
#12 *气骨*: The *Gù* (顾) edition has **"骨气"** (qi of the bones).

**Gold Case True Speech Treatise**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"The heavens have eight winds, the classics speak of five winds—what does this mean?*
The classics refer to *Jīngtún* (经豚), which governs the circulation of the *yíng* and *wèi* and the flow of *qi* and blood."

Qìbó replied: *"When the eight winds arise as pathogenic forces, they become the *jīng* winds. When they strike the five *Zàng* organs, the pathogenic *qi* manifests as disease.
Examining their origin: the eight winds, when pathogenic, enter the *jīngmai* (meridians), then follow their paths to strike the five *Zàng* organs, where the pathogenic *qi* assaults the righteous *qi*, thus causing disease.

What is meant by *four seasons’ victory*: spring overcomes *zhǎngxià* (long summer), *zhǎngxià* overcomes winter, winter overcomes summer, summer overcomes autumn, and autumn overcomes spring—this is what is called the *four seasons’ victory*.
Spring is wood, summer is fire, *zhǎngxià* is earth, autumn is metal, winter is water; each overcomes by what it subdues—this is their victory.

When speaking of the five seasons’ mutual victory, it does not mean that the eight winds, upon entering, cause disease, but rather that each season’s weakness invites disease.

*Victory* means to subdue and conquer.

The east wind arises in spring, its disease affects the liver, and its *shù* (acupuncture point) is at the neck and nape.
Spring wind first stirs the *róng* (blossoms) of all things, so its *shù* is at the neck and nape. The *Lìjì* (历忌) states: *‘On days *jiǎ-yǐ* (甲乙), do not treat the neck.’* This is what is meant.

The south wind arises in summer, its disease affects the heart, and its *shù* is at the chest and ribs.
The heart’s *shàoyīn* meridian ascends the chest and emerges at the ribs, so its *shù* is there.

The west wind arises in autumn, its disease affects the lungs, and its *shù* is at the shoulders and back.
The lungs govern the upper burner; the back is the chest’s *fǔ* (palace), and shoulders and back follow in sequence, so its *shù* is there.

The north wind arises in winter, its disease affects the kidneys, and its *shù* is at the waist and thighs.
The waist is the kidney’s *fǔ*, and the thighs follow in sequence, connected by *qi*, so both are mentioned.

The center is earth, its disease affects the spleen, and its *shù* is at the spine.
The spine corresponds to earth, and it resides centrally.

Thus, spring *qi* diseases manifest in the head—spring *qi* refers to liver *qi*—each following the *Zàng* organ’s corresponding *qi*.

**Newly corrected text:** According to the *Zhōulǐ* (周礼), *"In spring, there are many head ailments."*

Summer *qi* diseases manifest in the *Zàng* organs—this is the heart’s correspondence.
Autumn *qi* diseases manifest in the shoulders and back—this is the lungs’ correspondence.
Winter *qi* diseases manifest in the four limbs.
The four limbs have little *qi*; cold toxins easily injure them, and disease follows the pathogenic *qi* that enters.

Thus, spring often causes *guǐniǔ* (鼻血/鼻涕),
as the *Lǐjì Yùelìng* (礼记月令) states: *"If *jìqiū* (季秋) follows *xiàlìng* (夏令), the people often suffer from *guǐniǔ*."*

Mid-summer often causes chest and rib diseases,
for the heart’s meridian follows the chest and ribs.

Long summer often causes *dòngxiè* (洞泄) and cold in the abdomen,
as earth governs the center, becoming the *cānglín zāopò shuǐgǔ* (倉廩糟粕水谷)—thus causing *dòngxiè* and cold in the abdomen.

Autumn often causes wind and *yuè* (疟),
for cooling breaks summer heat, resulting in this disease.
The *Shēngqì Tōngtiān Lùn* (生气通天论) states: *"If *pòhàn* (魄汗) is not fully released, the form is weak and *qi* is scattered; the *xùshù* (穴俞) close, and wind-*yuè* emerges."* This explains cooling breaking summer heat.

The *Lǐjì Yùelìng* states: *"If *mèngqiū* (孟秋) follows *xiàlìng* (夏令), the people often suffer from *yuèjí* (疟疾)."*

Winter often causes *bìjué* (痹厥).
Blood follows water; cold causes it to congeal like ice, and with *qi* flowing thinly, *bìjué* results.

Thus, if in winter one does not practice *ànjiāo* (按娇),
and in spring does not practice *guǐniǔ* (轨钮),
*—*where *àn* means massage, and *jì* (跻) refers to the nimble movements of hands and feet, as in *dǎoyǐn* (导引)—
then disturbing the sinews and bones causes *yángqi* not to be stored.
Spring’s *yángqi* ascends, overburdening the lungs, which connect to the nose, and disease manifests.
Thus, winter’s failure to practice *ànjì* leads to spring’s *guǐniǔ*.

*Guǐ* means nasal discharge, *niǔ* means nasal bleeding.
*Zhān* (跚) is pronounced *qiáo*.

If spring does not cause neck and nape disease,
mid-summer does not cause chest and rib disease,
long summer does not cause *dòngxiè* and cold in the abdomen,
autumn does not cause wind-*yuè*,
and winter does not cause *bìjué*—
then there will be *sūnxiè* (飧泄) with sweating.
These five preceding sentences all result from failing to practice *ànjì* in winter.

**Newly corrected text:** The phrase *"sūnxiè ér hànchū"* (飧泄而汗出) seems extraneous above.

Essence is the foundation of the body.
Thus, those who store essence in winter will not suffer from spring *wēnbìng* (温病).
This directly means that if winter’s *ànjiāo* preserves *jīngqi*, *yáng* does not ascend recklessly, so spring has no *wēnbìng*.

If summer heat causes no sweating, autumn will bring wind-*yuè*.
This directly means that wind and cold *qi* break summer’s sweat.

**Newly corrected text:** The meaning below does not connect well with the preceding text.

This is the pulse law of the *píngrén* (平人).
It refers to the pulse law of the *píngbìngrén* (平病人).
Thus it is said: *"Within yin there is yin, within yang there is yang."*
This refers to their initial emergence and their reign.

In daylight until noon, the heavens are *yáng*—this is *yáng* within *yáng*;
From noon until dusk, the heavens are *yáng*—this is *yín* within *yáng*.
At noon, *yáng* is at its peak, hence *yáng* within *yáng*.
At dusk, *yín* is at its peak, hence *yáng* within *yín*.
Since *yángqi* governs the day, from dawn until dusk is all the heavens’ *yáng*, yet within it there are distinctions of *yín* and *yáng*.

From night until the rooster crows, the heavens are *yín*—this is *yín* within *yín*;
From the rooster’s crow until dawn, the heavens are *yín*—this is *yáng* within *yín*.
At the rooster’s crow, *yángqi* has not yet emerged, hence the heavens are *yín*.
At dawn, *yángqi* has already ascended, hence *yáng* within *yín*.

Thus, the human body follows this pattern.
When speaking of human *yín-yáng*, the exterior is *yáng*, the interior is *yín*.
When speaking of the *yín-yáng* of the human body, the back is *yáng*, the abdomen is *yín*.
When speaking of the *yín-yáng* of the *Zàngfǔ* within the body, the *Zàng* are *yín*, the *fǔ* are *yáng*.
*Zàng* refers to the five *shén* (神) organs.
*Fǔ* refers to the six *huàfǔ* (化府).
The liver, heart, spleen, lungs, and kidneys—the five *Zàng*—are all *yín*.
The gallbladder, stomach, large intestine, small intestine, bladder, and triple burner—the six *fǔ*—are all *yáng*.

The *Língpǔ Jīng* states: The Triple Burner#1 overlaps above with the Hand *Shǒuxīn* (Hand Heart) Master.

It also says: The foot Triple Burner is another name for *Tàiyáng* (Major Yang).

The *Zhènglǐ Lùn* states: The Triple Burner#1 is a named entity without form, overlapping above with the Hand *Shǒuxīn* Master and below with the right kidney. It governs the *yèdào* (conveying) *qi*, and is called the *Shǐzhě* (Messenger).

Thus, why does one seek to know *yín* within *yín* and *yáng* within *yáng*? Because winter illnesses reside in *yín*, summer illnesses in *yáng*, spring illnesses in *yín*, and autumn illnesses in *yáng*—all are observed in their respective locations for the application of acupuncture and *shíliàn* (stone therapy).

The back is *yáng*, and within *yáng* is the *yáng* organ—the heart.
The heart is a *yáng* organ, situated in the upper burner, with *yáng* dwelling in *yáng*, hence it is called *yáng* within *yáng*.
The *Língpǔ Jīng* states: The heart is the *mǔ*#2 organ.
*Mǔ* means *yáng*.

The back is *yáng*, and within *yáng* is the *yín* organ—the lungs.
The lungs are a *yín* organ, situated in the upper burner, with *yín* dwelling in *yáng*, hence they are called *yín* within *yáng*.
The *Língpǔ Jīng* states: The lungs are the *pín*#3 organ.
*Pín* means *yín*.

The abdomen is *yín*, and within *yín* is the *yín* organ—the kidneys.
The kidneys are a *yín* organ, situated in the lower burner, with *yín* dwelling in *yín*, hence they are called *yín* within *yín*.
The *Língpǔ Jīng* states: The kidneys are the *pín* organ.
*Pín* means *yín*.

The abdomen is *yín*, and within *yín* is the *yín* of the utmost *yín*—the spleen.
The spleen is the *kuò* (embracing) organ, situated in the middle burner, with *Tàiyín* (Major Yin) dwelling in *yín*, hence it is called *yín* of the utmost *yín* within *yín*.
The *Língpǔ Jīng* states: The spleen is the *pín*#4 organ of *jié* (截).
*Pín* means *yín*.

These are all the mutual correspondences of *yín-yáng*, superficial-deep, interior-exterior, and male-female, hence they align with the *yín-yáng* of the heavens.
Their *qi* and forms correspond harmoniously, thus they can align above with the heavens.

The Emperor#5 asked: Do the five organs correspond with the four seasons, and each has its own *shōushòu* (receiving) function?
*Guībó* (Master Gui) replied: They do.
The east is green, entering through the liver, opening at the orifices of the eyes, storing *jīng* (essence) in the liver.
*Jīng* refers to *jīngqi* (essence-*qi*).
The *qi* of the wood essence is the spirit and soul, the season of ascending *yáng*, with the eyes as its function, hence it opens at the eyes.
Its illnesses manifest as *jīnghè* (startle and terror),
symbolizing the bending and stretching of wood with its tremulous motion.
○Newly corrected version: Upon examining the east, it is said that the illness manifests as *jīnghè*; the other seasons are omitted, following the *Wǔcháng Zhèngdà Lùn* (Grand Treatise on the Five Constants) where it records *jīnghè* as the manifestation. This text is likely superfluous.
Its flavor is sour, its nature akin to grasses and trees.

Its nature is soft, brittle, and capable of bending and straightening.
Its domesticated animal is the rooster, taken from *xùn* (docility), as the *Yì* says: *"Xùn"* is the falcon.
Its grain is wheat, the longest of the five grains, hence its use in the *Shù* region.
*The Běn Cǎo* states: "Wheat is the longest of the five grains."
○Newly corrected version: According to the *Wǔcháng Zhèngdà Lùn*, it states: "Its domesticated animal is the dog, its grain is hemp." Its correspondence to the four seasons is the Great Year Star, the refined *qi* of wood, which governs the Great Year Star, completing a celestial cycle in twelve years.
Thus, the *qi* of spring resides in the head, as all things flourish above, hence the *qi* of spring resides in the head.
○Newly corrected version: The *Shù* region specifies that the *qi* of spring resides in the head, not stating "thus the illness is in the head," while other regions state "thus the illness is in [a certain organ]," employing parallel structure.

Its tone is *jiǎo* (the fifth musical note), for *jiǎo* is the sound of wood.
In the first month of spring, the pitch pipe is *Tàizhù*, generated by *Línzhōng*, with a length of eight inches, increased by one-third.
In the second month of spring, the pitch pipe is *Jiāzhōng*, generated by *Yízé*, with a length of seven inches and five *fēn* (sub-units).
○Newly corrected version: According to Zhēng Xīngchéng, it is seven inches, two thousand seven hundred eighty-seven *fēn*, with an additional seven hundred seventy-five *fēn*.
In the third month of spring, the pitch pipe is *Gūxǐ*, generated by *Nánlǚ*, with a length of seven inches and ten *fēn*.
○Newly corrected version: According to Zhēng Xīngchéng, it is nine *fēn* per inch.
These three pipes all correspond to the original *qi*.
Its number is eight, for wood generates the number three, completing to eight.
*The Shàngshū Hóngfàn* states: "Three is wood."
Thus, it is known that illness resides in the sinews, for the firmness and softness of wood resembles the *qi* of sinews.
Its odor is pungent.
The *qi* of wood, when transformed, becomes restless.
○Newly corrected version: The *Yuèlìng* records "pungent" as *shàn* (aromatic).

The south is red, entering through the heart, opening at the ears, storing *jīng* in the heart.
The *qi* of fire essence is the spirit of the spirit, the tongue being the heart’s organ—though it should be said "the tongue," the tongue is not an orifice, hence it is said "ears."
*The Miǔ Cì Lùn* states: "The collateral of the hand’s *shǎo yīn* converges in the ear."
This meaning is taken from here.
Thus, illness resides in the five *zàng* (viscera),

With summer *qi* residing in the viscera,
Its flavor is bitter, its kindred is fire,
Its nature is flaming upward, scorching and searing.
Its livestock is sheep—
*"Sheep"* as livestock, for it is yet incomplete.
With earth as the sovereign, thus broadly speaking.
○Newly corrected version: According to *The Great Treatise on the Five Constants*, "Its livestock is horses."

Its grain is millet—
Millet’s hue is red,
Its correspondence to the seasons:
Above, it manifests as the Wandering Star,
The refined *qi* of fire ascending—
Above, it manifests as the Wandering Star,
completing a celestial circuit in 740 days.
Thus, it is known that illness resides in the vessels,
For fire’s restless agitation resembles the *qi* of swine.
Its tone is *zhēng*—
*Zhēng*, the voice of fire.
In early summer, the pitch pipe is *Zhònglǚ*,
Generated by *Wúshè*, three parts plus one-third,
Tube length: six inches and seven divisions.
○Newly corrected version: According to Zhēng Kāngchéng: six inches, nine thousand six hundred eighty-three divisions, with twelve thousand nine hundred seventy-four as the unit.

In mid-summer, the pitch pipe is *Kuíbīn*,
Generated by *Yīngzhōng*, three parts plus one-third,
Tube length: six inches and three divisions.
○Newly corrected version: According to Zhēng Kāngchéng: six inches, eighty-one divisions, with twenty-six as the unit.

In late summer, the pitch pipe is *Línzhōng*,
Generated by *Huángzhōng*, three parts plus one-third,
Tube length: six inches.
All three tubes correspond to the *qi* of fire.

Its number is seven—
Fire generates the number two, completing the number seven.
*The Shàngshū Hóngfàn* states: "Two is fire."
Its odor is burnt.
The *qi*, when transformed by fire, becomes burnt.
Central yellow, entering through the spleen,
Opening at the mouth, storing *jīng* in the spleen,
The refined *qi* of earth is the spirit of intent—
The spleen governs the transformation of grains,
The mouth governs receiving nourishment,
Thus, it opens at the mouth.
Hence, illness resides at the root of the tongue,
For the spleen’s *tún* ascends to the root of the tongue,
Thus, the pathogenic *qi* settles there.
Its flavor is sweet, its kindred is earth,
Its nature is tranquil and transformative.

Its livestock is the ox—
Earth reigns over the four seasons, so it takes the *chǒu* (丑, the second earthly branch) ox, and also because the ox’s color is yellow.

Its grain is millet—
Millet is yellow in color and sweet in flavor.

Its correspondence to the four seasons is the **Zhèn** (鎮, "settling") star,
The refined *qi* of earth ascends as the **Zhèn** star, completing a **wǔshíqiūtiān** (五十六年, "56-year celestial cycle") in one revolution.

Thus, it is known that illness resides in the flesh—
Earth’s yielding and thick nature aligns with the *qi* of flesh.

Its tone is **gōng** (宮, "the pentatone"),
The **gōng** tone is the voice of earth.
The *Lǜshū* (律書, "Classical Music Treatise") designates **Huángzhōng** (黃鐘, "Yellow Bell") as the **zhuó gōng** (浊宮, "muddy pentatone"), and **Línzhōng** (林鐘, "Forest Bell") as the **qīng gōng** (清宮, "clear pentatone"), for **Línzhōng** governs the pipes of the sixth month.
The five tones regard **gōng** as primary, with the **lǜ-lǚ** (律吕, "classical pitch and rhythm") initially emerging from **Huángzhōng** as the **zhuó gōng**, and **Línzhōng** as the **qīng gōng**.

Its number is five—
Earth’s number is five. The *Shàngshū Hóngfàn* (尚书洪范) states: "Five is earth."

Its odor is fragrant—
The *qi*, when transformed by earth, becomes fragrant.

---
To the west, white color,
Entering through the lungs, opening at the nose,
The lungs—
The refined *qi* of metal is the spirit of the **pò** (魄, "etheric soul"), for the lungs store *qi*, and the nose governs breathing, hence it opens at the nose.

Thus, illness resides in the back—
The lungs are positioned in the chest, and the back serves as the chest’s **fǔ** (府, "granary/abode").

Its flavor is pungent, its kindred is metal,
Its nature is resonant and firm.

Its **livestock is the horse**—
Livestock of the horse is taken from **Qián** (乾, "the Creative/Heaven"). The *Yì* (易, *I Ching*) says: "Qián is the horse."
○The *Xīnjiào Zhèngyún* (新校正, "Newly Revised Edition") states: According to the *Wǔ Cháng Zhèngdà Lùn* (五常政大论, "Treatise on the Five Constants and Their Grand Governance"), its **livestock is the falcon** (鹞).

Its **grain is rice**—
Rice is firm and white.

Its **correspondence with the four seasons** is the **Tàibái Star** (太白星, "Great White Star").
The refined *qi* of metal ascends as the **Tàibái Star**, completing a cycle in **365 days**.
Hence, one knows that illness resides in the **skin and fur**—
The firm and dense nature of metal aligns with the **skin and fur**.
Its **sound is shāng** (商, "the fifth musical note").
In the **Mèngqiū** (孟秋, "early autumn") month, the **lǜ-lǚ** (律吕) follows the **Yízé** (夷则, "Even Pitch") standard, generated by **Dàlǚ** (大吕, "Great Lǚ"), with a ratio of **two parts shāng to one part yīn** (吟). The **guǎn** (管, "bamboo flute") measures **5 inches 7 divisions** in length.

In the **Zhòngqiū** (仲秋, "mid-autumn") month, the **lǜ-lǚ** follows the **Nánlǚ** (南吕, "Southern Lǚ") standard, generated by **Tàizǔ** (太簇, "Great Cluster"), with a ratio of **three parts shāng to one part yīn**. The **guǎn** measures **5 inches 3 divisions** in length.

In the **Jìqiū** (季秋, "late autumn") month, the **lǜ-lǚ** follows the **Wúshè** (无射, "No Projection") standard, generated by **Jiázhōng** (夹钟, "Intermediate Bell"), with a ratio of **three parts shāng to one part yīn**. The **guǎn** measures **5 inches** in length.
These are the **three flutes**, all responding to the *qi* of metal.

Its number is **nine**—
Metal generates the number **four**, completing the number **nine**.
The *Shàngshū Hóngfàn* states: "Four is metal."

Its odor is **stinky**—
The *qi*, when transformed by metal, becomes the **ranid** (腥膻, "stinky and malodorous") *qi*.

To the **north, black color**,
Entering through the **kidneys**, opening at the **two yīn** (二阴, "two private orifices"),
Storing **jīng** (精, "essence") in the kidneys—
The refined *qi* of water is the **spirit of the zhì** (志, "will/volitional soul"), for the kidneys store essence, and the private orifices govern its discharge, hence it opens at the **two yīn**.
Thus, illness resides in the **drainage channels**—
The **drainage channels** (溪) refer to the **small gatherings of flesh** (肉之小会).
The *Qì Xuē Lùn* (气穴论, "Treatise on the *Qi* and Orifices") states: "The grand gathering of flesh is the **gǔ** (谷, 'valley'), the small gathering of flesh is the **drainage channels**."

Its flavor is **salty**, its kindred is **water**,
Its nature is **moist and downward**, permeating like **seepage**.

Its **livestock is the wild boar** (蠡, *jīng* 豕).
Its **grain is beans**—
Livestock of the **wild boar** (竞, *jīng* 豕) refers to the wild boar.
Grain of the **beans** (豆) refers to their black color.

Its **correspondence with the four seasons** is the **Chén Star** (辰星, "Morning Star").
The refined *qi* of water ascends as the **Chén Star**, completing a cycle in **365 days**.

Thus it is known that disease resides in the **bones**—
The bones govern **obscurity and darkness**, their substance concealed within,
By affinity they align, hence disease lodges in the bones.

Its **sound is *yǔ*** (羽),
For *yǔ* is the sound of **water**.

In the **first month of winter** (孟冬),
The **pitchpipe** resonates with *Zhōngzhōng* (钟),
Born of *Gūxǐ* (姑洗),
With a length of **4 inches and 7½ divisions** (三分喊一),
The **bamboo pipe** measures **4.75 units**.

In the **second month of winter** (仲冬),
The pitchpipe resonates with *Huángzhōng* (黄钟),
Born of *Zhònglǚ* (仲吕),
With an added **third part** (三分益一),
The **bamboo pipe** measures **9 units**.

In the **third month of winter** (季冬),
The pitchpipe resonates with *Dàlǚ* (大吕),
Born of *Diànbīn* (奠宾),
With an added **third part** (三分益一),
The **bamboo pipe** measures **8.4 units**.

These three pipes all correspond to **water qi**.

Its **number is six**—
Water generates the number **one**, completing the cycle at **six**.
The *Shàngshū Hóngfàn* (尚书洪范) states: **"One is water."**

Its **odor is rotten**.
When *qi* follows water, it transforms into the **stench of decay**.

Thus, the skilled pulse-taker must carefully examine the **Five Zàng** and **Six Fǔ**,
Observing **inversion and compliance**, the **principles of yin and yang, exterior and interior, female and male**,
Holding it in mind with intent,
Uniting heart with **essence**—
When the heart aligns with the subtle essence,
Then one deeply comprehends **adaptation and transformation**.

Teach not the unworthy, instruct not the insincere—
This is called **attaining the Dao**.

Adapt to their capacity and impart knowledge—
This is called **mastery in teaching and transmission**.

The *Língshū Jīng* (灵枢经) states:
Those with **keen vision** may be taught to **discern colors**,
Those with **acute hearing** may be taught to **perceive sounds**,
Those with **quick and eloquent speech** may be taught to **articulate discourse**,
Those who are **slow, tranquil, and deft-handed**, with **discerning minds**,
May be taught to **wield needles and moxa**,
To **regulate blood and *qi***, adjusting **disorders and inversions**,
To **discern yin and yang** while encompassing **all directions**,
To **relax joints and tendons with gentle movements**, harmonizing the mind—
These may be taught **guiding and breathing exercises**.

Those who are **light of speech, scornful of others, or prone to malice**,
May be taught to **spit and incant over illnesses**.

Those whose **nails are brittle, hands prone to injury, or who endure suffering**,
May be taught to **press accumulations and relieve stagnation**.

Thus, each finds their **aptitude**—
Only then may the method be applied, and their **name be renowned**.

Hence it is said:
**"Teach not the unworthy, instruct not the insincere."**

*(End of the fourth scroll of the annotated *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwèn* supplement.)*

**The Five Scroll of the Annotated *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwèn* Supplement**

**#2** *Pìn* (originally *Jīng*): Corrected from the *Gù* edition. The character *cáng* (藏) was originally omitted beneath *Pìn*, restored from the *Gù* edition.

**#3** *Wèi* (originally *Pìn*, per the *Gù* edition).

**#4** *Shí* (originally *èrshí*, per the *Gù* edition).

**#5** *Shàng* (originally *zhī*, corrected per the *Gù* edition).

**#6** *Zhǔ yíng* (originally *shàng nì*, corrected per the *Gù* edition).

**#7** *Gù* (originally *jí*, corrected per the *Gù* edition; applied uniformly throughout).

**#8** *Tài* (originally *yú*, corrected per the *Gù* edition).

**#9** *Èr fēn* (originally *sān fēn*, per the *Gù* edition).

**#10** *Zhī* (originally *zhī*, corrected per the *Gù* edition).

**Collated by the Song Grandee and Secretariat Official Lín Yì et al.,**
