**Supplementary Annotations to the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon* *Sùwèn* (《素问》) – Scroll Seven**
*Revised by Tang Grand Steward’s Scholar Xī Xuànzǐ Wáng Bīng, Annotated by Song Lightly Robed Scholar Lín Yì et al., Corrected by Na Sūn Zhào*

**Discourse on the Differentiation of Yin and Yang**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"What are the four **jīng** (经—*vital channels*) and twelve **cóng** (从—*sequential pulses*)?"*

**Jīng** refers to **jīngtún** (经豚—*canonical pulses*).
**Cóng** refers to **shùncóng** (顺从—*conformity*).

Qíbó replied:
*"The four **jīng** correspond to the four seasons, and the twelve **cóng** correspond to the twelve months, which in turn align with the twelve pulses. In spring, the pulse is **xián** (弦—*taut*); in summer, **hóng** (洪—*full*); in autumn, **fú** (浮—*superficial*); in winter, **chén** (沉—*deep*). These are the **jīngtún** of the four seasons.

The **cóng** refers to the **tiānqì** (天气—*celestial qi*) flowing sequentially through the twelve **chén** (辰—*celestial stems*), thus corresponding to the twelve months. The twelve months are:
- Spring: **Jiǎnyín** (建寅—*commencing in the Tiger*), **Mǎo** (卯), **Chén** (辰);
- Summer: **Jiǎnwèi** (建巳—*commencing in the Snake*), **Wǔ** (午), **Wèi** (未);
- Autumn: **Jiǎnshēn** (建申—*commencing in the Monkey*), **Yǒu** (酉), **Xū** (戌);
- Winter: **Jiǎnhài** (建亥—*commencing in the Pig*), **Zǐ** (子), **Chǒu** (丑).

The twelve **tún** (豚—*pulses*) are those of the **shǒusānyīn, sānyáng** (手三阴、三阳—*three yin and three yang of the hands*) and **zúsānyīn, sānyáng** (足三阴、三阳—*three yin and three yang of the feet*), their **qi** (气—*qi*) and **shù** (数—*numerical correspondences*) aligning, hence their **cānhé** (参合—*interrelation*).

Pulses have **yīnyáng** (阴阳—*yin and yang*). Knowing **yáng** (阳—*yang*) reveals **yīn** (阴—*yin*), and knowing **yīn** reveals **yáng**. Deep understanding encompasses their **biànyì** (变易—*transformations*).

There are five **yáng** (阳—*yang*), and five times five makes **èrshíwǔ yáng** (二十五阳—*twenty-five yang*).
The five **yáng** are the **yángqi** (阳气—*yang qi*) of the five **zàng** (藏—*viscera*).
The five **zàng** correspond to the seasons, each manifesting a **tún** (豚—*pulse*). Within a single pulse, the **yángqi** of the five **zàng** are encompassed. Five times five yields **èrshíwǔ yáng** (二十五阳—*twenty-five yang*).

**New Annotation:** According to the *Yùjī Zhēncáng Lùn* (《玉机真藏论》), *"Thus, diseases manifest in five transformations, and five times five makes twenty-five transformations."* The meaning aligns with this.

What is called **yīn** (阴—*yin*) is the **zhēncáng** (真藏—*true viscera*). When **seen** (见—*manifest*), it signifies **bài** (败—*decline*), and decline inevitably leads to death.

The five **zàng** are **yīn**, hence they are called the **zhēncáng**. When **seen** (见—*manifest*), it refers to:
- The **gān tún** (肝豚—*liver pulse*) arriving—**zhōngwài jí** (中外急—*urgent within and without*), like tracing a blade’s edge, **zézé** (责责—*trembling*) as if plucking a **qínsè** (琴瑟弦—*zither string*).
- The **xīn tún** (心豚—*heart pulse*) arriving—**jiān ér bó** (坚而搏—*firm and beating*), like stroking **cāngmáo zǐ** (苍苗子—*green grain seeds*), **lěilěi** (累累—*beaded*).
- The **fèi tún** (肺豚—*lung pulse*) arriving—**dà ér xū** (大而虚—*large and hollow*), like feathers brushing the skin.
- The **shèn tún** (肾豚—*kidney pulse*) arriving—**bó ér jué** (搏而绝—*beating then vanishing*), like fingering stone, **pīpī** (辟辟—*resonant*).
- The **pí tún** (脾豚—*spleen pulse*) arriving—**ruò ér zàshù zàshū** (弱而乍数乍疏—*weak, intermittently rapid then sparse*).

When such **tún** (豚—*pulses*) are **seen** (见—*manifest*), they all signify **zàngbài shénqù** (藏败神去—*visceral decline and spirit’s departure*), hence death is imminent.

**Lěi** (累) is pronounced **lì** (力) with a sharp tone.

What is called **yáng** (阳—*yang*) is the **wèiyuàn zhī yáng** (胃院之阳—*yang of the stomach and intestines*).
The **yáng** of the **wèiyuàn** (胃院—*stomach and intestines*) refers to the **rényíng zhī qì** (人迎之气—*qi of the *Rényíng* pulse*).
Observe its **tún** (豚—*pulse*)—its **dòngjìng xiǎodà** (动静小大—*movement, stillness, size*)—and whether it corresponds to the pulse.

The stomach is the **shuǐgǔ zhī hǎi** (水谷之海—*sea of water and grain*), so by examining its **qì** (气—*qi*), one knows the location of the disease.
The **Rényíng** pulse is located beside the **jiéhóu** (结喉—*laryngeal prominence*), where the pulse responds to the hand. Its **tún** (豚—*pulse*) typically is **zuǒxiǎo ér yòudà** (左小而右大—*smaller on the left, larger on the right*). The left is used to **hòu zàng** (侯藏—*auscultate the viscera*), the right to **hòu fǔ** (侯府—*auscultate the bowels).

**One Annotation:** *"Wèibāo zhī yáng"* (胃胞之阳—*yang of the stomach sac*) is incorrect.

**Guān** (管) is pronounced **guǎn** (管).

To **bié yú yáng** (别於阳—*differentiate in yang*) reveals the **bìngchù** (病处—*location of disease*).
To **bié yú yīn** (别於阴—*differentiate in yin*) determines the **sǐshēng zhī qī** (死生之期—*period of life or death).

**Yáng** (阳—*yang*) guards the exterior as **gù** (固—*fortified*), yet when **wàixié** (外邪—*external pathogens*) strike, differentiating in **yáng** reveals the **bìngchù** (病处—*location of disease*).
**Yīn** (阴—*yin*) harbors the spirit within. If examining the **zhēnzhèng chéngbài** (真正成败—*true authenticity of success or failure*), differentiating in **yīn** determines the **bìngzhě sǐshēng zhī qī** (病者死生之期—*patient’s period of life or death*).

**New Annotation:** According to the *Yùjī Zhēncáng Lùn* (《玉机真藏论》), *"Differentiating in yang reveals the origin of the disease; differentiating in yin determines the period of life or death."*

The three **yáng** (阳—*yang*) are in the head, the three **yīn** (阴—*yin*) in the hands—this is what is meant by **"one"** (一).
The head refers to **Rényíng** (人迎), the hand to **Qìkǒu** (气口). These two correspond, moving together and returning together. If their **xiǎodà qīdēng** (小大齐等—*size and equality are uniform*), they are called **píngrén** (平人—*the healthy individual*).
Thus, it is said that they are **"one"** (一).

**Qìkǒu** (气口) is located one **cùn** (寸) behind the **yújì** (鱼际—*fish border*) of the hand, while **Rényíng** (人迎) is one **cùn wǔfēn** (寸五分—*one and a half cun*) beside the **jiéhóu** (结喉—*laryngeal prominence*). Both can be used to **hòu zàngfǔ zhī qì** (侯藏府之气—*auscultate the viscera and bowels’ qi*).

To **bié yú yáng** (别於阳—*differentiate in yang*) reveals the **bìngjì shí** (病忌时—*forbidden times for the disease*).
To **bié yú yīn** (别於阴—*differentiate in yin*) determines the **sǐshēng zhī qī** (死生之期—*period of life or death*).
By **shí qì dìng qī** (识气定期—*recognizing qi and fixing the period*), one knows the **bìngjì** (病忌—*forbidden times*).
By **shěn míng chéngbài** (审明成败—*carefully discerning success or failure*), one knows the **sǐshēng zhī qī** (死生之期—*period of life or death*).

**Jǐn shú yīnyáng** (谨熟阴阳—*carefully mastering yin and yang*), **wú yǔ zhòngmóu** (无与众谋—*no need for collective deliberation*).
By **jǐnliàng qìhòu** (谨量气候—*carefully measuring qi and conditions*), one becomes **jīngshú yīnyáng** (精熟阴阳—*profoundly skilled in yin and yang*), thus the **bìngjì** (病忌—*forbidden times*) become clear, and doubts about **shēngsǐ** (生死—*life and death*) resolve themselves. When the path is correct, there is no confusion—why seek counsel from others?

What is called **yīnyáng** (阴阳—*yin and yang*) refers to:
- **Qù** (去—*departure*) as **yīn** (阴—*yin*), **zhì** (至—*arrival*) as **yáng** (阳—*yang*);
- **Jìng** (静—*stillness*) as **yīn** (阴—*yin*), **dòng** (动—*movement*) as **yáng** (阳—*yang*);
- **Chí** (迟—*slowness*) as **yīn** (阴—*yin*), **shù** (数—*rapidity*) as **yáng** (阳—*yang*).

This speaks of the **tún dòng zhōng** (豚动之中—*within pulse movement*).

For those holding the **zhēntún zhī zàngmài** (真脉之藏脉—*true pulses of the viscera*):
- If the **gān tún** (肝豚—*liver pulse*) is **xuányuè jí** (悬绝急—*suspended, abrupt, and urgent*), death occurs in **shíbā rì** (十八日—*eighteen days*);
- If the **xīn tún** (心豚—*heart pulse*) is **xuányuè** (悬绝—*suspended and abrupt*), death occurs in **jiǔ rì** (九日—*nine days*);
- If the **fèi tún** (肺豚—*lung pulse*) is **xuányuè**, death occurs in **shíèr rì** (十二日—*twelve days*);
- If the **shèn tún** (肾豚—*kidney pulse*) is **xuányuè**, death occurs in **qī rì** (七日—*seven days*);
- If the **pí tún** (脾豚—*spleen pulse*) is **xuányuè**, death occurs in **sì rì** (四日—*four days*).

The **zhēntún zhī zàngtún** (真豚之藏豚—*true pulses of the viscera*) refer to the **zhēncáng zhī mài** (真藏之脉—*true viscera’s pulses*).

The **shíbā rì** (十八日—*eighteen days*) is the remainder of the **jīn-mù chéngshù** (金木成数—*metal-wood numerical correspondence*).
The **jiǔ rì** (九日—*nine days*) is the remainder of the **shuǐhuǒ shēngchéng shù** (水火生成数—*water-fire generative numerical correspondence*).
The **shíèr rì** (十二日—*twelve days*) is the remainder of the **jīnhuǒ shēngchéng shù** (金火生成数—*metal-fire generative numerical correspondence*).
The **qī rì** (七日—*seven days*) is the remainder of the **shuǐtǔ shēngshù** (水土生数—*water-earth generative numerical correspondence*).
The **sì rì** (四日—*four days*) is the remainder of the **mù shēngshù** (木生数—*wood generative numerical correspondence*).

Thus, the *Discourse on the Healthy Person’s Qi Manifestations* (《平人气象论》) states:
*"When the liver pulse appears on **gēngxīn** (庚辛—*Gengxin*), death follows; when the heart pulse appears on **rényǐ** (壬癸—*Rényǐ*), death follows; when the lung pulse appears on **bǐngdīng** (丙丁—*Bǐngdīng*), death follows; when the kidney pulse appears on **wùjǐ** (戊己—*Wùjǐ*), death follows; when the spleen pulse appears on **jiǎyǐ** (甲乙—*Jiǎyǐ*), death follows."* This is because the **shù** (数—*numerical correspondences*) align, and those who reach their **qī** (期—*period*) perish without resistance.

**Why?** Because they cannot withstand the **kèzé zhī qì** (克贼之气—*overpowering pathogenic qi*).

It is said that when **two-yang** diseases manifest in the heart and spleen, there is inability to conceal or bend [one’s body], and women cease menstruating. The **two-yang** refers to the **Yangming** pulse of the large intestine and stomach.

*"Conceal or bend"* refers to matters of hidden intimacy. When the intestines and stomach fall ill, the heart and spleen are affected. If the heart is affected, blood does not flow; if the spleen is affected, flavors are not transformed. When blood does not flow, women cease menstruating; when flavors are not transformed, men produce little semen. Thus, matters of hidden intimacy cannot be fulfilled.

The *Discourse on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* states: *"Those whose essence is insufficient should be supplemented with flavors."* Hence, when flavors are not transformed, the essence-qi diminishes.

The *Treatise on Strange Diseases* states: *"The womb and fetus are connected to the kidneys."* Again, the *Evaluation of Febrile Diseases* says: *"When menstruation does not arrive, the womb’s pulse is closed. The womb’s pulse belongs to the heart and connects within the womb, forcing the qi upward, blocking the heart’s qi from descending. Thus, menstruation does not arrive."*

This is its meaning. Again, the *Essay on the Primordial Truth of the Ancient Times* states: *"At twenty-one [women], the Heavenly Essence arrives, the Uterus Channel opens, and the Great Surge Pulse flourishes, so menstruation descends in its proper time. At twenty-eight [men], the Heavenly Essence arrives, and the essence-qi overflows and drains."*

Thus, in women, this manifests as amenorrhea; in men, as diminished semen. If transmitted as **wind consumption** or **breathing obstruction**, death follows without remedy—speaking of its profound and enduring nature. When the stomach’s disease deepens and spreads to the spleen, it becomes **wind-heat consumption**, eroding the body. When the large intestine’s disease worsens and spreads to the lungs, it causes wheezing and sudden gasping. When the intestines, stomach, spleen, and lungs all affect the heart—**one zàng and two fǔ**—they mutually overpower and weaken one another, leading to untreatable death.

*"Responsible"* (責) is pronounced *bèn*.

When **three-yang** diseases manifest, they produce **chills and fever**, leading to **flaccidity, edema, and ulcers**; or **withering and syncope**. The **three-yang** refers to the pulses of the large intestine, small intestine, and bladder.

The small intestine’s pulse arises from the hand, travels up the arm, circles the shoulder, and ascends to the head. The bladder’s pulse descends from the head, branches down the back, passes through the buttocks, and enters the perineum, following the anus. Thus, when disease is in the upper body, it produces chills and fever; when in the lower body, it causes **flaccidity, edema, ulcers, and syncope**.

*"Pain"* (痛) is **aching**; *"withering"* (痿) is **weakness**; *"syncope"* (厥) is **foot numbness**, meaning **inverted qi**.

If transmitted, it becomes **dryness of the skin**; if transmitted further, it becomes **drooping hernia**. When heat is severe, the essence and blood are exhausted, so the qi that nourishes the skin and hair disperses entirely. When yang-qi sinks downward and yin-pulse contends upward, upward contention brings excess cold, while downward sinking relaxes the tendons, causing the testicles to droop and loosen, resulting in **drooping hernia**.

It is said that when **one-yang** disease manifests, there is **shortness of breath, coughing, and frequent diarrhea**. The **one-yang** refers to the **Shaoyang** pulses of the gallbladder and triple burner. Gallbladder-qi overpowers the stomach, hence frequent diarrhea. When the triple burner is internally diseased, there is shortness of breath; when yang ascends to the lungs, there is coughing. Why? Because the heart’s fire responds internally.

If transmitted, it becomes **heart-tugging**; if transmitted further, it becomes **diaphragm obstruction**. When diaphragm-qi overpowers the heart, heart-heat causes internal **tugging**. When the triple burner internally congeals, central heat causes **obstruction and blockage**.

*"Tugging"* (掣) is pronounced *chè*, meaning **to drag**.

When **two-yang and one-yin** diseases manifest, they cause **startle, back pain, frequent belching, and yawning**, known as **wind syncope**. The **one-yin** refers to the **Jueyin** pulses of the Heart Conductor and liver.

The Heart Conductor’s pulse arises from the chest, emerges to belong to the heart. The classics say: *"Heart disease causes pain between the shoulder blades and shoulders."* Again, in the qi, it manifests as belching, hence back pain and frequent belching. When heart-qi is insufficient, kidney-qi overpowers it; the liver governs startle, hence startle and frequent yawning. Liver-qi is wind, and kidney-qi is inverted; since it is both wind and rebellion, it is called **wind syncope**.

When **two-yin and one-yang** diseases manifest, there is **distension, heart fullness, and frequent flatulence**. The **two-yin** refers to the **Shaoyin** pulses of the heart and kidneys. When kidney and gallbladder qi rebel together, the triple burner does not function, and the qi is constricted upward, causing heart fullness. When the lower body is empty and the upper body is full, the qi escapes outward.

When **three-yang and three-yin** diseases manifest, they cause **hemiplegia, withering, and inability to lift the limbs**. When the three yin are insufficient, **hemiplegia** occurs; when the three yang are excessive, **withering** ensues. *"Withering"* means **altered function and weakness**.

When one-yang pulses are **stirred**, it is called **hook**; when one-yin is stirred, it is called **hair**. When yang is **overwhelming and urgent**, it is called **string**. When yang arrives and suddenly **cuts off**, it is called **stone**. When yin and yang **overstep**, it is called **slippery**.

How does one know the yin-yang disease pulses are evil? When one-yang is stirred, the pulse appears **hook-like**. Why? The **one-yang** refers to the triple burner, the heart’s **auxiliary fǔ**. When one-yang is stirred, the **hook pulse** corresponds to it—the **hook pulse** belongs to the heart, speaking of its **true manifestation**.

The **one-yin** is **Jueyin**, the liver’s wood-qi. *"Hair"* belongs to the lungs, the **metal pulse**. When metal stirs wood, the pulse becomes **hair-like**; when metal-qi internally overpowers, wood-yang is still dominant, urgent and internally visible, the pulse becomes **string**. If yang-qi arrives and is suddenly **cut off**, the pulse is called **stone**, belonging to the kidneys. When yin and yang qi **overstep**, neither can overpower the other, so the pulse is like **slippery water**.

When yin contends internally and yang disturbs externally, the **spirit-sweat** does not conceal itself, and **four reversals** arise. When they arise, they **specialize in the lungs**, causing wheezing and gasping. If metal-stirring does not cease, yang-qi overwhelmingly prevails, and the two qi clash—internal contention and external disturbance—leading to unceasing sweating. When hands and feet become cold, yang-qi internally flips, sweat does not conceal itself, and heat attacks the lungs, so when it arises, it **specializes in the lungs**, causing wheezing and gasping.

The birth of yin lies in harmony, which is called *hé* (和). Yin refers to the five spirit-organs, meaning that the five organs can generate and preserve the true harmony of Heaven’s *qi* only when each follows its inherent nature and remains tranquil. If they stray from their proper course, they will be overpowered by other *qi*, and myriad diseases arise from this. How can one not be cautious in nurturing life?

Thus, when *yang* clashes with *yang*, the *yang-qi* is dispersed and broken, and the yin-qi perishes. *Yang* refers to *yang-qi*—when it steams internally and flows as sweat externally, scorching without cessation, *yang* prevails over *yang*, and its excess cannot endure long before the *yang-qi* scatters. Once *yang* is broken, yin cannot stand alone, so when *yang-qi* is dispersed, yin-qi also fades—this is the result of contending for victory and inviting defeat.

When *yang* and *yin* are unbalanced, the channel *qi* is severed. For those with pure blood, *yang* is always dominant; one must harmonize their *qi* and ensure its smooth circulation. If they fail to cultivate deep thought and moderation, disrupting the natural order of *qi*, *yang* becomes excessive, and the organs perish—death is then inevitable, and longevity impossible.

For the category of *dead yin*, death occurs within three days—*fire* overpowers *metal*. For the category of *living yang*, death occurs within four days—*wood* overpowers *fire*. [*Note: Some texts correct this to "four days to live," but the original context confirms "death."*]

The *living yang* refers to the liver and heart: the mother nurtures the child, hence *living yang*—not only does *wood* generate *fire*, but *yang-qi* itself governs life. The *dead yin* refers to the heart and lungs: yin governs punishment and slaughter, and *fire* again overpowers *metal*, causing *metal* to perish when attacked by *fire*, hence *dead yin*. The *double yin* refers to the lungs and kidneys—both mother and child are governed by yin-qi, hence *double yin*. The *avoided yin* refers to the kidneys and spleen—death is inevitable. When earth-qi is disrupted, water cannot ascend—this is *avoided yin*.

*Structured yang* causes limb swelling—since the four limbs are the roots of all *yang*. *Structured yin* causes one *sheng* of blood in the stool—yin governs blood. If it recurs, two *sheng* appear; if it recurs again, three *sheng* appear. When yin and yang are misaligned, excessive yin and deficient yang is called *stone-water*, causing lower abdominal swelling—this is *losing the law*. When two *yang* structures form, it is called *consumption*—two *yang* structures refer to simultaneous heat in the stomach and large intestine. When the intestines and stomach harbor heat, they crave cold liquids.

When three *yang* structures form, it is called *obstruction*—three *yang* structures refer to heat in the small intestine and bladder. Heat in the small intestine dries the blood, and heat in the bladder exhausts the fluids, causing constipation. When three *yin* structures form, it is called *water*—three *yin* structures refer to cold in the spleen and lungs, causing *qi* to condense into water.

When one *yin* and one *yang* structure form, it is called *throat obstruction*—one *yin* refers to the heart’s channel, and one *yang* refers to the triple burner’s channel. The triple burner and heart channels converge at the throat, and internal heat causes obstruction. *Obstruction* is pronounced *bì* (闭).

When yin pulses clash with *yang* separately, it is called *having a child*—yin refers to the *cun* position. *Clash* means striking the hand. If the *cun* pulse beats forcefully, differing from the *guan* position, *yang-qi* rises strongly, signaling a sign of pregnancy—because there is a distinct *yang* within yin.

When yin and yang are both deficient, the intestines are disrupted, and death follows. [*Note: Some texts read "avoided" (避) instead of "disrupted" (辟).*] If stomach *qi* does not linger, the intestines open uncontrollably, and yin cannot retain—this is the exhaustion of true *qi*, hence death.

When *yang* overwhelms yin, it is called *sweat*—when *yang* is below and yin above, *yang-qi* rises and strikes upward; if yin complies, it condenses into sweat. When yin is deficient and *yang* strikes, it is called *uterine bleeding*—when the yin channels are insufficient, the *yang* pulses beat violently, causing internal rupture and downward blood flow.

If all three yin pulses beat, death occurs at midnight on the twentieth day—this aligns with the spleen and lungs’ numerical cycle. *Beating* refers to a hidden drumming, differing from the usual pulse. When yin-qi reaches its extreme, death occurs at midnight.

If two yin pulses beat, death occurs at dusk on the thirteenth day—this aligns with the heart and kidneys’ numerical cycle. When yin-qi is not yet extreme, death occurs at dusk.

If one yin pulse beats, death occurs on the tenth day—this aligns with the liver and heart’s numerical cycle.

If all three *yang* pulses beat and drum, death occurs in three days—*yang-qi* is swift and urgent.

If all three yin and three *yang* pulses beat, the abdomen swells, the body hair falls out, and defecation is impossible—death occurs in five days, as yin is also involved. *Hidden curves* refers to defecation.

If two *yang* pulses beat, their *qi* is chaotic, and death is untreatable, occurring within ten days—this aligns with the stomach and large intestine’s numerical cycle. [*Note: Some texts omit one *yang* pulse beating.*]

[*End of the annotated commentary on the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Classic, Plain Questions*, Volume Seven.*]

Death.

The numerical cycle of the liver and heart is thus.

If all three *yang* pulses beat and drum, death occurs in three days—*yang-qi* is swift and urgent.

If all three yin and three *yang* pulses beat, the chest and abdomen swell, the body hair falls out, and defecation is impossible—death occurs in five days, as yin is also involved. *Hidden curves* refers to defecation.

If two *yang* pulses beat, their *qi* is chaotic, and death is untreatable, occurring within ten days—this aligns with the **stomach** and large intestine’s numerical cycle. [*Note: Some texts omit one *yang* pulse beating.*]

---
[*Supplement to the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Classic, Plain Questions*, Volume Eight, with annotations by Wang Bing, Chancellor of the Imperial Secretariat under the Tang Dynasty. Later revised by Lin Yi and others, officials of the Song Dynasty, and finally corrected by Sun Zhao, the Song Imperial Censor and Director of the Imperial Farm.*]

*#7* "Carry" was originally "kidney," corrected according to Gu Ben.
*#8* "Lung" was originally "pulse," corrected according to Gu Ben.

*#10* "Qi" was originally "principle," corrected according to Gu Ben.

「The *Linglan Secret Canon* (论篇) [Newly Revised Text] states: According to Quan Yuanqi’s original title, it was named *The Twelve Zang Organs and Their Functions* (《十二藏相使》). The Yellow Emperor asked: I wish to hear about the functions and roles of the twelve Zang organs—how do they differ in rank and status? The Zang are called "Zang," meaning the repositories within the abdomen; they are not the twelve forms of the spirit and body as commonly understood.

Qibo replied: Your question is profound! Let me explain fully.

The **heart** is the organ of the sovereign, from which **virtue/power** and clarity emerge. It governs affairs through the **Dao/Way**, thus it is the sovereign’s organ; its purity and stillness command the spirit, hence it is said that **virtue/power** and clarity arise from it.

The **lungs** are the organ of the ministerial aide, from which regulation and order emerge. Though its station is high, it is not the sovereign, so it serves as a ministerial aide; it oversees the circulation of **honor-qi** and **defense-qi**, hence regulation and order come from it.

The **liver** is the organ of the general, from which strategy and foresight emerge. It is bold and decisive, hence called the general; its **qi** is yet to manifest, thus strategy and foresight arise from it.

The **gallbladder** is the organ of rectitude, from which judgment and decision emerge. It is firm, upright, and swift in action, hence it is the organ of rectitude; it is straightforward without hesitation, thus judgment and decision come from it.

The **pericardium** is the organ of the attendants, from which joy and delight emerge. The pericardium lies between the breasts, serving as the **sea of qi**. The heart, as sovereign, issues commands through the **pulse** (#1), while the pericardium governs **qi**, distributing it to yin and yang. When **qi** is harmonious and the will is at ease, joy and delight naturally arise, and it regulates yin and yang. Thus, it is the organ of the attendants.

**Spleen and stomach** are the organ of the granaries, from which the five tastes emerge. They contain and process the five grains, hence they are the granaries’ organ; they nourish the four limbs, thus it is said that the five tastes arise from them.

The **large intestine** is the organ of transmission, from which transformation emerges. Transmission refers to conveying the impure **Dao/Way**; transformation refers to altering the form of substances. Hence, it is called the organ of transmission, and transformation comes from it.

The **small intestine** is the organ of reception and containment, from which further transformation emerges. It receives and processes the remnants from the stomach, transforming them before passing them into the large intestine. Thus, it is the organ of reception and containment, and further transformation comes from it.

The **kidneys** are the organ of vigor and strength, from which ingenuity and craft emerge. They excel in function, hence called the organ of vigor; they shape and refine, thus ingenuity and craft arise from them. In women, this corresponds to their ingenuity and craft; in men, it aligns with their robust strength.

The **San Jiao/Triple Burner** is the organ of the waterways, from which fluid pathways emerge. It guides and harmonizes yin and yang, opening and unblocking obstructions, hence it is the organ of the waterways, and fluid pathways emerge from it.

The **bladder** is the organ of the isolated palace, where **bodily fluids** are stored, and **qi** transformation enables their release. Its station is that of an isolated palace, hence it is called the organ of the palace. It resides in the lower abdomen, hollow within, thus storing **bodily fluids**. If it receives **qi** from the **sea of qi** for transformation, then urination flows freely; if the **sea of qi**’s influence is insufficient, then urination becomes blocked and difficult. Hence, it is said that **qi** transformation enables their release.

The *Linglan Classic* states: The kidneys connect to the lungs above, thus they govern the two Zang organs; the bladder is the isolated palace. This is what is meant.

**Urine** is called *shou* (瘦).

In total, these twelve organs must not fail one another. If they do, calamity and harm will follow, hence they must not fail one another.

[Newly Revised Text] states: Upon closer examination, there are actually eleven organs, as the spleen and stomach share one function.

Thus, if the sovereign’s **virtue/power** is clear, then all below will be at peace, and if one cultivates life through this, longevity will follow, and one will not perish in this world. If applied to governing the realm, great prosperity will arise.

The sovereign refers to the heart’s organ. If the sovereign is virtuous and clear, then rewards and punishments will be unified; unified rewards and punishments mean officials will follow the law. When officials follow the law, the people will not suffer unjust or excessive punishments, hence it is said that a clear sovereign brings peace to the realm (#2).

If the heart’s **virtue/power** is internalized, then it discerns good and evil; discerning good and evil means it perceives safety and danger; perceiving safety and danger means the body will not be harmed prematurely by unrighteous **Dao/Way**. Thus, if one cultivates life through this, longevity will follow, and one will not face peril in this world.

When applied to cultivating life, one avoids peril in this world; when applied to the sovereign, the realm is at peace. If this is used as the sovereign’s guiding principle, then the nation’s fortunes will flourish.

If the sovereign’s **virtue/power** is unclear, then the twelve organs are in peril, their functions blocked and stagnant, and the body is gravely harmed. If one cultivates life through this, misfortune will follow; if applied to governing the realm, the lineage will face great danger. Beware! Beware!

Functions refer to the pathways of spirit and **qi** (#3).

If the heart’s **virtue/power** is unclear, then righteousness and vice become indistinguishable; if righteousness and vice are not distinguished, then harm and benefit cannot be separated. If harm and benefit are not separated, then the calamities of reckless action will ensnare the body, leading to exhaustion and depletion. Hence, the body is gravely harmed, and if one cultivates life through this, misfortune will follow.

If the sovereign’s **virtue/power** is unclear, then authority is delegated to the left and right. If authority is delegated to the left and right, then power and influence act arbitrarily; arbitrary power and influence mean officials cannot follow the law. When officials cannot follow the law, the people lose their bearings and are all subjected to injustice and distortion.

Moreover, the people are the foundation of the state; if the foundation is secure, the state is stable. If the foundation is not secure, how can the state endure? The establishment of ancestral temples—how can they not face ruin and peril? Hence, it is said: "Beware! Beware!" meaning one must be deeply cautious.

**Exhaustion** is pronounced *ji* (瘠).

The **Dao/Way** is subtle and infinite in transformation; who can fathom its origin?

[Newly Revised Text] states: According to *The Grand Essentials* (《太素》), the original reads: "The diligent one is ever vigilant" (肖者濯濯). The **Dao/Way**’s applications are subtle when minute and profound, penetrating all things; vast when expanded, infinite in transformation. Yet its depths and sources—who can truly comprehend them?

How constrained it is! The diligent one is ever vigilant, yet who can grasp its essentials?

The critical and harmonious alignment of the body’s **Dao/Way** must be understood; who is the adept at discerning its essence?

**Constrained** (窘) is also **essence** (要). *Huoqi* (霍瞿) means "constant motion." The essential principles of the body must be sought, and the **Dao/Way** is what governs them. Yet through the ebb and flow of changes, one investigates the laws of nature and sings of knowing the fundamental source of transformation. Though ever vigilant and diligent, seeking clarity, its essence remains profound—who can truly know it? Since it cannot be known, it grows ever deeper and more distant; the subtle and mysterious essence is yet unknown, and who can say who is truly adept at understanding it?」

The profound and mysterious, deep and distant—though not grasped by seeking through reason, yet when examined within the self, the twelve **organs** (官) may be roughly explored, and this becomes the **Dao/Way** for governing the body.

**Faint and elusive** (闵闵) is the same as **deep and distant** (深远). **Adept** (良) means **good** (善).

---
*The **Dao/Way** of subtle brilliance (精光), the great sage’s work (大圣之业), and the proclamation of the grand **Dao/Way** (大道)—*
*unless through fasting, purification, and selecting auspicious days (斋戒择吉日),*
*I dare not receive it.*
*This is due to profound reverence (深敬).*

Han Kangbo said:
*"On the day of heart-washing (洗心) and alignment (日齐),*
*one must guard and restrain (防息) and observe restraint (日戒)."*

Thus, the Yellow Emperor (黄帝) chose an auspicious day and favorable omen (吉日良兆),
and stored the **Essence of the Soul** (灵兰) within a secret chamber (室),
to pass it down and preserve it.
*This is the utmost secrecy (秘之至也).*

*Supplementary Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon, Plain Questions*
*Tang Taipu Ling 启玄子 Wang Bing’s annotations,*
*Song Guanglu Jian 直秘阁 Lin Yi’s revisions,*
*Song Shou Shangshu 守尚书屯田郎 Sun Zhao’s corrections of errors.*

**Chapter on the Six Divisions and Hidden Symbols (六节藏象论篇)**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I have heard that Heaven uses the six divisions of six (六六之节) to complete a year, and that Earth uses nine cycles of nine (九九制会) to regulate its affairs. The new revision states: ‘See further below: Earth uses nine cycles of nine (九九制会) to regulate its affairs.’ It is said that humans also have three hundred sixty-five nodes (节), as do Heaven and Earth since ancient times. But I do not know what this means.

The six divisions of six refer to the six cycles of the six *Hexagrams* (六甲之日), completing the seasonal divisions of a year. The nine cycles of nine refer to the nine revolutions of the nine *Divisions of the Earth* (九野之数), regulating the correspondence of human form with the cosmic *ways* (会通). It is said that humans have three hundred sixty-five nodes to align with Heaven’s six divisions of six since ancient times. If one were to use nine cycles of nine as a reckoning method, then one and a half years would constitute a single revolution—yet I do not know what the true original intent of this reckoning was.*

*New revision states: ‘See Wang’s annotation: one and a half years constitutes a single revolution.’ According to the nine cycles of nine (九九制会), it should read: ‘one and a half years plus one-fourth of a year constitutes a single revolution.’*

Qibo replied: *"Your question is most luminous! Let me elucidate it fully.

The six divisions of six and the nine cycles of nine are the means by which Heaven’s measures and the *numbers of qi* (气之数) are rectified. The six divisions of six are Heaven’s measures; the nine cycles of nine are the *numbers of qi*. By ‘numbers of qi,’ I mean the *qi of generation and transformation* (生成之气).

The division of Heaven’s revolution spans nearly three hundred sixty-five degrees and one-fourth of a degree. When evenly distributed through the twelve *Seasonal Qi* (节气), the *qi* completes three hundred sixty days in a cycle, yet small months still fall short of this total. Therefore, the sixty-four *qi* are always adjusted with intercalary months. Why? Because of the accumulated discrepancies in their divisions.

The generative processes of Heaven and Earth originate from the *sixfold foundation of yin and yang* (陆於阴阳), while the movement of human and divine *essence* (神) begins and ends with the nine *qi*. Yet the function of these nine *qi* is vast indeed! The *Lü Shū* (律书) states: ‘The *huángzhōng* (黄钟) pipe is nine inches long, and on the day of the winter solstice, the *qi* corresponds to the *ashen* (灰飞) phase.’ Thus, the generation of all things is indeed tied to the nine *qi*.

In ancient times, the ‘nine inches’ referred to today’s ‘seven and three-tenths inches’ (七寸三分), though variations exist due to differing standards of measurement. The *Lü Shū* (律书) further states: ‘The *huángzhōng* pipe is nine inches long, and on the day of the winter solstice, the *qi* corresponds to the *ashen* (灰飞) phase.’ Thus, the generation of all things is indeed tied to the nine *qi*.

The *measures of Heaven* (天度) regulate the movement of the sun and moon. The *numbers of qi* mark the functions of generation and transformation. ‘Regulate’ means to establish standards; ‘mark’ means to set guiding principles. The standards for the sun and moon’s movement determine whether their paths are slow or swift. The marking of the functions of generation and transformation reveals that when the *qi* arrives, its effects manifest. If the *qi*’s responses are without error, the principles of generation and transformation remain unbroken. The sun’s slow or swift movement governs the length of large and small months, and thus the seasons shift. Hence, days vary in length, months shift between warmth and cold, and the cycles of gathering, storing, generating, and growing never fail to align with the proper times.

Heaven is yang, Earth is yin, the sun is yang, and the moon is yin. Their movements have divisions and guiding principles, and their revolutions follow fixed *Dao* (道理). The sun moves one degree per day, while the moon moves thirteen degrees and a fraction, completing three hundred sixty-five days in a year. Thus, the accumulation of *qi*’s surplus results in intercalary months.

The sun moves slowly, so its daily traversal of Heaven’s one degree requires three hundred sixty-five days to complete a full revolution, yet there remains a fractional degree unaccounted for. The moon moves swiftly, so its daily traversal of Heaven’s thirteen degrees and a fraction completes a revolution in twenty-nine days. By ‘fraction,’ I mean that beyond the thirteen degrees, it moves an additional seven-tenths of a degree, hence the statement: ‘the moon moves thirteen degrees and a fraction.’

The *Lǐ Yì* (礼义) and the *Han Lü Lì Zhì* (律历志) of the Han state: ‘The twenty-eight *mansions* (宿) and all stars move from east to west across Heaven, while the sun, moon, and five planets move from west to east across Heaven.’ But the *Grand Historian’s* (太史) account says: ‘All move eastward across Heaven, turning from east to west.’ The various *reckoners of time* (历家) state that in the first four days of the moon’s cycle, its movement is most rapid, traversing fourteen degrees and a fraction per day and night. From the fifth to the eighth days, its movement is slightly slower, traversing thirteen degrees and a fraction per day and night. From the ninth to the nineteenth days, its movement is even slower, traversing twelve degrees and a fraction per day and night. From the twentieth to the twenty-third days, its movement quickens slightly, traversing thirteen degrees and a fraction per day and night. From the twenty-fourth day to the end of the month, its movement quickens greatly, traversing fourteen degrees and a fraction per day and night. But the *Grand Historian’s* account of the moon’s movement does not match this.

The moon’s movement varies: it is swift for the first fifteen days and slow for the last fifteen, or slow for the first fifteen and swift for the last. Generally, in one month, one-fourth of the days exhibit either swift or slow movement, and the degrees of swiftness and slowness are not fixed. Still, the moon ultimately completes a revolution in twenty-seven days, traversing three hundred sixty degrees in total. On the twenty-ninth day, the sun moves twenty-nine degrees, while the moon moves three hundred eighty-seven degrees, falling short by seven degrees. On the thirtieth day, the sun shifts again, and the moon’s movement reaches eight-tenths of a day’s fraction (十三分日之八), only then aligning with the sun. This is the *greatly depleted month* (大尽之月). If the moon’s movement reaches half of a day’s fraction (十三分日之半), it is also considered a greatly depleted month. If it reaches five-sixths of a day’s fraction (十三分日之五之六) and aligns with the sun, it is a *slightly depleted month* (小尽之月). Hence, the statement: ‘large and small months complete three hundred sixty-five days to form a year.’

To speak precisely: three hundred sixty-five days and one-fourth of a day constitute the law of a year. Since the fraction does not complete a full day, it is rounded to six (六), hence the statement: ‘If one were to use six small fractions as the standard, then a year would only have three hundred fifty-four days, leaving an eleven-day surplus unaccounted for.’*"*

The deficiency of the moon’s hours is supplemented by the surplus days beyond the year, hence the leap month begins thirty-two days after the previous leap month, thus completing the intercalation.

*The Shangshu* states: *"Three hundred sixty days and six weeks, using the leap month to regulate the four seasons and complete the year."* Thus its meaning is:

The accumulated surplus fills the intercalary month, yet it does not exhaust the celestial degree because it follows the moon’s large and small cycles. Establish the beginning at the start, mark the midpoint in the middle, and extend the surplus to the end—thus the celestial degree is fulfilled.

*End* is the beginning; *beginning* is the initial. *Mark* means to manifest; *midpoint* refers to the month’s half. *Extend* means to shift positions. It speaks of establishing the initial *qi* at the first node’s day, manifesting the *dou* constellation at the midpoint hour, and shifting the surplus leap to the subsequent cycle. Therefore, before the leap month, the *qi* does not align with the month, and after the leap month, the month does not align with the *qi*.

Hence, the regulation of ordinary months begins and marks the midpoint, while the leap month’s reckoning has neither beginning nor midpoint. Even if the calendar includes them, they belong to other node-*qi* cycles. Therefore, the calendar does not say, *"The [seasonal] node of such-and-such month, the leap month’s node in such-and-such month."* The meaning of extending to the end is now clear. Thus, it is said: *"Establish the beginning at the start, mark the midpoint in the middle, and extend the surplus to the end."*

From this, the leap month is formed by extending the days, thus fulfilling the celestial degree.

The Emperor said: *"I have already heard of the celestial degree. I wish to hear how the *qi* and numbers harmonize?"*

Gǐ Bó replied:

*"Heaven uses six times six as its nodes, Earth uses nine times nine for its gatherings. [New annotation: The original text states: *‘Man uses nine times nine for its gatherings.’*] Heaven has ten days—when six cycles complete, the *jiǎzi* sequence returns, and six repetitions conclude the year, totaling three hundred sixty days.

*Ten days* refers to the days of *jiǎ-yǐ-bǐng-dīng-wù-jǐ-gēng-xīn-rén-guǐ* [the ten Heavenly Stems]. Ten is the supreme number of Heaven and Earth. *The Yì Jīng Shì Yì* states: *‘Heaven is nine, Earth is ten.’*

Thus, sixty days complete one cycle of *jiǎzi*, and six cycles return to the beginning. Therefore, the days of a year total three hundred sixty, which is not the celestial degree’s number. This is because each of the twelve months originally had thirty days; if small months are subtracted, the days differ again.

Since antiquity, those who harmonized with Heaven’s order have taken life’s foundation—rooted in yin and yang. Their *qi* flows through the nine regions and nine orifices, all communicating with Heaven’s *qi*.

*Communicating with Heaven* refers to the primal *qi*, the very essence of Heaven. Yet, form is borrowed from Earth’s generation, while life is bestowed by Heaven’s decree. Thus, the *qi* of life, connected to Heaven, draws from the yin field, forming the root and foundation.

*The Bǎo Mìng Quán Xíng Lùn* states: *"Man is born of Earth, his fate suspended by Heaven. When Heaven and Earth merge their *qi*, life is named ‘human.’"*

*The Sì Qì Tiáo Shén Dà Lùn* states: *"Yin and yang, the four seasons—these are the end and beginning of all things, the source of death and life."* It further says: *"To act against their root is to sever their foundation, destroying their essence."*

Thus is its meaning.

The Nine Regions refer to **Jì, Kè, Qīng, Xú, Yáng, Jīng, Yǔ, Líng, and Yōng**.

Yet, the Earth is divided into the Nine Regions, while humans possess the Nine Orifices. Vital essence (*shén*) circulates endlessly, and *qi* harmonizes with the Three Celestial Stems (*sānshēn*), hence the saying: "Nine Regions, Nine Orifices." As the *Língshū Jīng* states: *"The Earth has Nine Regions; the human body has Nine Orifices."* This is its meaning.

First, it speaks of *qi*, referring to the primal *qi* of Heaven (*tiānzhēn*), which is always connected to the center. When Heaven’s *qi* does not cease, the true spirit (*zhēnlíng*) remains within, and in all its manifestations—emerging, concealing, moving, or resting—it is entirely in harmony with Heaven. Hence, it is said: *"All communicate with Heaven’s *qi*."*

Thus, its life is rooted in Five (*wǔ*), yet its *qi* originates from Three (*sān*). The body’s existence relies on the Five Phases (*wǔxíng*) for function, while tracing its origin reveals it arises from the Three *qi*. Hence, it is said: *"Its life is rooted in Five, its *qi* originates from Three."*

The Three *qi* also correspond to the Three Celestial Stems. Therefore, the following text states:

○ *New Annotation*: Examining the ancient teachings of those who harmonize with Heaven, this aligns with *The Treatise on the Circulation of Vital Essence Through Heaven*, though the annotations differ; both should be considered.

Three forms Heaven, three forms Earth, three forms humanity. Not only does humanity arise from the Three *qi*, but the Dao of Heaven and Earth is likewise so. Hence, the *Yì Jīng*’s trigrams—*Qián* and *Kūn* included—are all composed of three.

Three thrice combined, totaling nine, divided into the Nine Wilds, which correspond to the Nine Caverns. The Nine Wilds align with the Nine Caverns in meaning. As the *Ěr Yǎ* states: *"Beyond the city lies the suburbs; beyond the suburbs, the fields; beyond the fields, the pastures; beyond the pastures, the forests; beyond the forests, the marshes; beyond the marshes, the wilderness."* This is what is meant.

○ *New Annotation*: According to the current *Ěr Yǎ*, it states: *"Beyond the city is called suburbs; beyond the suburbs, pastures; beyond the pastures, wilderness; beyond the wilderness, forests; beyond the forests, marshes."* This differs from what Wang [citation] quoted.

Thus, the Four Physical Caverns and Five Spiritual Caverns combine to form the Nine Caverns in correspondence. The Four Physical Caverns are: 1) the head and horns, 2) the ears and eyes, 3) the mouth and teeth, 4) the chest. These are external divisions, hence their names. The Five Spiritual Caverns are: 1) the liver, 2) the heart, 3) the spleen, 4) the lungs, 5) the kidneys. These are internal repositories, hence their names. The so-called Spiritual Caverns are: the liver houses the *hún* (ethereal soul), the heart houses the *shén* (spirit), the spleen houses the *yì* (intent), the lungs house the *pò* (corporeal soul), and the kidneys house the *zhì* (will). Thus, the distinction between the two is made.

○ *New Annotation*: This is the text from *The Illuminated Treatise on the Five *Qi***, differing in emphasis from *The Treatise on the Circulation of Vital Essence Through Heaven*. It also diverges from *The Treatise on the Three Departments and Nine Diagnoses* in its annotations, explaining the theory of Spiritual and Physical Caverns as detailed in *The Treatise on the Three Departments and Nine Diagnoses*.

The Emperor said: *"I have already heard of the convergence of six sixes and nine nines. Master speaks of accumulated *qi* filling the months—pray, what is meant by *qi*? I beg the Master to dispel my ignorance and clarify my doubts!"*

The Emperor said: *"I pray for Your Majesty to expound the essential truths, to reveal what has not yet been heard, and to clarify the hearts of those with doubts and open the ears of those shrouded in ignorance, so that they may comprehend and all attain profound understanding."*

Qī Bó replied: *"This is the secret of the Supreme Daoist Sovereign (Shànggǔ Dìjūn), transmitted by the venerable Master (xiānshī)."* The Supreme Daoist Sovereign refers to the ancient imperial sage. The venerable Master refers to **Yí Dài Jì** (仪贷季), the ancestor’s teacher of Qī Bó, who was the ancient expert in discerning the **color** and **pulse** of the **Eight Winds** (bā fēng). The *Treatise on Transmuting Intent into Qi* (《Yí Jīng Biàn Qì Lùn》) states: *"In the ancient times, the venerable Master **Yí Dài Jì** discerned the **color** and **pulse** of the **Eight Winds**, thereby attaining harmony between the Spiritual and Physical Caverns (shénmíng) and aligning with the unchanging principles of **Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth**, the **Four Seasons**, the **Six Harmonies** (liù hé), and the **Eight Winds**."* This is what is meant.

The Emperor said: *"I pray for Your Majesty to continue expounding this."*

Qī Bó replied: *"Five days are called a **candidate** (hòu), three candidates are called a **phase** (qì), six phases are called a **season** (shí), and four seasons are called a **year** (suì), each following its respective governing principles (zhǔzhì)."* The sun traverses **five degrees** of Heaven each day, hence five days. Three candidates sum to **fifteen days**, the proper duration of a phase. Six phases encompass **ninety days**, which is the proper length of three months, though they may vary, hence the **eighteen candidates** constitute the six phases, called seasons. Four seasons span **three hundred sixty days**, hence they are called a year. Each follows its governing principle, meaning that within a year, the days align with one of the **Five Phases** (wǔxíng) as their governing **qi**, ruling and dominating accordingly. Thus, it is said: *"The Five Movements (wǔyùn) succeed one another, each governing its own, and the final days of the year return in cycles, establishing seasons and distributing phases like an endless ring. The candidates follow the same law."* Hence, it is said: *"If one does not know the excess or deficiency of the yearly **qi**, nor the rise and fall of the **Phases’** vigor and decline, nor the origins of emptiness and fullness, one cannot be a skilled practitioner (gōng)."* The Five Movements refer to the **qi** of the Five Phases, which respond to Heaven’s movements and govern transformations. *Succeed* means to inherit, as a son succeeds a father. The Five Phases’ **qi**, parent to child, governs the entire cycle of the year, perpetually renewing.

*Season* refers to the establishment of **Spring** before its due time. *Phase* refers to the **qi** that governs the **Spring** (túnqì). When the **Spring qi** arrives before its due time, the pulse **qi** also arrives early, hence it is said: *"The season establishes its phase."* A *candidate* refers to the **five degrees** the sun traverses each day, meaning that even within a single candidate, the **Five Phases’ qi** generate in sequence, and any deviation leads to illness. The *Treatise on Transmuting Intent into Qi* states: *"In the ancient times, the venerable Master **Yí Dài Jì** discerned the **color** and **pulse** of the **Eight Winds**, thereby attaining harmony between the Spiritual and Physical Caverns, and aligning with the unchanging principles of **Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth**, the **Four Seasons**, the **Eight Winds**, and the **Six Harmonies**."* This is what is meant. *Skilled practitioner* refers to one adept at cultivation and nourishment (xiūyǎng). It is said: *"Only when one understands this thoroughly can one traverse the world with mastery."* [*New Annotation*: The Master’s commentary states that *"The season establishes its phase"* refers to the **qi** and pulse governing the season before its due time, i.e., the **Spring qi** before **Spring** begins. It is noted that the present text of *The Great Essentials* (《Tài Sù》) lacks this passage. **Yí** (仪) may be an error for **jiù** (就), meaning *"to approach"* or *"to conform"* to.]

The Emperor said: *"The Five Movements begin in cycles, like an endless ring. How do their excesses and deficiencies manifest?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"The Six Phases alternate in succession, each having its own dominion (suǒshèng). The changes of excess and deficiency are their constant principle."* It is said that the changes of excess and deficiency are visible, for this is Heaven’s eternal Dao.

The Emperor said: *"What constitutes balanced **qi**?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"It is the absence of excess."* If one does not deviate from the standard candidates, there is no excess.

The Emperor said: *"What of excess and deficiency? How should they be addressed?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"They are detailed in the *Treatise*."* [*New Annotation*: The Master’s commentary states that the *Treatise on the True Essentials of the Five Organs* (《Yù Jī Zhēn Cáng Lùn Piān》) has already been expounded. However, this passage specifically discusses the excess and deficiency of the **Spring qi** (túnqì), and does not cover the excess and deficiency of the **Five Movements** or balanced **qi**. It should refer to the *Grand Treatise on the Interaction of Qi* (《Qì Jiāo Biàn Dà Lùn》) and the *Treatise on the Five Constant Regulations* (《Wǔ Cháng Zhèng Dà Lùn Piān》), which do detail these matters.]

The Emperor said: *"What is meant by ‘dominion’?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"**Spring** dominates **Late Summer** (Chángxià), **Late Summer** dominates **Winter**, **Winter** dominates **Summer**, **Summer** dominates **Autumn**, and **Autumn** dominates **Spring**—this is the dominion of the Five Phases’ seasons. Each **qi** names its corresponding **Cavern** (zàng)."* **Spring** corresponds to **Wood**, and **Wood** dominates **Earth**; **Late Summer** corresponds to **Earth**, and **Earth** dominates **Water**; **Winter** corresponds to **Water**, and **Water** dominates **Fire**; **Summer** corresponds to **Fire**, and **Fire** dominates **Metal**; and **Autumn** corresponds to **Metal**, and **Metal** dominates **Wood**. This is always so. Within the four seasons, **Late Summer** is added, hence it is said: *"This is the dominion of the Five Phases’ seasons."* **Late Summer** refers to the sixth month, when **Earth** is generated from **Fire** and prolonged within **Summer**, having grown and now ruled, hence **Late Summer**. Each **qi** names its corresponding **Cavern**: the **Wood** of **Spring** internally aligns with the **Liver**; **Late Summer’s Earth** aligns with the **Spleen**; **Winter’s Water** aligns with the **Kidneys**; **Summer’s Fire** aligns with the **Heart**; and **Autumn’s Metal** aligns with the **Lungs**. Hence it is said: *"Each **qi** names its corresponding **Cavern**."* *Names* means *commands* (mìng).

The Emperor said: *"How does one know their dominion?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"One seeks their arrival. All return to the beginning of **Spring**."* The beginning of **Spring** refers to the day of **Spring’s** establishment. **Spring** is the longest of the four seasons, hence all candidates and phases return to the days before **Spring** begins. If they arrive before their due time, this is called **excess** (tàoguò), where they thin the **qi** of what they do not dominate and ride upon the **qi** of what they do dominate, termed **excessive proliferation** (qìyín). Without proper distinction, the perverse **qi** invades internally, and even a skilled practitioner cannot resist. [*These ten characters are disjointed in meaning; they likely result from an ancient textual error.*] The following five characters detail the proper course. They are marked in red ink here.

If they arrive after their due time, this is called **deficiency** (bùjí), where the **qi** of what they dominate acts arbitrarily, and the **qi** of what they generate suffers illness, while the **qi** of what they do not dominate becomes thin. This is termed **constricted qi** (qìpò)."

The so-called **"seeking its arrival"** (qiú qí zhì) refers to the time when **qi** arrives. In general, the arrival of **qi** is always considered to be fifteen days before the **solar term of Spring Begins** (Lìchūn), marking the beginning of the **Five Agents' divination** (wǔháng zhī hòu).

If it arrives **before its due time**, this means the **qi** of the **Agent** it ought to govern has not yet manifested, yet arrives prematurely. When it arrives prematurely, this is **excess qi** (yǒuyú), hence called **excess** (tàoguò). If it arrives **after its due time**, this means the **qi** of the **Agent** it ought to govern has twice failed to arrive, only then appearing belatedly. When it arrives belatedly, this is **deficient qi** (bùzú), hence called **deficiency** (bùjí).

In **excess**, the **qi** of what it ought not to dominate grows thin, while the **qi** of what it ought to dominate proliferates, termed **excessive proliferation** (qìyín). In **deficiency**, the **qi** of what it ought to dominate acts arbitrarily, while the **qi** of what it ought to generate falls ill, and the **qi** of what it ought not to dominate grows thin—this is termed **constricted qi** (qìpò).

As for the **Five Agents' qi** (wǔxíng zhī qì), the **qi** that I dominate is called **what I dominate** (suǒshèng), the **qi** that dominates me is called **what I do not dominate** (suǒbùshèng), and the **qi** that generates me is called **what I generate** (suǒshēng). For instance, if **Liver-Wood** (gān mù) has **excess qi** (yǒuyú), this means **Lung-Metal** (fèi jīn) is deficient. Metal does not restrain Wood, hence Wood is in **excess**. Once Wood-**qi** is excessive, it then reverses to thin **Lung-Metal**, while riding upon **Spleen-Earth** (pí tǔ), hence it is said that **excess** leads to thinning **what I do not dominate** and riding upon **what I dominate**.

All these cases involve the **Five Zang** (wǔzàng) **qi** internally invading and merging, thus causing illness, hence termed **excessive proliferation** (qìyín). The remaining cases of **excess** follow the same principle.

Again, if **Liver-Wood** **qi** is deficient (bùzú), it cannot restrain Earth; Earth-**qi**, unchecked, acts arbitrarily, and Wood is oppressed by Earth, hence it is said that the **qi** of what it ought to dominate acts arbitrarily, while the **qi** of what it ought to generate suffers illness. When **Liver-Wood** **qi** is unbalanced, **Lung-Metal** **qi** naturally grows thin, hence it is said that **what I do not dominate** grows thin. However, when Wood-**qi** is unbalanced, Earth and Metal mutually thin each other, and their mutual oppression leads to illness, hence termed **constricted qi** (qìpò). The remaining cases of **deficiency** follow the same principle.

If one carefully observes its time, the **qi** can be anticipated; if one misses the time and observes in reverse, the **Five Treatments** (wǔzhì) are not distinguished, and perverse **qi** internally invades, making even a skilled practitioner powerless.

By **"time"**, it means the time when the **qi** arrives. Observing the **yearly cycle** (nián) begins at the **solar term of Spring Begins** (Lìchūn), observing the **qi** begins at the fixed **Four Seasons' qi** (sìqì), and observing the **daily cycle** (rì) follows the **divinatory days** (hòurì). Thus, it is said: *"If one misses the time and observes in reverse"* (fǎn hòu qí shí), the **Five Treatments** are not distinguished, and perverse **qi** internally invades, making even a skilled practitioner powerless.

The **Sovereign** (Dì) asked: *"Is there any that does not succeed?"* Meaning, is there any **qi** of the **Five Agents** that does not follow in succession?

**Gūbù** (Qíbó) replied: *"The **Heavenly qi** (cāngtiān zhī qì) cannot deviate from its constancy. If the **qi** does not succeed, this is called **constancy's deviation** (bùcháng). **Constancy's deviation** leads to change.*

By **"change"**, it means the alteration of **Heaven's constancy** (tiān cháng).

The **Sovereign** asked: *"How does deviation lead to change?"*

**Gūbù** replied: *"When change arrives, illness ensues. If the **qi** of what it ought to dominate is weak, while the **qi** of what it ought not to dominate is strong, and if it is further compounded by a perverse **qi**, then death follows. Hence, if it is not its due time, the illness is mild; if it is its due time, the illness is severe."*

This means that when **Heaven** (Tiān) distributes its **qi**, it does not exceed the **Five Agents**; humans exist within this **qi**, so how could they not conform to **Heaven's Way** (tiāndào)? When a person's **qi** is disordered, not aligning with **Heaven's constancy**, this is the cause of illness and death. As *The Zuo Tradition* (Zuo Zhuan) says: *"To defy **Heaven** is inauspicious."* This is of the same category.

For example, if it is the **year of Wood** (mù zhí nián), yet **Fire** **qi** arrives, illness will follow two years later. If **Earth** **qi** arrives, illness will follow three years later. If **Metal** **qi** arrives, illness will follow four years later. If **Water** **qi** arrives, illness will follow five years later. When **True qi** (zhēnqì) is deficient and further compounded by perverse **qi**, the **True qi** internally weakens, hence it is said that when **True qi** is deficient and further invaded by perverse **qi**, death follows.

If it is not the **year of the Agent's reign** (wáng zhí nián), yet the **qi** of the **Five Agents** conflicts, the illness will be mild and prolonged, not causing internal injury to the **Spirit-Stores** (shéncáng), hence it is said that if it is not its due time, the illness is mild and enduring.

If it is the **year of the Agent's reign**, then it is prone to perverse **qi**, hence when it is the **Agent's due time**, the illness becomes severe. All **qi** that arrives in the **year of its Agent's reign** readily invites perverse **qi**, hence it is said that if it is not its due time, the illness is mild; if it is its due time, the illness is severe.

*The Comprehensive Evaluation of the Empty and Full Theory* (Tōngpíng xūshí lùn) states: *"If it is not its due time, it generates [illness]; if it is its due time, it leads to death."* By **"due time"**, it means the **year of the Agent's reign**.

The **Sovereign** said: *"Good."*

I have heard that the **Five Agents' qi** combine to form **shapes** (xíng), and through changes, their names are established. As for the **Heavenly** and **Earthly** circulation (yùn) and the **Yin-Yang** transformations (huà), how do they relate to the myriad things—what is few and what is many? *[The newly corrected text states: "From here, the previous Gūbù's question 'Is it not manifest?' (Zhāohū zāi wèn) is detailed. The Yuan Ji's annotation and *The Grand Essentials* (Tài Sù) both lack this, suggesting it may be a supplement by Wang Shi."*

**Gūbù** replied: *"Your question is profound indeed! **Heaven** is vast beyond measure, **Earth** is vast beyond reckoning. The **Great Spirit** (Dà shén) inquires, and I shall outline its principles."*

This means that **Heaven** and **Earth** are vast and cannot be fully measured or grasped by human understanding, and their transformations are profound and subtle—how could one encompass them with mere human thought? The **Great Spirit** inquires, praising the **Sage's** deep understanding, and thus I speak broadly of the **grand framework** (gāngjì).

Grasses grow in **five colors** (wǔsè), and the **Five Colors'** variations** (wǔsè zhī biàn) are countless. Grasses produce **five flavors** (wǔwèi), and the **Five Flavors'** subtleties** (wǔwèi zhī měi) are boundless.

This means that the myriad things of creation, each inheriting different transformations, are such that even the eyes cannot fully perceive their colors and the mouth cannot fully savor their flavors—how much more so could the human heart encompass them all? People's tastes and desires differ, yet each has their own inclinations.

This means that though the variations of colors and flavors are countless, people's tastes and desires are naturally aligned with what their own hearts love, hence it is said that tastes and desires differ, yet each has their own inclinations.

**Heaven** nourishes humans with the **Five Qi** (wǔqì), and **Earth** nourishes humans with the **Five Flavors** (wǔwèi). **Heaven** nourishes humans with the **Five Qi** in this way: **dryness** **qi** (zàoqì) affects the **Liver**, **scorch** **qi** (jiāoqì) affects the **Heart**, **fragrant** **qi** (xiāngqì) affects the **Spleen**, **rancid** **qi** (xīngqì) affects the **Lungs**, and **putrid** **qi** (fǔqì) affects the **Kidneys**.

Earth nourishes humans with the **Five Flavors** (wǔwèi) in this way: **sour** flavor enters the **Liver**, **bitter** flavor enters the **Heart**, **sweet** flavor enters the **Spleen**, **pungent** flavor enters the **Lungs**, and **salty** flavor enters the **Kidneys**.

The **clear yang** transforms into **qi**, ascending to become **Heaven**; the **turbulent yin** congeals into **flavors**, descending to become **Earth**. Hence, **Heaven** nourishes humans with **qi**, while **Earth** nourishes humans with **flavors**.

The *Discourse on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* states: The **clear yang** is **Heaven**, the **turbulent yin** is **Earth**. It further states: **Yang** is **qi**, **yin** is **flavor**.

The **Five Qi** enter through the nose, stored in the **Heart** and **Lungs**, ascending to refine the **Five Colors** (wǔsè) and clarify the **Five Sounds** (wǔshēng). The **Five Flavors** enter through the mouth, stored in the **intestines** and **stomach**, where flavors are retained to nourish the **Five Qi**. When the **Five Qi** harmonize, **vital fluids** (jīnyè) are generated, and **spirit** (shén) naturally arises.

The **Heart** manifests in the **complexion** (miànsè), the **Lungs** govern **sound**, hence the **Five Qi** are stored in the **Heart** and **Lungs**, ascending to refine the **Five Colors** and clarify the **Five Sounds**.

**Qi** is the **mother of fluids** (shuǐmǔ), so flavors are stored in the **intestines** and **stomach**, internally nourishing the **Five Qi**. When the **Five Qi** harmonize and transform, **vital fluids** are generated, and **vital fluids** interact with **qi** to form **spirit-qi** (shénqì), enabling life and propagation.

The **Emperor** asked: How do the **inner manifestations** (zàngxiàng) correspond to this?

**Xiàng** refers to what is visible externally and can be observed. **Gūbó** replied:

The **Heart** is the root of **life**, the abode of **spirit** (shén). Its **luster** (huà) appears in the **face**, its **fullness** (chōng) resides in the **blood vessels** (xuèmài). It is the **supreme yang** within **yang**, harmonizing with **summer qi** (xiàqì).

The **Heart** is the **official of the sovereign**, where **spirit** and **clarity** (shénmíng) emanate. For the **sovereign** is the pivot upon which all things thrive or decline, hence it is said that the **Heart** is the root of **life**, the abode of **spirit**.

**Fire qi** ascends upward, so its **luster** appears in the **face**. The **Heart** nourishes **blood**, its **virtue** (dé) lies in the **blood vessels**, hence its **fullness** resides there. The **Heart** rules over **summer**, its **qi** aligning with the **supreme yang**, for the **supreme yang** dwells within the **fire of summer**, hence it is said to be the **supreme yang** within **yang**, harmonizing with **summer qi**.

The *True Sayings of the Golden Chamber* states: From **dawn** (píngdàn) to **midday**, it is **Heaven’s yang**, the **yang within yang**.

---

The **Liver** is the origin of **extreme exertion** (bìjí), the dwelling of **soul** (hún). Its **luster** appears in the **nails**, its **fullness** resides in the **tendons**. It generates **blood-qi**, its flavor is **sour**, and its color is **blue-green**.

The **Emperor** (of **spring**) is the beginning of **growth**, hence it is said that the **Liver** generates **blood-qi**. The *Discourse on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* states: The **Emperor** generates **wind**, **wind** generates **wood**, and **wood** generates **sour**. The **Liver** aligns with **wood**, hence its flavor is **sour**. It further states: **Spirit** in the **zang** is the **Liver**, in **color** it is **blue-green**. Hence its color is **blue-green**.

For the **minor yang** resides within the **yang** position, ruling over **spring**, hence it is said to be the **yang within yang’s minor yang**, harmonizing with **spring qi**.

The *True Sayings of the Golden Chamber* states: From **dawn** to **midday**, it is **Heaven’s yang**, the **yang within yang**.

The **Newly Corrected Edition** states: Examining the original text by **Quán Yuánqǐ**, as well as *The Canon of the Celestial Stem and Earthly Branch* (*Jǐa-Yǐ Jīng*) and *The Great Essentials* (*Tài Sù*), it reads **"minor yang within yin"**—this should be rendered **"minor yang within yin"**. Further examining **Wang’s** citation of *The True Sayings of the Golden Chamber*, which states: *"From dawn to midday, it is Heaven’s yang, the yang within yang,"* as evidence, it appears **Wang** intended **"minor yang within yang"**. Yet, upon closer inspection of the preceding text—where the **heart** is described as **"major yang within yang"**—**Wang** cites the same passage from dawn to midday as proof. Now, applying this same logic to the **Liver**, he fails to cite *"From cockcrow to dawn, it is Heaven’s yin, the yang within yin,"* as evidence. Thus, **Wang’s** annotation is clearly erroneous, and we should follow **Quán Yuánqǐ’s** original text and *The Canon of the Celestial Stem and Earthly Branch* and *The Great Essentials*, rendering it **"minor yang within yin"** as correct.

The **Spleen**, **Stomach**, **Large Intestine**, **Small Intestine**, **Triple Burner**, and **Bladder** are the origins of the **granaries** and the dwelling of **nutritive qi** (*yíng*), hence they are called **"organs"** (*qì*). They are capable of transforming waste (*zāo pò*), converting flavors, and regulating intake and excretion. All can receive and store, endlessly circulating and transporting—thus they are the origins of the **granaries**, named **"organs"**.

**Nutritive qi** arises from the **middle burner**, where the **Spleen** and **Stomach** reside, hence it is said to be the dwelling of **nutritive qi**. Yet, when water and grain flavors enter the **Spleen** and **Stomach**, the **Spleen** and **Stomach** transform waste while refining their flavors, expelling them through the **Triple Burner** and **Bladder**—thus it is said they *"convert flavors and regulate intake and excretion."*

Its **manifestation** lies in the **four whites of the lips**, its **fullness** in the **muscles**, its flavor **sweet**, its color **yellow**.

The **Newly Corrected Edition** states: These six characters should be omitted, and the forty-character citation from *The Discourse on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* should also be removed, as they were already explained in the preceding section.

This pertains to the category of **extreme yin**, harmonizing with **earth qi**.

The **mouth** is the **orifice** of the **Spleen**, and the **Spleen** governs **muscles and flesh**, hence it is said that its **manifestation** lies in the **four whites of the lips**, its **fullness** in the **muscles**. The **"four whites"** refer to the white flesh at the four corners of the lips.

*The Discourse on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* states: The **center** generates **dampness**, **dampness** generates **earth**, and **earth** generates **sweet**. The **Spleen** corresponds to **earth**, hence its flavor is **sweet**. It further states: In the **zang**, it is the **Spleen**; in **color**, it is **yellow**. Hence its color is **yellow**. The **Spleen** harbors **earth qi**, and **earth** aligns with **extreme yin**, thus it is said this belongs to the category of **extreme yin**, harmonizing with **earth qi**.

*The True Sayings of the Golden Chamber* states: **Extreme yin within yin** is the **Spleen**.

All **eleven zang** organs derive their order from the **Gallbladder**. From the **heart** above to the **Gallbladder** below, they number **eleven**. Yet the **Gallbladder**, being central, upright, and unyielding without private deviation, is thus the standard by which the **eleven zang** are arranged in sequence.

Hence, if the **pulse at the chin** (*rén yíng*) is **onefold** in strength, the illness lies in **minor yang**; **twofold**, in **major yang**; **threefold**, in **yang brightness**; and **fourfold or more**, it is **rebellious yang**. This is the **law of the yang pulses**.

**Minor yang** refers to the **Gallbladder pulse**; **major yang**, to the **Bladder pulse**; and **yang brightness**, to the **Stomach pulse**.

*The Spiritual Pivot* (*Líng Shū*) states: *"If the pulse is **onefold** in agitation, it lies in the **hand’s minor yang**; **twofold**, in the **hand’s major yang**; **threefold**, in the **hand’s yang brightness."* The **hand’s minor yang** is the **Triple Burner pulse**; the **hand’s major yang**, the **Small Intestine pulse**; and the **hand’s yang brightness**, the **Large Intestine pulse**.

**"Onefold"** means the **chin pulse** is **onefold** greater than the **wrist pulse** (*cùn kǒu*); the rest follow the same principle. If it is **fourfold or more**, it is the extreme of **yang excess**, hence **rebellion and resistance** occur, and food cannot enter.

*The Treatise on Correct Principles* (*Zhèng Lǐ Lùn*) states: *"Rebellion leads to vomiting."*

If the **wrist pulse** is **onefold** in strength, the illness lies in **jue yin**; **twofold**, in **minor yin**; **threefold**, in **major yin**; and **fourfold or more**, it is **obstructed yin**. This is the **law of the yin pulses**.

**Jue yin** refers to the **Liver pulse**; **minor yin**, to the **Kidney pulse**; and **major yin**, to the **Spleen pulse**.

*The Spiritual Pivot* states: *"If the pulse is **onefold** in agitation, it lies in the **hand’s jue yin**; **twofold**, in the **hand’s minor yin**; **threefold**, in the **hand’s major yin."* The **hand’s jue yin** is the **Pericardium pulse**; the **hand’s minor yin**, the **Heart pulse**; and the **hand’s major yin**, the **Lung pulse**.

The principle of **"fold"** follows that of the **yang pulses**. If it is **fourfold or more**, it is the extreme of **yin excess**, hence **obstruction** occurs, and **urine cannot pass**.

*The Treatise on Correct Principles* states: *"Obstruction means inability to urinate."* **"Urine"** refers to **small urination**.

If both the **chin pulse** and the **wrist pulse** are **fourfold or more** in strength, it is **obstructed rebellion**. The **obstructed rebellion pulse** is **weak**, unable to reach the **Heaven-Earth vital essence**, and thus death ensues.

**"Both strong"** means both exceed the ordinary pulse by **fourfold**. Things cannot endure prolonged excess; when pushed to the extreme, they decline and decay. Hence, if unable to reach the **Heaven-Earth vital essence**, death follows.

*The Spiritual Pivot* states: *"When yin and yang are both excessive, they cannot nourish each other, hence it is called **obstructed rebellion**. The **obstructed rebellion** condition means death before its natural term."*

The **Newly Corrected Edition** states: **"Weak"** (*yíng*) should be rendered **"full"** (*yíng*).

The pulse being **fourfold or more** in strength is not **weak** (*yíng*), but rather **excessive to the extreme**. The ancient text uses **weak** (*yíng*) interchangeably with **full** (*yíng*).
