*Huangdi Neijing Suwen* **Supplementary Commentary**, Volume Ten:
Tang **Grand Marshal** *Qixianzi* **Wang Bing’s** **sequential annotations**, **reexamined** by Song **Grand Secretary** *Zhishimi* **Lin Yi** and colleagues, **revised** by Song **Clerk of the Board of War** and **Superintendent of Agriculture** *Sun Zhao* for textual errors.

**Chapter on the Formation of the Five Viscera** **Newly Revised Commentary** reads:

According to this chapter, it is titled *Chapter on the Formation of the Five Viscera* and does not mention *Treatise* (论), for this chapter directly records the matters of the five viscera’s formation, without the question-and-answer discourse found elsewhere. Hence, it does not mention *Treatise*. Later sections that do not mention *Treatise* follow this same principle.

The **heart’s** **affiliation with vessels** (合脉), for **fire-qi** is dynamic and restless, and vessels share this quality of uniformity. The heart’s **visceral correspondence** (藏应) aligns with **fire**, hence its affiliation with vessels.

Its **manifestation of luster** (荣色) is **red**, for fire ascends in brilliance, and its color is red. Hence, its luster appears on the **face** in **red hue**.

**Newly Revised Commentary** states: It is unclear why Wang Bing restricts the **face’s** **luster** to **red**. Generally, all colors visible on the face are manifestations of the heart’s luster, not confined solely to red.

Its **visceral dominion** (主) is the **kidneys**, for the heart **stands in awe** (畏) of the kidneys. **Fire** is subdued by **water**, and **water** is the **kidneys’** **official organ** (官), hence the heart stands in awe of the kidneys.

The **lungs’** **affiliation with skin** (合皮), for **metal-qi** is firm and resolute, and skin shares this quality. The lungs’ visceral correspondence aligns with **metal**, hence their affiliation with skin.

Its **manifestation of luster** is **hair** (毛), for hair attaches to skin and **leather**, hence its external manifestation.

Its **visceral dominion** is the **heart**, for **metal** is subdued by **fire**, and **fire** is the **heart’s** official organ, hence the lungs stand in awe of the heart.

The **liver’s** **affiliation with sinews** (筋), for **wood’s** nature is flexible and straight, and sinews share this quality. The liver’s visceral correspondence aligns with **wood**, hence its affiliation with sinews.

Its **manifestation of luster** is **nails** (爪), for nails are the **remnant** (余) of sinews, hence their external manifestation.

Its **visceral dominion** is the **lungs**, for **wood** is subdued by **metal**, and **metal** is the **lungs’** official organ, hence the liver stands in awe of the lungs.

The **spleen’s** **affiliation with flesh** (合肉), for **earth’s** nature is yielding and thick, and flesh shares this quality. The spleen’s visceral correspondence aligns with **earth**, hence its affiliation with flesh.

Its **manifestation of luster** is the **lips** (唇), for the **mouth** is the spleen’s official organ, hence its luster appears on the lips. The **lips** refer to the **four boundaries** (四际) of **white** hue, not **red**.

Its **visceral dominion** is the **liver**, for **earth** is subdued by **wood**, and **wood** is the **liver’s** official organ, hence the spleen stands in awe of the liver.

The **kidneys’** **affiliation with bones** (合骨), for **water’s** nature is fluid and moist, and **essence-qi** (精气) shares this quality. Bones conduct **marrow** (髓) and **essence**, hence their affiliation with bones.

Its **manifestation of luster** is **hair** (发), for the **brain** is the **sea of marrow** (髓海), and the **kidneys’ qi** governs it, hence its external manifestation in hair.

Its **visceral dominion** is the **spleen**, for **water** is subdued by **earth**, and **earth** is the **spleen’s** official organ, hence the kidneys stand in awe of the spleen.

Thus, excessive consumption of **salt** (咸) causes **vessels to congeal and weep** (脉凝泣) and **complexion to alter** (变色). The heart corresponds with **pork** (豚), and its luster is color. **Salt** benefits the **kidneys**, overpowering the **heart**; when the heart cannot prevail, vessels congeal and weep, and the **facial hue shifts** (颜色变易).

Excessive consumption of **bitter** (苦) causes **skin to wither** (皮槁) and **hair to fall out** (毛拔). The lungs correspond with **skin**, and its luster is hair. **Bitter** benefits the **heart**, overpowering the **lungs**; when the lungs cannot prevail, skin becomes **withered and dry** (枯槁), and hair is shed.

Excessive consumption of **acrid** (辛) causes **sinews to tighten** (筋急) and **nails to wither** (爪枯). The liver corresponds with **sinews**, and its luster is nails. **Acrid** benefits the **lungs**, overpowering the **liver**; when the liver cannot prevail, sinews grow taut and nails dry and wither.

Excessive consumption of **sour** (酸) causes **flesh to develop nodules** (肉胝胜) and **lips to peel** (唇揭). The spleen corresponds with **flesh**, and its luster is the lips. **Sour** benefits the **liver**, overpowering the **spleen**; when the spleen cannot prevail, flesh develops **nodules and excess** (胝胜), and the **lips’ skin peels upward** (揭举). **Nodules** (胝) are pronounced *dīng nǐ qiè*. **Peeling** (揭) is pronounced *cè jiù qiè*.

Excessive consumption of **sweet** (甘) causes **bones to ache** (骨痛) and **hair to fall out** (发落).
The **kidneys** correspond with **bones**, and their luster is **hair**. **Sweet** benefits the **spleen**, overpowering the **kidneys**; when the kidneys cannot prevail, bones ache and hair falls out.
This is how the **Five Flavors** cause harm.

When the **Five Flavors** enter the mouth, they are distributed to the **intestines and stomach**, nourishing the **Five Viscera** internally. Each has its own nourishment and desires; when desires are indulged, they mutually harm one another. Thus, it is said:

The **heart** desires **bitter** (苦), for it aligns with **Fire**.
The **lungs** desire **acrid** (辛), for they align with **Metal**.
The **liver** desires **sour** (酸), for it aligns with **Wood**.
The **spleen** desires **sweet** (甘), for it aligns with **Earth**.
The **kidneys** desire **salty** (咸), for they align with **Water**.
This is how the **Five Flavors** align with the **Five Viscera**.
Each should follow its desire and return to its scent.

The **qi** of the **Five Viscera**—
*(New annotation: According to Quan Yuanqi’s text, this section on the Five Flavors’ alignment belongs with the preceding passage. The *Tai Su* agrees.)*

If the **complexion** appears **green like fresh grass**, death is near.
*(兹, zī—"harsh," referring to the green of newly sprouting grass.)*
If it is **yellow like a persimmon’s rind**, death is near.
If it is **black like coal**, death is near.
*(矣, yǐ—"coal." 良, liáng—"coal," pronounced like "tái.")*
If it is **red like congealed foul blood**, death is near.
*(恤血, xùxuè—"putrid, clotted blood," dark red-black. 恤, xù—pronounced *fāng bēi qiè*.)*
If it is **white like withered bone**, death is near.
*(White and dry, like the whiteness of parched bone.)*
These are the **Five Colors** signaling death.
When the **viscera decay**, these deathly hues appear.
The *San Bu Jiu Hou Lun* states: *"When the Five Viscera decay, their colors must wither (夭)."* *(夭, yāo—"to die young," here meaning "to perish.")* This is what is meant.

If the **complexion** is **green like emerald feathers**, life is near.
If it is **red like a parrot’s crest**, life is near.
If it is **yellow like a crab’s belly**, life is near.
If it is **white like pig fat**, life is near.
If it is **black like crow’s feathers**, life is near.
These are the **Five Colors** signaling life.
All are signs of **luster and moisture**; though their hues may be pleasing, if they appear **dim and swollen**, it is even better.

Thus, it is further said:
Life in the **heart** appears as if wrapped in **white silk with vermilion**.
Life in the **lungs** appears as if wrapped in **white silk with red**.
Life in the **liver** appears as if wrapped in **white silk with green**.
Life in the **spleen** appears as if wrapped in **white silk with yellow like *kuàliú* fruit**.
Life in the **kidneys** appears as if wrapped in **white silk with purple**.
This is the **true** appearance of life’s **external luster**.
*(缟, gǎo—"white silk." 给, jǐ—"thin green silk.")*
The **Five Viscera’s** colors and flavors correspond as follows:
**White** aligns with the **lungs** and **acrid**.
**Red** aligns with the **heart** and **bitter**.
**Green** aligns with the **liver** and **sour**.
**Yellow** aligns with the **spleen** and **sweet**.
**Black** aligns with the **kidneys** and **salty**.
Each aligns with its respective **viscus** in color and flavor.

Thus:
**White** aligns with **skin**,
**Red** with **veins**,
**Green** with **sinews**,
**Yellow** with **flesh**,
**Black** with **bone**.
Each aligns with the **qi** of the **viscus** it nourishes.

All **veins** belong to the **eyes**.
*(Veins are the repositories of blood. The *Xuanming Wuqì Piān* states: "Prolonged gazing harms blood." Thus, it is clear that all veins belong to the eyes.)*
*(New annotation: According to Huangfu Shian, the *Jiǔ Juàn* states: "The heart houses veins; veins harbor the spirit. The spirit illuminates the body, hence it is said they belong to the eyes.")*

All **marrow** belongs to the **brain**.
*(The brain is the "sea of marrow," hence all marrow belongs to it.)*

All **sinews** belong to the **joints**.
*(Sinews, where qi is firm and gathered, all converge between the bones and joints.)*
The *Xuanming Wuqì Piān* states: "Excessive walking harms sinews." Thus, it is clear that all sinews belong to the joints.

All **blood** belongs to the **heart**.
*(Blood resides within the veins and belongs to the heart.)*
The *Bā Zhèng Shénmíng Lùn* states: "Blood and qi are the essence of humanity." Since the spirit is the heart’s master, thus all blood belongs to the heart.

All **qi** belongs to the **lungs**.
*(The lungs store and govern qi.)*

This is the **morning and evening rhythm** of the **Four Limbs and Eight Orifices**.
*(Orifices are the small gatherings of flesh. The Eight Orifices refer to the elbows and knees. Thus, qi, blood, sinews, and veins mutually wax and wane, creating the rhythm of morning and evening.)*

When a person lies down, **blood returns to the liver**.
*(The liver stores blood; the heart circulates it. When a person moves, blood flows through the channels; when still, it returns to the liver’s storage.)*
Why? Because the liver governs the **Sea of Blood**.
The liver receives blood and thus can see.
*(The eyes are the liver’s organ, so the liver receives blood and enables vision.)*
The **feet** receive blood and thus can walk.
*(Qi moves, and blood flows; thus the feet receive blood and enable walking.)*
The **palms** receive blood and thus can grasp.
*(For the function of grasping.)*
The **fingers** receive blood and thus can pick up.
*(For the function of receiving.)*
Since **blood and qi** are the **essence of humanity**, those who receive blood can all function.

If **wind blows over a sleeping person**, blood congealing on the **skin** causes **numbness** (痹).
*(痹, bì—"numbness," pronounced *jīng* or *jūn*.)*
If it congeals in the **veins**, it causes **stagnation** (泣).
*(泣, qì—"stagnation," meaning blood does not flow smoothly.)*
If it congeals in the **feet**, it causes **syncope** (厥).
*(厥, jué—"syncope," meaning the feet reverse their function.)*
These three conditions occur when blood flows but cannot return to its **channels**.
*(Channels are the pathways for blood flow, the great conduits.)*
*(隧, suì—"conduit," pronounced *suì*.)*

Humans have **Twelve Great Valleys**.
*(The great conduits’ gatherings are called "Great Valleys." The Twelve Divisions refer to the twelve meridian pathways.)*

There are **354 minor orifices**, twelve fewer than the total.
*(The minor gatherings of the collaterals are called "minor orifices." If counting 365 minor collaterals, excluding the twelve major junctions, it should be 353. The text states 354 due to a scribal error in transcribing "three" as "four.")*
*(New annotation: According to alternate texts and Quan Yuanqi’s version, the *Tai Su* uses "关" [junctions] instead of "俞" [acupoints].)*

This is where the **Defensive Qi** lingers and stagnates, and where **pathogenic Qi** takes residence.
When Defensive Qi is full and flowing, pathogenic Qi cannot settle.
When Defensive Qi is deficient and stagnates, pathogenic Qi invades—hence the saying, *"where pathogenic Qi takes residence."*

Use **acupuncture and lithotherapy** to purge it.
*"Purge"* (绿) means to **leach and expel** along the meridians.

When pathogenic Qi resides where Defensive Qi stagnates, needling the **collaterals and valleys** will cause it to **leach and flow away** with the pulse.

At the **onset of illness**, the **Five Phases** mark the cycle.
*"Five Phases"* refers to the **Five Zang meridians** as the framework for life and death.

To discern its origin, first establish its **root**—
*"Root"* (母) means the **Seasonal Sovereign Qi** of the time.
First establish the Seasonal Sovereign Qi, then seek the **pathogenic and righteous Qi**.

The so-called *"Five Phases"* are the **Five Meridians**—
That is, the **Five Zang meridians**.

Thus, **headaches and vertex disorders**, with **lower emptiness and upper fullness**, stem from **Foot Minor Yin and Foot Major Yang**; severe cases penetrate the **kidneys**.
**Foot Minor Yin** is the **kidney meridian**.
**Foot Major Yang** is the **bladder meridian**.

The **bladder meridian** arises at the **inner canthus**, ascends the forehead to the vertex;
Its **branching collaterals** descend from the vertex to the **upper ear corner**;
Its **direct course** enters the vertex, networks the brain, descends to branch at the nape, follows the shoulder blade, enters the **paravertebral region**, reaches the **lumbar center**, descends to network the **kidneys**, and connects to the **bladder**.

Since the **kidneys are weak** and cannot draw **Major Yang Qi**, the result is **headaches and vertex disorders**.
When the **meridian disease worsens**, it invades the **Zang**.

**Sudden vertigo, blurred vision, and violent shaking**, with **lower fullness and upper emptiness**, stem from **Foot Minor Yang and Foot Jue Yin**; severe cases penetrate the **liver**.
*"Sudden"* (徇) is **rapid**.
*"Blurred"* (蒙) is **obscured**.
When **vision suddenly fails and shakes violently**, it is **acute illness**.
*"Blindness and deafness"* refers to **gradual illness**.
**Foot Minor Yang** is the **gallbladder meridian**.
**Foot Jue Yin** is the **liver meridian**.

The **Jue Yin meridian** originates from the lower abdomen, ascends beside the stomach, connecting to the liver and networking the gallbladder, piercing the diaphragm, spreading across the ribs, following the posterior aspect of the throat, and entering the **occipital region** (*顽颗*). It then ascends to emerge at the forehead and converges with the **Governor meridian** at the vertex.

Its divergent branch descends from the eye system to encircle the lower cheek.

The **Foot Minor Yang meridian** begins at the **outer canthus** (*目锐毗*), ascends to meet the **corner of the head** (*头角*), descends behind the ear, follows the neck, and enters the **suprascapular fossa** (*缺盆*). Its divergent branch, arising from behind the ear, enters the ear; another branch diverges from the outer canthus, descends to the **mandible** (*顾*), joins the **masseter muscle** (*颊车*), descends the neck, and merges with the pathways below the suprascapular fossa in the chest, piercing the diaphragm, networking the liver, and connecting to the gallbladder.

Now, due to **insufficient qi**, these diseases arise.
○The newly corrected version states: According to Wang's annotation, *"徇蒙"* means "sudden obscuration of vision," but the meaning remains unclear. *"徇蒙"* likely refers to **violent shaking of the eye and facial regions**, accompanied by **frequent, severe spasms** and **dimness**#4. Additionally, the Minor Yang meridian's descent below the forehead (*下额*), in the *Jia Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), is recorded as *"下颂"* (*descending to the mandible*).

**Occipital region** (*顽颗*):
- *顽* (Hu Lang cut): **occipital bone**
- *颗* (Su Lang cut): **base of the skull**

「**Systematic Connections:**
- *系* (Xī, pronounced *Xī-Dì* cut): **to connect/bind**
- *额* (é): **forehead** (pronounced *quán*)

**Abdominal distension and tightness**, affecting the *jì* (diaphragm region) and flanks, with **inverted rebellion**—where **qi rises from below to assault the eyes**—involving the **Foot Taiyin** and **Foot Yangming** meridians.
- *朕* (zhèn): **the flanks (above the ribs)**
- **Inverted rebellion (下厥上冒)**: **Qi ascending rebelliously from below, overwhelming the eyes.**
- **Foot Taiyin**: **Spleen meridian** (*脾豚*)
- **Foot Yangming**: **Stomach meridian** (*胃脉*)

**Foot Taiyin Meridian** arises from the **inner anterior thigh (股内前康)**, enters the abdomen, connects to the spleen, networks the stomach, and ascends to the *jì* (diaphragm region).
**Foot Yangming Meridian** originates at the **nose**, converges at the **philtrum (频)**, descends along the **external nose**, networks the **chin and jaw (颐颌)**, passes through the **throat**, enters the suprascapular fossa, connects to the stomach, and networks the spleen. Its **direct course** descends from the suprascapular fossa to the **inner thigh (乳内康)**, then to the **inguinal region (侠齐)**, entering the **gas street (气街)**. Its **branching pathway** arises from the **stomach’s lower orifice**, follows the **abdominal flank (腹裹)**, reaching the **gas street** and merging below the **pubic bone (髑)**. Thus, these diseases arise.

- *肚* (dù, *qù-yú* cut): **abdomen**
- *骸* (hái, pronounced *yú*): **pubic bone**

**Coughing with upward-rising qi**, where **inverted rebellion lodges in the chest**, involves the **Hand Yangming** and **Hand Taiyin** meridians.
- **Hand Yangming**: **Large Intestine meridian** (*大肠脉*)
- **Hand Taiyin**: **Lung meridian** (*肺豚*)

**Hand Yangming Meridian** descends from the **anterior edge of the shoulder (肩髑前廉)**, ascends to emerge above the **vertebral junction (柱骨之会)**, enters the suprascapular fossa, networks the lungs, descends to the *jì* (diaphragm region), and connects to the large intestine.
**Hand Taiyin Meridian** originates from the **middle burner (中焦)**, descends to network the large intestine, ascends along the **stomach’s orifice**, reaches the *jì* (diaphragm region), connects to the lungs, and from the lungs’ **system (系)**, emerges horizontally beneath the armpit. Thus, **coughing with upward-rising qi** lodges in the chest.

○ **Newly Corrected Version states:** According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), *"厥"* is annotated as **#5 disease**.

**Restlessness of the heart and headache**, where the disease resides in the *jì* (diaphragm region), involves the **Hand Jùyáng** and **Hand Shàoyin** meridians.
- **Hand Jùyáng**: **Small Intestine meridian** (*小肠脉*)
- **Hand Shàoyin**: **Heart meridian** (*心脉*)」

The **Hand Jùyáng Meridian** (Small Intestine) descends from the shoulder, enters the *quēpén* (supraclavicular fossa), networks the heart, follows the throat, descends to the *jì* (diaphragm region), reaches the stomach, and belongs to the small intestine. Its branching divergence ascends from the *quēpén*, follows the neck and cheek, and reaches the *ruìbì* (outer canthus of the eye).

The **Hand Shàoyin Meridian** (Heart) originates from the heart, emerges to belong to the heart’s **system (系)**, descends to the *jì* (diaphragm region), and networks the small intestine.

Thus, **restlessness of the heart and headache** reside in the chest (**#6 disease**).

○ **Newly Corrected Version states:** According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), *"chest pain, distended branches, and pain radiating to the waist and back"* are symptoms of the **Hand Shàoyin** and **Hand Tàiyáng** meridians.

Now, the **pulse’s** qualities—**great, small, smooth, rough, floating, and deep**—can be distinguished by the fingers.
- **Small pulse** is fine and minute,
- **Great pulse** is full and expansive,
- **Smooth pulse** flows effortlessly,
- **Rough pulse** moves with difficulty,
- **Floating pulse** appears beneath the fingers,
- **Deep pulse** is only felt upon pressing.
Even if the pulse manifests in countless varied forms, **skilled hands and keen insight** can still distinguish them.

The **five viscera’s symbols** can be inferred through analogy.
- **Symbol (象)** refers to **qi manifestations**.
Though the five viscera are hidden and unseen, their **qi manifestations, nature, and functions** can still be inferred through analogical reasoning.

How so?
- The liver’s symbol is **wood**, manifesting in **curvature and straightness**.
- The heart’s symbol is **fire**, manifesting in **flame and ascent**.
- The spleen’s symbol is **earth**, embodying **stability and tranquility**.
- The lungs’ symbol is **metal**, embodying **rigidity and centrality**.
- The kidneys’ symbol is **water**, embodying **moisture and descent**.

These are the **primary indications of the viscera’s essence**. Their **qi manifestations** vary with circumstances, and those that align with analogous patterns can be inferred accordingly.

The **five viscera’s resonance** can be discerned through perception.
- **Resonance (音)** refers to the **five tones**.
The liver’s tone is *角 (gū)*, the heart’s is *征 (zhēng)*, the spleen’s is *宫 (gōng)*, the lungs’ is *商 (shāng)*, and the kidneys’ is *羽 (yǔ)*—these are their **constant responses**.
Yet when their **mutual overcoming and defeat** occur, and the tones are **absent or excessive**, even those with **acute hearing and keen minds** can still perceive and recognize them through **intuition (#7)**.

The **five colors’ subtle diagnosis** can be observed with the eyes.
- **Color (色)** refers to **hue**.
The liver’s color is **green**, the heart’s is **red**, the spleen’s is **yellow**, the lungs’ is **white**, and the kidneys’ is **black**—these are their **constant hues**.
Yet when their **qi manifestations interact**, and subtle signs of **auspiciousness or inauspiciousness** appear, even those with **clear vision and profound wisdom** can **divine and discern** them.

Those who **harmonize pulse and color** can achieve **complete accuracy**.

- **Green hue** corresponds to a **tight pulse**,
- **Red hue** corresponds to a **hook-shaped pulse**,
- **Yellow hue** corresponds to a **leathery pulse**,
- **White hue** corresponds to a **hair-like pulse**,
- **Black hue** corresponds to a **firm pulse**—these are their **constant color-pulse correlations**.
Yet when **cross-referencing discrepancies and congruities**, and **determining success or failure**, one must **examine with precision and without doubt**, achieving **complete accuracy in every case**. The **diseases of pulse and color** will be exemplified in the following explanations.

When the **red pulse** arrives,
it is **gasping and firm**—diagnosis states: *"There is stagnant qi in the chest, periodically disrupting digestion, named **heart stagnation (心痹)**."*
- **Gasping (喘)** refers to a pulse arriving like sudden **shortness of breath**.
The **viscera reside high**—when diseased, the pulse manifests as **gasping**.
Thus, the **heart and lungs (two viscera #8)** are uniquely mentioned.

**Gasping** indicates **insufficient heart qi**, while **firmness** indicates **excess pathogenic qi**.
The **heart meridian** originates from the **chest**, hence stagnant qi in the chest disrupts digestion.

- **Stagnation (积)** refers to **pathogenic qi accumulation**.
- **Stagnation (痹)** refers to **visceral qi failing to circulate freely**.
One contracts this from **external injury**, or when **overthinking weakens the heart**, allowing **evil to follow (#9)**.
- **Overthinking weakens the heart**, so **external evils seize the opportunity** and settle there.

When the **white pulse** arrives,
it is **gasping and floating**, with **upper insufficiency and lower excess**, **startled by fright**, and there is **stagnant qi in the chest**—**gasping** indicates **insufficiency**, **floating** indicates **lung emptiness**, and **lung insufficiency** is called **heart emptiness**. When the upper is empty, the lower becomes **full and solid**.

Because of its **insufficiency**, one is prone to **fright**, and **qi stagnates in the chest**.
Yet when the **pulse is gasping and floating**, it is **lung (#10) self-insufficiency**.
When **gasping and empty**, it is **heart qi ascending to overwhelm the lungs**, causing **lung heat** and **qi unable to nourish**—named **lung stagnation (#11)**, with **external cold and heat symptoms**.
One contracts this from **excessive drinking leading to internal injury**.
- **Alcohol’s bitter, dry nature** benefits the heart internally, and **drunkenness followed by sexual excess** causes **heart qi to overwhelm the lungs**.

When the **green pulse** arrives,
it is **long and springy from left to right**, with **stagnant qi beneath the heart and in the arms**, named **liver stagnation (肝痹)**.
- **Long and springy pulse** indicates **tightness and tension**; **tension** signifies **cold qi**, and **central dampness** makes it **springy**.
The **liver governs the flanks and ribs**, and is **near the heart**, so **qi accumulates beneath the heart**, also affecting the **head**.
The *Zhènglǐ Lùnmíng Yì* (《正理论脉名例》) states: *"A tight pulse resembles cutting a silk thread."*
- **Springy pulse** means the pulse **rebounds against the fingers from left to right**.
One contracts this from **cold and dampness**, similar to the **law of hernia (疝)**—with **waist pain, cold limbs, and tight head pulse (#12)**.
- **Tight pulse (#13)** indicates **cold**, and **long pulse** indicates **dampness**.
Hernia is also caused by **cold and dampness**, hence *"similar to the law of hernia."*

The **liver pulse** originates from the **foot**, ascends to the **head**, and emerges at the **forehead**, meeting the **Governor Vessel (#14)** at the **apex**.
Thus, when diseased, the **limbs become cold** and the **head aches**.
- **Cold (清)** is also **limbs becoming cold (玲)**.
- **Hernia (疝)** is pronounced *shuān* (所晏切).

When the **yellow pulse** arrives,
it is **great and empty**, with **stagnant qi in the abdomen** and **#15 stagnant pathogenic qi (厥气)**, named **stagnant hernia (厥疝)**.
- **Great pulse** indicates **excess qi**, while **empty pulse** indicates **emptiness**.
When both **qi and emptiness** are present, **spleen qi accumulates in the abdomen**.
If **kidney qi reverses upward**, then it is **stagnant hernia**.
If **kidney qi does not ascend**, then **both are empty**, and **spleen qi accumulates (#15)**.

In **women**, the symptoms are similar—one contracts this when **sudden exertion causes limbs to sweat** and **exposure to wind**.
- **Women’s symptoms are similar**, meaning they share the same **indications**.
Wind **communicates with the liver**, so when **sweating and exposed to wind**, **spleen qi accumulates in the lower abdomen**, causing **bilateral distension (腹两丁)**.

When the **black pulse** arrives,
it is **firm and great above**, with **stagnant qi in the lower abdomen and genitals**, named **kidney stagnation (肾痹)**.

「上」 refers to the **cun-kou pulse** [radial artery at the wrist].
The **kidney governs the lower burner**, so **qi accumulates in the lower abdomen and genitals**.

One contracts this by **bathing in cold water and then going outdoors**.
Moisture injures the lower burner, naturally affecting the **kidney**—how much more so when bathing in cold water and then exposed? How could one avoid illness?

The *Ling Shu Jing* states:
*"Below the midpoint of the body is where moisture resides."*

In general, **five abnormal pulse-color combinations** are signs of **auspicious prognosis**:
- **Face yellow, eyes green**
- **Face yellow, eyes red**
- **Face yellow, eyes white**
- **Face yellow, eyes black**

These are all **not fatal**, for they indicate the presence of **stomach qi**—thus, life is preserved.

**Annotation:** The newly corrected text states that the *Jia-Yi Jing* lacks the term *"奇豚"* (strange pulse).

However, the following **five abnormal pulse-color combinations** are **fatal**:
- **Face green, eyes red** #16
- **Face red, eyes white**
- **Face green, eyes black**
- **Face black, eyes white**
- **Face red, eyes green**

These are all fatal because they lack **yellow**, meaning **stomach qi is absent**.
The **stomach qi** is the foundation of life—
thus, without yellow, death is certain.

**Chapter on the Distinct Functions of the Five Vísceras**
The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I have heard that certain **way-adept practitioners** (方士) claim that the brain and marrow are **vísceras** (藏), while others say the intestines and stomach are **vísceras**, or even **palaces** (府). Their views contradict one another, yet all insist they are correct. I do not know their **Dao/Way** (道), and I wish to hear their reasoning."*

**Annotation:** *Way-adept practitioners (方士)* refers to those who understand the principles of **Daoist** medicine and cosmology. The text describes the conflicting interpretations regarding the classification of organs as **vísceras** (藏) or **palaces** (府), though such distinctions are already addressed in the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon* (黄帝内经).

Qìbó replied: *"The brain, marrow, bones, blood vessels, gallbladder, and the **uterus** (女子胞) are six entities born from **earth-qi** (地气). They are all stored in the **yīn** (阴) and manifest the attributes of earth, hence they are called **vísceras** (藏) and not **palaces** (府). They are designated as the **‘strange and constant palaces’** (奇恒之府).

The brain merges with marrow, bones, and blood vessels—though named a **palace** (府), it truly aligns with the **‘spiritual storehouses’** (神藏). The gallbladder combines with the liver yet differs from the six **palaces** in its transmission and transformation. The **uterus** (胞), though involved in reception and discharge, receives and stores **precious vital essences** (精气) and discharges them to form the body’s features. When these features discharge, it signifies the culmination of transformation. However, its reception and discharge differ from the six **palaces**, thus it is called a **víscera** (藏) and not a **palace** (府). It is also known as the **‘strange and enduring palace’** (奇怛之府).

The stomach, large intestine, small intestine, **triple burner** (三焦), and bladder are five entities born from **heaven-qi** (天气). Their nature mirrors heaven, hence they are called **palaces** (府) and not **vísceras** (藏). They receive the **impure qi** (浊气) of the five **vísceras**, and are designated as the **‘palaces of transmission and transformation’** (传化之府). These cannot retain substances long—they are merely conduits for transformation and discharge. When water and grain enter the body, their **dregs and waste** (糟粕) undergo transformation and are expelled. They cannot be stored within, only transformed and discharged. Thus, they are called the **‘palaces of transmission and transformation’** (传化之府). The **‘gateway of vital essences’** (魄门) also serves the five **vísceras**, yet water and grain cannot be stored within it.

**Annotation:** *The **‘gateway of vital essences’** (魄门)* refers to the **anal orifice** (肛#1), which internally connects with the lungs.

When it receives transformed substances, it acts as a conduit for the five **vísceras**. Yet water and grain cannot be stored within it.

The five **vísceras** (五藏) store **precious vital essences** (精气) and do not discharge them, hence they are **full** (满) yet cannot be **solid** (实). **Precious vital essences** (精气) constitute **fullness** (满), while water and grain constitute **solidity** (实). Since the five **vísceras** only store **precious vital essences**, they are **full** yet cannot be **solid**.

**Newly corrected text:** *According to the full text of Quán Yuánqǐ (全元起) and the *Jia-Yi Jing* (甲乙经) and *Tài Sū* (太素), **precious vital essences** (精气) should read **‘spiritual vital essences’** (精神).*

The six **palaces** (六府) transmit and transform substances but do not store them, hence they are **solid** (实) yet cannot be **full** (满). This is because they do not store **precious vital essences** (精气), only receiving water and grain.

The reason for this is as follows: when water and grain enter the mouth, the stomach becomes **solid** (实) while the intestines become **empty** (虚)—since they have not yet descended. When food descends, the intestines become **solid** (实) while the stomach becomes **empty** (虚). Thus, it is said that the **palaces** are **solid** yet cannot be **full**, while the **vísceras** are **full** yet cannot be **solid**.

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does the **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口) uniquely govern the five **vísceras**?"*

**Annotation:** *The **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口)* refers to the **‘cubit inch’** (寸), also known as the **‘pulse gateway’** (脉口). The **cubit inch** (寸) is located at the **‘hand’s fish际’** (手鱼际) behind the **‘same-body cubit’** (同身寸), one **cubit** (寸) from the wrist. It is where one can observe the **‘flourishing and decline of vital qi’** (气之盛衰) and the **‘movement and stillness of the pulse’** (脉之动静).

Qìbó replied: *"The stomach is the **‘sea of water and grain’** (水谷之海), the great source of the six **palaces**. The human body has four **‘seas’** (海), and the **‘sea of water and grain’** (水谷之海) is one of them. Once water and grain are received by the stomach, they nourish the four sides of the body. Since the stomach is the origin of all transmission and transformation, it is the great source of the six **palaces**.

The five **flavors** (五味) enter the mouth and are stored in the stomach, where they nourish the **‘qi of the five vísceras’** (五藏气). The **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口) is also part of the **hand’s greater yīn** (手太阴) channel.

**Annotation:** *The **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口)* is where the pulse of the **hand’s greater yīn** (手太阴) channel can be observed.

Thus, the **‘qi and flavors’** (气味) of the five **vísceras** and six **palaces** all originate from the stomach and manifest at the **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口).

The **Dao/Way of nourishing vital qi** (荣气之道) is that **‘internalized grain becomes solid’** (内谷为实).

**Newly corrected text:** *Upon closer examination, this note originates from the *Língshū* (灵枢), with **‘solid’** (实) corrected to **‘treasure’** (宝).*

When grain enters and is received by the stomach, **vital qi** (气) is transmitted to the lungs. The **‘specialized precious vital essences’** (精专) follow the lung’s **vital qi** (气) and travel to the **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口), hence it is said that their changes manifest at the **‘gateway of vital essences’** (气口).

**Newly corrected text:** *According to the full text of Quán Yuánqǐ (全元起), **‘out’** (出) should read **‘enter’** (入).*

Thus, the five **vital qis** (五气) enter the nostrils and are stored in the heart and lungs. When the heart and lungs are diseased, the nostrils become obstructed.

In treating illness, one must always examine its **‘root’** (下), adjust the pulse, observe the patient’s **‘intentions and will’** (志意), and align with their disease.

**Annotation:** *The **‘root’** (下)* refers to the **‘feasibility of treatment as seen below the eyes’** (目下所见可否).

To regulate the **‘flourishing and decline of the pulse’** (脉之盈虚), to observe the **‘correctness or deviation of intentions and will’** (志意之邪正), and to determine the **‘appropriateness of treatment based on the depth, shallowness, or prognosis of the disease’** (病深浅成败之宜), one must then adhere to the principles of treatment.

**Newly corrected text:** *According to the *Tài Sū* (太素), this should read: **‘In treating illness, one must examine both its upper and lower aspects, adjust the pulse and observe, and consider the patient’s intentions and will, along with their disease’s capacity for recovery’** (凡治病必察其上下，适其脉候，观其志意，与其病能).*

Those who are **‘obsessed with ghosts and spirits’** (拘於鬼神) cannot be spoken to about **‘the ultimate virtue/power’** (至德). When **‘intentions and will are deviant’** (志意邪), they favor **‘dissecting and praying’** (析祷). Speaking of **‘ultimate virtue/power’** (至德) would conflict with their beliefs, hence they cannot be addressed on this matter.

Those who **‘abhor acupuncture and lithotomy’** (恶於针石) cannot be spoken to about **‘the ultimate skill’** (至巧). If they detest acupuncture and lithotomy, then **‘skill cannot be applied’** (巧不得施), hence it is said they cannot be spoken to about **‘ultimate skill’** (至巧).

**Annotation:** *Abhor (恶), pronounced wū.*

If a patient **‘refuses treatment’** (病不许治), their illness will not be cured, and treatment will be futile. If the patient’s heart **‘does not allow treatment’** (不许人治之), they will surely die again. If one **‘forcibly treats’** (强为治), the treatment will also fail, hence it is said that the treatment will be futile.
