**Pulse Essentials Discourse**
The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How should one examine the pulses?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"The method of pulse examination is best performed at dawn, when the **yin qi** has not yet stirred, the **yang qi** has not yet dispersed, food and drink have not been consumed, the **channels** are not yet full, the **collaterals** are evenly harmonized, and the circulation of **qi** and blood remains unperturbed. Thus, one may then diagnose the **aberrant pulses**."*

Stirred: *"Stirred and descending in weakness."*
Dispersed: *"Dispersed and spreading outward."*
Aberrant: *"Pulses that differ from the usual patterns."*

○Newly corrected text states: *"According to *The Classic of Pulses* and *The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions*, the term 'aberrant pulses' should be **‘aberrant (this is incorrect)’**, not **‘over (this is incorrect)’**."*

Wang’s annotation: *"Yin qi has not yet stirred"* refers to its descending in weakness.
According to *The Golden Chamber’s True Utterances*: *"From dawn until noon, the **yang** of Heaven, the **yang** within **yang**, is the purest **yang** of the day. Thus, dawn is the time when **yin qi** has not yet stirred—how could there be a meaning of descending in weakness?"*
Examining the pulse’s movement and stillness to observe **clarity and brightness**, inspecting the five colors, and discerning the **dharma** of the five **zàng organs**—whether they are in excess or deficiency—the **fù organs**’s strength or weakness, and the **form’s** waxing or waning, one may thereby correlate and determine the division between life and death.

Examining: *"Using the fingers to press close to the **precise brightness** (穴)."*
**Precise brightness** (精明): A **point**’s name.
Located in the **Bright Hall** (明堂) beside the two eyes’ inner corners, the **Blue#1** point, so called because it is near the eyes.
*"The pulse’s rise and fall, its abundance or scarcity, are observed through the **precise brightness**’s **qi** and color, while examining the **zàng** and **fù** organs for excess or deficiency, correlating their patterns to determine the division between life and death."*

*"The pulse is the repository of blood—*
**Repository** (府): *to gather*.
*"All variations in blood’s abundance or scarcity are manifest within the **channels**."*

Thus, *The Discourse on Needle Techniques* states: *"When the pulse is full, the blood is full; when the pulse is empty, the blood is empty—this is the norm. If it deviates from this, there is **disease**."*

Therefore, if the pulse is:
Long, then **qi** is harmonized and health prevails;
Short#3, then **qi** is deficient and **disease** arises;
Rapid, then there is **heat** and the mind is troubled;
Overfull, then **evil forces** are rampant and **disease** advances.

Long pulses come and go with length;
Short pulses come and go with brevity;
Rapid pulses come and go with urgency and speed;
Overfull pulses come and go with a broad, distended rhythm.

When the pulse is strong at the **upper** (inch) position, **qi** is high;
○Newly corrected text states: *"According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s version, ‘high’ (高) should be ‘**li**’ (鬲)."*
When the pulse is strong at the **lower** position, **qi** is bloated;
When the pulse is **intermittent**, **qi** is diminished;
When the pulse is **smooth**, **qi** is scarce;
○Newly corrected text states: *"According to *The Great Essentials*, ‘smooth’ (滑) should be ‘**fine**’ (细)."*
When the pulse is **rough**, there is **heart pain**.
**Upper** (上): Refers to the **inch** position.

The **lower** position refers to the **cubit** region.
**Stenosis** refers to a pulse that is full and distended.
An **intermittent pulse** moves and then stops abruptly, unable to return on its own.
A **fine pulse** moves like a dandelion seed.
A **rough pulse** is stiff and unyielding in its coming and going.

A **turbulent pulse** arrives in surges like a gushing spring—when such a pulse appears, the disease advances and the complexion grows wan. A **fading pulse** departs gradually like a snapped string—this is a sign of death.
**Chaotic turbulence** refers to a pulse whose **qi** is in disarray alone.
**Sudden collapse** refers to a pulse that arrives taut and large, firm yet prolonged.
**Like a gushing spring** means the pulse flows ceaselessly, rising but never receding.
**Fading** means it lingers faintly, barely perceptible to the hand.
**Like a snapped string** means the pulse abruptly ceases, as though a string had been severed.

If the disease progresses daily and the complexion grows foul, such pulses are all **ominous signs of death**.
○Newly corrected text states: According to *The Canon of Medicine in Categories (Jia-Yi Jing)* and *The Pulse Classic (Mai Jing)*, it reads: *"When the pulse is **discordant and turbulent**, arriving like a gushing spring, the disease advances and becomes perilous; when it **wanes and drifts** like a snapped string, death follows."*

The **luster of the five colors** is the **qi’s** manifestation.
The refined essence of the five **qi** manifests above as the five colors, transforming within the luminous clarity.
*The Treatise on the Six Nodal Phases and the Symbolic Organs* states:
*"Heaven nourishes man with the five **qi**; the five **qi** enter through the nose and are stored in the heart and lungs, ascending to refine the five colors."*

Thus, one must discern the five colors with clarity.
**Red** should be like silk-wrapped cinnabar, not like ochre;
**White** should be like goose down, not like salt.
○Newly corrected text states: According to *The Canon of Medicine in Categories*, it reads: *"White should be like the luster of a white jade, not like the inner (unpolished) side."*
*The Great Essentials* presents this twice.
**Green** should be like the sheen of a dark jade, not like indigo;
**Yellow** should be like silk-wrapped realgar, not like yellow soil;
**Black** should be like deep lacquered color, not like ashen gray.
○Newly corrected text states: According to *The Canon of Medicine in Categories*, it reads: *"Like charcoal color."*

When these **debased hues**—ochre, salt-white, indigo, yellow soil, or ashen gray—appear, they are signs of **qi’s** decay, and thus life is short.

The **luminous clarity** is what allows one to perceive all things, distinguish white from black, and judge length from shortness. To invert long for short, white for black—this is the **virtue/power** of clarity failing. Beware of such errors.
Such confusion arises only when **luminous clarity** has waned.

The Five **Zàng** [1] are the guardians of the **center** [2]. Within the body’s form, the Five **Shén** [3] reside where these guardians hold their place. This is how one **clearly observes** the Five **Zàng** [1].
○Newly corrected text states: According to *The Canon of Medicine in Categories* (*Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*) and *The Great Simplicity* (*Tài Sù*), **"guard"** is translated as **"Fǔ"** [4].

When the **center** is **replete** with **Zàng** [1], and **qi** [5] prevails over **injury/fear** [6], the voice sounds as if speaking from within a chamber—this is the **center**’s **dampness** [7].
The **center** refers to the abdomen. **Replete** means **qi** is abundant. **Zàng** refers to the **lungs** [8] storing **qi** [5]. **Qi** prevailing means it overcomes normal **breathing** [9], causing panting and irregular respiration. When abdominal **qi** is excessive, the **lungs**’s storage is full, **qi** overcomes breathing, and one is prone to **injury/fear** [6], the voice fails to emerge as if confined in a chamber—this is all due to **dampness** in the abdomen.

If speech is faint, and one must pause the whole day before resuming, this is **depletion of qi** [10].
If the voice is weak and thin, with speech halting and unable to continue, then severe **depletion of qi** [10] is evident.

When **clothing** is not properly **enveloped** [11], and **speech** oscillates between **good and evil** [12], without regard for **proximity or distance** [13], this is the **disorder of luminous clarity and spirit** [14].
When the **granaries** [15] are **not securely stored** [16], this is the **failure of the gates and doors** [17].
**Granaries** refers to the **spleen and stomach** [18]. **Gates and doors** refers to the **Pò Men** [19].
*The Secret Essentials of the Mysterious Pivot* (*Líng Lán Mì Diǎn Lùn*) states: The **spleen and stomach** are the officials of the **granaries**.
*The Treatise on the Separate Functions of the Five Zàng* (*Wǔ Zàng Bié Lùn*) states: The **Pò Men** also serves as a messenger for the Five **Zàng**, preventing water and grain from being stored for too long. The **Pò Men** is the **anus**.
**Wanting** refers to **restraint of urination**. If **water and grain** [20] do not cease, this is the **bladder’s failure to store**.
**Water and grain** refers to the **flow of the anterior yin** [21].

**Retaining the guardians** leads to life; **losing the guardians** leads to death.
When these **granaries** fail to store, **qi** prevails over **injury/fear** [6], **clothing** is not properly **enveloped**, and **water and grain** [20] do not cease, it is because **spirit and qi** retain their proper guardianship, leading to life, or lose it, leading to death.

How does one know when **spirit and qi** fail to **guard**?
If **clothing** is not properly **enveloped**, and **speech** oscillates between **good and evil** [12] without regard for **proximity or distance** [13], this is the **evidence of disorder**.
Severe **disorder** means **spirit and qi** no longer **guard** the **Zàng**.

The Five **Zàng** are the **body’s strength** [22].
When the **Zàng** are **settled**, the **spirit guards**; when the **spirit guards**, the **body is strong**—thus they are called the **body’s strength**.

The **head** is the **Fǔ** of **luminous clarity** [23]. If the head tilts and **vision deepens**, the **spirit is about to be depleted**.
The **back** is the **Fǔ** of the **chest** [24]. If the back **bends** and the shoulders **sag**, the **Fǔ** is about to **fail**.
The **waist** is the **Fǔ** of the **kidneys** [25]. If **turning and swaying** [26] are impossible, the **kidneys** are about to **wear out**.
The **knees** are the **Fǔ** of **sinews** [27]. If **flexion and extension** are impossible, and one **stumbles** while walking,
○Newly corrected text states: According to another version, **"stumbles"** is written as **"bows"**; *The Great Simplicity* (*Tài Sù*) uses **"stumbles"**.
the **sinews** are about to **wear out**.
The **bones** are the **Fǔ** of **bone marrow** [28]. If one cannot stand for long, and **walking causes trembling** [29], the **bones** are about to **wear out**.
All are called **Fǔ** because of where they **reside** and what they **govern**.
**Retaining strength** leads to life; **losing strength** leads to death.
**Strength** refers to **qi** in the **center** being **robust and firm** to **settle and guard**.
**Gū Bó** [30] said:
○Newly corrected text states: It appears that **"Gū Bó said"** is missing the preceding **question** before it.

---
[1] **Zàng** (藏) – *Viscera* (in TCM, the five major organs: heart, lungs, liver, spleen, kidneys).
[2] **Center** (中) – *Central region of the body*, often referring to the abdomen or core.
[3] **Shén** (神) – *Spirit/essence* (in TCM, the vital spirit associated with each organ).
[4] **Fǔ** (府) – *Palaces* (in TCM, the six hollow organs: stomach, intestines, bladder, gallbladder, lungs, and heart, contrasted with the five solid Zàng).
[5] **Qi** (气) – *Vital energy* (in TCM).
[6] **Injury/fear** (伤恐) – *Fear and injury* (emotional and physical disturbances).
[7] **Dampness** (湿) – *Dampness/phlegm* (in TCM, a pathological condition).
[8] **Lungs** (肺藏) – *Lungs* (here, the lungs as a Zàng organ storing qi).
[9] **Breathing** (呼吸) – *Respiration*.
[10] **Depletion of qi** (夺气) – *Qi depletion* (a severe loss of vital energy).
[11] **Clothing** / **Enveloped** (衣被不敛) – *Clothing and bedding are not properly gathered* (a sign of disordered spirit).
[12] **Good and evil** (善恶) – *Moral and improper speech*.
[13] **Proximity or distance** (亲疏) – *Near and far* (lack of respect or discretion).
[14] **Disorder of luminous clarity and spirit** (神明之乱) – *Disorder of the spirit and luminous clarity*.
[15] **Granaries** (仓) – *Storage organs* (spleen and stomach).
[16] **Not securely stored** (凛不藏) – *Not properly contained* (a sign of spleen/stomach dysfunction).
[17] **Failure of the gates and doors** (门户不要) – *Failure of the Pò Men* (a sign of kidney dysfunction).
[18] **Spleen and stomach** (脾胃) – *Spleen and stomach* (TCM organs).
[19] **Pò Men** (魄门) – *Anus* (here, a metaphor for the kidney’s role in retaining essence).
[20] **Water and grain** (水谷) – *Water and food* (here, urine and stool).
[21] **Flow of the anterior yin** (前阴之流注) – *Urine flow*.
[22] **Body’s strength** (身之强) – *Physical vitality*.
[23] **Luminous clarity** (精明) – *Spiritual clarity/acuity*.
[24] **Chest** (胸中) – *Thoracic region*.
[25] **Kidneys** (肾) – *Kidneys* (TCM organs).
[26] **Turning and swaying** (转摇) – *Rotational movement*.
[27] **Sinews** (筋) – *Tendons*.
[28] **Bone marrow** (髓) – *Bone marrow* (in TCM, the essence stored in bones).
[29] **Trembling** (振掉) – *Shaking/trembling* (a sign of bone weakness).
[30] **Gū Bó** (岐伯) – *A legendary figure in TCM, often attributed as the speaker of classical medical teachings*.

「The reversal of the four seasons—when there is excess, it becomes *jing* (essence); when deficient, it becomes *consumption* (xiao). When the body exceeds its proper state, deficiency becomes *jing*; when deficient, excess becomes *consumption*. When yin and yang fail to correspond, the disease is called *guan ge* (blockage).

The pulse reflects these excesses and deficiencies: all deficiencies deplete blood and *qi*; all excesses allow pathogenic *qi* to overwhelm *jing*. When yin and yang fail to harmonize, they cannot nourish each other, hence *guan ge*.

The Emperor asked:
*"How does the pulse move with the four seasons? How can one know the location of a disease? How can one know its transformations? How can one know when disease shifts from internal to external—or vice versa? May I inquire about these five matters?"*
*(He sought to understand the correspondence of the seasons and the harmony of yin and yang.)*

Gū Bó replied:
*"The pulse moves with the four seasons, revealing the disease’s location, its transformations—though the text’s structure here is somewhat disjointed. The later discussion of internal and external disease does not fully align. Let me explain how this aligns with the grand cycles of Heaven.*

Within the six directions—above, below, and the four cardinal points—the transformations of Heaven and Earth, the responses of yin and yang: the warmth of spring becomes the heat of summer; the urgency of autumn becomes the fury of winter. The four seasonal shifts move the pulse upward and downward.

Spring’s pulse is soft and weak, light and slippery—like the motion of a compass’s edge, balanced within and without, hence *‘spring corresponds to the compass.’*
Summer’s pulse is surging and great, slippery and rapid—like a carpenter’s square, upright and level, hence *‘summer corresponds to the square.’*
Autumn’s pulse is fine and sparse, light and rough—like a balance scale, evenly poised, hence *‘autumn corresponds to the balance.’*
Winter’s pulse is firm and solid, with a subtle slipperiness—like a weighing scale’s counterweight, descending beyond the balance, hence *‘winter corresponds to the counterweight.’*

Thus, from autumn’s balance to winter’s counterweight, the pulse’s highs and lows differ accordingly. This reflects the varying *qi* of yin and yang.

Therefore, forty-five days after the winter solstice, yang *qi* subtly ascends while yin *qi* subtly descends; forty-five days after the summer solstice, yin *qi* subtly ascends while yang *qi* subtly descends. Yin and yang follow their appointed times, and the pulse aligns with them. When their rhythms diverge—like the pulse’s divisions—one can foretell the time of death.

By observing the standards of yin and yang’s ascent and descent, one knows the sequential changes of the channels; by discerning the failures of seasonal *qi*, one knows the cycles of *qi* and blood merging and separating. When these cycles are precise, one can determine the exact time of death.

The pulse holds subtle mysteries—one must examine it closely. Its examination begins with yin and yang, tracing their ascent and descent to uncover the profound functions of the channels’ *qi*. Thus, one must not neglect this study, for yin and yang are its foundational principles.

The origins of these principles stem from the Five Phases, which generate in measured degrees, fitting the seasons’ due order. *(This explains how the pulse’s examination aligns with Heaven and Earth’s responses.)*

To investigate excesses and deficiencies, one must assess their forms against the seasons’ proper *qi*. *(Here, ‘due’ may also be read as ‘numbers,’ aligning with cosmic order.)*

To restore balance—writing off excess, supplementing deficiency—is to follow Heaven and Earth’s natural way. For Heaven and Earth’s method is to reduce excess and replenish deficiency; this is the law of Heaven and Earth. When writing off excess and supplementing deficiency is precise, the same applies to regulating *qi*.

By grasping the fundamental principle, one can know life and death.

Thus, sound harmonizes with the Five Tones, color with the Five Phases, and the pulse with yin and yang. *(Sound corresponds to the five musical notes; color to the five elemental hues; the pulse reveals the ebb and flow of cold and heat.)*

When yin is excessive, one dreams of crossing vast waters in fear; *(water embodies yin, hence the dream of water and dread.)*
When yang is excessive, one dreams of great fires burning; *(fire embodies yang, hence the dream of flames and scorching.)*
When both yin and yang are excessive, one dreams of mutual destruction and injury; *(this mirrors the clashing of opposing forces.)*
When upper *qi* is excessive, one dreams of flying; *(ascending *qi* manifests as flight.)*
When lower *qi* is excessive, one dreams of falling; *(descending *qi* manifests as a fall.)*
After extreme overeating, one dreams of giving; *(internal excess prompts generosity.)*
After extreme hunger, one dreams of taking; *(internal deficiency prompts acquisition.)*
When liver *qi* is excessive, one dreams of anger; *(the liver’s emotion is anger.)*
When lung *qi* is excessive, one dreams of weeping. *(The lung’s sound is sorrowful, hence weeping in dreams.)*

*(Note: The following lines on heart, spleen, and kidney dreams appear misplaced here; they belong to the *Lingshu* [Spiritual Pivot] and are fully recorded in the *Jia-Yi Jing* [ABC Canon].)*

When worms proliferate, one dreams of gathering crowds;»

When worms within the body are numerous, one dreams of gathering crowds;
When long worms are numerous, one dreams of mutual assaults and injuries.
When long worms move, inner tranquility is disrupted;
Inner unrest disturbs the spirit, causing dreams of this nature.

○*(New校正 states: These two lines also seem misplaced here and should belong to another text’s omitted passage.)*

Thus, pulse-taking has its principles: emptiness and stillness are its safeguards.
The earlier mention of pulse response reveals the origin of pulse-taking.
Yet the true method of pulse-taking lies in:
Clearing the mind and calming the will—
Only thus can one preserve the balance of fullness and emptiness without error.
○*(New校正 notes: In the *Jia-Yi Jing* [ABC Canon], 保 [preserve] is written as 宝 [treasure].)*

In spring, the pulse floats like fish swimming on waves;
Though it rises, it has not yet fully ascended.
In summer, it lies at the skin, effervescent with abundance—
A boundless vitality, mirroring nature’s excess.
Effervescent, here meaning level and overflowing.
When *yang qi* is at its peak, the pulse too reflects nature’s abundance,
Easier to grasp and more robust.

In autumn, it descends beneath the skin, as the *mian-chong* worms prepare to leave;
Following the gradual decline of *yang qi*, hence "descends beneath the skin."
How do we know *yang qi* is declining?
The *mian-chong* worms are about to retreat into concealment.
In winter, it rests at the bones, the *mian-chong* worms encircling tightly,
And the virtuous person stays indoors.
"At the bones" refers to the pulse being deep and hidden.
"Encircling tightly" means *yang qi* is withdrawn and stored.
"Virtuous person stays indoors" is a human analogy.
Thus it is said:
Those who understand the inner pulse examine and record its changes,
Those who understand the inner pulse, meaning those who know the pulse’s *qi*,
Thus they examine and establish its guiding principles.
Those who understand the outer pulse complete its cycles.
Those who understand the outer pulse, meaning those who know the physical signs,
Thus they use the five colors to complete and begin anew.
These six principles are the fundamental laws of pulse-taking.
By observing these six, one can then discern the pulse’s transformations.

○*(New校正 states: These preceding lines detail the Yellow Emperor’s inquiry on how the pulse moves in the four seasons.)*

When the heart pulse beats firmly and long, one suffers from a disease where the tongue curls and speech fails;
Beating, meaning it strikes against the hand.
All pulses that beat firmly and long indicate excessive mental strain and extreme depletion of the pulse’s *qi*.
The heart-hand *shao-yin* pulse rises from the heart’s membrane, ascends alongside the throat,
Hence the tongue curls short and speech becomes impossible.
When the pulse is effervescent and scattered, one suffers from dissipation—
The pulse’s *qi* disperses and the body’s fire weakens.
All pulses that are effervescent and scattered indicate *qi* excess and blood deficiency.
Dissipation, meaning the *qi* scatters away.
Weakened, meaning the *qi* encircles and fails to sustain.
The pulse’s *qi*, like a ring’s circulation, when the fire’s season is past,
Naturally dissipates and weakens.
○*(New校正 notes: In the *Jia-Yi Jing* [ABC Canon], 渴 [thirst] is written instead of 环 [ring].)*

When the lung pulse beats firmly and long, one suffers from spitting blood;
Lung *qi* depletion to its extreme causes the vessels to reverse,
And vessel reversal leads to blood leakage—
Hence blood is spat out.
When the pulse is effervescent and scattered, one suffers from *guan-han* (flooding sweats),
Even to the point where sweat no longer disperses and evaporates.
Sweat leaks from the *xuan-fu* (mysterious palace), fluids surge and overflow,
Cold water floods and washes, the skin tightens and sweat is trapped—
Thus the flooding sweat remains, and one no longer sees scattered evaporation.
Flooding, here meaning flooding and washing.
This often occurs in extreme summer heat.
○*(New校正 states: The following lines on each organ’s color are omitted for the heart and lung, suggesting missing text.)*

When the liver pulse beats firmly and long, its color is not green,
One suffers from *diao-ruo* (collapse-like) attacks;
Because blood resides in the lower ribs, it causes wheezing and reverse breathing.
All pulses that show the organ’s *qi* yet fail to match its color
Indicate that the disease does not originate from within—
Rather, it is an external affliction overcoming the body.
The liver’s stored pulse is upright and long,
Hence it is said that when its color is not green,
One suffers from *diao-ruo* (collapse-like) attacks.
The liver governs the two lower ribs,
Hence "because blood resides in the lower ribs."
The liver’s *jue-yin* pulse spreads across the ribs,
Follows the throat’s posterior path;
Its branches, further diverging, pass from the liver to pierce the *ge* (diaphragm),
And ascend to the lungs.
Now, if blood gathers in the lower ribs,
It forces the blood-*qi* to ascend and press against the lungs,
Hence the wheezing and reverse breathing.
When the pulse is effervescent and scattered with a luster,
One suffers from *yi-yin* (overflowing drink)—
Overflowing drink means violent thirst and excessive drinking,
And fluids easily seep into the muscles, skin, intestines, and stomach.
A floating, lustrous complexion is the sign of internal dampness,
And blood deficiency with internal dampness means fluids are not metabolized—
Hence it is said one will suffer from overflowing drink.
The fluids overflow and seep, hence they easily enter the muscles, skin, intestines, and stomach.
○*(New校正 notes: In the *Jia-Yi Jing* [ABC Canon], 溢 [overflow] is written instead of 易 [easily].)*

When the stomach pulse beats firmly and long, its color is red,
One suffers from *zhe-bi* (bent thigh)—
The stomach’s *qi* is depleted, redness appears as the heart’s fire rescues it,
The heart’s nature mirrors fire, hence the red color.
The stomach’s *yang-ming* pulse descends from *qi-chong* (gastric surge),
Passes beneath the spleen, reaching *fu-tu* (hidden rabbit)—
Hence when the spleen is diseased, the thigh feels bent.
When the pulse is steady and scattered, one suffers from *shi-bi* (food stagnation pain).
Pain, here meaning discomfort.
The stomach’s *yang-ming* pulse, with its branches,
Descends from *da-ying* (great welcome) to *ren-ying* (human welcome),
Follows the throat’s posterior path into the *que-pen* (missing basin),
Descends to the *ge* (diaphragm) and connects to the stomach, linking with the spleen—
Hence when food stagnates, pain arises and the *qi* does not disperse.
○*(New校正 states: Though it defines 痹 [pain] as discomfort, the meaning remains unclear.)*

When the spleen pulse beats firmly and long, its color is yellow,
One suffers from shortness of breath;
The spleen’s depletion leaves the lungs unsustained, and the lungs govern breath—
Hence the shortness of breath.
When the pulse is effervescent and scattered with no luster,
One suffers from swelling in the lower leg—
Like water’s appearance.
A floating, lustrous complexion is the sign of dampness,
And without moisture, it is said like water’s appearance.
The spleen’s *tai-yin* pulse rises from the inner anterior ankle,
Ascends to the inner knee, follows the lower leg’s posterior path,
Exits before the *jue-yin* (intermediate *yin*) region,
Ascends along the inner thigh to enter the abdomen—
Hence when the spleen is diseased, the lower leg swells.

When the kidney pulse beats firmly and long, its color is yellow and red,
One suffers from *zhe-yao* (bent waist)—
The yellow-red hue indicates the heart and spleen are drying the kidney,
And the kidney receives external *yang*, hence the waist feels bent.
The waist is the kidney’s domain,
Thus the disease manifests in the center.

「When the pulse is deep yet scattered, it indicates a deficiency of blood—
So severe that it may never return.
The kidney governs water, producing and transforming *jin-ye* (essence-fluid),
But now the kidney-*qi* fails to transform, hence the deficiency of blood,
Until it reaches a state where it cannot be replenished.

The Yellow Emperor said: The newly revised text states:
*"To elaborate on the Yellow Emperor’s question regarding the recovery through counteracting excesses,"*
This is taken from *Yuan Qi’s* original in the *Tang Ye* (Decoction) chapter.

When the pulse of the heart is found to be **urgent** (*jìngjí*),
What disease does this signify?
How does the disease manifest?

**Gui Bo** replied: The disease is called **heart hernia** (*xīn zhuàn*),
And there will be a palpable mass in the lower abdomen.
The heart is the *mao* (masculine) **zang** (viscera),
Its *qi* corresponds to *yang*,
But now the pulse is cold in nature, hence the hernia.
All pulses that are **tense and urgent** (*jìngjí*) are signs of **cold**.

*Form* here refers to the **manifestation of the disease**.

The Yellow Emperor said: How can this be explained?
**Gui Bo** replied: The heart is the *mao* (masculine) **zang**,
And the small intestine serves as its **minister** (*shǐ*).
Thus it is said that a mass will appear in the lower abdomen.
The lower abdomen is the small intestine’s domain.
The *Ling Lan Mi Dian Lun* states:
*"The small intestine is the organ that receives and distributes."*

Because it receives and distributes, the mass resides within.
The Yellow Emperor said: When the pulse of the stomach is examined,
How does the disease manifest?
**Gui Bo** replied: A **stomach pulse** that is **full** (*shí*) causes distension,
A **stomach pulse** that is **empty** (*xū*) causes diarrhea.
When the pulse is **full**, the *qi* is in excess, hence distension and fullness;
When the pulse is **empty**, the *qi* is insufficient, hence diarrhea.

*The newly revised text states:*
*"This elaborates on the Yellow Emperor’s prior inquiry about the location of the disease."*

The Yellow Emperor said: What is meant by *"disease that has formed and then changes"*?

Gui Bo replied:
*"The **Wind** transforms into **Cold and Heat**;
*The *Generations of Vital Qi and Its Celestial Connection* states:*
'It arises from exposure to **dew and wind**,
thus generating **Cold and Heat**.'
Hence, **Wind** transforms into **Cold and Heat**.*

**Zhàng** transforms into **consumptive wasting** (*xiāozhòng*).
*Zhàng* refers to **damp-heat**.
When **damp-heat** accumulates within, it thus alters into **consumptive wasting**.
The signs of **consumptive wasting** are: one eats well yet remains thin.

*The newly revised text states:*
'This elaborates on the prior inquiry to the Yellow Emperor: how does the disease transform?'

The Yellow Emperor said: What is meant by *"disease that has formed and then changes"*?
Gui Bo replied: **Stiffness and flaccidity** (*tānzhòng*), **muscle atrophy** (*jīnrèn*), **tendon contractions and bone pain** (*jiǎnluán gǔtòng*), these are all from what?
*An*, what is this?
Speaking of how they arise.

Gui Bo replied: This is **swelling from Cold-qi** (*hánqì zhī zhòng*), a variation of the **Eight Winds**.
The **Eight Winds** are the winds from the **Eight Directions**.
Yet **swelling and flaccidity** arise from injury by the **winds from the Southeast and Southwest**;
**Tendon contractions and bone pain** arise from injury by the **winds from the Northeast and North**.

*The *Spirit Pivot Classic* states:*
'When **Wind** comes from the **Northeast**, it is called **Infant Wind** (*yīng'ér fēng*), and when it injures a person, it manifests externally in the **tendons and joints**.'
'When **Wind** comes from the **Southeast**, it is called **Weak Wind** (*ruòfēng*), and when it injures a person, it manifests externally in the **muscles**.'
'When **Wind** comes from the **Southwest**, it is called **Plotting Wind** (*móufēng*), and when it injures a person, it manifests externally in the **flesh**.'
'When **Wind** comes from the **North**, it is called **Great Rigid Wind** (*dàgāng fēng*), and when it injures a person, it manifests externally in the **bones**.'

From these **Four Winds**' variations, the **Three Diseases** arise, hence the subsequent inquiry corresponds to this.

The Yellow Emperor said: How should they be treated?
Gui Bo replied: These are diseases of the **Four Seasons**,
and they should be treated by **counteracting their prevailing influences** (*shìng*), thus achieving recovery.
*Shìng* means **conquering and overcoming**.
As in **Metal conquers Wood**, **Wood conquers Earth**, **Earth conquers Water**, **Water conquers Fire**, **Fire conquers Metal**.
This is the principle of **mutual overcoming**.

The Yellow Emperor said: When there are **pre-existing diseases** (*gùbìng*) causing the **Five Zàng** to move,
and further injuring the **pulse and complexion** (*mài sè*),
how can one discern whether the disease is **chronic** (*jiǔ*) or **acute** (*bào*)?

Gui Bo replied: Your inquiry is thorough indeed.
If the **pulse is fine** (*xiǎo*) and the **complexion is not diminished** (*sè bù duó*), it is a **new disease** (*xīnbìng*).
The **vitality remains strong** (*shén yóu qiáng*).

If the **pulse is not diminished** but the **complexion is diminished**, this is a **chronic disease** (*jiǔbìng*).
The **vitality is sustained** while **pathogenic forces** (*xié*) overwhelm the **qi**.

If the **pulse and the Five Colors** are both diminished, this is a **chronic disease**.
The **vitality and qi** are both declining.

If the **pulse and the Five Colors** are neither diminished, this is a **new disease**.
The **vitality and qi** are both strong.

When the **Liver** and **Kidney** pulses arrive simultaneously,
their **complexion** is **sallow and red** (*cāng chì*),
it indicates **injury from pathogenic forces** (*huǐshāng*).
If **blood is not yet visible**, it means the **pathogenic forces have not yet manifested**.
If **blood is already visible**, it means **dampness** (*shī*) is like **Water** (*shuǐ*) flooding the abdomen.

*Why is this so?*
Because the **Liver**'s pulse is **sallow**, the **Heart**'s pulse is **red**,
and when the **Heart**'s pulse appears, it should be **robust** (*hóng*).
The **Kidney**'s pulse should appear when the **complexion is black** (*sè hēi*).
Now, the **Kidney**'s pulse arrives, yet the **complexion is red** instead—
hence, it is due to **injury from pathogenic forces**,
and **blood has not yet manifested**.

If **blood is already visible**, then it is **damp-qi** and **Water** accumulating in the abdomen.

The pulse within the *cùn* (寸) and the two sides of the *chǐ* (尺) indicates the *jì xié* (季胁).

The *cùn* is the region within the *chǐzé* (尺泽) point.
The two sides refer to the external aspects of the *chǐ* (尺) on each side.
Since *jì xié* (季胁) is near the **Kidney**, the *chǐ* (尺) governs it,
thus the pulse within the *cùn* (寸) and the two sides of the *chǐ* (尺) indicates the *jì xié* (季胁).

The external side of the *chǐ* (尺) is used to diagnose the **Kidney**,
and the internal side of the *chǐ* (尺) is used to diagnose conditions within the abdomen.
The external side of the *chǐ* (尺) refers to its external aspect,
and the internal side of the *chǐ* (尺) refers to its internal aspect.
Below the external side of the *chǐ* (尺) on both sides are the *jì xié* (季胁) divisions,
above the *jì xié* (季胁) are the **Kidney** divisions,
and within the *jì xié* (季胁) are the divisions of the abdomen.

On the *chǐ* (尺) above:
The left external side diagnoses the **Liver**,
and the internal side diagnoses the *gé* (鬲).
The **Liver** governs the *gé* (鬲), which is the *gé* (鬲) itself.

The right external side diagnoses the **Stomach**,
and the internal side diagnoses the **Spleen**.
The **Spleen** resides centrally, so it is diagnosed from the internal side.
The **Stomach** is the *shì* (市), so it is diagnosed from the external side.
Above the *chǐ* (尺) above:
The right external side diagnoses the **Lung**,
and the internal side diagnoses the chest’s central region.
Since the **Lung**’s lobes hang externally, it is diagnosed from the external side.
The chest’s central region governs the *qìguǎn* (气管), so it is diagnosed from the internal side.

The left external side diagnoses the **Heart**,
and the internal side diagnoses the *tánzhōng* (膻中).
The **Heart** governs the *gé* (鬲) within the chest,
and the *tánzhōng* (膻中) is the *qìhǎi* (气海), where the voice originates.
*Newly corrected version*: It is detailed in Wang’s text that the *tánzhōng* (膻中) refers to the *ài* (隘).
This is likely an error; the previous context suggests otherwise.

For diagnosis, the front is examined first, and the back is examined afterward.
The upper-front refers to the left *cùnkǒu* (寸口).
The lower-front refers to the chest’s anterior region, including the *qìhǎi* (气海) and the *qìhǎi* (气海) itself.
The upper-back refers to the right *cùnkǒu* (寸口).
The lower-back refers to the chest’s posterior region, including the back and the *qìguǎn* (气管).

The uppermost region diagnoses matters of the chest and throat,
while the lowermost region diagnoses the lower abdomen, lumbar spine, thighs, knees,
and issues extending through the legs to the feet.
The uppermost region reaches the *yújì* (鱼际) point,
while the lowermost region refers to the pulse’s movements at the end of the *chǐ* (尺).

The lower abdomen is the *bāo* (胞, bladder).
The movements of *qi* (气) in the lumbar spine, thighs, knees, and central leg,
as well as their connections and locations, are all diagnosed by examining their nearness or distance.
This discerns their good or evil nature.

If the pulse is **coarse and large** (*cūdà*), it indicates **deficient Yin** and **excessive Yang**,
resulting in **heat within the body** (*rèzhōng*).
Coarse and large refers to a **robust and expansive pulse** (*mài hóngdà*).
A robust pulse signifies heat, hence **heat within the body**.

If the pulse **arrives swiftly and departs slowly** (*láijíqùxú*), with **fullness above and emptiness below** (*shàngshíxiàxū*),
it indicates **syncope and vertigo** (*juéxiānjì*).
If the pulse **arrives slowly and departs swiftly** (*láixúqùjí*), with **emptiness above and fullness below** (*shàngxūxiàshí*),
it indicates **evil wind** (*èfēng*).
This is also a pulse condition.
Thus, when **evil wind** occurs within the body,
it is due to **excessive Yang**,
because the pulse is **empty above** (*shàngxū*), hence **excessive Yang**.

If the pulse is **deep, fine, and rapid** (*chénxìshuò*) in both sides of the *chǐ* (尺),
it indicates **Kidney’s *shàoyīn* (少阴) syncope** (*shàoyīn jué*).
If the pulse in the *chǐ* (尺) is **deep, fine, and rapid** (*chénxìshuò*),
it is due to the **Kidney’s *shàoyīn* (少阴) *qi* (气) in reverse** (*nì*).
Why?
Because the *chǐ* (尺) pulse should not appear rapid (*shuò*).
If it is rapid, it is called syncope (*jué*).
If the pulse is **deep, fine, and rapid** (*chénxìshuò*) on both sides of the *chǐ* (尺),
it refers to the **Kidney’s *shàoyīn* (少阴) *qi* (气)**.

If the pulse is **fine, deep, and scattered** (*xìchénsàn*), it indicates **cold and heat** (*hánrè*).
If the pulse is **floating and scattered** (*fú sàn*), it indicates **chest collapse** (*xiōngpū*).
A floating pulse signifies **emptiness** (*xū*),
and scattered indicates **deficient *qi* (气)** (*bùzú*).
When *qi* (气) is empty and blood is deficient, it causes **dizziness and collapse** (*tóuxuàn ér pūdǎo*).
The *xiōng* (胸) is pronounced as *shùn* (顺).

If the pulse is **floating but not rapid** (*fú ér bùzào*), it is all in the **Yang meridians** (*yángmài*).
This indicates **heat**.
If the pulse is **rapid** (*zào*), the disease is in the **hand Yang meridians** (*shǒuyángmài*).
This refers to the general principle.
If the pulse is merely **floating but not rapid** (*fú ér bùzào*),
the disease is in the **foot Yang meridians** (*zúyángmài*).
Hence it is said: If the pulse is **rapid** (*zào*), the disease is in the **hand** (*shǒu*).
**Yang** represents **fire-qi**, hence **heat**.

If the pulse is **fine and deep** (*xìchén*), it is all in the **Yin meridians** (*yīnmài*).
This indicates **bone pain** (*gǔtòng*).
If the pulse is **static** (*jìng*), the disease is in the **foot** (*zú*).
If the pulse is **fine, deep, and rapid** (*xìchénzào*), the disease originates in the **hand Yin meridians** (*shǒuyīnmài*).
If the pulse is **static** (*jìng*), the disease originates in the **foot Yin meridians** (*zúyīnmài*).
Hence it is said: If the pulse is **static** (*jìng*), the disease is in the **foot** (*zú*).
**Yin** governs the **bones**, hence **bone pain**.

If the pulse **beats rapidly once and then stops** (*shuòdòng yīdài*), it indicates the disease is in the **Yang meridians** (*yángmài*),
resulting in **diarrhea and bloody stools** (*xièjí biānxìng xuè*).
*Dài* (代) means **cessation** (*zhǐ*).
A rapid pulse that stops once signifies the **Yang *qi* (气)**’s disease, hence **disease in the Yang meridians**.
This is so because diarrhea and bloody stools are associated with such a pulse.

If the pulse is **rough upon palpation** (*sè*), it indicates **excessive Yang *qi*** (*yángqì yǒuyú*).
If the pulse is **slippery** (*huá*), it indicates **excessive Yin *qi*** (*yīnqì yǒuyú*).
*Newly corrected version*: It is detailed that "excessive *qi*" (*qìduō*) is likely an error; it should be **excessive blood** (*xuèduō*).

**Excessive Yang *qi*** causes **body heat without sweat** (*shēnrè wúhàn*),
and **cold body with sweat** (*hànshēn lěng*).
Blood deficiency and *qi* excess can be inferred from this.

If both **Yin and Yang *qi*** are excessive (*yīnyáng yǒuyú*),
there is **no sweat and coldness** (*wúhàn ér hán*).
**Excessive Yin *qi*** causes **excessive Yang without sweat** (*yángyú wúhàn*)
and **excessive Yin with cold body** (*yīnyú shēnhán*),
hence **no sweat and coldness**.

If the **skin feels as though Yin and Yang *qi*** are both excessive (*fúruò yīnyáng yǒuyú*),
and when **pushed externally**, the pulse **does not emerge externally** (*nèi ér bù wàinèi*),
it indicates **accumulation in the heart and abdomen** (*xīnfù zhōngjī*).
The pulse is examined at the *jīn* (筋) of the arm.
If the examination is not precise (*bùshěn*),
push the *jīn* (筋) outward to make the pulse **travel externally but not emerge externally** (*wàixíng nèi ér bù chū wàinèi*),
it is due to **accumulation within the heart and abdomen**.

If when **pushed internally**, the pulse **does not emerge internally** (*wàinèi ér bù nèinèi*),
it indicates **body heat** (*shēnrè*).
The pulse is distant from the arm’s *jīn* (筋).
If pushed to make it **near and not distant** (*yuǎn ér bùjìn*),
it is **excessive Yang *qi***, hence **body heat**.

If when **pushed upward**, the pulse **does not descend** (*shàng ér bùxià*),
it indicates **lumbar and foot coldness** (*yāozú qīng*).
If the pulse is pushed and examined, and it **rushes upward strongly** (*mài shàng yǒng shèng*),
it is due to **excessive Yang *qi***, hence **lumbar and foot coldness** (*yāozú líng*).
*Newly corrected version*: According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), "upward and not downward" (*shàng ér bùxià*) should be "downward and not upward" (*xià ér bùshàng*).

If when **pushed downward**, the pulse **does not ascend** (*xià ér bùshàng*),
it indicates **head and neck pain** (*tóuxiàng tòng*).
If the pulse is pushed and examined, and it **sinks downward** (*mài chén xià chè*),
it is due to **excessive Yang *qi***, hence **head and neck pain**.

If upon **pressing to the bone** (*ànzhī zhìgǔ*), the pulse’s *qi* (气) is **weak** (*shǎo*),
it indicates **lumbar and spinal pain** (*yāobèi tòng ér shēn yǒuzhì*).

The **excessive Yin *qi*** (阴气大过) is the cause of this condition.
