If one **seizes the pulse at the opportune moment** [qǔ zhī yǐ shí], then **all actions will succeed** [wàn jǔ wàn quán]. One should **administer treatment according to the seasonal location of blood and *qi*** [dàng yǐ sì shí xuè qì suǒ zài ér wéi liáo ér].

○[Newly corrected version states:] The phrase **"seize the pulse at the opportune moment"** [qǔ zhī yǐ shí] is rendered as **"treat and guide it"** [zhì zhī qū zhī] in *The Canon of A and B* [《Jiǎ Yǐ Jīng》], and **"never delay"** [wú hòu qí shí] aligns with the Wang lineage’s text, forming two complementary interpretations.

When **form and spirit-*qi* are discordant** [xíng qì xiāng shī], it is called **difficult to treat**. When **form is strong yet spirit-*qi* is weak** [xíng shèng qì xū], or **spirit-*qi* is strong yet form is weak** [qì shèng xíng xū], these are instances of **discordance**.

When **color is dull and luster is absent** [sè yāo bù zé], it is called **difficult to resolve**. *Dull* [yāo] means **obscured and unsightly**. *Luster absent* [bù zé] means **dry and withered**.

When the **pulse is firm and solid** [mài shí yǐ jiān], it is called **the illness worsening**. When the **spring pulse is firm and solid** [chún shí yǐ jiān], it signifies **pathogenic *qi* is rampant** [xié qì shèng], hence the illness **worsens**.

When the **pulse contradicts the four seasons** [mài nì sì shí], it is called **untreatable**, for the **vitality is inverse** [qì nì].

The following four sentences are the **Four Difficulties** [sì nàn], hence the subsequent passage states: **"One must discern the Four Difficulties and clearly inform the patient."** These Four Difficulties are what **the novice easily speaks of but the master struggles to apply**.

The so-called **"pulse contradicts the four seasons"** [nì sì shí] refers to:
- **Spring pulse resembling the lung’s drum** [chún dé fèi chún], yet appearing in **autumn** [qiū].
- **Summer pulse resembling the kidney’s drum** [xià dé shèn chún], yet appearing in **winter** [dōng].
- **Autumn pulse resembling the heart’s drum** [qiū dé xīn chún], yet appearing in **summer** [xià].
- **Winter pulse resembling the spleen’s pulse** [dōng dé pí chún], yet appearing in **spring** [chūn].

*Suspended and abrupt* [xuán jué] means **like a hanging object severed from its source**. If there is **no visceral form** [wèi yǒu zàng xíng], yet the **pulse is deep and slow** [mài chén sè] in **spring and summer**, or **floating and large** [mài fú dà] in **autumn and winter**, it is called **pulse contradicting the four seasons**.

○[Newly corrected version states:] According to *The Treatise on the Gastric Pulse of Balanced Individuals* [《Píng Rén Qì Xiàng Lùn》], it states: **"When the pulse is deep and slow, it is called *thin* [shòu]."** The meaning is the same as above. This text is erroneous; that treatise is correct.

In cases of:
- **illness with heat yet pulse is static** [réng],
- **diarrhea yet pulse is large** [xiè ér mài dà],
- **bleeding yet pulse is firm** [tuō xuè ér mài shí],

or when the **pulse is firm and solid in the middle** [mài zài zhōng shí jiān], or when the **pulse is not firm and solid on the exterior** [mài zài wài bù shí jiān], these are all **difficult to treat**.

These are all **difficult to treat** because **they do not correspond with the symptoms** [yǐ qí yǔ zhèng bù xiāng yìng].

○[Newly corrected version states:] According to *The Treatise on the Gastric Pulse of Balanced Individuals* [《Píng Rén Qì Xiàng Lùn》], it states: **"Illness is in the middle with *qi* deficiency** [mài zài zhōng yǐ xū], **and in the exterior with pulse deep and slow** [mài zài wài yǐ sè jiān]."** This is the opposite of the above. This text is mistaken; that treatise is accurate.

From the time when there was no mention of *qi* forms in spring and summer until now, this aligns with *The Treatise on the Gastric Pulse of Balanced Individuals*, with its interpretations fully detailed therein.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"I have heard that the distinction between emptiness and fullness determines life and death. I wish to hear the details."*

Qìbó replied: *"Five cases of fullness lead to death, and five cases of emptiness lead to death. The five fullnesses refer to the fullness of the five **zàng** organs. The five emptinesses refer to the emptiness of the five **zàng** organs."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"I wish to hear of the five fullnesses and five emptinesses."*

Qìbó replied: *"A **pulse that is strong**, **hot skin**, **abdominal distension**, **obstruction of the anterior and posterior passages**, and **foul breath**—these are called the five fullnesses. Fullness refers to the predominance of **pathogenic *qi***.

Now, a **strong pulse** pertains to the **heart**; **hot skin** pertains to the **lung**; **abdominal distension** pertains to the **spleen**; **obstruction of the anterior and posterior passages** pertains to the **kidney**; and **foul breath** pertains to the **liver**.

A **fine pulse**, **cold skin**, **scanty *qi***, **diarrhea with undigested food**, and **inability to ingest food and drink**—these are called the five emptinesses. Emptiness refers to the insufficiency of **true *qi***.

Now, a **fine pulse** pertains to the **heart**; **cold skin** pertains to the **lung**; **scanty *qi*** pertains to the **liver**; **diarrhea with undigested food** pertains to the **kidney**; and **inability to ingest food and drink** pertains to the **spleen**."

The Yellow Emperor said: *"But sometimes there are cases where life is preserved—why is that?"*

Qìbó replied: *"When **congee enters the stomach** and **diarrhea ceases**, the empty ones may recover. When **sweating occurs and bowel movements normalize**, the full ones may recover. These are the signs."*

**Full Annotation:**
*"When congee can be ingested and enters the stomach, the stomach *qi* harmonizes, and the diarrhea gradually stops. As the stomach *qi* regains strength, the empty ones may recover. For the full ones, if sweating occurs externally and bowel movements normalize afterward, the condition naturally balances."*

---
*(End of Volume Fifteen of the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon – Plain Questions* with Supplementary Commentary)*
*(Note: The following text contains corrections based on the *Metu* edition.)*

---
*(Volume Sixteen of the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon – Plain Questions* with Supplementary Commentary, annotated by Tang Taicang Ling Shì Xuānzǐ Wáng Bīng, collated by Song Guānglù Qīng Zhí Mìbù Lín Yì, and revised by Song Shǒushù Shùbiàn Túntián Láng Sūn Zhào.)*

**Discourse on the Three Divisions and Nine Investigations**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I have heard of the Nine Needles from Master [Qibo], vast and profound, beyond counting. I wish to grasp their essential Dao, to pass it down to my descendants, to transmit it to future generations, to inscribe it upon my bones and marrow, to store it in my liver and lungs, to receive it with solemn reverence—daring not to divulge it recklessly. [Here,] ‘enemy blood’ means ‘drinking blood’—to align with the Heavenly Dao. [Correction:] The newly collated text reads: ‘to align with the Heaven and Earth.’

There must be a beginning and an end, corresponding above to the luminaries and constellations of the celestial calendar, and below to the four seasons and five phases, with their hierarchies of honor and rank—winter’s yin and summer’s yang—how should one harmonize humanity with these? I wish to hear the method.

[Explanation:] ‘Heavenly luminaries’ refers to the sun, moon, and stars. ‘Calendar records’ refers to the sun and moon’s passage through the twenty-eight lunar mansions and the 365 degrees of the celestial sphere. [This speaks of] how the human form’s blood, *qi*, and the circulation of *honor* and *defense* align with the shifting seasons and correspond to the sun and moon’s paths.

Yet the Dipper’s Pole rotates, and the Yellow and Red Axes diverge."*

Winter, the sun follows the Yellow Axis near the south, so yin prevails;
Summer, the moon follows the Yellow Axis near the north, so yang flourishes.

The *qi* of the four seasons and five phases—
When the sovereign rules, it is noble;
When the minister aids, it is lowly.

Qìbó replied: *"Exquisite is your question!
This is the ultimate reckoning of Heaven and Earth.
The Way penetrates the subtle and refined, hence it is called an exquisite question.
'Ultimate reckoning' means the supreme principle of numbers.*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear the ultimate reckoning of Heaven and Earth,
How it harmonizes with the human form’s blood and *qi*,
And how it determines life and death—
How should one proceed?"*

Qìbó said: *"The ultimate reckoning of Heaven and Earth
Begins at One and ends at Nine.
Nine is an odd number.
Thus, the numbers of Heaven and Earth reach their extreme here.

One is Heaven,
Two is Earth,
Three is Humanity.
Multiply by three—
Three threes make Nine—
To correspond with the Nine Regions.
*The Classic of Names (Èr Yǎ)* says:
Beyond the city walls is the *jiāo* (suburb),
Beyond the *jiāo* is the *diàn* (hunting grounds),
Beyond the *diàn* is the *mù* (pasture),
Beyond the *mù* is the *lín* (forests),
Beyond the *lín* is the *jiǒng* (wilds),
Beyond the *jiǒng* is the *yě* (unbounded wilderness).
This speaks of their remoteness.

Thus, the human body has three divisions,
Each division has three pulses,
To discern life and death,
To diagnose a hundred ailments,
To regulate excess and deficiency,
And to dispel pathogenic *qi* and disease.

The ‘three divisions’ refer to the upper, middle, and lower regions of the body—not the *cùn*, *guān*, and *chǐ* [pulse positions].
Within these divisions, the channels and collaterals traverse,
Thus, observing the pulses to determine life or death
And applying needle techniques—
Pathogenic *qi* and disease can be removed."

The Emperor said: *"What are these three divisions?"*

Qìbó replied: *"There is the lower division, the middle division, and the upper division.
Each division has three pulses—
Heaven, Earth, and Humanity—
Which must be pointed out and explained clearly to be considered true.
[This warns:] One must receive instruction from a master.
*The Treatise on the Four Errors* says:
‘If one does not fully receive [teaching] from a master,
And rashly practices diverse pulse-taking,
Claiming it as the Way while renaming one’s own achievements,
Misusing lancets and needles—
Regret for one’s body will follow.’

*The Rites* say: ‘Do not presume in doubtful matters.’
‘Presume’ means to act without certainty.

**Upper Division:**
*Heaven* is the dynamic pulse of the two brows;
Located on either side of the forehead,
It responds to the hand—
The *qi* of the Foot *Shǎo Yáng* channel flows here.

*Earth* is the dynamic pulse of the two cheeks;
Located below the nostrils, near the *jùlú* [maxillary] region,
It responds to the hand—
The *qi* of the Foot *Yáng Míng* channel flows here.

*Humanity* is the pulse before the ear;
Located in the depression before the ear,
It responds to the hand—
The *qi* of the Hand *Shǎo Yáng* channel flows here.

**Middle Division:**
*Heaven* is the Hand *Tài Yīn* [Lung channel];
The Lung pulse,
Located at the posterior wrist crease, *Jīng Gǔ*,
It responds to the hand.

*Earth* is the Hand *Yáng Míng* [Large Intestine channel];
The Large Intestine pulse,
Located at the junction of the second and third metacarpals, *Hé Gǔ*,
It responds to the hand.

*Humanity* is the Hand *Shǎo Yīn* [Heart channel];
The Heart pulse,
Located at the ulnar end of the transverse carpal crease, *Shén Mén*,
It responds to the hand.
*The Spiritual Pivot: Treatise on Holding the Needle and Grasping the Pulse* asks:
‘If the *Shǎo Yīn* has no outlet, does the heart not fall ill?’
The reply:
‘When the external channel is diseased, the organ remains unaffected,
Thus, only the pulse at the posterior wrist crease, ulnar end, is taken.’

**Lower Division:**
*Heaven* is the Foot *Jué Yīn* [Liver channel];
The Liver pulse,
Located at the outer edge of the hairline, one and a half *cùn* below *Yáng Wèi*,
At the *Wǔ Lǐ* position,
Taken externally, it responds to the hand.
For women, *Tài Chōng* is taken—
Located two *cùn* behind the base of the big toe, in the depression.

*Earth* is the Foot *Shǎo Yīn* [Kidney channel];
The Kidney pulse,
Located in the depression above the medial malleolus, at *Dà Xī*,
It responds to the hand.

*Humanity* is the Foot *Tài Yīn* [Spleen channel];
The Spleen pulse,
Located at the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, at *Jī Mén*,
With the foot slightly everted and the sole exposed,
It is taken here, and it responds to the hand.
To examine the *qi* of the stomach,
Take the pulse above the medial malleolus, at *Chōng Yáng*,
Where the pulse in the depression responds to the hand.

Thus, the lower division’s *Heaven* pulse examines the liver—
The Foot *Jué Yīn* channel flows here.
*Earth* examines the kidneys—
The Foot *Shǎo Yīn* channel flows here.
*Humanity* examines the *qi* of the spleen and stomach—
The Foot *Tài Yīn* channel flows here.
Since the spleen and stomach are connected by membrane,
Examining the spleen also examines the stomach."

The Emperor said: *"How does one examine the middle division?"*

Qìbó replied: *"It also has Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.
*Heaven* examines the lungs—
The Hand *Tài Yīn* channel is here.
*Earth* examines the chest’s *qi*—
The Hand *Yáng Míng* channel is here.
The classics say: ‘The intestines and stomach are examined together.’
Thus, the chest’s *qi* is examined.
*Humanity* examines the heart—
The Hand *Shǎo Yīn* channel is here."

The Emperor said: *"How does one examine the upper division?"*

Qìbó replied: *"It also has Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.
*Heaven* examines the *qi* of the head and horns—
Its position is at the head and horns, hence it examines their *qi*.
*Earth* examines the *qi* of the mouth and teeth—
Its position is near the mouth and teeth, hence it examines them.
*Humanity* examines the *qi* of the ears and eyes—
Its position aligns with the ear, and the pulse extends to the outer canthus,
Hence it examines them."*

The three divisions each have their own Heaven, their own Earth, and their own Humanity.
Threefold, they complete Heaven—
*The New Annotation* says: "Examine from *Threefold, they complete Heaven* to *nine orifices*, as it overlaps with *The Treatise on the Six Nodal Transformations*, with interpretations detailed therein."
Threefold, they complete Earth;
Threefold, they complete Humanity.
Threefold and thrice again, combined they form nine—
Nine divisions become the Nine Wilds, the Nine Wilds become the Nine Orifices.
Thus, they correspond to the ultimate numbers of Heaven and Earth.
Hence, five are the *Spirit Orifices*, four are the *Form Orifices*, together making the Nine Orifices.
The so-called *Spirit Orifices* are:
The liver houses the *hun* (ethereal soul),
The heart houses the *shen* (spirit),
The spleen houses the *yi* (intent),
The lungs house the *po* (corporeal soul),
The kidneys house the *zhi* (will).
Since all are inhabited by *shenqi* (spiritual *qi*), they are called the five *Spirit Orifices*.
The so-called *Form Orifices* are all like vessels externally expanded, hollow yet unyielding, converging within material form—hence they are called *Form Orifices*.
The four *Form Orifices* are:
One, the head and horns;
Two, the ears and eyes;
Three, the mouth and teeth;
Four, the chest.

*The New Annotation* says: "Examine the commentary on *Spirit Orifices* in *The Manifestation of the Five *Qi***—its text also overlaps with the annotations of *The Doctrine of the Movement of *Qi* Through Heaven* and *The Treatise on the Six Nodal Transformations*."

When the five *zàng* (viscera) are ruined, their colors must wither—
Withering is death.
Withering refers to the color of death, an abnormal sign.
Color is the banner of the spirit; the *zàng* are the spirit’s dwelling.
Thus, when the spirit departs, the *zàng* decay;
When the *zàng* decay, the color shows abnormal signs—death.

The Emperor asked: *"How does one diagnose?"*

Qìbó replied: *"First, measure the body’s fatness or leanness,
Then regulate the *qi*’s excess or deficiency—
Excess, drain it; deficiency, supplement it.
*Measure* means to gauge.
Draining excess, supplementing deficiency—this is called *following the Way of Heaven*.
*The Laozi* says: *‘The Way of Heaven takes from the having surplus to supplement the insufficient.’*
First, remove the blood and vessels, then regulate—
Do not inquire about the patient’s illness; balance is the goal.
When blood and vessels are full and firm, it means *pathogenic* *qi* lingers.
Thus, first puncture to remove blood, then regulate.
Do not probe the patient’s excess or deficiency—
Essentially, balance the pulse and *qi* as the standard.

The Emperor asked: *"How does one determine life or death?"*
*Measuring the body’s fatness or leanness, regulating the *qi*’s excess or deficiency,
Without questioning the patient, balance as the standard—
Life and death are thus determined.*

Qìbó replied: *"If the form is robust but the pulse is fine,
With little breath insufficient for respiration—this is perilous.
Form and *qi* are contrary, so vital *qi* is in extreme danger.
*The Treatise on the True Essence of the Divine Machine* says:
*‘When form and *qi* harmonize, it is treatable.’*
Now, the pulse and *qi* are insufficient, while the form is robust and excessive—
The signs do not support each other, hence it is perilous.
*Perilous* means near death, yet still alive.
*The Treatise on Piercing the Will* says:
*‘When *qi* is full and form is full, when *qi* is deficient and form is deficient—this is normal.
To reverse this is illness.’*
Now, the pulse is fine with little *qi*—this is *qi* weakness,
While the body is robust and excessive—this is *form* excess.
When form is excessive and *qi* is weak, vital *qi* tilts toward peril.
*The New Annotation*: According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s annotation and *The Canon of the Heavenly Stem and Earthly Branch* and *The Pulse Canon*, *perilous* is written as *dead* in both.

If the form is lean and the pulse is large,
With abundant *qi* in the chest—this is death.
This is when form and *qi* are insufficient,
While pulse and *qi* are excessive—hence death.
When the form is lean, the pulse is large, and chest *qi* is abundant,
The *Form Orifice* is already damaged—hence it is death.

Cases like these all involve form and *qi* not harmonizing.
When form and *qi* harmonize, there is life.
When the five *zàng* are unregulated, there is illness.
*Param* means to cross-examine, *wu* means to classify—
Cross-examining and classifying yet unregulated means deviating from the norm—illness.
When the three divisions and nine diagnoses all fail to correspond—death.
*Fail* means the *qi* diagnoses do not align.
The signs of failing correspondences in diagnosis are seven—
Their states are as described below.

When the pulses above, below, left, and right correspond like the rhythmic pounding of a *cāng* (mortar),
The illness is severe.
When above, below, left, and right fail to correspond beyond counting—death.
The three divisions, nine diagnoses, above, below, left, and right—
A total of eighteen diagnoses.
*Like the pounding of *cāng*** refers to the large, rhythmic beating,
As when pounding grain in a mortar—up and down.
*The Pulse Classic on Subtle Essentials* says: *‘Large pulses indicate advancing illness.’*
Thus, the illness is severe.
*Beyond counting* means ten beats per breath or more.
*The Pulse Method* says:
*‘One breath, the pulse arrives twice;
One inhalation, the pulse arrives twice—this is normal.
Three arrivals per breath is *déjīng* (departing essence),
Four arrivals is *tuōjīng* (detached essence),
Five arrivals is death,
Six arrivals is life’s end.’*
Now, when the pulses fail to correspond and exceed counting—
This is beyond ten arrivals.
At five arrivals, it is already death—
How much more at ten!

Even if the middle division’s diagnosis is alone in harmony,
Yet fails to correspond with the other *zàng*—death.
When the middle division’s diagnoses are deficient—death.
The middle division, left and right—
A total of six diagnoses.
If the upper and lower divisions already do not correspond,
While the middle alone is harmonious—
It will not endure long in the upper and lower—
This is also *qi* decay—hence all lead to death.
*Deficient* means one-sided lack.

*The New Annotation* says: "The original text lacks the eight characters *‘When the middle division’s diagnoses are deficient—death.’*
According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s annotated edition and *The Canon of the Heavenly Stem and Earthly Branch*, these were added,
And there is an explanation of *deficient* in the annotation,
Though the text omits it—this omission occurred after Wang’s annotation."

If the inner eye sinks—death.
This refers to the *Tàiyáng* (Greater Yang).
The *Tàiyáng* pulse arises at the inner canthus.
When the inner eye sinks, the *Tàiyáng* is severed—hence death.
This is spoken of as *Tàiyáng* because it governs all *yáng* *qi*—
Hence it is mentioned alone.

The Emperor asked: *"How does one know where the illness lies?"*

Qìbó replied: *"Observe when one of the nine diagnoses is alone small—illness;
Alone large—illness;
Alone rapid—illness;
Alone slow—illness;
Alone hot—illness;
Alone cold—illness;
Alone sunken and low—illness."*

The signs of **lost correspondence** in diagnosis encompass seven cases—this is what is meant.

Yet when the pulse exhibits all seven diagnoses, it means the **Five Phases** are unbalanced, and following whichever one is uniquely abnormal reveals the illness.

Using the left hand, press five *cù* above the ankle on the **left** foot and hand, while the right hand strikes at the ankle itself. Both hands and feet are examined thus: above the hand’s ankle lies the **Hand Taiyin** pulse; above the foot’s ankle lies the **Foot Taiyin** pulse. The **Foot Taiyin** pulse governs flesh, corresponding to the lower body, while the **Hand Taiyin** pulse governs *qi*, corresponding to the middle body. Hence the text later states: *"If flesh withers and does not recede, death."* If the middle region alternates between sparse and frequent, death follows.

**Newly corrected annotation:** The *Canon of Heavenly Stem and Earthly Branch* and Quán Yuánqǐ’s annotated edition both state: *"Press with the left hand five *cù* above the ankle, while the right hand strikes at the ankle."* Quán Yuánqǐ’s annotation says: *"Above the inner ankle, the *Yīnjiāo* emerges, connecting to the bladder and linking to the kidneys. The kidneys are the **Mìngmén** (Gate of Life), hence its examination to determine life or death."* The current text omits the *"the"* character but adds *"regardless"* and *"foot."* Wang’s annotation interprets *"both hands and feet examined"* as the solution, which is forced—it should follow Quán Yuánqǐ’s old edition and the *Canon of Heavenly Stem and Earthly Branch* as correct.

If the response extends beyond five *cù* upward, moving like worms—no illness exists; this is due to harmonized *qi*. If the response is rapid, with the middle hand feeling chaotic—illness; if the middle hand feels sluggish—illness. *"Chaotic"* means disordered; *"sluggish"* means slow. If the response cannot reach five *cù* upward and does not answer when struck—death. The *qi* is severed, hence no response. Thus, if flesh withers and does not recede, death follows. When the **Gǔqì** (grain *qi*) weakens externally, the flesh appears stripped away. When **Tiānzhēn** (Heavenly Purity) is exhausted internally, the body cannot move. Both **Gǔqì** and **Tiānzhēn** decline—death is inevitable. *"Recede"* means to depart, as in *"to move away."* If the middle region alternates between sparse and frequent—death. This alternation is the *qi*’s chaotic loss, hence death.

If the pulse **substitutes** and **hooks** (like the *Xià* pulse), the illness lies in the **luò** (collateral) vessels. *"Hooking"* refers to the *Xià* pulse; moreover, *Xià* *qi* resides in the *luò*, hence the illness is in the *luò*. When the *luò* vessels receive evil, the **jīngmài** (channel) pulses stagnate and falter, hence the substituting stoppage.

The **Nine Diagnoses** must correspond: if upper and lower align—no loss. *"Align"* means equal in speed, size, etc. If one diagnosis lags, illness exists; if two lag, the illness is severe; if three lag, the illness is critical. *"Lag"* means they do not respond together. *"Together"* means *"same"* or *"unified."* Examine the **fǔ** (organs) and **zàng** (entrails) to know the period of death or life. When illness enters the **fǔ**, recovery follows; when it enters the **zàng**, death follows. Hence, the period of life or death is determined—examine to know it. One must first know the **jīngmài**, then know the disease pulse. The **jīngmài** are the pulses of the four seasons and five **zàng**.

If the **true zàng** pulses appear, death is imminent. The **true zàng** pulses are:
- The **true liver** pulse arrives, firm and tense like tracing a blade’s edge, *zhézhé* like pressing a *qín* or *sè* string.
- The **true heart** pulse arrives, firm and beating, like tracing *cāngmáo zǐ* (a type of seed) clustered together.
- The **true spleen** pulse arrives, weak, alternating between frequent and sparse.
- The **true lung** pulse arrives, large and hollow, like feathers brushing the skin.
- The **true kidney** pulse arrives, beating and abrupt, like plucking a stone *bìbì*.

These five are all cases where the **true zàng** pulses appear but **wèiqì** (stomach *qi*) is absent. The *Treatise on the Physiology of the Common Man* states: *"The stomach is the common *qi* of the healthy; if a person lacks stomach *qi*, it is called **nì** (reversal), and reversal means death."* This is what is meant.

*"Death is imminent"* means that if the pulse overpowers its own seasonal time, death follows. The *Treatise on the Physiology of the Common Man* states:
*"If the liver appears on *gēngxīn* (days governed by Wood), death follows.
If the heart appears on *rénguǐ* (days governed by Fire), death follows.
If the spleen appears on *jiǎyǒu* (days governed by Earth), death follows.
If the lung appears on *bǐngdīng* (days governed by Metal), death follows.
If the kidney appears on *wùjǐ* (days governed by Water), death follows."*
This is called *"death is imminent."*

If the **Foot Taiyang** *qi* is severed, the foot cannot flex or extend, and death will occur with the eyes staring upward. The **Foot Taiyang** pulse arises at the inner canthus, ascends the forehead to meet at the crown, enters to network the brain, descends to branch at the nape, follows the inner shoulder, skirts the spine to the waist’s center. Its branch further descends from the shoulder, passes through the buttock, reaches the **píshū** (sacral vertebra), descends to meet the **yīnliáng** (inguinal region), pierces the **duān** (perineum), follows the heel to the foot’s outer side. If the **Taiyang** *qi* is severed, death will be as described.

**Newly corrected annotation:** According to the *Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment*, the three **yang** and three **yin** pulses’ terminal signs are recorded. Here, only the **Foot Taiyang** *qi* severed case is mentioned—likely the rest of the text is omitted. Additionally, the annotation *"passes through the buttock"* is written as *"passes through the girdle"* in the *Canon of Heavenly Stem and Earthly Branch*. Wang’s annotation in the *Treatise on Ulceration* and *Treatise on Malarial Fever* uses *"contributes to swelling."* Again, in the *Treatise on Lumbago*, it is written as *"passes through the buttock."* Examining the *Canon of Heavenly Stem and Earthly Branch*, *"buttock"* should be *"swelling."*

The Emperor asked: *"How does one know the time of death in winter’s yin and summer’s yang?"* (Referring to the time of death.)

Qìbó replied: *"If the **Nine Diagnoses** pulses are all **depressed, fine, suspended, and severed**, this is **yin**, governing winter, hence death occurs at midnight. If they are **exuberant, agitated, and rapid**, this is **yang**, governing summer, hence death occurs at noon. Position has no fixed abode; extremes invert. The *Kàn* and *Kūn* trigrams’ lines—when yin reaches its extreme, the dragon struggles in the wild; when yang reaches its extreme, the soaring dragon regrets. Hence, when yin and yang pulses reach their extremes, death occurs at midnight or noon.*

Thus, those with **cold-heat diseases** die at dawn. This too is the principle of extremes transforming. At dawn, **Wood** reigns—**Wood** *qi* is **wind**, hence during Wood’s reign, cold-heat diseases lead to death. The *Treatise on the Movement of Vital *Qi* Through the Heavens* states: *"Exposure to dew and wind gives rise to cold-heat."* Hence, cold-heat diseases are caused by thin, invasive **wind**. Those with **heat in the center** or **heat diseases** die at noon.

At the extreme of **yang**, those afflicted by **wind** die at dusk. This is due to the **Taoist hour clash** between *Mao* (coat) and *You* (snake).

Those with **water** diseases die at midnight, for **Water** reigns then. If the pulse is alternately sparse, rapid, slow, or hurried, death occurs at the **four seasonal crossings**—*Chen*, *Wei*, *Chou*, and *You*—when **Earth** temporarily reigns. The *spleen qi* is internally severed, hence death at these crossings.

Even if the flesh has already detached and the **Nine Regions** are harmonized, death still occurs. This is called **"form and *qi* not harmonizing."** If the **Nine Regions** are already detached but the body remains, even if the **Nine Regions** are balanced, death still occurs.

If the **Seven Diagnoses** are present but the **Nine Regions** all comply, death does not occur. If the **Nine Regions** follow the **Four Seasons’ commands**, even if the **Seven Diagnoses** appear, life is preserved. *"Comply"* means to follow in accordance.

The cases I speak of as not dying are **wind-*qi* diseases** and **monthly cycle diseases**, which resemble the **Seven Diagnoses** but are not. Hence, they do not lead to death. The pulse of **wind diseases** is large and rapid. The pulse of **monthly cycle diseases** is small and faint. Though the **Nine Regions** and the **Seven Diagnoses** appear similar, the signs of life and death differ, hence they do not lead to death.

If one has the **Seven Diagnoses** and the pulse and **Nine Regions** are disordered, death occurs. Though the **Nine Regions** follow and the **Seven Diagnoses** appear, if the pulse is chaotic, life is still lost. There must be **groaning and sighing**. When the **stomach essence** is exhausted and the spirit does not guard the heart, at the time of death, these groans and sighs emerge. The *Treatise on the Manifestation of the Five *Qi*** states: *"The heart is responsible for sighing; the stomach for groaning."*

One must carefully inquire about the patient’s initial illness and the current condition. *"Condition"* means the present state. One must trace the beginning and examine the end. Then, each must palpate the pulse, observing the **meridians’** floating and sinking, and follow them upward and downward, whether they flow or resist. If the pulse is rapid, there is no illness—**qi** is strong. If the pulse is slow, illness is present—**qi** is deficient. If the pulse does not circulate, death occurs—the spirit has departed. If the skin is taut, death occurs—the bones are withered.

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How can such cases be treated?"*
Gebber replied: *"For **meridian diseases**, treat the **meridian**—seek the excess. For **grand collateral diseases**, treat the **grand collateral blood**—if blood stagnates, lance it to remove it."* (New annotation: The *Jia Yi Jing* states: *"For collateral diseases, treat the collateral blood."* There is no *"grand"* character.)

If the disease lies in **odd meridians**, lance the **odd meridians**—*"odd"* refers to irregular, unpaired *qi* that intersects with the **meridians**, hence it is lanced obliquely. Lance the **grand collaterals** left-to-right or right-to-left. If emaciation lingers without improvement, regulate the pulse and lance it. If the disease-*qi* lingers, the body withers, and the signs do not shift, then adjust the treatment and lance it. This further clarifies the earlier passage where no inquiry was made about the disease, and balance was the goal.

If there is **upper fullness and lower emptiness**, palpate and follow the pulse, seeking the **structured grand collaterals**, lance to release the blood, and ensure the **meridian** flows. *"Structured"* means blood congeals in the **grand collateral**. Once the blood is released, the **meridian** will flow freely. The earlier passage states: *"First remove the blood and *qi*, then restore balance."* This clarifies that the **structured grand collateral** must be addressed first. (New annotation: The *Jia Yi Jing* reads *"to harmonize the *qi*"* instead of *"to see it flow."*)

If the pupils are high, **Taiyang** is deficient. If the eyes are hooded, **Taiyang** is severed—this is the critical point between life and death, and must be observed.

(Note: The text mentions *"hand fingers and the five toes above the outer ankle"*—likely a scribal error.)

**Discourse on the Meridian Variations**
The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Do a person’s dwelling, movement, stillness, courage, or timidity cause the pulse to vary?"*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Do a person’s dwelling, movement, stillness, courage, or timidity cause the pulse to vary?"*

**Qi Bó** replied: *"All human experiences of fright, terror, overwork, exertion, or stillness—whether from movement or rest—will cause the pulse to vary. By 'vary,' I mean that the pulse deviates from its usual state, the **常侯** [constant norm].

Thus, nighttime walking causes **喘息** [labored breathing] originating from the **肾** [kidneys]. The kidneys reign supreme at night, their **氣** [*qi*] merging with the **幽冥** [profound darkness], so nighttime walking exhausts the kidneys, resulting in **喘息** [labored breathing] arising internally from the kidneys. If **淫氣** [*excessive or errant qi*] afflicts the **肺** [lungs], then nighttime walking strains the kidneys, leading to **喘息** [labored breathing], where the **淫氣** [*excessive qi*] does not follow its proper course—this will cause disease in the lungs.

If one falls into terror, **喘息** [labored breathing] emerges from the **肝** [liver]. Fear originates in the liver, and falling damages the sinews and blood, causing **奔喘** [sudden, erratic breathing], hence it arises from the liver. When **淫氣** [*excessive qi*] harms the **脾** [spleen], the liver’s wood nature acts in reckless excess, thereby damaging the spleen’s earth nature.

If one is startled or terrified, **喘息** [labored breathing] originates from the **肺** [lungs]. Sudden fright leaves the heart without support#1, and the spirit without anchor—**氣** [*qi*] becomes disordered in the chest, thus **喘息** [labored breathing] arises from the lungs. If **淫氣** [*excessive qi*] injures the heart, then fright causes the spirit to stray, and the **淫氣** [*errant qi*] rebounds to harm the heart.

When crossing water and stumbling or falling, **喘息** [labored breathing] emerges from the **肾** [kidneys] and **骨** [bones]. Dampness permeates the kidneys, and the bones fall under their dominion—thus, when crossing water and stumbling or falling, **喘息** [labored breathing] arises from the kidneys and bones. 'Stumbling' refers to tripping the feet, and 'falling' refers to the body toppling."

「跌 [*díe* – *to trip/fall*], pronounced *diè*; **仆** [*pǔ* – *to topple*], pronounced *fù*. At such times, the **勇者** [bold individuals] will disperse their **氣** [*qi*] and thus recover, while the **怯者** [timid individuals] will retain it and fall ill. **氣** [*qi*] has strength and weakness, the **神** [spirit] has vigor and frailty, hence the varied symptoms.

Thus it is said: The **道** [Way] of diagnosing illness lies in observing a person’s boldness or timidity, their **骨** [bones], **肉** [flesh], **皮肤** [skin], and discerning their condition to establish the diagnostic method. To grasp their innate disposition and understand their symptoms is to attain profound insight, aligning with the **物宜** [principles of correspondence].

Hence, when one’s **饮食** [diet] is excessively indulged, **汗** [sweat] emerges from the **胃** [stomach]. When the stomach is overfilled and replete, **汗** [sweat] thus arises from the **胃** [stomach]. Sudden fright depletes the **精** [essence], causing **汗** [sweat] to emanate from the **心** [heart]. Fright disrupts the heart’s **精** [essence], making the **神** [spirit] and **氣** [*qi*] surge upward—**阳** [yang] energy grows thin within—thus **汗** [sweat] arises from the **心** [heart]. When bearing heavy loads or traveling far, **汗** [sweat] emerges from the **肾** [kidneys]. **骨** [Bones] labor and **氣** [*qi*] rebels, the **肾** [kidneys] then overworks and suffers, hence when bearing heavy loads or traveling far, **汗** [sweat] arises from the **肾** [kidneys]. Rapid running or terror induces **汗** [sweat] from the **肝** [liver]. Violent exertion upon the **筋** [tendons], the **肝** [liver]’s **氣** [*qi*] exhausted to its limit, thus **汗** [sweat] arises from the **肝** [liver] in cases of rapid running or terror. Shaking the body or enduring hardship causes **汗** [sweat] from the **脾** [spleen]. "Shaking the body" refers to movements requiring force, not rapid running or long travel. Yet when such movements exert strength, the **谷精** [nutrient-essence of grains] disperses throughout—**脾** [spleen] transforms water and grain—thus **汗** [sweat] arises from the **脾** [spleen].

Thus, in spring, autumn, winter, and summer, the four seasons’ **阴阳** [yin-yang], illnesses arise from excessive strain—this is the norm. If one does not suit their nature and forces action, imbalance will spawn disease—this is the constant principle. The five **藏** [organs] receive **氣** [*qi*], each with its fixed allocation; if overused and depleted, disease ensues. Hence the following text states:

**食气** [*qi* of food] enters the **胃** [stomach], dispersing **精** [essence] to the **肝** [liver], and **淫气** [*excessive qi*] to the **筋** [tendons]. The **肝** [liver] nourishes the **筋** [tendons], so when the **胃** [stomach] disperses the **谷精** [*qi* of grain-essence] into the **肝** [liver], it permeates and nourishes the **筋络** [tendinous network]. **食气** [*qi* of food] enters the **胃** [stomach], **浊气** [*impure qi* – *grain-qi*] returns to the **心** [heart], and **淫精** [*errant essence*] overflows into the **脉** [vessels]. **浊气** [*impure qi*] refers to **谷气** [*qi* of grains]. The **心** [heart] resides above the **胃** [stomach], so **谷气** [*qi* of grains] returns to the **心** [heart], overflowing essence into the **脉** [vessels]. Why? Because the **心** [heart] governs the **脉** [vessels]. **脉气** [*qi* of vessels] flows through the **经** [channels], **经气** [*qi* of channels] converges in the **肺** [lungs], which receives the **百脉** [hundred vessels] and distributes **精** [essence] to the **皮毛** [skin and hair]. It speaks of **脉气** [*qi* of vessels] flowing and dispersing as the great **经** [channels], **经气** [*qi* of channels] returning to the **宗** [root], ascending to the **肺** [lungs]. The **肺** [lungs] serves as the **华盖** [*huágài* – *ornamental pavilion*], positioned high, its regulation unmatched, hence it receives the **百脉** [hundred vessels].

*The *Discourse on the Physiology of the Normal Person* [*Píngrén Qìxiàng Lùn*] states: The **藏真** [true essence of organs] is higher than the **肺** [lungs], enabling it to govern the **荣卫** [*róngwèi* – *nutritive and defensive qi*] and **阴阳** [yin-yang]. Thus, the **肺** [lungs] receives the **百脉** [hundred vessels], yet it disperses and transforms **精气** [*qi* of essence], distributing it to the **皮毛** [skin and hair].

When **毛脉** [hair and vessels] merge with **精** [essence], **氣** [*qi*] flows to the **府** [*fǔ* – *entrails*]. The **府** [*fǔ*] refers to where **氣** [*qi*] accumulates—this is called the **气海** [*Qìhǎi* – *Sea of Qi*], located between the two breasts, with the right side named **膻中** [*tánzhōng* – *chest center*]. **府** [*fǔ*]’s **精神** [*shénqì* – *spirit-qi*] disperses, lingering in the four **藏** [organs], while **氣** [*qi*] returns to the **权衡** [*Qūnhéng* – *balancing point*]. The **膻中** [*tánzhōng* – *chest center*]’s dispersed **氣** [*qi*] divides into three **隧** [*sùn* – *passages*]: the lower flows to the **气街** [*Qìjiē* – *Street of Qi*], the upper to the **息道** [*Xīdào* – *Pathway of Breath*], and the **宗气** [*Zōngqì* – *Root Qi*] lingers in the **海** [*Hǎi* – *Sea*], accumulating in the chest—this is called the **气海** [*Qìhǎi* – *Sea of Qi*].

Thus, through this differentiation, the four **藏** [organs] remain stable, the three **焦** [*jiāo* – *burners/triple energizers*] balanced, and the inner and outer, upper and lower all find their proper place. When **权衡** [*Qūnhéng* – *balancing point*] is harmonized, the **气口** [*Qìkǒu* – *Qi Mouth*] forms a **寸** [*cùn* – *inch*], determining life or death. The **三世** [*Sānshì* – *three generations’*] **脉法** [*màifǎ* – *pulse methods*] all measure three **寸** [*cùn*] as the division for **寸关尺** [*cùnguānchǐ* – *inch, wrist, cubit*]. Thus, when the inner and outer, high and low **氣** [*qi*] are balanced, the **气口** [*Qìkǒu* – *Qi Mouth*]’s pulse becomes a **寸** [*cùn*].

The **气口** [*Qìkǒu* – *Qi Mouth*] is the grand convergence of **脉** [vessels], where all **百脉** [hundred vessels] assemble, hence its divisions determine life or death. **饮** [fluids] enters the **胃** [stomach], dispersing **精气** [*qi* of essence], ascending to the **脾** [spleen]. Water and drink flow downward, reaching the **中焦** [*Zhōngjiāo* – *middle burner*], where water transforms into **精微** [*jīngwēi* – *essence and subtleties*], ascending as **云雾** [*yúnwù* – *clouds and mist*]. When **云雾** [*yúnwù*] disperse and change, they pour into the **脾** [spleen].

*The *Spiritual Pivot Classic* [*Língshū Jīng*] states: "The **上焦** [*Shàngjiāo* – *upper burner*] is like mist, the **中焦** [*Zhōngjiāo* – *middle burner*] like a pivot." This is what is meant.

**脾气** [*Qi* of spleen] disperses **精** [essence], ascending to the **肺** [lungs], regulating the waterways and distributing downward to the **膀胱** [*pángguāng* – *bladder*]. When water and earth harmonize, they ascend to nourish **肺金** [*Feìjīn* – *lung metal*], and **金气** [*qi* of metal] connects with the **肾** [kidneys], hence the regulation of waterways and the downward transmission to the **下焦** [*Xiàjiāo* – *lower burner*], where the **膀胱** [bladder] receives and transforms it into **波** [*bō* – *urine*].

*The *Spiritual Pivot Classic* [*Língshū Jīng*] states: "The **下焦** [*Xiàjiāo* – *lower burner*] is like a marsh." This is what is meant.

**水精** [*Qi* of water-essence] disperses throughout, the five **经** [channels] flow together, aligning with the four seasons. The **五藏** [*Wǔzàng* – *five organs*]’s **阴阳** [yin-yang] are measured as the norm.

From this, **水精** [*qi* of water-essence] disperses, **经气** [*qi* of channels] flows, **筋骨** [tendons and bones] solidify, **血气** [*xuèqì* – *blood-qi*] harmonizes, and it corresponds with the four seasons’ **寒暑** [*hánshǔ* – *cold and heat*], confirming the **五藏** [*Wǔzàng* – *five organs*]’s **阴阳** [yin-yang]. **睽** [*kuí* – *to diverge*] and **度** [*liáng* – *to measure*] fullness and emptiness, this is the **常道** [*Chángdào* – *constant principle*]. **度** [*liáng*] means to measure, **以** [*yǐ*] means to use.

*The newly corrected text states: According to one version, it should read: "yin-yang **动静** [*Dòngjìng* – *active and passive*]." When **太阳** [*Tàiyáng* – *Greater Yang*] **藏** [*zàng* – *organ*] alone arrives, **厥喘** [*juéchuǎn* – *reverse breathing/labored breathing*] occurs with **虚气** [*xūqì* – *empty qi*] rebelling—this is **阴** [yin] deficiency and **阳** [yang] excess. **阴** [yin] refers to the **肾** [kidneys], **阳** [yang] to the **膀胱** [bladder]. Hence the following text states:

"Both **表** [*biǎo* – *exterior*] and **裹** [*guǒ* – *enveloping*] should be dispelled, and the **下俞** [*Xiàyǔ* – *lower acupuncture points*] taken." **阳** [yang] alone arrives means **阳气** [*qi* of yang] is excessively strong. When **阳气** [*qi* of yang] is excessive, **阴** [yin] deficiency allows **阳邪** [*yángxié* – *yang pathogens*] to invade, hence both **表** [*biǎo*] and **裹** [*guǒ*] must be dispelled, and the **足** [*zú* – *foot*]’s **六俞** [*Liùyǔ* – *six acupuncture points*] taken.

*The newly corrected text states: It seems "six" should be "acupuncture points" [*穴* – *xué*], an error.* The **府** [*fǔ* – *entrails*] has six **俞** [*yǔ* – *acupuncture points*], while the **藏** [*zàng* – *organs*] have five. Now, when both **藏** [*zàng*] and **府** [*fǔ*] are dispelled, it should not be called six **俞** [*yǔ*]; six **俞** [*yǔ*] cannot encompass the **藏** [*zàng*]. **穴俞** [*xuéyǔ* – *acupuncture points*] can include both **藏** [*zàng*] and **府** [*fǔ*].

When **阳明** [*Yángmíng* – *Lesser Yang*] **藏** [*zàng* – *organ*] alone arrives, this is **阳气** [*qi* of yang] being excessively dense, requiring **写阳补阴** [*xiě yáng bǔ yīn* – *dispel yang and supplement yin*] and taking the **下俞** [*Xiàyǔ* – *lower acupuncture points*].

When **少阳** [*Shǎoyáng* – *Lesser Yang*] **藏** [*zàng* – *organ*] alone arrives, this is **厥气** [*juéqì* – *reverse/pathogenic qi*], with **娇** [*qiāo* – *to press lightly*] the **前** [*qián* – *forehead*] and **卒** [*cù* – *to strike suddenly*] the **大** [*dà* – *great*]. **踏** [*tà* – *to tread*] refers to **阳踏脉** [*yángtà mài* – *yang-pressing pulse*], located below the outer ankle of the foot. The **足少阳脉** [*Zú Shǎoyáng Mài* – *foot lesser yang channel*] travels to the end of **绝骨** [*jué gǔ* – *cutting bone*], descending from the outer ankle’s front, following the foot’s lateral side.

Now when one **stumbles forward** [*shān qián*] and **strikes suddenly** [*cù dà*], this is the **Lesser Yang** [*Shǎoyáng*] **qi** being excessive—hence, the **foot acupuncture points of Lesser Yang** are taken.

When **Lesser Yang alone arrives**, this is the **excess of one yang**—**Lesser Yang** itself. **"Excess"** refers to **Great Excess** [*Dàguò*]. Because of this **Great Excess**, one **presses lightly the forehead** [*qiāo qián*] and **strikes suddenly** [*cù dà*].

When the **Too-Yin** [*Tàiyīn*] **organ** is **palpitating** [*bó*], one must **focus the mind and verify the truth**—if the **Too-Yin** pulse is **latent yet throbbing** [*fú gǔ*], then one must **focus the mind and examine it closely**. If it is truly the **organ’s pulse**, it should not be treated.

When the **five pulses are diminished** and **stomach qi is unbalanced**, this pertains to the **three yins**—the **Too-Yin** pulse of the **spleen**. When the **five organ pulses are diminished** and **stomach qi is disordered**, this is also an **excess of Too-Yin**. One should treat the **lower acupuncture points**, **supplementing yang** and **dispelling yin**, for the **yin qi is excessively overbearing**.

When **one yang howls alone** [*yī yáng zhì xiào*], this is **Lesser Yang reversal** [*jué*]. **"Howling"** refers to a **whistling sound in the ears**, like a **howling voice**. Since the **gallbladder** and **triple burner** pulses all enter the ear, when **qi reverses upward**, the ears whistle.
