**Chapter on the Laws of Organ Qi** [*Zàngqì Fǎ Shí Luàn Piān*]

**The Yellow Emperor** asked: *"If one harmonizes human form with the **Four Seasons** and **Five Phases** for treatment, how does one follow the natural order? How does one go against it? I wish to understand the principles of **gain and loss**. Tell me the details."*

**Qíbó** replied: *"The **Five Phases** are **metal, wood, water, fire, and earth**, each taking turns in **nobility and humility**, determining **life and death**, deciding **success and failure**, and establishing the **qi of the five organs**. When asking about **critical moments**, one can determine the **periods of life and death**."*

**The Emperor** said: *"I wish to hear this thoroughly."*

**Qíbó** replied: *"The **liver governs spring**, corresponding to **wood**. The **foot Reversal-Yin** and **Lesser Yang** channels govern treatment. **Reversal-Yin** is the **liver pulse**; **Lesser Yang** is the **gallbladder pulse**. Since the **liver and gallbladder** are paired, their treatments are the same. The days are **Jia and Yi**—**Jia and Yi** belong to **wood**, the **eastern stem-branches**. The **liver suffers from urgency**; one should **urgently eat sweet** to **relax it**. **Sweetness** has a **harmonizing, relaxing nature**."

**New Annotation** states: Referencing **Quán Yuánqǐ’s** text: *"The liver suffers from urgency, meaning its **qi is in excess**."*

*"The **heart governs summer**, corresponding to **fire**. The **hand Lesser Yin** and **Too-Sun** channels govern treatment. **Lesser Yin** is the **heart pulse**; **Too-Sun** is the **small intestine pulse**. Since the **heart and small intestine** are paired, their treatments are the same. The days are **Bing and Ding**—**Bing and Ding** belong to **fire**, the **southern stem-branches**. The **heart suffers from slackness**; one should **urgently eat sour** to **contract it**. **Sourness** has a **contracting, astringent nature**."*

**New Annotation** states: Referencing **Quán Yuánqǐ’s** text: *"The heart suffers from slackness, meaning **heart qi is deficient**."*

*"The **spleen governs long summer**—**long summer** refers to the **sixth month**. **Summer** is the **mother of earth**; earth **grows in the center**, and since it **lengthens** in treatment, it is called **long summer**."*

**New Annotation** states: Referencing **Quán Yuánqǐ’s** text: *"The spleen reigns over the four seasons; the sixth month is where **fire reigns**, as the spleen governs the **center**, the sixth month being the **midpoint of the twelve months** and **halfway through the year**, hence the spleen reigns over the sixth month."*

*"The **foot Too-Yin** and **Yang-Bright** channels govern treatment. **Too-Yin** is the **spleen pulse**; **Yang-Bright** is the **stomach pulse**. Since the **spleen and stomach** are paired, their treatments are the same. The days are **Wu and Ji**—**Wu and Ji** belong to **earth**, the **central stem-branches**. The **spleen suffers from dampness**; one should **urgently eat bitter** to **dry it**. **Bitterness** has a **drying nature**."*

*"The **lung governs autumn**, corresponding to **metal**. The **hand Too-Yin** and **Yang-Bright** channels govern treatment. **Too-Yin** is the **lung pulse**; **Yang-Bright** is the **large intestine pulse**. Since the **lung and large intestine** are paired, their treatments are the same. The days are **Geng and Xin**—**Geng and Xin** belong to **metal**, the **western stem-branches**. The **lung suffers from upward-reversing qi**; one should **urgently eat bitter** to **drain it**. **Bitterness** has a **dispersing, draining nature**, hence the **lung** uses it."*

**New Annotation** states: Referencing **Quán Yuánqǐ’s** text: *"Lung qi reversing upward means its **qi is in excess**."*

*"The **kidney governs winter**, corresponding to **water**. The **foot Lesser Yin** and **Too-Sun** channels govern treatment. **Lesser Yin** is the **kidney pulse**; **Too-Sun** is the **bladder pulse**. Since the **kidney and bladder** are paired, their treatments are the same. The days are **Rén and Guǐ**—**Rén and Guǐ** belong to **water**, the **northern stem-branches**. The **kidney suffers from dryness**; one should **urgently eat pungent** to **moisten it**, **open the remaining passages**, **direct fluids**, and **circulate qi**. **Pungency** has a **moistening nature**."*

When the **victorious principle** is opened and **fluids reach their proper course**, then **lung qi descends and flows**, and the **kidney and lung communicate**—thus it is said that **qi is harmonized**.

When illness is in the **liver**, it is cured in **summer**—
the **child restrains its specter**—
the **remaining effects are the same**.

If not cured in **summer**, it worsens in **autumn**—
the **child rests**, and the **specter reigns again**—
the **remaining effects are the same**.

If not fatal in **autumn**, it persists into **winter**—
the **specter rests**, and the **mother nourishes**,
so **qi is sustained in the domain of the parents**.
The **remaining effects are the same**.

It revives in **spring**,
returning to its proper place—
thus it **rises again**.
The **remaining effects are the same**.

**Avoid exposure to wind**—
for **wind-qi** penetrates the **liver**, so it must be **restrained and not provoked**.

For those with **liver disease**, recovery occurs in **Jǐng and Dīng**—
**Jǐng and Dīng** correspond to **summer**.
If not cured in **Jǐng and Dīng**, it worsens in **Gēng and Xīn**—
**Gēng and Xīn** correspond to **autumn**.
If not fatal in **Gēng and Xīn**, it persists into **Rén and Guǐ**—
**Rén and Guǐ** correspond to **winter**.
It revives in **Jiǎ and Yǐ**—
corresponding to **spring wood**.

For those with **liver disease**:
**Dawn clarity is keen**,
**evening fatigue is severe**,
**midnight tranquility prevails**.
When **wood rules**, **clarity is sharp**.
When **metal rules**, **fatigue intensifies**.

**When water rules, thus tranquility retreats.**
The **remaining clarity is the same**, but its **tranquility differs slightly**.
The **liver seeks to disperse**—
**urgently consume pungent** to disperse it,
for **the organ’s qi must be dispersed**—
thus **pungent releases and scatters it**.
*The *Yīn-Yáng Yìng Xiàng Dà Lùn* states:*
**"Pungent and sweet disperse as yang."**
*The *Píng Rén Qì Xiàng Lùn* states:*
**"The organ’s true essence disperses in the liver."**
This speaks of its **constant dispersion**.
**Use pungent to supplement it, sour to alleviate it.**
Pungent’s flavor disperses—hence it **supplements**,
Sour’s flavor contracts—hence it **alleviates**.

*Newly corrected text states:*
*"According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s version:*
**‘Use sour to supplement it, pungent to alleviate it.’**
This forms another principle."*

**When disease is in the heart,**
recovery occurs in **long summer**,
long summer uncured, worsens in **winter**,
winter not fatal, persists into **spring**,
revives in **summer**—
as with the **liver’s pattern**.

**Avoid warm foods and heated garments.**
Heat causes **heart agitation**—thus it is **prohibited**.
For those with **heart disease,**
recovery occurs in **Wù and Jǐ**—
**Wù and Jǐ correspond to long summer**.
If **Wù and Jǐ** do not cure, it worsens in **Rén and Guǐ**—
**Rén and Guǐ correspond to winter**.
If not fatal in **Rén and Guǐ**, it persists into **Jiǎ and Yǐ**—
**Jiǎ and Yǐ correspond to spring**.
It revives in **Jǐng and Dīng**—
corresponding to **summer fire**.

**For those with heart disease,**
clarity peaks at **midday**,
intensifies at **midnight**,
and calms at **dawn**—
this too follows the **resting and reigning principle**.

The heart craves **vigorous vitality**—
in urgency, consume **salty** to **restrain** it,
for the **organs’ qi** prefers moderation,
thus **salty** softens and restrains.

*The Treatise on the Qi of the Common Man* states:
*The organ’s true essence communicates with the heart.*
This speaks of its **constant need for restraint**.

**Supplement with salty** to reinforce,
**use sweet** to relieve.
Salty reinforces—**taken for its softening restraint**.
Sweet relieves—**taken for its gentle ease**.

**When disease is in the spleen,**
recovery occurs in **autumn**,
autumn uncured, worsens in **spring**,
spring not fatal, persists into **summer**,
revives in **long summer**—
**as with the liver’s pattern**.
**Avoid warm foods, overfeeding, damp terrain, and damp garments.**
Warmth, dampness, and overfeeding
all harm **spleen qi**—thus they are **prohibited**.

For those with **spleen disease,**
recovery occurs in **Gēng and Xīn**—
**corresponding to autumn’s energy**.
If **Gēng and Xīn** do not cure, it worsens in **Jiǎ and Yǐ**—
**corresponding to spring’s energy**.
If not fatal in **Jiǎ and Yǐ**, it persists into **Jǐng and Dīng**—
**corresponding to summer’s energy**.
It revives in **Wù and Jǐ**—
**corresponding to long summer**.

*Spleen disease*:
clarity fades at **sunset**,
intensifies at **sunrise**—
*The Newly Corrected Text* notes:
According to *The Canon of Start and Termination*, "sunrise" should read **"dawn"**.
Though sunrise and dawn are temporally equal,
the earlier text, speaking of **Wood’s reign**, always uses **"dawn"**
rather than "sunrise," for sunrise varies in winter and summer,
while **"dawn"** is a fixed standard.
At **midday**, it quiets.

When **Earth reigns**, clarity is **bright yet clear**,
when **Wood conquers**, it **worsens**,
when **Metal assists**, it **calms and retreats**—
this too follows the **resting and reigning principle**.

One erroneous version reads **"midday persists"**—**incorrect**.

Thus, the **five organ diseases** all follow the **cycle of overcoming**:
they worsen at what they **cannot overcome**,
persist at what they **generate**,
and revive when they **return to their proper position**.
Hence, each has **times of remission and severity**,
and fixed **terms of life and death**.

The spleen craves **slowness**—
in urgency, consume **sweet** to **slow it**,
for **sweet’s nature is harmonious and gentle**,
aligning with its **stillness**.
**Use bitter** to relieve,
**sweet** to supplement.
Bitter relieves—**taken for its firm dryness**.
Sweet supplements—**taken for its tranquil ease**.

**When disease is in the lungs,**
recovery occurs in **winter**,
winter uncured, worsens in **summer**,
summer not fatal, persists into **long summer**,
revives in **autumn**—
**as with the liver’s pattern**.
**Avoid cold foods, cold drinks, and cold garments.**
The lungs **abhor cold qi**—thus food and clothing are **prohibited**.
*The Spiritual Pivot* states:
*"Cold exposure and cold drinks injure the lungs."*
Drinks already harm the lungs—**how much more so food!**
The lungs do not **solely abhor cold**; they also **fear heat**.

For those with **lung disease,**
recovery occurs in **Rén and Guǐ**—
**corresponding to winter water**.
If **Rén and Guǐ** do not cure, it worsens in **Jǐng and Dīng**—
**corresponding to summer fire**.
If not fatal in **Jǐng and Dīng**, it persists into **Wù and Jǐ**—
**long summer earth**.
It revives in **Gēng and Xīn**—
**corresponding to autumn metal**.

For those with **lung disease,**
**palpitations** occur at **midday**, **worsening** at noon, **subsiding** at midnight.
When **Metal rules**, palpitations **abate**;
when **Water rules**, they **subside**;
when **Fire rules**, they **worsen**.
The lungs **seek contraction**—
**urgently consume sour** to **contract** them,
for **sourness contracts and consolidates**.
Use **sourness to supplement** and **pungent to vent**.
Sourness **supplements** by contracting;
pungent **vents** by dispersing.

---

For **kidney disease,**
recovery occurs in **Jia and Yi**—
**corresponding to spring wood**.
If **Jia and Yi** do not cure, it worsens in **Wù and Jǐ**—
**long summer earth**.
If not fatal in **Wù and Jǐ**, it persists into **Gēng and Xīn**—
**autumn metal**.
It revives in **Rén and Guǐ**—
**corresponding to winter water**.
**As with the liver’s pattern**.
**Avoid withered, scorched, hot foods, warm roasted meats, and warm garments.**
The kidneys **abhor dryness**—thus these are **prohibited**.
*The Newly Corrected Text* notes:
*"In other editions, 'scorched' is written as 'withered.'"*
**Qīng (青, green)** corresponds to **Cuì (悴, withered)**.
**Huàn (焕, scorched)**—pronounced *Wū-lái*—means **heat and agitation**.
The kidneys **abhor dryness**—thus these are **prohibited**.

For those with **kidney disease,**
**palpitations** occur at **midnight**, **worsening in all seasons**, **subsiding at dawn**.
When **Water rules**, palpitations **abate**;
when **Earth rules**, they **worsen**;
when **Metal rules**, they **subside**.
The kidneys **seek firmness**—
**urgently consume bitter** to **firm** them,
for **bitterness firms and dries**.
Use **bitterness to supplement** and **salty to vent**.
Bitter **supplements** by firming;
salty **vents** by **moistening**—
**moistening**, as **wet earth subdues**.
Thus, **venting is used**.

Now, when **evil qi** invades the body,
it **adds according to its overcoming nature**—
**evil**, meaning **that which is unnatural**.
Wind, cold, heat, dampness, hunger, satiety, labor, and rest—
all are **evil**; not only **ghosts, poisons, epidemics, and plagues**.
When it reaches **what generates it**, it **abates**—
meaning **when it reaches what it generates**.
When it reaches **what it cannot overcome**, it **worsens**—
meaning **when it reaches what overcomes it**.
When it reaches **what it generates**, it **persists**—
meaning **when it reaches what generates it**.
When it **returns to its proper position**, it **revives**—
meaning **when it resides in its governing domain**.
**First, determine the five viscera’s pulses**—
then one may speak of **when it worsens**, or of **life and death**.
The **pulses of the five viscera** are:
**liver—string-like**, **heart—hooked**, **lungs—floating**, **kidneys—winding**, **spleen—slippery**—
thus one may speak of **life, death, and worsening**.

*The Treatise on Three Departments and Nine Lords* states:
*"First, know the regular pulses,
then know the diseased pulses."*
This is what is meant.

For **liver disease,**
pain radiates from the **lower ribs to the lower abdomen**,
causing **easiness to anger**.
The **liver’s Jueyin pulse** ascends from the foot,
circles the genitals,
reaches the lower abdomen,
then ascends through the **liver’s gate (gallbladder region)**,
spreading across the ribs—
thus pain radiates from the **lower ribs to the lower abdomen**.
When its **qi is replete**, one is **easily angered**.
*The Spiritual Pivot* states:
*"When liver qi is replete, anger arises."*
When **depleted**, vision becomes **blurred** (*"brǎng-brǎng"*), hearing **fails**,
and one is **easily frightened**, as if **being pursued**.
The **liver’s Jueyin pulse** travels from the ribs along the throat,
enters the **occiput**, and connects to the **optic nerve**.
The **gallbladder’s Shaoyang pulse** has a branch
that enters the ear from behind,
exits at the ear’s front,
and reaches the **posterior corner of the orbit**—
thus the disease manifests as such.
**Fear** means **terror**, **the spirit’s unrest**.
Take its **channels**—**Jueyin and Shaoyang**—
**channels** meaning **the regular pulses**.
Since it is not a **collateral disease**, take its **channels**.
Take **Jueyin** to regulate **liver qi**,
take **Shaoyang** to adjust **inverted qi**.
Thus, the following states:
When **qi is inverted**, there is **headache, deafness, and swollen cheeks**.
The **liver’s Jueyin pulse** ascends from the **optic nerve**,
exits at the forehead,
and meets the **governing vessel at the crown**—
thus **headache**.
The **gallbladder’s Shaoyang pulse** has a branch
that exits the ear and travels to the **ear’s front**;
another branch reaches the **cheekbone**.
Again, the **Jueyin pulse** has a branch
that descends from the **optic nerve to the cheek**, wrapping around—
thus **deafness, inability to hear, and swollen cheeks**.
Hence, the earlier text **simultaneously takes Shaoyang**.
For **bloodletting**:
If the **pulse is full of blood**, differing from the norm,
it is a sign of **inverted qi**—
**needle the affected side accordingly**.

For **heart disease,**
there is **chest pain**, **rib distension**, **lower rib pain**, **pain in the chest, back, shoulders, and inner arms**,
The **heart’s Shaoyin pulse** has a branch
that travels along the chest and exits the ribs.
Again, the **hand’s Jueyin pulse (Pericardium)** arises in the chest;
its branch also travels along the chest and exits the ribs,
descending three inches below the armpit,
ascending to the **armpit’s underside**,
descending along the **inner arm**, between the **Taiyin and Shaoyin**,
entering the **elbow’s interior**, then descending along the arm between the two tendons.
Again, the **heart’s Shaoyin pulse** has a direct path
that returns from the heart to the lungs,
ascends below the armpit,
descends along the **inner arm’s posterior groove**,
travels behind the **Taiyin and Pericardium**,
enters the **inner elbow**, and reaches the **end of the pisiform bone**.
Again, the **small intestine’s Taiyang pulse** ascends from the arm,
circles the **shoulder blade**, and crosses above the shoulder—
thus the disease manifests as such.
**Burnt (燸)**, pronounced *Rén-zhū*.

When the **Spleen’s virtue/power** is deficient, the chest and abdomen become distended,
and pain draws from the armpit to the waist.
The **hand’s Shaoyin pulse** (of the Pericardium) travels from the chest,
descending to the **lateral costal region** (鬲) and connecting with the **Sanjiao** (Triple Burner).
Its divergent branch follows the chest and exits through the ribs.

The **heart’s Shaoyin pulse** (of the Kidney) descends from the heart,
passing through the **lateral costal region** (鬲) and connecting with the **small intestine**.
Thus, the disease manifests as such.
**Puncture** (取) the **channel’s pulse** (经), specifically the **Shaoyin and Taiyang** (of the hand), and the **blood beneath the tongue**.
The **Shaoyin pulse**, ascending from the heart’s system to the **sides of the throat** (侠咽喉), is why blood is taken from the **root of the tongue** and along the channel.
For its **variant diseases** (变病), puncture the **blood in the "You" point** (邮).
If it changes to **vomiting** (呕), then puncture the **blood-filled Shaoyin "You" point** (邮).
The **hand’s Shaoyin "You"** (邮) lies behind the palm’s pulse,
half an inch from the wrist, aligned with the **little finger’s posterior groove**.

For **Spleen disease**, the body feels heavy,
muscles weaken and atrophy (痿),
the feet cannot be drawn up (足不收),
movement becomes **limp** (善痪),
and there is pain beneath the feet.
The **Spleen’s nature** is **earth**, and it governs **flesh** (肉),
so when deficient, the body feels heavy and muscles atrophy.
**Atrophy** (痿) means **weakness without strength**.
The **Spleen’s Taiyin pulse** arises at the **big toe’s end**,
ascending along the **inner side of the toe**,
passing the **anterior groove of the medial malleolus** (内踝前廉),
and moving up the **inner leg** (踹内).
The **Kidney’s Shaoyin pulse** begins beneath the **little toe**,
slanting toward the **sole of the foot** (足心),
ascending the **inner leg** (揣内),
and emerging along the **posterior groove of the medial malleolus** (蝈内康).
Thus, when the Spleen is diseased,
the feet cannot be drawn up (足不收),
movement becomes **limp** (善痪),
and there is pain beneath the feet.
Hence, **blood is taken from the Taiyin pulse** (少阴).
**Newly corrected text** states:
According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), it reads: **prone to hunger** (善饥), **muscle atrophy**.
The *Qian Jin Fang* (《千金方》) states: **prone to hunger**, **foot atrophy unable to draw up**.
The *Qi Jiao Bian Da Lun* (《气交变大论》) states: **muscle atrophy**, **foot atrophy unable to draw up**, **prone to limpness**.
**Atrophy** (痿), pronounced *Wěi-ní*, is a **damp disease** (湿病), rendering the feet unable to move.
**Limp** (痪), pronounced *Xì* or *Chǐ-zhì*, refers to **childhood weakness**.

When deficient, the abdomen is distended,
the intestines rumble (呜),
**undigested food leaks** (飧泄),
and food is not properly metabolized (食不化).
The **Spleen’s Taiyin pulse** ascends from the **inner thigh** (股内),
entering the abdomen and connecting with the **Spleen and Stomach** (脾络胃).
Thus, the disease manifests as such.
The *Ling Shu Jing* (《灵枢经》) says:
When the **central qi** (中气) is insufficient,
the abdomen becomes **prone to distension** (善满),
and the intestines rumble (善呜).
**Puncture** the **channel’s pulse** (经), specifically the **Taiyin, Yangming, and Shaoyin blood**.
The **Shaoyin pulse** is the **Kidney’s channel** (肾脉).
Since the earlier disease was **prone to limpness** and **pain beneath the feet**,
blood is taken from it.
Blood is taken when it is **full** (满).

For **Lung disease**, there is **wheezing** (喘),
**coughing** (咳),
**reverse flow of breath** (逆气),
shoulder and back pain,
**Newly corrected text** states:
According to the *Qian Jin Fang* (《千金方》), it reads: **shoulder stiffness** (肩息) and **back pain**.
**Sweating** (汗出),
**numbness of the lips** (尸阴),
**pain in the knee and thigh** (股膝),
and the **sole of the foot, inner leg, and heel** (牌踹腑足) all ache.
The **Lung’s nature** is **metal**, governing **respiration** (喘息).
When it shifts to **coughing** (咳), the disease presents as **wheezing, coughing, and reverse breath**.
The **back** is the **chest’s repository** (府),
and the **shoulder** is adjacent to it,
so shoulder and back pain occur.
The **Lung nourishes skin and hair** (皮毛),
and when **pathogenic forces** (邪) prevail,
**heart fluids leak outward** (心液外泄),
causing **sweating**.
The **Kidney’s Shaoyin pulse** ascends from the foot,
following the **inner leg** (踹内),
emerging along the **posterior groove of the medial malleolus** (胭内康),
and moving up the **inner thigh’s posterior groove** (股内后康),
piercing the **spine** (贯脊) and connecting with the **Kidney**, linking to the **Bladder**.
When the **Lung is diseased**, the **lip pulse** (唇脉) is affected by **pathogenic forces**,
so there is **numbness of the lips, pain in the knee and thigh, sole of the foot, inner leg, and heel**.
Thus, **blood is taken from the Shaoyin pulse** (少阴).

When deficient, there is **shortness of breath** (少气),
unable to **respond to inhalation** (不能报息),
**deafness** (耳聋),
and **numbness of the lips** (嗑乾).
The **qi is weak and scarce** (气虚少),
so it is insufficient to **respond to incoming breath**.
The **Lung’s Taiyin network** (络) converges in the **ear** (耳中),
so **deafness** occurs.
The **Kidney’s Shaoyin pulse** ascends from the **Kidney**,
piercing the **liver’s lateral costal region** (鬲),
entering the **Lung** (肺中),
and ascending the **throat**, alongside the **root of the tongue**.
When the **Lung is deficient**, the **Kidney’s qi** is insufficient to **moisten the throat** (以上润於哑),
so **numbness of the lips** occurs.
Thus, the **following text** also takes blood from the **Shaoyin pulse**.
**Puncture** the **channel’s pulse** (经), specifically the **Taiyin, foot’s Taiyang exterior, and Shaoyin interior blood**.
The **foot’s Taiyang exterior and Shaoyin interior** refers to the **direct upward path** from the **inner side of the big toe** and the **posterior groove of the medial malleolus**—
this is the **Shaoyin pulse**.
Observe the **left and right foot’s Shaoyin sections** for **blood fullness** (血满) differing from the norm,
and **puncture it immediately**.

For **Kidney disease**, the abdomen is distended,
the **channels are swollen** (经肿),
**Newly corrected text** states:
According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), it reads: **channels are swollen and painful**.
There is **wheezing, coughing, body heaviness**,
**night sweats** (寝汗),
**aversion to wind** (憎风),
and **cold extremities**.
The **Kidney’s Shaoyin pulse** arises from the foot,
ascending along the **inner leg** (踹内),
passing through the **horizontal bone** (横骨),
and alongside the **navel** (齐),
moving upward through the **abdominal region** (腹裹),
entering the **Lung** (肺).
Thus, the abdomen becomes distended,
the **channels are swollen**,
and there is **wheezing and coughing**.
When the **Kidney is diseased**, the **bones cannot function**,
so the body feels heavy.
**Pathogenic forces** attack the **Lung**,
**heart qi weakens internally** (心气内微),
and **heart fluids become sweat** (心液为汗),
causing **night sweats**.
Since the **channels are swollen**,
**sweat further leaks** (汗复津泄),
**yin stagnates in the hidden repository** (阴凝玄府),
and **yang scatters in the upper burner** (阳烁上焦).
**Internal heat and external cold** arise,
so there is **aversion to wind**.
**Aversion to wind** means **deeply detesting it**.
When deficient, there is **pain in the chest**,
**pain in the large and small intestines** (大腹小腹),
and **unsettled emotions** (清厥意不乐).
The **Kidney’s Shaoyin pulse** (豚) emerges from the **Lung**,
connecting with the **heart** and converging in the chest.
When the **Kidney’s qi is deficient**,
the **heart lacks regulation** (心无所制),
**heart qi relies on the Lung** (心气需肺),
so pain gathers in the chest.
The **foot’s Taiyang pulse** (豚) descends from the **nape** (项下),
reaching the foot.
When the **Kidney is deficient**, the **Taiyang’s qi** cannot **flourish in the foot**,
so the **foot’s qi is limp** (足玲),
and **breath reverses** (气逆).
**Limpness** (清) means **weak and limp qi**.
**Reverse breath** (厥) means **inverted qi**.
Since the **qi is weak and limp** and **breath reverses**,
there is pain in the **large and small intestines**.
When **emotional balance is lacking** (志不足),
the **spirit becomes restless** (神躁扰),
so there is **unsettledness**.
**Newly corrected text** states:
According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), **large and small intestines** (大腹小腹) should read **large and small intestines** (大肠小肠).
**Puncture** the **channel’s pulse** (经), specifically the **Shaoyin and Taiyang blood**.

The **principles of acupuncture** (几刺之道) are:
When deficient, **supplement it** (补之),
when **excessive**, **drain it** (写之).
When neither deficient nor excessive,
**puncture along the channel** (以经取之).
This is called **attaining the Dao/Way**.
If the **channels and networks contain blood** (经络有血),
**puncture and remove it** (刺而去之).
This is called **upholding the law** (守法).

One must first **assess the body’s form** and **determine the state of qi**, then **remove the blood** from the vessels before **balancing excess and deficiency**.

The *Sanbu Jiuhou Lun* (《三部九候论》) states:
*"First, measure the body’s fatness and thinness to regulate the deficiency or excess of qi. If excess, drain it; if deficient, supplement it. First remove the blood stagnation, then adjust it."* This is precisely what is meant.

The liver’s color is green; it should be fed **sweet** foods—**glutinous rice, beef, dates, and gourd**—all of which are sweet. The liver’s nature is prone to **urgency**, so sweet foods are taken to **soothe and relax** it.
**Newly corrected text** states: See the section on the liver’s green color to the end of the passage; the full text in the *Quan Yuan Qi* edition is in Volume Six, but Wang [the annotator] moved it here.

The heart’s color is red; it should be fed **sour** foods—**adzuki beans** (**Newly corrected text**: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* and *Tai Su*, adzuki beans are written as *má* [hemp]), **dog meat, plums, and leeks**—all of which are sour. The heart’s nature is prone to **sluggishness**, so sour foods are taken to **contract and consolidate** it.

The lungs’ color is white; they should be fed **bitter** foods—**barley, mutton, and indigo**—all of which are bitter. The lungs are prone to **inverted qi**, so bitter foods are taken to **dispel and drain** them.

The spleen’s color is yellow; it should be fed **salty** foods—**soybeans, pork, chestnuts, and radishes**—all of which are salty. Examining these dietary correspondences reveals the principle of **adjusting and harmonizing the pivotal mechanisms**.

The kidneys govern the **stomach’s gate**, and the spleen is paired with the stomach, so **salty, soft, and moistening** foods are used to **facilitate its function**. When the gate is unobstructed, stomach qi flows, and when the stomach moves, spleen qi transforms accordingly—thus, the spleen’s dietary preference differs from the others.
**Newly corrected text** states: Referring to the earlier text:
*"The liver suffers from urgency; urgently feed sweet to relax it.
The heart suffers from sluggishness; urgently feed sour to contract it.
The spleen suffers from dampness; urgently feed bitter to dry it.
The lungs suffer from inverted qi; urgently feed bitter to drain it.
The kidneys suffer from dryness; urgently feed pungent to moisten it."*
Here, the dietary recommendations for the liver, heart, lungs, and kidneys align with the earlier passage, except for the spleen, which should be fed salty rather than bitter—thus, Wang [the annotator] specially explains its meaning.

The kidneys’ color is black; they should be fed **pungent** foods—**yellow millet, pheasant meat, peaches, and onions**—all of which are pungent. The kidneys’ nature is prone to **dryness**, so pungent foods are taken to **moisten and nourish** them.

Pungent **disperses**, sour **contracts**, sweet **relaxes**, bitter **fortifies**, and salty **softens**. These are the **natural properties of qi**.
Yet pungent and bitter flavors are not merely for **dispersion and fortification**. Pungent can also **moisten and disperse**, while bitter can also **dry and drain**—thus, the earlier passage states:
*"The spleen suffers from dampness; urgently feed bitter to dry it,
The lungs suffer from inverted qi; urgently feed bitter to drain it,"*
referring to the **drying and draining** effects of bitter.
It also states:
*"The kidneys suffer from dryness; urgently feed pungent to moisten it,"*
referring to the **moistening** effect of pungent.
*Delü* (奕) is pronounced *ruǎn* (soft).

**Toxic medicines dispel evil**—
Medicines, including **metals, gems, earth, stones, herbs, trees, vegetables, fruits, insects, fish, and birds/beasts**, are all capable of **dispersing evil and nourishing the true** (正).
Yet only **toxic medicines** can effectively **repel evil and stabilize the true**, and because they can do so, they are universally called *toxic medicines*.
**Newly corrected text** states: According to the *Ben Cao* (《本草》), *"Lower-grade medicines are assistants; they treat diseases in accordance with the earth’s influence, are often toxic, and should not be taken long-term. They are used to eliminate cold and heat, dispel evil qi, break stagnations, and cure diseases."* Hence, it is said that **toxic medicines dispel evil**.

**The Five Grains nourish**—glutinous rice, adzuki beans, barley, soybeans, and yellow millet.
**The Five Fruits assist**—peaches, plums, apricots, chestnuts, and dates.
**The Five Livestock benefit**—cattle, sheep, pigs, dogs, and falcons.
**The Five Vegetables fulfill**—gourds, radishes, *peng* (蓬, possibly *Cynanchum*), onions, and leeks.
**Newly corrected text** states: The *Wuchang Zhengda Lun* (《五常政大论》) says:
*"Greatly toxic medicines cure disease, removing six out of ten ailments.
Moderately toxic medicines cure disease, removing seven out of ten ailments.
Slightly toxic medicines cure disease, removing eight out of ten ailments.
Non-toxic medicines cure disease, removing nine out of ten ailments.
Foods of grain, meat, fruit, and vegetables—when fully consumed—should not be overused, lest they harm the true (正)."*

When **qi and flavor are harmonized and taken together**, they **supplement essence and strengthen qi**.
Qi refers to **yang transformation**, while flavor refers to **yin application**. When qi and flavor are harmonized, they **nourish essence and vital energy**.
The *Yin-Yang Yingxiang Da Lun* (《阴阳应象大论》) states:
*"Yang is qi, yin is flavor. Flavor nourishes form, form nourishes qi, qi nourishes essence, and essence transforms. Essence consumes qi, form consumes flavor."*
It also states:
*"When form is deficient, warm it with qi.
When essence is deficient, supplement it with flavor."*
Thus, the principle of **supplementing essence and strengthening qi** becomes clear.
**Newly corrected text** states: Sun Simiao (孙思邈) said:
*"Essence consumes qi, and qi nourishes essence to brighten the complexion.
Form consumes flavor, and flavor nourishes form to generate strength.
Essence follows the Five Qi to become spirit—if consumed improperly, it harms essence.
Form receives flavor to solidify—if flavor is unbalanced, it damages form.
Thus, the Sage first uses dietary prohibitions to preserve nature, then prescribes medicines to safeguard life.
Qi and flavor, when warm and supplementing, preserve essence and form."*
This is what is meant by **harmonizing qi and flavor to supplement essence and strengthen qi**.

These five categories—**pungent, sour, sweet, bitter, and salty**—each have their uses: some **dispel**, some **contract**, some **relax**, some **urgently act**, some **fortify**, and some **soften**. They correspond to the **Four Seasons and Five Viscera**, and diseases follow the appropriate flavors.
Using the **Five Flavors to regulate the Five Viscera**—pairing the liver with sweet, the heart with sour, the spleen with salty, the lungs with bitter, and the kidneys with pungent—each is applied as needed, whether to **relax, contract, moisten, drain, disperse, or fortify**. This is not for the purpose of **mutual generation and nourishment**, but for **functional application**.

**End of the annotated commentary on the *Huangdi Neijing Suwen* (黄帝内经素问), Volume 17.** #1 *Yǐ* (倚) is the original reading.
#2 *Gān* (肝, liver) was originally *fèi* (肺, lungs), corrected according to the *Gu* edition.
#3 *Shū* (枢) is written as *guì* (柜) in the *Gu* edition.

**#4 *Kuí* (睽):** The *Gu* edition reads it as **"guì" (揆)**.

**#5 *Qi* (气):** Originally **"qián" (前)**, corrected according to the *Gu* edition.

**#6 *Bó* (搏):** The *Gu* edition reads it as **"bó" (搏)**. The following **"bó" (搏)** character is modeled similarly.

**#7 *Gān* (肝):** Originally **"pí" (脾)**, corrected according to the *Gu* edition.

**#8 *Mài* (脉):** Originally **"liǎn" (脸)**, corrected according to the *Gu* edition.

**#9 *Jī* (饥):** Originally **"jī" (肌)**, corrected according to the *Gu* edition.

**#10 *Fèi* (肺):** The *Gu* edition reads it as **"xíng" (形)**.

**#11 *Jiān* (肩):** Originally **"yǒu" (有)**, corrected according to the *Gu* edition.

**#12 *Yīn* (阴):** Originally omitted; supplemented according to the *Gu* edition.

**Title of the Sutra:** *Huangdi Neijing Suwen* Supplementary Commentary.

*The Huangdi Neijing Suwen* is a pre-Qin composition of unknown authorship, annotated by Tang Dynasty official Wang Bing, the *Taipu Ling* (太仆令) and *Qǐxuán Zǐ* (启玄子). The annotations were later verified by Song Dynasty officials Lin Yi (林亿) and others, with the title *Song Shǒushàngshū Tún Tián Láng* (宋守尚书屯田郎). The text was reexamined and erroneous readings corrected by Sun Zhao (孙兆).

**The "Xuanming Wǔqì" (宣明五气) Chapter**
*Supplementary Commentary on the Huangdi Neijing Suwen* – Volume 18.

**The "Xuanming Wǔqì" (宣明五气) Chapter**
*Supplementary Commentary on the Huangdi Neijing Suwen* – Volume 18.

**The Five Flavors and Their Corresponding Organs:**
The five flavors enter as follows:
Acid enters the liver—*the liver corresponds to wood and thus absorbs the flavor of acid*.
Pungent enters the lungs—*the lungs correspond to metal and thus absorb the flavor of pungent*.
Bitter enters the heart—*the heart corresponds to fire and thus absorbs the flavor of bitter*.
Salty enters the kidneys—*the kidneys correspond to water and thus absorb the flavor of salty*.
Sweet enters the spleen—*the spleen corresponds to earth and thus absorbs the flavor of sweet*.
*Newly corrected annotation:* According to the *Taipu* edition, it further states: *Mild enters the stomach*. This is called the "Five Entries."
*Newly corrected annotation:* According to the *Zhizhen Yaodalu* (至真要大论), it states: *The five flavors enter the stomach, each returning to what they favor. Thus, acid first enters the liver, bitter first enters the heart, sweet first enters the spleen, pungent first enters the lungs, and salty first enters the kidneys.*

**The Five Diseases of the Organs:**
The heart manifests as *sighing*—*it resembles fire blazing upward, and the sigh follows the flames. The heart does not endure filth, hence the sigh emerges.*
The lungs manifest as *coughing*—*they resemble metal’s firmness and strength; when struck, they produce sound. Evil *qi* strikes the lungs, hence the cough.*
*Cough:* pronounced as *kǔ* (苦盖切).
The liver manifests as *speech*—*it resembles wood’s branching tendrils, which are flexible and divergent. Speech should be yielding and indirect, hence it arises from the liver.*
The spleen manifests as *swallowing*—*it resembles earth’s capacity to contain and embrace; all things return inward, and its gathering nature accepts everything, hence the swallowing.*
*Gathering:* pronounced as *xī* (吸).
The kidneys manifest as *yawning* and *sneezing*—*they resemble water flowing downward, generating mist and clouds above. When *qi* stagnates in the stomach, yawning arises. The *Taiyang* *qi* harmonizes and flourishes, filling the heart, and when it emerges from the nose, it produces a sneeze.*
*Sneeze:* pronounced as *dì* (帝).
The stomach manifests as *reverse *qi* (gastric inversion), *hiccough*, and *fear*—*it is the sea of water and grain, and the kidneys serve as its gate. When the gate is closed and does not function smoothly, *qi* reverses and ascends. Because the stomach embraces water and grain and favors cold, the cold and grain *qi* clash, hence the hiccough. When cold is excessive, hiccoughs arise; when heat is excessive, fear emerges. Why? Heat in the stomach weakens kidney *qi*, hence the fear. The following passage states: *When the vital *qi* converges in the kidneys, fear arises.*
*Hiccough:* pronounced as *wù* (呼会切), resembling a bird’s cry.

The large and small intestines manifest as *diarrhea*—*the lower burner overflows as water. The large intestine is the repository of the Dao’s transmission, and the small intestine is the repository of what is received. When the *qi* of what is received is depleted, the transmission’s regulation fails, hence diarrhea occurs. The lower burner is where division and distribution take place; when *qi* is obstructed and cannot be expelled, it overflows as water.*
*Obstructed:* pronounced as *pí* (陂栗切).

The bladder, when not functioning smoothly, manifests as *□* (unclear term) and *incontinence*—*the bladder is the repository of fluids, and water is distributed through it. If the pulses of the foot *Sanjiao* are replete, it restrains the lower burner and prevents passage, hence no urination occurs. If the pulses of the foot *Sanjiao* are depleted, it fails to restrain the lower burner, hence incontinence arises.*
*The Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经) states: *The foot Sanjiao is the branch of the Taiyang meridian. Together with the Taiyang’s main meridian, it connects with the bladder’s network, restraining the lower burner. When replete, it closes and blocks the □ (unclear term); when depleted, it causes incontinence.*

The gallbladder manifests as *anger*—*it is upright yet decisive, without partiality or bias, and its nature is strong yet restrained, hence the emergence of anger.*
*The Liu Jie Zangxiang Lun* (六节藏象论) states: *The gallbladder holds the central position among the eleven organs.*
This is called the "Five Diseases."

**The Five Convergences of the Essences:**
When the vital *qi* converges in the heart, it produces *joy*—*the vital *qi* refers to the essence of fire. When the lungs are depleted and the heart’s essence converges with them, it results in joy.*
*The Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经) states: *Excessive joy and delight harm the *po* (魄).*
*The *po* is the spirit of the lungs, clarifying how the heart’s fire essence converges with the lungs’ metal essence.*

When it converges in the lungs, it produces *sadness*—*when the liver is depleted and the lungs’ *qi* converges with it, it results in sadness.*
*The Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经) states: *Sorrow and grief disturbing the center harm the *hun* (魂).*
*The *hun* is the spirit of the liver, clarifying how the lungs’ metal essence converges with the liver’s wood essence.*

When it converges in the liver, it produces *worry*—*when the spleen is depleted and the liver’s *qi* converges with it, it results in worry.*
*The Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经) states: *Persistent anxiety and melancholy harm the *yi* (意).*
*The *yi* is the spirit of the spleen, clarifying how the liver’s wood essence converges with the spleen’s earth essence.*
*When it converges in the spleen, it produces *fear*—*the original text states *hunger* (饥). When the kidneys are depleted and the spleen’s *qi* converges with them, it results in fear.*
*Fear:* meaning *fear and trepidation.*
*The Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经) states: *Persistent fear and dread harm the *jing* (精).*
*The *jing* is the spirit of the kidneys, clarifying how the spleen’s earth essence converges with the kidneys’ water essence.*

When it converges in the kidneys, it produces *fear*—*when the heart is depleted and the kidneys’ *qi* converges with it, it results in fear.*
*The Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经) states: *Restlessness, vigilance, and excessive thought harm the *shen* (神).*
*The *shen* is the master of the heart, clarifying how the kidneys’ water essence converges with the heart’s fire essence.*
*Restlessness and vigilance:* meaning *startled and fearful.*
These are all instances where the *shen* (正气) is insufficient, and the *victorious qi* (胜气) converges with it, thus resulting in these conditions. Hence, the following passage states: *This is called the "Five Convergences," where depletion leads to convergence.*

**The Five Detestations of the Organs:**
The heart detests heat—*heat causes the vessels to become turbid and sluggish.*
The lungs detest cold—*cold causes *qi* to stagnate.*
The liver detests wind—*wind causes the sinews to wither and contract.*
The spleen detests dampness—*dampness causes the flesh to slacken and swell.*
The kidneys detest dryness—*dryness causes the *jing* (精) to be exhausted and depleted.*
*Newly corrected annotation:* According to Yang Shangshan (杨上善), it states: *If we follow today’s conventions, it would read: "the lungs detest dryness." However, here it states "the lungs detest cold," and "the kidneys detest dryness," because dryness occurs at the beginning of autumn and cold at the end of winter. The lungs are associated with autumn, and since they greatly detest cold, it is stated as its end. The kidneys are associated with winter, and since they do not greatly detest dryness, it is stated as its beginning.*
This is called the "Five Detestations."

**The Five Transformations of Fluids:**
The heart generates *sweat*—*it drains through the skin.*
The lungs generate *nasal mucus*—*they moisten the nasal passages.*
The liver generates *tears*—*they flow into the eyes.*
The spleen generates *saliva*—*it overflows from the lips and mouth.*
The kidneys generate *saliva*—*it arises from the teeth.*
This is called the "Five Fluids."

**The Five Prohibitions of the Flavors:**
Pungent *qi* disperses *qi*—*when *qi* is diseased and weak, one should not consume excessive pungent flavors;*
*Diseased:* meaning *weakness that cannot overcome itself.*

「Bitter *qi* disperses blood—when blood is diseased, one should not consume excessive bitter flavors;
Salt *qi* disperses bone—when bone is diseased, one should not consume excessive salt;
*The Newly Corrected Edition* states: According to Huangfu Shian, salt first disperses the kidneys.
Here, "disperses blood" means that since the kidneys correspond to the Triple Burner, though blood vessels belong to the liver and heart, they follow the path of the middle burner, hence salt enters and disperses blood.
Bitter disperses the heart—here, "disperses bone" means that water and fire mutually assist, and bone-*qi* communicates with the heart.

Sweet disperses flesh—when flesh is diseased, one should not consume excessive sweetness;
Sour disperses sinews—when sinews are diseased, one should not consume excessive sourness.

All these are for accelerating *qi* movement, hence one should not consume too much.
Excessive consumption worsens the disease, so the diseased should not consume too much.
This is called the "Five Prohibitions," forbidding excessive intake.

*The Newly Corrected Edition* states: According to *The Great Essentials* (*Tai Su*), the Five Prohibitions are:
Liver disease prohibits pungent,
Heart disease prohibits salty,
Spleen disease prohibits sour,
Lung disease prohibits bitter,
Kidney disease prohibits sweet—
this is called the "Five Censorships."
Yang Shangshan says: When the mouth craves and one eats or drinks excessively, the *yarrow* stalks themselves censure it—this is called the Five Censorships.

**The Five Manifestations of Disease:**
Yin-diseases manifest in bone,
Yang-diseases manifest in blood,
Yin-diseases manifest in flesh—
Bone and flesh belong to yin and are tranquil, so yang-*qi* follows them.
Blood belongs to yang and is dynamic, so yin-*qi* seizes it.

Yang-diseases manifest in winter,
Yin-diseases manifest in summer—
Summer’s yang-*qi* is abundant, so yin-diseases manifest in summer.
Winter’s yin-*qi* is abundant, so yang-diseases manifest in winter.
Each follows its deficiency.
This is called the "Five Manifestations."

**The Five Disruptions by Evil:**
Evil entering yang causes madness;
Evil entering yin causes numbness.
Evil residing in yang’s vessels causes limbs to burn fiercely, hence madness.
Evil entering yin’s vessels causes the six channels to congeal and stagnate, hence numbness.
*Dì* (涩), pronounced *sè* (stiffness).

Striking yang causes vertigo—
Evil internally striking yang causes thin, rapid pulses, hence upper vertigo.
Striking yin causes [missing character]—
Evil internally striking yin causes pulses that do not flow, hence emaciation and inability to speak.

*The Newly Corrected Edition* states: According to *The Difficult Classic* (*Nan Jing*), excessive yang causes madness, excessive yin causes epilepsy.
Cao Yuanfang says: Evil entering yin causes epilepsy.
*The Pulse Classic* (*Mai Jing*) says: Yin adhering to yang causes madness, yang adhering to yin causes epilepsy.
Sun Simiao says: Evil entering yang causes madness, evil entering yin causes blood numbness; evil transmitted through yang causes epilepsy and tetany, evil transmitted through yin causes pain and emaciation.
Quan Yuanqi says: Once evil has entered yin and is transmitted to yang, with evil-*qi* flourishing and the viscera receiving evil, it causes loss of appetite, and the nourishing-*qi* fails to circulate through the body. Evil and righteous-*qi* clash, erupting as epilepsy.
Once evil has entered yang and is transmitted to yin, the viscera receive evil, hence inability to speak—this is the victory of evil over righteousness.
The theories of all schools differ; now they are all recorded.

When yang enters yin, it becomes tranquil;
When yin exits to yang, it becomes angry.
Disease follows where it goes.
*Zhī* (之), meaning "to go."

*The Newly Corrected Edition* states: According to Quan Yuanqi, yang entering yin causes tranquility, exiting causes fear.
*The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions* (*Qian Jin Fang*) says: Evil entering yin causes tranquility, yin exiting to yang causes anger.
This is called the "Five Disruptions."

**The Five Manifestations of Evil:**
Spring with autumn pulses,
Summer with winter pulses,
Late summer with spring pulses,
Autumn with summer pulses,
Winter with late summer pulses—
this is called "yin exiting to yang," where the disease is prone to anger and incurable.
This is called the "Five Evils," all sharing the same fate—death is inevitable.

*The Newly Corrected Edition* states: Yin exiting to yang causes anger, as seen earlier; this repetition disrupts the text’s logic—likely an error in ancient collation.

**What the Five Viscera Store:**
The heart stores *shén*—the transformation of vital essence and *qi*.
*The Spiritual Pivot* (*Ling Shu*) says: The convergence of two essences is called *shén*.
The lungs store *pò*—the auxiliary essence and *qi*.
*The Spiritual Pivot* says: The simultaneous inflow and outflow of essence is called *pò*.
The liver stores *hún*—the assistant to spiritual *qi*.
*The Spiritual Pivot* says: What follows *shén* in movement is called *hún*.
The spleen stores *yì*—memory without forgetting.
*The Spiritual Pivot* says: When the heart recalls, it is called *yì*.
The kidneys store *zhì*—focused intent without distraction.
*The Spiritual Pivot* says: Where intent resides is called *zhì*.
The kidneys receive the essence of the five viscera and six bowels, the root of original *qi*, and the foundation of life—acting as the gate for the stomach. Thus, *zhì* governs life’s continuity.

*The Newly Corrected Edition* states: According to Yang Shangshan, the kidneys consist of two parts: the left is the kidney, storing *zhì*; the right is the *Mingmen* (Gate of Life), storing essence.
This is called the "Five Viscera’s Stores."

**What the Five Viscera Govern:**
The heart governs the vessels—
It regulates nourishing-*qi*, moving with each breath.
The lungs govern the skin—
They envelop the front flesh, blocking all evils.
The liver governs the sinews—
They connect the joints, moving with the spirit.
The spleen governs the flesh—
The kidneys govern the bones—
The spleen governs flesh, covering and protecting sinews and bones, circulating defensive-*qi*.
The kidneys govern bones—
They stretch sinews, transform marrow, and support the body upright.
This is called the "Five Governances."

**The Five Exhaustions:**
Prolonged viewing harms blood—
Exhausting the heart.
Prolonged exposure harms *qi*—
Exhausting the lungs.
Prolonged sitting harms flesh,
Prolonged standing harms bones,
Prolonged walking harms sinews—
Prolonged sitting harms flesh—exhausting the spleen.
Prolonged standing harms bones—exhausting the kidneys.
Prolonged walking harms sinews—exhausting the liver.
This is called the "Five Exhaustions."

**The Five Pulses Corresponding to Symbols:**
The liver pulse is *xuán* (string-like)—
Deep, hollow, and slippery, straight and long.
The heart pulse is *gōu* (hooked)—
Like a hook lying down, strong on arrival, weak on departure.»

**The Five Viscera’s Pulses:**
The spleen pulse is *dài* (intermittent)—
Deep and weak.
The lung pulse is *máo* (downy)—
Light, floating, and hollow, like feathers.
The kidney pulse is *shí* (stony)—
Firm and forceful, like a stone cast.

This is called the **"Five Viscera’s Pulses."**

**The Blood, Qi, Form, and Will Section**
The natural constants of humankind:
The *Taiyang* [foot] channel is always abundant in blood and scarce in *qi*.
The *Shaoyang* [foot] channel is always scarce in blood and abundant in *qi*.
The *Yangming* [foot] channel is always abundant in *qi* and blood.
The *Shaoyin* [foot] channel is always scarce in blood and abundant in *qi*.
The *Jueyin* [foot] channel is always abundant in blood and scarce in *qi*.
The *Taiyin* [foot] channel is always abundant in *qi* and scarce in blood.
This is the **Heaven’s constant measure**.
The abundance or scarcity of blood and *qi*—this is Heaven’s constant measure.

Thus, the **Dao of Needling** always follows the principle of **reducing the excess**.

---
**Newly Corrected Version:**
According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*’s *"Twelve Channel Waters"*:
- *Yangming* (abundant blood and *qi*)—needle to a depth of **four *cù* (分)**, retain for **ten breaths**.
- *Taiyang* (abundant blood and *qi*)—needle to a depth of **five *cù* (分)**, retain for **seven breaths**.
- *Shaoyang* (scarce blood, abundant *qi*)—needle to a depth of **four *cù* (分)**, retain for **five breaths**.
- *Taiyin* (abundant blood, scarce *qi*)—needle to a depth of **three *cù* (分)**, retain for **four breaths**.
- *Shaoyin* (scarce blood, abundant *qi*)—needle to a depth of **two *cù* (分)**, retain for **three breaths**.
- *Jueyin* (abundant blood, scarce *qi*)—needle to a depth of **one *cù* (分)**, retain for **two breaths**.

The *Taiyang* and *Taiyin* channels’ blood and *qi* measures differ from the *Su Wen*.
Yet the *"Twenty-Five Physiognomies of Yin-Yang"* aligns with the *Su Wen*.
Huangfu Cong [皇甫謇] doubted and preserved both accounts.

---
**The Yin-Yang Pairings of the Hands and Feet:**
The *foot Taiyang* and *Shaoyin* are exterior-interior.
The *foot Shaoyang* and *Jueyin* are exterior-interior.
The *foot Yangming* and *Taiyin* are exterior-interior—
This is the **foot’s Yin-Yang**.

The *hand Taiyang* and *Shaoyin* are exterior-interior.
The *hand Shaoyang* and *heart channel* are exterior-interior.
The *hand Yangming* and *Taiyin* are exterior-interior—
This is the **hand’s Yin-Yang**.

Now, knowing the Yin-Yang afflictions of the hands and feet,
**In treating disease, one must first reduce the blood**,
Then address the suffering,
Observe the patient’s desires,
And only then **reduce the excess and supplement the deficient**.

*"First reduce the blood"* means:
When the blood vessels appear unusually full and distinct from the norm, then reduce them.
It does not mean that needling always begins by reducing the blood.

**Locating the Back Shu Points:**
First, measure the distance between the two nipples.
Fold it in half, then subtract half again.
The two remaining corners are used as a guide—
Hold them upright and apply to the back,
With one corner at the top aligned with the **Dàzhuī (大椎)**,
The two lower corners marking the **lung’s shu point** below.

*"Measure"* means to use grass to gauge the nipple span,
Removing a quarter, making the diagonal equal to the horizontal,
Folding into three corners—
When the upper corner aligns with the **Dàzhuī (大椎)**,
The lower corners mark the **lung’s shu point**.

*"Schù"* (拄) is pronounced *"zhù"* (俞).

Move downward one degree—this is the **heart’s shu point**.
That is, align the upper corner with the **third vertebra**.
Move downward one degree—
The left corner is the **liver’s shu point**,
The right corner is the **spleen’s shu point**.
Move downward one degree—this is the **kidney’s shu point**.

This is called the **"Five Viscera’s Shu Points"** and the **degrees for moxibustion and needling**.

The *Ling Shu Jing* and *Zhong Yue* both state:
- The **lung’s shu point** is beside the **third vertebra**,
- The **heart’s shu point** is beside the **fifth vertebra**,
- The **liver’s shu point** is beside the **ninth vertebra**,
- The **spleen’s shu point** is beside the **eleventh vertebra**,
- The **kidney’s shu point** is beside the **fourteenth vertebra**.

Examining this text’s grass-measuring method:
For an average person,
The first measurement’s lower corners roughly align with the **lung’s shu point**,
The second measurement’s lower corners roughly align with the **heart’s shu point**,
The third measurement’s lower corners roughly align with the **seventh vertebra**—
Beside the seventh vertebra lies the **Ge shu (鬲俞)**.

This text states:
*"The left corner is the liver’s shu point, the right corner is the spleen’s shu point,"*
Which differs from the *Zhong Yue* and other classics.
The fourth measurement’s lower corners roughly align with the **ninth vertebra**—
Beside the ninth vertebra lies the **liver’s shu point**.
The text mentions the **kidney’s shu point** but does not clarify its source.

**Form at Ease, Will in Distress—Disease Arises in the Pulses, Treated by Moxibustion and Needling.**
*"Form"* refers to the body’s physique.
*"Will"* refers to the mind’s intentions.
In detail, the **Seven Spirits** each govern their own domain;
In broad terms, they are categorized by **form and will** as interior and exterior.

*"Form at ease"* means not overburdening oneself with labor.
*"Will in distress"* means deep rumination and excessive thought.
Not overburdening oneself keeps sinews and bones harmonized;
Deep rumination and excessive thought disrupt the **honor and defense**, causing *qi* and blood to stagnate—
Thus, disease arises in the pulses.

The **principles of reducing excess and supplementing deficiency** are the **Dao of moxibustion and needling**.
Yet one must first reduce the **blood vessels** before regulating them—
Hence the earlier text states:
*"In treating disease, first reduce the blood, then address the suffering,
Observe the patient’s desires,
And only then reduce the excess and supplement the deficient."*

When **form and will are both at ease**, disease arises in the **flesh**,
And is treated with **needle and stone**.

「*"Will at ease"* means joyful and unrestrained, forgetting one’s worries.
Yet when sinews and bones are not labored, the mind and spirit are joyful and unrestrained,
Then the flesh’s pores align harmoniously, the **Dao of *qi*** overflows and fills,
The **defensive *qi*** becomes congested and knotted—
Thus, disease arises in the **flesh**.

The **defensive *qi*’s** lingering stagnation is treated with **needling to reduce** it;
Knotted **pus and blood** are broken with **stone needle**—
*Stone needle*, meaning the **lancing stone needle** (砭石).
Now it is also replaced with **external needles**.

*Trang* (锋), pronounced *bì* (铍).

*"Form in distress, will at ease"*—disease arises in the **sinews**, treated with **moxibustion and Daoist exercises**.
*Form in distress* means engaging in **scholarly or laborious pursuits**.
Yet when one overdoes scholarly or physical labor,
Exceeding proper measure, it leads to **exhaustion and injury**—
Exhaustion from labor then gives rise to injury, hence disease arises in the **sinews**.

*Moxibustion* refers to **herbal moxibustion** (药熨).
*Daoist exercises* means **guided stretching and movement** (导引).

*"Form in distress, will in distress"*—disease arises in **throat constriction and hoarseness** (咽隘),
And is treated with **various medicines** (百药).
When one engages in excessive labor and deep rumination,
Worry causes **liver *qi*** to merge with the **spleen**,
The liver and gallbladder unite,
And the throat becomes its conduit—
Thus, disease arises in **throat constriction**.

The *Sutra of the Five *Qi* of Manifestation* (《宣明五气篇》) states:
*"When vital essence and *qi* merge in the liver, one falls into worry."*

The *Treatise on Strange Diseases* (《奇病论》) says:
*"The liver is the general of the central body,
Its decisions hinge on the gallbladder,
And the throat serves as its messenger."*

To practice true benevolence and forgiveness in loving others,
and to harmonize with the dust and toil of life without seeking advancement,
avoids the injury of Zhang Yi’s high-gated arrogance—this is to nourish the form externally.
When internal and external nourishment are fully realized,
one need not seek life and yet lives long,
need not seek longevity and yet attains it—
this is the ultimate of the Daoist’s art in nurturing the form.

The Emperor of Primordial Mystery said:
*'The highest is to nurture the spirit;
the next is to nurture the form.'*
Examining Wang’s commentary,
it focuses solely on nurturing the spirit in the practice of acupuncture,
a view that is too narrow compared to Shangshan’s teachings.

If one were to interpret these five principles as applying only to the moment of acupuncture,
then the following passage on knowing poisonous medicines as true would be misconstrued,
and Wang’s theory would not be limited solely to acupuncture as its solution.

**Three:** *Knowing poisonous medicines as true*—
poisonous medicines attack evil,
and their use must conform to what is fitting and proper—
this is the true Dao of healing.

**Four:** *Mastering the size of the phlebotomy stone*—
In ancient times, the phlebotomy stone was used as a needle,
so the *Nine Needles* are not mentioned here—only the phlebotomy stone.
When crafting its size,
it must be used according to the disease’s requirements.

*New Annotation:* According to Quan Yuanqi:
*The phlebotomy stone is an ancient external treatment with three names:
one called *needle-stone*, two called *phlebotomy stone*, three called *cauterizing stone*—
in essence, they are the same.
In ancient times, iron could not be cast,
so stone was used as a needle.
Thus, it was named *needle-stone*,
speaking of its craftsmanship—sharpened and honed to a fine edge,
its size adjusted to match the disease.
The Yellow Emperor created the *Nine Needles* to replace the cauterizing stone.
In the most ancient treatments,
each method was applied as appropriate.
In the regions of the *Bundle States*, many suffered from atrophy and swelling,
so the phlebotomy stone emerged there.

**Five:** *Knowing the diagnosis of blood and qi in the reservoirs and storage organs*—
The *Six Yang* are reservoirs, the *Six Yin* are storage organs.
Thus, the *Blood and Qi, Form and Will* chapter states:
*The Greater Yang has abundant blood and little qi;
the Lesser Yang has little blood and abundant qi;
the Yang Brightness has abundant qi and little blood;
the Lesser Yin has little blood and abundant qi;
the Sinking Yin has abundant blood and little qi;
the Greater Yin has abundant qi and little blood.*

Thus, when puncturing the Yang Brightness, one releases blood and evil qi;
when puncturing the Greater Yang, one releases blood and evil qi;
when puncturing the Lesser Yang, one releases qi and evil blood;
when puncturing the Greater Yin, one releases qi and evil blood;
when puncturing the Lesser Yin, one releases qi and evil blood;
when puncturing the Sinking Yin, one releases blood and evil qi.
To know precisely the excess or deficiency,
and to supplement accordingly, ensures complete efficacy.
The five methods stand complete,
each with its priority.
When the situation demands it, apply accordingly.

In the present age of acupuncture,
one treats the empty as if full,
and the full as if empty—
this is what all practitioners commonly know.
But to follow Heaven and conform to Earth,
to move in response to circumstances,
harmonizing like echoes, following like shadows—
the Dao has no need of ghosts or spirits,
coming and going alone.
To move in response to circumstances speaks to its efficacy;
like shadows and echoes, it speaks to its immediacy.
How could there be any need for summoning ghosts or spirits?
It is only because one moves in response to circumstances naturally.

The Emperor said:
*'I wish to hear its method.'*

Geben said:
*'The true essence of acupuncture
must first cultivate the spirit.
Concentrate the spirit,
quiet and undisturbed—
this is the true essence of acupuncture.

Only after the five storage organs are settled
and the nine diagnostic regions are examined,
should one then consider the needle.
The seven diagnostic methods must be precise,
and the five storage organs must not be in rebellion.
Externally and internally, the form and qi must align,
and one must not impose their own form upon the patient.

When the patient’s condition is thoroughly understood,
then the needle may be applied.
To "play" with the diagnosis means mastery.
The *Discourse on the Transmission of Disease from Root to Branch* states:
*"Master the yin and yang thoroughly,
and do not consult with the masses."*
This is of the same kind.

*New Annotation:* This passage originates from the *Discourse on Yin-Yang Differentiation*,
not the *Discourse on the Transmission of Disease from Root to Branch*, as mistakenly stated.

The patient’s condition may be empty or full.
Do not approach when the five storage organs are empty,
and do not retreat when they are full.
When the moment arrives,
the decision must be made without hesitation.

The patient’s emptiness or fullness
does not arise from mere distance or proximity,
but from the momentary ebb and flow of blood and qi.
Before its manifestation,
it is like a cloud hanging—visible but slow to change;
when it manifests,
it is like lightning flashing—too swift for the finger to follow.
The difference in speed is thus.

*New Annotation:* In the *A-B Canon*, the character is □.
Quan Yuanqi’s original text and the *Taisu* also use □.
□ is pronounced *shùn* (顺).

When the hand moves with intent,
the needle gleams evenly.
The hand moves with the needle,
the mind focused as if on a single task.
The *Needle Classic* says:
*"Unify the form,
listen to its movement and stillness,
and know the evil and the true."*
This is what is meant.

*The needle gleams evenly*
refers to the needle’s form,
its cold light evenly balanced above and below.

With a still mind and measured breath,
observe the changes in the patient’s condition—
this is called *sufficiently subtle*,
where even the form of the unseen is discerned.
Though the needle’s work is precise and the intent profound,
one still cannot fathom the shifting forms of blood and qi.

*New Annotation:* According to the *Eight Regulations of Divine Clarity*:
*"Observing the subtle*
speaks of the form and qi of the *honor* and *defense* mechanisms,
which do not manifest externally,
yet the skilled practitioner alone perceives them—
adjusting according to the day’s cold or warmth,
the month’s emptiness or fullness,
and the seasonal qi’s ascent or descent,
harmonizing them in combination.
The practitioner often sees these changes beforehand,
though they do not manifest externally,
hence the saying: *observing the subtle.*"

「When the practitioner observes its *wūwū* (dark and obscure), its *jìjì* (dense and concentrated), following the sight of its *fēi* (soaring), yet does not know its master—
*Wūwū* is when one marvels at the arrival of the *qi*;
*Jìjì* is when one laments its response.

The *qi* obtained from the needle, like watching a crow soar in the sky,
who could possibly know the original source that summons it?
It is merely seen as the ebb and flow of the *jingmai* (meridian vessels),
yet one still does not grasp who calls it forth.

When it lies dormant, it is like a crossbow held steady;
when it rises, it is like a trigger released.
Before blood and *qi* respond to the needle, they rest quietly, like a crossbow at ease;
when they respond to the needle, they surge forth swiftly, like a trigger loosed.

The Yellow Emperor asked: How does one determine when it is *xū* (empty)?
How does one determine when it is *shí* (full)?

The practitioner does not merely rely on the arrival of the *qi*—
its empty and full states cannot be fixed by simply counting breaths!
The criteria for its empty and full forms are not so rigid—
how then does one discern them?

Gūbó replied: When needling the *shí* (full), one must await its *xū* (empty);
when needling the *xū* (empty), one must await its *shí* (full).
This means one must rely on the *qi*’s arrival to have effect—
not rigidly adhering to breath counts as a fixed rule.

Once the *jingqi* (meridian *qi*) has arrived,
guard it carefully and do not let it slip away—
do not alter the method and lose the *jingqi*.

Depth and shallowness depend on intent;
far and near are as one.
Like standing at the edge of a deep abyss,
one’s hand grips like holding a tiger—
the spirit does not stray among myriad things.

This speaks of focused concentration.
The *jingmai* (meridian vessels) and *qi* needled,
though their depths vary,
yet their supplementation and reduction are equal—
the practitioner’s singular intent makes the hand firm as grasping a tiger,
and the spirit does not wander externally.

*New Annotation:* According to the *Zhēnjiě Lùn*:
When needling the *shí* (full), one must await its *xū* (empty)—
leave the needle until the *yīnqi* (yin *qi*) surges forth, then remove it.
When needling the *xū* (empty), one must await its *shí* (full)—
leave the needle until the *yángqi* (yang *qi*) rises and warmth appears beneath the needle, then remove it.
Once the *jingqi* (meridian *qi*) has arrived,
guard it carefully and do not let it slip away—
do not change the method or lose the *jingqi*.
Depth and shallowness depend on intent—
one must know the disease’s internal or external nature.
Far and near are as one—
the signs of depth and shallowness are equal in severity.
Like standing at the edge of a deep abyss—
one must not dare to falter.
Hand as firm as grasping a tiger—
one must act with boldness and strength.
Spirit does not stray among myriad things—
calm the intent and observe the patient,
without glancing left or right.

#13 *Steel*: Originally 『攻』 (*attack*), corrected to 『戾』 (*steel*) according to the *Gùběn* (Metropolitan Museum Edition).
#14 *Distracted*: The spirit does not stray among myriad things.」

「#2 Illumination: Originally 『名』 (*name*), corrected to 『明』 (*illumination*) according to the *Gùběn* (Metropolitan Museum Edition).
#3 Lesser Yang: Originally 『是伤』 (*this injury*), corrected to 『少阳』 (*Lesser Yang*) according to the *Gùběn*.
#4 Knows: Originally 『之』 (*it*), corrected to 『知』 (*knows*) according to the *Gùběn*.
