Annotated by *Táng Tàipù Lìng Qǐ Xuānzǐ Wáng Bīng*, revised by *Sòng Guānglù Qīng Zhí Mìgé Lín Yì* et al., corrected by *Sòng Shǒushù Shàngshū Fúntián Láng Sūn Zhào*.」

**Eight Correct Principles of Divine Clarity (Bā Zhèng Shén Míng Lùn) Discourse**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"The use of needles for treatment must surely follow certain principles and rules. What are these principles and rules today?"*
(*"Service" (服), "principles" (法), "rules" (则).*)

Qībó replied: *"Follow the Dao of Heaven and align with the Earth, harmonizing with celestial luminosity."* (*i.e., the movements of the sun, moon, stars, and constellations.*)

The Yellow Emperor said: *"I wish to hear this fully."*

Qībó said: *"In general, the principles of acupuncture must observe the sun’s warmth and cold, the moon’s waxing and waning, the stars and constellations, and the eight correct seasonal rhythms of qi. Only when the qi is stable may one administer treatment.*

*Observing the sun and moon refers to noting the sun’s warmth or cold and the moon’s phases of fullness or emptiness. The stars and constellations refer to first knowing the divisions of the Twenty-Eight Lunar Mansions and their correspondence with the water clock’s divisions.*

*Briefly put, one adds the sun’s position to the mansions above, thus knowing whether human qi resides in the Greater Yang (太阳) or not. When the sun moves one mansion, human qi is in the Three Yang and Yin divisions.*

*More precisely, from the mansion Fáng (房) to Bì (毕)—fourteen mansions—fifty water clock divisions pass, marking half the day. From the mansion Xù (勖) to Xīn (心)—also fourteen mansions—fifty water clock divisions pass, marking the full day. Thus, from Fáng to Bì is yang, from Xù to Xīn is yin, yang governing the day, yin governing the night.*

*Nearly every day, the sun moves one mansion, so the water clock marks three divisions and seven subdivisions (四) in total.*

*The *Língshū Jīng* states: *"One water clock division, human qi is in the Greater Yang; two divisions, human qi is in the Lesser Yang; three divisions, human qi is in the Yang Brightness; four divisions, human qi is in the Yin divisions. The water clock divisions do not stop, and the movement of qi follows accordingly."*

*It further states: *"When the sun moves one mansion, human qi circulates one full cycle of the body and eight-tenths of another. When the sun moves two mansions, human qi circulates three full cycles and six-tenths of another. When the sun moves three mansions, human qi circulates five full cycles and four-tenths of another. When the sun moves four mansions, human qi circulates seven full cycles and two-tenths of another. When the sun moves five mansions, human qi circulates nine full cycles. Yet when the sun moves twenty-eight mansions, human qi circulates fifty full cycles and four-tenths of another. Thus, one must observe the sun, moon, stars, and constellations."*

*The eight correct seasonal rhythms of qi refer to the winds of the eight nodes that gather at the Supreme One (太一). One must observe where these winds reside before treating. The phrase "only when the qi is stable may one administer treatment" means that when the winds of the eight nodes have settled, one may then treat the channels and collaterals, balancing emptiness and fullness.*

*Hence, the *Lìjì* (Calendar of Taboos) states: *"For five days before and after each of the eight nodes, one must not administer acupuncture or moxibustion, or disaster will follow."* This is because the qi has not yet settled, so treatment is forbidden.*

**Newly corrected annotations state:** *"The winds of the eight nodes gathering at the Supreme One are detailed in the *Tiānyuán Yùcè* (Celestial Origins’ Jade Register)."*

*Thus, when Heaven is warm and the sun is bright, human blood is pure and the defensive qi ascends, making blood easy to disperse and qi easy to move. When Heaven is cold and the sun is obscured, human blood congeals and the defensive qi descends. (*"Congeals" (凝泣) refers to blood settling like snow in water. "Dissipate" (写) is pronounced as *yì* (slave teaching), meaning "abundant."*)*

*When the moon first appears, blood and qi begin to refine, and the defensive qi begins to circulate. When the moon reaches fullness, blood and qi are abundant, and the flesh and muscles firm. When the moon’s fullness wanes, the flesh and muscles weaken, the channels and collaterals become empty, the defensive qi departs, and the form stands alone.*

*Therefore, one must regulate blood and qi according to the seasons. When Heaven is cold, one must not disperse, for blood congeals and defensive qi descends. When Heaven is warm, there is no congealing. Blood is pure and qi moves easily. When the moon is new, one must not disperse; when the moon is full, one must not supplement; when the moon’s fullness wanes, one must not treat. This is called aligning with the seasons.*

(*i.e., observing the natural order of Heaven.*)

*Following Heaven’s sequence, supplementing or dispersing at the proper time, adjusting light and position, and standing upright to await the moment. One must observe the sun’s movement, determine the qi’s location, stand facing south, and wait for the qi to arrive before regulating it.*

*Thus, dispersing when the sun and moon are new is called "emptying the storage" (*藏虚*), meaning "blood and qi are weak."*

**Newly corrected annotations state:** *"In the original text, ‘storage’ (藏) was mistakenly written as ‘caustic’ (咸#1); it should be ‘empty’ (虚)."*

*Supplementing when the moon is full is called "excessive fullness" (*重实*), for blood and qi overflow, and the collaterals retain stagnant blood. (*"Collaterals" (络) are also channels (经); this is an error. "Stagnant" (留) should be "flowing" (流). This is incorrect.*)*
(*i.e., "blood and qi are abundant."*)

*When the moon’s fullness wanes, treating is called "disordering the channels" (*乱经*), for yin and yang become confused, true and false qi indistinguishable, stagnation causing retention, external emptiness and internal disorder, and licentious pathogens arising. (*"Qi loses its measure" (气失纪), so licentious pathogens arise.*)*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How does one observe the stars and the eight correct seasonal rhythms?"*

Qībó replied: *"The stars and constellations are what regulate the sun and moon’s movements. (*"Regulate" (制) means "institutionalize."*)*

*By establishing the stars and constellations, one may know the sun and moon’s institutionalized movements.*

*Briefly put, the Twenty-Eight Lunar Mansions of the Great Heavenly Cycle are divided into thirty-six parts. When human qi completes one full cycle, it nearly reaches eighteen parts. The body’s circumference is sixteen *zhàng* (丈) and two *chǐ* (尺), corresponding to the Twenty-Eight Mansions. Combined with the water clock’s hundred divisions, the total movement is eight hundred and ten *zhàng*, dividing day and night.*

*Thus, for every ten breaths, qi moves six *chǐ*, and the sun moves two divisions. Two hundred and seventy breaths, qi moves sixteen *zhàng* and two *chǐ*, completing one full cycle of the body, with the water clock marking two divisions and the sun moving twenty divisions. Five hundred and forty breaths, qi completes two full cycles of the body, the water clock marks four divisions, and the sun moves forty divisions. Two thousand seven hundred breaths, qi completes ten full cycles of the body, the water clock marks twenty divisions, and the sun moves five mansions and twenty divisions. Thirteen thousand five hundred breaths, qi completes fifty full cycles of the body, the water clock marks one hundred divisions, and the sun moves the Twenty-Eight Mansions.*

*More precisely, one must add one full cycle of ten divisions and six-tenths of another, thus exhausting all the odd subdivisions."*

Thus, the stars and constellations are used to regulate the movements and degrees of the sun and moon.

○The newly corrected text states: *"The detailed explanation of the Twenty-Eight Mansions completing a full cycle as the sun moves through the Twenty-Eight Mansions is taken from the original text of the *Ling Shu Jing* [《灵枢经》]. Now it is fully elaborated in the *Jia Yi Jing* [《甲乙经》]."*

The Eight Directions serve to observe the **Eight Winds**—the **Dao/Way’s** pernicious **qi**—as they arrive at appointed times. The Eight Directions refer to the **Dao/Way’s** rectified **qi** of the Eight Nodes. The Eight Winds are:
- **East** (束方): the **Ying Xi** [婴兄] Wind,
- **South** (南方): the **Great Weak** [大弱] Wind,
- **West** (西方): the **Strong** [刚] Wind,
- **North** (北方): the **Great Strong** [大刚] Wind,
- **Southeast** (束北方): the **Fierce** [凶] Wind,
- **Southwest** (束南方): the **Weak** [弱] Wind,
- **Southwest** (西南方): the **Plotting** [谋] Wind,
- **Northeast** (西北方): the **Folding** [折] Wind.

**Pernicious qi** refers to that which seizes upon the body’s vulnerabilities and causes illness. **Arriving at appointed times** means that when the **Dao/Way’s** **Great Unity** [太一] shifts its abode, the Eight Winds, in accordance with the **Dao/Way’s** Nodes, strike the **Central Official** [中官] and arrive.

○The newly corrected text states: *"The detailed explanation of the **Great Unity** shifting its abode and the Eight Winds striking the **Central Official** is fully elaborated in the *Tian Yuan Yu Ce* [《天元玉册》]."*

The Four Seasons are used to partition the **Dao/Way’s** **qi** of spring, autumn, winter, and summer, adjusting it according to the times, and to avoid the pernicious **qi** of the Eight Directions so as not to be afflicted. The **Dao/Way’s** **qi** of each season manifests as follows:
- **Spring qi** resides in the **meridians** [经] and **muscles** [豚],
- **Summer qi** resides in the **collaterals** [络] and **tendons** [孙],
- **Autumn qi** resides in the **skin** [皮] and **flesh** [肤],
- **Winter qi** resides in the **bones** [骨] and **marrow** [髓].

If one is exposed to pernicious **qi**, the **True qi** [真气] of the body is disturbed, and if one avoids it and does not transgress, illness will not arise. The *Ling Shu Jing* [《灵枢经》] says: *"The sage avoids evil **Dao/Way**, as one avoids arrows and stones."* This is because such **qi** can harm the **True qi**. When the body’s vulnerabilities coincide with the **Dao/Way’s** vulnerabilities, the two **qi**s resonate, and the **Dao/Way’s** **qi** reaches the bones. If it enters, it injures the **Five Zang** [五藏]. This is because **Dao/Way’s** vulnerabilities resonate with the body’s vulnerabilities, and **qi**s of similar nature respond to each other. The skilled practitioner can rescue it, and thus it cannot harm. If observed correctly, it will not harm; hence, the saying: *"The **Dao/Way’s** taboos must not be unknown."* The body’s taboos are in relation to the **Dao/Way’s** taboos, hence the term **"Dao/Way’s** taboos." If one transgresses them, illness arises, hence they must not be unknown.

The Emperor said: *"Good."* I have heard the method of the stars and constellations, but I wish to hear the method of the ancients.

**Gui Bo** [岐伯] replied: *"The method of the ancients is to first master the *Zhen Jing* [《针经》]."* To verify it in the present, one must first know the sun’s cold and warm phases, the moon’s waxing and waning, and observe the **Dao/Way’s** **qi**’s rise and fall to adjust it within the body, thus ensuring the efficacy of treatment. If the **Dao/Way’s** **qi** is observed without error, treatment will be effective.

To **observe its subtlety** [冥冥], it means that the **form**, **Dao/Way’s** **qi**, and the **Nourishing** [荣] and **Defensive** [卫] **qi** do not manifest externally, yet only the skilled practitioner knows them. This clarifies the meaning of the previous section’s *"quietly gaze"* [静意视], observing the **Dao/Way’s** **qi**’s changes—this is called **subtlety**, for its form is unknown.

Though the **form**, **Dao/Way’s** **qi**, and the **Nourishing** and **Defensive** **qi** do not appear externally, the skilled practitioner, through clear intuition and divine insight, alone discerns their waxing and waning, and can distinguish good from evil.

○The newly corrected text states: *"By correlating the sun’s cold and warm phases, the moon’s waxing and waning, and the Four Seasons’ **Dao/Way’s** **qi**’s rise and fall, the practitioner harmonizes them and often perceives these changes beforehand. However, they do not manifest externally, hence the saying: 'to observe its subtlety.' The practitioner’s ability to perceive them beforehand arises from what? It is because they adhere to the principles and possess clear intuition. Intuition that extends to the infinite allows them to pass it on to future generations, hence the practitioner’s distinction. Principles being established make transmission possible, and if transmission continues unbroken, their intuitive understanding will extend infinitely. Because they alone perceive and know, the practitioner thus differs from others. Yet these changes do not manifest externally, hence both they and others cannot see them. The practitioner’s distinction from the coarse lies in the fact that the coarse cannot perceive them. The **form** is invisible, the **taste** is inaudible, hence the term **subtlety**—like the **Dao/Way’s** **qi** of the divine hair and beard. It speaks of the **form** and **Dao/Way’s** **qi**, and the **Nourishing** and **Defensive** **qi** not manifesting externally, and thus being unseen, hence 'invisible to the eye,' 'tasteless to the tongue.' Hidden like a crossbow drawn, rising like a trigger released, deep and unfathomable, no one knows the origin—this is like the **Dao/Way’s** **qi** of the divine hair and beard."*

**Pernicious qi** refers to the **Dao/Way’s** pernicious **qi** of the Eight Directions. The **Dao/Way’s** pernicious **qi** of the Eight Directions refers to the pernicious **qi** of the Eight Nodes. It comes from the realm of vulnerabilities and seizes upon them to enter and cause illness, hence it is called the **Eight Winds’ pernicious qi**.

**Pernicious and rectified** [正邪] **qi** refers to when the body’s **form** is strained by exertion and sweat emerges, the **Dao/Way’s** **True qi** [胜理] is exposed. If it encounters even one pernicious wind, the person within becomes faint, hence the saying: *"No one knows its nature, no one sees its form."* **Rectified and pernicious** **qi** does not come from the realm of vulnerabilities. Because the person within becomes faint, no one knows their intentions, nor sees their appearance.

The skilled practitioner rescues it at its inception, ensuring they first perceive the **Three Divisions** [三部] and **Nine Observations** [九候] of the **Dao/Way’s** **qi**, fully harmonizing it so that it does not fail and thus saving it—hence the term **skilled practitioner**. The lesser practitioner rescues it after it has already taken form, after it has already failed. To rescue it after it has taken form means that they do not know the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations** of the **Dao/Way’s** **qi**, and thus illness arises and it is too late to save.

○The meaning is fully elaborated in the *Li He Zhen Xie Lun* [《离合真邪论》]*.

To know its location means to know the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations** of the illness’s **pulse** [脉] and then to treat it, hence the saying: *"to guard its gateways."* No one knows its nature, yet its **form** is seen. The **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations** are the gateways for observing **Dao/Way’s** pernicious **qi**. To guard the gateways means to see the **form** of the pernicious **qi**. Because the person within becomes faint, no one knows its nature.

The Emperor said: *"I have heard of the methods of supplementation and drainage, but I have not grasped their meaning."*

Qi Bo replied: *"Drainage must follow the **right timing** [方], for **timing** means when **qi** is at its peak, when the moon is full, when the sun is warm, when the body is at rest, and when the breath is inhaled inward before inserting the needle. Then, one must wait for the exhalation to turn the needle and withdraw it slowly. Hence, drainage must follow the **right timing**, allowing the **qi** to flow accordingly. **Timing** is akin to **correctness**.

When pernicious **qi** is drained out, the true **qi** will flow freely. **Supplementation** must follow **movement** [员], for **movement** means **propulsion**, and **propulsion** refers to dispersing stagnant **qi** so that it must circulate freely. **Movement** also means redirecting unhealed pulses to restore balance. Needling must strike the **honorific vessels** [荣], withdrawing with inhalation to expel. When the needle reaches the blood, it is called striking the **honorific vessels**.

Thus, **timing** and **movement** are not about the needle’s shape but about the principles of **propulsion** and **redirection**. Therefore, nurturing the **spirit** [神] requires knowing the body’s fatness or leanness, the flourishing or decline of **honorific** and **defensive** **qi**, blood, and **qi**—for blood and **qi** are the essence of human **spirit**, which must be carefully nurtured. When the **spirit** is at peace, life extends; when the **spirit** departs, the body decays. Hence, it must be carefully nurtured.

The Emperor said: *"How profound your discourse! You harmonize the human form with **Yin** and **Yang**, the responses of emptiness and fullness, the mysterious and the apparent. Who but you could comprehend this? Yet you often speak of **form** and **spirit**—what do you mean by **spirit**? What do you mean by **form**? I wish to hear it fully."*

**Spirit** refers to enlightened awareness. **Form** refers to the observable **form**—what can be examined through physical diagnosis.

Qi Bo said: *"Let me speak of **form**. **Form** is what the eyes cannot see—when you ask about a patient’s ailment, the *newly corrected text* notes: ‘By pressing where it hurts’ [按其所痛], which also makes sense. Seek it along the **meridians**, and it appears clearly before you. Pressing finds nothing, yet its nature is unknown—hence, **form**. Externally, it hides its formlessness, so the eyes see nothing. Internally, it conceals its presence, yet diagnosis can trace it along the **meridians**. ‘Appearing suddenly before you’ means that within the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations**, it may suddenly appear without warning. The *Li He Zhen Xie Lun* states: ‘In **Yin** and **Yang**, it cannot be measured. Follow it through the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations**, and it may suddenly appear—then block its path early. This is its meaning.’

The Emperor said: ‘What is **spirit**?’

Qi Bo replied: *"Let me speak of **spirit**. **Spirit** is what the ears cannot hear—yet the eyes see clearly, the heart opens, and the will acts first. Sudden enlightenment dawns, though words cannot express it. All may look, yet only one sees. It seems as if in darkness, yet one alone perceives with sudden clarity, like clouds dispersed by wind. Hence, it is called **spirit**.

‘The ears cannot hear’ speaks to the subtlety of **spirit’s** work. ‘The eyes see clearly, the heart opens, and the will acts first’ means the heart’s understanding is like a scroll unrolled, the eyes’ vision like mist clearing—though **spirit** is internally unified, the will has already moved ahead. ‘Sudden enlightenment’ refers to clarity and insight. ‘Though words cannot express it’ means the heart is clear and understood, yet speech cannot convey it. ‘All may look, yet one sees alone’—it seems as if in darkness, yet one suddenly perceives. Once alone in insight, the eyes alone see clearly, like clouds scattering under wind, sunlight breaking through—how profound is **spirit**! Its wonders are beyond words.

Its principles stem from the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations**; the theories of the **Nine Needles** need not be retained. If the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations** of the **meridians** are taken as foundation, then the mysteries of **spirit** and enlightenment can be mastered. If one discards the **Nine Needles** theories, knowledge will only grow broader, yet understanding will remain distant. Hence, the **Three Divisions** and **Nine Observations** are the root—discarding the **Nine Needles** theories is unnecessary."*

---

**Li He Zhen Xie Lun** [《离合真邪论》]

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I have heard of the **Nine Needles** and their nine principles. You have expanded them into ninety-nine—eighty-one treatises. I have grasped their meaning. The classics speak of the rise and fall of **qi**, its leftward and rightward shifts, adjusting the upper to the lower, the left to the right, and supplementing or draining at **honorific** and **transporting** points. I understand this. These are the shifts of **honorific** and **defensive** **qi**, the origins of emptiness and fullness—not pernicious **qi** entering the **meridians** from outside.

I wish to hear of pernicious **qi** within the **meridians**: how does it affect the patient, and how should it be treated?"*

Qi Bo answered: *"The sages established their measurements to align with Heaven and Earth. Thus, Heaven has the **mansions** [宿], Earth has the **classifying waters** [经水], and humans have **meridians**. **Mansions** refer to the Twenty-Eight **Mansions**. **Classifying waters** are the seas: the **Sea**, the **Jing** River, the **Wei** River, **Hu** Lake, the **Mian** River, the **Ru** River, the **Jiang** River, the **Huai** River, the **Luo** River, the **He** River, the **Zang** River, and the **Ji** River—named so because they internally correspond to the **meridians**. **Meridians** refer to the **meridians** of the hands and feet, the three **Yin** and three **Yang**.

The *newly corrected text* notes: ‘The **foot Yang Ming** externally corresponds to the **Sea**, internally to the **stomach**; the **foot Tai Yang** externally to the **Jing** River, internally to the **bladder**; the **foot Shao Yang** externally to the **Wei** River, internally to the **gallbladder**; the **foot Tai Yin** externally to **Hu** Lake, internally to the **spleen**; the **foot Jue Yin** externally to the **Mian** River, internally to the **liver**; the **foot Shao Yin** externally to the **Ru** River, internally to the **kidneys**; the **hand Yang Ming** externally to the **Jiang** River, internally to the **large intestine.’"*

The **hand Tai Yang** externally corresponds to the **Huai River**, internally to the **small intestine**; the **hand Shao Yang** externally to the **Luo River**, internally to the **San Jiao**; the **hand Tai Yin** externally to the **He River**, internally to the **lung**; the **hand Jue Yin** externally to the **Zhang River**, internally to the **heart wrapper**.

When the **Heaven and Earth** are temperate and harmonious, the **meridian waters** remain tranquil; when **Heaven is cold and Earth frozen**, the **meridian waters** congeal and weep; when **Heaven is scorching and Earth hot**, the **meridian waters** boil and overflow; when **sudden winds rage**, the **meridian waters** surge and rise in waves. The **human meridians** likewise respond.

When **evil** enters the **pulses**, cold causes the blood to congeal and weep, while heat makes the **qi** pure and moist. If **emptiness-evil** seizes the opportunity to invade, it is like the **meridian waters** encountering wind—when the **pulses move**, they also rise and fall at times, flowing smoothly within the **meridians**, smoothly, smoothly—moving in accordance with the **meridian’s** ebb and flow, following the rhythm of inhalation and exhalation, though their form may vary.

When it reaches the **cun-kou** of the **middle hand**, it is sometimes large, sometimes small. When large, **evil** has arrived; when small, it is balanced. Its course has no fixed location—large refers to the **pulse’s** usual diagnostic form, while small does not mean fine, but rather, in comparison to large, it is called small. If there is no large for comparison, then it is merely the ordinary **meridian qi**.

However, **evil qi** follows **yin qi** into **yin meridians** and **yang qi** into **yang meridians**, hence its course has no fixed location. Whether in **yin** or **yang**, it cannot be measured, for it follows the **meridian’s** flow. By observing it, the **three regions and nine candidates**—if suddenly encountered—must be pressed and halted, met and drained. When the path is cut off, the **great evil qi** cannot prevail.

What is meant by *draining*? As the later text states: *"Inhale and insert the needle, ensuring the **qi** does not disperse; remain still and dwell, preventing **evil** from spreading. Exhale and turn the needle, taking **qi** as the criterion. Wait for exhalation to withdraw, and when fully exhaled, depart. Thus, the **great qi** is fully released, hence it is called draining."*

According to the **meridian’s** principle, one must first **supplement true qi** before draining **evil**. How so? The later **supplementation method** states: *"When exhalation is complete, insert the needle and dwell still."* In this **draining method**, *"Inhale and insert the needle, then dwell still."* Though the timing of inhalation and exhalation differs—when inhaling, there is no exhalation—since the moment of insertion and the duration of dwelling are the same, the priority of **supplementation** becomes clear.

The *Needle Classic* says: *"Draining is called welcoming—holding the needle crosswise and inserting it, releasing and withdrawing it, expelling **yang** with the needle, allowing **evil qi** to escape."* **Supplementation** is called following—like forgetting, like moving forward, like repenting, like the buzzing of a mosquito, like lingering and returning. Thus, **supplementation** involves prolonged dwelling with the needle.

The reason **supplementation** comes first is that if **true qi** is insufficient, the needle will drain it, leaving the **meridian** unfilled. If **evil qi** has no outlet to expel, **supplementation** must first fortify **true qi** before draining **evil**.

*Withdraw* means to draw out; *depart* means to leave the **acupoint**. When exhalation is complete, withdraw to the **acupoint’s** threshold, and when fully exhaled, leave the **acupoint’s** gate. Thus, the **meridian qi** settles and stabilizes, and **evil qi** has no place to linger, so the **great evil qi** follows the needle outward.

*Exhalation* refers to **qi** exiting; *inhalation* refers to **qi** entering; *turning* means manipulating the needle. **Great qi** refers to the **great evil qi** that disrupts **yin** and **yang**.

The **Emperor** asked: *"How does one supplement when there is deficiency?"*

**Qi Bo** replied: *"One must first palpate and trace it, press and disperse it, push and press it, tap and agitate it, grasp and lower it, connect and take it, externally drawing its threshold to seal its **spirit**."*

*Palpate and trace* means to touch with the hand. *Press* means to press with the fingers. *Palpate and trace* seeks to relax the **qi**; *press and disperse* makes the **meridians** propagate. *Push and press* compresses the skin; *tap and agitate* makes the **pulse qi** taut. *Grasp and lower* prepares the needle’s placement. *Connect and take* follows the standard method. *Externally drawing its threshold* is the same as *pushing and pressing*—compressing the skin outside the **acupoint** so that when the needle is removed, the unbroken skin remains. The **acupoint’s** gate, if left unopened, allows the **spirit qi** to retreat inward, hence it is said to *seal its spirit*.

The *Regulating the Meridians* text states: *"Externally draw the skin, aligning it with its gate."* It also says: *"Push and close its gate, preserving the **spirit qi**."* This is what is meant.

The *newly corrected text* notes: *"According to Wang’s citation of the *Regulating the Meridians* text, it is now clear that this is not the original text but appears in the *Needle Methods* section of the *Jia Yi Jing*. The following lines are from the current passage."* *Palpate* is pronounced *mén*. *Grasp* is pronounced *xiè jiāo qiè*.

*"When exhalation is complete, insert the needle and dwell still, taking **qi’s** arrival as the reason for withdrawal."* Though *exhalation* is also akin to *inhalation*, it means that withdrawal must wait until **qi** arrives, not based on the number of breaths. The *Needle Classic* says: *"If **qi** does not arrive upon insertion, do not ask how many times; if **qi** arrives upon insertion, withdraw without reinserting."* The key is not the speed of breaths but ensuring **qi** arrives before needle withdrawal, not removing the needle prematurely while **qi** is still absent.

---

*"This is the text of the current chapter. **Mén** [palpate] is pronounced *mén*. **Zhuā** [grasp] is pronounced *xiè jiāo qiè* [sidelong, exchange, and stop].

*'When exhalation is complete, insert the needle and remain motionless, taking **qi’s** arrival as the reason for withdrawal.'* Though *exhalation* is also akin to *inhalation*, it means that withdrawal must await **qi’s** arrival, not the count of breaths. The *Needle Classic* states: *'If **qi** does not arrive upon insertion, do not question its number; if **qi** arrives upon insertion, withdraw without reinserting.'* Thus, the essence lies not in the pace of breaths but in ensuring **qi** arrives before needle removal, lest one withdraw prematurely while **qi** remains absent.*

**Translation:**

*"Like awaiting a precious guest, one does not know when evening comes—
this instructs practitioners to observe **qi’s** movements.
*Mù* [evening] means *late*.
When **qi** arrives, adjust and guard it,
*shì* [adjust] meaning to regulate harmoniously,
*hù* [guard] meaning to take heed.
It says: when **qi** has settled and balanced,
one must guard it carefully,
lest it shift and the ailment recur.
The *Needle Classic* says:
*'When **qi** has arrived, guard it and do not lose it.'*
This is its meaning.
What is meant by *guard it carefully* shall be explained as follows.

*Newly corrected text states*: Upon examining the *Needle Classic*’s words,
this is the text from the *Essential Life, Complete Form* chapter of the *Plain Questions*,
also found in the *Needle Resolution* chapter.
*Observing inhalation and withdrawing the needle*,
**qi** must not escape,
each remaining in its place.
Pushing and closing the orifice,
one ensures the *shénqi* [spirit-qi] remains,
the *dàqì* [great-qi] lingering—
thus it is called *bǔ* [supplementation].
This is the correct terminology.
When the outer orifice is sealed,
the *shénqi* [spirit-qi] returns,
*observing inhalation and withdrawing the needle*,
the *dàqì* [great-qi] does not leak—
the meaning of *supplementation* is thus clearly understood.
Yet this *dàqì* [great-qi] refers to the **qi** circulating through the major channels,
governing the *róng* [nutritive] and *wèi* [defensive].
The Emperor asked: *'How does one observe **qi**?'*
This means: how does one discern the **qi** that can be taken?
Gěibó [Master Gui] replied:
*'The pathogenic factor departs from the collateral vessels and enters the channels,
dwelling within the blood vessels.*
The *Miscellaneous Needling* chapter says:
*'When the pathogenic factor lodges in the body,
it first settles in the skin and fur,
lingering but not departing,
then enters and settles in the muscle layer,
lingering but not departing,
then enters and settles in the collateral vessels,
lingering but not departing,
finally entering and settling in the channel vessels.'*
Thus it is said: *'The pathogenic factor departs from the collateral vessels and enters the channels.'*
Its cold and heat have not yet harmonized,
like waves surging up—
sometimes present, sometimes absent,
thus not always lingering.
Since it circulates through the sixteen *zàngfǔ* [viscera-organ] channels,
measuring sixteen *cùn* [inch] and two *chǐ* [foot],
it does not always remain where it is observed.
Thus it is said:
*'When it arrives, one must press and halt it,
halt and take it,
lest one encounter its surge and drain it.'*
*Chōng* [surge] refers to the **qi** aligned with the *shuǐxià* [water clock]’s divisions.
The *Spiritual Pivot* says:
*'One *kè* [division] after the water clock strikes,
the **qi** of the body is in the *Tàiyáng* [Greater Yang] channel;
two *kè* after the water clock strikes,
the **qi** of the body is in the *Shàoyáng* [Lesser Yang] channel;
three *kè* after the water clock strikes,
the **qi** of the body is in the *Yángmíng* [Yang Brightness] channel;
four *kè* after the water clock strikes,
the **qi** of the body is in the *Yīnfèn* [Yin Division].'*
When **qi** is in the *Tàiyáng* [Greater Yang] channel,
the *Tàiyáng* [Greater Yang] channel alone is flourishing;
when **qi** is in the *Shàoyáng* [Lesser Yang] channel,
the *Shàoyáng* [Lesser Yang] channel alone is flourishing.
If one sees a channel flourishing alone,
one mistakenly assumes the pathogenic factor has arrived,
and drains it with the needle—
this will instead harm the *zhēnqì* [true/essential **qi**].
Thus the text continues:
*'True **qi** is the channel **qi**;
when the channel **qi** is greatly depleted,
it is said that its arrival cannot be encountered—
this is the meaning.'*
If the channel **qi** aligns with the *shuǐxià* [water clock]’s divisions,
and one mistakenly assumes it is the pathogenic factor,
then draining it will lead to great error—
thus it is said: *'Its arrival cannot be encountered.'*
Hence it is said:
*'If one fails to discern the pathogenic factor,
the true **qi** has already passed,
draining it will cause the true **qi** to escape,
and once escaped, it will not return;
the pathogenic factor will return,
and the disease will worsen—
if one does not realize the pathogenic factor’s return,
and instead drains the innocent true **qi**,
the true **qi** will escape,
the pathogenic factor will re-invade,
the channel **qi** will be greatly depleted—
thus the disease worsens and accumulates.'*
Thus it is said: *'Once it departs, it cannot be recalled.'*
After it has followed the channel’s flow and gone,
it cannot be summoned back again.

*It cannot be 'hooked' to trigger [needling]*
means that one must wait for the pathogenic factor’s arrival before needling and draining.
If even a slight and subtle presence is known,
how much more so when **qi** surges like waves—
one cannot know its arrival.

*Whether earlier or later*
refers to when the blood and **qi** are already depleted—
the disease cannot be treated.
It means: if one takes **qi** when it should not be taken,
one has missed the timing.
*The newly corrected text states*: According to Quányuán’s original,
*jìn* [exhausted] should be *xū* [depleted].
The character *jìn* is a mistake for *xū*.
Thus it is said:
*'One who knows the timing of **qi’s** arrival, like a trigger,
one who does not know the timing, like knocking on a drum—
it does not respond.'*
Thus it is said:
*'One who understands the **qi’s** mechanism cannot fail to trigger it;
one who does not understand the **qi’s** mechanism will knock but fail to trigger it.'*
The *mechanism* refers to the subtle movements—
it emphasizes knowing its subtleties.

The Emperor asked: *'How does one supplement or drain?'*
Gěibó [Master Gui] replied:
*'This is attacking the pathogenic factor—
rapidly draining to remove excess blood,
and restoring the true **qi**.
One drains only when blood is present.
This is when the pathogenic factor has newly lodged,
dissipating but not yet settled.
Pushing it makes it advance,
withdrawing it makes it halt.
If one needles against its flow,
it warms the blood.'*
It means:
when the pathogenic factor has newly lodged,
not yet settled in a fixed location,
if one pushes the needle to supplement,
it will advance along with the supplementation;
if one withdraws the needle to guide it,
it will remain where the needle is directed.
If one does not drain the excess blood
but instead warms it,
the pathogenic factor will internally prevail and worsen its harm—
thus the text continues:
*'Draining its blood will make the disease vanish immediately.'*
The Emperor said: *'Excellent.'*
Yet when true **qi** and pathogenic factor are harmonized,
no waves or surges arise—
how does one observe it?
Gěibó [Master Gui] replied:
*'Discern the palpation of the three divisions and nine regions,
adjusting according to their fullness or depletion—
this is the method.
Drain the full, supplement the depleted;
when neither full nor depleted,
use the channel’s standard to take it.
Examine the left, right, above, and below—
where **qi** is lost or concealed—
discern the disease’s hiding place and await it.
If **qi** is in the *Yīnfèn* [Yin Division],
observe its presence in the *Yīnfèn* [Yin Division] before needling;
if **qi** is in the *Yángfèn* [Yang Division],
observe its presence in the *Yángfèn* [Yang Division] before needling—
this is called *encountering the timing*.
The *Spiritual Pivot* says:
*'One *kè* [division] after the water clock strikes,
the **qi** of the body is in the *Tàiyáng* [Greater Yang] channel;
four *kè* after the water clock strikes,
the **qi** of the body is in the *Yīnfèn* [Yin Division].'*
If the divisions accumulate without ceasing,
the **qi** will follow accordingly,
cycling and beginning anew.
Thus one must discern the disease’s hiding place,
await its **qi**, and then needle it.

If one does not know the three divisions,
the *Yin* and *Yang* are not distinguished,
the *Heaven* and *Earth* are not separated.
The *Earth* must be observed as *Earth*,
the *Heaven* as *Heaven*,
and the *Human* as the *Human*—
adjusting at the *Zhōngfǔ* [Middle Region],
to establish the three divisions.
Thus it is said:
*'If one needles without knowing
the three divisions and nine regions,
the location of the disease and pulse,
even if the **qi** is greatly excessive,
the practitioner cannot restrain it.'*"*

The **Dao** of *inhibition* refers to restraining the **qi**.

Yet if one still cannot discern where the malevolent **qi** resides,
how could one ever restrain its malevolent **qi**?

If the *Zhūfá* [punishment of a grain] is without excess,
it is called *Dàhuò* [Great Confusion].
If one disturbs the great channels,
the true **qi** cannot be restored,
using the solid as the void,
taking the malevolent as the true.
If one needles without proper principle,
one becomes a thief of **qi**,
plundering the patient’s vital **qi**.
If one treats what is *fù* [supplementary] as *nì* [inverse],
the *Róngwèi* [Nutritive and Defensive] **qi** will scatter in disorder,
the true **qi** already lost,
while the malevolent **qi** lingers within.
This cuts off the patient’s longevity,
bringing early misfortune.

Ignorance of the three divisions and nine regions is long-lasting.
Without keen discernment of what is false,
without thorough learning of what is true,
one will disturb the great channels,
become a thief of **qi**,
and cause harm with every move—
how could one endure?

If one does not grasp the harmonization of the four seasons and five phases,
and follows their mutual overcoming,
releasing the malevolent to attack the true,
it will cut off the patient’s longevity.
It is not only ignorance of the three divisions and nine regions that is harmful—
if one does not know the sequence of the four seasons and five phases’ **qi**,
it is also enough to damage and cut off the patient’s life.

When the malevolent **qi** arrives as a new guest,
its dwelling place is not yet fixed.
Push it and it advances,
draw it and it halts,
encounter it and release it,
and the disease will immediately cease.

This principle must be repeated.
The *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwen* [Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon, Plain Questions] *Bǔzhù* [Supplementary Notes] concludes here.

**Discussion on Diagnosing Empty and Full States**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"What does 'empty' and 'full' refer to?"*

Qibo replied: *"When pathogenic *qi* is excessive, it is 'full'; when vital *qi* is depleted, it is 'empty.'*
*'Depleted' means the vital *qi* is diminished, as if taken away."*

The Emperor said: *"How do 'empty' and 'full' manifest?"*
*(Referring to the general principles of the five *zàng* organs' empty and full states.)*

Qibo said: *"When *qi* is empty, the lungs are empty; when *qi* is reversed, the feet are cold. If it occurs outside its proper season, life follows; if it occurs in its proper season, death follows.*
*'Outside its proper season' refers to the years before or after the prime of life.*
*'In its proper season' refers to the prime years.*
*The other organs follow the same principle. The five *zàng* behave uniformly."*

The Emperor asked: *"What is meant by 'compound fullness'?"*

Qibo replied: *"By 'compound fullness,' we mean severe febrile disease, where *qi* is hot and the pulse is full. This is called 'compound fullness.'"*

The Emperor asked: *"If both the *jing* channels and *luò* collaterals are full, how does this present, and how should it be treated?"*

Qibo replied: *"When both *jing* and *luò* are full, the pulse at the *cùn* (wrist) is taut while the *chǐ* (ankle) is relaxed. All such cases must be treated accordingly.*
*Thus, 'slippery' follows the natural order, while 'rough' is contrary.*
*'Taut' refers to a slippery pulse at the mouth.*
*In matters of empty and full, all begin with their inherent nature.*
*Therefore, when the five *zàng* and their tissues are smooth and free-flowing, longevity follows.*
*When things are born, they are smooth and free-flowing; when they die, they become withered and rough. Hence, 'rough' is contrary, while 'smooth' follows the natural order.*
*'Follows' means 'in harmony.'"*

The Emperor asked: *"If the *luò* collaterals are deficient while the *jing* channels are excessive, how does this present?"*

Qibo replied: *"When the *luò* collaterals are deficient while the *jing* channels are excessive, the pulse at the mouth is hot while the *chǐ* is cold.*
*This is contrary in autumn and winter but harmonious in spring and summer, and treatment should focus on the disease.*
*Since *yang* *qi* ascends in spring and summer, a hot pulse at the mouth with cold at the *chǐ* is harmonious.*
*The twelve *jing* channels and fifteen *luò* collaterals each have excess or deficiency on the left and right sides. The practitioner must locate their precise condition to apply acupuncture or moxibustion accordingly. Hence, it is said, 'treatment focuses on the disease.'"*

The Emperor asked: *"If the *jing* channels are empty while the *luò* collaterals are full, how does this present?"*

Qibo replied: *"When the *jing* channels are empty while the *luò* collaterals are full, the *chǐ* pulse is hot and full, while the mouth pulse is cold and rough. This leads to death in spring and summer but survival in autumn and winter.*
*In autumn and winter, *yang* *qi* descends, hence the hot pulse at the *chǐ*. Cold is harmonious."*

The Emperor asked: *"How should this be treated?"*

Qibo replied: *"When the *luò* collaterals are full and the *jing* channels are empty, moxibustion is applied to *yin* and acupuncture to *yang*; when the *jing* channels are full and the *luò* collaterals are empty, acupuncture is applied to *yin* and moxibustion to *yang*.*
*This is because the *yin* division governs the *luò* collaterals, while the *yang* division governs the *jing* channels."*

The Emperor asked: *"What is meant by 'compound emptiness'?"*
*(This reverses the earlier discussion on 'compound fullness.')*

Qibo replied: *"When the pulse *qi* is empty at the *cùn* and *chǐ*, this is called 'compound emptiness.'*
*(Referring to both the *cùn* and *chǐ* pulses being empty.)*
*The newly corrected text states: According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, it reads 'pulse empty, *qi* empty, *chǐ* empty—this is called compound emptiness.' This text omits one 'empty' and adds an 'above.'*
*Wang Bing’s annotation states that both *cùn* and *chǐ* pulses are empty, but this does not include *qi* emptiness.*
*Detailed earlier: In febrile disease, hot *qi* and a full pulse constitute compound fullness. Here, empty pulse and empty *qi* at the *chǐ* constitute compound emptiness. Thus, when both pulse and *qi* are full, it is compound fullness; when both are empty, it is compound emptiness—not merely when both *cùn* and *chǐ* are empty."*

The Emperor asked: *"How should this be treated?"*

Qibo replied: *"By 'empty *qi*,' we mean instability. When the *chǐ* is empty, walking feels unsteady.*
*When the *cùn* is empty, the pulse moves erratically; when the *chǐ* is empty, walking is labored and insufficient.*
*The newly corrected text states: According to Yang Shangshan, 'empty *qi* refers to an unstable constitution from birth.'*
*Wang Bing’s claim that an empty *cùn* pulse moves erratically is incorrect.*
*'Empty pulse' means it does not conform to *yin*.*
*It does not conform to the signs of *Tài Yīn*.*
*How do we know?*
*The *qi* mouth is the pulse’s critical junction, the movement of *Shǒu Tài Yīn*.*
*In such cases, slippery leads to survival, rough leads to death."*

The Emperor asked: *"If cold *qi* suddenly surges upward, causing a full and solid pulse, how does this present?"*
*(Referring to hot *qi* and a full pulse, which was already described as compound fullness—slippery follows the natural order, rough is contrary. Now, if cold *qi* causes a full pulse, can it also be called compound fullness? How does this affect slippery/rough and life/death?)*

Qibo replied: *"If fullness is slippery, life follows; if fullness is contrary, death follows.*
*'Contrary' means 'rough.'*
*The newly corrected text states: Wang Bing’s claim that 'contrary' means 'rough' is greatly incorrect.*
*Ancient texts are concise, with frequent parallel phrasing. Earlier, 'slippery' was mentioned, and now 'contrary' is stated. From 'slippery follows,' it is clear that 'contrary' refers to 'rough,' not that 'contrary' means 'rough.'"*

The Emperor asked: *"If the pulse is full and solid, with cold hands and feet but a hot head, how does this present?"*

Qibo replied: *"In spring and autumn, life follows; in winter and summer, death follows.*
*Generally, cold hands and feet in summer are not illness but result from summer following winter’s order—if caught in summer, death follows in winter.*
*In winter, a full and solid pulse with a hot head is not illness but results from winter following summer’s order—if caught in winter, death follows in summer.*
*Reversing winter and summer, none would die. Only when contracted in spring and autumn—true illness—does survival follow.*
*Death occurs in the first month of the respective season.*
*If the pulse is floating and rough, with the body hot, death follows."*

*The newly corrected text states: According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, this passage was misplaced in the original text, appearing later under the Emperor’s question on 'form, bone, pulse, and sinew measurements—how do we know their degrees?' The meaning does not align. Wang Bing recognized the error but did not know that Huangfu Shian had previously relocated it here. Now, this passage is removed from its later position and inserted here.*

The Emperor asked: *"What if the entire body is swollen and full?"*

Qìbó said: *"When the entire body is swollen and full, the pulse is taut, large, and rigid, with a rough *cù* at the *chǐ* position that does not respond to pressure.
'Form entirely full' means the four limbs and internal organs are fully distended."*

*The newly corrected text states: According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* and *Tàisū*, *cù* (rough) was originally written as *mǎn* (full).*

*"In such cases, if the condition aligns with the Dao, life follows; if it opposes, death follows."*

The Emperor asked: *"What does it mean for the condition to align with the Dao and thus lead to life, or oppose it and lead to death?"*

Qìbó said: *"When the hands and feet are warm, that is alignment with the Dao. When the hands and feet are cold, that is opposition."*

The Emperor asked: *"For an infant suffering from heat illness, with a pulse that moves like a suspended object—what is the prognosis?"*
*Suspended* refers to the pulse’s movement as if something were hanging and swaying.

Qìbó said: *"If the hands and feet are warm, life follows; if cold, death follows."*

*The newly corrected text states: According to the *Tàisū*, the character 'hand' is omitted here. Yang Shàngshàn commented: 'When the feet are warm, *qi* descends, and thus life follows; when the feet are cold, *qi* does not descend, leading to opposition and death.'*

The Emperor asked: *"For an infant struck by wind-heat, with wheezing, grunting, and shouldered breathing—what is the pulse like?"*

Qìbó said: *"One who wheezes, grunts, and breathes with shouldered effort has a full, large pulse. If it is relaxed, life follows; if taut, death follows."*
*Relaxed* refers to the pulse’s movement as if slackened.
*Taut* refers to the pulse’s tension like a drawn string.

The pulse’s urgency is not merely about the coming and going.

*The *Zhènglǐ Shānghàn Lùn* states: "Relaxed (pulse) indicates wind-heat invasion."* Hence, for an infant struck by wind-heat, a relaxed pulse means life follows, while a taut pulse means death follows.

The Emperor asked: *"For intestinal obstruction with bloody stools—what is the prognosis?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the body is hot, death follows; if cold, life follows. Heat signifies the corruption of blood, hence death; cold signifies the *hóngqì* (nutritive *qi*) remains intact, hence life."*

The Emperor asked: *"For intestinal obstruction with white froth—what is the prognosis?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the pulse is deep, life follows; if the pulse is superficial, death follows. This is an instance where an yin-disease presents with yang-pulse features, contrary to the symptoms, hence death follows."*

The Emperor asked: *"For intestinal obstruction with pus and blood—what is the prognosis?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the pulse is suspended and severed, death follows; if it is smooth and large, life follows."*

The Emperor asked: *"For cases of intestinal obstruction where the body is not hot and the pulse is neither suspended nor severed—what is the prognosis?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the pulse is smooth and large, life follows; if it is suspended and rough, death follows. This is determined by the *zàng* (viscera). When the liver presents with *gēngxīn* (regeneration) signs, death follows; when the heart presents with *rén guǐ* (kidney-related) signs, death follows; when the lung presents with *bǐngdīng* (third and fourth heavenly stems) signs, death follows; when the kidney presents with *wùjǐ* (fourth and fifth heavenly stems) signs, death follows; when the spleen presents with *jiǎyǐ* (first and second heavenly stems) signs, death follows. This is called determining by the *zàng* (viscera)."*

The Emperor asked: *"For epilepsy—what is the prognosis?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the pulse is large and smooth, the disease may subside over time; if the pulse is small, firm, and urgent, death follows and it is untreatable. A small, firm, and urgent pulse signifies yin, and when a yang-disease presents with yin-pulse features, death follows and it is untreatable."*

*The newly corrected text states: According to Cháo Yuánfāng, it reads: "If the pulse is deep, small, and urgent, death follows and it is untreatable; if the pulse is small and taut, it is also untreatable."*

The Emperor asked: *"For epilepsy, how do the pulse’s vacuity and repletion manifest?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the pulse is vacuous, it may be treated; if replete, death follows. This is because the features are contrary."*

The Emperor asked: *"For wasting diseases (due to damp-heat) in vacuity and repletion—what is the prognosis?"*

Qìbó said: *"If the pulse is replete and large, though the disease is long-standing, it may be treated; if the pulse is suspended, small, and firm, though the disease is long-standing, it is untreatable. In chronic illness, blood and *qi* are weakened; if the pulse does not correspond to being replete and large, treatment is ineffective."*

*The newly corrected text states: Examining the *Jīng* (Classical Canon), it says that a replete and large pulse in chronic illness may be treated, but this is noted as incorrect. According to *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, *Tàisū*, and Quán Yuánqǐ’s original text, it states that it may be treated. Additionally, according to Cháo Yuánfāng, it reads: "If the pulse is rapid and large, life follows; if it is fine, small, and superficial, death follows." It also states: "If the pulse is deep and small, life follows; if it is replete, firm, and large, death follows."*

*The term *zhàng* (瘴) is pronounced *tú dān* (徒丹), meaning damp-heat disease.*

The Emperor asked: *"How do we discern the extent of disease in form, bones, pulse, and sinews?"*

The extent of form is detailed in *Sānbèi Jīng*; the extent of sinews, pulse, and bones are found in *Língshū Jīng*. This inquiry also belongs at the beginning of those canonical treatises, suggesting an error in text arrangement. One version of the *Jīng* (Canon) places this question as the beginning of *Nìcóng Lùn* (Discourse on Contrary and Conformity), which is incorrect.

The Emperor asked: *"In spring, we urgently treat the *jīngluò* (channels and collaterals); in summer, we urgently treat the *jīngshù* (acupuncture points); in autumn, we urgently treat the six *fǔ* (organs); in winter, we close and seal the body. When the body is closed and sealed, why do we still use acupuncture and moxibustion for diseases like *tānzhù* (paralytic disorders) and *yǒngjū* (abscesses)?"*

*Urgent* here means *rapid or intense*. *Closed and sealed* refers to the *qi* pathways being obstructed. The phrase *use acupuncture and moxibustion sparingly* does not refer to *tānzhù* (paralytic disorders) and *yǒngjū* (abscesses). Even in winter, when the *qi* pathways are closed and sealed, diseases like *tānzhù* and *yǒngjū* are severe, with internal formation of large abscesses. If not urgently treated with acupuncture and moxibustion to release them, sinews will be eroded and bones will rot, so even in winter, these diseases should be treated with acupuncture and moxibustion to open and release them. *Tānzhù* diseases do not resolve quickly.

Why, then, can diseases like *tānzhù* and *yǒngjū* still be treated with acupuncture and moxibustion in winter? This is because these diseases require urgent release; if not treated promptly, the abscesses will penetrate and erode the sinews and bones, piercing through the *zàngfǔ* (viscera and organs). *Tānzhù* is characterized by indeterminate pain, and pressing it does not yield a clear response. The pain appears and disappears unpredictably. Treat by needling *Shǒu Tàiyáng Jīngluò* (hand lesser yang channels) beside the *sānlěi* (three interstices) and *yīngmài* (sinew vessels) on both sides, three times each.

If *tānzhù* manifests as intense heat, treat by needling *Zú Shǎoyáng* (foot lesser yang) at *wǔ* (five), three times. If the heat persists after needling, treat by needling *Shǒu Xīnmǎo* (hand heart vessel) at *sānlěi* (three interstices) and the *jīngluò* (channels) of *Shǒu Tàiyīn* (hand greater yin) at *dàgǔ* (great bone), three times each. *Dàgǔ* refers to the shoulder, specifically the *jiānzhēn* (shoulder acumen) point, located in the depression posterior to the shoulder joint.

For sudden *tānzhù* with sinew displacement, where pain follows the channels, and the *pòhàn* (ghostly sweat) does not cease while *bāoqì* (uterine *qi*) is insufficient, treatment is applied to the *jīngshù* (acupuncture points). If *tānzhù* erupts suddenly, pain follows the channels, sinews become inflamed, and channels tense; flesh between the sinews aches, sweat seeps as if not fully exhausted, and there is *bāoqì* (uterine *qi*) insufficiency, all may be treated by supplementing and releasing the acupuncture points along the affected channels.

*The newly corrected text states: These two conditions were previously scattered in the text; now they are moved to align accordingly.*

For sudden abdominal distension, pressing does not relieve it. Treat by needling the *jīngluò* (channels) of *Shǒu Tàiyáng* (hand greater yang), which is the *mù* (gathering) point of the stomach. *Shǒu Tàiyáng* refers to the hand greater yang channel, and the *jīngluò* (channels) of this channel generate (the disease) at *zhōngyuàn* (middle courtyard), which is the stomach’s *mù* (gathering) point. *The Zhōnggào* (Middle Announcement) states: *"The middle courtyard is the stomach’s gathering point, located between the ribs and the umbilicus, where the hand greater yang and lesser yang, and foot greater yang channels converge."* Hence, it is called the *jīngluò* (channels) of the stomach’s *mù* (gathering) point.

*The newly corrected text states: According to *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, it reads: "Needling the hand greater yang channel’s *jīngluò* (channels) and blood releases the disease. It lacks the phrase ‘the stomach’s gathering point, etc.’ Additionally, Yang Shàngshàn’s annotation states ‘foot greater yang.’ Their explanations differ, and it is unclear which is correct."*

For the *Shǎoyīn* (lesser yin) point, three inches lateral to the spine, treat by needling the two adjacent points five times each with a sharp, thin needle. The *Shǎoyīn* point refers to the two points beside the 14th vertebra, which is the *shù* (acupuncture point) of the kidney.

*The newly corrected text states: According to *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, it reads: "Use a sharp, thin needle. After needling, the patient stands for as long as eating a meal, then cross-check by needling the points where the channel passes through the yang region, several times."*

For **cholera** (*huòluàn*), needle the *shù* (acupuncture point) and its adjacent points five times. For cholera, the *Shǎoyīn* *shù* and the *Zhìshì* point beside it are selected.

○ *Newly corrected text states*: According to Yang Shàngshàn, "For cholera, needle the *shù* and its five adjacent points. For the *foot Yangming* channel, take three points above as well." The *foot Yangming* refers to the *stomach shù*. Selecting the *stomach shù* also includes the third point upward from the two lateral points beside the *Shǎoyīn shù*—this is the *stomach倉* (*Cāng*) point.

Needle the *xiǎojīng mài* (surprise pulse) five times—this refers to *Yanglíngquán*, located in the depression above the outer side of the knee. Needle the *hand Taiyin* channel five times, the *foot Taiyang* channel five times, and the lateral branches of the *hand Shǎoyīn* channel once, the *foot Yangming* channel once, inserting three needles five *cù* above the ankle. The *foot Taiyang* refers to the *foot Greater Yang* channel. Needling the *hand Taiyin* five times refers to the *Yújì* point, located on the inner side of the base of the thumb, where the dispersing pulse lies. Needling the *foot Taiyang* five times refers to the *Chéngshān* point, located in the depression between the muscles at the back of the heel. The lateral branches of the *hand Shǎoyīn* channel refer to the *Zhīzhèng* point, five *cù* above the wrist crease, where the muscle divides at the edge of the ulna—this is where the *hand Shaoyang* collateral diverges toward the *hand Shǎoyīn*. The *foot Yangming* point refers to the *Jiěxī* point, located in the depression above the ankle. Five *cù* above the ankle refers to the *Guāngmíng* point of the *foot Shaoyang* collateral.

According to *The Inner Canon’s Bright Hall* and *The Central Edict Acupuncture Atlas*, all are said to treat cholera, with clear textual evidence. ○ *Newly corrected text states*: According to another edition’s annotation, none are said to treat cholera—its meaning remains unclear. Additionally, according to *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* and *Tàisù*, needling the *xiǎojīng mài* five times is for treating *jīngjué* (convulsive spasm), while Wang’s annotation claims it is for cholera—Wang’s annotation is incorrect.

In general, treating **consumption** (□), **striking illness** (*pūjī*), **hemiplegia** (*piāngkū*), **flaccid paralysis** (*wěijué*), **gastric distension with inverted flow** (*qìmǎn fǎinì*), **obesity in the wealthy** (*féiguìrén*—*gāoliáng* illness), **blockage** (*gé*) leads to obstruction and stagnation, causing upper and lower disconnection—this is the disease of **sudden grief** (*bàoyōu*). Sudden **syncope** (*jué*) with deafness, **unilateral obstruction** (*piānsè*), and **closure** (*bì*) occur when internal *qi* suddenly weakens. Diseases not arising from internal or external **wind** (*fēng*) linger and persist. **Foot lameness** (*zhǐbó*) is caused by cold, wind, and dampness. **Consumption** refers to internal **consumption** (*xiāo*). □ refers to **latent heat** (*fúrè*). **Syncope** (*jué*) refers to **inverted *qi*** (*qìnì*), **high** (*gāo*) meaning **grease** (*gāo*), and **liáng** meaning **rice** (*liáng*). **Foot** (*zhǐ*) refers to the foot.

The obese accumulate **internal heat** (*rèzhōng*), and those who consume too much sweetness accumulate **central fullness** (*zhōngmǎn*). Thus, when heat-*qi* invades internally, it manifests as **consumption**, **hemiplegia**, **gastric distension**, and **inverted flow**. **Inverted** (*nì*) means contrary to normal conditions, differing from the common person. However, those afflicted by **grief and worry** have *qi* that is blocked and stagnant, leading to **obstruction** (*gé*), **closure** (*sè*), and **blockage** (*bì*), causing *qi* and pulses to be severed, resulting in upper and lower disconnection. When *qi* is fixed internally, **urination and defecation** become **unilateral and obstructed**.

Why? Because the **viscera and storage organs** fail to transform and disperse *qi*—thus it is so.

「When **external wind** invades a person, if the **latent pathogenic factors** (*fǔzàng*) do not disperse, the **yang-qi** internally suffers, causing **heat to surface externally** (*rè wài fān*). Thus, it lingers in the **fleshy layers**, leading to **consumption** (*xiāo*), while the **skin and muscles adhere to the bones** (*pífū zhuó yú jīngǔ*).

If **dampness** prevails in the **foot**, the **sinews** become inflexible; if **cold** prevails in the **foot**, they contract and spasm. When **wind, dampness, and cold** dominate, the **defensive-qi** (*wèiqì*) becomes **congested and clustered** (*jiéjù*), and this congestion causes **muscle pain**, resulting in **limping** (*bó*) and an inability to walk. *Dì* means the sole of the foot, as if cut by a stone.

The **Yellow Emperor** said: **"Jaundice and sudden pain**, **epilepsy and madness**, and **prolonged inverted flow** (*jiǔnì*) are all generated by this. When the **Five Viscera** are unbalanced and the **Six Storage Organs** are obstructed, these diseases arise. Thus, **headaches and ringing in the ears**, along with **the nine orifices** being inflexible, are manifestations of the **intestines and stomach** (*chángwèi*).

The **Three Yang meridians of the foot** (*zú sān yáng*) travel from the head down to the foot, but if **prolonged inverted flow** persists and does not descend, the *qi* accumulates in the **upper burner** (*shàngjiāo*), causing **jaundice and sudden pain**, **epilepsy and madness**, and **inverted flow of the *qi*** (*qìnì*). When **diet and drink** are **improper** (*shíyǐn shīyí*), and **vomiting and diarrhea** exceed **moderation** (*tǔlì guòjié*), the **Six Storage Organs** become obstructed, and the **Five Viscera’s *qi*** fails to harmonize.

When the **intestines and stomach** are **blocked and congested** (*pǐsè*), the *qi* does not flow in sequence. If the *qi* does not flow in sequence, the **upper, lower, internal, and external** regions mutually **overpower and counter** (*hùxiāng shèngfú*), causing **headaches and ringing in the ears**, along with **the nine orifices** being inflexible.

**Discussion on the *Tàiyīn-Yángmíng* Theory** (*Lùn piān*): The **spleen (viscera)** and **stomach (storage organ)**, both belonging to the **Earth element** (*tǔ*), though their functions differ, are interconnected. Thus, their diseases present differently, and so their inquiries diverge.

**Qíbó** replied: "When **yin and yang are displaced** (*yīnyáng yìwèi*), they alternately manifest as **excess and deficiency** (*gēngxū gēngshí*), **inversion and compliance** (*gēngnì gēngcóng*). Sometimes they originate from within, sometimes from without—since their paths differ, the diseases bear distinct names.

The **spleen (viscera)** belongs to **yin**, and the **stomach (storage organ)** belongs to **yang**. The **yang meridians** descend, while the **yin meridians** ascend; the **yang meridians** course externally, and the **yin meridians** course internally. Thus, it is said that since their paths differ, the diseases bear distinct names.

**Newly Corrected Annotation** (*xīnjiāozhèng yún*) states: According to **Yáng Shàngshàn**, in **spring and summer**, **Yángmíng** is **excess** (*shí*), and **Tàiyīn** is **deficient** (*xū*). In **autumn and winter**, **Tàiyīn** becomes **excess**, and **Yángmíng** becomes **deficient**. This is the alternation of **excess and deficiency** (*gēngshí gēngxū*).

In **spring and summer**, **Tàiyīn** is **inverted** (*nì*), and **Yángmíng** is **compliant** (*cóng*); in **autumn and winter**, **Yángmíng** is **inverted**, and **Tàiyīn** is **compliant**. This is the alternation of **inversion and compliance** (*gēngnì gēngcóng*).

The **Yellow Emperor** said: "I wish to hear of their **distinct pathological presentations** (*yìzhuàng*)."

**Qíbó** said: "The **yang** is the **celestial *qi*** (*tiāngì*), governing the **external**; the **yin** is the **terrestrial *qi*** (*dìgì*), governing the **internal**. This is what is meant by **displacement of yin and yang** (*yīnyáng yìwèi*).

Thus, when the **yang channels** are **excess** (*shí*), the **yin channels** are **deficient** (*xū*). This is what is meant by the alternation of **excess and deficiency** (*gēngshí gēngxū*).

When one **encounters malevolent wind and vacuous pathogens** (*fànzéifēngxīeyán*), the **yang** suffers first; when **diet, drink, and daily activities** are **unrestrained** (*shíyǐn bùjié qǐjū bùshí*), the **yin** suffers first. This is what is meant by saying that sometimes the disease originates from within, sometimes from without.

If the **yang** suffers, the *qi* enters the **Six Storage Organs**, causing **febrile body** (*shēnrè*) and **irregular external symptoms** (*bùshí wài*). It manifests as **shortness of breath and labored respiration** (*shuǎn hū*). If the **yin** suffers, the *qi* enters the **Five Viscera**, causing **abdominal fullness and obstruction** (*fùmǎn bìsè*). It manifests as **undigested food in the stool** (*shìxiè*), and if prolonged, as **intestinal prolapse** (*chángwèi*).

This is what is meant by saying that since their paths differ, the diseases bear distinct names.

Thus, the **throat** governs **celestial *qi*** (*tiāngì*), and the **throat passage** (*yàn*) governs **terrestrial *qi*** (*dìgì*). Therefore, when the **yang** suffers from **wind-qi** (*fēngqì*), and the **yin** suffers from **damp-qi** (*shīqì*), **like *qi* seeks like** (*tóngqì xiāngqiú*). Hence, the **yin-qi** ascends from the foot to the head, descending along the arm to the fingertips; the **yang-qi** ascends from the hand to the head, descending to the foot. This is what is meant by the alternation of **inversion and compliance** (*gēngnì gēngcóng*).

The **《Língshū Jīng》** states: "The **Three Yin meridians of the hand** (*shǒu sān yīn*) originate from the **viscera** and travel to the hand; the **Three Yang meridians of the hand** (*shǒu sān yáng*) originate from the hand and travel to the head; the **Three Yang meridians of the foot** (*zú sān yáng*) originate from the head and travel to the foot; the **Three Yin meridians of the foot** (*zú sān yīn*) originate from the foot and travel to the abdomen. Since their courses differ, there is alternation of **inversion and compliance** (*gēngnì gēngcóng*).

Thus, it is said: In **yang diseases**, the *qi* first **ascends to its extreme** (*shàngxíngjí*), then descends; in **yin diseases**, the *qi* first **descends to its extreme** (*xiàxíngjí*), then ascends. This refers to their **general tendencies**, though the **foot’s *Lesser Yin* meridian** (*zú shǎoyīn*) descends, differing from the other **yin meridians**.

Therefore, those **injured by wind** first suffer **upper symptoms**; those **injured by dampness** first suffer **lower symptoms**. The **yang-qi** ascends and flames upward (*yángqì yànshàng*), so it is first affected by **wind**; the **yin-qi** descends and moistens downward (*yīnqì rùnxià*), so it is first affected by **dampness**. This is because **like *qi* seeks like** (*tóngqì xiānghé*).

The **Yellow Emperor** said: "When the **spleen is diseased**, why do the **four limbs** fail to function? (*sìzhī bùyòng héyán*)"

**Qíbó** replied: "The **four limbs** all **draw *qi* from the stomach** (*bèngqì yú wèi*), yet they cannot directly reach the **meridians** (*jīng*). **Newly Corrected Annotation** (*xīnjiāozhèng yún*) states: According to **《Tàisū》**, it should be "directly reach the **limbs** (*jìngzhì*)" instead of "reach the **meridians**."

**Yáng Shàngshàn** says: "The **stomach** provides **water and grain** (*shuǐgǔ*) to nourish the **four limbs**, but it cannot directly reach them. Instead, it relies on the **spleen**, which receives **water and grain** and their **essence and fluids** (*jīngyè yīnwèi*), and then distributes **nutritive and defensive *qi*** (*yíngwèi*) to the **four limbs**. The **spleen** must rely on its **transformation and dissemination** (*bùhuà*) to enable the **four limbs** to perceive and receive nourishment.

Now, if the **spleen is diseased** and cannot **transport the stomach’s essence and fluids** (*wèi tīngyè bùnéngxíng*), the **four limbs** will not receive **water and grain**. The *qi* daily **wanes** (*rìyǐkuī*), and the **meridian pathways** (*màidào*) become inflexible. The **sinews, bones, muscles, and flesh** all lack *qi* to sustain them, so they **fail to function** (*bùyòng*).

The **Yellow Emperor** said: "Why does the **spleen** not govern its own season?"

**Qíbó** replied: "The **spleen** belongs to **Earth** (*tǔ*), and it governs the **center** (*zhōngyāng*). It **assists the Four Viscera** (*sìzàng*) of the **four seasons** (*sìjì*), each for **eighteen days** (*shíbā rì*), and so it **cannot govern a season alone** (*bùdé dúlì yú shí*). The **spleen (viscera)** constantly **depends on the stomach’s Earth essence** (*chángzhuó yú wèi tǔ zhī jīng*). Earth, as the **source of all things** (*shēngwànwù*), follows the **principles of Heaven and Earth** (*fǎ tiāndì*), so its influence extends from the **upper to the lower**, from **head to foot** (*shàngxià zhì tóuzú*), and it **cannot govern a season alone** (*bùdé zhǔshí*).

**Govern** (*zhì*) means **master**; **depend** (*zhuó*) means **constantly rely**. The **Earth *qi*** (*tǔqì*) in the **four seasons** each **assumes dominion** (*jìwáng*) for **eighteen days** at the **end of their respective seasons** (*jìjiū*), thus the **Five Phases’ *qi*** (*wǔxíng zhī qì*) each **rules for seventy-two days** (*bāshí èr rì*), completing a **year’s cycle** (*yǐ zhōng yīsuì zhī rì*).

The **external seasons** govern the **four limbs**, which internally correspond to the **hand and foot meridians** (*shǒuzú zhī jīng*).

The **Yellow Emperor** said: "The **spleen** and **stomach** are connected only by a **membrane** (*mó*), yet the **spleen** can **transport the stomach’s essence and fluids**—why is this?"

**Newly Corrected Annotation** (*xīnjiāozhèng yún*) states: According to **《Tàisū》**, it should be "with **convergence points** (*mù*) they **mutually counter** (*xiāngnì*)" instead of "connected by a **membrane**."

**Yáng Shàngshàn** says: "The **spleen** is **yin**, and the **stomach** is **yang**; the **spleen** is **internal**, and the **stomach** is **external**—their **positions differ**, so they **mutually counter** (*xiāngnì*). Yet the **spleen** can **transport the stomach’s essence and fluids**—why is this?"

Qì Bó said: "The **Foot Taiyin** (*zú tàiyīn*) is the **three yins** (*sān yīn*), its **meridian** (*jīng*) piercing the **stomach** and connecting to the **spleen**, intertwining with the **larynx** (*yǎ*), hence the **Foot Taiyin** **transports qi** (*xíngqì*) among the **three yins**.

The **Yangming** (*yángmíng*) is the **external** (*biǎo*), and the **stomach** is the **spleen’s external** (*pí zhī biǎo*). It is the **sea of the five zàng organs and six fǔ palaces**, also **transports qi** (*xíngqì*) among the **three yangs** (*sān yáng*). The **zàng organs and fǔ palaces** each **draw their qi** (*shòuqì*) from their respective **meridians** (*jīng*) through **Yangming**, hence the **stomach transports** its **essence and fluids** (*jīn yè*).

If the **four limbs** (*sì zhī*) fail to **receive the water and grain’s qi** (*bǐng shuǐgǔ qì*), they **daily grow weaker** (*rì yǐ yì shuāi*), and the **yin channels** (*yīn dào*) become **obstructed** (*bù lì*), leaving **tendons, bones, muscles, and flesh** (*jīngǔ jīròu*) without **qi** (*qì*) to **nourish their growth** (*yǐ shēng*), hence they **do not function** (*bù yòng yān*).

This further clarifies the **spleen’s role in governing the four limbs** (*pí zhǔ sì zhī yì*).

In the **"Yangming Meridian Explication"** (*Yángmíng jīng jiě piān*), the **Yellow Emperor** asked: "When the **Foot Yangming meridian** (*zú yángmíng zhī jīng*) is diseased, the patient **hates others** (*è rén*) and **fire** (*huǒ*), hears the **sound of wood** (*mù yīn*) and **startles in alarm** (*tìrán ér jīng*), yet **bells and drums** (*zhōnggǔ*) do not affect them. Why do they **startle in alarm** upon hearing the **sound of wood**? I wish to hear its reason.

The previous section stated: 'When it enters the **six fǔ palaces**, the body grows **hot without season** (*shēnrè bù shí*), and **breathing becomes labored** (*shàng wéi chuǎn hū*).'

Yet now, the **Foot Yangming meridian** is the **stomach meridian** (*wèi jīng*), and its disease differs from the previous section’s account—it **startles in alarm** upon hearing the **sound of wood**, hence the **Emperor’s inquiry** (*wèn qí yì*).

Qì Bó replied: "The **Foot Yangming meridian** is the **stomach meridian**, and the **stomach** is **earth** (*tǔ*). Thus, when they **startle in alarm** upon hearing the **sound of wood**, it is because **earth hates wood** (*tǔ è mù*). **《Yīnyáng Shū》** states: 'Wood **overcomes earth** (*mù kè tǔ*).' Hence, **earth hates wood**.

The **Emperor** said: 'Well explained.'

Why do they **hate fire** (*è huǒ*)?

Qì Bó said: "The **Yangming meridian** governs **flesh** (*ròu*), its **meridian**—**newly corrected annotation** (*xīnjiāozhèng yún*) states: 'According to **《Jiǎyǐ Jīng》**, it should be **muscle** (*jī*).'—when the **blood and qi** (*xuè qì*) are **abundant** (*shèng*), and **pathogenic factors** (*xié kè*) lodge there, **heat** (*rè*) arises. When **heat** is **severe** (*shèng*), they **hate fire**.

The **Emperor** was **astonished** (*yì*) beyond the **usual** (*cháng*). **Adyr** (*yú*), pronounced as **'yu'** (*yú*).

Qì Bó said: "The four limbs are the roots of all Yang meridians. When the four limbs are **solid** (*shí*), **solid** means they can ascend heights (*dēng gāo*).

The **Emperor** asked: 'Why do they **hate people** (*è rén*)?'

Qì Bó replied: 'When the **Yangming meridian** is in **ulceration** (*jué*), they **pant** (*chuǎn*) and **groan** (*wǎn*). When they groan, they **hate people**. Groaning and **internal heat** (*wǎn rè nèi yù*) accumulate, hence they are **vexed by people** (*fán è rén*).

**Newly corrected annotation** (*xīnjiāozhèng yún*) states: 'According to *Mài Jiě* (The Pulse Explanation), why do they wish to **seal themselves within doors and windows** (*bì mén yǒu ér chǔ*)? It is because **Yin and Yang clash** (*yīn yáng xiāng bó*), when **Yang is exhausted** (*yáng jìn*) and **Yin is abundant** (*yīn shèng*), hence they **seal themselves within doors and windows** (*bì mén yǒu ér chǔ*). Groan (*wǎn*), pronounced as **'wān'** (*wǎn*, *wū guàn qiè*).

The **Emperor** said: 'Some **pant and die** (*chuǎn ér sǐ*), others **pant and survive** (*chuǎn ér shēng*), why is that?'

Qì Bó replied: 'When **ulceration** (*jué*) **affects the Zàng organs** (*lián zàng*), they die; when it **affects the Jīng meridians** (*lián jīng*), they survive. **Jīng** refers to the **meridians** (*jīng mài*). **Zàng** refers to the **Five Spirit Stores** (*wǔ shén zàng*). The reason they die when **ulceration** affects the Zàng organs is because **the Spirit departs** (*shén qù*).

The **Emperor** said: 'Well explained.'

When the **disease is severe** (*bìng shèn*), they **discard their garments and flee** (*qì yī ér zǒu*), **ascend heights and sing** (*dēng gāo ér gē*), or even **go without food for several days** (*bù shí shù rì*), **scale walls and climb onto roofs** (*yú yuán shàng wū*), and the places they ascend to are all **beyond their usual capacity** (*bù shì qí sù suǒ néng*). Yet, in their **disease state**, they **gain abilities** (*fǎn néng*)—why is that? **Sù** means **inherent** (*běn*). **Adyr** (*yú*), pronounced as **'yu'** (*yú*), means **to scale walls** (*mò qiáng*).

The **Emperor** found it **strange** (*guài*) and **marveled at its unusualness** (*qǐ qí yì yú cháng*).

The **Sù** said: "The **four limbs** (*sì zhī*) are the **root of all Yang** (*zhū yáng zhī běn*). When **Yang is strong** (*yáng shèng*), the **four limbs become full** (*sì zhī shí*), and if they are full, one can **ascend heights** (*néng dēng gāo*).

**Yang** receives **qi** (*qì*) from the **four limbs**, hence the **four limbs** serve as the **root of all Yang**.

○The **newly revised edition** states: According to *The Pulse Explications* (*Mài Jiě*), it is because **Yin and Yang contend**, and the **external** (*wài*) **unites with Yang** (*bìng yú yáng*).

The **Emperor** asked: "Why do they **discard their garments and flee** (*qì yī ér zǒu*)?"

**Discard** (*qì*) means **to abandon or refuse to use** (*bù yòng*).

The **Sù** replied: "When **heat is excessive** (*rè shèng*) in the **body** (*shēn*), they **discard their garments** and wish to **flee** (*yù zǒu*)."

The **Emperor** asked: "Why do they **speak wildly, curse, or praise** (*màng yán mà jìn bù bì qīn shū*) without **distinction between close and distant** (*ér gē*)?"

The **Sù** replied: "When **Yang is strong** (*yáng shèng*), it causes one to **speak wildly, curse, or praise** (*màng yán mà jìn*), without **distinction between close and distant** (*bù bì qīn shū*), and also **not to desire food** (*bù yù shí*). Because they **do not desire food** (*bù yù shí*), they **wildly flee** (*màng zǒu*).

The **Yangming Stomach meridian** (*Zú Yángmíng wèi mài*) descends to the **lower epigastrium** (*xià gé*), connecting to the **Stomach network** (*wèi luò*) and **Spleen** (*pí*). The **Taoyin Spleen meridian** (*Zú Tàiyīn pí mài*) enters the **abdomen** (*rù fù*), connecting to the **Spleen network** (*pí luò*) and **Stomach** (*wèi*), ascends to the **upper epigastrium** (*shàng gé*) beside the **throat** (*yé yán*), and links to the **root of the tongue** (*lián shé běn*), dispersing beneath the **tongue** (*sàn shé xià*), hence the **disease manifests thus**.
