**Discussion on Febrile Diseases**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"There are patients with febrile disease who sweat profusely yet soon relapse into heat. Their pulse is rapid and tense, undiminished by sweating. They speak incoherently and cannot eat. What is the name of this illness?"*

Qibo replied: *"This is called the **Yin-Yang Exchange**—**Exchange** means death. **Exchange** refers to the mingling of Yin and Yang qi without distinction."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear the explanation."*

Qibo said: *"All sweating in the body originates from grain. Grain generates essence, and when essence-qi prevails, it manifests as sweat. Now, when pathogenic forces contend within the flesh and bone, and sweating occurs, it means the pathogen retreats while essence prevails—this is the **initial sweating**. When essence prevails, the patient should be able to eat and not relapse into heat. If heat recurs, it is the pathogen; sweating is essence-qi. If sweating appears yet heat immediately returns, the pathogen is dominant. The inability to eat stems from **essence having no means**—**no means** means no capacity to generate sweat. When grain fails to transform, essence does not form, and essence, untransformed, cannot flow—thus, no means to produce sweat. If the disease lingers, the patient’s lifespan will swiftly decline. If sweating appears rapidly yet lingers without cessation, the patient’s life will swiftly become perilous."*

**New Verification Notes:** *"Examine **disease lingering**—according to Wang Bing’s annotation, *disease* should read *illness* (疾). Additionally, the *Jia-Yi Jing* reads *while heat lingers* (而热留者)."*

*"Moreover, the *Treatise on Heat* states: ‘If sweating occurs yet the pulse remains rapid and robust, death follows.’ The *Treatise on Heat* refers to the ancient *Hot Disease Treatise*. After sweating, the pulse should slow and quiet, but if it remains rapid, tense, and full, it indicates **True Qi exhaustion** and **pathogen dominance**—thus, death is certain. Now, the pulse does not correspond with sweating; this is **inability to overcome the disease**, and death is manifest. A pulse that is not tranquil but rapid and robust is **non-correspondence**. Incoherent speech is **loss of will**—**loss of will** means death. Will aligns with essence; now essence has no means, so will has no dwelling—will, unanchored, is lost. Now three signs of death are seen, none of life—even if recovery seems possible, death is inevitable. Sweating with a rapid, robust pulse—**first death**; inability to overcome the disease—**second death**; incoherent speech and loss of will—**third death**."*

The Emperor asked: *"There are patients with fever, sweating, and restlessness—yet sweating does not alleviate their distress. What is this illness?"*

Qibo replied: *"If sweating occurs with fever, it is **Wind**; if sweating brings restlessness yet does not resolve, it is **Convulsion**. The illness is named **Wind-Convulsion**."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear its full account."*

Qibo said: *"The **Jiuyang** channel governs the body’s qi, so it first receives the pathogen. The **Shaoyin** acts as its external covering—when heat arises, it ascends along with it, and **ascending** leads to **convulsion**."* (**Ascending** refers to Shaoyin following Taiyang upward.**)

The Emperor asked: *"How should it be treated?"*

Qibo replied: *"Use **acupuncture on the external covering**, and administer decoctions."* (**This means draining Taiyang and supplementing Shaoyin.** The decoction is to **check the ascending kidney-qi**.**)

The Emperor asked: *"What of **Labor Wind** as a disease?"*

Qibo replied: *"Labor Wind originates in the lungs’ domain—thus it is called **Labor Wind**."* (**Labor** refers to **kidney exhaustion**.**) The kidney channel ascends from the kidney, piercing the liver’s *ge*, and entering the lung—thus, kidney exhaustion generates wind, residing beneath the lung. Its symptoms cause the patient to **forcefully gaze upward**."* (**New Verification Notes:** *"According to Yang Shangshan, **forcefully upward** means a tendency to tilt the head back."*)

**Translation:**

*"Míngshì"* refers to closing the eyes yet seeing indistinctly. Again, in *The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions*, *"míngshì"* is rendered as *"dizziness of the eyes."* Saliva drips like mucus, aversion to wind with trembling chills—these are the symptoms of **Labor Wind**.

The **Bladder Channel** arises from the inner canthus, ascends to the forehead, intersecting at the crown, entering to network the brain, then descending to branch at the nape, following the inner aspect of the shoulder and spine to the waist, entering to network the kidney. Now, since kidney essence is insufficient, the Bladder externally draws in, and the Bladder’s *qi* cannot ascend to nourish—thus, the patient’s head and nape stiffen, and vision becomes indistinct.

The lungs, thinly assaulted by wind, with **labor-qi** ascending in demand, cause saliva to issue like nasal mucus. Kidney *qi* being insufficient, *yang* attacks internally, merging with **labor-heat**—thus, aversion to wind and trembling chills arise.

The Emperor asked: *"How should it be treated?"*

Qibo replied: *"By halting excessive flexion-extension."* (*"Sǎo"* means "to stop"; *"fǔyǎng"* refers to bending and stretching.) This means restraining movement to prevent **labor-qi** from further spreading.

For those of **Great Yang** (elderly), **reclaiming essence** takes three days; for those of middle years, five days; for those lacking clarity, seven days. (**New Verification Notes:** According to *The Canon of A and B*, it reads *"three days or five days,"* while *The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions* states *"awaiting three or five days, those lacking clarity."* This differs from the above.)

Coughing up greenish-yellow sputum, its form like pus, as large as a marble, emerging from the mouth or nose—if it does not emerge, the lungs are injured, and injury to the lungs means death.

The **Great Yang** refers to the **Bladder meridian**. The Bladder and Kidney form exterior-interior pairings, hence the **reclaiming of essence** by the **Great Yang**.

*"Great"* means *"great"* or *"large."* However, the **Taiyang meridian** absorbs and draws in essence-*qi*, ascending to assault the lungs—three days for the elderly, five days for those of middle years, and seven days for those who have never relied on essence-*qi*. At this point, they should cough up thick sputum, greenish-yellow like pus.

For those with **balanced coughing**, the sputum rises from the throat and exits through the mouth; for those with **sudden, violent coughing**, the *qi* surges against the **reservoir gate** and exits through the nose.

Such cases all stem from **Kidney *qi* exhaustion**, **Lung *qi* depletion**, and **Yang *qi* oppression**—thus, if the sputum does not emerge, the lungs are injured. Injury to the lungs causes the **Nourishing and Defensive *qi*** to disperse and dissolve, the **spirit** failing to govern internally, and thus death ensues.

---
**New Verification Notes:** According to Wang’s commentary: *"Sudden, violent coughing"*—the *qi* surges against the **reservoir gate** and exits through the nose. The *Nan Jing* mentions *"chongmen"* (reservoir gate), with no mention of *"zhimen"* (reservoir gate). It is likely a miswriting for *"zimen"* (responsibility gate). Yang Cao states: *"Gui"* refers to the *"ge"* (cauldron), where the stomach *qi* emerges; the stomach transmits grain-*qi* to the lungs, and since the lungs lie above the cauldron, the stomach is called the **responsibility gate**.

The Emperor asked: *"If one has **Kidney Wind**, with the face swollen and distended, impairing speech, should it be treated with acupuncture?"*

*"Cīrán"*—swollen and raised. *"Yōng"*—swelling beneath the eyes, resembling the shape of an external silkworm. The **Kidney meridian** ascends from the Kidney, piercing the liver’s cauldron, entering the lungs, and traveling along the throat beside the root of the tongue—thus impairing speech.

*"Yì"*—pronounced *mòjiāng*.

Qibo replied: *"It should not be needled when empty. Needling when it should not be needled will cause the disease-*qi* to arrive within five days."* *"Zhì"*—the arrival of the disease-*qi*. This is because the **Zang organs** are associated with a single day, and within five days, the *qi* reaches the Kidney.

Since the Kidney is already deficient, and **Wind** internally assails it, the swelling is considered **excess**. If needled excessively, it will further damage the **Zang *qi***; with **True *qi*** insufficient, it cannot recover, hence the disease-*qi* will arrive within five days.

The Emperor asked: *"What will its arrival entail?"*

Qibo replied: *"It will manifest as shortness of breath, intermittent fever, fever rising from the chest and back to the head, sweating, hot hands, dry mouth, bitter thirst, yellow urine, swelling beneath the eyes, abdominal rumbling, heaviness of the body making movement difficult, absent menstruation, restlessness with inability to eat, inability to lie flat—lying flat causes coughing. The disease is named **Wind-Water**, discussed in *The Methods of Needling*.*" (*The Methods of Needling*—a lost chapter in the current text.)

The Emperor asked: *"I wish to hear its explanation."*

Qibo replied: *"Where the evil lingers, the *qi* must be deficient. If **Yin** is deficient, **Yang** will necessarily assail it—thus shortness of breath, intermittent fever, and sweating. Yellow urine indicates heat in the lower abdomen. Inability to lie flat stems from stomach disharmony. Lying flat worsens coughing, as it presses upward against the lungs. All cases with **Water-*qi*** first show slight swelling beneath the eyes."*

The Emperor asked: *"Why is this so?"*

Qibo replied: *"Water is **Yin**; beneath the eyes is also **Yin**; the abdomen is where **ultimate Yin** resides. Thus, if Water is in the abdomen, it must cause swelling beneath the eyes. True *qi* reversing upward causes bitter taste, dry tongue, inability to lie flat—lying flat causes coughing up clear water. All Water diseases thus cannot be exposed externally; if exposed, it causes fright, and fright worsens coughing. Abdominal rumbling indicates the disease originates in the stomach. Assaulting the Spleen causes restlessness and inability to eat; inability to swallow food indicates stomach cauldron obstruction. Heaviness of the body and difficulty moving stem from the stomach meridian in the foot. Absent menstruation is due to **Bao meridian** closure—the **Bao meridian** belongs to the Heart and networks within the uterus. Now, since *qi* presses upward against the lungs, Heart *qi* cannot descend and communicate, hence menstruation ceases."*

The previous explanations remain unclear regarding *"fever rising from the chest and back to the head, sweating, hot hands, dry mouth, and bitter thirst."* This appears to be an omission or error in the ancient text.

What is the case? The **Kidney’s Shao Yin meridian** ascends from the Kidney, passing through the liver’s cauldron, entering the lungs, and traveling along the throat beside the root of the tongue.

Additionally, the **Bladder’s Taiyang meridian** ascends from the inner canthus, crossing the forehead to the crown; its branch extends from the crown to the upper ear corner, while its direct path enters to network with the brain, then descends separately along the nape, following the shoulder blade, entering beside the spine to reach the waist, and descending into the flank.

Now, since **Yin is deficient and Yang is excessive**, heat rises from the chest and back to the head, causing sweating, dry mouth, and bitter thirst. The Heart is a **Yang Zang organ**, its meridian traveling through the arm and hand. The Kidney is a **Yin Zang organ**, its meridian following the chest and foot. Kidney deficiency leads to Heart *qi* excess, hence the hot hands. Moreover, since both Heart and Kidney meridians belong to **Shao Yin**, the Emperor said: *"Excellent."* (Discussion of **inverted regulation** concludes.)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does the human body sometimes feel neither excessively warm nor excessively hot—yet still experience heat with restlessness and fullness? It differs from the usual state, hence the term **‘unusual.’**"* (A new annotation reads: *"According to the *Jia Yi Jing*, the original text lacks the three characters ‘for the.’"*)

Qi Bo replied: *"When **Yin qi** is deficient and **Yang qi** prevails, heat arises with restlessness and fullness."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does the body not feel cold from external clothing, nor does the interior harbor cold **qi**—yet cold seem to emerge from within?*" (This implies confusion over which **Yin** or **Yang** factor serves as the primary source of the illness.)

Qi Bo said: *"This person has excessive **bi qi** (stagnant **qi**), with **Yang qi** deficient and **Yin qi** abundant. Thus, the body feels cold as if emerging from water."* (This indicates that the condition stems from the imbalance of **Yin** and **Yang** within the body’s own **qi**, not from external cold or internal cold **qi**.)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does a person have all four limbs hot, and upon encountering wind and cold, feel scorched like by fire?"* (A new annotation reads: *"According to the original text by Quan Yuanqi, the phrase ‘like by fire’ is absent; the *Tai Su* text reads ‘scorched as in fire,’ hence the adoption of the *Tai Su* version.*")

Qi Bo replied: *"This person has **Yin qi** depleted and **Yang qi** excessive. The four limbs belong to **Yang**, and when two **Yang** forces combine, while **Yin qi** is deficient and weak, the insufficient **Yin** (water) cannot extinguish the rampant **Yang** (fire). Thus, **Yang** alone dominates, and when **Yang** alone dominates, it cannot sustain growth—it merely prevails and ceases.*" (Water represents **Yin**, fire represents **Yang**; now, since **Yang qi** is in excess and **Yin qi** is insufficient, it is said that ‘insufficient water cannot extinguish rampant fire.’*) The term *治* (here) means **"prevail"** or **"dominate,"** while *胜* means **"excessive"** or **"overpowering."**

Thus it is said: **"When Yang alone prevails, it merely dominates and then ceases."**

When encountering wind and feeling scorched like fire, this person’s flesh will **wither**—*wither* meaning **decay**. It means that over time, this person’s flesh will **waste away**.

*(New annotation: The phrase "as scorched like fire" should follow the Tai Su version: "as scorched by fire.")*

The Emperor asked: *"There are people who feel cold in their bodies—hot water cannot warm them, thick clothing cannot keep them warm, yet they do not shiver. What illness is this?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"This person’s **kidney qi** has long been excessive#5, and they are of a **water**-dominated constitution. The **Taiyang** energy is declining, the **kidney fat** is withered and does not grow. One **water** cannot overpower two **fires**—the **kidney** is **water**, yet it arises from the **bones**. If the **kidney** does not thrive, the **marrow** cannot fill, and thus the cold reaches even the bones.

*‘To be of a **water**-dominated constitution’ means their desires are excessive.*

The reason they do not shiver is that the **liver** is one **Yang**, the **heart** is two **Yang**, and the **kidney** is a **lonely organ**—one **water** cannot overpower two **fires**, so they do not shiver. The disease is called **bone impediment (gu bi)**, and this person’s joints will **contract**.

*If the **kidney** does not thrive, the **marrow** does not fill; if the **marrow** does not fill, the **sinews** dry and shrink, causing the joints to stiffen and lock.*

The Emperor asked: *"There are people whose flesh is **prickly**—even when close to quilts and padding, they still feel prickly. What illness is this?"*
*Prickly (ke) is pronounced as in ‘cure’ (lǜ).*

Qi Bo replied: *"Their **Nutritive Qi (Rong)** is deficient, while their **Defensive Qi (Wei)** is excessive. If **Nutritive Qi** is deficient, they feel **numb**; if **Defensive Qi** is deficient, they feel **weak**. If both **Nutritive** and **Defensive Qi** are deficient, they are **numb and weak**, and their flesh remains as it is. The person’s body and will no longer align—this is called **daily death**. The body does not respond to the will, and the will does not fulfill the body’s needs—these two seem to have no connection."*

*(New annotation: According to the Jia Yi Jing, "daily death" should read "thirty-day death.")*

The Emperor asked: *"There are people with **rebellious qi** who cannot lie down and whose breathing makes a sound; some cannot go outside and whose breathing is silent; some whose breathing makes a sound though their daily activities are normal; some who wheeze when lying down or walking; some who wheeze when unable to go outside and cannot walk; and some who wheeze when unable to go outside at all. What organ causes these conditions? I wish to know the reason."*

Qi Bo replied: *"Those who cannot go outside and whose breathing makes a sound suffer from **rebellious Yangming**. The **foot three Yang** meridians descend, but now they rebel and ascend—thus their breathing makes a sound.

**Yangming** is the **stomach meridian**, and the **stomach** is the **sea of the six fu**, the **sea of water and grain**. Its **qi** also descends. When **Yangming** rebels and cannot follow its proper path, they cannot go outside.

As the *Lower Classic* says: ‘If the **stomach** is not harmonized, the exterior will not be at ease.’ This is what is meant.

*The **Lower Classic** refers to the ancient Upper Classic.*"

「Now, if one’s daily activities remain unchanged but breathing emits a sound, this is due to **rebellious Lung network meridians**—the network meridians cannot follow the main meridians in their normal ascent and descent, so they linger in the main meridians and fail to move freely. The diseases of network meridians are subtle, hence daily activities remain unchanged while breathing emits a sound.

As for those who cannot go outside at all and thus wheeze, this is the **intrusion of Water-qi**. For Water-qi flows along the **body fluids**, and the **kidneys** are the **reservoir of water**, governing the **body fluids**, as well as **sleep and wheezing**.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Well spoken."*

Upon further examination of the text’s meaning, there are cases where one cannot go outside and yet breathes without sound, cases where one can go outside but still wheezes, and cases where one cannot go outside and cannot walk, yet wheezes—these three distinctions are all missing and not yet discussed. This is likely an omission from the ancient texts.

**In the *Cao Lun* (Discussion on Malaria):**
The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Both **intermittent fever** and **malaria** originate from **wind**, yet why do they manifest at specific times?*

**Cao** (瘠) is akin to **old** (老), also meaning **emaciated** (瘦).
○The *New Corrected Edition* states: *"According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (甲乙经), ‘Both **malaria** and **fever** originate from **wind**, yet why do they act by the **day** and erupt at specific **times**?’ This differs from the current text."*

*The *Tai Su* (太素) aligns with the current text.*

Yang Shangshan (杨上善) notes: *"Cao* (瘠) may refer to cases where attacks occur every two days, known as **two-day malaria**; yet this text only describes summer injury from **heat** turning into autumnal disease, sometimes as **wasting malaria** (疳疟), or simply **malaria**, without specifying the frequency of attacks by days. It merely responds to the **four seasons**, and the symptoms vary, thus it is only called *cao* (瘠)."*

Qi Bo replied: *"When malaria first erupts, it begins in the **hair follicles** (毫毛), followed by stretching and yawning, then **chills and shivering** (寒栗), **shaking** (鼓颔), and **pain in the lumbar region and spine** (腰脊俱痛). When the **chills** recede, **internal and external heat** (内外皆热) ensues, with **headache as if the skull were splitting** (头痛如破), and **thirst with a desire to drink in large gulps** (渴欲玲饮).

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"What **qi** causes this? I wish to hear its **Dao/Way**."*

Qi Bo said: *"The **Yin** and **Yang** forces rise and fall, contending in exchange, with **emptiness** and **fullness** alternating. This is because **Yin** and **Yang** **qi** shift positions—**Yang qi** descends to its utmost then ascends, while **Yin qi** ascends to its utmost then descends. Thus, it is said that **Yin** and **Yang** forces rise and fall, contending.

When **Yang qi** is deficient, the body feels **external cold**; when **Yin qi** is deficient, **internal heat** arises. When **Yang qi** is excessive, the body feels **external heat**; when **Yin qi** is excessive, **internal cold** arises. From this, when **chills** recede, **heat** emerges, and **emptiness** and **fullness** alternate, causing the **Yin** and **Yang** **qi** to shift and transform. When **Yang qi** merges with **Yin**, **Yin** becomes **full** while **Yang** is deficient; when **Yangming** (胃脉, the Stomach channel) is deficient, **chills and shivering** (寒栗) and **shaking** (鼓颔) occur.

When **Yang qi** merges with **Yin**, it means **Yang qi** enters the **Yin** domain. **Yangming** (胃脉, the Stomach channel) converges at the **oral cavity** (承浆), then retreats and branches downward along the **posterior mandible** (下廉), emerging at **Dà Yíng** (大迎). Its divergent branch descends from **Dà Yíng** forward to **Rén Yíng** (人迎). Hence, when **Yang qi** is insufficient, one feels **aversion to cold**, **chills and shivering**, and **vibration of the jaw** (颐颌振动).

When the **Large Intestine channel** (巨肠, 膀胱脉, the Bladder channel) is deficient, **pain in the lumbar region, spine, and occiput** (腰背头项痛) arises. The **Great Yang** (巨阳) refers to the **Bladder channel** (膀胱脉). Its **pathway** (咏) branches downward from the head, follows the **inner shoulder** (循肩膊内), runs alongside the **spine** (侠脊), and reaches the **lumbar region** (抵腰中). Thus, when its **qi** is insufficient, **pain in the lumbar region, spine, and occiput** arises.

When all three **Yang channels** (三阳) are deficient, **Yin qi** prevails, and **Yin qi** prevailing causes **bone coldness and pain** (骨寒而痛). **Chills** originate from within, so both **internal and external coldness** occur. When **Yang qi** is excessive, **external heat** arises; when **Yin qi** is deficient, **internal heat** arises. If **internal and external heat** both emerge, **panting** (喘) and **thirst** occur, hence the desire to **drink in large gulps** (玲饮).

**Heat** injures **qi**, so when **internal and external heat** both arise, **panting** and **thirst** occur. All these symptoms stem from **summer injury** (夏伤) by **heat** (暑), where **heat qi** is excessive and lodges within the **skin** (皮肤), outside the **intestines and stomach** (肠胃). This is where the **Nourishing qi** (荣气) resides. Outside the **intestines and stomach**, the **Nourishing qi** (荣气) governs, hence it is said that this is where the **Nourishing qi** resides.

**Convergence** (合) is akin to **residing**. This makes one’s **pores** (汗空) **loose** (疏), allowing **pathogenic factors** to invade. When autumn arrives, **sweat** (汗出) emerges and encounters **wind**, or if one contracts it through bathing, **water pathogenic factors** (水气) lodge within the **skin**, residing alongside the **Defensive qi** (卫气). The **Defensive qi** (卫气) circulates through the **Yang** domain by day and through the **Yin** domain by night. When it encounters **Yang**, it emerges externally; when it encounters **Yin**, it withdraws internally. When **internal and external Defensive qi** (卫气) converge, the disease manifests each day.

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does the disease manifest on alternating days?"* (间日发作)

Qi Bo replied: *"The pathogenic **qi** lodges deeply within, withdrawing into the **Yin** domain. **Yang qi** alone emerges, while **Yin evil** (阴邪) remains internally. **Yin** and **Yang** contend, and the pathogenic **qi** cannot fully emerge, hence the disease manifests on alternating days. Since it does not meet with the **Defensive qi**, it erupts every other day."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Excellent."* (善) *"Why does the disease manifest later in the day in some cases and earlier in others?"* (其作日晏与其日早者)

Qi Bo replied: *"When pathogenic **qi** invades the **Wind Palace** (风府), it descends along the **spine’s sides** (循膂而下). The **Wind Palace** (风府) is an acupuncture point located at the nape, two *cùn* (寸) above the hairline and two *cùn* (寸) from the midline, within the **great sinew** (大筋) at the **base of the neck** (宛宛中). **Shè** (膂) refers to the **lateral sides of the spine** (脊两傍).

The **Defensive qi** (卫气) gathers at the **Wind Palace** (风府) each day and night, descending one **vertebral segment** (节) each subsequent day. Thus, the disease manifests later (晏), as the pathogenic **qi** first lodges in the **back** (脊背). Each time it reaches the **Wind Palace** (风府), the **Defensive qi** opens the **pathway**, allowing pathogenic **qi** to enter. When pathogenic **qi** enters, the disease erupts, causing the disease’s manifestation to grow progressively later each day. The **vertebral segment** (节) refers to the **joints of the spine** (脊骨之节), but when pathogenic **qi** is distant, its convergence is delayed, hence the manifestation occurs in the evening (暮).

When it emerges from the **Wind Palace** (风府), it descends one **vertebral segment** (节) each day, reaching the **sacrum** (骸骨) by the **25th day** (二十五日), then entering the **spinal interior** (脊内) on the **26th day** (二十六日), and flowing into the **hidden sinew pathway** (伏膂之脉). From the **nape** (项) downward to the **tailbone** (尾骯), there are roughly **24 segments** (节), hence it descends one **segment** each day, reaching the **sacrum** on the **25th day**, and entering the **spinal interior** on the **26th day**, flowing into the **hidden sinew pathway** (伏膂之脉). The **hidden sinew pathway** (伏膂之脉) refers to the **pathway of the Kidney channel** (肾脉) that runs concealed between the **sinews** (膂筋), as the **Kidney channel** (肾脉) ascends along the **inner thigh** (循股内), then follows the **posterior knee** (后康), pierces the **spine**, and connects to the **kidneys** (属肾). Its **straight pathway** (直行者) ascends from the **kidneys**, passing through the **liver** (贯肝), entering the **diaphragmatic region** (鬲), and reaching the **lungs** (入肺中). Since it pierces the **spine** (贯脊), it does not directly correspond to standard **acupuncture points** (应行穴), but instead follows the **hidden sinew pathway** (循膂伏行), hence it is called the **hidden sinew pathway** (伏膂脉).

The disease that manifests on alternating days arises because pathogenic **qi** withdraws internally into the **five Zàng** (五藏), connecting horizontally with the **membrane’s source** (募原). Its **pathway** (道) is distant, its **qi** deep, and its progression slow, unable to align with the **Defensive qi** (卫气) in its circulation. Unable to emerge fully, the disease thus manifests on alternating days. **Membrane’s source** (募原) refers to the **diaphragmatic region’s root and system** (鬲募之原系).

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Master Qi Bo says that the **Defensive qi** (卫气) reaches the **Wind Palace** (风府) each day, and when it does, the **pathway** opens (胜理开), allowing pathogenic **qi** to enter, and the disease erupts. But if the **Defensive qi** descends one **segment** (节) each day, its emergence should not be at the **Wind Palace**; how does it manifest daily?"* (今卫气日下一节，其气之发也不当风府；其日作者奈何？)

The **new annotated revision** states: *"According to the text of Quán Yuánqǐ, from this point onward, the **pathway** (道) of the pathogenic **qi** resides in the head and nape, descending when the **Defensive qi** (卫气) does, hence the eighty-eight characters all speak of this. This pathogenic **qi** lingers in the head and nape, descending along the **pathways** (膂) of the **Zàng** (藏), thus the distinction between **void** (虚) and **replete** (实) states, and when the pathogenic **qi** occupies different regions, it does not align with the **Wind Palace** (风府) of the **Defensive qi**. Therefore, when pathogenic **qi** occupies the head and nape, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the head and nape; when it occupies the back, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the back; when it occupies the lumbar and sacral regions, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the lumbar and sacral regions; when it occupies the hands and feet, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the hands and feet. Hence, the lower sections [of the text] prescribe needling based on the region where the pathogenic **qi** resides.

Where the **Defensive qi** (卫气) converges with the pathogenic **qi**, the disease erupts. Therefore, the **Wind Palace** is not constant, and wherever the **Defensive qi** emerges, it opens the **pathway** (胜理) for the pathogenic **qi** to enter, and wherever the pathogenic **qi** converges, that becomes its **palace** (府). Since **void** (虚) and **replete** (实) differ, and the pathogenic **qi** occupies varied regions, when the **Defensive qi** and the pathogenic **qi** converge, the disease erupts—not always aligning with the **Wind Palace** for its manifestation."* (The new annotated revision states: *"According to the text of Quán Yuánqǐ and the *Jia Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), from this point onward, the pathogenic **qi** lingers in the head and nape, descending as the **Defensive qi** does, hence the eighty-eight characters all speak of this. This pathogenic **qi** occupies the head and nape, descending along the **pathways** (膂) of the **Zàng**, thus the distinction between **void** and **replete** states, and when the pathogenic **qi** occupies different regions, it does not align with the **Wind Palace** of the **Defensive qi**. Therefore, when pathogenic **qi** occupies the head and nape, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the head and nape; when it occupies the back, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the back; when it occupies the lumbar and sacral regions, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the lumbar and sacral regions; when it occupies the hands and feet, the disease erupts as the **Defensive qi** reaches the hands and feet. Hence, the lower sections prescribe needling based on the region where the pathogenic **qi** resides. The **Defensive qi**, where it converges with pathogenic **qi**, gives rise to the disease. Therefore, the **Wind Palace** is not fixed, and wherever the **Defensive qi** emerges, it opens the **pathway** for pathogenic **qi** to enter, and wherever the pathogenic **qi** converges, that becomes its **palace**. Since **void** and **replete** differ, and the pathogenic **qi** occupies varied regions, when the **Defensive qi** and the pathogenic **qi** converge, the disease erupts—not always aligning with the **Wind Palace** for its manifestation."*)

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Well said. Now, the **Wind** (风) and **cold-induced malaria** (疟) share similarities and belong to the same category, yet **Wind** persists constantly, while **cold-induced malaria** has periodic rest—why is this so?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"The **qi** of **Wind** lingers in its place, hence its constancy; the **qi** of **cold-induced malaria** follows the **pathways** (经络) and **meridians** (胜理), descending internally and pressing outward. When the **Defensive qi** (卫气) aligns with it, the disease erupts."* (The **new annotated revision** states: *"According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), the text reads: ‘descending as the **Defensive qi** does, then its **qi** transmits internally.’ The text of Quán Yuánqǐ and *Tai Su* (《太素》) also follow this. ‘Lingers’ means to remain fixed; ‘follows’ means to accompany."*)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does **cold-induced malaria** (疟) first manifest as **Cold** (寒) and then as **Heat** (热)?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"In summer, one is injured by **Great Heat** (大暑), causing excessive **sweating** (汗). The **pathway** (胜理) opens and the **qi** erupts, then encountering the **Cold** (寒) of the lingering summer **qi** (夏气), which presses inward. In autumn, one is injured by **Wind** (风), and thus the disease is formed."* (The **new annotated revision** states: *"According to the *Jia Yi Jing* and *Tai Su*, the text reads: ‘the lingering **Cold** (小寒) presses inward.’ ‘Great Heat’ is the **yang** **qi**; when injured by **Wind**, the **yang** **qi** is obstructed, hence in autumn, one is injured by **Wind**, and thus the disease is formed. **Cold** is the **yin** **qi**, and **Wind** is the **yang** **qi**; first injured by **Cold**, then by **Wind**, hence it first manifests as **Cold** and then as **Heat**. The disease erupts at fixed times, thus it is called **Cold Malaria** (寒疟). When exposed to **dew** (露) and **cold** (寒), the **Wind** and **Cold** injure the body."*)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does it first manifest as **Heat** (热) and then as **Cold** (寒)?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"This is because one is first injured by **Wind** (风) and then by **Cold** (寒), hence it first manifests as **Heat** and then as **Cold**. It also erupts at fixed times, thus it is called **Warm Malaria** (温疟). Because it first manifests as **Heat**, it is called **Warm** (温). When it manifests solely as **Heat** without **Cold**, the **yin** **qi** is first exhausted, and the **yang** **qi** erupts alone, leading to **scanty breath** (少气), **vexation** (烦冤), and **hot extremities** (手足热) with **nausea** (欲呕), thus it is called **Heat Malaria** (瘴疟). **Heat Malaria** refers to extreme **Heat** (极热)."* (The pronunciation of **瘴** is *zhuàng*, with the tone of *dàn* (干).)

The Yellow Emperor said: *"The classics state that **excess** (有余) should be **drained** (写), and **deficiency** (不足) should be **supplemented** (补). Now, **Heat** (热) is **excess**, and **Cold** (寒) is **deficiency**. The **Cold** (寒) in **malaria** (疟) cannot be warmed by **hot water** (汤) or **fire** (火), and when it erupts as **Heat**, **ice** (冰) or **cold water** (水) cannot cool it. These are all cases of **excess** and **deficiency**. At such times, even a skilled practitioner cannot stop it, and it must be allowed to decline before needling is applied—what is the reason for this?"*

*"I wish to hear your explanation. Why not simply let it reach its peak and then cease?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"The classics state that one should not needle the **intense Heat** (缟缟) of **malaria**, nor the **sluggish pulse** (浑浑) or the **profuse sweating** (洒洒) of **malaria**. Hence, it is said that the disease is in opposition and cannot yet be treated."* (The **new annotated revision** states: *"According to the text of Quán Yuánqǐ and *Tai Su*, the text reads: ‘one should not needle the **intense Heat** (气) of **malaria**.’ ‘缟’ is pronounced as *guǎn*, with the tone of *yāo* (妖). ‘Intense Heat’ means extreme **Heat**; ‘sluggish pulse’ means without discernible pattern; ‘profuse sweating’ means excessive **sweating**."* (The pronunciation of **洒** is *lù*, with the tone of *lù* (鹿).)

*"When **malaria** first erupts, the **yang** **qi** converges with the **yin**, and at that time, the **yin** is **void** while the **yang** is **replete**. Externally, there is no **qi**, hence it first manifests as **Cold** (寒) with **shivering** (栗). When the **yin** **qi** reaches its peak of obstruction, the **yang** **qi** then emerges again. The **yang** and **yin** **qi** converge externally once more, and thus the **yin** becomes **void** while the **yang** is **replete**, hence it first manifests as **Heat** (热) with **thirst** (渴). When the **yin** **qi** is **replete**, the **stomach** (胃) is **Cold**, hence it first manifests as **Cold** with **shivering**; when the **yang** **qi** is **replete**, the **stomach** is **Hot**, hence it first manifests as **Heat** with **desire to drink** (欲饮). The **qi** of **malaria** converges with **yang**, and the **yang** prevails; it converges with **yin**, and the **yin** prevails. When the **yin** prevails, there is **Cold**; when the **yang** prevails, there is **Heat**. **Malaria** is the **violent** (暴) **qi** of **Wind** and **Cold**, which is not constant and repeats when the disease reaches its extreme."* (The **new annotated revision** states: *"According to the *Jia Yi Jing*, the text reads: ‘**malaria** is the **violent** **qi** of **Wind** and **Cold**, which is not constant, and repeats when the disease reaches its extreme.’ The text of Quán Yuánqǐ and *Tai Su* reads: ‘**malaria** is the **qi** of **Wind** and **Cold**, which is not constant, and repeats when the disease reaches its extreme.’ The character ‘至’ (至) connects with the preceding sentence, differing from Wáng Shì’s interpretation. The eruption of the disease is like the **Heat** of fire, or the **violence** of wind and rain that cannot be withstood. Because of its extreme intensity, it cannot be withstood. Hence the classics say: ‘When its **peak** (盛) is **correct** (方), one must **drain** (毁) it,’ and ‘When it **declines** (衰), treatment must be **vigorous** (大昌).’ This is what is meant. ‘方’ means ‘correct’ or ‘proper.’ When the disease is at its **peak**, one must **drain** it, or one may harm the **true** **qi** (真气), hence it is said to **drain** (毁). When the disease has declined and one **supplements** the **qi** of the **meridians** (经气), the pathogenic **qi** will further retreat, and the **true** **qi** will stabilize, hence it is said to **prosper greatly** (大昌). Before the disease erupts, the **yin** has not yet converged with the **yang**, nor the **yang** with the **yin**. If one adjusts it accordingly, the **true** **qi** will stabilize, and the pathogenic **qi** will vanish. The **draining** (写) and **supplementing** (补) are **correct** (铃), and the **pathways** (爻) are **proper** (当), hence the **true** **qi** stabilizes and the pathogenic **qi** vanishes."*)

The skilled physician cannot treat it once it has erupted, for the **qi** is in reverse. The **true** **qi** is suppressed, while the pathogenic **qi** thrives unchecked; when the **true** **qi** cannot overcome the pathogenic **qi**, this is what is meant by **reverse**.

The Emperor said, *"Excellent."* How should one **attack** it? What about timing—when should one act?

Gebi replied: When the **malaria** is about to erupt, the **yin** and **yang** are about to shift, and it must begin from the four extremities. When **yang** is already injured, **yin** follows, so one must **fortify** the affected areas **beforehand** and **bind** them tightly, preventing the pathogenic **qi** from entering and the **yin** **qi** from escaping. Carefully observe the **pulse**—when the **true** **qi** is still moving through the **collateral vessels** and **network vessels** and has not yet fully converged, **bleed** them all. This is when the **true** **qi** is still departing but has not yet fully withdrawn. *"Fortify"* means to **bind** the four limbs tightly, so that the **qi** remains in its proper place, and the pathogenic **qi**’s location will then reveal itself. Once revealed, **bleed** it out.

*"Departing"* is akin to *"leaving."*

The Emperor said: If the **malaria** does not erupt, what should one look for?

Gebi replied: The **malaria** **qi** must alternately surge and decline, corresponding to where the **qi** resides. If the disease is in the **yang**, there will be heat and a **frenetic pulse**; if in the **yin**, there will be cold and a **tranquil pulse**. Since **yin** is tranquil and **yang** is frenetic, the **pulse** follows accordingly. When both reach their extremes, **yin** and **yang** both decline, the **defensive** **qi** separates, and thus the disease abates. When the **defensive** **qi** gathers again, the disease recurs. When **yin** and **yang** clash to their utmost, extremes invert—thus, when they reach their peak, both **yin** and **yang** decline.

The Emperor said: Sometimes the fever recurs every two days or even several days apart, and sometimes there is thirst, sometimes not. What is the reason for this?

Gebi replied: The recurrence of the fever is due to the pathogenic **qi** and **defensive** **qi** lingering in the six **fu** organs, sometimes failing to meet, unable to converge, hence the intervals before the fever returns. When the **qi** does not meet, the fever cannot erupt for several days.

**Malaria** arises from the alternating dominance of **yin** and **yang**, sometimes severe, sometimes mild, hence the variation in thirst. When **yang** dominates and **yin** is severely weakened, there is thirst; when **yang** dominates but **yin** is not severely weakened, there is no thirst. *"Dominates"* means it is stronger than the opposing **qi**.

The Emperor said: The classics state, *"If one is injured by summer heat, one will inevitably fall ill with **malaria** in autumn."* Yet not all cases of **malaria** correspond to this—why is that?

Gebi replied: This is in accordance with the four seasons. When the disease manifests differently, it is contrary to the seasons. For those who fall ill in autumn, the cold is severe—autumn’s **qi** is clear and cool, **yang** descends, and heat is stored in the muscles, hence the severe cold. For those who fall ill in winter, the cold is not severe—winter’s **qi** is harsh and cold, **yang** is concealed, not contending with the cold, hence the cold is not severe. For those who fall ill in spring, they dislike wind—spring’s **qi** is mild and warm, **yang** disperses outward, internally strengthening and opening, hence they dislike wind. For those who fall ill in summer, they sweat profusely—summer’s **qi** is hot, **fluids** are abundant, and they disperse through the skin, hence the excessive sweating.

The Emperor said: How does **temperate malaria** and **cold malaria** differ in their **lodging**? Where do they reside in the **zang**? Why do they **settle** there?

*"Lodging"* means where they reside. *"Zang"* refers to the five **spiritual** **zang** organs.

Gebi replied: **Temperate malaria** is contracted in winter from exposure to wind and cold, with the pathogenic **qi** lodging in the **bone marrow**. When spring arrives, **yang** surges greatly, and the pathogenic **qi**, unable to escape on its own, encounters intense summer heat. The **brain marrow** is consumed, muscles atrophy, and the **natural** **pathways** open and release **qi**—perhaps due to exertion—causing the pathogenic **qi** and sweat to exit together. This disease lodges in the **kidneys**, its **qi** first emerging from within and then dispersing outward. The **kidneys** govern winter, winter governs **bone marrow**, and the brain is the **sea of marrow**, with upper and lower correspondences. When **heat** rises and **ulcers**, the **marrow** is consumed, and as the **marrow** is consumed, **heat** **qi** disperses outward, causing muscles to wither—thus, the disease lodges in the **kidneys**.

Such cases involve **yin** deficiency and **yang** excess; **yang** excess brings heat, while **yin** deficiency—meaning the **kidney’s** stored **qi** is depleted—and **yang** excess—meaning the **Bladder’s** **Taiyang** **qi** is strong—when the disease declines, the **qi** returns inward. When it returns inward, **yang** weakens, and **yang** weakness brings cold. Hence, it first manifests as heat, then as cold, and is called **temperate malaria**.

*"Declines"* refers to the disease’s retreat. *"Returns inward"* means it enters the **kidney’s** **yin** **vessels**.

The Emperor said: What of **marsh malaria**?

Gebi replied: **Marsh malaria** arises when the **lungs** inherently harbor **heat** **qi**, which surges upward in **ulceration**, with the **middle** **qi** being solid and not dispersing outward. If one then exerts themselves, the **natural** **pathways** open, and wind and cold lodge between the skin and muscles, where the fever erupts. When it erupts, **yang** **qi** thrives, and if it does not decline, the disease persists. Its **qi** does not reach the **yin**—

Cháo Yuánfāng states: *"Its qi does not reach the yin"*—meaning it does not return inward.

Thus, it only manifests as heat and not cold, with its qi concealed within the **heart** and lodged externally between the skin and muscles. This causes the flesh to waste away and muscles to wither, hence it is called **marsh malaria**.

The Emperor said: *"Good."*

---
**Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwèn** *Pūzhùshì* **Volume Twenty-Two** concludes.

**Volume Twenty-Three** of the **Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwèn** *Pūzhùshì* bears the **Táng** *Tàibùlìng* **Qǐ Xuànzǐ** **Wáng Bīng**’s annotations, with **Sòng** *Guànglùqīng Zhí* **Lín Yì** and others reviewing corrections, and **Sòng Shǒushàngshū** **Tún tián láng** **Sūn Zhào** further revising errors.

#1 *"Welcoming"* → **Originally "reverse"** (逆).
#2 *"At"* → **Originally "release"** (放), corrected per the **Wáng Bīng** annotation.
#3 *"Await"* → **Originally "await"** (俟), annotated as *"candidate"* (候) by **Wáng Bīng**.
#4 *"Who"* → **Originally "also"** (者), corrected per the **Wáng Bīng** annotation.
#5 *"Strong"* → **Originally "strong"** (胜), annotated as *"flourishing"* (盛) by **Wáng Bīng**.
#6 *"Palace"* → **Originally "sweat"** (府), corrected per the **Wáng Bīng** annotation.
#7 *"Receive"* → **Originally "long"** (受), corrected to *"endure"* (久) per the **Wáng Bīng** annotation.

**Needle the Malaria Chapter**

The malaria of the **Foot Taiyang** meridian causes lower back pain and heaviness of the head, with chill beginning in the back.

The **Foot Taiyang** (Bladder) meridian’s course enters the **glomus of the brain** (脳) from the crown, descends to branch beneath the nape, follows the inner aspect of the shoulder, and flanks the spine to reach the waist’s center. Its divergent branches separate from the inner shoulder, spreading left and right to pierce the **臀** (buttocks), passing through the **spleen pivot** (脾枢).

Thus, it causes lower back pain and heaviness of the head, with chill beginning in the back.

**Newly verified annotation states:** According to the *Three Divisions and Nine Officials Treatise* (《三部九侯论》), the term **贯肿** (pierce the swelling) is corrected to **贯臀** (pierce the buttocks) in the *Needle Lower Back Pain* (《刺腰痛》) annotation as well. The *Discourse on Syncope* (《厥论》) annotation renders it **贯肿**, while the *Canon of Medicine in Categories A and B* (《甲乙经》) also uses **贯肿**.

The onset is chill followed by heat, with a **dizzy, faint, and scorching sensation** (缟搞暍暍然). **缟缟** (dizzy) describes extreme heat, and **暍暍** (scorching) also indicates intense heat. Since the **Taiyang** (Bladder) meridian is deficient, chill appears first; when the chill reaches its peak, heat arises—thus, heat follows. **暍** (scorching, pronounced *yè*) ceases when sweating emerges, yet it proves difficult to resolve.

**Newly verified annotation states:** The full text of **Quán Yuánqǐ** (全元起) and the *Canon of Medicine in Categories A and B* (《甲乙经》), as well as the *Essentials of the Taiyang and Taiping Canons* (《太素》), all render this as "chill first, heat later, with thirst; when thirst ceases, sweating emerges"—differing from this passage. Needling the **部中** (meridian’s central section) induces bleeding.

The **Taiyang’s *you***—this is called **Jīnmén** (Golden Gate).
**Jīnmén** lies below the outer ankle, also named **Rìguānliáng** (Sun’s Pass Bridge), where the **Yang Maintenance** (*Yángwéi*) meridian branches.
Needling may penetrate to **three *cùn*** (fifths of the body’s height), or if moxibustion is applied, **three *zhàng*** (sessions) may be used.
The *Huángdì Zhōnggào Tújīng* states: *Wěizhōng* governs it.
Thus, the ancient method took *Wěizhōng* as the *youzhōng* (central *you*).

*Wěizhōng* lies at the center of the buttock, near the **File Mark’s** pulsating artery, where the **Taiyang** meridian of the foot enters.
Needling may penetrate to **five *cùn***, retained for seven breaths; if moxibustion is applied, **three *zhàng*** may be used.
**New verification states:** Examining the *you* needling in the *Jīayǔ Jīng*, it reads *pīnzhōng* (buttock center).
Now, Wang’s two annotations concur—*pīnzhōng* should be taken as correct.

For **fever of the *Shàoyáng*** (foot *Minor Yang*), it makes the body’s **chills and heats alternate**—
the body’s chills and heats alternate,
then as follows:
chill is not severe, heat is not severe,
since **Yang qi** is not yet盛 (*shèng*), thus it behaves thus.
One **avoids people**, and upon seeing people, the heart trembles—
the **gallbladder** and **liver** are paired; when the liver is vacuous, its **#1** *xie* (evil) **thins its qi**, hence one avoids people, and upon seeing them, the heart trembles.
Heat is excessive, sweating is profuse—
when **evil is盛**, heat is excessive; **wind-stroke** causes sweating.
Needle the **foot *Shàoyáng***. **Xiáxī** governs it.

**Xiáxī** lies at the junction of the second toe (next to the little toe) on the foot, in the depression before the metatarsal bone—this is the **honor vessel** of *Shàoyáng*. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn* (same-length units as the body), retaining the needle for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

For **fever of the *Yángmíng*** (foot *Major Yang*), it makes one first experience chills—shivering and trembling—with severe chills lasting long before heat arrives. When the heat subsides, sweating occurs, and one finds relief upon seeing sunlight, moonlight, or fire. When **Yang is vacuous**, the exterior first feels cold; when Yang vacuity reaches its extreme, it rebounds in excess, hence the severe chills lasting long before heat arrives. When the heat subsides and sweating ceases, **Yin internally grows strong**, and since Yang cannot overcome Yin, one finds relief upon seeing sunlight, moonlight, or fire.

Needle **Fùshàng** on the foot *Yángmíng*. This is the **Chōngyáng** point.
It lies five *cùn* above the ankle on the bone, where the pulsating artery is found. Three *cùn* above the **Xiagǔ** depression, this is the **source** of *Yángmíng*. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn*, retaining the needle for ten breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Fùshàng** is pronounced *fù* (as in "deliver").

For **fever of the *Tàiyīn*** (foot *Greater Yin*), it makes one discontented, prone to deep sighing—
when **heart qi flows into the lungs**, joy arises, but the **spleen’s storage** receives the illness. The **heart (mother)** attempts to rescue it, and **fire-qi descends into the spleen**, failing to ascend to the lungs.
Additionally, the *Tàiyīn* vessel branches and ascends from the stomach to the **epigastrium**, entering the heart. Hence, one becomes discontented and prone to deep sighing.
One loses appetite, with frequent chills, heats, and sweating—
the **spleen governs transformation of grains**, and **nutritive qi** assists the four limbs. Now that **evil thins its qi**, all the **viscera lack nourishment**; earth relies on the four seasons, and when the **sovereign (spleen) is weak**, **pathogenic qi contend**. Hence, one loses appetite, with frequent chills, heats, and sweating.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, it reads: "Frequent chills, little heat."
When the illness arrives, one becomes prone to vomiting; after vomiting, the illness wanes.
The *Tàiyīn* vessel of the foot enters the abdomen, connecting to the spleen and networked with the stomach, ascending to the **epigastrium** and **Xiáyǐn**. Hence, when the pathogenic qi arrives, vomiting occurs, and after vomiting, the illness wanes. **Take it immediately.**
Wait for the illness to wane, then **take it**—this refers to needling the **jing-well** and **yuan-source** points, as well as **Gōngsūn**.
**Gōngsūn** lies one *cùn* behind the base of the big toe on the foot, a *Tàiyīn* network point. Needling may penetrate to four *cùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

For **fever of the *Shàoyīn*** (foot *Minor Yin*), it causes severe vomiting, with frequent chills and heats—more heat than chills—
the *Shàoyīn* vessel of the foot pierces the **liver’s epigastrium**, entering the lungs, and follows the throat. Hence, severe vomiting occurs, with frequent chills and heats. The **kidney is the Yin viscera**, and **Yin-qi generates cold**; now that **Yin-qi is insufficient**, heat predominates over chills.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, it reads: "Severe vomiting, frequent chills, little heat."
One desires to shut oneself in darkness, and the illness is difficult to cure.
The *Yángmíng* vessel of the stomach, when diseased, desires solitude in darkness—now this refers to **stomach (earth) illness**, yet **kidney (water) is affected**; earth **executes water**, hence the illness is difficult to cure.
**Tàizhōng** and **Tàixī** govern it.
**Tàizhōng** lies in the depression behind the inner ankle’s **street** (midline), a *Shàoyīn* network point. Needling may penetrate to two *cùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Tàixī** lies in the depression above the heel’s pulsating artery behind the inner ankle, the *Shàoyīn* **yuan-source** point. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, it reads: "The illness is difficult to cure; take **Tàixī**."
Additionally, according to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, **Tàizhōng** is recorded as **"suōzhōng behind the heel"**; in the *"Needling Lumbar Pain"* section’s annotation, it reads **"pulsating artery behind the heel’s street"**; in the *"Water Orifices"* annotation, it states **"behind the inner ankle"**—these annotations differ, and the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* should be taken as correct.

For **fever of the *Juéyīn*** (foot *Converging Yin*), it causes lumbar pain, lower abdominal fullness, and **difficult urination resembling fever**—not **epilepsy**—with frequent urination, anxiety, and **insufficient qi**, making the abdomen **moist and resonant**.
The *Juéyīn* vessel of the foot follows the **inner thigh**, entering the **sacrum**, encircling the **genitals**, and reaching the lower abdomen. Hence, the illness manifests thus.
**Cì** refers to **inability to urinate**.
**Yìyì** describes **blocked flow**.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, the three characters **"frequent urination, anxiety"** are recorded as **"frequent sighing."**

Needle the foot *Juéyīn*. **Tàichōng** governs it, lying in the depression two *cùn* behind the base of the big toe, the *Juéyīn* **yuan-source** point. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn*, retaining the needle for ten breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *"Needling Lumbar Pain"* annotation, it reads: **"In the depression behind the joint, pressing the artery."**

For **lung fever**, it makes one feel **heart-chilled**—
with severe chills followed by heat, and when heat arrives, one is prone to **startling**, as if seeing something.
Needle the **hand *Tàiyīn* and *Yángmíng***.
**Fēngquē** governs it.
**Lièquē** lies one and a half *cùn* behind the wrist, a *Tàiyīn* network point. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn*, retaining the needle for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* may be used.
The *Yángmíng* point: **Hégǔ** governs it.
**Hégǔ** lies at the junction of the second finger (next to the thumb) on the hand, where the *Yángmíng* vessel passes. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn*, retaining the needle for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

For **heart fever**, it causes **severe mental agitation**, a desire for cold water, with **predominant chills** and **little heat**.
Needle the **hand *Shàoyīn***.
**Shénmén** governs it.
**Shénmén** lies in the depression at the end of the **sharp bone** on the palm’s posterior, the *Shàoyīn* **yuan-source** point. Needling may penetrate to three *cùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *Tàisū*, it reads: **"Desire for cold water and predominant chills, with little heat and severe heat."**

**Liver ague** causes the patient to appear ashen-gray, sighing deeply, with a lifeless appearance. Needle the *foot Juéyīn* until blood appears.
**Zhōngfēng** governs it.
**Zhōngfēng** lies one and a half *cùn* above the medial malleolus, in the depression when the foot is dorsiflexed. It belongs to the *foot Juéyīn* channel. Needling should draw blood; habitual needling may penetrate four *fēn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Spleen ague** causes chills, abdominal pain, and when heat arises, rumbling in the intestines, followed by sweating after the rumbling ceases. Needle the *foot Tàiyīn*.
**Shāngqiū** governs it.
**Shāngqiū** lies just below and slightly anterior to the medial malleolus, in the depression, belonging to the *foot Tàiyīn* channel. Needling may penetrate three *fēn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Kidney ague** causes the patient to tremble, with lumbar and spinal pain, difficulty turning, constipation, a tight chest, and cold hands and feet. Needle the *foot Tàiyáng-Shàoyīn*.
**Tàizhōng** governs it.
Locate it as in the method for *foot Shàoyīn* ague.

**Stomach ague** initially presents as a carbuncle (*jū*), with voracious hunger yet inability to eat, and distension of the abdomen after eating—due to **stomach heat and spleen vacuity**, hence the voracious hunger yet inability to eat, and postprandial abdominal distension.
**Newly corrected text states:** According to the *Tàisū*, it reads: **"Initially presents as a carbuncle."**
Needle the transverse vessels of the *foot Yángmíng-Tàiyīn* to draw blood. **Lìduì, Jiěxī, and Sānlǐ** govern it.
**Lìduì** lies at the tip of the second toe, adjacent to the nail like a scallion leaf—*Yángmíng*’s **well** point. Needling may penetrate one *fēn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for one breath. If moxibustion is applied, one *zhàng* may be used.
**Jiěxī** lies three and a half *cùn* above *Chōngyáng*, in the depression on the wrist—*Yángmíng* channel. Needling may penetrate five *fēn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Sānlǐ** lies three *cùn* below the knee, between the two tendons beside the *fù* bone—*Yángmíng*’s **convergence** point. Needling may penetrate one *cùn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
However, for the *foot Yángmíng*, these three points are used, and the *foot Tàiyīn* transverse vessels are needled to draw blood.
The **transverse vessels** refer to the oblique vessels crossing the large pulse anterior to the medial malleolus—*Tàiyīn*’s channel vessels.
**Newly corrected text states:** *Jiěxī* is detailed as three and a half *cùn* behind *Chōngyáng*. According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, it is one and a half *cùn*; the *Qì Xuélùn* annotation states two and a half *cùn*.

When ague heat arises, needle the **pulsating vessel on the dorsum of the foot**—*Yángmíng*’s vessel. Open the space and let blood flow; the patient will immediately feel cold. *Yángmíng*’s vessel is rich in blood and *qi*; with excessive heat and robust *qi*, letting blood will immediately induce cold.

When ague is about to turn cold, needle the *hand Yángmíng-Tàiyīn* and *foot Yángmíng-Tàiyīn*—that is, open the points and let blood flow, following the **well** and **convergence** points.

If the ague pulse is **full, large, and tense**, needle the **back shu** points using a **midline needle**, one on each side of the **five *Zhù* shu** points, adjusting for fatness or thinness to draw blood. The **back shu** refers to *Dàzhú*; the **five *Zhù* shu** refers to *Huìxī* (pronounced *Huìxí*).
If the ague pulse is **small, firm, and tense**, moxibustion is applied to the *Jīng-Shàoyīn* channel, and the **finger well** is needled.
Moxibustion on the *Jīng-Shàoyīn* channel refers to **Fùliú**. *Fùliú* lies two *cùn* above the medial malleolus, in the depression—*foot Shàoyīn* channel. Needling may penetrate three *fēn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* may be used.
Needling the **finger well** refers to needling **Zhìyīn**. *Zhìyīn* lies on the lateral side of the little toe, adjacent to the nail like a scallion leaf—*foot Tàiyáng*’s **well** point. Needling may penetrate one *fēn* of the *tóngshēncùn*, retaining the needle for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

If the ague pulse is **full, large, and tense**, needle the **back shu** points using **five *Zhù* shu** and **back shu**, one each, adjusting for fatness or thinness, following the *Sānbèi Fǎ* to reach the blood vessels. The **back shu** refers to *Dàzhú*; the **five *Zhù* shu** refers to *Huìxī* governing it.
**Newly corrected text states:** From *"If the ague pulse is full, large, and tense"* to the end of this annotation, the text and annotation total fifty-five characters, which should be omitted. The passage duplicates the preceding text; Wang’s annotations merely follow without additional meaning, unlike Shì’ān’s precision, so it is not repeated.

If the ague pulse is **slow, large, and vacuous**, medicinal treatment is appropriate; needling is contraindicated. A slow pulse indicates **windstroke**; a large pulse indicates **real *qi***; a vacuous pulse indicates **blood vacuity**. With blood vacuity and real *qi*, and wind further assaulting, medicinal treatment is preferred to expel the pathogen; needling to let blood is inappropriate.

In treating ague, needle **only when the attack begins**, as if after a meal’s duration—delaying beyond this misses the optimal timing. At the onset, **true and false *qi*** reside separately, and pathogenic waves have not yet surged, making treatment possible. If delayed, true and false *qi* merge, and needling may instead injure the true *qi*, hence the saying *"missing the timing."*

**Newly corrected text states:** From *"If the ague pulse is slow, large, and vacuous"* to here, the entire passage originally appeared in Volume Four of Yuánqǐ’s text, later appended by Wang.

For agues where the pulse is **not apparent**, needle the **webbed spaces between all ten fingers** to draw blood; the patient will recover once blood is released. First, locate and remove all **erythematous spots** like small mung beans on the body.

For the **twelve types of ague**, their onsets occur at different times. Observe the patient’s symptoms to determine which channel’s pulse is affected. Follow the **symptoms and signs** to identify the diseased pulse. Needle **at the onset**, as if after a meal’s duration: one needling weakens it, two needlings resolve it, and three needlings cure it.

If the ague does not cease, needle the **two pulses beneath the tongue** (*Lianquan*) to draw blood; the method is detailed below.

If the ague persists, needle the **abundant meridians at the armpit** (*Weizhong*—i.e., **Weizhong**, *Dazhu*, *Fengmen*, and *Refu* acupoints) to draw blood, or needle the **region below the nape and beside the spine** (*Dazhu*, *Fengmen*, *Refu*), which will surely cease it. These are all the **pulse-qi of the Foot Taiyang Channel**.

**Weizhong** (*Dazhu*) is located below the first cervical vertebra on both sides, each at a distance of **one to one-and-a-half body-inches** (*tóngshēncùn*), within the depression. Needling can penetrate **three body-inches’ worth**, leaving the needle for seven breaths; if moxibustion is applied, **five moxa cones** (*wǔzhuàng*) may be used. **Fengmen and Refu** are found below the second cervical vertebra (*#6—i.e., the second cervical vertebra, *C2*), each at a distance of **one to one-and-a-half body-inches**, with needling penetrating **five body-inches’ worth**, leaving for seven breaths; if moxibustion is applied, **five moxa cones** may be used.

*Note:* The newly corrected text states: Regarding *Dazhu* moxibustion, the *Jiayi Jing* records **seven moxa cones**, while the *Qixue Lun* annotation also records **seven moxa cones**; however, the *Cihuo Lun* and *Rexue* annotations both record **five moxa cones**.

The **two pulses beneath the tongue** are **Lianquan**, an acupoint. Located at the **chin, beneath the tongue’s root, and above the hyoid bone**, it is the **convergence of Yinwei and Renmai**. Needling can penetrate **three body-inches’ worth**, leaving for three breaths; if moxibustion is applied, **three moxa cones** may be used.

When needling agues, first inquire about where the patient’s symptoms first appeared. Needle that region first.

If **headaches** or **heaviness** are the initial symptoms, needle the **top of the head** and the **spaces between the eyebrows and temples** to draw blood. The **top of the head** refers to **Shangxing and Baihui**; the **spaces between the eyebrows** refer to **Xuánlú**; the **spaces between the temples** refer to acupoints like **Zhuánzhú**.

If **neck or back pain** is the initial symptom, needle those regions first. The **neck** is governed by **Fengchi and Fengfu**; the **back** by **Dazhu and Shendao**.

If **lumbar or spinal pain** is the initial symptom, needle **Weizhong** to draw blood.

If **arm pain** is the initial symptom, needle the **ten fingers of the Hand Shaoyin and Yangming Channels**. *Note:* The newly corrected text states: According to another version, it is the **Hand Yin and Yang Channels**; the original text also reads **Hand Yin and Yang**.

If **acidic or painful sensations along the limbs** are the initial symptoms, needle the **ten fingers of the Foot Yangming Channel** to draw blood. Each method corresponds to the **path of the pathogenic factor** (*xiéjū*) and should be adjusted accordingly.

For **wind-induced ague**, when the ague occurs, the patient **sweats and dislikes wind**; needle the **blood vessels of the three Yang channels’ back-shu points**. *Note:* The *Jiayi Jing* states **Foot Three Yang**.

If **abdominal pain is severe**, pressing it causes no resistance, and the condition is called **"drilling marrow disease"** (*bìsuǐ bìng*), then use a **sharp needle** to pierce the **absolute bone** (*juéshǔ*—i.e., **Yangfu** acupoint) and draw blood; the patient will recover immediately. The method is similar to the **moxibustion technique for Zhongfu and Shendao** described in the *Qixue Lun*.

**Zhǒu** (*Zhou*—pronounced as *hóngfù* in phonetic annotation) and **镜** (*Jìng*—pronounced as *chúxián* in phonetic annotation) refer to **elbow and shoulder pain**. For **generalized body pain**, needle **Zhiyin**.

*Note:* The newly corrected text states: The *Jiayi Jing* does not include the term **"Zhiyin"**.

For all **Yin Channel well points** (*jǐng*), there is no bloodletting; one needling is sufficient. The **well points** are all located at the **tips of the fingers**; the **well point of the Foot Shaoyin Channel** is at the **center of the sole**.

If the ague **does not cause thirst** but occurs **every other day**, needle the **Foot Taiyang Channel**. *Note:* The newly corrected text states: The *Jiǔjuàn* records **Foot Yangming**; the *Taosū* agrees.

If the ague **causes thirst** and occurs **every other day**, needle the **Foot Shaoyang Channel**. *Note:* The newly corrected text states: The *Jiǔjuàn* records **Hand Shaoyang**; the *Taosū* agrees.

For **warm ague**, where **no sweat is produced**, apply **fifty-nine needlings**. From **stomach-induced ague** onward, refer to the *Huángdì Zhōngzhì Tújīng* for its governing principles; discrepancies may reflect ancient variations in technique.

**Qi Jue Theory** (*Qìjué Lùn*)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How do the five Zang organs and six Fu organs transmit cold and heat to one another?"*

**Qíbó** replied: *"The kidney transmits cold to the liver, causing **flaccid paralysis** (*tānzhǒng*) and **swelling**, with **shortness of breath** (*shǎoqì*). The liver stores blood, but when cold enters, the **Yang-qi** fails to disperse. If the Yang-qi does not disperse, blood stagnates and the **pulse-qi becomes sluggish** (*qìsè*), hence the **flaccid paralysis** and **shortness of breath**."

*Note:* The newly corrected text states: According to the original *Yuánqǐ* text, it reads: *"The kidney transmits cold to the spleen."* Yuanqi’s annotation states: *"The kidney is injured by cold and transmitted to the spleen; the spleen governs flesh, and cold in the flesh congeals into firmness, which then transforms into pus, hence the **flaccid paralysis** (*tān*)."* Blood is injured and **pulse-qi is deficient**, hence the **shortness of breath**." The *Jiayi Jing* also reads *"transmits cold to the spleen,"* but Wang mistakenly altered the original text, interpreting it as *"liver,"*—another error by a learned scholar.

*"The spleen transmits cold to the liver, causing **flaccid paralysis**, **swelling**, and **tendon spasm** (*jīnluán*). The spleen governs and stores flesh, while the liver governs tendons; warm flesh relaxes tendons, but cold flesh tightens them, hence the **tendon spasm**." Cold flesh congeals the **Wei-qi**, causing **flaccid paralysis** and **swelling**.

*"The liver transmits cold to the heart, causing **madness** (*kuáng*) and **blocked midriff** (*gé sè zhōng*). The heart is a **Yang Zang organ**, with the spirit dwelling within; if cold invades it, the spirit becomes disordered, hence the **madness**. The Yang-qi is obstructed by cold, hence the **blocked midriff** and **impaired central passage** (*zhōng bùtōng*)."

*"The heart transmits cold to the lung, causing **lung consumption** (*fèi xiāo*). For lung consumption, when the patient drinks, the liquid **sinks immediately** (*yīn yī wù èr*), and death is inevitable. The heart is a Yang Zang organ, and if it **inversely receives cold**, the cold-qi cannot be dissipated, then transmitted to the lung. Cold follows the heart’s fire inward, **melting the metal essence** (*jīn jīng*), and the metal is harmed by the fire’s pathogenic factor, hence the **lung consumption**." Yet the lung stores and **consumes/melts** (*xiāo shuò*), and if its **pulse-qi has no foundation**, then drinking causes **immediate sinking** (*yīn yī*) and **double waves** (*bō èr*). Metal and fire **mutually harm** (*xiāng zé*), hence death cannot be treated.

*"The lung transmits cold to the kidney, causing **rushing water** (*yǒngshuǐ*). For rushing water, pressing the abdomen causes no firmness; **water-qi invades the large intestine**, and when the patient moves, the **intestines rumble** (*wū*), producing a **splashing sound** (*zhuózhuó*), as if a **pouch wrapped in liquid** (*nángguǒ jiāng*). This is the **disease of water**." The lung stores **pulse-qi**, while the kidney governs water; if lung cold enters the kidney, the kidney’s **pulse-qi is excessive** (*yǒuyú*), and the **excessive pulse-qi rushes upward to the lung**, hence the term **"rushing water"**. The large intestine is the **Fu organ of the lung**, but since both the lung and kidney are **afflicted by cold**, neither can transmit it properly, so the **water-qi invades the large intestine**. The kidney, **receiving congealed cold**, cannot **transform fluids**; the large intestine **accumulates water** and fails to **drain properly**, hence when the patient moves, the **intestines rumble** and produce a **splashing sound**, as if a **pouch wrapped in liquid**, manifesting as the **disease of water**.

「○The newly corrected text states: According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), **"disease of water"** is treated as a matter of the lung. When the spleen transmits heat to the liver, it results in *jīngniǔ* (惊钮). The liver stores blood and also governs shock; thus, when heat afflicts the liver, shock occurs and blood issues from the nose. If the liver transmits heat to the heart, death ensues. The two Yang organs (heart and liver) harmonize, and fire (heart) and wood (liver) mutually consume each other#8; hence, when liver heat enters the heart, death is certain. The *Yīn-Yáng Biélùn* (阴阳别论) says: The "heart of the liver" is called *shēngyáng* (生阳), and those afflicted by *shēngyáng* perish within four days.

○The newly corrected text states: According to the meaning of the *Yīn-Yáng Biélùn* (阴阳别论), this differs from the passage above. The Wang school incorrectly cites that flawed text to support this interpretation. When the heart transmits heat to the lung, it becomes *lìxiāo* (鬲消). The heart and lung are paired organs, separated by the oblique *lì* (鬲) membrane, which connects downward to the horizontal *lì* (鬲) membrane; thus, when heart heat enters the lung, prolonged transmission and transformation result in *lì* (鬲) heat and *xiāo* (消渴), causing excessive thirst.

When the lung transmits heat to the kidney, it becomes *róuzhìng* (柔痊). *Róu* (柔) refers to weak tendons, while *zhìng* (痉) refers to rigid bones that do not comply. When both *qi* (气) and bones are heated, marrow fails to nourish internally, causing bones to become rigid and strong yet unable to move, while tendons grow weak and slack, lacking strength. *Zhìng* (痉) is pronounced *zhí* (职).

When the kidney transmits heat to the spleen, it becomes *xū* (虚), and *chángbì* (肠僻) leads to death, rendering it incurable. The spleen, representing earth, normally restrains water, but when the kidney instead transmits heat to it, the spleen’s earth nature cannot control water, resulting in prolonged depletion (*xū* 损). Those with *chángbì* (肠僻) death have their kidney’s *jīngqì* (精气) internally consumed; the lower burner lacks governance to sustain it, so *chángbì* (肠僻) is eliminated and *qì* (气) cannot be restrained.

When the *bāo* (胞) transmits heat to the bladder, it causes *zhèngniào xuèyǔ* (症溺血). The bladder is the repository of body fluids, while the *bāo* (胞) oversees their reception; thus, when heat enters the bladder, the *bāo* (胞) is internally heated, causing the yin vessels to overflow, resulting in inability to urinate and blood in the urine. The *Zhènglǐ Shū* (正理论) states: Heat in the lower burner causes blood in the urine. This is what is meant.

When the bladder transmits heat to the small intestine, the *lì* (鬲) and intestines become obstructed, and the mouth develops *kūilián* (口麋). The small intestine’s pulse connects with the heart, descends the throat, passes through the diaphragm, and reaches the stomach before belonging to the small intestine; thus, when it receives heat, it obstructs the *lì* (鬲) and intestines below, while above, sores form in the mouth and *kū* (麋) appears. *Kū* (麋) means "rotting." *Lián* (斓) is pronounced *méi* (糜), with a tone of *wǔ* (武) and cut as *bēi* (悲). When the small intestine transmits heat to the large intestine, it becomes *chù* (处痴) or *chén* (沉). Once the small intestine’s heat has entered, the large intestine is affected by both heats, causing blood to overflow and resulting in *fúxuàn* (伏痕). Stagnant and uncirculated blood leads to delayed menstruation and non-flow, hence the term *fúxuàn* (伏痴) or *chén* (沉). *Chù* (处) is synonymous with *fú* (伏). *Xuàn* (痕) is mistakenly transmitted as *shuài* (疝).

When the large intestine transmits heat to the stomach, the patient eats voraciously yet grows emaciated, termed *shíyì* (食亦). The stomach is the "sea of water and grain," its *qi* nourishing muscles externally; heat consumes water and grain while also melting muscles, causing voracious eating yet emaciation. *Shíyì* (食亦) refers to food entering and being easily expelled, failing to nourish flesh and skin. *Yì* (亦) means "easily." ○The newly corrected text states: According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), *入* (入) is written as *又* (yòu). The Wang school’s annotation reads: "Voracious eating yet emaciation." This lacks meaning and is not as coherent as the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* (甲乙经) version, which should be read in conjunction with the following text. When the stomach transmits heat to the gallbladder, it is also termed *shíyì* (食亦). The meaning is the same as above.

When the gallbladder transmits heat to the brain, it results in *sīnlèi níbì* (辛类鼻渊). *Níbì* (鼻渊) refers to incessant discharge of turbid mucus. When brain fluids seep downward, they form turbid mucus, which flows continuously like a water spring, hence the term *níbì* (鼻渊). *Bì* (渊) means "nasal obstruction." The *Zú-Tàiyáng* (足太阳) pulse originates at the inner canthus, ascends the forehead, and converges at the vertex before entering the brain. The *Zú-Yángmíng* (足阳明) pulse originates at the nose, converges at the *bì* (频) point, and runs beside the *Tàiyáng* (太阳) pulse. When the brain is heated, the *Zú-Tàiyáng* (足太阳) pulse reverses, and both *Zú-Tàiyáng* (足太阳) and *Zú-Yángmíng* (足阳明) pulses become excessive, afflicting the *lèi* (类) region, causing nasal pain (*sīn* 辛). Hence, the following text states: It transmits as *niǔliè míngmù* (钮瓖暝目). *Sīn* (辛) means "acidic#10/painful."」

When the *Zú-Yángmíng* pulse converges at the *bì* (频) point and runs beside the *Tàiyáng* (太阳) pulse, if the ears become excessively heated, the yang collaterals overflow, and the yang collaterals overflowing cause *niǔ* (钮) to discharge blood in sweat. *Qì* (戚), here meaning "blood in sweat."

When the blood discharge is severe, the *Yángmíng* and *Tàiyáng* pulses weaken, failing to nourish the eyes, hence the ears become *míng* (暝). *Míng* means "darkened." *Dié* (蝶) is pronounced *mò jié qiè*.

Thus, this condition arises from *qìjué* (气厥). *Jué* (厥) means "inversion of *qi*." All such cases stem from *qi* inversion.
