**Huángdì nèijīng Sūwèn bǔ zhùshì wén** *Vol. 27*
Annotated by **Táng Tàipù Lìng Qǐ Xuànzǐ Wáng Bīng**, revised by **Sòng Guànlǜ Qīng Lín Yì** et al., and corrected by **Sòng Shǒushù Shàngshū Tún Tián Láng Sūn Zhào**.

**Chapter on "Jue" (Sudden Collapse)**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why does the condition of **Jue** (厥) involve cold and heat?"*
**Jue** refers to the reversal of **Qi** (氣) ascending.

The world mistakenly transmits it as *"foot **Qi**"* (脚氣), so I have broadly annotated the theories.

Qibo replied: *"When the **Yang Qi** (陽氣) weakens below, it results in cold **Jue**; when the **Yin Qi** (陰氣) weakens below, it results in hot **Jue**.*
**Yang** refers to the three **Yang** meridians of the foot;
**Yin** refers to the three **Yin** meridians of the foot.
*Below* means the foot.

The Emperor said: *"Why must hot **Jue** begin from the foot below?"*
Since **Yang** governs the exterior and **Jue** occurs internally, He inquired.

Qibo said: *"The **Yang Qi** originates from the outer side of the five toes of the foot, while the **Yin** meridians gather below the foot and converge at the foot’s center. Thus, when **Yang Qi** prevails, the foot below grows hot.*
In general terms:
The **Foot Taiyang** (足太陽) meridian emerges from the outer lateral end of the little toe;
The **Foot Shaoyang** (足少陽) meridian emerges from the end of the little toe’s adjacent toe;
The **Foot Yangming** (足陽明) meridian emerges from the ends of the middle and big toes,
all ascending along the **Yang** pathways of the foot.
The **Liver** and **Spleen** meridians gather below the foot,
converging at the foot’s center,
so when **Yin** is weak, the foot below grows hot.

**New Annotation:** *"According to the Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙經), ‘**Yang Qi** originates from the foot’ should read ‘**Yang Qi** ascends from the foot.’ ‘*Originates*’ should be corrected to ‘*ascends*.’"*

The Emperor said: *"Why must cold **Jue** begin from the five toes and ascend to the knee?"*
Since **Yin** governs the interior and **Jue** occurs externally, He inquired.

Qibo said: *"The **Yin Qi** originates from the inner side of the five toes, gathers below the knee, and converges above it. Thus, when **Yin Qi** prevails, cold ascends from the five toes to above the knee—but this cold does not come from the exterior; it all comes from the interior.*
This is also a general statement.

The **Foot Taiyin** (足太陰) meridian originates from the inner lateral end of the big toe;
The **Foot Jueyin** (足厥陰) meridian originates from the center of the three hairs at the end of the big toe;
The **Foot Shaoyin** (足少陰) meridian originates below the little toe, slanting inward toward the foot’s center,
all ascending along the **Yin** pathways of the foot and entering the **Yin** of the thigh, then the abdomen.
Thus, it is said that they gather below the knee and converge above it.

The Emperor said: *"Why does cold **Jue** occur when it does?"*
Qibo replied: *"The anterior **Yin** (前阴) is where the **Zong** (宗) tendons converge and where the **Taiyin** (太陰) and **Yangming** (陽明) meridians meet.*
The **Zong** tendons align at the **Jia** (侠) and **Qi** (齐), merging below with the **Yin** organs.
Thus, it is said that the anterior **Yin** is where the **Zong** tendons converge.
**Taiyin** refers to the **Spleen** meridian;
**Yangming** refers to the **Stomach** meridian.
The **Spleen** and **Stomach** meridians both support the **Zong** tendons closely,
so it is said that they meet at the **Taiyin** and **Yangming**.

**New Annotation:** *"According to the Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙經), ‘*Anterior **Yin** (前阴)*’ is where the **Zong** tendons converge,’ should read ‘*Anterior **Jueyin** (厥陰)*’ is where the tendons gather.’*
**Quanyuan** (全元起) states: ‘*Anterior **Yin** (前阴)*’ refers to **Jueyin** (厥陰).*
This differs from Wang’s annotation but is another valid interpretation.

*In spring and summer, **Yang Qi** is abundant while **Yin Qi** is scarce;
in autumn and winter, **Yin Qi** thrives while **Yang Qi** weakens.*
This is the **Dao/Way** (道) of Heaven’s constant order.
*For those of robust constitution (質壮),*
when autumn and winter deplete their **vitality** (所用),
the descending **Qi** (下氣) struggles upward and cannot recover,
causing **Essence** (精氣) and **Qi** (氣) to overflow downward,
while **pathogenic **Qi** (邪氣)** follows and ascends.

**Quality** (質) refers to bodily constitution.
**Depleted by overuse** (奪於所用) means excessive desires drain their **Essence** and **Qi****.
**Qi arises from the center** (氣因於中) —
**New Annotation:** *"According to the Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙經), ‘*Qi arises from the center*’ (氣因於中) should read ‘*Qi arises from the center of the body*’ (所中)."*

When **Yang Qi** weakens, it cannot permeate and nourish the **meridians** (經) and **collaterals** (絡), so **Yang Qi** diminishes daily, while **Yin Qi** remains alone, hence the hands and feet become cold.

The Emperor asked: *"How does heat-induced **ulceration** (熱厥) arise?"*
Trace its origin, and you shall know.

Qìbó replied: When **alcohol** enters the **stomach** (胃),
the **collaterals** (絡脈) become full while the **meridians** (經脈) grow empty.
The **Spleen** (脾) governs the distribution of **fluids** (津液) to the **stomach** (胃),
and when **Yin Qi** is depleted, **Yang Qi** invades.
When **Yang Qi** invades, the **stomach** (胃) becomes unbalanced,
and when the **stomach** (胃) is unbalanced, **Essence** (精氣) is exhausted.
When **Essence** (精氣) is exhausted, it cannot nourish the four limbs (四支).
The **front Yin** (前阴) is where the **Tai-Yin** (太陰) and **Yang-Ming** (陽明) meridians converge—
thus it is named.
When the **stomach** (胃) is unbalanced, **Essence** (精氣) is exhausted.
When **Essence** (精氣) is internally insufficient, the four limbs lack **Qi** to nourish them.
Such a person must often be intoxicated (數醉),
or overfed (若饱) and then engage in sexual activity (以入房),
causing **Qi** to gather in the **Spleen** (脾) and fail to disperse.
When **alcohol Qi** (酒氣) and **grain Qi** (谷氣) clash,
heat flourishes within, thus heat spreads throughout the body,
and internal heat causes **urine** (溺) to turn red.

When **alcohol Qi** (酒氣) is excessive and **Spleen Qi** (脾氣) is weakened,
**Kidney Qi** (腎氣) declines daily, and **Yang Qi** (陽氣) prevails alone,
hence the hands and feet become hot.
Intoxication and overfeeding followed by sexual activity
exhaust **Essence** (精氣) internally, leaving the center empty and heat invading,
thus **Kidney Qi** (腎氣) weakens, **Yang** (陽) predominates while **Yin** (陰) is depleted,
and heat arises in the hands and feet.

The Emperor asked: *"Why does **ulceration** (厥) sometimes cause abdominal distension (腹满),
sometimes sudden loss of consciousness (暴不知人),
and sometimes take half a day or even a full day before consciousness returns?"*
*"Sudden"* (暴) is akin to *"abrupt"* (卒).
It refers to an abrupt onset where one is unaware and unresponsive.
*"Unknown to others"* (不知人) means one does not recognize people at all.
Some call this **corpse-like **ulceration** (尸厥)**.

Qìbó replied: When **Yin Qi** (陰氣) is excessive in the upper body (上),
the lower body (下) becomes empty, causing abdominal distension (腹满).
When **Yang Qi** (陽氣) is excessive in the upper body (上),
the descending **Qi** (下氣) presses upward, and **pathogenic **Qi** (邪氣)** reverses,
reversing then causes **Yang Qi** (陽氣) to become chaotic,
and when **Yang Qi** (陽氣) is chaotic, one loses consciousness (不知人).

**Yin** (陰) refers to the **Tai-Yin** (足太陰) of the feet.
*New Annotation: According to the Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙經), the phrase "When **Yang Qi** is excessive in the upper body"* (陽氣盛於上) should read "When the **stomach** is full"* (腹满), which aligns with the Jia-Yi Jing's explanation.*

Why so? Because the Jia-Yi Jing states:
*"When the **Yang meridian** descends and collapses (陽脉下坠),
and the **Yin meridian** ascends in contest (阴脉上争),
it triggers **corpse-like **ulceration** (尸厥)**."*
How can **Yin Qi** (陰氣) be excessive above,
while also stating **Yang Qi** (陽氣) is excessive above?
Zhang Zhòngjǐng further explains:
*"When the **Shao-Yin** (少陰) meridian fails to reach,
**Kidney Qi** (腎氣) is weak, with little **Essence** (精) and **blood** (血).
**Qi** (氣) rushes upward, pressing the **heart** (心) and **diaphragm** (鬲).
**Zong Qi** (宗氣) retreats and gathers, causing **blood** (血) to congeal beneath the heart.
**Yang Qi** (陽氣) descends, and heat returns to the **Yin** (陰) regions of the legs,
moving with **Yin** (陰) and preventing the body from being at ease (不七).
This is **corpse-like **ulceration** (尸厥)**."*
Zhang Zhòngjǐng’s account of **Yang Qi** (陽氣) descending
indicates that **Yang Qi** (陽氣) cannot be excessive above,
thus confirming the Jia-Yi Jing’s interpretation.
Moreover, the Emperor’s annotation that **Yin** (陰) refers solely to **Tai-Yin** (足太陰) is also incomplete.

According to the *Móu Cì Lùn* (缪刺论):
*"When **pathogenic **Qi** (邪氣)** lodges in the **collaterals** (絡) of the **Shao-Yin** (手足少陰),
**Tai-Yin** (太陰), and **Yang-Ming** (足陽明) meridians,
these five **collaterals** (絡) all converge in the **ear** (耳).
The left **ear** (角) is where the **collaterals** (絡) ascend,
and when all five **collaterals** (絡) are depleted,
it causes the body’s **pulse** (脉) to move erratically while the form remains unresponsive,
appearing lifeless, or what is called **corpse-like **ulceration** (尸厥)**."*
How can one attribute **ulceration** (厥) solely to **Tai-Yin** (太陰)?

The Emperor said: *"Well explained.*
I wish to hear the **ulceration** (厥) patterns of the six **meridians** (經脈) and their corresponding diseases."*

Qìbó replied: When the **Jù-Yáng** (巨陽) meridian undergoes **ulceration** (厥),
the head swells and feels heavy (頭重),
the feet cannot move (不能行),
and it leads to **convulsions** (發為㿟仆).
The **Jù-Yáng** (巨陽) is the **Tai-Yang** (太陽) meridian.
The **Tai-Yang** (太陽) **collateral** (豚) begins at the inner canthus (目内毗),
ascends to the forehead (上额), and meets at the vertex (交巅上).
Its branches diverge (支别者) from the vertex to the upper ear angle (至耳上角).
Its direct course (其直行者) descends from the vertex into the **collaterals** (絡) of the brain (脑),
returns and emerges below the nape (下项),
follows the inner aspect of the shoulder and scapula (循肩膊内),
passes along the spine (侠脊抵腰中),
enters and descends along the **collaterals** (絡) of the lumbar region (膂),
connecting to the **Kidney** (腎) and **Bladder** (膀胱).
Its other branches (其支别者) descend from the lumbar region (腰中),
pass through the buttocks (下贯臀),
and enter the **Bladder** (胭中).
Another branch (其支别者) diverges from the inner scapula (膊内),
spreading left and right to descend through the **collaterals** (絡) of the buttocks (贯肿),
passing the **sacral hiatus** (□枢),
following the outer aspect of the hip (循□外饰后康下),
and merging with the **Bladder** (胭中).
Below, it descends into the inner aspect of the thigh (踹内),
emerges behind the medial malleolus (外踝之后),
and follows the **ankle bone** (京骨) to the lateral side of the little toe (至小指之端外侧).
Thus, **ulceration** (厥) patterns manifest externally as such.
*"Swelling"* (肿) should not be mistaken for *"heel"* (踵).

When the **Yang-Ming** (陽明) meridian undergoes **ulceration** (厥),
it causes **epilepsy** (癫疾) with a desire to flee or run (欲走呼),
abdominal distension that prevents movement (腹满不得外),
flushed and heated face (面赤而热),
hallucinations (妄见), and incoherent speech (妄言).

The **Yang-Ming** (足陽明) meridian begins at the nose (起於鼻),
meets the **Jīng** (類) at the midpoint of the forehead (交类中),
descends along the outer nose (下循鼻外),
enters the upper teeth (入上齿中),
returns and emerges beside the mouth (还出侠口环唇),
descends to meet the **Chéng Jiāng** (承浆),
then follows the jawline (颐后下廉),
emerges at the **Dà Yíng** (大迎),
and runs along the cheek (循颊) to the **ear** (至車上耳前),
passing the **Kè Zhǔ Rén** (客主人),
reaching the hairline (发际) and the forehead (至额颅).
Its branches (其支别者) diverge from the **Dà Yíng** (大迎) forward,
descend into the **Rén Yíng** (人迎),
follow the throat (喉咙) into the **suprasternal fossa** (缺盆),
descend to the **diaphragm** (鬲), connecting to the **stomach** (胃) and **Spleen** (脾).
Its direct course (其直行者) descends from the **suprasternal fossa** (缺盆),
along the inner aspect of the breast (乳内廉),
then beside the **Qí** (齐) into the **Qì Jiē** (气街).
Another branch (其支别者) begins below the **stomach** (胃),
follows the abdominal **collaterals** (絡) (循腹裹),
descends to the **Qì Jiē** (气街) and merges there.
Below, it descends to the **stomach** (下入胃),
reaches the **Fú Zǐ** (伏菟),
and enters the **knee** (膝).
It descends along the outer aspect of the lower leg (下循腑外康),
attaches to the **foot** (下足附),
and enters the inner side of the middle toe (入中指内问).
Another branch (其支别者) diverges three inches below the knee (下膝三寸),
descending to the outer aspect of the middle toe (入中指外闲).
Yet another branch (其支别者) ascends along the outer aspect of the foot (附上),
enters the outer side of the big toe (入大指闲),
and emerges at its tip (出其端).
Thus, **ulceration** (厥) manifests as such.
*"Epilepsy"* (癫) should not be confused with *"vertex"* (巅).

When the **Shao-Yáng** (少陽) meridian undergoes **ulceration** (厥),
it causes sudden deafness (暴聋),
swollen cheeks with heat (颊肿而热),
lateral pain (胁痛),
and **pathogenic **Qi** (邪氣)** preventing the **organs** (腑) from functioning properly (不可以运).
The **Shao-Yáng** (足少陽) meridian begins at the outer canthus (目锐毗),
ascends to the temple (头角) and behind the ear (下耳后),
follows the neck (循颈),
runs in front of the **hand Shao-Yáng** (手少陽) meridian,
reaches the shoulder (至肩上),
and meets the **hand Shao-Yáng** (手少陽) meridian behind it (交出手少陽之后),
entering the **suprasternal fossa** (入缺盆).
Its branches (其支别者) diverge from behind the ear (耳后),
enter the **ear** (入耳中),
and emerge to run in front of the ear (走耳前),
reaching the outer canthus (至目锐毗后).

The **Shao-Yáng** (少陽) branch diverges from the outer canthus (目锐毗) below the **Great Welcome** (大迎), merging with the **hand Shao-Yáng** (手少陽) meridian at the **Manifest** (显), descending to join the **Cheek Cart** (颊车), then passing down the neck to merge with the **suprasternal fossa** (缺盆) and proceed into the chest (胸中). It pierces the **diaphragmatic region** (鬲), networks the liver (络肝), and belongs to the gallbladder (属胆). Following the lateral ribs (循胁裹), it emerges at the **Qi Street** (气街), encircles the **medial border of the scapula** (髦际), and horizontally enters the **Medullary Depression** (髅厌).

Its direct course (其直行者) descends from the **suprasternal fossa** (缺盆) into the **axillary region** (下掖), travels across the chest and passes the **Seasonal Rib** (季胁), then merges with the **Spleen Depression** (脾厌). Below this, it follows the **Spleen-Yang** meridian (脾阳), emerges at the **external Knee Support** (膝外康), descends to enter before the **external Auxiliary Bone** (外辅骨), reaching down to the **Extreme Bone** (绝骨) and its tip (之端). It then emerges before the **external ankle** (外踝), ascends along the **foot’s lateral aspect** (足附), and exits at the **end of the little toe** (小指) and the **second toe** (次指). Thus, the **ulceration** (厥) of the **Shao-Yáng** (少陽) meridian manifests as such.

The **ulceration** (厥) of the **Tai-Yin** (太阴) meridian results in abdominal fullness (腹满) and distension (腹胀), difficulty in defecation (后不利), loss of appetite (不欲食), and nausea upon eating (食则呕). It also causes inability to urinate (不得外).

The **foot Tai-Yin** (足太阴) meridian originates at the **tip of the big toe** (大指之端), ascends the **inner side of the leg** (膝股内前廉), and enters the abdomen, belonging to the spleen (属脾) and networking the stomach (络胃). It then ascends through the **diaphragmatic region** (鬲), alongside the throat (侠咽), connecting to the **root of the tongue** (舌本) and dispersing beneath the tongue (散舌下).

Its branch diverges again from the stomach (复从胃), separates at the **diaphragmatic region** (上鬲), and flows into the heart (注心中). Thus, the **ulceration** (厥) of the **Tai-Yin** (太阴) meridian manifests as such.

The **ulceration** (厥) of the **Shao-Yin** (少阴) meridian causes dry mouth (口乾) and red urine (溺赤), as well as abdominal fullness (腹满) and heart pain (心痛).

The **foot Shao-Yin** (足少阴) meridian ascends the **inner posterior aspect of the thigh** (股内后康), pierces the spine (贯脊), and belongs to the kidneys (属肾), networking the bladder (络膀胱).

Its direct course (其直行者) ascends from the kidneys (从肾上), pierces the **liver’s diaphragmatic region** (贯肝鬲), enters the lungs (入肺中), follows the throat (循喉咙), and runs alongside the **root of the tongue** (侠舌本).

Its branch diverges from the lungs (从肺出), networks the heart (络心), and flows into the chest (注胸中). Thus, the **ulceration** (厥) of the **Shao-Yin** (少阴) meridian manifests as such.

The **ulceration** (厥) of the **Jue-Yin** (厥阴) meridian causes distension and pain in the lower abdomen (少腹肿痛), abdominal fullness with **blocked bowel movements** (腹胀泾没不利), a preference for lying with knees flexed (好卧屈膝), **retraction and swelling of the genitals** (阴缩肿), and **internal heat in the organs** (腑内热).

The **foot Jue-Yin** (足厥阴) meridian begins one **cun** below the **inner ankle** (内踝), ascends eight **cun** along the **medial malleolus** (踝), and crosses behind the **Tai-Yin** (太阴) meridian. It then ascends the **inner thigh** (胭内康), follows the **medial aspect of the thigh** (循股阴), enters the **medial border of the scapula** (髦中), descends to encircle the **genital region** (环阴器), reaches the **lower abdomen** (抵小腹), and runs alongside the stomach (侠胃), belonging to the liver (属肝) and networking the gallbladder (络胆). It ascends to pierce the **diaphragmatic region** (贯鬲). Thus, the **ulceration** (厥) of the **Jue-Yin** (厥阴) meridian manifests as such.

[Note: One text reads **internal heat in the organs** (腑内热), but another reads **external heat in the organs** (腑外热). This discrepancy is due to transmission errors in the copied texts.]

When **excess** (盛), **acupuncture** (写) is applied; when **deficient** (虚), **moxibustion** (补) is used. If neither excess nor deficiency exists, the **meridian’s points** (穴俞) and **classical methods** (经法) are employed, adjusting the **breathing techniques** (留呼多少) accordingly.

If neither excess nor deficiency exists, it means that **pathogenic Qi** (邪气) has not yet become excessive, while **true Qi** (真气) has not yet become deficient. Thus, the treatment is guided by the **meridian’s points** (穴俞) and **classical methods** (经法).

The **Tai-Yin ulceration** (太阴厥逆) causes **organ constriction and spasm** (腑急孪), with heart pain radiating to the abdomen (心痛引腹). This is the **primary disease** (治主病者).

The **foot Tai-Yin** (足太阴) meridian originates at the **tip of the big toe** (大指之端), follows the **inner side of the leg** (内侧) up to the **front of the inner ankle** (内踝前康), and ascends the **inner border of the leg** (上端内). It then travels along the **posterior aspect of the tibia** (腑骨后), up to the **front inner aspect of the thigh** (膝股内前康), and enters the abdomen (入腹).

Its branch diverges again from the stomach (复从胃), separates at the **diaphragmatic region** (上鬲), and flows into the heart (注心中). Thus, **organ constriction and spasm** (腑急孪) and heart pain radiating to the abdomen (心痛引腹) occur.

The **Tai-Yin** (太阴) **pulse** (豚) has **left and right variations** (行有左右). One should observe where it **exceeds** (有过者) and **acupuncture** (发取) accordingly, hence the term **primary disease** (治主病).

[Newly corrected text states:] The details from *"Tai-Yin Ulceration"* (《太阴厥逆》) to the end of the section are originally found in Volume Nine of the *Complete Works of Quán Yuānshǐ* (全元起本), but the *Wáng* edition (王氏) relocated them here.

The **Shao-Yin ulceration** (少阴厥逆) causes **deficient fullness** (虚满) and **nausea with vomiting** (呕变), as well as **leakage of clear fluids** (下泄清). This is the **primary disease** (治主病者).

As its **pulse** (豚) ascends from the kidneys (从肾上), pierces the **liver’s diaphragmatic region** (贯肝鬲), and enters the lungs (入肺中), it follows the throat (循喉咙), hence the symptoms manifest as such.

The **Jue-Yin ulceration** (厥阴厥逆) causes **lumbar spasm and pain** (挛腰痛), **deficient fullness with anterior closure** (虚满前闭), and **delirious speech** (谵言).

[Newly corrected text states:] According to *Quán Yuānshǐ* (全元起), **delirious speech** (谵言) refers to **speech due to Qi deficiency** (气虚独言). The pronunciation of **谵** (谵) is *yàn* (俨).

This is the **primary disease** (治主病者).

The **Jue-Yin ulceration** follows its pulse as it courses through the inner thigh (*gǔ yīn*), enters the perineum (*máo zhōng*), encircles the external genitalia (*yīn qì*), and ascends again along the throat’s posterior path. It connects to the root of the tongue (*luò shé běn*), hence the symptoms manifest as such.
**Newly corrected note:** According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), the Jue-Yin channel does not connect to the root of the tongue. Wang Bing’s annotations in *The Treatise on Heat Needling* (《刺热篇》), *The Treatise on Lumbar Pain Needling* (《刺腰痛篇》), and this passage all state it connects to the root of the tongue. However, in his annotations on *The Wind Theory* (《风论》) and *The Theory of Stagnation* (《痹论》), he does not mention this connection. Wang’s annotations vary, and the *Jia-Yi Jing* should be considered authoritative.

When all three **Yin channels** are in reverse (*sān yīn jùnì*), they cannot advance or retreat, causing the hands and feet to become cold, and death occurs within three days. The **Yin channels are severed**, hence death occurs within three days.

**Tài-Yáng ulceration** (*Tàiyáng jùnì*) causes rigidity and collapse (*jiāng pū*), vomiting blood, and frequent belching (*shàn niǔ*). This is the **primary disease** (*zhì zhǔ bìng zhě*).
Its pulse arises from the inner canthus (*mù nèi pí*), ascends along the spine, and connects to the brain (*luò nǎo*), hence the symptoms manifest as such. *Jiāng* is pronounced *liáng*, *pū* as *fù*.

**Shǎo-Yáng ulceration** (*Shǎoyáng jùnì*) causes dysfunction of the joints and mechanisms (*jīguān bù lì*), meaning the waist cannot move (*yāo bù kě xíng*), and the neck cannot turn (*xiàng bù kě gù*).
Its pulse courses beneath the neck, encircles the perineum (*ráo máo jì*), and horizontally enters the spleen’s upper region (*shàng pí yàn zhōng*). Hence the symptoms manifest as such.
When **intestinal paralysis** (*fā cháng tān*) occurs, it is untreatable, and if there is **startle** (*jīng*), death follows.
The **foot Shǎo-Yáng pulse** (*zú Shǎoyáng tún*) pierces the diaphragm (*guàn lì*), connects to the liver, and belongs to the gallbladder (*shǔ dǎn*). It courses along the ribs, wraps around the flanks (*xiōng bāo*), and emerges at the hip joint (*qì jiē*). When intestinal paralysis occurs, the channel’s *qi* is severed, hence it is untreatable, and if there is startle, death follows.

**Yángmíng ulceration** (*Yángmíng jùnì*) causes dyspnea and coughing (*chuǎn kè*), feverish body (*shēn rè*), frequent startle (*shàn jīng*), and vomiting blood (*niǔ xuè*).
Its pulse courses along the throat (*xún hóulǒng*), enters the supraclavicular fossa (*rù quēpén*), descends to the diaphragm (*xià lì*), belongs to the stomach, and connects to the spleen (*shǔ pí*). Hence the symptoms manifest as such.

**Shǒu-Tài-Yīn ulceration** (*Shǒu-Tàiyīn jùnì*) causes **deficient fullness** (*xū mǎn*) and coughing, with frequent frothy vomiting (*shàn ōu mò*). This is the **primary disease** (*zhì zhǔ bìng zhě*).
The **hand Tàiyīn pulse** arises from the middle burner (*zhōng jiāo*), descends to connect with the large intestine (*xià luò dà cháng*), then ascends along the stomach’s orifice (*hái xún wèi kǒu*), enters the diaphragm (*shàng lì*), and belongs to the lungs (*shǔ fèi*). Hence the symptoms manifest as such.

**Shǒu-Xīnzhǔ Shǎo-Yīn ulceration** (*Shǒu-Xīnzhǔ Shǎoyīn jùnì*) causes heart pain radiating to the throat (*xīn tòng yǐn hóulǒng*), feverish body (*shēn rè*), and is untreatable, leading to death.
The **hand Xīnzhǔ pulse** arises from the chest (*qǐ yú xiōng zhōng*), emerges to belong to the pericardium (*shǔ xīn bāo*).
The **hand Shǎoyīn pulse’s** branch separates (*qí zhī bié zhě*), ascending from the heart’s cords (*xīn xì*) to the side of the throat (*shàng xiè yàn hóulǒng*). Hence the symptoms manifest as such.

**Shǒu-Tàiyáng ulceration** (*Shǒu-Tàiyáng jùnì*) causes deafness and lacrimation (*ěr lóng qì chū*), inability to turn the neck (*xiàng bù kě gù*), and inability to flex or extend the waist (*yāo bù kě fǔ yǎng*). This is the **primary disease** (*zhì zhǔ bìng zhě*).
The **hand Tàiyáng pulse’s** branch separates (*qí zhī bié zhě*), ascending from the supraclavicular fossa (*cóng quēpén*), along the neck to the cheek (*xún jìng shàng jiá*), reaching the outer canthus (*zhì mù ruì pí*), then retreating into the ear (*què rù ěr zhōng*).
Another branch separates (*qí zhī bié zhě*), ascending from the cheek (*cóng jiá shàng sòng dǐ zhǐ bí*), reaching the inner canthus (*zhì mù nèi pí*). Hence, deafness and lacrimation occur, and the neck cannot turn.
The waist cannot flex or extend due to the pulse’s non-correspondence (*mài bù xiāng yìng*), likely an error in the transmitted text.

**Shǒu-Yángmíng Shǎoyáng ulceration** (*Shǒu-Yángmíng Shǎoyáng jùnì*) causes **pharyngeal obstruction** (*fā hóu bì*), **hoarseness** (*kē zhǒng*), and **spasm** (*jìng*). This is the **primary disease** (*zhì zhǔ bìng zhě*).
The **hand Yángmíng pulse’s** branch separates (*qí zhī bié zhě*), ascending from the supraclavicular fossa along the neck (*shàng jǐng*).
The **hand Shǎoyáng pulse’s** branch separates (*qí zhī bié zhě*), ascending from the chest’s center (*cóng tán zhōng*), emerging from the supraclavicular fossa, and ascending to the nape (*shàng xiàng*).
Hence the symptoms manifest as such.
**Newly corrected note:** According to *Quán Yuānshǐ* (全元起), *jìng* (痉) should be *jìng* (痊).

**Disease Diagnosis Chapter**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"When a person suffers from **stomach cavity atrophy** (*wèi yuàn tān*), how should one diagnose them?"*

Gē Bó replied: *"To diagnose this, one must examine the **stomach pulse** (*wèi mài*). Its pulse should be **deep and fine** (*chén xì*). If it is deep and fine, this indicates **inverted qi** (*qì nì*).

The stomach is the **sea of water and grain** (*shuǐ gǔ zhī hǎi*), its blood abundant and its qi robust. Now, if the pulse is instead **fine and weak** (*xiàn*), this is contrary to its usual state.

**Newly corrected note:** According to *Quán Yuānshǐ* (全元起), *chén xì* (沉细) in *Jia-Yi Jing* (甲乙经) is recorded as *xiàn sè* (涩), while *Tài Sū* (太素) retains *chén xì* (沉细).

If the pulse is inverted, the **Ren Ying pulse** (*rén yíng*) will be **excessively strong** (*shèn shèng*). When excessively strong, it indicates **heat** (*rè*). The **deep pulse** (*chén niǔ*) signifies **cold** (*hán*). Cold qi obstructs the **Yáng** (*yáng*), causing the Ren Ying to surge excessively.

The **Ren Ying pulse** is the pulse of the **hand Yángmíng meridian** (*shǒu yángmíng mài*), so when it is excessively strong, it indicates **heat**.

The **Ren Ying** refers to the pulse beside the **larynx** (*jié hóu bàng*) that responds to the hand.

The **stomach pulse** (*wèi mài*) follows the throat and enters the **suprasternal fossa** (*quē pén*), hence it is called the **Ren Ying pulse**.

If the pulse is inverted and excessively strong, **heat accumulates at the stomach’s entrance** (*wèi kǒu*) and stagnates, causing **stomach cavity abscess** (*wèi yuàn yōng*).

When **blood and qi are robust**, but **internal heat assails them**, the two forces combine with heat, forming an **abscess** (*yōng*).

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

He then asked: *"Why does a person sometimes feel uneasy externally?"*

Qi Bao replied: *"When the **viscera** are injured or when **essence** has a place of lodgment, there is ease, and thus people cannot suspend their illness in midair. When the **five viscera** are injured or when **water and grain essence-qi** have a place of lodgment, if one supports the lower body, it averts ease—yet injury still reaches the viscera, so people cannot suspend their illness in midair."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Why can a person not lie back externally?"*
Meaning: *"Why can one not recline outward?"*

Qi Bao replied: *"The **lung** is the canopy of the viscera, dwelling high and spreading its leaves, with the four viscera beneath it—thus it is said that the lung is the canopy of the viscera. When **lung-qi** is robust, the pulse becomes large, and when the pulse is large, one cannot lie back externally. When **lung-qi** is full and overflowing, lying back externally causes shortness of breath and panting, hence one cannot lie back externally."* (This discussion appears in *The Strange and Sudden Yīn-Yáng*.)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"There is a patient with **ulcerative collapse** (*jué*) whose left pulse, when examined, is sunken and tight, while the right pulse is floating and slow. If it is not as described, where does the illness lie?"*
*"Not as described"* means *"not sunken."*

Qi Bao replied: *"In winter, the right pulse should naturally be sunken and tight—this corresponds to the four seasons. If the left pulse is floating and slow, this contradicts the seasons. If it occurs on the left, the illness lies in the **kidney**, though it also concerns the **lung**, and there should be **lumbar pain**. In winter, if the left **kidney pulse** (*tún*) is floating and slow, floating indicates the **lung pulse**, hence it is said to also concern the lung. The **lumbar region** is the **kidney’s domain** (*fǔ*), so when the kidney is diseased, there is pain in the lumbar region."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How do you know this?"*

Qi Bao replied: *"The **Lesser Yīn pulse** (*shào yīn mài*) penetrates the **kidney** and connects with the **lung**. Now, the **lung pulse** appears, yet the kidney is diseased, hence the kidney causes **lumbar pain**. The left pulse being floating and slow is not the lung manifesting itself—rather, because the left kidney is deficient, the pulse cannot be sunken, so the **lung pulse** appears, and the kidney is diseased."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

There is a patient with **neck rigidity** (*jǐng láng*), sometimes treated with **stone cautery** (*shí*) or with **acupuncture and moxibustion**, yet both methods cure it. Where does the true principle lie?
Meaning: *"Though the methods of attack differ, the cure is the same—so where does the true method reside?"*

Qi Bao replied: *"This is a case of **same name, different category**."* (Though both are called *neck rigidity*, their subcutaneous distinctions are not uniform.)

Thus it is said:
*"When **abscess-qi** is stagnant, acupuncture should be used to open and remove it. When **qi is robust and blood is congested**, stone cautery should be applied to drain it—this is what is meant by **same illness, different treatments**."*
(*Xī* means **mole** or **dead flesh**. *Shí* refers to **stone lancets**, which can break large abscesses and release pus—now externally substituted with needles.)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"There is a patient with **rage-induced madness** (*nù kuáng*),"* (The *Tài Sū* reads *"excessive anger"* instead.)

This illness—how does it arise?
Qi Bao replied: *"It arises from the Yang."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How does Yang cause madness?"*
*"When angered, one does not consider disaster—thus it is called madness."*

Qi Bao said: *"The Yang-qi, when violently disrupted and unable to disperse, thus easily gives rise to anger. The disease is named **Yang Jue**—meaning the Yang-qi is oppressed and fails to spread. Such a person is prone to anger, having once been violently disrupted, leaving the heart unrelieved and constricted. All such cases stem from extreme Yang reversal, hence the name **Yang Jue**."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How do you know this?"*
Qi Bao replied: *"The Yangming pulse is always active, while the Jùyáng and Shàoyáng pulses are normally still. If they move when they should not, and the movement is excessive, this is the sign. It means the pulses of the neck and nape are ceaselessly agitated. The Yangming pulse, when active, moves beside the larynx—this is the region of the **Rényíng** and **Qìshè** pulses. If the Shàoyáng pulse moves beneath the jawline, this is the region of the **Tiānchuāng** and **Tiānyǒu** pulses. If the Jùyáng pulse moves in the hollow before the great tendons on either side of the nape, this is the region of the **Tiānzhù** and **Tiānróng** pulses. When these pulses move contrary to their usual stillness and do so excessively, this indicates the disease."*

(*New annotation: According to Wang’s commentary, Tiānchuāng belongs to Shàoyáng, and Tiānróng to Tàiyáng. However, the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* states that Tiānchuāng is where Tàiyáng pulse-qi manifests, and Tiānróng is where Shàoyáng pulse-qi manifests. The two positions overlap, and the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* should be considered authoritative.*)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How should it be treated?"*
Qi Bao replied: *"Deprive them of food, and it will be resolved."*

The food enters the **yin**, nurturing **qi** in the **yang**; thus, depriving them of food resolves it. If food is reduced, the **qi** weakens, so moderating their intake will halt the disease naturally.
(*New annotation: According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, "夺" should be read as "衰" (wither). The *Tàisū* agrees.*)

Let them drink **shēngtiělùo** as a remedy.
(*New annotation: The *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* reads "铁落" (tiělùo) and specifies it as a post-meal drink. Shēngtiělùo, bitter and slightly warm, regulates **qi** downward. Commonly miscalled "tiějiāng" (iron broth), it is not the same as raw iron liquid.*)

The phrase *"之或为人"* is a textual error.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Excellent."* There is a disease marked by **shēnrè** (body heat), **tuòyuè** (listlessness), profuse sweating as if bathed, aversion to wind, and shortness of breath. What is its name?

Qi Bao replied: *"It is called **jiǔfēng** (Alcohol Wind). It arises when one drinks alcohol and contracts wind."*

The *Fēng Lùn* states: *"Drinking alcohol while exposed to wind results in **lòufēng** (Leaky Wind)."* This is also called **lòufēng**.

Those who indulge excessively have **yang qi** flourishing beyond its proper measure, loosening the **li** (boundaries), and opening the **Xuānfǔ** (mysterious orifice). When **yang** is excessive, the tendons weaken, causing **shēntǐ jiěyuè** (body relaxation and listlessness).
When the **li** are loosened, wind strikes internally; when the **Xuānfǔ** opens, **qi** escapes externally—thus the profuse sweating as if bathed.
Wind assaulting externally thins the skin, while the loosened **li** allow sweat to pour out, depleting the interior. The lingering **zhàngrè** (damp-heat) harms the lungs, hence the aversion to wind and breathlessness.
Since the disease stems from alcohol, it is called **jiǔfēng**.

(*Phonetic notes: 解 (jiě) is pronounced as in "介" (jiè); 惰 (yuè) is pronounced as in "徒卦" (túguà).*)

---
*(Note: "解惰" (jiěyuè) is rendered as "relaxation and listlessness" to preserve the parallel structure with "筋痿弱" (tendon weakness) while maintaining readability.)*

The Sovereign said: *"How should this be treated?"*
Qibo replied: *"Take ten parts each of *Zézhé* (Alisma) and *Mùgé* (Kochia), and five parts of *Línxián* (Cervus antler velvet), combine them, and take a pinch with three fingers after meals.
*Mùgé* is bitter, warm, and balanced; it treats severe wind disorders and stops sweating.
*Línxián* is bitter, cold, and balanced; it treats wind-dampness and weakened tendons.
*Zézhé* is sweet, cold, and balanced; it treats wind-dampness and augments *qi*.
Thus, these functions determine their precedence in the formula.
'After meals' refers to taking the medicine afterward.

The term *tàn zhī xì* means examining minutely—like a needle’s precision, pressing firmly to discern firmness or diffuseness.

The *Upper Canon* speaks of *qi* ascending to Heaven.
The *Lower Canon* speaks of disease’s transformations.
The *Golden Cabinet* ranks life and death.
*Kuìdù* refers to measuring and assessing.
*Qíhéng* concerns extraordinary diseases.
The term *qí* means preventing extraordinary diseases from killing in the four seasons.
*Dá* means allowing death in the four seasons.
The *New Annotation* states: According to Yang Shangshan, if a disease spreads until its critical moment, death follows—this is *héng*.
If a disease arises midway and spreads, this is *qí*.
*Kuì* means probing deeply, examining the pulse’s logic.
*Dù* means determining the disease’s location and measuring it by the seasons.
All instances of *suǒwèi* clarify unresolved meanings.
Now, these *suǒwèi* phrases, when traced through preceding texts, do not align with this passage’s intent. It seems these few lines were mistakenly appended, likely a misplaced annotation from a missing or rearranged section in the original text. The ancient text is fragmented, and these lines were erroneously inserted here.

**Chapter on Extraordinary Diseases**

The Sovereign asked: *"A person carries a heavy burden for nine months, then loses speech—what is this called?"*
Qibo replied: *"This is called *zhòngshēn*—when the body contains another body, meaning pregnancy. The loss of speech (*yīn*) occurs because the fetus restrains *qi*, severing the *bāo* (uterine) network’s flow, leaving the woman unable to speak.
The *bāo*’s collateral vessels are severed—meaning the pulse is cut off and uncirculated, not that the innate *qi* is exhausted."*

The Sovereign asked: *"How do you know this?"*
Qibo replied: *"The *bāo*’s collateral connects to the kidneys, passing through the kidney’s root to the tongue’s base. Thus, speech fails.
The *Shào Yīn* (kidney) channel nourishes the tongue; if *qi* fails to circulate, the tongue cannot speak."*

The Sovereign asked: *"How should this be treated?"*
Qibo replied: *"Do not treat it. It will resolve by the tenth month.
At ten months, the fetus departs, the *bāo*’s collateral reconnects, and the kidney’s *qi* ascends to restore speech as before."*

The *Needling Method* states: *"Do not deplete the deficient nor overfill the excessive, lest chronic illness (*zhěn*) form.
If treatment contradicts this principle, the fetus may die and remain, becoming a fixed, enduring *zhěn*.
Only then should adjustment begin."*

The *New Annotation* states: According to *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* and *Tàisù*, these four characters are absent. According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s annotation: *"Untreatable" means the body, after nine months, is emaciated and burdened—treatment is impossible until the tenth month, when the fetus is born and the body returns to normal. Then adjustment may follow.
These four characters were mistakenly transcribed from Quán Yuánqǐ’s notes and should be deleted.

*"Do not deplete the deficient"* means the body is weak and emaciated—do not use heavy methods (*yuèshí*).
Pregnancy for nine months weakens tendons and bones, exhausts strength, and repels food, causing emaciation. Heavy methods would harm the already strained body.
*"Do not overfill the excessive"* means draining the fetus’s form would cause *jīng* (essence) to leak, leaving the disease to dominate alone—thus *zhěn* forms.
If the fetus restrains the *bāo*’s collateral, kidney *qi* is blocked. Draining it further would cause kidney essence to deplete, the fetus to perish in the womb, and the remains to linger, leading to solitary dominance—thus *zhěn* arises.

---
The Sovereign asked: *"A person suffers flank distension with upward-rising *qi*, lasting two or three years—what is this called?"*
Qibo replied: *"This is called *xījī*—it does not obstruct eating, and moxibustion or needling are forbidden. Treatment requires *dǎoyǐn* (guided exercises) and medication; medication alone cannot cure it.
The abdomen is formless, yet the flanks are distended and *qi* reverses, persisting for years. *Xī* (breath) and *jī* (form) intertwine—*qi* reverses, making breath difficult—hence the name *xījī*.
Since *qi* does not reside in the stomach, eating is unaffected. Moxibustion would generate internal heat, transforming *qi* into wind. Needling would disrupt the channels, leading to exhaustion—thus, it is forbidden.
Guided exercises can make *qi* flow, and prolonged medication can internally dissolve stagnation. Only then will it be cured.
If medication is relied upon alone, without guided exercises, it cannot effect a cure."*

---
The Sovereign asked: *"A person’s body and organs swell, encircling the waist with pain—what is this called?"*
Qibo replied: *"This is called *fúlìang*—due to the *Chōng* channel’s disorder, hence the name.
The *Chōng* channel, along with the *Shào Yīn* (kidney) collateral, originates below the kidney, emerges at the *qìjiē* (hip joint), follows the inner thigh, diagonally enters the *cháng* (uterus), traces the inner edge of the pelvis, and descends with the *Shào Yīn* channel to the inner ankle’s rear, entering the sole.
Its ascending branch emerges below the waist, three *cùn* from the navel (*guānyuán*), beside the waist, ascending straight to the throat, converging with the *Shào Yīn* channel.
Thus, the body and organs swell, encircling the waist with pain—this is called *fúlìang*.
*Huán* means encircling like a ring. This is the root of wind.
Its *qi* overflows into the large intestine, settling in the *huáng* (bladder), whose origin is below the waist—thus, the waist encircles with pain."*

The large intestine—*guǎng cháng*—is indeed the broad intestine. However, when referring to it in the *sutra*, it should be called the *huí cháng* (coiled intestine).

Why so? The *Líng Shū Jīng* states: "The coiled intestine lies at the waist. The right coiled intestine wraps around the leaf-like *jī* (caecum) and descends, while the broad intestine clings to the spine, receiving the coiled intestine. The left coiled intestine wraps around the leaf-like *jī*, ascending and descending with *bì* (divided) clarity and grandeur."

Upon examination, this is the coiled intestine, not the large intestine as commonly spoken. Yet, the large intestine and coiled intestine both harmonize with the lungs, and from this harmony, life is sustained. Therefore, they are collectively called the large intestine. It must not be disturbed, for disturbing it brings the illness of *shuǐ nì sè* (urinary difficulty and constipation).

Since the *Chōng* channel originates below the kidney, emerging at the *qìjiē* (hip joint), and its ascending branch arises from the *bāo* (uterus), ascending to emerge beside the waist at *guānyuán* (the navel region), disturbing it causes urinary difficulty and constipation. "Disturbing" refers to striking the waist with potent poisons or drugs, causing severe downward flux. This passage serves as a repeated explanation of a rare condition, as seen in the *Fù Zhōng Lùn* (Discourse on the Abdomen).

The Emperor asked: "There are cases where the *chě* (cubit) pulse is extremely frequent, the tendons tense, and visible—what illness is this?"

"Tendons tense" refers to the two tendons in the *chě* (cubit) region behind the hand being taut. The *Mài Yào Jīng Wéi Lùn* (Essentials of Pulse Doctrine) states: "The outer cubit pulse reflects the kidney, while the inner cubit pulse reflects the abdomen." Now, if the cubit pulse is frequent and tense, it indicates heat, which should relax the tendons. Instead, the cubit tendons are tense and visible, while abdominal tendons should also be tense—thus, the question arises: why does this occur as an illness?

The *Líng Shū Jīng* answers: "Heat relaxes the tendons, while cold tightens them." *Qí Bó* (Gebber) said: "This is called *zhěn jīn* (tendon contraction). When the tendons of the abdomen contract, and white or black colors appear on the face, the illness is severe. 'Abdominal tendons contract' refers to the tendons beside the waist and within the abdomen all becoming tense. Since the inner cubit pulse reflects the abdomen, if the cubit tendons are tense, the abdominal tendons will also be contracted and rigid. 'Colors appear' refers to their manifestation on the face. The five colors, when observed, white indicates cold, and black also indicates cold; thus, the appearance of these two colors makes the illness even more severe."

The Emperor asked: "There are cases where a person suffers from chronic headaches for several years—what causes this, and what is its name?"

This illness of headache should not persist beyond a month; if it remains unresolved for years, it is strange and thus questioned. *Qí Bó* replied: "This is due to exposure to extreme cold, which penetrates to the bone marrow. The marrow, with the brain as its sovereign, suffers inversion, causing headaches and toothaches. The brain is the marrow, governing the teeth, which are the marrow’s residue. When the brain inverts and cold invades the bones, headaches and toothaches arise. This condition is named *jué nì* (inversion disorder)."

The Emperor said: "Good."

The full annotation states: "The brain first generates the marrow, and since there is marrow, there are bones and teeth, which are the marrow’s root."

The Emperor asked: "There are cases where a person’s mouth tastes sweet—what is the illness called, and how is it acquired?"

*Qí Bó* replied: "This is due to the overflow of the five *qì* (vital energies), named *pí kuàng* (splenic inversion)." *Kuàng* refers to heat. When the spleen is heated, the four *zàng* (viscera) share its influence, causing the five *qì* to overflow upward.

Its origin lies in splenic heat, hence the name *pí kuàng*. When the five flavors enter the mouth, they are stored in the stomach. The spleen distributes their refined *qì* and *jīn yè* (body fluids). Since the spleen holds the fluids, it makes the mouth taste sweet. When splenic heat internally seeps, the fluids linger in the spleen, and the stomach’s nourishment is improperly transformed. The refined *qì* then overflows, and the mouth tastes the spleen’s *qì*, hence the sweetness.

The fluids lingering in the spleen indicate its dampness, which leads to a tendency toward obesity. The new corrected version states: "According to the *Tài Sū*, the condition arises as *shāo kuàng* (consumptive inversion)." Such individuals often consume excessive sweet and fatty foods. Fatty foods obstruct the natural flow, preventing *yáng qì* (yang energy) from dispersing outward, causing internal heat. Sweet foods, with their mild and harmonious nature, can also lead to *zhōng mǎn* (mid-abdominal fullness), as they tend to accumulate and stagnate. Internal heat causes *yáng qì* to rise, leading to thirst and dryness. Mid-abdominal fullness means lingering *chén qì* (stale energy), which then overflows as splenic *qì*, hence the term "the *qì* overflows upward, transforming into *xiāo kuàng* (consumptive disorder)." The *Yīn Yáng Yìng Xiàng Dà Lùn* (Grand Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang) states: "Acrid and sweet flavors disperse and are yang in nature." The *Líng Shū Jīng* states: "Excessive sweetness in the diet causes *mèn* (stupor)." Yet, this arises from mid-abdominal fullness.

The new corrected version states: "According to the *Jiǎ Yǐ Jīng*, *xiāo kuàng* (consumptive disorder) should be written as *xiāo kuàng* (consumptive inversion)." It is treated with *lán* (orchid), which dispels *chén qì* (stale energy). *Lán* refers to the orchid plant. *Shén Nóng* (Divine Farmer) said: "Orchid is acrid, hot, and balanced. It facilitates waterways, wards off evil omens, and clears phlegm and *bì* (stagnation) from the chest." "Dispels" means to remove. "Stale" refers to lingering energy. Orchid removes the lingering, stagnant sweet and fatty *qì* that cannot be transformed, as its acrid nature disperses.

The *Zàng Qì Fǎ Shí Lùn* (Treatise on the Laws of the Visceral Energies) states: "Acrid is dispersing."

The Emperor asked: "There are cases where a person’s mouth tastes bitter, and *yáng líng quán* (Liver 5, Yang Mound Spring) is treated." What is the illness called, and how is it acquired?

*Qí Bó* replied: "The illness is named *dǎn kuàng* (biliary inversion)." *Kuàng* also means heat. The bile’s flavor is bitter, hence the bitter taste in the mouth.

The new corrected version states: "According to the full *Yī Qǐ* (Rise and Fall) text and *Tài Sū*, there are no six characters: 'mouth tastes bitter, treat at *yáng líng quán*.'" Upon careful examination of the context, this passage is likely erroneous.

The liver is the sovereign of the center, with its authority residing in the gallbladder. The throat serves as its messenger. The *Líng Lán Mì Dìan Lùn* (Secret Canon of the Orchid and Bell) states: "The liver is the sovereign of the center, where planning and contemplation originate. The gallbladder is the central authority, where decisions and judgments emerge. The liver and gallbladder harmonize, their energies interflowing, hence all planning and contemplation follow the gallbladder’s sequence. The throat corresponds to the gallbladder, thus it serves as the messenger."

The new corrected version states: "According to the *Jiǎ Yǐ Jīng*, the gallbladder is the repository of central precision, and the five viscera follow its sequence, with the throat as its messenger." This passage is likely erroneous.

Such individuals often engage in excessive planning and contemplation without decisive action, causing the gallbladder to become depleted and its *qì* to overflow upward, resulting in a bitter taste in the mouth.

The treatment involves the **gallbladder’s *mù*** (acupuncture point) and ***yù*** (back-shu point)**.
The chest and abdomen are called ***mù***, while the back is called ***yù***.
The **gallbladder’s *mù*** lies beneath the nipple, two ribs outward, at the lower edge of the ***Qīmén*** (Gate of Fate), five *cùn* (fingers’ breadth) from the midline of the body.
The ***yù*** is located below the tenth vertebra, with each side one and a half *cùn* from the midline of the body.
This is detailed in the *"Yīnyáng Shí’èr Guān Xiàngshǐ"* (Twelve Officials of Yin and Yang: Correspondences and Messengers).
The text states that the full treatment method is contained therein, but that passage is now lost.

The **Emperor** asked: *"If one has a **yīn** pulse that is fine and faint like hair, this is deficiency. What disease is this? What is its name?"*

**Correction:** Upon closer examination, these fifteen characters were originally a transcription error.
According to the *Jiǎ Yǐ Jīng* and *Tàisū* (Great Essentials), this passage does not exist.
It is actually from **Quán Yuánqǐ’s** annotations, mistakenly transcribed into the text.
Now recorded as a note:

The **Tàiyīn** (Greater Yin) pulse is fine and faint like hair—this is deficiency.
What disease does it manifest?
What is its name?

The **Emperor** asked: *"What does ‘□’ mean? It refers to urinary retention. ‘波’ means frequent urination. ‘颈膺如格’ means the neck and chest feel as though obstructed, as if resisting and failing to harmonize. ‘人迎躁盛’ refers to the pulse at the lateral neck (structural throat), where the pulse is full, tense, and rapid—unusually agitated and swift—this is the stomach pulse.*

*The **Tàiyīn** pulse, fine and faint like hair, refers to the pulse at the radial side of the thumb’s proximal phalanx, one *cùn* above the wrist crease. This is the lung pulse, the proper channel of **Tàiyīn** hand pulse, through which the five **zàng** (viscera) may be diagnosed.*

**Qíbó** said: *"When disease is in **Tàiyīn**, its excess lies in the stomach, its root in the lung. The disease is called *jué* (syncope), and if it occurs, it is untreatable. Frequent urination, body heat like burning charcoal, neck and chest obstruction, and labored breathing with inverted *qi*—all these indicate that the **Tàiyīn** pulse should be surging and robust, yet now it is instead fine and faint like hair. This is a contradiction between disease and pulse. How does this arise?*

*It is due to the lung’s inverted *qi* overwhelming the stomach, causing the *rényíng* pulse to surge violently. Hence, it is said that the disease is in **Tàiyīn**, with its excess in the stomach. Because of the wheezing and inverted *qi*, it is also said to involve the lung. Since the disease arises from inverted *qi* and the symptoms do not correspond, it is named *jué* (syncope), and death is inevitable. This is what is called ‘five excesses and two deficiencies.’"*

The **Emperor** asked: *"What are these ‘five excesses and two deficiencies’?"*

**Qíbó** replied: *"The ‘five excesses’ refer to the five diseases of excess *qi*, and the ‘two deficiencies’ refer to the two diseases of deficient *qi*. Now, externally there are five excesses, internally there are two deficiencies. Thus, the body is neither superficial nor deep—this is clearly a death sentence. The five external excesses are: 1) body heat like burning charcoal, 2) neck and chest obstruction, 3) surging *rényíng* pulse, 4) wheezing, and 5) inverted *qi*. The two internal deficiencies are: 1) frequent urination (as if ‘波’), and 2) the **Tàiyīn** pulse being fine and faint like hair. If the disease is said to be superficial, then internally there are two deficiencies; if it is said to be deep, then externally there are five excesses. Since neither superficial nor deep treatment can be applied, and supplementation or purgation is impossible, it is said that this is clearly a death sentence."*

The **Emperor** asked: *"If a person is born with *diān* (convulsive) disease, what is its name? How is it contracted? All diseases arise from wind, rain, cold, heat, yin, yang, joy, or anger. Yet before encountering pathogenic *qi*, a newborn already has *diān*—could this be from congenital injury?"* (Thus, he asked.)

*‘Diān’ refers to the upper *diān* (head).*

**Qíbó** said: *"The disease is called *táibìng* (congenital disease). This is contracted when, in the mother’s womb, she experiences a great fright, causing her *qi* to rise but not descend, with essence and *qi* converging, thus making the child manifest *diān* (convulsions). ‘Essence and *qi*’ refers to the yang essence and *qi*."*

The **Emperor** asked: *"There is a disease where the face appears bloated and mottled, like water, with a pulse that is large and taut, yet the body feels no pain, does not emaciate, cannot eat much, and eats little. What is its name?"*

*‘□然’ means the face is swollen and discolored. ‘Large and taut’ means like a drawn bowstring. The *qi* is cold and internally invasive, yet there is no pain—this differs from common cases, hence the repeated inquiry.*

**Qíbó** said: *"The disease originates in the kidney and is called *shènfēng* (kidney wind). The pulse is taut like a bowstring, large and tense, with labored *qi* internally accumulating, cold further invading, and labored *qi* clashing with cold. This transforms into wind, and since wind overcomes the kidney, it is called *shènfēng*. When *shènfēng* occurs, the patient cannot eat, is prone to startling, and if startled, their heart *qi* collapses—death follows. Kidney water receives wind, and heart fire weakens; fire and water are both exhausted, hence death again."* The **Emperor** said: *"Understood."*
