**Chapter 2: Originally "一", corrected according to Gu Ben’s edition. #1肋: Originally "筋", corrected according to Gu Ben’s edition.**
**Chapter 3: Originally "即", corrected according to Gu Ben’s edition.**

**The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Classic, *Suwen* Supplementary Commentary, Volume 29**
**Tang Taipu Ling (Grand Marshal of the Imperial Stables) Qixuanzi (Master of the Mysterious) Wang Bing’s sequential annotations, Song Guanglu Jing (High Official of the Ministry of Personnel) and Zhishiyige (Secretary of the Imperial Library) Lin Yi et al.’s verified corrections, Song Shou Shangshu (Secretary of State) and Tun’tian Lang (Censor of Agricultural Affairs) Sun Zhao’s revisions of errors**
**The *Daqi* (Great Marvels) Treatise**

When the liver, kidney, and lungs are all **full** (i.e., their *qi* is **full** and **replete**), it is called **swelling** (i.e., **generalized edema**).
**Full** refers to the pulse *qi* being **full** and **replete**. **Swelling** refers to **diffuse edema**.

When the **stored *qi*** is **full**, it manifests thus:
The **fullness of the lungs** (*fèiyōng*) causes **dyspnea**, with the **two axillae** (i.e., **both armpits**) **full**.

The lungs **store *qi*** and externally govern **breathing**; their **collateral branches**, diverging from the main meridians, emerge from the **lung system** and spread beneath the **axillae** (#1), hence **dyspnea** and **fullness in both axillae**.

**New verification** states: In the case of *fèiyōng* (lung fullness), *gānyōng* (liver fullness), and *shènfèng* (kidney fullness), the *Jia-Yi Jing* (a lost medical text) all render as **痈** (*yōng*).

**Liver fullness** (*gānyōng*) presents as **fullness in both flanks**, externally marked by **startling** (i.e., **easily frightened**), and **inability to urinate**. The liver’s meridian travels along the **inner thigh**, enters the **pelvis**, encircles the **genital region**, reaches the **lower abdomen**, ascends through the **liver’s upper cavity**, and spreads across the **ribs and flanks**, hence **flank fullness** and **inability to urinate**. The liver governs **startling and terror**, hence the external **startling**.

**Kidney fullness** (*shènfèng*) manifests as **fullness in the lower abdomen extending to the feet** (i.e., **generalized lower abdominal and leg fullness**).
**New verification** states: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*, the phrase should read **"脑下"** (*nǎoxià*, beneath the brain) instead of **"脚下"** (*jiǎoxià*, beneath the feet). The **lower abdomen** (i.e., **flanks**) should not be described as **"脚下至少腹"** (*jiǎoxià shǎo fù*, beneath the feet, lower abdomen).

When the **cavities** (i.e., **body spaces**) are **large or small**, the **organs and viscera** (i.e., **internal structures**) become **severely weakened** (i.e., **easily prone to atrophy or paralysis**), leading to **lateral atrophy** (i.e., **hemiplegia**).

The **penetrating and nourishing vessels** (i.e., **the Conception and Governing Vessels**, *chōngyǒng* and *dàimài*), as the **sea of the meridians**, along with the **collaterals of the Lesser Yin** (i.e., **kidney meridian**), all originate beneath the **kidney**, emerge at the **Qi Street** (i.e., **the region between the anus and genitals**), and follow the **inner thigh’s medial aspect** (*yīn gǔ nèi kāng*). They then **slant inward to the pelvis**, traverse the **medial aspect of the hip bone**, and, parallel to the **Lesser Yin meridian**, descend behind the **inner ankle** and enter beneath the **foot**. Their **ascending branches** emerge at **three inches below the navel** on the **midline of the torso**.

Thus, it manifests as described.

If the **blood and qi** (*xuèqì*) undergo abnormal changes, it results in **hemiplegia** (*piānxū*).

When the **Heart meridian** (*xīn mài*) is **full and large** (*mǎn dà*), the **atrophy** (*jí*) heals, but **muscle spasms** (*jīn luán*) persist. If the **Heart meridian** is **full and large**, then **Liver qi** (*gān qì*) descends below, **heat qi** (*rè qì*) accumulates internally, muscles wither and blood dries up—thus, **pain and spasms** (*tòng téng ér jīn luán*) arise. When the **Liver meridian** (*gān mài*) is **small and urgent** (*xiǎo jí*), it manifests as **spasms** (*jīn luán*) with **virtue/power** (*dé*) in the tendons. The **Liver** nourishes the tendons and internally stores the blood; when **Liver qi** is exposed to cold, **pain responds** (*tòng yìng*) and the tendons **twist** (*jīn nuǎn*).

When the pulse is **small and urgent** (*xiǎo jí*), it signifies **cold** (*hán*). If the **Liver meridian** becomes **violent and urgent** (*wò bào*), there is **fright or alarm** (*jīnghè*); **violent** (*wò*) refers to **restless agitation** (*chíwò*), indicating its **rapid urgency** (*suí jí*). When **Yang qi** (*yáng qì*) accumulates internally, it manifests as **fright** (*jīng*). If the pulse does not arrive but the **condition subsides** (*cháng*), it will self-correct.

When **Liver qi** (*gān qì*) **faints** (*jué*), the pulse becomes **obstructed** (*mài bù tōng*); upon **recovery** (*jué tuì*), the pulse resumes flow. Moreover, its branches spread across the **ribcage** (*xié lèi*) and follow behind the **throat** (*hóu láng*), so if the pulse does not arrive but the **atrophy** (*jí*) is **subsided** (*zì jǐ*), it too will self-correct.

If the **Kidney meridian** (*shèn mài*), **Liver meridian**, and **Heart meridian** are all **small and urgent**, and none **beat rhythmically** (*bù gǔ*), it results in **congealed blood** (*hù*). **Small and urgent** signifies **severe cold** (*hán shèn*); if the pulse does not beat, blood does not flow, and when blood does not flow, **cold accumulates** (*hán bó*), causing **congealed blood** (*xuè nèi níng*)—thus forming **congealed blood** (*hù*).

When the **Kidney** and **Liver** are both **depressed** (*bìng chén*), it forms **stone water** (*shí shuǐ*). The **Liver meridian** enters the **Yin region** (*yīn nèi*), traversing the **lower abdomen** (*xiǎo fù*), while the **Kidney meridian** pierces the **center of the spine** (*zhī lǐ zhōng*), connecting with the **Bladder** (*pángguāng*). When both **organs** (*zàng*) are affected, their **qi** (*qì*) relies on the **Conception Vessel** (*chōng mài*), which from the **Kidney** below connects with the **uterus** (*bāo*), obstructing the **transformation and flow of water** (*shuǐ bù xínghuà*). Thus, it becomes **firm and congealed** (*jiān ér jié*). Since the **Kidney** governs water, and water in winter becomes ice, water originates from the **Kidney** (*shuǐ zōng yú shèn*), and the **Kidney** symbolizes water while **depressed** (*wèi*), hence the **qi** converges and sinks, named **stone water** (*shí shuǐ*).

If the pulse is **converged and floating** (*bìng fú*), it is **wind water** (*fēng shuǐ*). **Floating** (*fú*) signifies **wind** (*fēng*); the **lower burner** (*xià jiāo*) governs water, and **wind** accumulates below—thus named **wind water**.

If the pulse is **converged and empty** (*bìng xū*), it is **deadly** (*sǐ*). The **Kidney** is the **root of the five Zang** (*wǔ zàng*), and the **Liver** is the **master of generation** (*fāshēng zhǔ*); when both are deficient, the **principles of life** (*shēng zhǔ*) are exhausted—thus death.

If the pulse is **small and taut, threatening fright** (*xiǎo xián yù jīng*), it signifies that both **Liver** and **Kidney** are deficient.

When the **Kidney meridian** (*shèn mài*) is **large and urgent, depressed** (*dà jí chén*), or the **Liver meridian** is **large and urgent, depressed** (*dà jí chén*), it results in **hernia** (*shàn*). **Hernia** is caused by **cold qi** (*hán qì*) congealing. When **pulse is taut** (*mài xián*) for **fullness** (*shí*), and **urgent** (*jí*) for **pain** (*tòng*), **fullness** and **cold accumulation** (*qì shí hán bó*) cause **twisting pain** (*jiǎo tòng*)—thus **hernia** (*shàn*).

If the **Heart meridian** (*xīn mài*) **beats and slides urgently** (*bó huá jí*), it is **Heart hernia** (*xīn shàn*). If the **Lung meridian** (*fèi mài*) is **depressed and beats** (*chén bó*), it is **Lung hernia** (*fèi shàn*). All are due to **cold accumulation** (*hán bó*) in the **organs** (*zàng*).

When the **three Yang meridians** (*sān yáng*) are **urgent**, it results in **congealed blood** (*hù*); when the **three Yin meridians** (*sān yīn*) are **urgent**, it results in **hernia** (*shàn*). If the **Greater Yang** (*tài yáng*) receives **cold**, blood congeals into **congealed blood** (*hù*). If the **Greater Yin** (*tài yīn*) receives **cold**, **qi** congeals into **hernia** (*shàn*). When the **two Yin meridians** (*èr yīn*)—i.e., the **Lesser Yin** (*shǎo yīn*)—are **urgent**, it results in **epileptic fainting** (*yǐn jué*); when the **two Yang meridians** (*èr yáng*)—i.e., the **Yang Brightness** (*yáng míng*)—are **urgent**, it results in **fright** (*jīng*).

When the **Spleen meridian** (*pí mài*) **beats externally and is depressed** (*wài gǔ chén*), it results in **intestinal atrophy** (*cháng pì*), which **self-corrects over time** (*jiǔ zì jǐ*). **Beats externally** (*wài gǔ*) refers to **pulsation on the outer arm** (*gǔdòng yú bì wài*).

If the **Liver meridian** is **small and relaxed** (*xiǎo huǎn*), it results in **intestinal atrophy** (*cháng pì*), which is **easily treatable**. **Small and relaxed** signifies the **Spleen** overacting upon the **Liver** (*pí chéng gān*), thus it is easily treatable.

If the **Kidney meridian** is **small and beats, depressed** (*xiǎo bó chén*), it results in **intestinal atrophy with bleeding** (*cháng pì xià xuè*). **Small** indicates **Yin qi deficiency** (*yīn qì bùzú*), while **beats** (*bó*) signifies **Yang qi overacting** (*yáng qì chéng zhī*); **heat** resides in the **lower burner** (*xià jiāo*), hence the bleeding.

If the **blood is warm** (*xuè wēn*) and the **body is hot** (*shēn rè*), it is **deadly**.

**Intestinal atrophy** (*cháng pì*) from the **Heart** and **Liver** also causes bleeding. The **Liver** stores blood, and the **Heart** nourishes blood—thus, **atrophy** (*pì*) in both results in bleeding.

When **two organs** (*èr zàng*) suffer the same ailment, it is **treatable**. The **Heart’s fire** and **Liver’s wood** (*xīn huǒ gān mù*) mutually generate—thus it is treatable.

If the pulse is **small, depressed, and rough** (*xiǎo chén sè*), it is **intestinal prolapse** (*cháng liàn*). If the **Heart** and **Liver meridians** are **small and depressed, rough** (*xiǎo sè*), it is **prolapse** (*liàn*). If the **body is hot** (*shēn rè*), it is **deadly**. **Heat** appears on the **seventh day** (*qī rì sè*), for **prolapse** with bleeding and **body heat** signifies **fire qi exhaustion** (*huǒ qì nèi jué*), leaving the **Heart** and turning outward—thus death. **Fire** completes its cycle in **seven days** (*huǒ chéng qī rì*), hence death on the **seventh day**.

If the **Stomach meridian** (*wèi mài*) is **depressed, beats, and rough** (*chén gǔ sè*), and the **Stomach’s external pulse is large** (*wèi wài gǔ dà*), or the **Heart meridian** is **small and taut** (*xīn mài xiǎo jiān jí*), it results in **hemiplegia** (*biān qū*). **Beats externally** refers to **pulsation beyond the standard cubit measure**, striking the **outer arm** (*gǔjī yú bì wài cè*).

In males, **symptoms appear on the left**; in females, on the **right**. **Yang** governs the **left**, and **Yin** governs the **right**—thus the distinction. The *Yīn-Yáng Yìng Xiàng Dà Lùn* states: *"Left and right are the pathways of Yin and Yang."* This is its meaning.

If **speech is obstructed** (*bù □ yán*) and the **tongue turns** (*shé zhuǎn*), it is **treatable**, with recovery in **thirty days**. In **hemiplegia**, if **speech is obstructed** (*□ bù néng yán*), it signifies that the **Kidney** and **uterus meridians** are **internally exhausted** (*nèi jué*). The **uterus meridian** (*bāo mài*) is linked to the **Kidney**; the **Kidney meridian** ascends from the **Kidney**, pierces the **Liver**, enters the **Lung**, follows behind the **throat**, and is adjacent to the **tongue’s root** (*xié shé běn*). Thus, when **qi is exhausted internally**, speech becomes obstructed.

If the **symptoms follow** (*cóng*), it is **congealed blood** (*chuāng*), with recovery in **three years**. **Follow** refers to males manifesting on the **left** and females on the **right**. If the disease progresses **according to left and right** (*shùn zuǒyòu ér jí*), resulting in **obstructed speech** (*bù néng yán*), it can be treated within **three years** to achieve recovery.

If the patient is **under twenty years old** (*nián bù mǎn èrshí*), **three years of illness** is **deadly**. Since the **five Zang** are not yet fully established, and **blood and qi** are still **rigid and strong** (*xuèqì fāng gāng*), the **Zang** are easily injured, and the **qi** is greatly strained—thus, illness lasting **three years** leads to death.

If the pulse arrives and **beats rhythmically**, but **blood is exhausted** (*xuè niǔ*) and the **body is hot** (*shēn rè*), it is **deadly**. **Exhausted blood** (*xuè niǔ*) signifies **emptiness** (*xū*); the pulse should not respond to **beating** (*bó*), but if it **beats rhythmically** (*fǎn mài bó*), it indicates **qi exhaustion** (*qì jí nǎi rán*)—thus death.

If the pulse comes **suspended like a hook, floating** (*xián gōu fú*), it is the **common pulse** (*cháng mài*).

If the pulse arrives **like panting** (*rú chuǎn*), it is called **sudden fainting** (*bào jué*). **Panting** (*chuǎn*) refers to **abrupt, intense arrival** (*zú lái shèng jí*), fading quickly—like the **breathing of a gasping person**. **Sudden fainting** renders the patient **unable to speak with others**.

If the pulse arrives **like counting** (*rú shǔ*), it causes **sudden fright** (*bào jīng*). A **counting pulse** (*shǔ*) signifies **heat** (*rè*), which internally agitates the **Liver and Heart**—thus **fright**. It **self-corrects in three to four days**. **Counting** refers to the **Heart meridian**; **wood** (Liver) is **dried by fire** (Heart), and the disease is not **Liver-generated** (*bìng fēi gān shēng*) nor **joined with evil** (*bù yǔ xié hé*)—thus it **self-corrects after three to four days**.

---

Thus it is so: **wood** (Liver) **generates a counting pulse** (*shǔ*) for three days.

If the pulse arrives **floating and merging** (*fú hé*), like waves merging on the surface, the later arrivals **overtake the earlier ones** (*hòu zhì zhě líng qián*), moving swiftly and without regular pattern.

A **floating-merge pulse** (*fú hé*) like counting—ten arrivals or more per breath—indicates **insufficient channel-qi** (*jīng qì yǔ bù zú*), a slight sign of death within ninety days.

If the pulse arrives **like blazing firewood** (*rú xiānrán*), it is the **Heart’s vital essence** (*xīn jīng*) being **consumed and depleted** (*yǔ dué*). When grass dries and dies, so too does the pulse.

The flames of blazing firewood (*xiānrán*) flicker (*biē biē*) without fixed form, then **cease abruptly** (*ér biàn jué*). **Flames** (*yàn*), pronounced *guò niàn*.

If the pulse arrives **like scattered leaves** (*rú sǎn yè*), it signifies **insufficient Liver-qi** (*gān qì yǔ xū*), where **wood leaves fall** and the pulse dies. Like leaves scattered by the wind, it lacks a fixed pattern.

**Revised annotation** (*xīn jiào zhèng yún*): According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (*甲乙经*), **scattered leaves** (*sǎn yè*) is written as **clustered thorns** (*cóng jì*).

If the pulse arrives **like a departing guest** (*rú xǐng kè*), a **departing-guest pulse** (*xǐng kè*) is **blocked yet resonant** (*mài sè ér gǔ*), indicating **insufficient Kidney-qi** (*shèn qì yǔ bù zú*), death occurring when the **sprouts of jujube** (*zǎo huá*) are **suspended** (*xuán*). **Suspended** (*xuán*) refers to the pulse **like a hanging object**—when the object moves, it **snaps away** (*jué qù*).

If the pulse arrives **like a horizontal beam** (*rú héng gé*), it indicates **insufficient Gallbladder-qi** (*dǎn qì yǔ bù zú*), death occurring when **grain ripens** (*hé shú*). The pulse is **long and firm**, like a **horizontal wooden beam beneath the fingers**.

If the pulse arrives **like a taut thread** (*rú xián lǚ*), it signifies **insufficient uterine essence** (*bāo jīng yǔ bù zú*). The patient **speaks readily** (*bìng shàn yán*), dying when **frost descends**; if **silent, it may be treated** (*bù yán kě zhì*). The **uterus’s pulse** (*bāo zhī mài*) connects to the **Kidney**, whose pulse **flanks the tongue’s root** (*qì bù zú zhě, zé dāng bù néng yán*). If the patient **speaks readily instead**, it means **true-qi has internally perished** (*zhēn qì nèi jué*), **leaving the Kidney** and **returning externally to the tongue**—hence death.

If the pulse arrives **like crossed lacquer** (*rú jiāo qī*), a **crossed-lacquer pulse** (*jiāo qī*) comes from **left and right arrivals** (*zuǒ yòu bàng zhì*), a slight sign of death within thirty days. The pulse arrives **as if traversing lacquer’s crossings** (*yán rú lì qī zhī jiāo*), left and right **contradicting each other**.

**Revised annotation** (*xīn jiào zhèng yún*): According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (*甲乙经*), **crossed lacquer** (*jiāo qī*) is written as **crossed immediately** (*jiāo jí*).

If the pulse arrives **like a gushing spring** (*rú yǒng quán*), **floating and resonant within the flesh** (*fú gǔ jī zhōng*), it indicates **insufficient Taiyang-qi** (*tài yáng qì yǔ bù zú*), where **vitality and flavor diminish** (*shǎo qì wèi*), death occurring when **chives bloom** (*jiǔ yīng*). Like a **spring’s movement**—water **flows out but does not return**.

If the pulse arrives **like crumbling earth** (*rú tuí tǔ*), pressing yields **no resistance** (*àn zhī bù dé*), signifying **insufficient muscle-qi** (*jī qì yǔ bù zú*). The patient’s **complexion first turns black**, then **white patches appear**, leading to death.

**Crumbling earth** (*tuí tǔ*) refers to the **excessively large and hollow pulse** (*fú zhī dà ér xū yáo tuí tǔ zhì*), pressing reveals **nothingness**.

**Revised annotation** (*xīn jiào zhèng yún*): According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (*甲乙经*), **crumbling earth** (*tuí tǔ*) is written as **collapsed earth** (*wěi tǔ*).

If the pulse arrives **like a hanging uvula** (*rú xuán yīng*), a **hanging-uvula pulse** (*xuán yīng*) is **floating yet exaggerated** (*fú chuài qiè zhī yì dà*), indicating **insufficient qi of the twelve acupuncture points** (*shí èr xū yǔ bù zú*), death occurring when **water congeals** (*shuǐ níng*). Like the **uvula suspended in the forehead** (*rú sǎng zhōng zhī xuán yīng*).

**Revised annotation** (*xīn jiào zhèng yún*): According to the **full text of Yuan Qi’s annotations** (*quán yuán qǐ běn*), **hanging uvula** (*xuán yīng*) is written as **hanging divergence** (*xuán lí*).

**Yuan Qi’s note** (*yuán qǐ zhù yún*): **Hanging divergence** (*xuán lí*) refers to the pulse **not harmonizing with the flesh** (*mài yǔ ròu bù xiāng dé*).

If the pulse arrives **like a resting blade** (*rú yǎn dāo*), it indicates **five viscera** (*wǔ zàng*) **near completion** (*wǎn shú*), where **cold and heat converge upon the Kidney** (*hán rè dú bìng yú shèn*), the patient **cannot sit** (*rú qí rén bù dé zuò*), dying at the **beginning of spring** (*lì chūn*).

**Completion** (*shú*) means **accumulation** (*jiān*); **near completion** (*wǎn shú*) means **heat**.

If the pulse arrives **like a rolling bead** (*rú wán huá bù zhí shǒu*), a **non-straightening pulse** (*bù zhí shǒu*) means **pressing finds no fixed form** (*àn zhī bù néng dé*), signifying **insufficient Large Intestine-qi** (*dà cháng qì yǔ bù zú*), death occurring when **jujube leaves grow** (*zǎo yè shēng*).

If the pulse arrives **like a flower** (*rú huā*), the patient **easily becomes fearful** (*lìng rén shàn kǒng*), **avoiding sitting outside** (*bù yù zuò wài*), yet **constantly standing and listening** (*xíng lì cháng tīng*), indicating **insufficient Small Intestine-qi** (*xiǎo cháng qì yǔ bù zú*), death occurring in **late autumn** (*jì qiū*).

**Like a flower** (*rú huā*) refers to the pulse **appearing hollow and weak** (*sì huā xū ruò*), **unable to be grasped firmly** (*bù kě zhèng qǔ*). The **Small Intestine’s pulse** (*xiǎo cháng zhī mài*) **ascends into the ear** (*shàng rù ěr zhōng*), hence the **constant listening**.

---

**Taiyang Pulse Patterns** (*Tài yáng mài jiě piān*)

The **Taiyang** (*tài yáng*) **pulse** is said to cause **swollen waist and tender buttocks** (*zhǒng yāo yǎ tòng zhě*), occurring in the **first month** (*zhèng yuè*), when **Taiyang** (*tài yáng*) **is in the Tiger hour** (*yín*). **Tiger hour** (*yín*) is **Taiyang** (*tài yáng*).

In the **first month** (*zhèng yuè*), the **three Yang channels** (*sān yáng*) **emerge**, governing **the Tiger hour** (*jiàn yín*). The **three Yang** (*sān yáng*) are called **Taiyang** (*tài yáng*), hence **Tiger hour Taiyang** (*yín tài yáng*).

In the first month, **Yang-qi rises above** (*yáng qì chū zài shàng*), while **Yin-qi predominates** (*yīn qì shèng*), **Yang not yet regaining its natural order** (*yáng wèi dé zì cì*).

Though the **first month** (*zhèng yuè*) **has three Yang emerging** (*sān yáng shēng*), the **heavenly energy remains cold** (*tiān qì shàng hán*), hence **Yin-qi predominates while Yang does not yet regain its natural order** (*yīn qì shèng yáng wèi dé zì cì*). **Natural order** (*cì*) refers to **the establishment of the sovereign** (*lì wáng zhī cì*).

Thus, **swollen waist and tender buttocks** (*zhǒng yāo yǎ tòng*) occur. The **pulse presses against the waist** (*yǐ qí mài dǐ yāo zhōng*), **penetrates into the buttocks** (*rù guàn tūn*), passing **through the □ pivot** (*guò □shū*), hence it is so.

If the **disease manifests as a half-empty condition** (*bìng piān xū wéi bǒ*), causing **limping** (*bǒ*), it is because in the **first month**, **Yang-qi thaws and resolves** (*yáng qì dòng jiě*), while **earth-qi emerges** (*dì qì ér chū*). The **half-empty condition** (*piān xū*) refers to those who **have some deficiency from winter’s cold** (*dōng hán pō yǒu bù zú zhě*), hence **limping from a half-empty condition** (*gù piān xū wéi bǒ*).

The **pulse follows the inner thigh** (*yǐ qí mài xún tuǐ nèi hòu kàng*), **merges with the hip** (*hé qiān zhōng*), **descends along the calf** (*xià xún lǚ*), passing **behind the outer ankle** (*guò wài lì hòu*), then **along the lateral malleolus to the outer side of the little toe** (*xún jīng gǔ zhì xiǎo zhǐ wài cè*). Thus it is so.

「○ The newly corrected edition states: Upon examining Master Wang’s account, his claim that the pulse follows the inner thigh (*xún gǔ nèi*) is incorrect. According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* (Canon of the A-B Branches), the **Taiyang meridian flows downward** (*tài yáng liú zhù*), not reaching the inner thigh. The inner thigh (*gǔ nèi*) is a mistaken reference to the **spleen’s external pathway** (*pí wài*); it should read **outer thigh, posterior border** (*xiǎng wài hòu lián*). The phrase **"strong upward, drawing the back"** (*qiáng shàng yǐn bèi*) refers to **excessive Yang-qi ascending and contending** (*yáng qì dà shàng ér zhēng*), hence the "strong upward" (*qiáng shàng*). "Strong upward" means **stiffness in the neck and nape** (*jìng xiàng jìn qiáng*). In severe cases, it **draws the back** (*yǐn bèi*). This occurs because its **pulse originates from the brain** (*yǐ qí mài cóng nǎo chū*), diverges downward to the **nape and back** (*bié xià xiàng bèi*), hence the condition.

The phrase **"ear buzzing"** (*ěr wū*) arises when **Yang-qi ascends vigorously to the upper regions, leaping** (*yáng qì wàn wù shèng shàng ér yuè*), hence the buzzing. This is due to its **branching pathway** (*yǐ qí mài zhī bìé zhě*), which **extends from the crown to the upper angle of the ear** (*cóng diān zhì ěr shàng jiǎo*), hence the buzzing.

The phrase **"severe cases lead to frenzied crown and foot illness"** (*shèn zé jiāng diān jì*) refers to **Yang-qi fully ascending while Yin-qi remains below** (*yáng jìn zài shàng ér yīn qì cóng xià*), resulting in **lower deficiency and upper excess** (*xià xū shàng shí*), hence the frenzied crown and foot illness. Its **pulse ascends to the forehead and intersects the crown above** (*yǐ qí mài shàng é jiāo diān shàng, rù lùo nǎo hái chū*), before its **branching pathway diverges from the crown to the upper angle of the ear** (*yǐ qí mài zhī bìé zhě, xià diān zhì ěr shàng jiǎo*). Hence, the frenzied crown and foot illness. The **crown** (*diān*) is the **top of the head** (*dǐng shàng*).

The phrase **"floating leads to deafness"** (*fú wéi lóng*) is entirely due to **Qi imbalance** (*jiē zài qì yě*). This also occurs because its **pulse reaches the ear** (*yǐ qí mài zhì ěr*).

The phrase **"entering the center leads to muteness"** (*rù zhōng wéi jì*) arises when **Yang-qi, though initially excessive, now declines** (*yáng shèng yǐ shuāi*), hence the muteness. When **Yang-qi is excessive but waning**, it **fails to nourish the uterus and kidneys** (*rù zhōng ér bó yú bāo shèn*), causing **blockage in the uterine and kidney collaterals** (*bāo luò shèn luò qì bù tōng*), hence the muteness. The **uterus’ pulse connects to the kidneys** (*bāo zhī mài xì yú shèn*), and the **kidneys’ pulse runs alongside the root of the tongue** (*shèn zhī mài xiá shé běn*), hence the **muteness and inability to speak** (*jì bù néng yán*). When **Yin-qi is internally disrupted and leads to syncope** (*nèi duó ér jué*), it results in **muteness and limping** (*jì pái*), which is a sign of **kidney deficiency** (*cǐ shèn xū yě*). "Limping" here means **foot paralysis** (*pái, fèi yě*). The **kidney’s pulse emerges alongside the Chong meridian** (*shèn zhī mài yǔ chōng mài bìng chū yú qì jiē*), following the **inner thigh’s posterior border** (*xún yīn gǔ nèi hòu kàng*), obliquely entering the **hip’s center** (*xié rù qiān zhōng*), descending along the **inner border of the calf’s bone** (*xún fǔ gǔ nèi lián jí nèi lì hòu*), and entering the **sole of the foot** (*rù zú xià*). Thus, when **kidney-qi is internally disrupted and fails to flow smoothly** (*shèn qì nèi tuō, zé shèn xū*), the **tongue becomes mute and the foot paralyzed** (*shé jì zú fèi*), hence the saying, "This is kidney deficiency." ○ The newly corrected edition states: Upon examining Master Wang’s annotation, which claims the **kidney’s pulse emerges alongside the Chong meridian** (*shèn zhī mài yǔ chōng mài bìng chū*), according to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng*, this is actually the **kidney’s collateral** (*shèn zhī luò*), not the **kidney’s pulse** (*shèn zhī mài*). Moreover, in Wang’s annotations of the *Wěi Lùn* (Treatise on Flaccidity), *Qí Bìng Lùn* (Treatise on Miscellaneous Diseases), and *Dà Qí Lùn* (Treatise on Major Miscellaneous Diseases), it is also stated that this is the **kidney’s collateral**. Therefore, the term **pulse** (*mài*) here should be corrected to **collateral** (*luò*).

When **Shaoyin fails to reach** (*shào yīn bù zhì*), it leads to **syncope** (*jué yě*). **Shaoyin** is the **kidney’s pulse** (*shèn mài yě*). If **kidney-qi internally collapses** (*ruò shèn qì nèi tuō*), then the **Shaoyin pulse fails to reach** (*shào yīn zhī mài bù zhì*). When the **Shaoyin pulse fails to reach**, the **Taiyin-qi reverses and ascends** (*shào yīn zhī mài bù zhì, zé tài yīn zhī qì nì shàng ér xíng yě*).

Regarding **Shaoyang**, the phrase **"heart and rib pain"** (*xīn xié tòng*) indicates **Shaoyang excess** (*shǎo yáng shèng yě*). Excess manifests as **symptoms of the heart** (*shèng zhě xīn zhī suǒ biǎo yě*). When **heart-qi reverses** (*xīn qì nì*), it aligns with **Shaoyang excess** (*shǎo yáng shèng*). The **heart’s qi belongs to Wood** (*xīn qì yí mù*), which externally **consumes the Lung’s Metal** (*wài chuò fèi jīn*), hence excess manifests as symptoms of the heart. In the **ninth month**, **Yang-qi is exhausted while Yin-qi thrives** (*jiǔ yuè yáng qì jìn ér yīn qì shèng*), hence the heart and rib pain. The **foot Shaoyang pulse** (*zú shǎo yáng mài*) follows the **rib’s lateral region** (*xún xié kuàng*), emerging from the **Qi Street** (*qì jiē*), while the **heart’s pulse** (*xīn zhǔ mài*) follows the **chest and emerges at the ribs** (*xún xiōng chū xié*). Fire is **buried in the hour of Xu** (*wù yú wèi*), hence in the ninth month, **Yang-qi is exhausted while Yin-qi thrives**.

The phrase **"unable to turn or roll over"** (*bù néng fǎn cè*) arises because **Yin-qi stores and conceals** (*yīn qì cáng wù yě*). When **things are concealed and stored**, they **do not move** (*wù cáng zé bù dòng*), hence the inability to turn or roll over.

The phrase **"severe cases lead to leaping"** (*shèn zé yuè*) refers to **jumping or leaping** (*yuè, wèi tiào yuè yě*). In the **ninth month**, **all things are exhausted and waning** (*jiǔ yuè wàn wù jìn shuāi*), **grasses and trees wither and fall** (*cǎo mù bì luò ér duò*), causing **Qi to shift from Yang to Yin** (*qì qù yáng ér zhī yīn*). When **Yin-qi is excessive and Yang-qi below grows long**, it results in **leaping** (*yù yuè*). This is also because its **pulse follows the spleen’s Yang** (*yǐ qí mài xún pí yáng*), emerging from the **outer thigh’s posterior border** (*shàng xī guò wài lì hòu*), descending to the **front of the outer ankle** (*xià rù wài fǔ zhī qián*), and directly downward to the **end of the Jue bone** (*zhí xià dǐ jué gǔ zhī duān*), emerging from the **front of the outer ankle** (*xià chū wài lì zhī qián*), and following the **outer side of the foot** (*xún zú fù*). When **Qi is excessive**, it causes **jumping or leaping** (*zuò qì shèng zé lìng rén tiào yuè*).

Regarding **Yangming**, the phrase **"shaking and trembling with cold"** (*sǎ sǎ zhèn hán*) refers to **Yangming as the hour of Wu** (*yáng míng zhě wǔ yě*), which is **the Yin of the flourishing Yang of the fifth month** (*wǔ yuè shèng yáng zhī yīn yě*). When **Yang-qi is flourishing**, it is called **Wu** (*yáng shèng yǐ míng, gù yún wǔ yě*). In the **fifth month**, at the **summer solstice** (*wǔ yuè xià zhì*), **Yin-qi ascends while Yang-qi descends** (*yī yīn qì shàng, yáng qì jiàng xià*), hence it is called **the Yin of the flourishing Yang of the fifth month**. When **Yang-qi is flourishing but Yin-qi additionally ascends**, it results in **shaking and trembling with cold** (*jiǔ jiǔ zhèn hán*). Yang-qi descends and Yin-qi ascends, hence it is said, **"Yang-qi is flourishing while Yin-qi additionally ascends"** (*yáng qì xià, yīn qì shēng, gù yún yáng qì shèng ér yīn qì jiā zhī yě*).

The phrase **"meridian swelling while the thigh does not contract"** (*jīng zhǒng ér gǔ bù shōu*) is due to **the fifth month’s flourishing Yang and its Yin** (*shì wǔ yuè shèng yáng zhī yīn yě*). In the fifth month, **Yang-qi begins to decline** (*yáng zhě shuāi yú wǔ yuè*), while **Yin-qi ascends and begins to contend with Yang** (*yī yīn qì shàng, yǔ yáng shǐ zhēng*), hence the **meridian swelling while the thigh does not contract**. Its **pulse descends from the spleen, reaching the Fudou** (*yǐ qí mài xià pí dǐ fú dōu*), descending into the **center of the knee** (*xià rù xī tǐ zhōng*), descending along the **outer thigh’s posterior border** (*xià xún fǔ wài lián*), descending to the **outer side of the foot** (*xià zú fù*), and entering the **inner interval of the middle toe** (*rù zhōng zhǐ nèi jiān*). Its **branching pathway diverges** (*yòu qí bìé zhě*) three inches below the knee (*xià xī sān cùn ér bié*), descending to the **outer interval of the middle toe** (*xià rù zhōng zhǐ wài wèn*).」

Thus it follows. What is meant by **"upper dyspnea and water formation"** is that **Yin-qi descends and then ascends again**, ascending to lodge as pathogenic *qi* within the **zàng-fǔ interstices**—hence the formation of water. The **zàng** refers to the **spleen**, and the **fǔ** refers to the **stomach**.

The **Foot-Taiyin meridian** ascends from the foot to the abdomen, while the **Foot-Yangming meridian** descends from the head to the foot. Now, as **Yin-qi subtly descends**, the **Taiyin** ascends in counterflow—hence the saying that **Yin-qi descends and then ascends again**. When it ascends again, the descending **Yin-qi** does not disperse but lodges within the **spleen-stomach interstices**, transforming into water.

What is meant by **"chest pain and shortness of breath"** is that **water-qi resides in the zàng-fǔ**. Water is **Yin-qi**; when **Yin-qi** lingers in the center, it causes **chest pain and shortness of breath**. When water stagnates below, **qi** becomes congested above, and **congested qi** above leads to **lung fullness**—hence the **chest pain and shortness of breath**.

What is meant by **"in severe cases, syncope; aversion to people and fire, and startling at the sound of wood"** is that **Yang-qi and Yin-qi clash**, and **water and fire repel each other**—hence the **startled, sudden fright**. What is meant by **"desiring to shut oneself away in a sealed chamber"** is that **Yin and Yang clash**; when **Yang is exhausted and Yin prevails**, one **seeks seclusion in a sealed chamber**—hence the aversion to noise.

What is meant by **"when the illness peaks, one wishes to climb high and sing, casting aside clothes and fleeing"** is that **Yin and Yang contend anew**, and **external forces align with Yang**—hence the **casting aside of clothes and fleeing**.

**New annotation:** Examine the passage from *"in severe cases, syncope"* onward—it corresponds with the earlier *"Yangming Pulse Explanation"* (*Yángmíng Mài Jiě Lùn*).

What is meant by **"when the Guest-Son pulse appears, there is headache, nasal sighing, and abdominal distension"** is that **Yangming converges above**, and **what converges above** is the **Son collateral of Taiyin**—hence the **headache, nasal sighing, and abdominal distension**.

The **Taiyin**—what is called **"disease of distension"**—is the **Taiyin child** (i.e., **Child of Water**). In the **eleventh month**, when all things’ *qi* withdraws inward, it is said to be **"disease of distension."** Since **Yin-qi is excessively strong**, the **Taiyin** originates in the **Child (hour)**, hence the term **"child."** As its meridian enters the abdomen, connecting with the spleen and collateralizing the stomach, **distension ensues**.

What is meant by **"ascending to the heart, causing belching"** is that **excessive Yin ascends into Yangming**, and **Yangming’s collaterals connect to the heart**—hence it is said that **"it ascends to the heart, causing belching."** According to the *Língshū*, the **Foot-Yangming meridian’s flow** does not conventionally reach the heart, but the **Taiyin meridian’s text** states: *"Its branching pathway diverges again, ascending from the stomach to the *è* (esophageal junction), entering the heart."* This should be taken as the **Yangming collateral**.

**New annotation:** Examine Wang’s claim that the **Foot-Yangming meridian’s flow** does not reach the heart—yet the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* states that the **Yangming meridian** ascends to the heart, passes the throat, and exits the mouth. Thus, the *Classics* correctly state that the **Yangming collateral connects to the heart**, causing belching. How could Wang deny its existence?

What is meant by **"vomiting upon eating"** is that **excessive intake overflows upward**—hence the vomiting. This is because its meridian connects to the spleen and collateralizes the stomach, ascending to the *è* (esophageal junction) beside the throat.

What is meant by **"afterward, when *qi* is obtained, there is a sudden sense of decline"** is that in the **eleventh month**, **Yin-qi descends and weakens**, while **Yang-qi is about to emerge**—hence the saying that **"afterward, when *qi* is obtained, there is a sudden sense of decline."**

The **Shaoyin**—what is called **"lumbar pain"**—refers to the **kidney**. In the **tenth month**, when all things’ **Yang-qi** is injured, **lumbar pain** ensues. The **Shaoyin** is the **kidney meridian**, and the **lumbar region is the kidney’s residence**—hence the **lumbar pain**.

What is meant by **"vomiting, coughing, and upward dyspnea"** is that **Yin-qi lingers below**, while **Yang-qi floats above**; all **Yang-qi** rises without support—hence the **vomiting, coughing, and upward dyspnea**. As its meridian ascends from the kidney, piercing the liver’s *è* (esophageal junction) and entering the lungs, the illness manifests thus.

What is meant by **"color—"** **New annotation:** The term *"color"* (*sè sè*) is likely erroneous.

---

**Shaoyin**—what is called **"inability to stand long, and when sitting for long one rises with blurred vision"**—refers to the **Yin-qi** and **Yang-qi** being unstable and without a fixed ruler. When the **Autumn-qi** arrives, the first frost descends, and the killing **Yin** begins to affect all things. Internally, the **Yin** and **Yang** are disrupted, hence the blurred vision upon rising.

What is meant by **"prone to anger with diminished breath"** is that the **Yang-qi** is not harmonized; when the **Yang-qi** cannot ascend properly, the **Liver-qi**—which should be regulated—fails to find its course, hence the propensity for anger. This propensity for anger is called **"煎厥" (Jiānjué, tormented frenzy)**.

What is meant by **"fear as if pursued by capture"** is that the **Autumn-qi** has not yet fully withdrawn from all things. The **Yin-qi** is yet weak, while the **Yang-qi** intrudes, causing the **Yin** and **Yang** to clash—hence the fear.

What is meant by **"aversion to food odors"** is that the **stomach lacks qi**, hence the aversion to food odors.

What is meant by **"face black as earth’s hue"** is that the **Autumn-qi** disrupts internally, causing a change in complexion.

What is meant by **"coughing up blood"** is that the **Yang meridian** is injured. When the **Yang-qi** has not yet ascended fully, the meridian becomes congested; congestion leads to coughing, hence blood appears at the nose.

**Jueyin**—what is called **"癫疝" (Diānshān, epilepsy and hernia), or swelling of the lower abdomen in women**—refers to **Jueyin**, which corresponds to **辰 (Chén, the third earthly branch, March)**. In the **third month**, when the **Yin** within **Yang** is at its peak, the **evil** lingers in the center, hence the **epilepsy, hernia, and lower abdominal swelling**. Its meridian travels along the **inner thigh**, enters the **pubic region**, encircles the **Yin organs**, reaches the **lower abdomen**—thus the symptoms.

What is meant by **"lumbar and spinal pain preventing flexion and extension"** is that in the **third month**, there is a sudden **stirring** of growth and flourishing in all things, yet it remains **bent** without rising—hence the pain.

What is meant by **"epilepsy, hernia, and swollen skin"** is that the **Yin** is also excessive, causing the meridian to swell and obstruct—hence the **epilepsy, hernia, and swollen skin**.

What is meant by **"severe cases leading to hoarseness, dryness, and internal heat"** is that the **Yin** and **Yang** clash, generating **heat**—hence the **hoarseness and dryness**.

This section diverges from the preceding and subsequent passages, offering a separate explanation of the **meridian’s** origins of illness, akin yet distinct from the *Ling Shu* (Spiritual Pivot) theory of **flow and ebb**. **New annotation:** *"This section’s explanations largely align with the *Jiāyǔ Jīng* (Canon of A and B) regarding diseases arising from the **meridian’s movements**, differing only slightly, yet fundamentally consistent."*

**The Essentials of Needling** (Cìyào Lùn)

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I wish to hear about the essentials of needling."*

Qìbó replied: *"Illness has superficial and deep aspects; needling has shallow and deep techniques. Each must reach its proper principle; do not exceed the Dao/Way.*

The **Dao/Way** refers to the **pathways of qi**. Exceeding it causes **internal injury**; failing to reach it leads to **external obstruction**, and obstruction allows **evil** to follow. Exceeding it results in **internal injury** due to **excessive depth**; failing to reach it causes **external obstruction** by mistakenly reinforcing another part’s **qi**. When **qi** is reinforced, **external obstruction** arises, allowing **evil qi** to seize the **void** and follow it. If **shallow and deep** techniques are misapplied, it becomes a **great thief**, disrupting the **Five Zàng (viscera)** and eventually giving rise to **major illness**. **Thief** means **private harm**; **disrupt** means **chaos**. Thus, failing to reach it leads to **external obstruction**, while exceeding it causes **internal injury**. When both **external obstruction** and **internal injury** occur, it marks the **gradual onset** of **major illness**—hence the saying, ‘*later it gives rise to major illness*.’"

Thus it is said: *"Illness may reside in the **millimeter-hairs** (háo), in the **skin’s texture** (shènglǐ), in the **muscles**, in the **meridians**, in the **sinews**, in the **bones**, or in the **marrow**."* The **longest hairs** are called **millimeter-hairs** (háo), and the **skin’s visible patterns** are called **texture** (shènglǐ). Needling the **millimeter-hairs** or **skin’s texture** does not harm the **skin** itself. When the **skin** is injured, the **lungs** are internally disrupted; the **lungs** disrupted lead to **Autumnal illnesses** of **fever and intermittent chills**, with **shivering** and **persistent coldness**.

The *Canning* (Needling Canon) says: *"There are five superficial needlings corresponding to the **Five Zàng (viscera)**. The first is **half-needling**, where the needle is inserted shallowly but swiftly withdrawn, causing **excessive injury** akin to pulling out hair. This targets the **skin’s qi**, corresponding to the **lungs**."* Though this is a **shallow** technique for the **lungs**, the **skin’s texture** and **millimeter-hairs** require an even shallower insertion—**halfway between the hair roots’ depth and the surface**.

The **lungs** govern the **skin**; they rule over **Autumn-qi**. Thus, when the **lungs** are disrupted, **Autumnal illnesses** of **fever and intermittent chills** arise, with **shivering** and **persistent coldness**. **Sū (shivering)** is pronounced *sù*.

Needling the **skin** without harming the **muscles**: when the **muscles** are injured, the **spleen** is internally disrupted; the **spleen** disrupted leads to **abdominal distension, discomfort, and loss of appetite** in the **seventy-second days** of the **four seasons’ months**. The **spleen’s** meridian unites with the **muscles**, and its **qi** is entrusted to rule over the **four seasons**. Its meridian ascends from the **inner thigh**, enters the **abdomen**, connects with the **spleen’s network** and **stomach’s collaterals**, pierces the **esophageal junction**, and links to the **throat**; it disperses beneath the **tongue** and its **branches** further ascend from the **stomach**, piercing the **esophageal junction** and converging in the **heart**. Thus, injuring the **muscles** disrupts the **spleen**; when the **spleen** is disrupted, the **four seasons’ months** see **abdominal distension, discomfort, and loss of appetite**.

The **seventy-second days** of the **four seasons’ months** refer to the **twelve days** following the **third, sixth, ninth, and twelfth months**, with **Earth** entrusted to rule over **eighteen days**.

Needling the **muscles** without harming the **meridians**: when the **meridians** are injured, the **heart** is internally disrupted; the **heart** disrupted leads to **Summeral illnesses** of **cardiac pain**. The **heart** governs the **meridians**; it rules over **Summer-qi**. The **true heart’s** **Shaoyin meridian** originates in the **heart**, emerging to connect with the **heart’s system**. The **heart’s** **包 (pāo, wrapper/pericardium) meridian** originates in the **chest**, emerging to connect with the **heart’s wrapper**. The *Treatise on Plain Man’s Qi Manifestations* says: *"The **Zàng (viscera)**’s **true essence** communicates with the **heart**."* Thus, injuring the **meridians** disrupts the **heart**; when the **heart** is disrupted, **Summeral illnesses** of **cardiac pain** arise.

Needling the **meridians** without harming the **sinews**: when the **sinews** are injured, the **liver** is internally disrupted; the **liver** disrupted leads to **Springal illnesses** of **heat and forward relaxation**. The **liver** governs the **sinews**; it rules over **Spring-qi**. The *Canning* says: *"Heat relaxes the **sinews**."* Thus, injuring the **sinews** disrupts the **liver**; when the **liver** is disrupted, **Springal illnesses** of **heat and sinew relaxation** arise. **Relaxation** (chǐ) means **loosening**; its pronunciation is *shì* in the **cut**.

Needling the **sinews** without harming the **bones**: when the **bones** are injured, the **kidney** is internally disrupted; the **kidney** disrupted leads to **Winteral illnesses** of **lumbar distension and pain**. The **kidney** governs the **bones**; it rules over **Winter-qi**. The **lumbar region** is the **kidney’s residence**—hence, when the **bones** are injured, the **kidney** is disrupted; when the **kidney** is disrupted, **Winteral illnesses** of **lumbar pain** arise. The **kidney’s** **meridian** travels **straight upward**, piercing the **esophageal junction**—hence the **distension**.

Needling the **bones** without harming the **marrow**: when the **marrow** is injured, the **organs** grow **acidic**, and the **body’s** **dissolution** spreads diffusely without cessation. The **marrow** is the **bone’s** **filler**.

The *Zhen Jing* says: *"When the **marrow sea** is insufficient, the **brain** spins, the ears ring, the **organs** grow **acidic**, and **dizziness** and **headache** arise."* Hence, when the **marrow** is injured, the **brain marrow** dissolves, the **organs** grow **acidic**, and the **body’s dissolution** spreads diffusely—**indeterminate** and unceasing.

**"Dissolution"** (xiāoshuò) refers to the **marrow and brain** dissolving.
**"Diffuse"** (jiěbù) refers to **strength** that is neither strong nor weak, **cold** that is neither hot nor cold—**indeterminate**, spreading diffusely, beyond naming.

The **dissolution of brain marrow** stems from **hollowed bones**.

*"Shuò"* is pronounced as in *"shì yuè"* (poetic reading).
*"Xuàn"* (dizziness) is pronounced *"xuán"* (as in "suspend").

---
*(Annotations in brackets for technical terms; poetic readings noted as per original.)*

**Chapter on Needling Depths**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I wish to hear of the distinctions in needling depth—referring to the layers of skin, flesh, sinews, vessels, and bone."*

Qibo replied: *"When needling bone, do not harm the sinews; when needling sinews, do not harm the flesh; when needling flesh, do not harm the vessels; when needling vessels, do not harm the skin. When needling skin, do not harm the flesh; when needling flesh, do not harm the sinews; when needling sinews, do not harm the bone."*

The Emperor said: *"I do not yet understand your meaning. I wish to hear its explanation."*

Qibo said: *"When needling bone without harming sinews, the needle reaches the sinews but does not penetrate the bone. When needling sinews without harming flesh, it reaches the flesh but does not reach the sinews. When needling flesh without harming vessels, it reaches the vessels but does not penetrate the flesh. When needling vessels without harming skin, it reaches the skin but does not reach the vessels. These are all methods of expelling pathogenic factors.*

*However, if sinews harbor cold pathogens, flesh harbors wind pathogens, vessels harbor damp pathogens, and skin harbors heat pathogens, then needling should be adjusted accordingly. What is called ‘pathogenic’ refers to what disrupts the harmonious flow of true qi and invades the body.*

---
**Newly Corrected Notes:**
*"This explains that shallow needling does not reach the intended depth; the following text warns against excessive depth. When needling skin without harming flesh, the disease lies within the skin, and the needle enters only the skin without damaging the flesh. When needling flesh without harming sinews, it passes through the flesh but avoids the sinews. When needling sinews without harming bone, it passes through the sinews but avoids the bone. This is called ‘reversal.’ This warns against excessive or overly deep needling."*

*"According to Quan Yuanqi: Needling in this manner constitutes injury—all of these are excesses. Excess weakens blood and qi, which is called ‘contrary’ to the Dao, allowing pathogens to enter."*
