**Chapter on Needling Prohibitions**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I wish to hear of the prohibitions."*

Qibo replied: *"The viscera have critical vulnerabilities that must be observed. The liver arises on the left—its nature aligns with wood, ruling spring, when yang energy first emerges, hence its leftward origin. The lungs are housed on the right—their nature aligns with metal, ruling autumn, when yin energy contracts and kills, hence their concealment there."*

*"The heart lies externally—yang energy governs the exterior, and its nature aligns with fire. The kidneys govern internally—yin energy governs the interior, and their nature aligns with water."*

*"The spleen is called the ‘Director’—its ceaseless circulation of nourishing essence and transformation of waste into chyle makes it the Director. The stomach is called the ‘Market’—where water and grain enter, and the five flavors converge like a marketplace."*

*"Above the diaphragm, within the chest, lies the parent-child duo—the diaphragm’s upper region houses the *qihai* (Sea of Qi), the source of life and origin of the vital breath, thus called the ‘parent and child’ of humanity."*

*"According to Yang Shangshan: The heart below the diaphragm and above the *li* (stomach) is the *fang* (region of the heart), and the heart is the yang parent, while the lungs are the yin mother. The lungs govern qi, and the heart governs blood; together, they nourish and defend the body, hence ‘parent and child.’"*

*"Beside the seven lumbar vertebrae lies the *xiaoxin* (small heart)—the true heart, the hallowed chamber of the spirit’s essence."*

*"According to *Taisu*: *Xiaoxin* is also called *zhixin* (heart of will). Yang Shangshan says: The spine has twenty-one vertebrae; the kidneys lie beside the lower seven. The kidney spirit is called *zhi* (will), and the spirits of the five viscera each have their own essence—what the heart’s spirit governs is called *zhi*. To follow is fortune; to oppose is calamity."*

Eight are the principles by which a person is born and the form is completed: thus, following them brings prolonged fortune, while opposing them invites calamity.

If the **heart** is pierced, death occurs in one day, and its disturbance manifests as **sighing**. The **heart**’s relation to **qi** is expressed through sighing.

If the **liver** is pierced, death occurs in five days, and its disturbance manifests as **speaking** (or **yawning***†*). The **liver**’s relation to **qi** is expressed through speaking (or yawning). [*New校正* notes: According to *Quanyuanqi*’s original text and the *Jia-Yi Jing*, "speaking" should be translated as **yawning**. *Quanyuanqi* states: "If the **kidneys** are injured, it results in yawning, for the **yin-yang parent-child relationship** is affected." The *Wang* school alters "yawning" back to "speaking."]

If the **kidneys** are pierced, death occurs in six days (or three days*‡*), and its disturbance manifests as **sneezing**. The **kidneys**’ relation to **qi** is expressed through sneezing. [*New校正* notes: According to *Quanyuanqi*’s original text and the *Jia-Yi Jing*, "six days" should be "three days."]

If the **lungs** are pierced, death occurs in three days, and its disturbance manifests as **coughing**. The **lungs**’ relation to **qi** is expressed through coughing.

If the **spleen** is pierced, death occurs in ten days (or fifteen days*§*), and its disturbance manifests as **swallowing**. The **spleen**’s relation to **qi** is expressed through swallowing. [*New校正* notes: According to *Quanyuanqi*’s original text and the *Jia-Yi Jing*, "ten days" should be "fifteen days."]

Piercing the **five viscera** aligns with the *Zhenyao Jingzhonglun* and *Sishi* theories on **yin-yang parent-child** relations and **fortune/calamity** correspondence. This is the **Master Shu’s** sequential method of the viscera, ordered by their **generative cycle** (*shēng*). The *Jia-Yi Jing* arranges them as **heart, lungs, liver, spleen, kidneys**, following the **overcoming cycle** (*kè*). *Quanyuanqi*’s text by Cao Wen, however, lists them in a disordered, inconsistent manner.

If the **gallbladder** is pierced, death occurs in half a day, and its disturbance manifests as **vomiting**. The **gallbladder**’s **qi** is bold, hence its association with vomiting. [*New校正* notes: According to the *Zhenyao Jingzhonglun*, it further states: "If the **stomach** (*ge*) is pierced, it is called *shāngzhōng* (injury to the center), and though the illness may heal, death will occur within no more than a year."]

Piercing the **greater vessel** (*dàmài*) of the **foot** (*zhu*) results in **prostration and pallor**. The **foot**’s **greater vessel** is the **foot Taiyang meridian** (*zú-Tàiyáng jīngmài*). Piercing this vessel excessively causes one to collapse and lose color, as if stripped bare.

Piercing the **midline pulse** (*liùmài*) of the **face** (*miàn*) without proper caution leads to **blindness**. The **midline pulse** of the **face** is where the **hand Taiyang meridian** (*shǒu-Tàiyáng mài*)—the **Ren meridian** (*Rèn mài*)—intersects. The **hand Taiyang meridian** descends from the forehead diagonally to the inner corner of the eye. The **Ren meridian** ascends from the sides of the **nostrils** (*bí*) upward to the **perineum** (*tóngzǐxià*), hence piercing the **midline pulse** of the **face** may result in **blindness**.

Piercing the **brain’s door** (*nǎohù*) at the top of the head causes immediate death upon entry. The **brain’s door** is a **acupuncture point** located above the **occipital bone** (*zhěn gǔ*), connecting directly to the **brain**. Yet the **brain** is the **sea of marrow** (*suǐzhīhǎi*), where **true qi** (*zhēnqì*) converges; if pierced, **true qi** will leak, resulting in instant death.

Piercing the **midline pulse** (*zhōngmài*) beneath the **tongue** (*shé*) excessively, with blood not ceasing to flow, causes **aphonia**. The **tongue’s midline pulse** belongs to the **spleen meridian** (*pí mài*), which runs beside the **throat** (*yàn*) and connects to the **root of the tongue** (*shé běn*), then disperses beneath the tongue. If blood flows endlessly, the **spleen’s qi** cannot circulate and nourish the tongue, hence **aphonia** ensues.

Piercing the **networked vessels** (*bùluò*) beneath the **foot** (*zú*) without blood outflow results in **edema**. The **networked vessels** refer to the **collateral branches** (*luò*) spreading across the space before the **inner ankle** (*nèihuái*) on the underside of the foot, corresponding to the **Zhonggu** acupoint. The **midline pulse** of these **networked vessels** is actually the **Chong meridian** (*Chōng mài*), which descends alongside the **foot Shaoyin meridian** (*zú-Shàoyīn jīngmài*) and enters the **inner ankle**, then continues beneath the foot. If pierced without blood outflow, the **kidney meridian** and **Chong meridian**’s **qi** converge at **Zhonggu**, causing **edema**.

Piercing the **greater vessel** (*dàmài*) of the **searching meridian** (*xún*) results in **prostration and pallor**. The **searching meridian**’s primary treatment point is **Weizhong** (*wěizhōng*), equivalent to the **Weizhong** acupoint in the *Zhongyong Liuzhujing*. The term "piercing the **searching meridian** of the **foot**" refers to the **foot Taiyang meridian** (*zú-Tàiyáng jīngmài*), which begins at the **inner corner of the eye** (*mù nèi pí*), converges with the **hand Taiyang meridian** (*shǒu-Tàiyáng mài*), and its **hand Taiyang meridian** descends diagonally from the inner corner of the eye to the **forehead** (*é*). The **foot Taiyang meridian** ascends to the **head** (*tóu*), descends to the **neck** (*yáng*), and then follows the **foot**. Thus, piercing it excessively causes collapse and a face pale as if stripped of color.

Piercing the **midline pulse** (*zhōngmài*) of **Qijie** causes **edema, prostration, and a rodent-like appearance**. The **midline pulse** of **Qijie** belongs to the **gallbladder** and **stomach meridians** (*dǎn-wèi mài*). The **gallbladder meridian** (*dǎn mài*) travels along the **ribcage** (*xiē*), emerging at **Qijie**. The **stomach meridian** (*wèi mài*) enters **Qijie** beside the **navel** (*qí*), and its **branch** (*zhī*) originates from beneath the **stomach**, ascending along the **abdomen** (*fù*) to converge at **Qijie**. If pierced without blood outflow, the blood and **qi** gather internally, forming **edema** and a rodent-like appearance. **Qijie** is located four inches below the **navel** on either side, with **Nǔshū** (*鼠仆*) one inch above it, where the pulse is palpable. [*New校正* notes: Another text records "Nǔshū" as a mistake; the *Qifu Lun*’s annotation states: "Qijie is located below the **navel** (*qí*), one inch above the **horizontal bone** (*héng gǔ*), and beside the **misfortune** (*shū*)."]

Piercing the **spinal midline** (*jǐwèn*) and injuring the **marrow** (*suǐ*) causes **hunchbacked posture** (*yǔ*). **Hunchbacked posture** refers to **kyphosis** (*yǔcān*), where the body bends forward. The **spinal midline** refers to the **spaces between the vertebrae** (*jǐgǔ jiēwèn*). Piercing the **marrow** causes the **essence of the bones** (*gǔjīng*) and **qi** to leak, hence the **hunchbacked posture**.

Piercing the **midline pulse** (*zhōngmài*) above the **breasts** (*rǔ*) results in **edema at the root** and **ulceration**. The **breasts**’ upper and lower regions are governed by the **foot Yangming meridian** (*zú-Yángmíng jīngmài*). Within the **breasts**, **breast fluid** (*rǔyè*) seeps and **qi** and blood from the chest all discharge externally. If the **breasts** are pierced, **qi** and blood discharge together, causing **severe edema**. Within lies a **pus-filled root** (*nónggēn*), which internally erodes the **muscles and skin** (*jīfū*), turning into **pus** (*nóngshuǐ*), and thus the condition becomes chronic and does not heal.

Piercing **Qipan** causes **internal collapse** and **qi leakage**, resulting in **wheezing, coughing, and reversed breathing**. The **five viscera** are covered by the **lungs**, and **Qipan** serves as their **passage**. The **lungs** store **qi** and govern **respiration** (*xī*), and their relation to **qi** manifests as **coughing**. Piercing **Qipan**’s internal collapse causes **lung qi** to leak externally, hence **wheezing, coughing, and reversed breathing** ensue.

Piercing the **inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) of the **hand’s fish abdomen** (*yúfù*) results in **edema**.

The **inner fish abdomen** (*yúfù*) of the hand contains the **lung meridian** (*fèimài*), so piercing it too deeply causes **edema**.

○Newly corrected text reads: According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (甲乙经), "肺脉所流" should be rendered as **"留"** (*liú*, meaning "retain").

**Piercing without caution** a **heavily intoxicated** person causes **disordered qi** (*qìluàn*). The **meridian pulses** (*màishù*) are excessive beyond measure, so the act of piercing further disturbs them.
○Newly corrected text reads: According to the *Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经), "气乱" should be rendered as **"脉乱"** (*màiluàn*, meaning "disordered pulses").

**Piercing without caution** a **furious** person causes **reversed qi** (*qìnì*). Anger itself brings **reversed qi**, so piercing worsens it further.

**Piercing without caution** a **laboring** person causes **qi to surge** (*jìngqìyuè*). **Piercing without caution** a **recently overfed** person causes **qi to be abundant and full** (*qìshèngmǎn*). **Piercing without caution** a **starving** person causes **qi to be insufficient** (*qìbùzú*). **Piercing without caution** a **thirsty** person causes **dryness in the blood vessels** (*xuèmài gān*). **Piercing without caution** a **startled** person causes **the spirit to scatter and qi to be unregulated** (*shén dàngyuè ér qì bùzhì*).

○Newly corrected text notes: Upon careful examination, the seven conditions from "无刺大醉" (*wú chī dà zuì*) onward differ from the *Ling Shu Jing* (灵枢经). The *Ling Shu Jing* states:
*"Newly pierced without caution, already pierced without newness. Furious without piercing, already pierced without fury. Laboring without piercing, already pierced without labor. Intoxicated without piercing, already pierced without intoxication. Overfed without piercing, already pierced without overfeeding. Starving without piercing, already pierced without starvation. Thirsty without piercing, already pierced without thirst. Startled or terrified, first regulate their qi, then pierce them."*

**Piercing the inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) of the **great meridian** (*dàmài*) in the **inner thigh** (*yīngu*) causes **internal leakage** (*nèiliù*) and **deafness** (*lóng*). The **guest host** (*kèzǔrén*), a **meridian point** (*xué míng*), is now called **Upper Pass** (*Shàngguān*), located in front of the ear, above the **Kang bone** (*kāng qǐ*), where the opening reveals a hollow. Here, the **hand’s lesser yang** (*shǎoyáng*) and **foot’s greater yang** (*dàyáng*) meridians converge in the middle.
○Newly corrected text notes: The **guest host** (*kèzǔrén*) point, as registered in the *Qi Xue Lun* (气穴论), aligns with this description. According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (甲乙经) and *Qi Fu Lun* (气府论) annotations, the convergence involves the **hand’s lesser yang**, **foot’s lesser yang**, and **foot’s greater yang** meridians—likely omitting the **foot’s lesser yang** (*shǎoyáng*) meridian here.
The **inner depression** refers to piercing **too deeply**. Piercing too deeply disrupts the intersecting meridians, causing **internal leakage** in the ear. When **meridian qi leaks internally**, the **ear’s nourishment is lost**, hence **deafness**.

**Piercing the inner depression** of the **knee joint** (*xīhuì*) causes **fluid leakage** (*yèchū*), resulting in **limping** (*bǒ*). The **knee** is the **house of sinews** (*jīnfǔ*), where sinews gather. When **fluid leaks**, the sinews dry out, hence **limping**.
○**髋** (*huì*) is pronounced as **fèng** (*fèng*).

**Piercing the greater yin** (*tàoyīn*) meridian of the **arm** (*bì*) causes **excessive bleeding** (*xuèchūduō*), leading to **immediate death** (*lìsǐ*). The **greater yin** meridian of the arm is the **lung meridian** (*fèimài*). The **lungs** govern the circulation of **nourishing and defensive qi** (*róngwèi yīnyáng*), regulating the **opening and closing** (*zhìjié*) of the **body’s channels**. When **blood leaks excessively**, the **nourishing and defensive qi are severed**, hence **immediate death**.

**Piercing the lesser yin** (*shàoyīn*) meridian of the **foot** (*zú*) causes **double emptiness** (*chóngxū*), leading to **bleeding** (*xuèchū*) and **tongue immobility** (*shétóu nán yǐ yán*). The **lesser yin** meridian of the foot is the **kidney meridian** (*shènmài*). The **foot’s lesser yin** meridian **penetrates the kidney**, connects with the **lung**, and **anchors the root of the tongue** (*shětóu běn*), so when **double emptiness** causes **bleeding**, the **tongue loses mobility**.

**Piercing the inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) of the **chest’s center** (*yīngzhōng*), where the **lung meridian** (*fèimài*) lies, causes **wheezing, reversed breathing, and labored respiration** (*chuǎnnì yǎngxī*). **Lung qi** leaks upward, leading to **reversed breathing**.

**Piercing the inner depression** of the **elbow’s bend** (*zhǒuzhōng*), where **qi returns** (*qì guīzhī*), causes **inability to flex or extend** (*bùdé qūshēn*). The **elbow’s bend** refers to the **center of the elbow’s fold** (*zhǒu zhé zhōng*), specifically the **Sea of the Cubit** (*Chǐzé*) point. When piercing **exceeds the inner depression**, **malignant qi** (*èqì*) returns, **fixing the joints** (*guān jié*), hence **inability to flex or extend**.

**Piercing the inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) three **cun** below the **inner thigh** (*yīngu*) causes **incontinence** (*yíniào*). Three **cun** below the **inner thigh** is the **kidney’s collateral** (*shèn zhī luò*). The **rushing meridian** (*Chōngmài*) and the **lesser yin collateral** (*shàoyīn zhī luò*) both originate below the **kidney**, emerge at the **street of qi** (*qìjiē*), and follow the **inner thigh**. Those that ascend travel through the **uterus** (*bāozhōng*). Thus, piercing the **inner depression** causes **incontinence**.

**Piercing the inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) below the **armpit** (*yèxià*), within the **rib’s interspace** (*xiējiān*), causes **coughing** (*késòu*). Below the **armpit** is where the **lung meridian** (*fèimài*) lies. The **lung meridian** originates from the **lung**, connects with it, and **horizontally emerges below the armpit**. The **true heart meridian** (*zhēnxīn cángmài*), which travels **straight**, ascends from the **heart**, then **retroflexes to the armpit**. Piercing the **inner depression** causes both the **heart and lung** to move, hence **coughing**.

**Piercing the inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) of the **lower abdomen** (*shàofù*), where the **urinary bladder** (*pángguāng*) and **urine** (*niàoyè*) emerge, causes the **lower abdomen to feel full** (*shàofù mǎn*). When **bladder qi** leaks externally, the **stomach’s vital qi** (*gǔqì*) returns, hence the **lower abdomen feels full**. The **lower abdomen** refers to the region **below the navel** (*qí xià*).

**Piercing the inner depression** of the **stomach’s intestines** (*tángcháng*) causes **edema**.

The **stomach’s intestines** (*tángcháng*) contain the **foot’s greater yang** meridian (*zúdàmài*). When **greater yang qi** leaks, it results in **edema**.

**Piercing the inner depression** (*nèixiàn*) of the **orbital ridge** (*yǐngqióng*)’s **bone** (*gǔ*), where the **meridian** lies, causes **leakage** and **blindness** (*máng*). The **orbital ridge** (*yǐngqióng*) is the **frame of the eye** (*mù yǐng*). The **bone’s inner meridian** refers to the **eye’s frame bone** (*yǐngqióng gǔ*), which is the **eye’s anchor** (*yǎnzhī xì*) and the **liver’s meridian** (*gānmài*). Piercing the **inner depression** severs the **eye’s anchor**, causing **eye leakage** and **blindness**.

**Piercing the inner depression** of the **joints** (*guānjié*), where **fluid leaks** (*yèchū*), causes **inability to flex or extend**. All **sinews** (*zhūjīn*) belong to the **joints**, and **fluid** nourishes them. When **fluid leaks**, the **sinew sheaths dry out**, hence **inability to flex or extend**.

#1 The original text reads: "为" (*wéi*) instead of "谓" (*wèi*).

「#2 *Sufu* [足土, *Zútǔ*]: Originally 『*Lìtǔ* [历土], corrected according to *Gu*’s text. *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwèn* Supplementary Commentary, Volume 31. Tang Dynasty *Tàipú Lìng* [太仆令] *Qǐ Xuānzǐ* [启玄子] **Wang Bīng** [王冰]’s successive annotations, Song Dynasty *Guànglù Qīng* [光禄卿] and *Zhí Bì Gé* [直秘阁] **Lín Yì** [林亿] et al.’s revised annotations, Song Dynasty *Shǒu Shàngshū* [守尚书] and *Lǜntián Làng* [屯田郎] **Sūn Zhào** [孙兆]’s corrections of errors.

**Chapter: *Zhì Lùn* [志论]**
**Huángdì** [黄帝] asked: *"I wish to hear the essentials of emptiness and fullness* (*xūshí*)."
**Qíbó** [岐伯] replied: *"When **qi** is full, the form is full; when **qi** is empty, the form is empty. This is their constant principle; deviating from this brings illness.* (*shēngbìng*)"
The *Yīnyáng Yìngxiàng Dà Lùn* [阴阳应象大论] states: *"The form returns to **qi**."* (*xíng guī qì*)
From this, emptiness and fullness align accordingly.
Deviation (*fǎn*) refers to **qi** and form not harmonizing, losing the balanced condition. When form and **qi** oppose each other, illness arises.
**Qi** refers to **pulse qi** (*màiqì*); form refers to bodily form (*shēnxíng*).

When the **sustenance** (*gǔ*) is full, **qi** is full; when the **sustenance** is empty, **qi** is empty. This is their constant principle; deviating from this brings illness.
The *Língshū Jīng* [灵枢经] states: *"The **nourishing qi** (*róngqì*) flows thus: when **sustenance** enters internally, it is full; **sustenance** enters the stomach, and **qi** is transmitted to the lungs. When **essence** (*jīng*) is concentrated, it ascends through the **meridian pathways** (*jīngtōng*)."*
From this, **sustenance** and **qi**’s emptiness and fullness are assessed together.
When signs (*zhèng*) do not align, illness arises.

**Newly revised annotations** state: *"According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* [甲乙经], ‘full’ (*shí*) should read ‘treasure’ (*bǎo*)."*
When **pulse** is full, blood is full; when **pulse** is empty, blood is empty. This is their constant principle; deviating from this brings illness.
The **pulse** is the **repository of blood** (*xuèfǔ*), and emptiness and fullness are assessed together.
When signs do not align, illness arises.

**Huángdì** [黄帝] said: *"How does deviation occur?"*
**Qíbó** [岐伯] said: *"When **qi** is empty yet the body is hot, this is deviation."* (*fǎn*)
Empty **qi** means **yang qi** (*yángqì*) is insufficient; when **yang qi** is insufficient, the body should be cold. If the body is hot instead, **pulse qi** should be full, but since **pulse qi** is not full while the body is hot, the signs do not correspond, hence deviation.

**Newly revised annotations** state: *"According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* [甲乙经], ‘When **qi** is full, the body is cold; when **qi** is empty, the body is hot, this is deviation.’ Four characters should be added here."* (*yìng bǔ cǐ sì zì*)

When **sustenance** enters excessively yet **qi** is scant, this is deviation. The **stomach**’s production is **sustenance qi** (*gǔqì*), which is distributed throughout the **meridians** (*jīngmài*). When **sustenance** enters the **stomach**, the **pulse pathways** (*màidào*) disperse accordingly. Now, if **sustenance** enters excessively yet **qi** is scant, it means **stomach qi** does not disperse, hence deviation.

When **sustenance** does not enter yet **qi** is abundant, this is deviation. **Stomach qi** disperses externally, and the **lungs** (*fèi*) absorb it.

When **pulse** is full yet blood is scant, this is deviation. When **pulse** is scant yet blood is full, this is deviation.
The **meridians** (*jīngmài*) conduct **qi**; the **collaterals** (*luòmài*) receive blood. When **meridian qi** enters the **collaterals**, and the **collaterals** receive **meridian qi**, signs do not align, hence all deviations from the norm.

When **qi** is full, the body is cold—this is from **cold injury** (*shānghán*).
When **qi** is empty, the body is hot—this is from **summer-heat injury** (*shāngshǔ*).
Injury (*shāng*) means exposure to pathogenic factors.

Cold injures the form (*xíng*), hence **qi** is full and the body is cold.
Heat injures **qi**, hence **qi** is empty and the body is hot.

When **sustenance** enters excessively yet **qi** is scant, this is from **blood loss** (*tuōxuè*) and **dampness residing below** (*shī jū xià*).
Blood loss leads to blood emptiness; blood emptiness causes **qi** to be internally stagnant, transforming into **fluids** (*jīnyè*), flowing into the **lower burner** (*xiàjiāo*), hence dampness resides below.

When **sustenance** enters scantly yet **qi** is abundant, the pathogen lies in the **stomach** and **lungs**.
The **stomach** lacks sufficient **qi**, and **lung qi** descends into the **stomach**.
Thus, though the pathogen is in the **stomach**, when **lung qi** enters the **stomach**, **lung qi** fails to self-regulate. If **qi** does not self-regulate, pathogenic **qi** follows it, hence the pathogen lies in the **stomach** and **lungs**.

When **pulse** is small yet blood is abundant, this is from **retained fluids with heat** (*yǐnzhōng rè*).
Retained fluids (*liúyǐn*) linger in the **spleen** and **stomach**, causing **spleen qi** to overflow, which then generates **internal heat** (*zhōngrè*).

When **pulse** is large yet blood is scant, this is from **wind in the pulse** and **fluids not entering**.
Abundant **wind qi** (*fēngqì*) blocks **fluids** from entering the **pulse**.
Fullness (*shí*) means **qi** enters; emptiness (*xū*) means **qi** exits.
Entry is **yang**; exit is **yīn**. **Yīn** arises internally, hence exits; **yang** arises externally, hence enters.
When **qi** is full, it is **heat**; when **qi** is empty, it is **cold**.
When **yang** is excessive and **yīn** internally resists, **heat** arises.
When **yīn** is excessive and **yang** externally weakens, **cold** arises.

When **qi** enters fully, the left hand opens the **needle space** (*zhēnkōng*) for draining.
When **qi** exits fully, the left hand closes the **needle space** for supplementing.
This refers to the **needling technique** (*bǔxiě*).

The right hand holds the needle; the left hand manipulates the orifice (*xuéyǔ*).
Thus, when fullness is present, the right hand opens the **needle space** swiftly to drain it.
When emptiness is present, the left hand opens the **needle space** to supplement it.

Manipulating (*niǎn*), pronounced *niè* [涅].

**Chapter: *Zhēnjiě* [针解]**
**Huángdì** [黄帝] asked: *"I wish to hear the explanation of the *Nine Needles* (*Jiǔzhēn*), the principles of emptiness and fullness."*
**Qíbó** [岐伯] replied: *"Needling emptiness to achieve fullness: the needle tip feels hot, for **qi** is full and thus generates heat. Draining fullness: the needle tip feels cold, for **qi** is empty and thus generates cold.*

*Searching out and removing stagnant accumulations: this is expelling **noxious blood** (*èxuè*).*
Search (*sōu*) means **accumulation**; stagnant (*chén*) means **long-standing**; removal (*chú*) means **elimination**. This refers to **collateral meridians** where blood accumulates and becomes long-standing; needling expels and removes it.

*When pathogenic factors are excessive, needling emptiness: withdraw the needle without pressing.*
Pathogenic (*xié*) means **unorthodox** (*bùzhèng*) factors, not the **inherent qi** of the **meridian**; thus, this refers to pathogenic **qi**, not spirits, poisons, or **essence** (*jīng*) overcoming **true qi** (*zhēnqì*).

Withdrawing the needle without pressing causes the orifice to remain open, hence **meridian emptiness** is achieved, and pathogenic **qi** is expelled.

*Slow entry, swift pressing brings fullness; swift entry, slow pressing brings emptiness.*
Slow entry (*xú chū*) means the needle is withdrawn after **meridian qi** has been engaged for some time; swift pressing (*jí àn*) means pressing the orifice swiftly after the needle is withdrawn.
Thus, **true qi** does not disperse, and **meridian qi** remains intact, hence slow entry with swift pressing achieves fullness.

Swift entry (*jí chū*) means the needle is inserted into the orifice and immediately withdrawn upon reaching the **meridian**. Slow pressing (*xú àn*) means pressing the orifice gently after the needle is withdrawn, allowing pathogenic **qi** to disperse and **true qi** to recover, hence swift entry with slow pressing achieves emptiness.»

「The terms *fullness* and *emptiness* refer to the excess or deficiency of cold and warm **qi**.

Cold and warm **qi** refer to the yin and yang **qi** of the **meridians**.

*If present or absent* means that the condition cannot be immediately discerned—
its nature is obscure, and thus cannot be known upon direct examination.
When it cannot be known immediately, it is as if absent.
When one intuitively perceives it with divine insight, it is as if present.

*Detecting whether the disease is earlier or later* means understanding the sequence of the illness—
knowing whether it is earlier or later allows one to apply needling and moxibustion (*bǔ xiě*) appropriately.

To determine *fullness* or *emptiness* is for the practitioner not to stray from proper technique.
*The Needle Classic* states: *“When **meridian qi** has arrived, carefully guard it lest it be lost.”*
This is what is meant.

○The newly revised annotation reads: *“According to the *Jia-Yi Classic*, if present or if lost, it is *fullness* or *emptiness*.
If obtained or lost, it is deviation from proper technique.
Arbitrarily applying needling and moxibustion disrupts the major **meridians**, causing error:
If one mistakenly needles *fullness*, it will instead cause the condition to appear as if *obtained*;
If one mistakenly moxibustions *emptiness*, it will instead cause the condition to appear as if *lost*.
Hence, it is said: *‘If obtained or lost.’*
*The Needle Classic* states: *“There is no *fullness* without *emptiness*, no *emptiness* without *fullness*.”
This is its warning.

○The newly revised annotation reads: *“In detail, from the beginning of this section to here, the explanations differ yet complement those of the *Tai Su* chapter on the Nine Needles. These two classics illuminate each other.

The essence of *fullness* and *emptiness* lies in the Nine Needles, which are most ingenious—
each has its own fitting application.
For heat in the head and body, the *cai* needle is appropriate.
For **meridian qi** abundant in the flesh, the *yuan* needle is appropriate.
For **meridian qi** that is deficient and weak, the *ti* needle is appropriate.
For moxibustion to dispel heat and induce bleeding, or to expel pathogenic **qi** and stabilize the disease, the *feng* needle is appropriate.
For breaking numbness and swelling, or to induce pus and bleeding, the *zhu* needle is appropriate.
For regulating yin and yang, or to remove sudden **bi** syndrome, the *yuan-li* needle is appropriate.
For treating pain and **bi** syndrome within the **meridians** and **collaterals**, the *hao* needle is appropriate.
For **bi** syndrome deep-seated between bones, joints, or the lumbar and sacral regions, the *chang* needle is appropriate.
For **empty-wind** syndrome converging between bones, joints, or the skin, the *da* needle is appropriate.
This is what is meant by *‘each has its own fitting application.’*»

○The newly revised annotation reads: *“In another version, *zhu* is written as *pi* instead.”*

**Translation:**

**Tí**, pronounced *Shì*. The time for **supplementing** and **draining** must align with the **qi**’s opening and closing.

When the **qi** is present at the moment, it is called **opening**; when it has passed or not yet arrived, it is called **closing**. The **moment** refers to:
- One *kè* after the water clock’s float descends, the **qi** resides in **Taiyang**;
- Two *kè*, the **qi** resides in **Shaoyang**;
- Three *kè*, the **qi** resides in **Yangming**;
- Four *kè*, the **qi** resides in the **yin divisions**.

The water clock’s descent never ceases, nor does the **qi**’s movement. Thus, when the **qi** is present at the exact moment, it is **opening**; when it has passed or not yet arrived, it is **closing**.

The *Needle Classic* states:
*"Observe the **qi**’s location and strike accordingly—this is called **encountering the right time**."*
This is what is meant by **supplementing and draining at the proper time**.

○The newly revised annotation reads: *"From the beginning of this passage to here, the text originates from the *Lingshu Jing*, with the *Suwen* elaborating upon it, mutually illuminating each other."*

The *Jia-Yi Jing* states:
*"Supplementing and draining at the proper time is done with the needle."*
Here, the phrase *"with the needle"* is omitted.

The names of the **Nine Needles** differ in form because each needle targets what must be **supplemented or drained**. Their forms vary—long, short, sharp, or blunt—while their purpose is to **adapt to the treatment required**.

○The newly revised annotation reads: *"The shapes of the Nine Needles are now fully detailed in the *Jia-Yi Jing*."*

When **draining excess**, wait until the **yin qi** surges before removing the needle.
When **supplementing deficiency**, wait until the **yang qi** surges and warmth appears beneath the needle before removing it.
This emphasizes that **effectiveness depends on the arrival of the qi**.

Once the **meridian qi** has arrived, guard it carefully without alteration.

The **variation** refers to **alteration**, while **change** refers to **revision**—both are methods of **adapting technique**. It states that once the **qi** has arrived, one must **guard it carefully**, without altering the method, lest harm be invited.

**Depth and shallowness depend on intent**—this discerns the **internal and external nature of the disease**. **Intent** is also **will**; both **will and intent** govern the use of the needle.

**Near and far as one**—this means **depth and shallowness** are measured equally. It states that though the **qi** may differ in proximity, its **diagnosis** relies on its arrival and effectiveness.

**Like standing at the edge of a deep abyss**—one must not dare to falter. This means that **diagnosing and treating** excess or deficiency must be done with the caution of standing at the edge of a deep abyss, lest one lose the proper method of **supplementation or drainage**.

**The hand must grip like holding a tiger**—this seeks **strength**. **Strength** means holding the needle **firmly and resolutely**. The *Needle Classic* states: *"The method of holding the needle is that firmness constitutes **realness**."* This is its meaning.
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"In the Jia-Yi Jing, the character **real** is written as **precious**."*

**The spirit must not be distracted by trivial matters**—this means maintaining a **calm intent** while observing the patient, without glancing left or right. **Eyes must not wander**, and the **mind must focus solely** on the task, so that the needle’s use remains **unerring and without confusion**.
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"This passage, from ‘When draining excess,’ is detailed in the *Bao Ming Quan Xing Lun*, and this is another elucidation, mutually clarifying the meaning."*

**There must be no crookedness below**—this seeks **uprightness and correctness**. **Correctness** refers to **straight insertion**, with the needle neither deviating left nor right. **One must align the spirit properly**—this means gazing at the patient’s eyes to **command their spirit**, so that the **qi flows more easily**. **Examining their spirit**, ensuring it does not scatter, then the **qi follows the spirit’s command**, and **internal and external balance is easily achieved**.

As for the **Sanli (Three Miles)**, it is **three inches below the knee**. As for **holding the knee**—
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"According to Quan Yuanqi’s text, it is written as **lowering the abdomen**.* The *Tai Su* writes **entrusting it**. According to the *Gu Kong Lun*, **holding** is likely a miswriting of **instructing above**."* **Lifting the knee** makes the division clear. **Sanli** is the name of an acupoint, located **three inches below the knee**, between the two muscles outside the **abdomen**. Pressing firmly there will cause the **upper pulse of the foot** to stop, hence it is said: *"Lifting the knee makes the division clear."*

**Ju Xu (Giant Emptiness)** refers to the **abdomen’s sole depression**. **Ju Xu** is the name of an acupoint. **Treading** means **lifting**. To take **Ju Xu below Kang**, one must **lift the foot** to find the **depression between the two muscles outside the abdomen**.

**Xia Lian (Lower Slope)** refers to **what sinks downward**. To know the **Xia Kang** acupoint, it is the **sole depression between the two muscles outside the abdomen**.

The Emperor said: *"I have heard of the Nine Needles, which correspond above to the Heaven, Earth, four seasons, and yin-yang. I wish to hear their methods, so that they may be transmitted to future generations as a constant practice."*

Gibi said: *"Heaven, Earth, humanity, the four seasons, the five tones, the six pitches, the seven stars, the eight winds, and the nine wilds—all correspond to the body’s form. Each needle has its proper use, hence the **Nine Needles**."*

○The newly revised annotation reads: *"This passage varies slightly from the *Ling Shu Jing*."*

**Human skin corresponds to Heaven**—it **covers and protects**, the symbol of Heaven.
**Human flesh corresponds to Earth**—it is **soft, thick, and tranquil**, the symbol of Earth.
**Human vessels correspond to humanity**—their **flourishing and decline** mirror humanity’s symbol.
**Human sinews correspond to the seasons**—they are **firm and steadfast**, the symbol of the seasons.
**Human voice corresponds to the five tones**—they encompass all five tones.
**Human yin-yang merging in qi corresponds to the six pitches**—when **qi converges and flows without interruption**, it mirrors the pitches.
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"In another text, **qi** is written as **degree**."*

**Human teeth, face, and eyes correspond to the seven stars**—this refers to the **seven orifices of the face**.
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"This note is the words of Quan Yuanqi."*

**Human inhaling and exhaling correspond to the winds**—movement in and out mirrors the winds.
**The nine orifices and three hundred sixty-five collaterals correspond to the wilds**—what lies beyond the body’s form mirrors the wilds.

Thus:
- The **first needle** pierces the **skin**,
- The **second** pierces the **flesh**,
- The **third** pierces the **vessels**,
- The **fourth** pierces the **sinews**,
- The **fifth** pierces the **bones**,
- The **sixth** **harmonizes yin and yang**,
- The **seventh** **nourishes the essence**,
- The **eighth** **expels the wind**,
- The **ninth** **opens the nine orifices** and **removes the three hundred sixty-five nodes of the seasons**.
This is what is meant by **each having its master**.

The names of the **Nine Needles** are:
1. **Yin needle**,
2. **Yuan needle**,
3. **Chuan needle**,
4. **Feng needle**,
5. **Mei needle**,
6. **Yuanli needle**,
7. **Hao needle**,
8. **Long needle**,
9. **Da needle**.
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"In another text, **first** is written as **bì**."*

**Human heart and intent correspond to the eight winds**—movement and stillness are formless, the symbol of the winds.
**Human qi corresponds to Heaven**—it **flows endlessly**, the symbol of Heaven.
**Human hair, teeth, ears, eyes, and five sounds correspond to the five tones and six pitches**—hair and teeth grow, ears and eyes are clear, and the five sounds align, hence their correspondence to the five tones and six pitches.
**Human yin-yang vessels and blood-qi correspond to Earth**—yin and yang **interact**, generating vessels and blood, and **qi has fluctuations of excess and deficiency**, hence their correspondence to Earth.
**Human liver and eyes correspond to the nine**—liver **qi nourishes the eyes**, and wood generates the number three; three times three equals nine, hence the correspondence.

**The nine orifices and three hundred sixty-five**—
○The newly revised annotation reads: *"Quan Yuanqi’s text omits these seven characters."*

**One observes movement and stillness** to correspond to **Heaven’s two**,
**Two diagnose the five colors** to correspond to the **seven stars**,
**Three observe the hair’s luster** to correspond to the **five tones**,
**One diagnoses the pitches**—whether **excess or deficiency**—to correspond to the **six pitches**,
**Two correspond to Earth** to diagnose **high and low**—whether **excess or deficiency**—to correspond to the **nine wilds**,
**One node and **Yu** correspond** to diagnose **closed nodes**,
**Three correspond to humanity** to diagnose **tooth decay**—whether **much blood or little**—to correspond to the **ten divisions of angle**,
**Five correspond** to diagnose **slackness and urgency**—whether **deficient or excessive**—to correspond to the **six divisions**,
**Three correspond to the **cold node**—the **ninth division**,
**Four correspond to the seasons**—whether **cold, warm, dry, or humid**—to correspond to the **four seasons**,
**One corresponds to the opposite**—each of the **four directions** is explained separately.

This section of **124 characters** is **corrupted and decayed text**, with **fragmented logic**, making it difficult to discern its meaning. Yet, the ancient works still preserve it as a **foundation for later study**.

The *Long Ci Jie Lun* (Treatise on Long Needling Theory) states:
*"The Needling School does not diagnose; it listens to the patient’s words.*
If the **head** suffers **pain**, it is **needled deeply**—*‘deep’* meaning **deep needling**.
Thus, the following text says:
**Needling until the bone**—the illness is cured.
Above, **no harm comes to the bones, flesh, or skin**—*‘skin’* refers to the **Dao/Way of needling**.
The **Dao/Way of needling** is such that **deep needling of the bone** does not harm the bones, flesh, or skin.
**Yin needling**, entering **one side and four places**, treats **cold and heat**.
If the **head** has **cold or heat**, then **Yin needling** is used to treat it.
**Yin needling** refers to **sudden needling** in such quantities.
*[Note: Another version reads ‘**Yin needling**’ as ‘**level needling**’].
According to the *Jia Yi Jing* (The Canon of Needling A and B): **Yang needling** is **needling directly inward, one side and four places**. **Yin needling** is **needling left and right suddenly**. This **Yin needling** may likely be **Yang needling**.

**Deep and focused needling**—for treating **major cold and heat**—attacks the **central organs**.
**Pressing needling near the organs**, the **back nodes** are needled.
*‘Pressing’* means **gradually approaching**.
Needling **near the organs**, the **organs converge**.
Why needling near the organs? Because **the organ’s qi converges there**.
If **cold or heat** in the **abdomen is expelled**, then **stop needling**.
The **essence of needling** is to **withdraw the needle shallowly** and **let blood flow**.
If needling at **all the nodes**, it is done thus.

For treating **decay and abscesses**, needle **above the decay**.
Observe the **size and depth** of the **abscess**—if small, needle shallowly; if large, needle deeply.
*For large abscesses*, **more blood is drawn**; for small ones, **needle directly**—*this is the proper method*.
*[Note: Another version states: For large abscesses, **needle deeply and multiply**; for small ones, **use a bell-shaped needle**—this is the proper method].
If the **illness is in the lower abdomen**, with **accumulations**, needle **below the skin and marrow**, stopping **at the lower abdomen**.
Needle **along the sides of the spine**, **four vertebrae apart**, and **needle the two sides of the hip joint and flank ribs**.
**Guide the heat in the abdomen downward** until it is expelled.

*‘Lower abdomen accumulations’* refers to **cold and heat qi stagnating**.
*‘Skin and marrow’*—*[Note: The original text reads ‘**皮髓**’, but this may be an error. The *Jia Yi Jing* and other versions read ‘**皮骷**’ (skin and bone ends), meaning **needling horizontally at the lower edge of the ribcage**].
Examine the needling **without over-penetrating**.

The *Ci Jin Lun* (Treatise on Needling Prohibitions) states:
*"Needling the lower abdomen causes **urinary bladder dysfunction**, making the patient’s **lower abdomen full**. Thus, needling must not be deep."*

*‘Four vertebrae apart along the sides of the spine’*—*[Note: The original text lacks a node, likely referring to ‘**five vertebrae apart**’ (the **Shen** node below the fifth lumbar vertebra), which corresponds to the **heart** in the lower abdomen, hence the mention of needling there]*.
*‘Hip joint’*—*[Note: The character **骼** (*guǐ*) is likely a miswriting for **髁** (*kē*), a similar-sounding term for the **iliac crest**].
*‘Flank ribs’*—likely refers to **needling near the **Jìngmén** node (the **12th rib space**)**.

*[Note: ‘**皮骼**’ (*pí guǐ*) is likely a miswriting for ‘**皮骷**’ (*pí kē*), meaning **the ends of the ribs**. The *Jia Yi Jing* and other sources read ‘**皮骷**’ (*pí kē*), where **骷** (*kē*) means **bone ends**. **皮骷** refers to **needling horizontally at the rib ends**. The original text reads ‘**皮髓**’, but the annotation suggests **‘**齐傍缍起**’** (level beside the **12th rib space**), which is also unclear.]*

If the **illness is in the lower abdomen**, with **abdominal pain preventing urination or defecation**, it is called **hernia** (*shàn*).
Caused by **cold**, needle **both sides of the lower abdomen** and **between the hip joints**.
Needle **abundantly**, until the **Guìyin pulse** is cured.
The **Guìyin pulse** encircles the **external genitalia** and reaches the **lower abdomen**.
The **Chōng pulse** and the **minor Yin pulse’s collateral** both originate below the **kidneys**, exit at **Qìjiē**, and follow the **inner thigh**.
Later, they descend from the **lower abdomen** to the **central bone**—in women, entering the **system of the womb** (*xì tíng kǒng*).
Their collaterals follow the **external genitalia**, converging at **Zhuàn** (*zhuàn* node), circling behind it, then branching to the **lateral lower abdomen** and **minor Yin pulse’s collateral**, merging with the **major Yang pulse’s collateral** at **Shào Yīn’s upper inner thigh** and **Kāng** (*kāng* node).
They **pierce the spine** and belong to the **kidneys**.
In men, they follow the **penis** downward to **Zhuàn**, equal to women’s path.
Thus, **needling the lower abdomen and both sides of the inner thigh** is also done, as well as **needling between the hip joints**.

*‘Hip joint bone’*—the **iliac crest**, where the **spine’s sides** are **level and sunken**.
Since **hernia** is caused by **cold**, it is needled **abundantly** until the **heat in the lower abdomen is expelled**.

*[Note: Another version reads **‘**篡**’ (*zhuàn*) as **‘**基**’ (*jī*), with the initial illness reversed.]*

If the **illness is in the tendons**, with **tendon contraction and joint pain**, making movement impossible—this is called **tendon Bi** (*jīn bì*).
Needling **above the tendons** is the **proper method**.
Needle **between the muscle divisions**, avoiding the **bone**.
*‘Division’* refers to **where tendons and muscle collaterals intersect**.
Needling **tendons** must not harm the **bone**, hence **avoiding the bone**.
If the **illness originates in the tendons**, needle until the **Guìyin pulse** is cured.
Since **tendon Bi** arises from **tendon stagnation**, needling is stopped when the **tendon heat is expelled**.

If the **illness is in the muscles and skin**, with **pain throughout the muscles and skin**—this is called **muscle Bi** (*jī bì*).
Caused by **cold and dampness**, needle **major and minor divisions**—**withdraw the needle deeply** and **let blood flow abundantly**, using **heat as the proper method**.
*‘Major division’* refers to **the larger muscle divisions**.

---

*‘Minor division’* refers to **the smaller muscle divisions**.
**Do not harm tendons and bone**—if tendons and bone are harmed, **paralysis or transformation** will occur.
*The Needle Classic* states:
*"If the illness is shallow but the needle is deep, it injures the good flesh, and the skin becomes paralyzed."*
Again it says:
*"If the needle is too deep, the pathogenic *qi* will sink deeper, and the illness will worsen."*
Harming tendons and bone means the needle is too deep, hence **paralysis or transformation** occurs.
When **all divisions are heated**, the illness ceases.
**Heat can disperse cold**, thus the illness ceases when cured.

If the illness is in the **bone**, with **heaviness in the bone** so that it cannot be lifted, and **acidic pain in the marrow**, when **cold *qi* arrives**, it is called **bone Bi** (*gǔ bì*).
For deep cases, needle deeply, **without harming the vessels and flesh**—this is the method.
Its principle is to needle **major and minor divisions**; when the **bone is heated**, the illness ceases.
Why must one needle **bone Bi without harming vessels and flesh**?
It is to **self-regulate the *qi*** and **unblock the large and small divisions of the flesh**.

If the illness is in the **all-yang vessels**, with **alternating cold and heat**, and **all divisions alternating cold and heat**, it is called **madness** (*kuáng*).
This is **disordered *qi***.
Needle the **empty vessels**, and when **all divisions are heated**, the illness ceases.

When the illness first appears, it flares **once a year**; if untreated, it flares **once a month**; if still untreated, it flares **four or five times a month**, and it is called **epilepsy** (*diān bìng*).
Needle **all divisions and vessels**; for those without cold, **adjust with the needle**, and the illness ceases.

The newly corrected text states:
According to *The Canon of A and B*:
*"Needle all divisions; if the vessels are especially cold, supplement with the needle."*

If the illness is **wind with alternating cold and heat**, and **profuse sweating**, occurring **multiple times a day**, first needle **all divisions, networks, and vessels**.
When sweating occurs with **alternating cold and heat**, needle **once every three days**; in **one hundred days**, it will be cured.

If the illness is **great wind**, with **heaviness in the joints**, and **falling of beard and eyebrows**, it is called **great wind** (*dà fēng*).
Needle the **muscles and flesh**—this is the method.
Sweat will emerge over **one hundred days**, **dispersing the rebellious heat of the defensive *qi*** (*wèi*).
Needle the **bone marrow**; sweat will emerge over **one hundred days**, **dispersing the rebellious heat of the nourishing *qi*** (*róng*).
In total, **two hundred days**, and the **beard and eyebrows will regrow** before stopping the needle.
When **rebellious heat is dispelled**, **yin *qi* internally recovers**, hence **profuse sweating** and **regrowth of beard and eyebrows**.

**Volume Thirty-Two of the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Classic, Plain Questions*
*Commentary by Wang Bing, Revised by Sun Zhao and Others*
**Treatise on the Skin Division**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"I have heard that the skin has divisions, the vessels have their pathways, the sinews have their networks, and the bones have their measures. The diseases they generate differ, and their locations—left, right, above, below—correspond to yin and yang. I wish to hear the Way of this."*

Qibo replied:
*"To know this—*
*The skin’s divisions follow the pathways of the channels. This applies to all channels.*

*Trace the channels’ pathways and their governing regions, and the skin’s divisions will be known.*

*By ‘channels,’ I mean the twelve channels.*

*All twelve channels follow the same principle.*

*The yang of the Yang Brightness channel is called **Hàibèi**—
*‘Bèi’ means transformation and generation. ‘Hài’ is the killing *qi*. When the killing *qi* moves, transformation and generation flourish, hence **Hàibèi** (pronounced *fúfèi*).*

*Above and below follow the same principle. If you see floating networks within its region, they are all the networks of the Yang Brightness channel.*

*If the color is predominantly green, there is pain; if black, numbness; if yellow or red, heat; if white, cold. If all five colors appear, there is both cold and heat.*

*When the networks are盛 (*shèng*), they invade the channels as guests. Yang governs the exterior, yin the interior—*
*Here, ‘yang’ refers to yang networks, ‘yin’ to yin networks. This is a general statement.*

*All channels and networks seen on the hands, feet, and body follow this.*

*The yang of the Minor Yang channel is called **Shūchí**—
*‘Shū’ means pivotal; ‘chí’ means to hold.*

*Above and below follow the same principle. If you see floating networks within its region, they are all the networks of the Minor Yang channel.*

*When the networks are盛 (*shèng*), they invade the channels as guests. Thus, those in yang regions govern the interior, while those in yin regions govern the exterior, permeating inward. This applies to all channels.*

*The yang of the Major Yang channel is called **Guāngū**—
*‘Guān’ governs external movement, emphasizing stillness and stability, like the pivot of a door, ensuring *qi* harmony.*

*Above and below follow the same principle. If you see floating networks within its region, they are all the networks of the Major Yang channel. When the networks are盛 (*shèng*), they invade the channels as guests.*

*The yin of the Minor Yin channel is called **Shūrú**—
*‘Rú’ means compliance. It guards the pivotal points and follows the opening and closing of yin and yang.*
*[New annotation: In the *Jia-Yi Jing*, ‘rú’ is written as ‘rú’ (濡).]*

*Above and below follow the same principle. If you see floating networks within its region, they are all the networks of the Minor Yin channel. When the networks are盛 (*shèng*), they invade the channels as guests. When they invade the channels, they descend from the yang regions into the channels, and when they exit, they flow from the yin interior into the bones.*

*The yin of the Heart Conductor channel is called **Hàijiān**—
*The Heart Conductor’s *qi* enters beneath the armpit; if unharmonized, it obstructs the movement of the shoulder and armpit.*

*Above and below follow the same principle. If you see floating networks within its region, they are all the networks of the Heart Conductor channel. When the networks are盛 (*shèng*), they invade the channels as guests.*

*The yin of the Major Yin channel is called **Guānzhé**—
*‘Guān’ means to close; ‘zhé’ (蛰) means to hibernate, ensuring proper storage and retrieval.*
*[New annotation: In the *Jia-Yi Jing*, ‘zhé’ is written as ‘zhí’ (执).]*

*Above and below follow the same principle. If you see floating networks within its region, they are all the networks of the Major Yin channel. When the networks are盛 (*shèng*), they invade the channels as guests.*

*‘Division’ refers to the regions governed by each channel’s networks. ‘Floating’ means visibly apparent.*

*In total, the twelve channel networks are the divisions of the skin. They are arranged by yin and yang, with each division governing the skin, hence ‘the skin’s divisions.’*

*Therefore, when a hundred diseases first arise, they must first manifest in the skin and hair. When evil invades, the natural order of the skin is disrupted, and the disruption opens the way for the evil to enter the networks. If it lingers without leaving, it transmits into the channels. If it lingers without leaving, it transmits into the reservoirs. If it accumulates in the intestines and stomach,*
*‘Lǐn’ means accumulation.*

*When evil first enters the skin, there is a sudden chill, and the hairs stand on end. The natural order is disrupted;*
*‘Yìrán’ means aversion to cold. ‘Qǐ’ means the hairs rise erect. ‘Shènglǐ’ refers to the skin’s pores and texture.*

*When it enters the networks, the networks become full, and their color changes;*
*‘Shèng’ means fullness. ‘Biàn’ means deviation from the norm.*

*When it invades the channels as a guest, the channels, being empty, sink downward;*
*When the channels are empty and *qi* is deficient, they sink.*

*When it lingers between the sinews and bones, excessive cold causes sinew contraction and bone pain, while excessive heat causes sinew laxity and bone wasting, flesh erosion, and skin ulceration. The hair stands erect and decays.*
*‘Luán’ means contraction. ‘Chí’ means laxity. ‘Xiāo’ means erosion. The *Zhēn Jing* states: ‘Cold causes sinews to contract, heat causes them to relax. Excessive cold leads to pain, excessive heat to *qi* dissipation.’*
*‘Yàn’ is the flesh’s surface marker; thus, when flesh wastes, the surface breaks, and the hair stands erect and decays.*
*‘Yàn’ (胭) pronounced *qúdùn*.*

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"Master, you spoke of the twelve divisions of the skin. How do their diseases manifest?"*

Qibo replied:
*"The skin is the division of the channels. The *qi* of the channels flows through, each with its yin and yang, governing regions as it passes. Hence, it is called the ‘division of the channels.’*

*When evil invades the skin, the natural order is disrupted, and the disruption opens the way for the evil to enter the networks. When the networks are full, they flow into the channels. When the channels are full, the evil lodges in the reservoirs.*

*Thus, the skin has divisions. If not treated, great diseases arise.*

*The channels traverse the skin, each with its own divisions. When they receive evil *qi*, diseases follow accordingly—not because the skin’s *qi* alone can generate them.*
*[New annotation: In the *Jia-Yi Jing*, ‘bùyǔ’ is written as ‘bùqù’ (不愈).]"*

---

**Quan Yuanqi’s** version reads *bùyǔ*. Quan Yuanqi explains: *"This means that if the channels and collaterals fail to harmonize, the vital *qi* is injured from without, and evil *qi* flows inward, thus giving rise to great diseases."*

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

---
**Chapter on the Collaterals**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"When the collaterals are visible, their five colors differ—blue, yellow, red, white, and black—each distinct. What is the reason for this?"*

Qibo replied:
*"The channels have constant colors, but the collaterals do not. The channels circulate *qi*, so their colors consistently manifest in accordance with the seasons. The collaterals govern blood, so when they receive evil *qi*, their colors vary and are not uniform."*

The Emperor asked: *"What are the constant colors of the channels?"*

Qibo replied:
*"The heart is red, the lungs white, the liver green, the spleen yellow, and the kidneys black—each corresponding to the color of its respective channel."*

The Emperor asked: *"Do the yin and yang collaterals also correspond to their channels?"*

Qibo replied:
*"The colors of the yin collaterals correspond to their channels, but the colors of the yang collaterals vary without constancy, shifting with the four seasons. In accordance with the transformations of the seasonal *qi*—when cold prevails, they congeal and weep, turning blue-black; when heat prevails, they become moist and lustrous, turning yellow-red. These are the constant colors, indicating no disease. When all five colors appear together, it signifies cold and heat. *Chún* means dampness; *zé* means moist luster—referring to slight dampness and moisture."*

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

**Chapter on the *Qi* Points**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"I have heard that there are 365 *qi* points corresponding to the year. I do not know their locations and wish to hear them fully."*

Qibo bowed twice in response:
*"Your question is profound! If not for a sage like Your Majesty, who could exhaust this Dao? I will now speak at length to fulfill Your intent."*

The Emperor, clasping his hands, stepped back in deference:
*"Your teachings have illuminated my mind—though my eyes have not seen these points nor my ears heard their number, now my understanding is clear, and my perception is sharp."*

Qibo said:
*"This is what is meant by ‘the sage’s words are easy to grasp, like guiding a fine steed.’"*

The Emperor said:
*"I am not one who grasps the sage’s words easily. The world speaks of the *True Numbers* as opening the mind, but what I seek now are the *True Numbers* that dispel ignorance and resolve confusion—though this is still insufficient to fathom the profound and subtle. Nevertheless, I wish to hear Your full account of these points, so that I may understand their meaning. I will store them in the *Golden Case* and not reveal them further."*

*"The points"* refers to the locations of the acupoints.

Qibo bowed twice and rose:
*"Let me speak. When the back and heart press against each other in pain, the treatment involves *Tiantong* [天突], the ten vertebrae, and *Shangji* [上纪]#3.

*Tiantong* is located below the laryngeal prominence, four *cùn* (same-body inches) from the center of the neck’s anterior midline, where the *Ren* [任] channel converges. Needling should be done obliquely downward, penetrating one *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* (cones) may be used.

According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* and *The Illustrated Classic of Channel Flow and Acupoints*, there are no acupoints below the tenth vertebra on the spine—likely referring to the seventh vertebra, governed by the *Du* [督] channel’s *qi*.

The location of *Shangji* follows below.

*Shangji* is the *stomach’s* *mu* [募] point, located one *cùn* below the *upper* *yuan* [院], at the midpoint between the *xiphoid process* and the umbilicus. It is where the *Hand Taiyang*, *Hand Shaoyang*, and *Foot Yangming* channels originate, and where the *Ren* channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate one *cùn* and two *fèn* (finger-widths), or seven *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*: *"This is where the *Ren* channel converges."*

*Bì* [蔽] is pronounced *bì* (必寐切).

*Xiàji* [下纪] is *Guanyuan* [关元]. *Guanyuan* is the *mu* point of the small intestine, located three *cùn* below the umbilicus, where the three *yin* channels of the foot and the *Ren* channel converge. Needling may penetrate two *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths, or seven *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

When evil *qi* strikes the back, chest, yin, or yang—left or right—such diseases manifest as anterior and posterior pain, stiffness, chest and flank pain with dyspnea, inability to lie down, shortness of breath, and one-sided chest pain.

According to another text, *pìan* [偏] is also written as *mǎn* [满].

When the pulse is full and rises obliquely, emerging as a *shī* [尸] pulse, the collateral branches spread across the chest and flank, piercing the heart and passing through the *ge* [鬲], ascending to *Tiantong*, descending obliquely to the shoulder, and intersecting below the tenth vertebra#5.

Tracing this collateral’s flow and its pathological manifestations reveals that the *Du* channel’s collateral branches emerge from the coccyx, ascending and obliquely networking the flank, piercing the heart, passing through the *ge*, ascending to *Tiantong*, descending obliquely to the shoulder, and intersecting below the tenth vertebra#5.

According to the annotation: *"From ‘When the back and heart press against each other in pain’ onward, this appears to be a fragment from the *Bone Cavities* chapter, mistakenly inserted here."*

**The Fifty *Zàng* and *Shù* Points**

*"Zàng"* refers to the five *zàng* organs—liver, heart, spleen, lungs, and kidneys—not including the four *fǔ* [府] organs. *"Shù"* refers to the *jing-well*, *ying-spring*, *shù-stream*, *jing-river*, and *hé-sea* points—not the *back-shù* points.

However, the *jing-well*, *ying-spring*, *shù-stream*, *jing-river*, and *hé-sea* points are as follows:
- The *jing-well* of the liver is *Dàdūn* [大敦], located at the tip of the big toe, at the corner of the nail, between the three hairs. This is where the *Foot Jueyin* channel originates. Needling may penetrate three *fèn*, with retention for ten breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.
- The *ying-spring* is *Xíngwèn* [行间], located in the webbing between the big toe’s second phalanx where the pulse responds to pressure. This is where the *Foot Jueyin* channel flows.

According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*: *"Strike"* is written as *"flow,"* and *"remaining"* is written as *"retain."*

The *shù-stream* is *Tàichōng* [太冲], located at the back of the big toe’s root, two *cùn* (same-body inches) inward from the joint, in the depression where the pulse responds to pressure. According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* annotation on *"Needling for Lumbar Pain"*:
*"The joint’s inner side, two cùn inward from the joint, in the depression where the pulse responds to pressure."* This is where the *Foot Jueyin* channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn*, with retention for ten breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

The *jing-river* is *Zhōngfēng* [中封], located one and a half *cùn* (same-body inches) forward of the inner ankle, in the depression where the pulse responds to pressure. According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*, this is measured as one *cùn*. The point is taken by raising the foot, and it is best found when the foot is extended. This is where the *Foot Jueyin* channel flows. Needling may penetrate four *fèn*, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

The *hé-sea* is *Qūquán* [曲泉], located below the medial condyle of the femur, above the large tendon and below the small tendon, in the depression where the pulse responds to pressure. It is found when the knee is flexed. This is where the *Foot Jueyin* channel enters. Needling may penetrate six *fèn*, with retention for ten breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

For the *Heart Protector* channel:
- The *jing-well* is *Zhōngchōng* [中冲];
- The *ying-spring* is *Láoguān* [劳宫];
- The *shù-stream* is *Tàilíng* [太陵];
- The *jing-river* is *Wènshǐ* [问使];
- The *hé-sea* is *Qūzé* [曲泽].

**Zhōngchōng** is located at the tip of the middle finger, at the depression near the corner of the nail like the hollow of a chive leaf, where the *Heart Protector* channel’s pulse emerges. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths, or one *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Láoguān** is located at the center of the palm over the moving pulse, where the *Heart Protector* channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Tàilíng** is located in the depression between the two tendons behind the wrist, where the *Heart Protector* channel converges. Needling may penetrate six *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Wènshǐ** is located three *cùn* (same-body inches) above the wrist in the depression between the two tendons, where the *Heart Protector* channel flows. Needling may penetrate six *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or seven *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.
*[Correction note: The *Jia-Yi Jing* states three *zhàng* of moxibustion.]*

**Qūzé** is located below the inner elbow crease in the depression, found when the elbow is flexed, where the *Heart Protector* channel enters. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

For the *Spleen* channel:
- The *jing-well* is **Yǐnbái** [隐白];
- The *ying-spring* is **Dàdū** [大都].

For the **Spleen** channel:
- The *shu-stream* is **Tàibái** [太白];
- The *jing-river* is **Shāngqiū** [商丘];
- The *he-sea* is **Yīnlíngquán** [阴陵泉].

**Yǐnbái** is located on the inner side of the big toe, at the end of the foot, a distance from the toenail corner like a scallion leaf. It is where the **Foot Taiyin (Spleen)** channel emerges. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Dàdū** [大都] is located behind the root joint of the big toe in the depression. It is where the **Foot Taiyin (Spleen)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Tàibái** [太白] is located below the medial malleolus on the inner side of the foot in the depression, where the **Foot Taiyin (Spleen)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Shāngqiū** [商丘] is located below the inner ankle, slightly anterior in the depression, where the **Foot Taiyin (Spleen)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

**Yīnlíngquán** [阴陵泉] is located below the medial condyle of the tibia on the inner side of the knee in the depression, found when the leg is extended. It is where the **Foot Taiyin (Spleen)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths, or three *zhàng* of moxibustion may be applied.

For the **Lung** channel:
- The *jing-well* is **Shǎo-Shāng** [少商];
- The *ying-spring* is **Yújì** [鱼际];
- The *shu-stream* is **Tàiyuān** [太渊];
- The *jing-river* is **Jīngqú** [经渠];
- The *he-sea* is **Chǐzé** [尺泽].

**Shǎo-Shāng** [少商] is located at the inner side of the tip of the thumb, at a distance from the corner of the nail like a chive leaf. It is where the **Hand Taiyin (Lung)** channel originates. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for one breath. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
*Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it reads one *zhàng*.

**Yújì** [鱼际] is located at the inner side of the base of the thumb’s proximal phalanx, where the divergent vessels spread. It is where the **Hand Taiyin (Lung)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Tàiyuān** [太渊] is located in the depression at the wrist’s posterior midline. It is where the **Hand Taiyin (Lung)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Jīngqú** [经渠] is located in the depression at the wrist’s radial side. It is where the **Hand Taiyin (Lung)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. Moxibustion is prohibited, as it harms the spirit and clarity.

**Chǐzé** [尺泽] is located above the elbow crease, where the pulse moves. It is where the **Hand Taiyin (Lung)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

For the **Kidney** channel:
- The *jing-well* is **Yǒngquán** [涌泉];
- The *ying-spring* is **Rángǔ** [然谷];
- The *shu-stream* is **Tàixī** [太溪];
- The *jing-river* is **Fùliú** [复溜];
*Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], *liú* [溜] is written as *liú* [留].
*All instances of the character 溜 are similarly corrected.*
- The *he-sea* is **Yīngǔ** [阴谷].

**Yǒngquán** [涌泉] is located in the depression at the sole’s center, found when the foot is flexed and toes curled. It is where the **Foot Shaoyin (Kidney)** channel originates. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Rángǔ** [然谷] is located in the depression below the medial malleolus, anterior to the large bone. It is where the **Foot Shaoyin (Kidney)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used. Needling here often draws blood, inducing immediate hunger.

**Tàixī** [太溪] is located in the depression above the medial malleolus, where the pulse moves behind the calcaneus. It is where the **Foot Shaoyin (Kidney)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Fùliú** [复溜] is located in the depression two *cùn* above the medial malleolus.
*Newly corrected:* According to the annotation in the *Ci Yāo Tòng Shāng Piān* [刺腰痛篇], it states: "two *cùn* posterior to the medial malleolus, where the pulse moves."
It is where the **Foot Shaoyin (Kidney)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* may be used.

**Yīngǔ** [阴谷] is located below the knee, posterior to the medial collateral ligament, beneath the large tendon and above the small tendon. It is palpable when the knee is flexed. It is where the **Foot Shaoyin (Kidney)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

Thus, the five *zàng* [藏] *shu-points* [俞]—each *zàng* having five holes—comprise twenty-five *shu-points*. When both left and right channels are included, there are fifty holes.

The **Fǔ** [府] *shu-points* number seventy-two. *Fǔ* refers to the six *fǔ* [府], not including the nine *xíng-fǔ* [形府]. *Shu-points* here refer to *jing-well*, *ying-spring*, *shu-stream*, *jing-river*, and *he-sea*—not the back *shu-points*.

For the **Liver** channel’s corresponding *fǔ* (the **Gallbladder**):
- The *jing-well* is **Qiàoyīn** [窍阴];
- The *ying-spring* is **Xiáxī** [侠溪];
- The *shu-stream* is **Línqì** [临泣];
- The *original* is **Qiūxū** [丘虚];
- The *jing-river* is **Yángfǔ** [阳辅];
- The *he-sea* is **Yánglíngquán** [阳陵泉].

**Qiàoyīn** [窍阴] is located at the tip of the second toe (adjacent to the little toe), at a distance from the corner of the nail like a chive leaf. It is where the **Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder)** channel originates. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for one breath.
*Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it reads three breaths.
If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Xiáxī** [侠溪] is located in the depression at the base of the second toe’s proximal phalanx, anterior to the bifurcation of the metatarsal bones. It is where the **Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Línqì** [临泣] is located in the depression behind the second toe’s proximal phalanx, one and a half *cùn* from **Xiáxī**. It is where the **Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch.
*Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it reads two *fèn*.
With retention for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Qiūxū** [丘虚] is located in the depression below the lateral malleolus, three *cùn* from **Línqì**. It is where the **Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder)** channel passes. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Yángfǔ** [阳辅] is located above the lateral malleolus.
*Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it states: "four *cùn* above the lateral malleolus, at the anterior end of the fibula’s head, three *fèn* of the same-body inch from the front."
It is seven *cùn* from **Qiūxū**. It is where the **Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Yánglíngquán** [阳陵泉] is located one *cùn* below the knee, in the depression lateral to the patellar tendon. It is where the **Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate six *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for ten breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

For the **Spleen** channel’s corresponding *fǔ* (the **Stomach**):
- The *jing-well* is **Lìduì** [厉兑];
- The *ying-spring* is **Nèitíng** [内庭];
- The *shu-stream* is **Xiàngǔ** [陷谷];
- The *original* is **Chōngyáng** [冲阳];
- The *jing-river* is **Jiěxī** [解溪];
- The *he-sea* is **Sānlǐ** [三里].

**Lìduì** [厉兑] is located at the tip of the second toe (adjacent to the big toe), at a distance from the corner of the nail like a chive leaf. It is where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel originates. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for one breath. If moxibustion is applied, one *zhàng* may be used.

**Nèitíng** [内庭] is located in the depression on the lateral side of the second toe’s proximal phalanx. It is where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for ten breaths.
*Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it reads twenty breaths.

「○If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Lìduì (陷谷)** is located at the lateral side of the second toe’s proximal phalanx, posterior to the joint in the depression, two *cùn* away from **Nèitíng (内庭)**. It is where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Chōngyáng (冲阳)** is located five *cùn* above the ankle on the bone’s lateral edge, where the pulse moves. It is three *cùn* away from **Lìduì (陷谷)**. It is where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel passes. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for ten breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Jiěxī (解溪)** is located one and a half *cùn* behind **Chōngyáng (冲阳)** in the depression on the posterior side of the wrist. *Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it reads one and a half *cùn*; the *Shīcǎi* [刺疟] commentary states three and a half *cùn*. The *Su Wen* [素问] annotations differ; the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* reading should be followed. It is where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Sānlǐ (三里)** is located three *cùn* below the knee, between the two muscles on the lateral side of the tibia. It is where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate one *cùn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
