The **Lung** channel’s *fù* is the **Large Intestine**; the Large Intestine’s *jǐng* is **Shāngyáng (商阳)**;
the *róng* is **Èrjiān (二间)**;
the *yù* is **Sānjiān (三间)**;
the *yuán* is **Hégǔ (合谷)**;
the *jīng* is **Yángxī (阳溪)**;
the *hé* is **Qǔchí (曲池)**.

**Shāngyáng (商阳)** is located on the medial side of the second finger of the hand, at the tip of the nail, one *fèn* away from the corner like a chive leaf. It is where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel originates. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for one breath. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Èrjiān (二间)** is located in the depression on the medial side of the second finger’s proximal phalanx, anterior to the joint. It is where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Sānjiān (三间)** is located in the depression on the medial side of the second finger’s proximal phalanx, posterior to the joint. It is where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Hégǔ (合谷)** is located between the two bones of the second finger’s metacarpophalangeal joint on the hand. It is where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel passes. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Yángxī (阳溪)** is located in the depression between the two tendons on the radial side of the wrist. It is where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Qǔchí (曲池)** is located on the lateral side of the elbow, between the two bones when the elbow is flexed. It is where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel enters. To locate it, flex the elbow and cup the hand to the chest. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

---
The **Heart** channel’s *fù* is the **Small Intestine**; the Small Intestine’s *jǐng* is **Shǎozé (少泽)**;
the *róng* is **Qiángǔ (前谷)**;
the *yù* is **Hòuxī (后溪)**;
the *yuán* is **Wàngǔ (腕骨)**;
the *jīng* is **Yánggǔ (阳谷)**;
the *hé* is **Shǎohǎi (少海)**.

**Shǎozé (少泽)** is located at the tip of the little finger, one *fèn* away from the nail corner in the depression. It is where the **Hand Taoyáng (Small Intestine)** channel originates. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, one *zhàng* may be used.

**Qiángǔ (前谷)** is located in the depression on the lateral side of the little finger’s proximal phalanx, anterior to the joint. It is where the **Hand Taoyáng (Small Intestine)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Hòuxī (后溪)** is located in the depression on the lateral side of the little finger’s proximal phalanx, posterior to the joint. It is where the **Hand Taoyáng (Small Intestine)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, one *zhàng* may be used.

**Wàngǔ (腕骨)** is located in the depression below the distal radius on the lateral side of the wrist. It is where the **Hand Taoyáng (Small Intestine)** channel passes. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Yánggǔ (阳谷)** is located in the depression below the sharp bone (ulna styloid) on the lateral side of the wrist. It is where the **Hand Taoyáng (Small Intestine)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. *Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], it reads two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

---
The **Pericardium (Heart Package)** channel’s *fù* is the **Triple Burner (Sān Jiāo)**; the Triple Burner’s *jǐng* is **Guānchōng (关冲)**;
the *róng* is **Yèmén (液门)**;

The **Pericardium (Heart Package)** channel’s *fù* is the **Triple Burner (Sān Jiāo)**;
the Triple Burner’s *jǐng* is **Guānchōng (关冲)**;
the *róng* is **Yèmén (液门)**;
the *yǔ* is **Zhōngzhǔ (中渚)**;
the *yuán* is **Yángchí (阳池)**;
the *jīng* is **Zhīgōu (支沟)**;
the *hé* is **Tiānjǐng (天井)**.

**Guānchōng (关冲)** is located at the tip of the fourth finger (ring finger) of the hand, beside the little finger, at the corner of the nail like a *jiǔ* leaf. It is the point where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channel emerges. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Yèmén (液门)** is located in the depression beside the fourth finger (ring finger) of the hand, near the little finger. It is where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Zhōngzhǔ (中渚)** is located in the depression beside the fourth finger (ring finger) of the hand, near the little finger, behind the joint. It is where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Yángchí (阳池)** is located in the depression above the wrist crease on the dorsal side of the hand. It is where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channel passes. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Zhīgōu (支沟)** is located in the depression between the two bones on the dorsal side of the wrist, three same-body inches from the wrist crease. It is where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Tiānjǐng (天井)** is located in the depression between the two tendons on the lateral side of the elbow, one same-body inch behind the elbow joint. It is found when the elbow is flexed, and it is where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate one same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

The **Kidney (Shèn)** channel’s *fù* is the **Bladder (Pángguāng)**;
the Bladder’s *jǐng* is **Zhìyīn (至阴)**;
the *róng* is **Tōnggǔ (通谷)**;
the *yǔ* is **Shùgǔ (束骨)**;
the *yuán* is **Jīnggǔ (京骨)**;
the *jīng* is **Kūnlún (昆仑)**;
the *hé* is **Wěizhōng (委中)**.

**Zhìyīn (至阴)** is located on the lateral side of the little toe of the foot, beside the corner of the nail like a *jiǔ* leaf. It is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel emerges. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Tōnggǔ (通谷)** is located in the depression beside the little toe of the foot, near the joint, in front of the toe. It is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Shùgǔ (束骨)** is located on the lateral side of the little toe of the foot, behind the joint, in the depression between red and white flesh. It is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Jīnggǔ (京骨)** is located on the lateral side of the foot, below the large bone (calcaneus), in the depression between red and white flesh. It is found by pressing, and it is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel passes. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Kūnlún (昆仑)** is located in the depression above the heel bone (calcaneus) on the lateral side of the ankle, where fine pulses respond to pressure. It is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel flows. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for ten breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Wěizhōng (委中)** is located in the center of the popliteal fossa, where the pulse moves beneath the skin. *Newly corrected:* The details of **Wěizhōng (委中)** align with those in the *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经], *Zhīyào Jiāo Qīnguò Tújīng* [刺疟篇注], *Bìlùn* [痹论注], and *Gǔkōnglùn* [骨空论]. It is also stated in the *Rèxué Lùn* [热穴论注] and *Zhīrè Piān* [刺热篇注] that it is located behind the knee in the flexed area. It is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel enters. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

As such, the *yǔ* points of the six *fù* (viscera) are each six holes, totaling thirty-six *yǔ* points. Including both left and right channels, there are seventy-two holes. The **Hot (Rè)** *yǔ* points consist of fifty-nine holes, and the **Water (Shuǐ)** *yǔ* points consist of fifty-seven holes, all detailed in the *Shuǐ-Rè Xué #12 Lùn* [水热穴#12论]. *Newly corrected:* The **Hot (Rè)** *yǔ* points are also documented in the *Zhīrè Piān* [刺热篇注].

On the head, the five *háng* (rows) each have five holes, totaling twenty-five holes. These are also part of the **Hot (Rè)** *yǔ* points’ fifty-nine holes.

On the sides of the spine, five holes each, totaling ten holes. These are the **back shù (convergence) points** of the five *zàng* (viscera). **Lung Shù (Lung Convergence)** is located beside the third vertebra. **Heart Shù (Pericardium Convergence)** is beside the fifth vertebra. **Liver Shù (Liver Convergence)** is beside the ninth vertebra. **Spleen Shù (Spleen Convergence)** is beside the eleventh vertebra. **Kidney Shù (Kidney Convergence)** is beside the fourteenth vertebra. These five *zàng* convergence points are each one and a half same-body inches away from the midline of the spine, and they are all where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel converges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch; **Liver Shù (Liver Convergence)** is retained for six breaths, while the others are retained for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used. Counting these, there are ten holes.

Two holes beside **Dàzhōu (大椎)**. *Newly corrected:* The *Jiǎ-Yǔ Jīng* [甲乙经] and *Jīngmài Liúzhù Kǒngxué Tújīng* [经脉流注孔穴图经] do not record these points, and it is unclear which *yǔ* points they refer to. *Newly corrected:* The points beside **Dàzhōu (大椎)** are not documented; however, the points beside **Dàzhōu (大椎)** below are named **Dàzhù (大杼)** in later texts.

Two holes beside the **pupil (tóngzi)** and **floating white (fúbái)** of the eyes. The **pupil** is located outside the eye, five *fèn* from the **pī (canthus)**. It is where the **Hand Tàiyáng (Small Intestine)**, **Hand Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)**, and **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

The **floating white (fúbái)** is located behind the ear, one same-body inch from the hairline. It is where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** and **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used. Considering both left and right sides, there are four holes in total.

Two holes beside the **two zàng (viscera) yì (ulcerated) fēn (division)**. These are the **Huányà (环姚)** points, located behind the **píshuō (脾枢)**, where the **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** and **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate one same-body inch, with retention for two breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

○**Newly Corrected Edition states:** According to Master Wang, the point is located *behind* the *píshuō*; however, the *Jia-Yi Jing* states it is located *within* the *píshuō*. The character "后" (behind) should be corrected to "中" (within). For moxibustion, the *Jia-Yi Jing* specifies five *zhàng* instead of three.

**Duǐbí (犊鼻) – Two Points**
Located below the knee joint, above the *fǔ* (腑, lower burner), beside the *jiědàijīn* (解大筋, major hamstring tendon), where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate six *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Ērzhōng Duōsuǒwén (耳中多所闻) – Two Points**
Also called the **Tīngguān (听官, Auditory Official)** points. Located within the ear at a pearl-like spot, the size of a small red bean, where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Small Intestine)**, **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)**, and **Hand Tàiyáng (Small Intestine)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate one *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
○**Newly Corrected Edition states:** The *Jia-Yi Jing* specifies needling may penetrate three *fèn*.

**Méiběn (眉本) – Two Points**
Also called the **Zuānhú (钻竹, Bamboo Drilling)** points. Located in the depression at the inner brow, where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Wángǔ (完骨) – Two Points**
Located behind the ear, four *fèn* from the hairline, where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** and **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
○**Newly Corrected Edition states:** The *Jia-Yi Jing* specifies needling may penetrate three *fèn* (corrected from unclear characters), and moxibustion may be applied for seven *zhàng*.

**Xiàngzhōngyāng (项中央) – One Point**
Also called the **Fēngfǔ (风府, Wind Mansion)** point. Located at the nape, one same-body inch from the hairline, within the depression of the large tendon (*dàjīn*), where the **Du Mai (Governing Vessel)** and **Yang Wéi (Yang Linking Vessel)** channels converge. When speaking rapidly, the flesh rises; when resting, it subsides. Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths. Moxibustion, if applied improperly, may cause [damage] (character unclear).

**Zhěngǔ (枕骨) – Two Points**
Also called the **Qiàoyīn (窍阴, Hidden Yin)** points. Located above the *wángǔ* and below the occipital bone, where movement is palpable, where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** and **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
○**Newly Corrected Edition states:** The *Jia-Yi Jing* specifies needling may penetrate four *fèn*, and moxibustion may be applied for five *zhàng*.

**Shàngguān (上关) – Two Points**
As described in the *Zhēn Jīng (Needle Classic)*, needling here prevents yawning. Located at the upper anterior ear, beside the zygomatic bone, where a hollow appears upon opening the mouth, where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Small Intestine)** and **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used. Deep needling may cause deafness in the ear.

**Dàyíng (大迎) – Two Points**
Located one same-body inch and three *fèn* forward from the *qūè* (曲颌, mandibular angle), in the depression of the pulsating artery, where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Xiàguān (下关) – Two Points**
As described in the *Zhēn Jīng (Needle Classic)*, needling here prevents drinking. Located below the *shàngguān*, at the anterior ear’s pulsating artery, where a hollow appears upon closing the mouth after opening it, where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** and **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channels converge. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used. Moxibustion is contraindicated if there is *gānzhā* (乾挝, dry percussion) within the ear.
○**Newly Corrected Edition states:** The *Jia-Yi Jing* specifies *zhā* (抵, press) instead of *zhā* (挝, percussion). *Yí* (遗) is pronounced as *zhāi* (摘). *Qīn* (钦) is pronounced *qiūshù* (丘庶切).

**Tiānzhù (天柱) – Two Points**
Located beside the nape, at the hairline’s large tendon’s outer depression, where the **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate two *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Jùxū Shàngxiàlián (巨虚上下廉) – Four Points**
**Upper *lián* (廉):** Where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** and **Foot Tàiyáng (Bladder)** channels converge. Located six same-body inches below the *duǐbí*, at the outer depression of the *liǎn* (颊, cheek), where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate eight *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Lower *lián* (廉):** Where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** and **Foot Shǎoyáng (Triple Burner)** channels converge. Located six same-body inches and three *fèn* below the upper *lián*, where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, one *zhàng* may be used.
○**Newly Corrected Edition states:** According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*, the *Shīrè Piān (刺热篇, Needling Heat Section)* annotation, and the *Shuǐrè Xué (水热穴, Water-Heat Points)* annotation, the upper *lián* is located three *cùn* below *sānlǐ* (三里, Stomach 36). The text states six *cùn* below *duǐbí* because *sānlǐ* is three *cùn* below *duǐbí*, and the upper *lián* is another three *cùn* below *sānlǐ*, totaling six *cùn*.

**Qūyá (曲牙) – Two Points**
Also called the **Jiáchē (颊车, Jaw Cart)** points. Located at the depression of the curved jaw’s end, where a hollow appears upon opening the mouth, where the **Foot Yangming (Stomach)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Tiāntū (天突) – One Point**
Already explained in the preceding text.

**Tiānfǔ (天府) – Two Points**
Located three same-body inches below the armpit, in the depression of the inner upper arm’s pulsating artery, where the **Hand Tàiyīn (Lung)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Moxibustion is prohibited; needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for three breaths.
*Note: "燸" (nuò) is pronounced *nuòdào* (奴到切).*

**Tiānyòu (天牖) – Two Points**
Located between the neck tendons, above the *quēpén* (缺盆, suprasternal fossa), behind the *Tiānróng* (天容), before the *Tiānzhù* (天柱), below the *wángǔ* (完骨), and above the hairline, where the **Hand Shǎoyáng (Small Intestine)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate one same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Fútū (扶突) – Two Points**
Located one same-body inch below the *qūtuí* (曲颓, sternocleidomastoid muscle’s depression), behind the *Rényíng* (人迎), where the **Hand Yangming (Large Intestine)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Taken while tilting the head back, needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Tiānchuāng (天窗) – Two Points**
Located below the *qūtuí*, behind the *fútū*, in the depression of the pulsating artery, where the **Hand Tàiyáng (Small Intestine)** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate six *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Jiānjiě (肩解) – Two Points**

**Jiānjiěng (肩井) – Two Points**
Refers to the *Jiānjiěng* (shoulder well). Located on the shoulder, in the depression between the *Yángwéi* (阳维, Yang Link) and *Jiě* (解, Release) points, above the *kēpén* (缺盆, supraclavicular fossa). A convergence of the **Hand and Foot Shàoyáng** (少阳, Lesser Yang) channels. Needling may penetrate five *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), five *zhàng* of moxibustion may be used.

**Guānyuán (关元) – One Point**
**Newly Corrected Version:** (Details of this point have already been explained earlier; it was previously noted in the old text but is now omitted.)

**Wěiyáng (委阳) – Two Points**
Also called *Xiūfǔyú* (辅俞, Auxiliary Convergence). Located between the *Wàikāng* (外康) and *Liángkāng* (两筋) tendons in the *bīn* (胭, armpit) region. A branch of the **Foot Tàiyáng** (太阳, Greater Yang) channel. Needling may penetrate seven *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used. Taken while flexing and extending the arm.

**Jiānjīn (肩贞) – Two Points**
Located below the *Jiānjīn* (shoulder curve) and *Jiǎ* (甲, carpal bone), between the two bones where the shoulder relaxes, in the depression behind the *jiāngǒu* (肩髁, acromion). Where the **Hand Tàiyáng** channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate eight *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Mén (门) – One Point**
Located at the *yángwéi* (阳维, Yang Link) convergence of the **Dūmài** (督脉, Governing Vessel) and the two channels, within the *wǎnwǎn* (宛宛, nape hairline) region of the neck, penetrating into the root of the tongue. Taken while tilting the head back. Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch. Moxibustion is **forbidden** (刺之令人□), as it may cause harm.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Qìfǔ* (气府), it should be one same-body inch below the *Fēngfǔ* (风府, Wind Palace).

**Qí (齐) – One Point**
Located at the *qízhōng* (齐中, central sternum). **Forbidden** (禁不可刺)—needling may induce a malignant ulcer. If the needle causes *zèshǐ* (渍矢, pus and blood discharge), death is inevitable and incurable. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Xiōngshù (胸俞) – Twelve Points**
Refers to *Shùfǔ* (俞府, Convergence Palace), *Ouzhōng* (或中, Central Chest), *Shéncáng* (神藏, Spirit Concealment), *Língxū* (灵墟, Soul Abyss), *Shénfēng* (神封, Spirit Seal), and *Bùláng* (步廊, Pacing Corridor), totaling twelve points (left and right). **Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, the names are *Zhōuróng* (周荣, Circumferential Splendor) and *Xiōngqīng* (胸卿, Chest Noble).

- **Shùfǔ (俞府)** – Located below the *jùgǔ* (巨骨, clavicle), beside the *Xiàtán* (侠任, Lateral Conception) channel. Horizontally, two same-body inches from the *Tánmài* (任脉, Conception Vessel), in the depression. The lower five points are spaced one same-body inch and six *fèn* apart in the depression. Where the **Foot Shàoyín** (少阴, Lesser Yin) channel’s *qi* emerges. Taken while tilting the head back. Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch. If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, *Shùfǔ* is where the **Hand Tàiyín** (太阴, Greater Yin) channel’s *qi* emerges, and *Ouzhōng* (或中) is the convergence of the **Hand and Foot Tàiyín** channels.

- **Bèishù (背俞) – Two Points**
Also called *Dàzhù* (大杼, Great Pivot). Located on either side of the first vertebra of the spine, spaced one same-body inch and three *fèn* apart in the depression. A convergence of the **Dūmài** (督脉, Governing Vessel) branch and the **Hand and Foot Tàiyáng** (太阳, Greater Yang) channels’ *qi*. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, seven *zhàng* may be used.

**Yīngshù (膺俞) – Twelve Points**
Refers to *Yúnmén* (云门, Cloud Gate), *Zhōngfǔ* (中府, Central Palace), *Zhōuróng* (周荣, Circumferential Splendor), *Xiōngqīng* (胸卿, Chest Noble), *Tiānxī* (天溪, Celestial Ravine), and *Shídòu* (食窦, Food Cavern), totaling twelve points (left and right). **Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, the names are *Zhōuróng* (周荣) and *Xiōngqīng* (胸卿).

- **Yúnmén (云门)** – Located below the *jùgǔ* (巨骨, clavicle), beside the *Xiàtán* (侠任, Lateral Conception) channel. Horizontally, six same-body inches from the *Tánmài* (任脉, Conception Vessel) on either side.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Shuǐrè Xué* (水热穴), it is located beside the *Xiōngzhōngxíng* (胸中行, Central Chest Pathway), though the description differs, the location remains the same. In the depression where the artery pulses upon palpation, *Yúnmén* and *Zhōngfǔ* are spaced one same-body inch apart, and the remaining five points are spaced one same-body inch and six *fèn* apart in the depression. Where the **Hand Tàiyín** (太阴, Greater Yin) channel’s *qi* emerges. *Yúnmén* and *Shídòu* are taken while raising the arm; the others are taken while tilting the head back. Needling may penetrate seven *fèn* of the same-body inch for *Yúnmén* (too deep may cause *nìxī* (逆息, dyspnea)), three *fèn* for *Zhōngfǔ*, with retention for five breaths, and four *fèn* for the rest. If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly Corrected Version:** (Details of these twelve points being part of the **Hand Tàiyín** channel are clarified by Wang; according to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, *Yúnmén* is the **Hand Tàiyín**, *Zhōngfǔ* is the convergence of **Hand and Foot Tàiyín**, and the remaining points belong to the **Foot Tàiyín**, not all twelve being part of the **Hand Tàiyín**.)

**Fēnròu (分肉) – Two Points**
Located three *fèn* of the same-body inch above the *jué gǔ* (绝骨, lateral malleolus) on the outer ankle, where the tendons and muscles divide. Where the **Yángwéi** (阳维, Yang Link) channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, there is no *Fēnròu* point. The location may be in doubt, possibly referring to *Yángfǔ* (阳辅, Yang Auxiliary), located above the outer ankle, at the anterior end of the *jué gǔ* (绝骨), as noted in the previous three *fèn*. Alternatively, according to the *Cì Yāotòng* (刺腰痛) note, it is located at the posterior end of the *jué gǔ*, spaced two *fèn* apart, and needling may penetrate five *fèn*, with retention for ten breaths. The description here is slightly different.

**Huáishàng Héng (踝上横) – Two Points**
- **Inner Ankle Point (交信穴, Jiāoxìn)** – Located two same-body inches above the inner ankle, anterior to the **Foot Shàoyín** (少阴, Lesser Yin) and posterior to the **Foot Tàiyín** (太阴, Greater Yin) tendons and bones, at the *yīntà* (阴踏, Yin Step) channel’s *yóu* (邮, postal station). Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for five breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
- **Outer Ankle Point (附阳穴, Fùyáng)** – Located three same-body inches above the outer ankle, anterior to the **Foot Tàiyáng** (太阳, Greater Yang) and posterior to the **Foot Shàoyáng** (少阳, Lesser Yang) tendons and bones, at the *yángtà* (阳踏, Yang Step) channel’s *yóu* (邮). Needling may penetrate six *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, *Fùyáng* (附阳) is written as *Fùyáng* (付阳).

**Yīnyáng Tiāo (阴阳跚) – Four Points**
- **Yīntāo (阴跚穴, Yin Step)** – Located below the inner ankle, also called *Zhàohǎi* (照海, Illuminating Sea). Where the **Foot Shàoyín** (少阴) channel’s *qi* emerges. Needling may penetrate four *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for six breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
- **Yángtāo (阳跚穴, Yang Step)** – Also called *Shēn* (申, Extend) **mài** (脉). Where the **Foot Tàiyáng** (太阳) channel’s *qi* emerges. Located in the depression below the outer ankle.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Cì Yāotòng* (刺腰痛) note, it is located five *fèn* below the outer ankle; according to the *Miù Cì Lùn* (缪刺论), it is located half a same-body inch below the outer ankle.

- **Yángtāo (阳跚穴)** – Within the reach of the toenail, needling may penetrate three *fèn* of the same-body inch, with retention for seven breaths. If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.
**Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng*, retention for seven breaths is written as six breaths; according to the *Cì Yāotòng* (刺腰痛) note, it is written as ten breaths.

「The **Water Meeting** point (*Shuǐyù*, 水俞) lies among the **flesh divisions** (*ròufèn*, 肉分). The **flesh divisions** refer to the distinctions between the layers of flesh; this is where one treats **Water** (*shuǐ*, 水) by needling.

The **Heat Meeting** point (*Rètāo*, 热俞) lies within the **Qi points** (*qìxué*, 气穴). To address **Heat** (*rè*, 热), one needles these points.

The **Cold-Heat Meeting** points (*Hánrètāo*, 寒热俞) are located at the two **Knee Cavity** points (*liǎngkāiyàn*, 两骸厌) in the depression. The **Knee Cavity** refers to the hollow space on the outer side of the knee joint.

The **Great Prohibition** (*Dàjìn*, 大禁) is found five *cùn* below **Celestial Storehouse** (*Tiānfǔ*, 天府). This is the **Five-Li** point (*wǔlǐ*, 五里). It is called the **Great Prohibition** because needling is strictly forbidden here. The *Needle Classic* (*Zhēnjīng*, 针经) states: *"Needling the Five-Li, which lies midway between the two, five times upward exhausts its **Qi**; five times downward depletes its **Qi**—thus, twenty-five times fully exhausts its Meeting point."* This refers to the same. It further states: *"The Five-Li is five *cùn* behind **Pool of the Inch** (*Chǐzé*, 尺泽)."* This aligns with the text above.

In total, there are **365 Meeting points** (*sānlùoxīgǔ*, 孙络溪谷), the pathways through which needling may be administered. **Newly Corrected Version:** Upon closer examination, from the **Hidden Meeting** point (*Zàngyù*, 藏俞) to the **50th Meeting**, there are overlaps totaling **360 Meeting points**, including those from **Celestial Perforation** (*Tiāntū*, 天突), **Ten Vertebrae** (*Shízhuī*, 十椎), **Upper Record** (*Shàngjì*, 上纪), and **Lower Record** (*Xiàjì*, 下纪), amounting to **365 Meeting points** in all. However, accounting for overlaps, there are truly **313 Meeting points**.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"I have learned the locations of the **Qi points** and the pathways of the **wandering needle** (*yóuzhēn*, 游针). May I inquire about the **Grand Confluences** (*Sānlùoxīgǔ*, 孙络溪谷) and their applications?"*

The **Grand Confluences** (*Sānlùo*, 孙络) are the minor branches of the **Collaterals** (*luò*, 络), referring to their secondary divisions. Qìbó (*岐伯*) replied: *"The **365 Grand Confluences** of the **minor Collaterals** also correspond to the year, serving to drain excess **pathogenic factors** (*xíe*, 邪), to regulate the **Nourishing** (*róng*, 荣) and **Defensive** (*wèi*, 卫) **Qi**, and to prevent stagnation. When the **Defensive Qi** scatters and the **Nourishing Qi** overflows, when **Qi** is exhausted and **blood** congeals—externally manifesting as **fever** (*fā rè*, 发热), internally as **shortness of breath** (*shǎo qì*, 少气)—needling these points to drain the **pathogenic factors** and restore balance is done without regard to their specific **Meeting points** or **Confluences**.

If **Nourishing Qi** accumulates and **Defensive Qi** stagnates, causing internal and external **imbalance** (*xiāngbó*, 相薄), one must needle where the **blood Collaterals** (*xuèluò*, 血络) appear and drain them immediately—again, without concern for the **Meeting points** or **Confluences** of the channels.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"I wish to hear more about the **Confluences of the Grand Collaterals** (*Xīgǔ*, 溪谷)."*

Qìbó replied: *"The **Confluences** of the **major flesh divisions** (*ròufèn*, 肉分) are called **Grand Confluences** (*xīgǔ*, 溪谷), while those of the **minor flesh divisions** are called **minor Confluences** (*xī*, 溪). The **Confluences** of the **flesh divisions** regulate the **Nourishing** and **Defensive Qi**, harmonizing with the **Great Qi** (*dàqì*, 大气). **Newly Corrected Version:** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), this is written as *harmonizing with the **Great Qi** (合大气)*.

When **pathogenic factors** (*xíe*, 邪) obstruct and **Qi** stagnates, the **pulse** becomes hot and the flesh decays! If the **Nourishing** and **Defensive Qi** do not flow, it will inevitably lead to **pus** (*nóng*, 脓). If **pus** consumes the **bone marrow** (*guīyè*, 髓液) internally and ruptures the **thigh** (*dàwěi*, 大腘) externally, this is the result. If stagnation occurs at the **joints** (*jié*, 节), it will lead to **decay** (*bài*, 败). If stagnation occurs between the **bone joints** (*gǔjié*, 骨节) and where the **fluids** (*jīnyè*, 津液) perform their functions, the **bone marrow** (*guīyè*, 髓液) and **fluids** (*jīnyè*, 津液) will both be impaired, forming **pus**, and thus the **tendons** and **bones** will decay and rot, preventing **flexion and extension** (*qūshēn*, 屈伸).

If **Cold** (*hán*, 寒) accumulates and stagnates, the **Nourishing** and **Defensive Qi** will not reside there, causing the **tendons** to contract internally. **Newly Corrected Version:** According to the full text of Quán Yuánqǐ (全元起), this is written as *Cold causes the flesh to contract and the tendons to shrink*. The **ribs** and **elbows** will fail to extend, internally resulting in **bone numbness** (*gǔbì*, 骨痹), externally in **loss of sensation** (*bùrén*, 不仁). This is termed **Qi Deficiency** (*bùzú*, 不足), where **Great Cold** (*dàhán*, 大寒) lingers in the **Confluences**.

When **pathogenic factors** (*xíe*, 邪) are excessive and the **True Qi** (*zhēnqì*, 真气) is not nourished, the **bone marrow** overflows and is consumed internally, hence the condition arises. **Qi Deficiency** refers to **Yin Qi** (*yángqì*, 阳气) deficiency. When **Cold pathogenic factors** (*hánxíe*, 寒邪) linger externally, accumulating over time, **Yin Qi** cannot overcome them externally, causing internal consumption of the **tendons** and **bone marrow**, hence the term **Qi Deficiency**—where **Great Cold** (*dàhán*, 大寒) lingers in the **Confluences**.

The **365 Grand Confluences** also correspond to the year. Their minor **numbness** (*bì*, 痹) and **overflow** (*yìn*, 淫溢) follow the channels in their **circulation** (*xúngǔ*, 循脉往来). A **fine needle** (*wēizhēn*, 微针) may reach these, and the treatment follows the same principles as elsewhere. If the **Qi of minor Cold** (*xiǎohán*, 小寒) flows excessively and stagnates, causing **numbness** (*bì*, 痹) along the channels, needling to adjust it follows the same methods as usual.

The Yellow Emperor then parted his attendants, stood, and bowed twice, saying: *"Today, I have dispelled my ignorance and resolved my doubts. I shall preserve these teachings in the **Golden Treasury** (*Jīnkuì*, 金匮), and dare not speak of them again."* He then stored them in the **Golden Orchid Chamber** (*Jīnlán zhī shì*, 金兰之室), marking them as the locations of the **Qi points**.

Qìbó said: *"The **Collateral branches** (*sānlùo*, 孙络) that diverge from the primary channels—where the **blood** is abundant and must be drained—also number **365**, all converging upon the **Collaterals** (*luò*, 络) and transmitted through **twelve Collateral channels** (*shíèrlùomài*, 十四络脉), not just the **14 Collaterals** (*shísì luòmài*, 十四络脉). The **14 Collaterals** refer to the **Collaterals** of the **Twelve Primary Channels** (*shíèrjīng*, 十二经) combined with those of the **Governing Vessel** (*dūmài*, 督脉) and **Conception Vessel** (*rènmài*, 任脉). The **major Collateral** of the **Spleen** (*pízhīdàluò*, 脾之大络) originates in the **Spleen** itself, hence it is not included in this count.

Within the body, **ten Collaterals** (*shìmài*, 十脉) converge and drain into the **middle**. **Middle** refers to the **Collaterals** between the **Primary Channels** and **Secondary Channels** (*zhōngjīngluò*, 中经络). Though they run separately, they receive **pathogenic factors** and transmit them back to the **Collaterals** of the **Five Zàng Organs** (*wǔzàng*, 五藏), five on each side—thus, **ten Collaterals** in total.

**End of the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Classic* – *Plain Questions* – *Annotations on the Supplementary Text* – Volume 32.**
