**Chapter on the Theory of Bone Cavities**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"I have heard that wind is the origin of a hundred ailments. How should one treat it with acupuncture?"*
(*"Begin" here means "initial."*)

Qìbó replied:
*"When wind enters from without, it causes the body to tremble with cold, induces sweating, headache, heaviness of the body, and aversion to cold.
When wind invades the body’s form, it obstructs the proper flow of *qi*, sealing the pores tightly. The *yang* *qi* resists internally, while external cold prevails, their opposing forces clashing. As a result, the *honorific* and *defensive* *qi* lose their proper courses—thus the symptoms arise.

Treatment should target **Wind Palace** (*Fēngfǔ*), a channel point.
**Wind Palace** is located at the nape, one *cùn* (finger-breadth) above the hairline, in the midline.
(*It lies along the **Governing Vessel**, the confluence of the **Foot Taiyang** channel.*)
When needling, penetrate to four *fēn* (tenths of a *cùn*).
If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* (cones) may be used.*

**Newly corrected annotation states:**
*"According to the *Fēngfǔ* annotation, the *Treatise on Qi Cavities* and *Treatise on Qi Palaces* already contain this note, matching the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*. Here, it mistakenly states that it is the confluence of the **Governing Vessel** and **Foot Taiyang**, allowing five *zhàng* of moxa—this is actually the **Wind Gate** (*Fēngmén*) and **Heat Palace** (*Rèfǔ*) point.
It should read: *‘Confluence of the **Governing Vessel** and **Yang Link** (*Yángwéi*), retain the needle for three breaths—moxibustion is prohibited.’*
Thus corrected.

Regulate the *yin* and *yang*: if deficient, supplement; if excessive, reduce."*

The **Dao** of needle use follows the laws of Heaven’s constancy—reduce excess, supplement deficiency, for this is its norm.

For **Great Wind** with neck and nape pain, needle **Wind Gate** (*Fēngmén*).
**Wind Gate** is located above the **Great Vertebra** (*Dàzhuī*).
The **Great Vertebra** refers to the point above the **Great Vertebra** (*Dàzhuī*), one *cùn* (same-body inch) into the hairline.

For **Great Wind** with profuse sweating, moxa **Requesting Moxa** (*Qǐngxī*).
**Requesting Moxa** is a point on the **Wind Gate** (*Fēngmén*)—located three *cùn* beside the **Lateral Spine** (*Xiépǐ*), beneath the back.
Press it until the patient calls out, and the point will respond beneath your fingers.
It is the **Foot Taiyang** channel’s *qi* emerging here.
Needling may penetrate six *fēn* of the same-body inch; retain for seven breaths.
If moxibustion is applied, five *zhàng* may be used.
**Requesting Moxa** is named thus because of its response.

(*Bó* rhymes with *博*.)

For **Wind** that lingers like a monk, needle the **Brow Pinnacle** (*Méitóu*).
This refers to the **Drilling Bamboo** (*Zuànzhú*) point.
Located in the hollow of the brow where the pulse moves beneath your fingers,
it is the **Foot Taiyang** channel’s *qi* emerging here.
Needling may penetrate three *fēn* of the same-body inch;
if moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

**Lost Cushion** (*Shīzhěn*) is between the shoulder bones.
This refers to the **Missing Basin** (*Quēpén*) point.
Located in the hollow between the shoulder’s transverse bone,
it is the **Hand Yangming** channel’s *qi* emerging here.
Needling may penetrate two *fēn* of the same-body inch; retain for seven breaths.
If moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used—
needling too deep will cause the patient to gasp.

(*New annotation states: According to the *Qi Palaces* (*Qǐfǔ*) text, it should read **Foot Yangming**—
the *Difficult Classic* (*Nánjīng*) and *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* both record this as the **Foot Yangming** channel’s *qi* emerging here,
thus Wang’s annotation mentions both.)

For **Lost Cushion**, when the arm is flexed and bent at the elbow,
moxa **Spine Center** (*Jǐzhōng*).
(*Shāo* reads as *yáo*—*yáo* means to shake or move.)
Yet **Lost Cushion** is not only taken from the hollow between the shoulder’s transverse bone;
when correcting posture, moxa **Spine Center** as well.

To confirm its location, have the patient shake their arm and bend their elbow.
From the nape downward, align horizontally with the elbow’s tip—
the midpoint here is **Sun Gate** (*Yángguān*).
Located five *fēn* below the **16th vertebra** (*shíliù zhuījié*),
it is the **Governing Vessel**’s *qi* emerging here.
Needling may penetrate five *fēn* of the same-body inch;
if moxibustion is applied, three *zhàng* may be used.

(*New annotation states: **Sun Gate** (*Yángguān*) is not recorded in the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*.*)

For **sand-like networks** (*shālùo*) drawing from the **flanks** (*jìxiá*) to the **lower abdomen** (*shàofù*), causing distended pain,
needle **Requesting Moxa** (*Qǐngxī*).
(*Chǎo* refers to the hollow, soft areas beside the **Lateral Spine** (*Xiépǐ*).)
**Lower abdomen** means aligned with the navel.
When back pain prevents turning or shaking, urgently draw the **yin scrotum** (*yīnluǎn*), and needle **Eight Lumbar** (*Bāgé*) with the pain’s apex.
**Eight Lumbar** is located between the **lumbar vertebrae** (*yāoshǔ*).
(*Eight* may also mean *nine*—according to *True Bones* (*Zhēngǔ*) and *Central Canon of Acupuncture* (*Zhōnghuà Kǒngxué Jīng*), there is **Eight Lumbar** but no *Nine Lumbar*.)
**Divide** refers to the hollow between the lumbar vertebrae’s tendons and flesh.
For **rat-like atrophy** (*shǔshòu*) with cold and heat,
needle **Cold Palace** (*Hánfǔ*).
**Cold Palace** is located outside the **knee** (*xī*), at the **bone junction** (*jiě*).
(*Knee* refers to the outer bone.)
The **flexing and extending** point,
where cold *qi* thrives—
thus it is named **Cold Palace**.
(*Jiě* means bone junction; *yíng* means deep needling must strike the **network vessels** (*luò*).)

To take the point outside the knee, have the patient kneel.
To take the point on the sole, have the patient kneel with the foot’s hollow pressed firmly inward.

The **Conception Vessel** (*Rènmài*) arises below **Middle Extremity** (*Zhōngjí*), ascending along the **pubic hairline** (*máojié*).
It follows the **lower abdomen** (*fùguǒ*), passing through **Navel Center** (*Guānyuán*), reaching the throat, and ascending to the **chin** (*yè*), tracing the face to enter the eyes.

(*New annotation states: According to the *Difficult Classic* (*Nánjīng*) and *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, the phrase "ascending to the chin, tracing the face to enter the eyes" is absent.*)

The **Penetrating Vessel** (*Chōngmài*) arises from **Qi Street** (*Qìjiē*).
(*New annotation states: According to the *Difficult Classic* (*Nánjīng*) and *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng*, it should read **Foot Yangming**.*)
It ascends beside **Lesser Yin** (*Shàoyīn*), dispersing in the chest.
The **Conception Vessel** and **Penetrating Vessel** are **extraordinary channels** (*qíjīng*).
The **Conception Vessel** ascends centrally along the midline,
while the **Penetrating Vessel** ascends beside it on both flanks.

Yet **Middle Extremity** (*Zhōngjí*) refers to the point four *cùn* below the navel.
Speaking of below **Middle Extremity** means the **Conception Vessel** ascends internally from the lower abdomen,
then externally emerges at the **pubic hairline** (*máojié*) and rises—
not that it originates here.

**Navel Center** (*Guānyuán*) refers to the point three *cùn* below the navel.
**Qi Street** (*Qìjiē*) is the name of a point—
located one *cùn* above the **pubic hairline** (*máojié*) on both flanks.

Speaking of the **Penetrating Vessel** arising from **Qi Street** means it also ascends internally from the lower abdomen,
parallel to the **Conception Vessel**, then follows the **abdominal midline** (*fùguǒ*).

How so? The *Needle Classic* (*Zhēnjīng*) states:
The **Penetrating Vessel** is the **sea of the Twelve Channels** (*shíèrjīng hǎi*), arising with the **Lesser Yin** channel’s networks below the **kidneys** (*shèn*).
It emerges at **Qi Street** (*Qìjiē*).

It further states:
The **Penetrating Vessel** and **Conception Vessel** both originate from the **uterus** (*bāozhōng*).
They ascend along the **spine** (*bèiguǒ*), serving as the **sea of the channels and networks**.
Their external branches follow the **abdominal midline** (*fùguǒ*), converging at the throat,
then diverge to network the **lips and mouth** (*chúnkuǎn*).

When **blood** and *qi* are abundant, the skin grows hot.
When **blood** alone is abundant, it permeates the skin,
generating **hair** (*máo*).

From this, it is clear that the **Conception Vessel** ascends internally from the lower abdomen,
reaching below **Middle Extremity** (*Zhōngjí*), within **Qi Street** (*Qìjiē*).

(*New annotation states: **Qi Street** (*Qìjiē*) is emphasized in the *Qi Palaces* (*Qǐfǔ*), *Needling Heat* (*Cǎo Rè*), *Water-Heat Points* (*Shuǐ Rè*), and *Needling Prohibitions* (*Cǐ Jìn*) texts,
though the phrasing differs, the location remains the same.
It is fully annotated in the *Qi Palaces* text.*)

When the **Conception Vessel** is diseased,
men develop **seven internal hernias** (*qīliè*), and women suffer **prolapsed uterus** (*dàiyā húnjù*).
When the **Penetrating Vessel** is diseased,
**rebellious breath** (*nìqì*) and **abdominal urgency** (*jiéjí*) occur.

When the **Governing Vessel** is diseased,
the **spine stiffens and bends backward** (*jǐngqiáng fǎnzhé*).
The **Governing Vessel** is also an **extraordinary channel** (*qíjīng*).

Yet the **Conception Vessel**, **Penetrating Vessel**, and **Governing Vessel** share a single source with three branches,
thus some texts call the **Penetrating Vessel** the **Governing Vessel** as well.

How is this made clear? Now, both the *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) and the ancient *Classic of the Flowing Meridians* (《经脉流注图经》) state that the **Conception Vessel** (任脉) ascending along the back is called the **Governing Vessel** (督脉), while the **Conception Vessel** ascending straight from the lower abdomen is also called the **Conception Vessel**—this is simply a naming distinction based on the **yin-yang** (阴阳) differentiation of the **back and abdomen** (背腹).

The **Conception Vessel** (任脉) ascends from the **uterus** (胞), passing through the **girdle vessel** (带脉), converging at the **navel** (齐), and then ascending further. Thus, when men develop this disease, they suffer **seven internal hernias** (内结七疝), and when women develop it, they experience **prolapsed uterus** (带下痕聚). The **Penetrating Vessel** (冲脉) ascends alongside the **navel** (齐) and merges with the **Lesser Yin** (少阴) meridian, reaching the chest center. Therefore, when the **Penetrating Vessel** is diseased, **rebellious breath** (逆气) and **abdominal urgency** (裹急) occur.

The **Governing Vessel** (督脉) ascends along the **spine** (脊), encased by the **kidney meridian** (督脉). Thus, when the **Governing Vessel** is diseased, the **spine stiffens and bends backward** (脊强反折). The **Governing Vessel** originates below the **lower abdomen** (少腹) at the **central bone** (骨中央), entering the **systematic orifice** (系廷孔) in women. This "origin" is not its initial emergence, but rather, just as the **Conception Vessel** and **Penetrating Vessel** (任脉冲脉) emerge from the **uterus** (胞中), the **Governing Vessel** actually begins below the **kidneys** (肾下), descending to the **lower abdomen** (少腹) at the **central bone** (骨围之中央).

The **systematic orifice** (系廷孔) refers to the **Yao Luo** (窈漏), also known as the **Front Yin Orifice** (前阴穴). It is named so because its **yin systematic orifice** (阴廷) is connected to the center. The **orifice** (孔) is the upper end of the **urinary orifice** (溺孔), and the **Yao Luo** (窈漏) itself lies within the **Front Yin Orifice**. The **urinary orifice** (溺孔) is the **systematic orifice** (廷孔) located above the **Yao Luo**, and the **Governing Vessel** reaches this point from the **central bone** (骨围中央). Its **collateral** (络) follows the **yin instrument** (阴器), converging at the **two orifices** (问), encircling the **anus** (篡) from behind. The **collaterals** (别络) of the **Governing Vessel** split from the **urinary orifice** (溺孔) and each branch descends along the **yin instrument**, converging at the **two orifices** (问). After passing the **two orifices**, they split again and encircle the **anus** from behind.

The **collateral** (络) of the **Lesser Yin** (足少阴) meridian ascends from the **inner posterior aspect of the thigh** (上股内后廉), piercing the **spine** (贯脊) and connecting to the **kidney** (属肾). The **collateral** (络) of the **Greater Yang** (巨阳, 足太阳) meridian descends externally along the **spleen pivot** (脾枢), connecting to the **outer aspect of the thigh** (络股阳) and downward; its internal branch descends through the **buttocks** (贯臀), reaching the **perineum** (胭中) and merging with the external branch. Hence, it is said that the **collaterals** of the **Lesser Yin** and **Greater Yang** merge, ascending from the **inner posterior aspect of the thigh** (上股内后廉), piercing the **spine** (贯脊) and connecting to the **kidney** (属肾). (*New Annotation*: Upon careful examination, the term "行於焦" likely contains an error; the character "焦" should be reconsidered.)

The **collateral** (络) of the **Greater Yang** (足太阳) meridian originates from the **inner canthus** (目内毗), ascending along the forehead to meet at the **vertex** (巅上), entering the **brain** (络脑), then descending separately from the **nape of the neck** (下项), following the **inner aspect of the shoulder and scapula** (侠脊抵腰中), and descending to connect with the **kidney** (属肾). It then ascends, encircling the **buttocks** (臀). The **Conception Vessel** in men follows the **penis** (茎) down to the **anus** (篡), equal to that in women. The **Conception Vessel** ascending straight from the **lower abdomen** (少腹) pierces the **navel** (齐中央), ascending through the **heart** (心), entering the **throat** (喉), ascending to the **chin** (颐), encircling the **lips** (环唇), and striking below the **two eyes** (两目之下中央). From its origin at the **inner canthus** (目内毗) descending to the **anus** (篡) in women, it is also the **collateral** (别络) of the **Governing Vessel**.

The **Conception Vessel**’s **straight course** (直行) ascends from the **umbilicus** (尸上) along the **spine** (脊), reaching the **nose** (鼻). The **Conception Vessel**’s ascent from the **lower abdomen** (少腹) to below the **two eyes** (两目之下中央) is also part of the **Governing Vessel**’s course. Thus, the **Conception Vessel** and **Governing Vessel** are named differently but share the same fundamental **channel** (脉).

When this disease arises, it causes **pain ascending from the lower abdomen to the heart** (从少腹上冲心而痛), preventing forward and backward movement, resulting in **Penetrating Vessel hernia** (冲疝). Upon further examination, this disease actually stems from the **Conception Vessel** (任脉), as the *Classic* describes it as **Penetrating Vessel hernia** (冲疝), clearly distinguishing the **Governing Vessel** (督脉) as the separate governing meridian. How so? If there were only a single **vessel** (脉) and **qi** (气) without differentiation in **yin-yang** governing functions, then this disease would cause **pain in both the heart and back** (心背俱痛), why would it exclusively manifest as **hernia with heart-centered pain** (冲心而为疝)?

When women suffer from this disease, they experience **infertility** (不孕), **hemorrhoids** (瘾痔), **urinary incontinence** (遗溺), **dryness** (哑), and **vaginal dryness** (乾). This is due to the **Penetrating Vessel** and **Conception Vessel** ascending together from the **lower abdomen** (少腹) to the **throat** (咽喉), and the **Governing Vessel** following the **yin instrument** (阴器), converging at the **two orifices** (问), encircling the **anus** (篡) from behind, and then splitting to encircle the **buttocks** (臀). Hence, **infertility, hemorrhoids, urinary incontinence, dryness, and vaginal dryness** (不孕疮痔遗溺哑乾) occur.

The **Conception Vessel** is named as such because women receive it as a means of **nurturing life** (任养), hence the *Classic* states that this disease leads to **infertility** (不孕) in women. The **Penetrating Vessel** is named so because its **qi** ascends forcefully (上冲), causing the *Classic* to describe this disease as **pain ascending from the lower abdomen to the heart** (从少腹上冲心而痛). The **Governing Vessel** is named because it **supervises and leads** the **sea of meridians** (经脉之海).

Thus, these three vessels—**Conception, Penetrating, and Governing**—share a single source with three branches, sometimes being called collectively, which may seem confusing. Therefore, the following text states:

*The **Governing Vessel** disease is treated by needling the **Governing Vessel**, targeting the **bone above** (骨上). In severe cases, needle **below the navel** (齐下营). This is also the division of the **Conception Vessel** (任脉). The **Conception, Penetrating, and Governing Vessels** share the same name but differ in function, as clarified above.*

The **bone above** (骨上) refers to the **Lumbar Vertebrae** (腰横骨), specifically the **Hairline Interval** (髦际) and the **Curved Bone Orifice** (曲骨穴). The **Conception Vessel** is the **meeting point of the Lesser Yin** (足厥阴之会), and needling can penetrate to a depth of **1 cun** (同身寸之一寸半). If using **moxibustion** (灸), apply **three sessions** (三壮).

The **navel below** (齐下) refers to the **Yin Exchange Orifice** (阴交穴), located **1 cun** below the **navel** (齐直下同身寸之一寸). The **Conception Vessel** is the **meeting point of the Yin Penetrating** (阴冲之会), and needling can penetrate to a depth of **8 fen** (同身寸之八分). If using **moxibustion**, apply **five sessions** (五壮).

When the **ascending qi** (上气) produces a sound, treat the **central throat** (喉中央), specifically the **Heavenly Protrusion Orifice** (天突穴), located in the **midline of the supraclavicular fossa** (缺盆两问之中), **4 cun** below the **sternocleidomastoid junction** (颈结喉下同身寸之四寸中央), at the **Yin Maintenance** (阴维), the **meeting point of the Conception Vessel** (任脉之会). Needle with a **low-angle insertion** (低针), penetrating **1 cun** (同身寸之一寸), and retain the needle for **seven breaths** (七呼). If using **moxibustion**, apply **three sessions** (三壮).

For diseases where **qi ascends to the throat** (上冲喉), treat the **Gradual Orifice** (渐), which is located above the **chin** (侠颐). The **Yang Ming** (阳明) meridian ascends along the **chin** (渐上颐) and encircles the **lips** (环唇), hence the name **Gradual Orifice** (渐). This is known as the **Great Welcome** (大迎). The **Great Welcome** is situated in the **depression anterior to the condyloid process of the mandible** (曲颌前骨), **1 cun and 3 fen** below the **supraclavicular fossa** (同身寸之一寸三分陷), where the **qi of the Yang Ming meridian** (足阳明脉气) manifests. Needling can penetrate **3 fen** (同身寸之三分), and retain the needle for **seven breaths** (七呼). If using **moxibustion**, apply **three sessions** (三壮).

For **stiffness of the knee** that prevents bending or extending, treat the **Lan (楗)**.
**Lan** refers to the point above the **zangfu (脏辅) bone**, below the **horizontal bone (横骨)**, and in the center of the **outer thigh (股外)**. Locate it by standing beside the patient and palpating until the tendon moves under the hand.

For **knee pain while seated**, treat the **Ji (机)**, located where the **hip bones (髋骨)** meet on either side.

For **knee pain while standing, with heat in the knee joint (暑解)**, treat the **Hui Guan (骸关)**.
**Hui Guan** refers to the **knee joint (膝解)**. As one text states: *"When rising, the pain draws toward the knee joint."* Though the terms **暑 (heat)** and **引 (draw)** differ in meaning, **起 (rise)** and **立 (stand)** share a similar intent. If **knee pain extends to the big toe**, treat the **Wei (腘)**.
**Wei** is the **Weizhong (委中)** point, located behind the knee in the **hollow where the leg bends**, accessed from the back. The pulse moves under the hand—this is where the **Foot Taiyang (足太阳) meridian** enters. Needling may penetrate **five fen (同身寸之五分)**, retain for **seven breaths (七呼)**. If using **moxibustion**, apply **three sessions (三壮)**.

If **knee pain while seated feels as if something is hidden**, treat the **Guan (关)**, located above the **bink (胭)**, behind the **Dai (挞)**, accessed by standing behind the patient and pressing until the tendon moves under the hand.

For **knee pain preventing flexion or extension**, treat the **back’s inner region (背内)**, referring to the **Dazhu (大杼)** point.
Needling and moxibustion follow the same **division of sessions** as in *The Gas and Orifice Treatments (气穴)*.

If the **knee joint feels fractured (连腑若折)**, treat the **Yangming Zhongjiao (阳明中俞胶)**.
For **knee pain preventing movement, as if the joint were fractured**, needle the **Yangming meridian’s Zhongjiao (中俞胶)**, which corresponds to **Sanli (三里)**.
If the pain feels **as if the knee were separating (如别离)**, treat the **honor points (荣)** of **Juyang (巨阳)** and **Shaoyin (少阴)**.
The **Foot Taiyang honor point (足太阳荣)** is **Tonggu (通谷)**, located in the **hollow before the base joint of the little toe**, accessible from the outer side. Needling may penetrate **two fen (同身寸之二分)**, retain for **five breaths (五呼)**. If using **moxibustion**, apply **three sessions (三壮)**.
The **Foot Shaoyin honor point (足少阴荣)** is **Ranggu (然谷)**, located in the **hollow before the medial malleolus**, below the **large bone (大骨)**. Needling may penetrate **three fen (同身寸之三分)**, retain for **three breaths (三呼)**. If using **moxibustion**, apply **three sessions (三壮)**.

For **knee weakness with acidity (淫滦)**, unable to stand long, treat the **Shaoyang Wei (少阳之维)**.
*(Correction: According to the Jia Yi Jing, five cun above the lateral malleolus is the Foot Shaoyang luo (络), not Wei. The text likely contains an error.)*
Located **five cun (or four cun, per some texts)** above the **lateral malleolus (外踝)**. **淫滦** refers to a **weak, aching sensation without strength**.
*(Note: The Zhongyu Image Classic states there is no point four cun above the lateral malleolus; five cun corresponds to the Guangming (光明) point.)*
The **Foot Shaoyang luo (足少阳之络)** may be needled to **seven fen (同身寸之七分)**, retained for **ten breaths (十呼)**. If using **moxibustion**, apply **five sessions (五壮)**.
*(Correction: The Jia Yi Jing states needling should penetrate six fen, retained for seven breaths.)*

**Anatomical Clarifications:**
- Above the **zangfu (脏辅) bone**, below the **horizontal bone (横骨)** → **Dai (挞)**
- Beside the **hip (髋)** → **Ji (机)**
- The **knee joint (膝解)** → **Hui Guan (骸关)**
- Beside the **knee bone (侠膝之骨)** → **Lianhui (连骸)**
- Below the **hui (骸)** → **Fu (辅)**
- Above the **fu (辅)** → **Bink (胭)**
- Above the **bink (胭)** → **Guan (关)**
- The **horizontal bone on the head (头横骨)** → **Zhen (枕)**

Thus:
- **Zangfu bone above, waist-hip bone below** → **Dai (挞)**
- Above **Dai (挞)** → **Ji (机)**
- Outer **knee (膝外)** → **Hui Guan (骸关)**
- Behind **Dai (挞)** → **Guan (关)**
- Below **Guan (关)** → **Geng (蝈)**
- Below **bink (胭)** → **Fu (辅) bone**
- Above **fu (辅) bone** → **Lianhui (连骸)**
**Lianhui** refers to where the **hui (骸) bones connect**.
The **horizontal bone on the head** is the **occipital bone (枕骨)**.

**Water Orifice (水俞) – Fifty-Seven Points:**
Arranged in **five rows on the corpse (尸)**, **five rows on the upper body (伏菟)**, **two rows on the sides (左右)**, and **six rows above the ankles (踝上)**. Needling and moxibustion follow the divisions in *The Water-Heat Orifice Treatments (水热穴论)*. These are all **bone cavities**, hence their repetition in *The Gas and Orifice Treatments (气穴篇)*.

**Sui Kong (髓空)** is located **five fen behind the brain (脑后五分)**, below the **sharp bone at the nape (颤际锐骨)**, known as **Fengfu (风府)**, connecting to the **brain (通脑中)**.
One is located **below the gum base (龈基下)**, in the **hollow beneath the jawbone (颐下骨陷)**, containing a point the size of a **soybean (容豆)**, named **Xiaji (下绩)** in the *Zhongyu Image Classic*.
*(Note: **龈 (gēng)** is pronounced as in "silver")*

「One is located at the back of the neck (项), below the **Fùgǔ (复骨)**, known as the **Jímén (瘠门)** orifice. It is situated in the **soft hairline at the nape (项发际宛宛)**, entering the **tendon that connects to the root of the tongue (系舌本)**, where the **Dūmài (督脉)** and **Yángwéi (阳维)** channels converge. To locate it, tilt the head backward; needling may penetrate **four fen (分)** of the *tóngshēncǔn (同身寸)*. **Moxibustion (灸) is strictly prohibited (禁)** here.

One is located **above the spinal bone (脊骨)**, above **Fengfu (风府)**, known as the **Nǎohù (脑户)** orifice. It lies on the **occipital bone (枕骨)**, **one inch and five fen (一寸五分)** behind the **Dàyǔ (大羽)** point, where the **Dūmài (督脉)** and **Zú-Tàiyáng (足太阳)** channels converge. This is the **alternate orifice of the brain (别脑之户)**; moxibustion must not be applied recklessly, as improper use may cause **emaciation (瘠)**. Needling may penetrate **three fen (三分)**, with a retention of **three breaths (三呼)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic (甲乙经)*, **Dàyǔ (大羽)** is an alternate name for **Qiángyī (强一)**. The *Gas and Orifices (气府)* commentary notes: If moxibustion is applied, it may be done with **five units of strength (五壮)**.

The **hollow beneath the spinal bone (脊骨下空)** is located below the **Fùgǔ (复骨)** on the corpse. It is **not indicated for treatment (不应主疗)**, and its name is omitted in the *Classic (经)*. ○ *Newly corrected text* states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic (甲乙经)*, **Chángqiáng (长强)** lies at the end of the spinal bone, directly below the **Fùgǔ (复骨)** on the corpse. **Wang’s School (王氏)** notes: It is **not indicated for treatment**, and its name is omitted in the *Classic*. Perhaps this was an error (得非误乎)?」

**Marrow Cavities (髓空) and their Treatments:**

The **Marrow Cavities (髓空)** are numbered beneath the nose (面侠鼻), referring to apertures such as **the cranial orifices (颅髅等穴)**. The *Classic (经)* does not mark them with two fingers; their location is slight. Some say the **Marrow Cavity (骨空)** lies below the mouth, between the two shoulders. This refers to the **Great Welcoming Aperture (大迎穴)**. Needling or moxibustion here follows the same **units of strength (壮)** as the previous **premaxillary cavity (侠颐)**.

The **Marrow Cavity of the Arms (两膊骨空)** is found on the **sunny side of the arms (膊中之阳)**, near the **Shoulder Depression Aperture (肩髑穴)**. The *Classic (经)* does not name it.

The **Marrow Cavity of the Forearm (臂骨空)** lies on the **forearm’s sunny side (臂阳)**, four inches from the **ankle (踝)**, between two bones. It is one inch above **Supporting Valley (支沟)**, known as **Passage Cavity (通问)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic (甲乙经)*, one inch above **Supporting Valley (支沟)** is named **Three Sunny Connections (三阳络)**. Could **Passage Cavity (通问)** be its alternate name?

The **Marrow Cavity of the Thigh (股骨上空)** lies on the **thigh’s sunny side (股阳)**, emerging four inches above the **upper knee (上膝)**. It is found above **Hidden Beast (伏菟)** and below **Bearing the Whip (承挞)**.

The **Marrow Cavity of the Hip (腑骨空)** lies on the **upper end of the hip bone (辅骨之上端)**, referring to the **Calf’s Nose Aperture (犊鼻穴)**. It is located beneath the **hip bone (髋)**, beside the **great tendon (大筋)**, where the **Foot Yangming (足阳明)** pulse originates. Needling may reach **six-tenths of the same-body inch (同身寸之六分)**. Moxibustion may apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

The **Marrow Cavity of the Groin (股际骨空)** lies below the **Groin’s Movement (毛中动)**. The *Classic (经)* omits its name.

The **Corpse Bone Cavity (尸骨空)** lies behind the **Separating Bone (解骨)**, four inches away. This is known as the **Eight Lacerations Above the Corpse Bone (尸骨上八僇穴)**.

The **Flat Bone (扁骨)** has **permeating patterns (渗理赓)**, but no marrow cavity. If the bone lacks a cavity, the marrow also lacks an opening.

The **Shoulder Bone (肩骨)**, also called **Corpse Bone (尸问)** and **Flat Bone (扁戾骨)**, has **permeating channels (渗灌文理归奏)** on its surface but no distinct marrow cavity.

**Easy (易)**, meaning "thus," confirms that if a bone has a cavity, the marrow has an opening, and if the bone lacks a cavity, the marrow also lacks an opening.

**Moxibustion for Cold and Heat (寒热之法):**
First, apply moxibustion to **Great Spine (大椎)**, using **units of strength (壮)** equal to the patient’s age, as with counting breaths. Next, apply moxibustion to **Root Bone (根骨)**, also called **Tail’s End (尾穷)**, using the same method.

Observe the **sunken points on the back (背俞陷)** and apply moxibustion there—these are the **depressions between the scapula and spine (骨际有陷处)**. Lift the arm to locate sunken points above the shoulder; this is the **Shoulder Pair Aperture (肩偶穴)**. Between the two bones at the **shoulder’s end (肩端)**, where the **Hand Yangming (手阳明)** and **Treading Pulse (踏脉)** converge, needling may reach **six-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **six breaths (六呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

Apply moxibustion between the **two flanks (两季胁)**, at the **Capital Gate Aperture (京门穴)**, the **kidney’s gathering point (肾募)**. Located where the **iliac bone (骼骨)** meets the **lumbar region (腰中)** and the **flank’s root (季胁本)**, beside the spine, needling may reach **three-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **seven breaths (七呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

Apply moxibustion at the **upper end of the absolute bone (绝骨之端)** above the **outer ankle (外踝)**, referring to the **Yang Support Aperture (阳辅穴)**. Found on the **outer ankle (足外踝)** before the **absolute bone (绝骨)**, three-tenths of the same-body inch from the **ankle’s hollow (丘虚)**, where the **Foot Shaoyang (足少阳)** pulse flows, needling may reach **five-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **seven breaths (七呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic (甲乙经)*, it should be four inches above the outer ankle.

Apply moxibustion between the **second and third toes (小指次指)** of the foot, at the **Beside the Stream Aperture (侠溪穴)**. Found on the **second toe’s forked bone (次指歧骨)** before the **node (本节)** and the sunken point, where the **Foot Shaoyang (足少阳)** pulse flows, needling may reach **three-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **three breaths (三呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic (甲乙经)*, **flow (流)** should be **retained (留)**.

Apply moxibustion to the **sunken pulse below the heel (踹下陷脉)**, referring to the **Bearing Tendon Aperture (承筋穴)**. Found in the **center of the heel (瑞中央)** where the pulse sinks, it is where the **Foot Taiyang (足太阳)** pulse originates. Needling is **forbidden (禁)**; moxibustion may apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to the *Needling for Lumbar Pain (刺腰痛篇)* commentary, the **heel’s center (踹中央)** is like the **outer sunken point (外陷者中)**.

Apply moxibustion behind the **outer ankle (外踝)**, referring to the **Kunlun Aperture (昆仑穴)**. Found on the **heel bone (跟骨)** behind the outer ankle where the pulse sinks, fine vessels move in response to pressure. This is where the **Foot Taiyang (足太阳)** pulse flows. Needling may reach **five-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **ten breaths (十呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

Apply moxibustion to the **firm, tendinous point above the sternum’s cavity (缺盆骨上切之坚动)**. The *Classic (经)* omits its name; moxibustion should be applied according to its location.

Apply moxibustion between the **sunken bones in the chest’s center (膺中陷骨问)**, referring to the **Heavenly Piercing Aperture (天突穴)**. Needling or moxibustion follows the same **units of strength (壮)** as the previous sternal cavity (缺盆中).

Apply moxibustion below the **wrist’s bundle (掌束骨下)**, referring to the **Yang Pool Aperture (阳池穴)**. Found on the **inner wrist (手表腕)** where the pulse sinks, it is where the **Hand Shaoyang (手少阳)** pulse passes. Needling may reach **two-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **six breaths (六呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

Apply moxibustion three inches below the **navel (脐)**, at **Guanyuan (关元)**, directly below the navel, three same-body inches, where the **Three Yin of the Foot (足三阴)** and **Task Pulse (任脉)** converge. Needling may reach **two same-body inches (二寸)**, leaving **seven breaths (七呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **seven units of strength (七壮)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to the *Gas and Orifices (气府)* commentary, the statement "needling may reach **one inch and two-tenths (一寸二分)**" is incorrect.

Apply moxibustion to the **pulsing artery at the groin’s edge (毛际动脉)**, where the pulse moves in response to pressure—this is the **Gas Street Aperture (气街穴)**.

Apply moxibustion three inches below the **knee (膝下三寸)**, at the **Three Miles Aperture (三里穴)**. Found three same-body inches below the knee, outside the **hip bone (腑骨)** and between the **two tendons (康两筋肉)**, where the **Foot Yangming (足阳明)** pulse enters, needling may reach **one same-body inch (一寸)**, leaving **seven breaths (七呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

Apply moxibustion to the **pulsing artery above the foot’s Yangming (足阳明驸上动脉)**, referring to the **Rushing Yang Aperture (冲阳穴)**. Found five same-body inches above the **foot’s Yangming**, where the artery pulses between the bones, it is where the **Foot Yangming (足阳明)** pulse passes. Needling may reach **three-tenths of the same-body inch**, leaving **ten breaths (十呼)**. If moxibustion is used, apply **three units of strength (三壮)**.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic (甲乙经)* and **Quan Yuanqi’s (全元起)** original text, below the **Foot Yangming (足阳明)** there should be **moxibustion applied (灸之)**. The two apertures—**Rushing Yang (冲阳)** and **Pulsing Artery Above the Foot’s Yangming (驸上动脉)**—are now distinguished, but the *Classic* omits **moxibustion applied (灸之)**. Here, we retain the **moxibustion applied (灸之)** in the commentary for verification.

Apply moxibustion to the **apex above (巅上一灸之)**,

The **Baihui (百会)** acupoint is also one. Located at the crown’s center, within the whorl of hair where the depression of the finger fits, it is the convergence of the **Governing Vessel (督脉)** and the **Foot Taiyang (足太阳)** pulse. Needling may reach **three-tenths of the same-body inch**, or if moxibustion is applied, **five units of strength (五壮)** may be used.

Where a dog bites, apply moxibustion with **three units of strength (三壮)**. This follows the method of moxibustion for dog injuries. If a dog bite causes **chill and fever (寒热)**, apply moxibustion with **three units of strength (三壮)** using the dog-injury method.

○ *Newly corrected text (新校正)* states: If the **Foot Yangming (足阳明)** does not distinguish moxibustion separately, there would be only **twenty-eight points (二十八处)**. It is doubtful that Master Wang omitted the earlier moxibustion method. If the condition does not cease, one must examine the meridian that passes through the **Yang (阳)** side, repeatedly needle its **acupoints (俞)** and administer medicine.

**Chapter on the Water-Heat Acupoints (水热穴论篇)**
The Yellow Emperor asked: Why does the **Shao Yin (少阴)** meridian govern the **kidney (肾)**?
Why does the kidney govern **water (水)**?

Qibo replied: The kidney is the **ultimate Yin (至阴)**, and the ultimate Yin is where **water (水)** flourishes.
The **lung (肺)** is **Tai Yin (太阴)**, and the Shao Yin is the **winter pulse (冬脉)**.
Thus, its root lies in the kidney, its extremity in the lung; both accumulate **water (水)**.
Yin refers to **cold (寒)**. In winter, when cold reaches its peak, the kidney’s **qi (气)** resonates in harmony, hence it is said: *The kidney is the ultimate Yin*.
Water is sovereign in winter, hence it is said: *The ultimate Yin is where water flourishes*.
The **Shao Yin kidney meridian (肾少阴脉)** ascends from the kidney, piercing the **liver (肝)** and diaphragm, and entering the lung, hence it is said: *Its root lies in the kidney, its extremity in the lung*.
When the kidney’s **qi (气)** ascends in reverse, **water-qi (水气)** lodges in the lung, hence it is said: *Both accumulate water*.

The Yellow Emperor asked: How can the kidney accumulate water and cause illness?

Qibo replied: The kidney is the **gatekeeper of the stomach (胃之关)**, and when the gatekeeper’s passage is not smooth, water accumulates and follows its kind.
The gatekeeper regulates outflow and inflow; the kidney governs the **lower burner (下焦)**, with the **bladder (膀胱)** as its storehouse, overseeing its distribution and regulation. It controls the **two Yin orifices (二阴)**, hence when the kidney’s **qi (气)** flows, the two Yin orifices open, and when the two Yin orifices close, the stomach becomes full, hence it is said: *The kidney is the gatekeeper of the stomach*.
When the gatekeeper is closed, water accumulates; when water accumulates, **qi (气)** stagnates; when **qi (气)** stagnates, water forms; when water forms, **qi (气)** overflows. Water and **qi (气)** share the same nature, hence it is said: *When the gatekeeper’s passage is not smooth, water accumulates and follows its kind*.
*The Ling Shu Classic (灵枢经)* states: *The lower burner overflows as water*.
This is what is meant.

「Its essence is concealed. When the **qi (气)** and water overflow into the skin, **púzhǒng (驸肿)** ensues. **Púzhǒng (驸肿)** is the result of water accumulation giving rise to illness. "Upper" refers to the **lung (肺)**, and "lower" to the **kidney (肾)**. When both the lung and kidney overflow, water gathers in the abdomen and illness follows. The Emperor asked: "Does all water originate from the kidney?" Qī Bó (岐伯) replied: "The kidney is the **female organ (牝藏)**—**female (牝)**, meaning **Yin (阴)**—and it governs **Yin (阴)** positions, hence it is called the **female organ (牝藏)**. Earth **qi (气)** ascending belongs to the kidney, generating **fluids (水液)**, thus the kidney is said to receive the **sun’s daily descent into the Yin (日至阴)**.

Excessive exertion and overstrain cause **kidney sweat (肾汗)** to emerge. When this sweat encounters **wind (风)**, it cannot enter internally into the **storehouse (藏府)**, nor exit externally beyond the skin. Instead, it lingers in the **mysterious storehouse (玄府)**, circulating within the skin layers, transforming into **púzhǒng (驸肿)**. Its root lies in the kidney, and it is named **wind-water (风水)**. "Excessive exertion and overstrain" refers to **sexual overindulgence (力房)**. When **sexual overindulgence (劳勇)** causes sweating, the **mysterious storehouse (玄府)** opens; but if sweat then encounters **wind (风)**, the **mysterious storehouse (玄府)** closes again. Once closed, residual sweat cannot escape, pooling beneath the skin and converting into water, following the **wind (风)**. Thus, it is called **wind-water (风水)**.

The so-called **mysterious storehouse (玄府)** is the **sweat cavity (汗空)**. Sweat **qi (气)** is dark, emerging from this cavity, and gathering in the skin layers—hence the term **mysterious storehouse (玄府)**. **府 (府)** means "to gather."

The Emperor asked: "The **water acupoints (水俞)** number fifty-seven—what organ governs them?" Qī Bó (岐伯) replied: "The kidney has fifty-seven **acupoints (俞)**, where accumulated **Yin (积阴)** gathers, and from which water enters and exits. The five **rows (五行)** of **acupoints (俞)** on the corpse correspond to this—they are the **kidney’s acupoints (肾俞)**. The **acupoints (俞)** along the back span nearly five rows, with the central one emanating from the **Governing Vessel (督脉)**, and the four adjacent rows belonging to the **Foot Taiyang meridian (足太阳脉)**.

Thus, water-related illnesses manifest as **púzhǒng (驸肿)** and abdominal distension below, or **wheezing and labored breathing (喘呼)** above. When water settles in the kidney, it spreads downward to the abdomen and legs, causing **púzhǒng (驸肿)**. When it ascends into the lung, it triggers **wheezing and dyspnea (喘息)**, with sudden, forceful exhalations.

If water cannot be expelled externally, both the **manifestation (标)** and **root (本)** fall ill. The **manifestation (标)** is the lung, and the **root (本)** is the kidney. In such cases, it is a disease of **water accumulation in both lung and kidney (肺肾俱水)**. Hence, the lung governs **wheezing and labored breathing (喘呼)**, while the kidney governs **water retention and edema (水肿)**. The lung’s role in **wheezing and labored breathing (喘呼)** stems from its control over **respiration (呼吸)**; the kidney’s role in **water retention and edema (水肿)** arises from its governance over water.

Their **acupoints (俞)** interrelate and support one another, and both are affected by **water-qi (水气)**. If we partition their respective locations by name, it reflects the **meridians’ mutual correspondence (气相输应)**. If we trace the shared affliction to the **pathogenic water-qi (病气)**, it is all due to **water retention (水所留)**. "Retention" (留) is pronounced as **liú (力救切)**.

「Above the *fú tú* (伏菟, *tú* pronounced as *tù* 兔), there are two rows of five acupoints each—this is the **street of the kidney (肾之街)**, for *street (街)* refers to the **Dao/Way (道)**. In the abdominal region, there are five rows of central acupoints, with those on either side of the midline belonging to the **kidney’s stored meridian (足少阴脉)** and the **penetrating vessel (冲脉)**. The next rows outward belong to the **stomach’s府 (胃府)** and the **foot yang-ming meridian (足阳明脉)**. These four rows of acupoints lie above the *fú tú*.

The convergence of the three yin meridians at the foot is here. Below the ankle, there is one row of six acupoints each—this is the **kidney meridian’s downward course (肾脉之下行)**, named **Tàichōng (太冲)**. The kidney meridian and the penetrating vessel descend together along the foot, merging and expanding, hence the name *Tàichōng*.

All fifty-seven acupoints are the **hidden networks (阴络)** of the stored meridians, where **water-qi (水)** resides.

As the classics state, there are fifty-seven acupoints. On the back, five rows of five acupoints each align with the **governing vessel (督脉)** along the spine’s midline: **Jǐngzhōng (脊中)**, **Xuánshū (悬枢)**, **Mìngmén (命门)**, **Yāoshǔ (腰俞)**, and **Chángqiáng (长强)** lie in their respective positions.

Next, flanking the governing vessel on both sides, the **foot taiyang meridian (足太阳脉)** gives rise to: **Dàchángshǔ (大肠俞)**, **Xiǎochángshǔ (小肠俞)**, **Pángguāngshǔ (膀胱俞)**, **Zhōnggé-Nèishǔ (中膂内俞)**, and **Bái Huánshǔ (白环俞)**.

Further outward, the **foot taiyang meridian (足太阳脉)** again gives rise to: **Wèicāng (胃仓)**, **Huāngmén (肓门)**, **Zhìshì (志室)**, **Bāohuāng (胞肓)**, and **Zhìbiān (秩边)**.

Above the *fú tú*, there are two rows of five acupoints each. In the abdominal region, along the midline and flanking the **conception vessel (任脉)** and the **penetrating vessel (冲脉)**, where the **foot minor-yin meridian (足少阴)** converges, are: **Zhōngzhù (中注)**, **Sì Mǎn (四满)**, **Qìxué (气穴)**, **Dà Hè (大赫)**, and **Hénggǔ (横骨)**.

Next, flanking the **penetrating vessel (冲脉)** and the **foot minor-yin meridian (足少阴)**, the **foot yang-ming meridian (足阳明脉)** gives rise to: **Wàilíng (外陵)**, **Dàjù (大巨)**, **Shuǐdào (水道)**, **Guīlái (归来)**, and **Qìjiē (气街)**.

Below the ankle, there is one row of six acupoints each. On the upper inner ankle, the **foot minor-yin meridian (足少阴)** and the **yin-tà (阴踏)** meridian ascend along the medial malleolus. The **foot minor-yin meridian (足少阴)** contains **Dàzhōng (大钟)**, **Fùliú (复溜)**, and **Yīngǔ (阴谷)**. The **yin-tà meridian (阴踏)** contains **Zhàohǎi (照海)**, **Jiāoxìn (交信)**, and **Zhùbīn (筑宾)**. Though the **yin-tà** is a branch of the **foot minor-yin meridian (足少阴)**, it may also be governed as such. Counting these, one acupoint remains unaccounted for.

**Jǐngzhōng (脊中)** is located below the eleventh thoracic vertebra. To locate it, the patient should bend forward; the needle may be inserted to a depth of five *shēncǔn* (身寸, body-inch) divisions, but moxibustion is prohibited, as it may cause harm.

**Xuánshū (悬枢)** is located below the thirteenth thoracic vertebra. To locate it, the patient should bend forward; the needle may be inserted to a depth of three *shēncǔn* divisions, or moxibustion may be applied three times.

**Mìngmén (命门)** is located below the fourteenth thoracic vertebra. To locate it, the patient should lie prone; the needle may be inserted to a depth of five *shēncǔn* divisions, or moxibustion may be applied three times.

**Yāoshǔ (腰俞)** is located below the twenty-first thoracic vertebra. The needle may be inserted to a depth of two *shēncǔn* divisions. [Correction: According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* and *Miǔ Cì Lùn*, as well as the *Rè Xué* notes, the insertion depth is two *cùn* (寸). However, the *Cì Rè* and *Qì Fǔ* notes, along with this text, specify two *shēncǔn* divisions, and this should be followed.] After seven breaths, moxibustion may be applied three times.

**Chángqiáng (长强)** is at the sacral hiatus, a branch of the **governing vessel (督脉)** and a convergence of the **foot minor-yin meridian (足少阴)**. The needle may be inserted to a depth of two *shēncǔn* divisions, and after seven breaths, moxibustion may be applied three times. These five acupoints all belong to the **governing vessel (督脉)**.

[Correction: As detailed by Wang, one acupoint is missing. According to the *Qì Fǔ Lùn* notes, there is a **Yángguān (阳关)** acupoint below the twelfth thoracic vertebra. If counted, this accounts for the missing one.]

Next, flanking the **governing vessel (督脉)**, **Dàchángshǔ (大肠俞)** is located below the sixteenth thoracic vertebra, one-and-a-half *shēncǔn* from the **governing vessel (督脉)** on either side. The needle may be inserted to a depth of three *shēncǔn* divisions, and after six breaths, moxibustion may be applied three times.

**Xiǎochángshǔ (小肠俞)** is located below the eighteenth thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Dàchángshǔ (大肠俞)**.

**Pángguāngshǔ (膀胱俞)** is located below the nineteenth thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Dàchángshǔ (大肠俞)**.

**Zhōnggé-Nèishǔ (中膂内俞)** is located below the twentieth thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Dàchángshǔ (大肠俞)**. It lies beside the lumbar swelling, and the needle should be retained for ten breaths.

**Bái Huánshǔ (白环俞)** is located below the twenty-first thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same spacing as **Dàchángshǔ (大肠俞)**. To locate it, the patient should lie prone; the needle may be inserted to a depth of five *shēncǔn* divisions, or moxibustion may be applied three times.

[Correction: According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng*, the needle may be inserted to a depth of eight *fēn* (分), and moxibustion is prohibited.]

These five acupoints all belong to the **foot taiyang meridian (足太阳脉)**, which are referred to as the **kidney’s back-shu points (肾俞)**.

Further outward, **Wèicāng (胃仓)** is located below the twelfth thoracic vertebra on both sides, three *shēncǔn* apart. The needle may be inserted to a depth of five *shēncǔn* divisions, or moxibustion may be applied three times.

**Huāngmén (肓门)** is located below the thirteenth thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Wèicāng (胃仓)**.

**Zhìshì (志室)** is located below the fourteenth thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Wèicāng (胃仓)**. It is located while the patient sits upright.

**Bāohuāng (胞肓)** is located below the nineteenth thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Wèicāng (胃仓)**. To locate it, the patient should lie prone.

**Zhìbiān (秩边)** is located below the twenty-first thoracic vertebra on both sides, with the same needle insertion and moxibustion methods as **Wèicāng (胃仓)**. To locate it, the patient should lie prone.

These five acupoints all belong to the **foot taiyang meridian (足太阳脉)**.

Next, above the *fú tú*, there are two rows of acupoints. **Zhōngzhù (中注)** is located five *shēncǔn* divisions below the umbilicus, one *shēncǔn* from the **conception vessel (任脉)** on either side.

[Correction: According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* and the *Qì Fǔ* notes, though the text differs, the meaning is the same—one *cùn* (寸) from the midline.]

---

**Sìmǎn (四满)** is located one *cùn* below **Zhōngzhù (中注)**, on the midline. **Qìxué (气穴)** is one *cùn* below **Sìmǎn**, also on the midline. **Dàhè (大赫)** is one *cùn* below **Qìxué**, on the midline. **Hénggǔ (横骨)** is one *cùn* below **Dàhè**, on the midline. Each of these points is horizontally spaced one *cùn* from the midline, and they all belong to the **foot yangming meridian (足阳明脉)** and the **conception vessel (冲脉)** at its junction with the **foot lesser yin meridian (足少阴)**. Needling may reach one *cùn* deep; if moxibusting, five *zhuàng* may be applied.

Next are the two lateral points: **Wàilíng (外陵)** is one *cùn* below the umbilicus, on the midline.
[Correction: According to the *Qì Fǔ Lùn* (气府论), it is noted that **Wàilíng** is one *cùn* below **Tiānhéng (天枢)**. This is consistent with the above.]

The two lateral points are spaced one and a half *cùn* from the **conception vessel (冲脉)**. **Dàjù (大巨)** is one *cùn* below **Wàilíng**. **Shuǐdào (水道)** is three *cùn* below **Dàjù**. **Guīlái (归来)** is three *cùn* below **Shuǐdào**. **Qìjiē (气街)** is below **Guīlái**.

[Correction: According to the *Qì Fǔ* (气府), *Qì Rè* (刺热), and *Rèxué* (热穴) notes, **Qìjiē (气街)** is located one *cùn* above the **鼠眼 (shǔyǎn, "rat's eye")** on either end of **Hénggǔ (横骨)**. The *Qì Jìn* (刺禁) note states it is one *cùn* above the **鼠仆 (shǔpū, "rat's kneeling")** on the flanks of the abdomen, four *cùn* from the midline, where the pulse moves upon pressure. The *Gǔkōng* (骨空) note places it above the **鼠误 (shǔwù, "rat's error")** at the hairline. These notes differ, so I record them all.]

**鼠误 (Shǔwù)** is one *cùn* from the midline, with each point spaced two *cùn* apart horizontally.

The Emperor asked: *"Why in spring do we select the divergent meridian and the fleshly layer?"*
**Gībó (岐伯)** replied: *"Spring is when wood begins to dominate, and liver *qi* first arises. Liver *qi* is swift, its wind fierce, and the meridians lie deep with little *qi* present. Unable to penetrate deeply, we take the divergent meridians and the fleshly layer to reach the *qi*."*

The Emperor asked: *"Why in summer do we select the robust meridian and the victorious layer?"*
**Gībó** replied: *"Summer is when fire begins to dominate, and heart *qi* grows strong. The pulses are slender, the *qi* weak, and the yang *qi* overflows. Heat concentrates on the victorious layer, reaching even the meridians. Thus, we take the robust meridian and the victorious layer. When needling breaks the skin and the illness departs, the evil *qi* was shallow. 'Break' means to pierce through, allowing the illness to escape. The robust meridian refers to the yang meridians."*

The Emperor asked: *"Why in autumn do we select the meridian points and the convergences?"*
**Gībó** replied: *"Autumn is when metal begins to dominate, and the lungs prepare to withdraw and kill. The three yin meridians have already ascended#1, so metal gradually withdraws and kills. Metal overcomes fire, and the yang *qi* is at the convergences#2. The yin *qi* is just beginning to prevail, while damp *qi* reaches the body. With the gradual onset of rain, dampness, mist, and dew#3, we say damp *qi* reaches the body. The yin *qi* is not yet strong, so it cannot penetrate deeply. Thus, we take the points to disperse yin evil and the convergences to weaken yang evil. The yang *qi* begins to decline, so we take the convergences. This is the treatment variation of the early autumn."*

The Emperor asked: *"Why in winter do we select the well and spring points?"*
**Gībó** replied: *"Winter is when water begins to dominate, and the kidneys are closing. Yang *qi* is declining and weak, while yin *qi* is strong and firm. The greater yang meridian is submerged and recedes#4. The yang meridians then withdraw#5, so we take the well points to counter yin inversion and the spring points to nourish the yang *qi*.*
[Correction: According to **Quán Yuánqǐ (全元起)**, the original text reads *遣* (qiǎn, "dismiss") instead of *实* (shí, "nourish"), while the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* (甲乙经) and *Qiān Jīn Fāng* (千金方) read *通* (tōng, "unblock").]

Thus, it is said: *"In winter, take the well and spring points; in spring, do not take the convergences#6."* This is the treatment variation before winter.

[Correction: According to **Huángfǔ Shì’ān (皇甫士安)**, this refers to the treatment variation of early autumn.]

This is the principle.

[Correction: According to this text, the meaning differs significantly from the *Sìshí Qì Nì Fǒng* (四时刺逆从论) and *Zhěnyào Jīngzhōng Lùn* (诊要经终论), but aligns with the *Jiǔjuàn* (九卷).]

---

**On the ankle, there is one row of six points:**
**Dàzhōng (大钟)** is located behind the **inner ankle** at the **street (街)**.
[Correction: According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), it is noted as **冲中 (chōngzhōng, "central surge")** behind the heel. The *Qì Yuè* (刺疟) and *Qì Yāotòng* (刺腰痛) notes describe it as the **street (街)** behind the heel where the pulse moves. This text states "behind the inner ankle," which is incorrect.]

For the **foot lesser yin divergent meridian (足少阴络)**, which runs through the **foot taiyang meridian (足太阳)**, needling may reach two *cùn* deep, with retention for three breaths. If moxibusting, three *zhuàng* may be applied.

**Fùliù (复溜)** is located two *cùn* above the inner ankle, in the **陷者 (xiànzhě, "depression")**. It is where the **foot lesser yin meridian (足少阴脉)** passes. Needling may reach three *cùn* deep, with retention for three breaths. If moxibusting, five *zhuàng* may be applied.

**Zhàohǎi (照海)** is located below the inner ankle. Needling may reach four *cùn* deep, with retention for six breaths. If moxibusting, three *zhuàng* may be applied.

**Jiāoxìn (交信)** is located two *cùn* above the inner ankle, between the **lesser yin meridian (少阴)** in front and the **greater yin meridian (太阴)** behind, at the **street of Yīnjì (阴跻)**. Needling may reach four *cùn* deep, with retention for five breaths. If moxibusting, three *zhuàng* may be applied.

**Zhùbīn (筑宾)** is located at the upper division of the inner ankle, at the **street of Yīnwéi (阴维)**. Needling may reach three *cùn* deep. If moxibusting, five *zhuàng* may be applied.

**Yīngǔ (阴谷)** is located below the knee, behind the **inner condyle of the femur (内辅骨)**, beneath the **greater hamstring tendon (大筋)**, and above the **smaller hamstring tendon (小筋)**. Pressure here yields a response. It is found by flexing the knee, where the **foot lesser yin meridian (足少阴脉)** enters. Needling may reach four *cùn* deep. If moxibusting, three *zhuàng* may be applied.

The points below the **kidney meridian (肾经)** are collectively known as **Tàichōng (太冲)**.

---

The Yellow Emperor said: "Master, you spoke of treating heat diseases at fifty-nine points. I have pondered your meaning but cannot yet distinguish their exact locations. I wish to hear their precise locations and, in doing so, to understand your intent."

Qìbó (岐伯) replied: "The five points in the **central row of the head (头上五行行五者)** are used to **reverse the pathogenic heat of all the yang meridians (越诸阳之热逆)**.

The five points in the central row are:
- **Shàngxīng (上星)**, located directly above the **nasal bridge (鼻中央)** on the **cranium (颅)**, within the hairline, one *cùn* (寸) deep—**same-body measurement (同身寸)**—depressed to the width of a **middle finger (中容一很)**, needling may reach three *fēn* (分) of the *cùn*. Retention is for **six breaths (六呼)**. If moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.
- **Zìhuì (自会)**, one *cùn* behind **Shàngxīng (上星)**, depressed to the width of a **middle finger (中容一很)**, needling may reach four *fēn* of the *cùn*.
- **Qiántǐng (前顶)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* behind **Zìhuì (自会)**, between the bones, depressed—needling follows the method of **Zìhuì (自会)**.
- **Bǎihuì (百会)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* behind **Qiántǐng (前顶)**, at the **center of the crown (顶中央)**, where the hair whorls, depressed to the width of a **finger (容指)**, the convergence of the **Governing Vessel (督脉)** and the **foot greater yang meridian (足太阳脉)**. Needling follows the method of **Shàngxīng (上星)**.
- **Hòutǐng (后顶)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* behind **Bǎihuì (百会)**, on the **occipital bone (枕骨)**, needling follows the method of **Zìhuì (自会)**.

These five points are all where **qi of the Governing Vessel (督脉气)** emerges. **Shàngxīng (上星)** retains the needle for six breaths; if moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.

The next five points on the **lateral sides of the head (次两傍穴)** are:
- **Wǔchù (五处)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* from **Shàngxīng (上星)** on both sides.
- **Chéngguāng (承光)**, one *cùn* behind **Wǔchù (五处)**.
- **Tōngtiān (通天)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* behind **Chéngguāng (承光)**.
- **Luòquè (络却)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* behind **Tōngtiān (通天)**.
- **Yùzhěn (玉枕)**, seven *fēn* behind **Luòquè (络却)**.

These five points are all where **qi of the foot greater yang and foot lesser yang meridians (足太阳少阳)** and the **Yang Linking Vessel (阳维)** converge. Needling may reach three *fēn* of the *cùn*. **Wǔchù (五处)** and **Tōngtiān (通天)** each retain the needle for seven breaths; **Luòquè (络却)** for five breaths; and **Yùzhěn (玉枕)** for three breaths. If moxibusting, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.
*Annotation: According to the **Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙经)**, **Chéngguāng (承光)** is not moxibusted, and **Yùzhěn (玉枕)** is needled to a depth of two *fēn* of the *cùn*.*

The next five points on the **outer lateral sides of the head (又次两傍)** are:
- **Línqì (临泣)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* above the **eyes (目)**, within the hairline, the convergence of the **foot greater yang (足太阳)**, **foot lesser yang (少阳)**, and **Yang Linking Vessel (阳维)** meridians. Retention is for seven breaths; if moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.
- **Mùchuāng (目窗)**, one *cùn* from **Línqì (临泣)**.
- **Zhèngyíng (正营)**, one *cùn* from **Mùchuāng (目窗)**.
- **Chénglíng (承灵)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* from **Zhèngyíng (正营)**.
- **Nǎokōng (脑空)**, one *cùn* and five *fēn* from **Chénglíng (承灵)**.

These five points are all where **qi of the foot lesser yang and Yang Linking Vessel (足少阳阳维)** meridians converge. Needling may reach four *fēn* of the *cùn* for **Nǎokōng (脑空)** and three *fēn* of the *cùn* for the others.

The eight points below—**Dàzhū (大杼)**, **Yīngyǔ (膺俞)**, **Quēpén (缺盆)**, and **Bèiyǔ (背俞)**—are used to **drain heat from the chest (写胸中之热)**.

- **Dàzhū (大杼)** is located one *cùn* and five *fēn* from the **first cervical vertebra (项第一椎)** on both sides, the convergence of the **Governing Vessel (督脉)** and the **Separate Collateral of the hand and foot greater yang meridians (别络手足太阳)**. Needling may reach three *fēn* of the *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths; if moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.
*Annotation: According to the **Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙经)** and the note in the **Qi Xue (气穴)**, it is recorded as **seven cones (七壮)** for moxibustion, while the notes in **Sutras for Treating Malaria (刺疟)** and **Sutras for Treating Heat (刺热)** record **five cones (五壮)**.*

- **Yīngyǔ (膺俞)**, also known as **Zhōngfǔ (中府)**, is located in the **chest center (胸中)**, one *cùn* and six *fēn* from the midline on both sides, one *cùn* below **Yúnmén (云门)**, between the **third and fourth ribs (乳上三肋)**, where the **pulsing artery (动脉)** responds to pressure, depressed. It is taken while reclining, the convergence of the **hand and foot lesser yin meridians (手足太阴)**. Needling may reach three *fēn* of the *cùn*, with retention for five breaths; if moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.

- **Quēpén (缺盆)** is located in the depression of the **horizontal bone of the shoulder (肩上横骨)**, where the **qi of the hand greater yang meridian (手阳明脉气)** emerges. Needling may reach two *fēn* of the *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths; if moxibusting, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

- **Bèiyǔ (背俞)**, also known as **Fēngmén (风门)** and **Rèfǔyǔ (热府俞)**, is located one *cùn* and five *fēn* from the **second cervical vertebra (第二椎)** on both sides, the convergence of the **Governing Vessel (督脉)** and the **foot greater yang meridian (足太阳)**. Needling may reach five *fēn* of the *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths; if moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.
*Annotation: According to the **Zhèngyào Kǒng Xuē Tújīng (中诰孔穴图经)**, the name is not given here, but it is referred to as **Fēngmén (风门)** and **Rèfǔ (热府)**, which are the **back points for treating heat (背俞)**.*

- **Rèfǔ (热府)**, as recorded in the **Sutras for Treating Heat (刺热论)**, is unclear as to its exact location, but here it is specifically indicated as **Fēngmén (风门)** and **Rèfǔ (热府)**. In the **Qi Xue (气穴论)**, it is noted that **Dàzhū (大杼)** is the **back point for treating heat (背俞)**. The discrepancies in these three annotations suggest confusion among the commentators.

The next eight points—**Qìjiē (气街)**, **Sānlǐ (三里)**, **Jùxū (巨虚)** with its **upper (上)** and **lower (下)** **Lian (廉)**—are used to **drain heat from the stomach (写胃中之热)**.

- **Qìjiē (气街)** is located below the **umbilicus (腹齐)**, at the **ends of the transverse bone (横骨)**, one *cùn* above the **pubic symphysis (鼠辱)**, where the **pulsing artery (动脉)** responds to pressure. It is where **qi of the foot greater yang meridian (足阳明脉气)** emerges. Needling may reach three *fēn* of the *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths; if moxibusting, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.
*Annotation: The various annotations for **Qìjiē (气街)** differ; see the previous notes in the **Shuǐ Xuē (水穴)**.*

- **Sānlǐ (三里)** is located three *cùn* below the **knee (膝)**, outside the **patella (腑)**, between the **two hamstring tendons (两筋)** and the **muscles (肉)**, where the **foot greater yang meridian (足阳明脉)** enters. Needling may reach one *cùn*, with retention for seven breaths; if moxibusting, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

- **Jùxū (巨虚) Shànglián (上廉)**, where the **foot greater yang (足阳明)** and **foot greater yang (太阳)** meridians converge, is located three *cùn* below **Sānlǐ (三里)**, where **qi of the foot greater yang meridian (足阳明脉气)** emerges. Needling may reach eight *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibusting, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

- **Jùxū (巨虚) Xiàlián (下廉)**, where the **foot greater yang (足阳明)** and **foot lesser yang (少阳)** meridians converge, is located three *cùn* below **Shànglián (上廉)**, where **qi of the foot greater yang meridian (足阳明脉气)** emerges. Needling may reach three *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibusting, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

Yúnmén (云门), *kēgǔ* (髁骨), Wěizhōng (委中), and *suǐkōng* (髓空)—these eight points are used to **dispel** the **heat** of the four limbs.

- **Yúnmén (云门)** is located below **Jùgǔ (巨骨)**, along the chest’s midline, three *cùn* apart from the sides. The **pulse** responds upon touch, where **qi of the foot greater yin meridian (足太阴脉气)** emerges. *(○ Newly corrected: According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* (甲乙经) and the annotation of *Qì Xué* (气穴), as well as the annotation of *Cì Rè* (刺热), it should be **hand greater yin meridian (手太阴)**.)*
  *(○ Raise the arm to locate it; needling may reach seven *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibusting, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.)*

- **Kēgǔ (髁骨)** *(now **Jiānkē (肩髑)** in the *Zhōnghuì Kǒng Xué Tújīng* (中诰孔穴图经)) lies between the two bones at the shoulder’s end, where the **hand greater yang meridian (手阳明)** and **foot greater yang meridian (足太阳)** converge. Needling may reach six *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

- **Wěizhōng (委中)** is located at the back of the knee when bent, where the **popliteal artery (胭中央)** and **saphenous vein (文中)** pulsate. It is where the **foot greater yang meridian (足太阳脉)** enters. Needling may reach five *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

- *Suǐkōng (髓空)* *(now known as **Yāoyú (腰俞)** in the *Zhōnghuì Kǒng Xué Tújīng*)* is located below the **21st vertebra (第二十一椎节)** of the spine. It governs **failure of sweat (汗不出)** and **numbness of the feet (足清不仁)**. Here, **qi of the Governing meridian (督脉)** emerges. Needling may reach two *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied. *(○ Newly corrected: The needling depth of two *cùn* for Yāoyú should be two *fēn*; this is already detailed in the previous #5 annotation of *Shuǐ Xué* (水穴).)*

The **five yū points beside the spine (俞傍五)**, namely **Pòhù (魄户)**, *Shéntáng* (神堂), **Húnmén (魂门)**, **Yìhé (意合)**, and **Zhìshì (志室)**, are located three *cùn* apart from the midline on either side of the spine. All are where **qi of the foot greater yang meridian (足太阳脉气)** emerges.

- **Pòhù (魄户)** is located three *cùn* beside the **3rd vertebra (第三椎)**. In a seated position, needling may reach five *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.
- *Shéntáng (神堂)* is located three *cùn* beside the **5th vertebra (第五椎)**. Needling may reach three *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **five cones (五壮)** may be applied.
- **Húnmén (魂门)** is located three *cùn* beside the **9th vertebra (第九椎)**. In a seated position, needling may reach five *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.
- **Yìhé (意合)** *(now **Yìshè (意舍)**)* is located three *cùn* beside the **11th vertebra (第十一椎)**. In a seated position, needling may reach five *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.
- **Zhìshì (志室)** is located three *cùn* beside the **14th vertebra (第十四椎)**. In a seated position, needling may reach five *fēn* of the *cùn*; if moxibustion, **three cones (三壮)** may be applied.

All these **fifty-nine points (五十九穴)** are for treating **heat** on the left and right sides.

The Emperor said: *"When a person is injured by cold, how does it then become heat?"*

Gūibó (岐伯) replied: *"Cold in excess generates heat. When cold *qi* congeals externally, the **yang *qi* (阳气)** is suppressed internally. The **vital principles (胜理)**** become rigid and constrained, the **mysterious orifices (玄府)** are sealed shut. This causes *qi* to stagnate and fail to circulate freely, and the **humid *qi* (湿气)** to condense internally. The internal and external *qi* clash, and with cold prevailing, heat arises. Thus, when a person is injured by cold, it transforms into heat. Sweating to relieve it cures the condition, revealing the mechanism of external congealing and internal suppression. This is the case for new illnesses of several days."*

*(致, *zhì* or *chí* both acceptable.)*

The *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwén* **supplementary commentary** concludes for Volume Thirty-Five. #1 *"Shēng"* originally read as *"chéng"* (成), corrected according to the *Gù* edition. #2 *"Yǔ"* originally read as *"xià"* (下), corrected according to the *Xiǎn* edition. #3 *"Shǐ"* originally read as *"zhì"* (治); corrected according to the *Gù* edition. #4 *"Cì"* originally read as *"cì"* (刺), corrected according to the *Xiǎn* edition. #5 *"Lán"* originally read as *"qián"* (前), corrected according to the *Gù* edition. #6 *"Zhì"* in the *Gù* edition reads as *"wǔ"* (五). #7 The character *"zhì"* (志) below is similarly corrected.

**Volume Thirty-Six** of the *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwén* **supplementary commentary** presents the annotations of *Táng* Grand Steward *Qíxiānzǐ* **Wang Bīng**, followed by the *Sòng* Lightly Robed Grandee *Lín Yì* and others’ verification, and the *Sòng* Minister of War *Sūn Zhào*’s emendation of errors.

**Chapter: *Tiáojīng Lùn* (调经论)**

The Emperor asked: *"I have heard that acupuncture follows the principle of **‘excess is drained, deficiency is supplemented’ (刺法喜向，有余写之，不足补之)**. What is meant by **‘excess’ (有余)**? What is meant by **‘deficiency’ (不足)**?"*

Gūibó replied: *"Both excess and deficiency have five aspects—deficiency also has five. Your Majesty wishes to inquire which?"*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear it all."*

Gūibó said: *"The **spirit (神)** has excess and deficiency, the **qi (气)** has excess and deficiency, the **blood (血)** has excess and deficiency, the **body form (形)** has excess and deficiency, and the **will/intent (志)** has excess and deficiency. Altogether, these ten aspects are where the **imbalances of *qi* (气不等)** arise.

The **spirit (神)** belongs to the Heart, the **qi (气)** belongs to the Lungs, the **blood (血)** belongs to the Liver, the **body form (形)** belongs to the Spleen, and the **will/intent (志)** belongs to the Kidneys. Since each organ has its own governing principle, the imbalances arise.

The Emperor said: *"Humans possess **essence, *qi*, bodily fluids, and humors (精气津液)**; four limbs and nine orifices; five **viscera (藏)** and sixteen divisions; three hundred and sixty-five **nodes (节)**. From these arise a hundred diseases, and all diseases are marked by **‘void and repletion’ (虚实)**. Now, Master, you speak of five excesses and five deficiencies—how do they give rise to disease?"*

The *Zhēnjīng* states: *"The two **spirits (神)** intermingle, coalesce to form the body, and first arise as **essence (精)**. The **upper burner (上焦)**** opens and releases, disseminating the flavors of the five grains. It nourishes the skin, fills the body, and moistens the hair, like mist and dew watering the earth—this is **‘*qi* (气)**. When the **vital principles (胜理)**** discharge, and sweat emerges from the **vital principles (胜理)****, this is **‘bodily fluids (津)**. When **bodily fluids (津)**** seep into the **void orifices (空窍)****, and stagnate without flowing freely, they become **‘humors (液)**.

The **sixteen divisions (十六部)**** refer to the two hands, two feet, and nine orifices—totaling sixteen divisions. The **three hundred and sixty-five nodes (三百六十五节)**** do not refer to **‘joints (骨节)****, but rather to the places where **spirit and *qi* (神气)**** enter and exit."*

The *Zhēnjīng* further states: *"The **‘intersections of nodes’ (节之交)****, the three hundred and sixty-five **‘convergences’ (会)****, are all where **spirit and *qi* (神气)**** enter, exit, and circulate. They are not **‘joints (骨节)****. How do diseases arise from the **‘many and few’ (所有则多，所举则少)**** of the body’s nodes? Gūibó replied: *"All diseases arise from the five **viscera (藏)****. Specifically, from the five **spiritual viscera (神藏)****.

The Heart houses the **spirit (神)****, the Lungs house the **qi (气)****, the Liver houses the **blood (血)****, the Spleen houses the **flesh (肉)****, and the Kidneys house the **will/intent (志)****. These principles coalesce to form the body.

How do diseases arise from the five **viscera (藏)****? It is because the **five spiritual principles (五神)**** are housed within and form the viscera. When the **will/intent (志意)**** is harmonious, it internally connects with the **bone marrow (骨髓)****, thus forming the body, the viscera, and the five **spiritual principles (神)****. The **will/intent (志意)**** refers to the **‘great faculties’ (大几)**** of the five spiritual principles. The **bone marrow (骨髓)**** refers to the **‘outer manifestations and transformations’ (表裹之成化)****.

When the five spiritual principles are harmonious and the bone marrow transforms fully, the body and viscera are established, and then the five viscera mutually influence each other’s excesses and deficiencies."*

**New verification** states: *"According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), there are no characters **‘viscera (藏)****. The principles of the five viscera all emerge from the **‘channels and collaterals (经隧)****, which circulate **blood and *qi* (血气)****. When **blood and *qi* (血气)**** are disharmonious, a hundred diseases arise and transform. Thus, one must **‘guard the channels and collaterals (守经隧)****. The **‘collaterals’ (隧)**** are the **‘hidden pathways (潜道)****. The **‘channels’ (经脉)**** run deep and unseen, hence they are called **‘channels and collaterals (经隧)****. **Blood and *qi* (血气)**** are the **‘spirit’ (神)**** of humans; when **‘evil’ (邪)**** invades, **blood and *qi* (血气)**** become irregular, and irregular **blood and *qi* (血气)**** cause a hundred diseases to arise and transform. The **‘channels’ (经脉)**** are what govern **‘life and death’ (死生)****, treat a hundred diseases, and **‘adjust void and repletion (虚实)****. Therefore, one must **‘guard the channels and collaterals (守经隧)***."*

**New verification** states: *"According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), **‘channels and collaterals (经隧)**** are written as **‘channels and conduits (经渠)****, but their meanings are the same. #1"*

The Emperor asked: *"What are the signs when the **spirit (神)**** has excess or deficiency?"*

Gūibó replied: *"When the **spirit (神)**** has excess, the person laughs incessantly; when the **spirit (神)**** is deficient, the person is melancholy. #2 This pertains to the Heart’s **‘house’ (藏)***. The *Zhēnjīng* states: *"The Heart houses the **pulse (脉)****, and the **pulse (脉)**** contains the **spirit (神)****. When the Heart’s **‘*qi* (气)**** is void, the person is melancholy; when it is replete, the person laughs incessantly. Melancholy, in one case, is **‘worry’ (忧)***—this is an error."*

**New verification** states: *"Upon careful review, Master Wang’s annotation states: **‘Melancholy, in one case, is **‘worry’ (忧)***—this is an error.’** According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经) and *Tàisū* (太素), as well as the full edition of the *Yuánqǐ* (元起) commentary, it is all written as **‘worry’ (忧)***. **Huángfǔ Shì’ān** (皇甫士安) states: *"When the Heart is void, it causes melancholy; melancholy leads to worry. When the Heart is replete, it causes laughter; laughter leads to joy. The Heart and Lungs, and the Spleen and Heart, mutually form each other. Thus, joy originates in the Heart and completes in the Lungs; worry originates in the Spleen and completes in the Heart. When one exceeds its **‘proper measure’ (节)****, both viscera are injured."*

**Yáng Shàngshàn** (杨上善) states: *"The **‘melancholy’ (忧)**** of the Heart lies in its **‘variations’ (变动)****. The **‘melancholy’ (忧)**** of the Lungs lies in the **‘will/intent’ (志)**** of the Lungs. Thus, the Lungs govern autumn, and melancholy is their **‘proper emotion’ (正)****. The Heart governs summer, and its **‘variations’ (变)**** give rise to melancholy. Before **blood and *qi* (血气)**** coalesce, the five viscera are stable. When **‘evil’ (邪)**** lodges in the **‘body form’ (形)****, it first manifests as **‘shivering’ (洒淅)**** on the **‘hair follicles’ (毫毛)****, but has not yet entered the **‘channels and collaterals (经络)****. Thus, it is called **‘the subtle disease of spirit’ (神之微)***. Coalesce refers to **‘uniting’ (并合)****. Before uniting with **‘evil’ (邪)****, it is called **‘not yet united’ (未并)****. **‘Shivering’ (洒淅)**** is a cold appearance, first arising at the **‘hair follicles’ (毫毛)****, still within the **‘fine collaterals’ (小络)****. This is the **‘subtle disease of spirit’ (神之微病)****, hence it is called **‘the subtle disease of spirit’ (神之微)***."*

**New verification** states: *"According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), **‘shivering’ (洒淅)**** is written as **‘chill and convulsion’ (凄厥)****; in the *Tàisū* (太素), it is written as **‘pores and reverse flow’ (洫沂)****. **Yáng Shàngshàn** (杨上善) states: **‘*Xì* (洫)****, refers to **‘hair follicles/pores’ (毫毛)****; **‘reverse flow’ (逆流)**** is called **‘*yí* (沂)***.*"*

«When **evil qi** invades the **dominant meridians** (勝理), it behaves like water flowing backward through the **pores** (洫). The Yellow Emperor asked: *“How should one treat this with bloodletting and moxibustion?”*

Qibo replied: *“If **Dao/Way** (神) is in excess, one may let blood from its **fine collaterals** (小络) without piercing deeply into the **major meridians** (大經), thus restoring balance to **Dao/Way and qi** (神氣). Since the **evil** (邪) has entered the **fine collaterals** (小络), one may let blood from its **collateral pulses** (小络之脉), but avoid deep insertion of the needle—deep insertion risks harming the flesh. As the **evil** (邪) resides in the **fine collaterals** (小络), one must not allow the needle to strike the **major meridians** (大經). Once the **collateral blood** (络血) has been released, **Dao/Way and qi** (神氣) will naturally return to equilibrium.

*斥* (斥) means to **pierce deeply** (推). The **fine collaterals** (小络) are the **grand collaterals** (孙络). *“The *Needle Canon* (针经) states: The **major meridians** (經脉) are like **wrappings** (裹), while their **branches and horizontal extensions** (支而横者) are called **collaterals** (络). The **divergent pathways of the collaterals** (络之别者) are the **grand collaterals** (孙络).” Equilibrium refers to **harmonizing and regulating** (平调).

*The New Verification* states: *“This annotation cites the *Needle Canon* (针经) alongside the *Three Divisions and Nine Lords Treatise* (三部九侯论), where the latter refers to it as the *Miraculous Pivot* (灵枢). Thus, Wang’s intention is to point to the *Miraculous Pivot* (灵枢) as the *Needle Canon* (针经). According to the *Plain Questions* (素问) commentaries today, many passages citing the *Needle Canon* (针经) actually draw from the *Miraculous Pivot* (灵枢). However, since the *Miraculous Pivot* (灵枢) is incomplete in its current form, we cannot fully ascertain its meaning.”*

If **Dao/Way** (神) is insufficient, one should observe its **empty collaterals** (虚络), press them to **concentrate the qi** (致之), and **needle and harmonize** (刺而利之) without letting blood or **dispersing the qi** (泄其气), thus **unblocking the major meridians** (通其经) and restoring balance to **Dao/Way and qi** (神氣). One simply **unblocks the major meridians** (通经脉) to promote their **smooth flow and harmony** (和利), or presses the **empty collaterals** (虚络) to **concentrate the qi** (令其气致). Since **Dao/Way** (神) is insufficient, one must avoid letting blood or dispersing the qi.

*The New Verification* states: *“According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经), *按* (按) should be read as **‘cut’** (切), and *利* (利) as **‘harmonize’** (和).”*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *“How should one needle the **subtle disease** (微)?”*
Referring to the **initial onset** (前初起) at the **hair follicles** (毫毛), before it has entered the **meridians and collaterals** (经络).

Qibo replied: *“Do not disperse the disease through massage, nor deeply pierce with the needle. Instead, **concentrate the qi** (移气) where it is insufficient, and **Dao/Way and qi** (神氣) will thus recover. Massage the affected area without releasing the pressure, and when inserting the needle at the site of the disease, do not deeply pierce. This allows the patient’s **Dao/Way and qi** (神氣) to **turn inward toward the needle** (内朝於针), **concentrating the qi** (移其人神气) to restore its sufficiency. Then the **subtle disease** (微病) will naturally dissipate, and **Dao/Way and qi** (神氣) will return to normal.”

*The New Verification* states: *“According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经) and the *Tàisū* (太素), it reads **‘concentrate the qi at the foot’** (移气於足), without the **‘not’** (不) character. Yang Shangshan states: **‘Massage is to direct the qi toward the heel’** (按摩，使气至於踵也).”*

The Yellow Emperor said: *“Excellent.”*
*“How does one address **qi that is in excess or deficiency** (气有余不足)?”*
