Qibo replied: *“If **qi** (气) is in excess, there will be **shortness of breath, coughing, and upward-rising qi** (喘咳上气); if it is deficient, there will be **smooth breathing but little qi** (息利少气). The **lung** (肺) is the **storehouse** (藏) of **qi**. If the **lung’s qi** (肺气) is not smoothly flowing, one will **wheeze** (喘). The *Needle Canon* (针经) states: *“If the **lung’s qi** (肺气) is empty, then **nasal breathing is smooth but there is little qi** (鼻息利少气); if it is full, one **wheezes, gasps, and breathes with chest heaving** (喘喝胸凭仰息).”*

When **blood and qi have not yet united** (血气未并), and the **five zàng organs** (五藏) are stable, with only **minor ailments in the skin** (皮肤微病), this is called **‘*Báiqì* (白气) subtle leakage’** (微泄). The **lung** (肺) corresponds to the **skin** (皮), and its color is **white** (白), hence when the **skin** (皮肤) has minor ailments, it is called **‘*Báiqì* (白气) subtle leakage’** (白气微泄).

The Yellow Emperor asked: *“How should one treat this with bloodletting and moxibustion?”*

Qibo replied: *“If **qi** (气) is in excess, one may let blood from its **meridian pathways** (经隧) without harming the **meridian** (经) or letting blood or dispersing **qi** (气). If it is deficient, one should **reinforce the meridian pathways** (补其经隧) without dispersing **qi** (气). **Qi** (气) refers to **nutritive qi** (荣气). If one **bloodlets or needles** (针写) and **harms the meridian** (伤其经), then **blood will be released and nutritive qi dispersed** (血出而荣气泄脱). Thus, one must avoid letting blood or dispersing **qi** (气), only **releasing defensive qi** (卫气) instead. When **reinforcing with moxibustion** (针补), one should **select appropriate acupuncture points** (馑闭穴俞), yet even then, one must not disperse the **defensive qi** (卫气).”

*The New Verification* states: *“According to Yang Shangshan: **‘Meridian pathways** (经隧) refers to the **secondary branch** (别) of the **Hand Taiyin meridian** (手太阴). It travels from the **Hand Taiyin meridian** (手太阴) to the **Hand Yangming meridian** (手阳明), marking the **pathway from Hand Taiyin to Hand Yangming** (手太阴向手阳明之道). To **conduct the Dao/Way and qi** (道藏府阴阳) between the **zàng** (藏) and **fǔ** (府) organs and their **yin-yang** (阴阳) properties, both **reinforcement** (补) and **bloodletting** (写) should follow the **primary meridian** (正经) and its **secondary collateral routes** (别走之络). When bloodletting from a **yin meridian** (某阴经), one must not harm its **primary meridian** (正经).”*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *“How should one needle the **‘*Báiqì* (白气) subtle leakage’** (微泄)?”* —
Referring to the **previous discussion** (覆前).

Qi Bao said:
*"Do not cease the massage once the needle is withdrawn; observe the patient and say, ‘I will now deepen the insertion.’ If the needle is inserted too shallowly after being deepened, the vital essence and qi will retreat, while the pathogenic qi will scatter and find no place to rest. When the pathogenic qi is expelled beyond its natural limits, the true qi will then harmonize with the skin and flesh.

The term **‘massage’** refers to the affected area. **‘Re** (革)’ means *‘to change’*—when the patient hears the announcement of deep insertion but is instead given a shallow one, they will exhibit a fearful expression, causing the vital essence and qi to conceal themselves. If the needle’s adjustment aligns with the skin’s surface, the vital essence will retreat, and the pathogenic qi, finding no foothold, will scatter and dissipate beyond its natural course. Once the pathogenic qi is expelled, the true qi will then harmonize with the skin and flesh.

The Yellow Emperor said: ‘Excellent.’

**‘How does excess or deficiency of blood manifest?’**
Qi Bao said:
*‘Excess blood leads to anger; deficiency leads to fear. This pertains to the liver’s domain.’*
The *Needle Classic* states:
*‘The liver stores blood; when liver qi is deficient, fear arises; when excessive, anger emerges.’*

When blood and qi have not yet unified and the five **zàng** (藏) organs remain stable, if the **minor collateral vessels** (孙络) overflow externally, stagnant blood may remain in the **primary meridians** (经). If the collaterals harbor pathogens and their influence grows strong, they may invade the primary meridians—hence, *‘when minor collaterals overflow externally, stagnant blood remains in the meridians.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How should one reinforce or bloodlet?’**
Qi Bao said:
*‘If blood is in excess, bloodlet from the overfilled meridian to release its blood. If deficient, needle the pulse within the empty meridian, leaving the needle inserted for a prolonged period.’*
*(The *Jia-Yi Classic* and *Tai Su* state: ‘Leave the needle until the blood arrives.’)*

*‘If the pulse is large, withdraw the needle swiftly to prevent blood leakage. When the meridian’s pulse is full and tense, blood is in excess—thus, it must be released. If the meridian’s energy is deficient, blood is insufficient—hence, one must avoid excessive bloodletting. Leaving the needle inserted for a long time before swift withdrawal is called **reinforcement**.’*
The *Needle Resolution Treatise* states:
*‘Slow insertion followed by swift withdrawal strengthens.’*
This aligns with the same principle.

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does one needle stagnant blood?’**
Qi Bao said:
*‘Observe the blood collaterals and lance them to release the blood, ensuring no malignant blood re-enters the meridians to worsen the condition. If the blood collaterals are distended, press and lance them to expel the dark, pathogenic blood, preventing it from entering the meridians.’*

The Yellow Emperor said: **‘Excellent.’**

**‘How does excess or deficiency of form manifest?’**
Qi Bao said:
*‘Excess form results in abdominal distension, difficult urination, and dysmenorrhea; deficiency leads to impaired limb function. This pertains to the spleen’s domain.’*
The *Needle Classic* states:
*‘When spleen qi is deficient, the limbs become unusable, and the five **zàng** organs grow unstable; when excessive, the abdomen distends, and urination and menstruation become obstructed.’*
*(Urination refers to **dàbiàn** (大便); menstruation refers to **yùejīng** (月经).)*

When blood and qi have not yet unified and the five **zàng** organs remain stable, if the muscles twitch due to **‘micro-wind’** (微风)—a phenomenon where pathogenic forces thin the flesh and obstruct **wei qi** (卫气), causing **yang qi** (阳气) to surge inward—this movement is observed.

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How should one reinforce or bloodlet?’**
Qi Bao said:
*‘If form is in excess, bloodlet from the **yang meridians** (阳经); if deficient, reinforce the **yang collaterals** (阳络).’*
*(Together, they are called **jingluò** (经络).)*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does one needle **‘micro’** conditions?’**
Qi Bao said:
*‘Needle between the muscle layers, avoiding the primary meridians and injuring the collaterals. When **wei qi** recovers, the pathogenic qi will disperse.’*
**Wei qi** warms the muscle layers and nourishes the skin, maintaining the **shènglǐ** (胜理) and regulating openings and closures. Thus, when muscles twitch, needle between the muscle layers to expel the pathogen—without piercing the meridians or damaging the collaterals. Once **wei qi** restores its proper function, the pathogenic qi will scatter completely.

The Yellow Emperor said: **‘Excellent.’**

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘What are the excesses and deficiencies of the will (志)?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘Excess of will causes abdominal distension and diarrhea after meals; deficiency causes syncope (厥). The kidneys store the will. The *Needle Classic* (《针经》) states: The kidneys store essence, and essence contains the will. When kidney qi is deficient, syncope occurs; when excessive, distension arises. Distension refers to bloating; syncope refers to逆行 (reverse flow) surging upward. The foot少阴 meridian descends, and when its qi is insufficient, it follows the冲脉 (Conception Vessel) in reverse, surging upward. Before blood and qi unite, the five viscera are stable, yet the bones and joints twitch. The kidneys correspond to bones, so when pathogenic forces thin the bones, the joints move erratically—or as if something within them were beating like a drum.*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does one reinforce or reduce excess?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘When the will is excessive, reduce it by bleeding the然筋 (likely referring to the blood beneath the然谷, Foot Taiyi-1, the lesser bone)—*[Note: Some texts correct this to然谷下筋, while others suggest a possible error in the original, proposing然骨之前血 instead.]*—or by draining the blood there. If deficient, reinforce the复溜 (Foot Taiyi-2, the lesser bone’s secondary point). *然谷* is the lesser bone’s荣 (nourishing) point, located below the inner ankle’s large bone in a depression; its blood collaterals should be drained by needling three *cun* (same-body inches) deep, retaining the needle for three breaths, or moxibustion for three *zhàng* (units). *复溜* is the foot少阴 meridian’s point, located two *cun* above the inner ankle in a depression; needle three *cun* deep, retain for three breaths, or moxibustion for five *zhàng*.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does one needle when blood and qi have not yet united?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘Needle directly at the site of the pathogen—without piercing the meridians—so that the pathogenic force may be expelled. Do not seek fixed points; instead, target where the evil resides. Hence, it is said: *immediately needle the site of the pathogen.*’*

The Yellow Emperor said: **‘Excellent.’**
I have already heard of excess and deficiency in form, but I do not know how they arise.

Qi Bao replied:
*‘When qi and blood unite, yin and yang tilt against each other. Qi becomes disordered in the wei (defensive) layer, and blood flows backward in the meridians. When blood and qi separate, one becomes excessive while the other becomes deficient. Wei qi circulates outside the vessels, so when it is disordered, blood flows backward in the meridians. When blood and qi are disharmonious, one becomes deficient while the other becomes excessive. Blood unites with yin, and qi unites with yang, thus causing fright and madness. When qi unites with yang, excessive yang manifests externally, causing fright and madness. When blood unites with yang and qi unites with yin, it results in艮中 (a condition of stagnation). When qi unites with yin, excessive yang manifests internally, causing热中 (internal heat). *[Note: 贝 here is a variant of 热, meaning "heat."]* When blood unites above and qi unites below, the heart becomes agitated, restless, and prone to anger. When blood unites below and qi unites above, the mind becomes disordered and forgetful. *[Note: 上 refers to the region above the鬲 (stomach), 下 refers to below it.]’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘When blood unites with yin and qi unites with yang, causing blood and qi to separate, which is excess and which is deficiency?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘Blood and qi prefer warmth and dislike cold. Cold causes them to congeal and fail to flow, while warmth melts and disperses them. *[Note: 泣 here means to congeal like snow in water, unable to move or disperse.]* Thus, where qi unites, blood becomes deficient; where blood unites, qi becomes deficient. When qi unites with blood, blood is diminished—hence blood deficiency. When blood unites with qi, qi is diminished—hence qi deficiency.’*

The Yellow Emperor said: **‘Humans possess only blood and qi. Yet you say that when blood unites, it is deficiency, and when qi unites, it is also deficiency. Does this mean there is no excess?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘What exists is excess; what is absent is deficiency. When qi unites with blood, blood is absent—hence blood deficiency. When blood unites with qi, qi is absent—hence qi deficiency. Thus, when qi unites, there is no blood; when blood unites, there is no qi. Now, when blood and qi separate, it is called deficiency. When qi unites with blood, blood loses its qi; when blood unites with qi, qi loses its blood—hence it is said that blood and qi have separated. The collaterals and minute vessels both feed into the meridians; when blood and qi unite there, it becomes excess. When blood and qi surge upward together, it results in great厥 (syncope), which may cause sudden death. If the qi returns to normal, life is preserved; if it does not, death ensues.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘By what path does excess arise? By what path does deficiency depart? I wish to understand the essentials of excess and deficiency.’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘Yin and yang both have their meeting points. When yang is infused into yin and yin overflows externally, yin and yang balance evenly, filling the body. The nine candidates *[Note: 九候, diagnostic pulses]* are harmonized, and such a person is called 平人 (a balanced individual). *[Note: 平人 refers to one in harmonious health.]* The generation of pathogenic forces may arise from yin or from yang. Those arising from yang come from wind, rain, cold, and heat. Those arising from yin come from diet, dwelling, and the emotions of joy, anger, sorrow, and fear.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How do wind and rain harm a person?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘When wind and rain harm a person, they first lodge in the skin and hair, then enter the minute vessels. When the minute vessels are full, the pathogen transmits to the collaterals. When the collaterals are full, it flows into the major meridians. There, blood and qi combine with the pathogen in the muscle layers, causing the pulse to become firm and large—hence, it is called excess. Excess is characterized by external firmness and fullness; pressing it causes pain.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How do cold and dampness harm a person?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘When cold and dampness invade a person, the skin fails to contract *[Note: Some texts correct 不收 to 收, meaning "contracts," while others interpret 不收 as "insensitive."]* and the muscles become rigid. The nourishing blood congeals, the defensive qi departs, hence it is called deficiency. Deficiency is marked by a slack, insufficient pulse; pressing it warms the area, so it feels comfortable yet painless.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘What does *né* and *bì* mean?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘*Né *refers to wrinkled and slackened. *Bì* refers to slack and loose.’*
[New annotation: According to *Jia-Yi Jing*, it reads *shè-bì*; *Tai Su* also reads *shè-bì*.]

The Yellow Emperor said: **‘Good. How does *yin* generate excess?’**
*‘Excess,’* said Qi Bao, *‘refers to the dominance of pathogenic *qi*.’*
*‘When joy and anger are unregulated, *yin qi* rises in rebellion. When *yin qi* rebels upward, the lower body becomes deficient. When the lower body is deficient, *yang qi* rushes to fill it—thus, it is called excess.’*
[New annotation: According to the *Classic*, it reads: *‘When joy and anger are unregulated, *yin qi* rises in rebellion.’* It is suspected that the word *joy* is redundant.]

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does *yin* generate deficiency?’**
*‘Deficiency,’* said Qi Bao, *‘refers to the depletion of vital essence and *qi*.’*
*‘Joy causes *qi* to descend, sorrow causes *qi* to dissipate. When *qi* dissipates, the pulse becomes hollow and empty. If this is accompanied by cold exposure or improper diet, cold *qi* fills the body, causing blood to congeal and *qi* to depart—thus, it is called deficiency.’*
[New annotation: According to *Jia-Yi Jing*, it reads *‘then the organs are agitated.’*]

The Yellow Emperor said: **‘I have heard the *Classic* say: *yang* deficiency leads to external cold, *yin* deficiency leads to internal heat; *yang* excess leads to external heat, *yin* excess leads to internal cold. I understand these statements, but I do not know their underlying mechanisms.’**
*‘The *Classic* refers to the teachings of antiquity.’* Qi Bao replied:
*‘*Yang* receives *qi* from the upper burner, warming the skin and the spaces between muscles. If cold *qi* lingers externally, the upper burner becomes obstructed. When the upper burner is obstructed, cold *qi* remains trapped outside—thus, one experiences chills.’*
[Chills: trembling from cold.]

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does *yin* deficiency generate internal heat?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘When one is overworked and exhausted, the body and *qi* weaken, and the *qi* from food is insufficient. If the upper burner fails to function and the lower burner becomes obstructed, the stomach *qi* grows hot. Hot *qi* fills the chest—thus, internal heat arises.’*
[New annotation: According to *Jia-Yi Jing*, it reads *‘lower burner obstructed.’*]
*‘Excessive exertion leads to fatigue. Heavy labor without proper nourishment causes the *qi* from food to be insufficient.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does *yang* excess generate external heat?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘If the upper burner fails to function smoothly, the skin becomes tightly sealed, the interstices close, and the *Xuanfu* [mystic passage] is obstructed.’*
[New annotation: According to *Jia-Yi Jing* and *Tai Su*, the term *Xuanfu* is omitted.]
*‘Defensive *qi* cannot disperse outward—thus, external heat arises. When external cold toxins invade and internally assail the *yang* pathways, if external cold is excessive, the skin contracts, the interstices tighten, and defensive *qi* accumulates without circulation—thus, heat arises externally. When cold *qi* invades externally and *yang qi* resists internally, accumulated fire reverses inward—thus, external heat is generated.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does *yin* excess generate internal cold?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘When *jue* [reverse] *qi* rebels upward, cold *qi* accumulates in the chest and does not disperse. If it does not disperse, warm *qi* departs, and cold remains alone—thus, blood congeals and weeps. When it congeals, the pulse becomes obstructed.’*
[New annotation: According to *Jia-Yi Jing*, it reads *‘interstices obstructed.’*]
*‘The pulse becomes full and large yet rough—thus, internal cold arises.’*
[Warm *qi*: *yang qi*.]
*‘When *yin* rebels internally and fills the body, *yang qi* retreats to the exterior of the skin.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘When *yin* and *yang* are imbalanced, and blood and *qi* are disordered, forming disease—how should one treat it with acupuncture?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘When treating this, one must select points along the meridian pathways, drawing blood from the *ying* [nourishing] network and *qi* from the *wei* [defensive] network. One must measure the body’s form—adjusting for the seasons, varying in depth and angle.’*
[The *ying* network governs blood, which is *yin qi*. The *wei* network governs *qi*, which is *yang qi*.]
*‘The method of needle insertion requires first knowing the length and breadth of the body’s form, measuring according to the *San Bei* [Three Preparations] method to calculate proportions for the body, thus applying the divisions of *cun*. Hence, it is said: *use the body’s form.* The variations for the four seasons are detailed in the following section.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘When blood and *qi* are disordered, forming disease, and *yin* and *yang* are imbalanced—how should one supplement and drain?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘To drain excess, when *qi* is盛, insert the needle inward. The needle and *qi* enter together, opening its pathway like unlocking a door. When the needle and *qi* exit together, vital essence is unharmed, pathogenic *qi* descends, and the external pathway remains unsealed to expel the disease. Shake the needle vigorously to widen the channel—like clearing a road. This is called *great drainage*. It must be done decisively and swiftly—thus, the great pathogenic *qi* is subdued.’*
[Speaking of opening the orifice to release *qi*.]
[Decisive: swift. Speaking of swiftly withdrawing the needle.]
*The *Zhen Jing Lun* [Needle Classic Theory] says: *‘Swift insertion followed by slow withdrawal leads to deficiency—swiftly withdraw the needle and slowly press.’*
[Great *qi*: great pathogenic *qi*.]
[Subdued: retreated and bent.]

The Yellow Emperor asked: **‘How does one supplement deficiency?’**
Qi Bao replied:
*‘Hold the needle firmly without hesitation, steadying your intent. Wait for exhalation, then insert the needle. When *qi* emerges, the needle enters. When the needle is in place and the surroundings are sealed, vital essence cannot escape. Only then, firmly and swiftly withdraw the needle. When *qi* enters and the needle exits, heat cannot return. Seal the pathway, disperse the pathogenic *qi*, and vital essence is preserved. Move the needle according to the timing—*
[New annotation: According to *Jia-Yi Jing*, it reads *‘without delay.’*]
*—then there will be no disease.’*
[No disease: no ailment.]

*‘For those who practice acupuncture incorrectly—needling the collateral vessels—if pain is on the left, needle the right, and if pain is on the right, needle the left. If pain is on the left but the right pulse is diseased, use *ju* needling.’*
[*Ju* needling: needling the main meridian.]
*‘If pain is on the left, needle the right collateral vessel; if pain is on the right, needle the left collateral vessel. One must carefully examine the nine diagnostic regions—then the needle method is complete.’*

[End of *Huangdi Neijing Suwen* Supplementary Commentary, Volume Thirty-Six]
[End of *Huangdi Neijing Suwen* Supplementary Commentary, Volume Thirty-Seven]

**Tang Taipu Ling Qiuxuanzi Wang Bing’s Sequential Commentary**
**Song Guanglu Guoshi Zhi Mishi Lin Yi et al. Verified**
**Song Shou Shangshu Tun Tian Lang Sun Zhao Revising Errors**

**Miu Ci Lun (Treatise on Miu Needling)**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"I have heard of **miu ci** (乱刺), but I do not grasp its meaning. What is **miu ci**?"*

**Miu ci** refers to the acupuncture points used—where the needling must correspond like the **fǎnmiù** (纰缪) of threads in a loom, maintaining order.

Qibo replied:
*"When pathogenic forces invade the body, they first lodge in the **skin and fur**, and if they linger without leaving, they enter and lodge in the **minute collaterals (孙脉)**, and if they linger without leaving, they enter and lodge in the **network vessels (络脉)**, and if they linger without leaving, they penetrate into the **main meridians (经脉)**, internally connecting to the **five zang organs (五藏)**, dispersing through the **intestines and stomach**, affecting both **yin and yang**, and thus injuring the five zang. This is the progression of pathogenic forces entering from the skin and fur and reaching the five zang in sequence.

In such cases, one treats the **main meridians**.

But if pathogenic forces lodge in the **skin and fur**, enter and settle in the **minute and network vessels**, and linger without leaving, blocking and obstructing the flow so that they cannot enter the main meridians, they overflow into the **major network vessels (大络)**, giving rise to **strange diseases**.

When disease is in the **blood network vessels (血络)**, it is called **strange pathogenic forces (奇邪)**."*

**[New Verification Note: According to Quan Yuanqi, *‘大络’* refers to the *‘fifteen network vessels (十五络)’*.]**

*"When pathogenic forces lodge in the **major network vessels**, they may flow from left to right, or right to left, or move upward and downward, intersecting with the main meridians while spreading to the **four extremities**, their **qi** having no fixed location and not entering the **meridian points (经俞)**—this is called **miu ci**.*

*The **four extremities** refer to the **four limbs (四支)**."*

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"I wish to hear how **miu ci** works—when one treats the left by needling the right, and the right by needling the left. How does this differ from **jù ci (巨刺)**?"*

Qibo replied:
*"When pathogenic forces lodge in the **main meridians**, if the left is excessive, the right will be diseased, and if the right is excessive, the left will be diseased. There are also cases where the condition shifts.*

**[New Verification Note: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing*, it reads *‘disease shifts and moves (病易且移)’*.]**

*If pain persists on the left while the right pulse is already diseased, then one must use **jù ci**, needling directly into the **main meridian**—this is not the network vessels.*

*‘The one that is first diseased’ means that while the original pain has not yet ceased, the other side becomes diseased in succession.*

*Thus, when the **network vessels** are diseased, the pain corresponds to where the **network vessels intersect with the main meridians**, hence the term **miu ci**.*

*The **network vessels** refer to the **branching collaterals of the main meridians**, not the **separate meridians (正别)**—they also include the **public-sun (公孙)** and **feiyang (飞扬)** collateral branches and others.*

**[New Verification Note: According to Wang Shi, *‘non-separate meridians’*—but in this treatise, when pathogenic forces lodge in the **foot Taiyin network vessel (足太阴络)**, they cause lumbar pain, radiating from the **spleen (牌)** and merging with the **Yangming meridian**, ascending to the **network vessel of the throat (哑)**, piercing the **tongue’s center**—this is the **foot Taiyin’s proper meridian**, also a **combined vessel (兼脉)**. How can it be said to be *‘non-separate’*?"*

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"I wish to hear how **miu ci** is performed. How should the points be selected?"*

Qi Bó said:
*"When pathogenic forces lodge in the **foot Shaoyin network vessel (足少阴络)**, they cause sudden heart pain and violent distension, with the chest and ribs radiating outward and full. For its **collateral branches (别络)**, they follow the proper meridian from the **kidney (肾)**, ascending to pierce the **liver’s gate (肝鬲)**, coursing through the **heart’s envelope (心包)**, hence the disease manifests thus. If there is no stagnation, needle **Rán Gǔ (然谷)**, the point before **Rán Gǔ (然骨)**, to draw blood—like after a meal—will suffice. **Rán Gǔ (然谷)** lies on the medial ankle, where the **great bone (大骨)** is depressed inward, the **foot Shaoyin’s flourishing vessel (足少阴荣)**. The needle may penetrate **three-fen of a body-cun (同身寸)**, leaving it for three breaths. If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**. Needling here often draws blood, inducing immediate hunger. If the pain persists, take the right side for left-sided pain and vice versa—this follows the general rule. For a newly arising disease, five days of treatment suffice. If the disease has long existed but now flares anew, needle it five days first, then it shall be cured.

When pathogenic forces lodge in the **hand Shaoyang network vessel (手少阳络)**, they cause throat constriction and tongue rolling, dry mouth and restlessness of the heart, pain along the outer arm, and inability for the hand to reach the head. For its **meridian path (脉)**, it follows the hand’s outer surface, emerges along the outer arm, enters the **shoulder’s hollow (缺盆)**, spreads through the **axilla (擅中)**, and disperses into the **heart’s envelope network vessel (心包散络)**. Its **branching collaterals (支)**, from the **breast’s center (膻中)**, ascend to emerge above the **shoulder’s hollow (缺盆)**, then to the **nape (项)**, while the **heart governs the tongue (心主其舌)**, hence the disease manifests thus. Needle the **second finger’s nail (次指爪甲)**, one **fen** from the tip, on both hands—this is **Guān Chōng (关冲)**, the **well point (井)** of **Shaoyang**. The needle may penetrate **one-fen of a body-cun (同身寸)**, leaving it for three breaths. If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**. Both hands are needled, hence ‘each one fen.’ **Fen (痏)** means *‘sore’* or *‘wound.’*
**[New Verification Note: According to *Jia Yi Jing (甲乙经)*, the **Guān Chōng (关冲)** point emerges from the tip of the **second finger (次指)**, not the **middle finger (中指)**—this is an error. The effect is immediate for the young, but may take some time for the elderly. For left-sided pain, take the right side, and vice versa—this applies to new diseases lasting several days.]*"

When **evil qi** lodges in the **Jueyin (足厥阴)** sinews,
it causes sudden **testicular torsion (卒疝)** with violent pain.
For its sinews lie five **body-cun (同身寸)** above the **inner ankle (内踝)**,
branching off toward **Shaoyang (少阳)**.
Its divergent branches ascend along the meridian to the **testicles (睪)**, knotting at the **penis (茎)**—
thus causing sudden **testicular torsion (卒疝)** with violent pain.
**[Testicles (睪)]** are the **Nine Yin (阴九)**.

Needle the **nail of the big toe (足大指爪甲)** where it meets the flesh,
one **fen (瘠)** on each side—
this is the **Dàdūn (大敦)** point, the **well (井)** of **Jueyin (足厥阴)**,
located at the tip of the big toe, one **fen** from the nail corner (like a **scallion leaf**).
The needle may penetrate **three-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之三分)**, left for ten breaths.
If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**.
Men recover immediately; women may take some time.
Needle the opposite side for left or right pain.

When **evil qi** lodges in the **Taiyang (足太阳)** sinews,
it causes **head, nape, and shoulder pain (头项肩痛)**.
For its direct channel descends from the brain and branches at the nape;
its divergent branches descend from the inner arm, splitting left and right.
Again, its sinews ascend from the **foot (足#2)** along the back to the head—
thus causing **head, nape, and shoulder pain**.

**[New Verification Note: According to *Jia Yi Jing (甲乙经)*:
Its divergent branch enters the **brain (脑)** from the **vertex (巅)**, then descends, branching at the nape.
Master Wang says the *‘direct channel’* should read *‘divergent branch’* (支).]**

Needle the **nail of the little toe (足小指爪甲)** where it meets the flesh,
one **fen (瘠)** on each side—this is the **Zhìyīn (至阴)** point, the **well (井)** of **Taiyang (足太阳)**.
The needle may penetrate **one-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之一分)**, left for five breaths.
If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**.
**[New Verification Note: According to *Jia Yi Jing (甲乙经)*:
This point lies on the **outer side of the little toe (足小指外侧)**, one **fen** from the nail corner (like a **scallion leaf**).]**
If ineffective, needle **three-fen below the outer ankle (外踝下三瘠)**,
left or right as needed—recovery follows in the time it takes to eat a meal.
This is the **Jīnmén (金门)** point, the **post station (邮)** of **Taiyang (足太阳)**,
located below the outer ankle.
The needle may penetrate **three-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之三分)**.
If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**.

When **evil qi** lodges in the **Yangming (手阳明)** sinews,
it causes **chest distension (气满胸中)**, **shortness of breath (喘息)**, **rib pain (支胱)**, and **chest heat (胸中热)**.
For its channel enters the **suprasternal fossa (缺盆)** from the shoulder tip,
and its sinews diverge—
its branching paths ascend straight from the **suprasternal fossa (缺盆)** to the neck—
thus the disease manifests thus.

Needle the **nail of the index finger (手大指次指爪甲)** one **fen (瘠)** from the tip (like a **scallion leaf**) on each side,
left or right as needed—recovery follows in the time it takes to eat a meal.
This is the **Shāngyáng (商阳)** point, the **well (井)** of **Yangming (手阳明)**.
The needle may penetrate **one-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之一分)**, left for one breath.
If moxibustion is used, apply **one moxa cone (一壮)**.
**[New Verification Note: According to *Jia Yi Jing (甲乙经)*:
**Shāngyáng (商阳)** lies on the **inner side of the index finger (手大指次指内侧)**, one **fen** from the nail corner (like a **scallion leaf**).]**

When **evil qi** lodges between the **arm and palm (臂掌之间)**,
rendering flexion impossible,
needle behind the **wrist (踝)**.
**[New Verification Note: According to Quán Yuánqǐ’s original text:
This is the **root joint of the hand (手之本节踝)**.]
First press with the fingers until pain is found, then needle.
Use the **lunar waxing-waning cycle (月死生)** for dosage:
One **fen (痏)** per day during the waxing phase (1–15 days),
then decreasing by one **fen** per day after the 15th.
Days 1–15 are the **waxing (生)** phase; days 16 onward are the **waning (死)** phase—
the effect varies with **deficiency and excess (亏满)**.

When **evil qi** lodges in the **Yangjiao (足阳娇)** meridian,
it causes **eye pain beginning from the inner canthus (目痛从内毗始)**.
For its meridian arises at the foot, ascending to the head and connecting to the **inner canthus (目内毗)**—
thus the disease begins with **eye pain from the inner canthus**.

How is this known?
The *Eighty-One Difficult Questions (八十一难经)* states:
*The **Yangtā (阳踏)** meridian arises from the **heel (跟中)**, ascends along the outer ankle, and enters **Fēngchí (风池)**.*
The *Needle Classic (针经)* states:
*The **Yīnjī (阴跻)** meridian enters the **nasal cavity (鼾)** and connects to the **inner canthus (目内毗)**,
merging with **Taiyang’s Yangtā (太阳阳踏)** to ascend.*

Thus, it reaches the **inner canthus (目内毗)**.

Needle **two-fen below the outer ankle (外踝之下半寸)** on each side—
this is the **Shēnmài (申脉)** point, where **Yangtā (阳踏)** originates,
located in the **hollow below the outer ankle (外踝下陷者中)**, fitting a **nail (容爪甲)**.
The needle may penetrate **three-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之三分)**, left for six breaths.
If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**.
**[New Verification Note: According to the *Needling Lumbar Pain (刺腰痛)* annotation:
This point lies **five-fen below the outer ankle (外踝下五分)**.]**
Needle the opposite side for left or right pain—recovery follows in the time it takes to walk ten *li*.

If a person has **fallen and suffered internal blood stagnation (恶血留内)**,
causing **abdominal distension (腹中满胀)** and inability to **defecate or urinate (不得前后)**,
first administer **purgative herbs (利药)**.
This injures the **Jueyin (厥阴)** meridian above and the **Shaoyin (少阴)** sinews below.
Needle **below the inner ankle (足内踝之下)**, where the **blood vessels emerge before the bone (然骨之前血脉出血)**—
this is the **Shaoyin (少阴)** sinew.
**[New Verification Note: The *‘blood vessels’* (血脉) may be a miswriting for *‘sinews’* (络).]**
Needle the **pulsating artery on the medial malleolus (足驸上动脉)**—
this is the **Chōngyáng (冲阳)** point, the **source (原)** of the **stomach (胃)**.
The needle may penetrate **three-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之三分)**, left for ten breaths.
If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**.
It treats **abdominal distension with loss of appetite (腹大不嗜食)**.
Since the **abdomen is distended (腹胀满)**, this point is selected.
If ineffective, needle **one-fen above the big toe’s hairline (三毛上各一痏)**—
bleeding brings immediate relief.
Needle the opposite side for left or right pain.
This is the **Dàdūn (大敦)** point, the **well (井)** of **Jueyin (厥阴)**.

For those who **weep excessively (善悲)**, are **easily startled (惊)**, and **discontent (不乐)**,
needle as described above.

When **evil qi** lodges in the **Yangming (手阳明)** sinews,
it causes **deafness (耳聋)**, with intermittent inability to hear sounds.
For its divergent branch ascends from the **suprasternal fossa (缺盆)** to the neck, piercing the **cheek (颊)**,
and its sinews’ divergent paths enter the **ear**, converging at the **central vessel (宗脉)**—
thus the disease causes **intermittent deafness (耳聋时不闻声)**.

Needle the **nail of the index finger (手大指次指爪甲)** one **fen (瘠)** from the tip (like a **scallion leaf**) on each side—
hearing is immediately restored.
This is the same as the **Shāngyáng (商阳)** point above.
If ineffective, needle the **nail of the middle finger (中指爪甲)** where it meets the flesh—
hearing is immediately restored.
This is the **Zhōngchōng (中冲)** point, the **well (井)** of the **Heart (手心主)**,
located at the tip of the middle finger, one **fen** from the nail (in the **hollow like a scallion leaf**).
The needle may penetrate **one-fen of a body-cun (同身寸之一分)**, left for three breaths.
If moxibustion is used, apply **three moxa cones (三壮)**.

The ancient texts are missing their passages, leaving no **collateral vessels (络)** to trace.
Perhaps it refers to needling the **little finger’s nail (小指爪甲)**, where it meets the flesh.
How do we know?
The following text states: *"The collateral of the **Hand Lesser Yin (手少阴)** converges in the ear."*

If the little finger’s tip is called **Lesser Surge (少冲)**, the **well (井)** of **Hand Lesser Yin (手少阴)**, then needling it may penetrate **one fen**, left for **one breath**; if moxibustion is used, **one cone (一壮)** suffices.

---
**Newly corrected text states:**
According to Wang’s commentary, it is likely the **Lesser Surge (少冲)** point on the little finger’s nail.
Referring to the *Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙经)*:
*"The proper channel of **Hand Heart (手心主)** ascends along the throat, exits behind the ear, and merges below **Lesser Yang’s Complete Bone (少阳完骨)**.
Thus, why would one needle **Middle Surge (中冲)** instead of suspecting **Lesser Surge (少冲)**?
For cases of **intermittent deafness (不时闻)**, needling is forbidden.
If **intermittent deafness** occurs, the **collateral qi (络气)** has already severed—needling is thus prohibited.
For **wind in the ear (耳中生风)**, needling follows the same method:
Left ear treated with right needle, right ear treated with left.

For **numbness (痹)** wandering without fixed location—
painful in the **flesh divisions (分肉间)**, needle accordingly.
The **monthly death-and-life count (月死生)** determines the **fen (痏)** dosage.
For those using needles, adjust based on **qi’s ebb and flow (气盛衰)**.
Exceeding the daily count **dissipates qi (脱气)**; falling short **fails to release qi (气不写)**.
Left-side treatment with right needle, right-side with left—
when the disease ceases, stop.
If unresolved, repeat as prescribed.

Why regulate the **monthly death-and-life count (月死生)**?
To align with **qi’s ebb and flow (气盛衰)**.
On the **first day of the month**, use **one fen (一痏)**;
the **second day**, **two fen (二痏)**—gradually increasing to **fifteen fen (十五痏)** by the **fifteenth day**.
From the **sixteenth day**, decrease by **one fen daily**—
thus avoiding excess or deficiency.

When **evil (邪)** lodges in the **Foot Greater Yang (足阳明)** channel,
it causes **upper teeth (凯钮上齿)** to feel cold,
for its pulse arises from the **nasal intersection (鼻交类中)**, descends along the **outer nose (鼻外)**,
enters the **upper teeth (上齿中)**, then exits beside the mouth, encircling the lips.
It descends to meet **Receiving Saliva (承浆)**, then reverses along the **jaw’s posterior (颐后下康)**,
exits at **Great Welcome (大迎)**, follows **Cheek Cart (颊车)**, and ascends before the ear—

the channel’s ailments clarify **analogous regions (缪处之类)**—
hence the following text states:

Needle from the **nape (项)** and count the **vertebrae (脊椎)** beside the **spine (侠脊)**.
When pressing quickly (**疾按**), the **painful response (应手)** should be like the **pain (如痛)**.

When **evil (邪)** lodges in the **foot Shaoyang (少阳) channel’s collateral (络)**, it causes lingering pain at the **Huo (枢)**.

Thus, pain lingers at the **Huo (枢)**, and afterward, though the pain subsides, the leg **cannot be lifted (不可举)**.

Needle the **Huo (枢)** with a **hair-thin needle (毫针)**.
If the condition is **cold (寒)**, retain the needle for a long time, counting by the **lunar phases (月死生)** until recovery is achieved—**immediate cure (立已)**.

Retain the needle for **two breaths (二#13呼)**.
If **moxibustion (灸)** is applied, use **three cones (三壮)**.

The **hair-thin needle (毫针)** refers to the **seventh needle (第七针)**.

This passage says to needle the **Huo (枢)**, but Wang [commentator] mistakenly claimed *"needle behind the **Huo (枢)**"*—this is incorrect.

For treating all channels, if the **pathway (所过)** shows no disease, then the needling was **misplaced (缪刺)**.
This is the **correct statement (正言也)**.*

If the **channel (经)** shows no disease, then the **evil (邪)** resides in the **network vessels (络)**, hence the **misplaced needling (缪刺)**.

If the **pathway of the channel (经所过)** exhibits disease, then it is the **channel itself that is diseased**, and **misplaced needling should not be applied**.

For **deafness (耳聋)**, needle the **Hand Greater Yang channel (手阳明)**.
If ineffective, needle the **channel’s branch that emerges before the ear (通脉出耳前者)**.

The **Hand Greater Yang channel** refers to the **space between the second and third fingers of the hand**, resembling **leek leaves**—this is called **Shangyang (商阳)**.

According to the *Zhonggong Kongxue Tujing (中诰孔穴图经)*, the **Hand Greater Yang channel** includes the **four points—Shangyang (商阳), Hegu (合谷), Yangxi (阳溪), and Pianli (偏历)**—all of which govern **deafness**.
The **current text** specifies needling **Shangyang (商阳)** before the ear, not these **Hegu (合谷)** and the others.

The **branch channel before the ear (耳前通脉)**, belonging to the **Hand Greater Yang channel**, lies precisely at the **ear’s auditory aperture (听会)**. Needling may penetrate **four fen of the body’s cun (同身寸之四分)**. If moxibustion is applied, use **three cones (三壮)**.

For **tooth decay (齿齲)**, needle the **Hand Greater Yang channel**.
If ineffective, needle the **branch where its channel enters the teeth (脉入齿中者)**, and it will **instantly resolve**.

According to the *Jia-Yi Jing (甲乙)* and *Liu#15 Zhu Tujing (流#15注图经)*, the **Hand Greater Yang channel** includes the **seven points—Shangyang (商阳), Erwen (二问), Sanwen (三问), Hegu (合谷), Yangxi (阳溪), Pianli (偏历), and Wenliu (温留)**—all of which govern **toothache**.
The **Hand Greater Yang channel** passes through the cheek and enters the **lower teeth**, while the **Foot Greater Yang channel** follows the outer nose and enters the **upper teeth**.

*(齲, pronounced as in "qiū yǔ" cut)*

When **evil** lodges in the **interstices of the five Zàng (五藏之问)**, its affliction manifests as **pulsing pain that comes and goes in time**. Observe the disease: if the **pathway** is **erratic (缪)**, needle it at the **hand or foot nails (手足爪甲上)**.

Needle each at its **Jǐng (井)** point—**right side for left-sided ailments, left side for right-sided ailments**. Examine the **pulse (脉)**, and let **its blood (脉血)** flow; one needling per day. If one needling fails to resolve it, **five needlings will suffice**. If there is **blood in the pulse**, then needle it thus in this manner.

If the **erratic pathway** spreads and draws **upward to the teeth (上齿)**, causing **cold, painful lips and teeth (齿唇寒痛)**, observe the **hand’s dorsal pulse with blood (手背脉血者)** and remove it. If the disease **spreads erratically (缪传)** and draws upward to the teeth, with **cold, painful lips and teeth (齿唇寒痛)**, needle the **Hand Greater Yang collateral (手背阳明络)**.

At the **middle toe’s nail (足阳明中指爪甲上)**, one **Jǐng (瘠)**, and at the **second toe’s nail on the foot (手大指次指爪甲上)**, each one **Jǐng (瘠)**—**instant resolution**. **Right side for left-sided ailments, left side for right-sided ailments**. This refers to the **Lì Duì (厉兑)** point on the second toe.

The **second toe’s nail on the hand (手大指次指)**, this is the **Shangyáng (商阳)** point, the **Jǐng (井)** of the **Hand Greater Yang channel**. The *Needle Canon (针经)* states: **Toothache without aversion to cold drinks (齿痛不恶清饮)**, take the **Foot Greater Yang channel (足阳明)**. **Aversion to cold drinks (恶清饮)**, take the **Hand Greater Yang channel (手阳明)**.

*(New annotation: Referring to earlier text, when evil lodges in the Foot Greater Yang channel, needling the middle toe’s nail is correct; the mention of the "second toe" is an error and should be omitted.)*

When **evil** lodges in the **collaterals of the Hand, Foot Lesser Yin, Greater Yin, Foot Greater Yang channels (手、足少阴、太阴、足阳明之络)**, these **five collaterals (五络)** all converge in the **ear (耳中)**, spreading upward to the **left temple (左角)**. The **Hand Lesser Yin collateral (手少阴)**, the **True Heart pulse (真心脉)**. The **Foot Lesser Yin collateral (足少阴)**, the **kidney pulse (肾脉)**. The **Hand Greater Yin collateral (手太阴)**, the **lung pulse (肺脉)**. The **Foot Greater Yin collateral (足太阴)**, the **spleen pulse (脾脉)**. The **Foot Greater Yang collateral (足阳明)**, the **stomach pulse (胃脉)**.

These **five collaterals (五络)** all converge in the **ear**, and their **collaterals spread to the left temple (左额角)**. When all **five collaterals are exhausted (俱竭)**, it causes **the body’s pulses to move as usual (身脉皆动)**, yet **the form feels nothing (形无知)**, resembling a **corpse (尸)**, or called **corpse syncope (尸厥)**—**speaking of its sudden loss of consciousness as if dead (卒冒问而如死尸)**, while the **body’s pulses still move as in a living person (身脉犹如常人而动)**.

However, when **Yin-qi is excessive in the upper body (阴气盛於上)**, the **lower-qi becomes heavy (下气重)** and presses upward, while **evil-qi reverses (邪气逆)**, disrupting **Yang-qi (阳气)**. When **Yang-qi is disordered (阳气乱)**, the **five collaterals become blocked and stagnant (五络闭结)**, failing to flow—**thus its state resembles a corpse (故其状若尸)**. Since it arises from **syncope (厥)**, it is thus called **corpse syncope (尸厥)**.

Needle the **inner side of the big toe’s nail (足大指内侧爪甲上)**, **one cun from the tip (去端如韭叶)**, referring to the **Yǐnbái (隐白)** point, the **Jǐng (井)** of the **Foot Greater Yin channel**. Needling may penetrate **one fen of the body’s cun (同身寸之一分)**, retain for **three breaths (三呼)**. If moxibustion is applied, use **three cones (三壮)**.

Then needle the **sole of the foot (足心)**, referring to the **Yǒngquán (涌泉)** point, the **Jǐng (井)** of the **Foot Lesser Yin channel**. Needle using the method of taking **Yǒngquán (涌泉)** as before.

Then needle the **middle toe’s nail (足中指爪甲上)**, each one **Jǐng (瘠)**, referring to the **Lì Duì (厉兑)** point on the second toe of the **Foot Greater Yang channel**. Needle using the method of taking **Lì Duì (厉兑)** as before.

Then needle the **inner side of the big finger’s nail (手大指内侧)**, **one cun from the tip (去端如韭叶)**, referring to the **Shǎoshāng (少商)** point, the **Jǐng (井)** of the **Hand Greater Yin channel**. Needling may penetrate **one fen of the body’s cun (同身寸之一分)**, retain for **three breaths (三呼)**. If moxibustion is applied, use **three cones (三壮)**.

Then needle the **Palm’s Central Rushing (手心主)**, referring to the **Zhōngchōng (中冲)** point, the **Jǐng (井)** of the **Palm’s Central Rushing channel**. Needling may penetrate **one fen of the body’s cun (同身寸之一分)**, retain for **three breaths (三呼)**. If moxibustion is applied, use **one cone (一壮)**.

*(New annotation: According to the Jia-Yi Canon (甲乙经), needling the Palm’s Central Rushing is incorrect. Referring to the five collaterals’ count, it should not include the Palm’s Central Rushing either; thus, this method suggests six collaterals. This does not align with the clear intent of Wang Bing’s commentary.)*

At the **end of the sharp bone (锐骨)** on the **Lesser Yin channel (少阴)**, each one **Jǐng (瘠)**—**instant resolution**. This refers to the **Shénmén (神门)** point, located in the **depression at the posterior wrist’s sharp bone (掌后锐骨之端陷者中)**, the **Shu (俞)** point of the **Hand Lesser Yin channel**. Needling may penetrate **three fen of the body’s cun (同身寸之三分)**, retain for **seven breaths (七呼)**. If moxibustion is applied, use **three cones (三壮)**.

If it does not resolve, use a **bamboo tube (竹管)** to blow into both **ears (两耳)**, **speaking of directing qi into the ears (使气入耳中)**, internally assisting the **five collaterals (五络)**, and **restoring qi flow (令气复通)**. When the **inner tube enters the ear (当内管入耳)**, cover it with the **hand (以手密)**, ensuring the **qi does not escape (勿令气泄)**, and blow **forcefully (极吹)** until the **qi is compressed (气蹙然)**—**then the collaterals will flow (后络脉通)**.

*(New annotation: According to Tao Yinju (陶隐居), blow the left ear three times, then the right ear three times.)*

**Pluck the hair (鬓)** at the **left temple (左角)**, **one cun in width (发方一寸)**, and **treat with wine (墦治)**—**one cup of fine wine (美酒一杯)**. If unable to drink, **pour it down (灌之)**—**instant resolution**. The **left temple’s hair (左角之发)** is the **remnant of the five collaterals’ blood (五络血之余)**, hence it is **plucked (衅)**. **Treat with wine (墦治)**, **drink it with fine wine (饮之以美酒)**. **Wine (酒)** is used to **facilitate medication (行药)**, and its **nature is to ascend and internally course toward the Heart (势又炎上而内走於心)**—the **Heart governs the pulses (心主脉)**—**thus fine wine is administered for ingestion**.

**On the Methods of Needling and the Four Seasons’ Inverse and Conforming Principles**

In all needling, first observe the **meridian pathways (经脉)**, palpate them, and follow their course. Assess their **emptiness or fullness (虚实)** and regulate accordingly. If regulation fails, apply **orthodox needling (经刺)**. If there is pain but the meridian itself is unaffected, use **divergent needling (缪刺)**, and if the **skin’s collateral vessels (皮部有血络)** are visible, exhaustively remove them. This is the method of **divergent needling**.

---
**Theory of the Four Seasons: Inverse and Conforming Needling**

**Jueyin Meridian (厥阴)**
- **Excess (有余)** causes **yin numbness (阴痹)**—*numbness (痹)* refers to **pain (痛)**, and *yin* refers to **cold (寒)**. Excess means the **Jueyin qi is overabundant and full (厥阴气盛满)**, so **cold manifests externally (阴发於外)**, resulting in **cold numbness (寒痹)**.
  *(Annotation: The *New Rectification* states: In detail, Wang’s interpretation of *numbness* as *pain* is unclear.)*
- **Deficiency (不足)** causes **heat numbness (热痹)**. When *yin* is deficient, *yang* becomes excessive, hence **heat numbness**.
  - **Slickness (滑)** causes **fox hernia-wind (狐疝风)**.
  - **Dryness (涩)** causes **accumulation of gas in the lower abdomen (少腹积气)**.
  The **Jueyin meridian** travels along the **inner thigh (股阴)**, enters the **perineum (髦中)**, encircles the **genital organ (阴器)**, and reaches the **lower abdomen (少腹)**. Its collateral branches diverge, ascending along the **sperm duct (睪)**, converging at the **penis (茎)**, hence causing **fox hernia (狐疝)** and **accumulation of gas in the lower abdomen**.
  *(Annotation: According to Yang Shangshan (杨上善): *Fox hernia* refers to inability to urinate at night, only possible after sunrise—similar to human ailments, hence called *孤#18疝 (lonely hernia)*. Alternatively, *fox hernia* refers to **San Jiao’s lonely reservoir (三焦孤府)** causing hernia, hence *孤疝 (lonely hernia)*.)*

**Shaoyin Meridian (少阴)**
- **Excess (有余)** causes **skin numbness (皮痹)** and **hidden torsion (隐斡)**.
- **Deficiency (不足)** causes **lung numbness (肺痹)**, for **kidney water reverses and connects to the lung’s mother (肺母)**.
  The **foot Shaoyin meridian** ascends from the **kidney**, pierces the **liver’s diaphragm (肝鬲)**, and enters the **lung**, hence:
  - **Excess** causes **skin numbness and hidden torsion (隐斡)**.
  - **Deficiency** causes **lung numbness**.
  - **Slickness (滑)** causes **lung hernia-wind (肺风疝)**.
  - **Dryness (涩)** causes **accumulated stagnant blood (积没血)**.
  Since its **main meridian enters the lung, pierces the kidney, and collaterals connect to the bladder (膀胱)**, it results in **lung hernia and accumulated stagnant blood**.

**Taiyin Meridian (太阴)**
- **Excess (有余)** causes **flesh numbness (肉痹)** and **cold invasion (寒中)**.
- **Deficiency (不足)** causes **spleen numbness (脾痹)**.
  The **spleen governs flesh (脾主肉)**, hence such manifestations.
  - **Slickness (滑)** causes **spleen hernia-wind (脾风疝)**.
  - **Dryness (涩)** causes **accumulated heart-abdominal periodic fullness (积心腹时满)**.
  The **Taiyin meridian** enters the **abdomen, belongs to the spleen, and collaterals connect to the stomach (胃)**. Its branches diverge again from the stomach, ascending through the **diaphragm (鬲)**, pouring into the **heart (心中)**, hence causing **spleen hernia and periodic heart-abdominal fullness**.

**Yangming Meridian (阳明)**
- **Excess (有余)** causes **pulse numbness (脉痹)** and **periodic body heat (身时热)**.
- **Deficiency (不足)** causes **heart numbness (心痹)**.
  When the **stomach is excessive**, its qi ascends to the **heart**; when deficient, **numbness occurs beneath the heart (心下痹)**, hence these symptoms.
  - **Slickness (滑)** causes **heart hernia-wind (心风疝)**.
  - **Dryness (涩)** causes **accumulated periodic startling (积时善惊)**.
  The **heart’s governing meridian (心主之脉)** arises from the **chest**, emerges to belong to the **heart包 (pericardium)**, descends through the **diaphragm (鬲)**, and sequentially collaterals the **San Jiao (三焦)**, hence causing **heart hernia and periodic startling**.

**Taiyang Meridian (太阳)**
- **Excess (有余)** causes **bone numbness (骨痹)** and **body heaviness (身重)**.
- **Deficiency (不足)** causes **kidney numbness (肾痹)**.
  The **Taiyang and Shaoyin** are **external-internal pairs (表裹)**, so both excess and deficiency manifest in the **kidney**.
  - **Slickness (滑)** causes **kidney hernia-wind (肾风疝)**.
  - **Dryness (涩)** causes **accumulated periodic vertigo (积善时巅疾)**.
  The **Taiyang meridian** converges at the **vertex (巅上)**, enters to collateralize the **brain (脑)**, descends along the **loins (膂)**, and collaterals the **kidney (肾)**, hence causing **kidney wind and vertigo**.

**Shaoyang Meridian (少阳)**
- **Excess (有余)** causes **tendon numbness (筋痹)** and **rib-side fullness (胁满)**.
- **Deficiency (不足)** causes **liver numbness (肝痹)**.
  The **Shaoyang and Jueyin** are **external-internal pairs (表裹)**, so ailments manifest in the **liver**.
  - **Slickness (滑)** causes **liver hernia-wind (肝风疝)**.
  - **Dryness (涩)** causes **accumulated periodic tendon tightness and eye pain (积时筋急目痛)**.
  The **liver governs tendons (肝主筋)**, hence **periodic tendon tightness**. The **Jueyin meridian** ascends to the **forehead (额)**, converges with the **Governor Vessel (督脉)** at the **vertex (巅)**, and its branches diverge from the **eye system (目系)**, descending along the **cheek (颊)**, encircling, hence **eye pain**.
