**The Qi of the Seasons in the Body**

The **Spring qi** resides in the **meridians (经脉)**,
The **Summer qi** in the **fine collaterals (孙络)**,
The **Long Summer qi** in the **muscles (肌肉)**,
The **Autumn qi** in the **skin (皮肤)**,
The **Winter qi** in the **bone marrow (骨髓)**.

**Emperor:** I wish to hear the reason for this.
**Ghibu (岐伯):** In **Spring**, the **heavenly qi begins to open (天气始开)**, the **earthly qi begins to release (地气始泄)**, frost thaws and ice melts, water flows, and **meridians are unblocked (水行经通)**, hence **human qi resides in the meridians (人气在脉)**.

In **Summer**, the **meridians are full and qi overflows (经满气溢)**, entering the **fine collaterals to receive blood (孙络受血)**, filling the **skin and flesh (皮肤充实)**.

In **Long Summer**, the **meridians and collaterals are all flourishing (经络皆盛)**, internally overflowing into the **muscles (肌中)**.

In **Autumn**, the **heavenly qi begins to withdraw (天气始收)**, **victorious principles close and seal (胜理闭塞)**, and the **skin tightens (皮肤引急)**—*引* means **taut and contracted (牵引以缩急)**.

In **Winter**, **conservation occurs (盖藏)**, **blood and qi reside internally (血气在中)**, attaching to the **bone marrow (骨髓)**, communicating with the **five viscera (五藏)**.

Thus, **pathogenic qi** always follows the **seasonal qi and blood**, entering as a **guest**. When it transforms, its extent is unpredictable, yet it **must follow the meridian qi**. **Repel and remove the pathogenic**, and **disordered qi will not arise**. **Harmonize with the qi**, and **disorder will not occur**.

**Emperor:** How does **contrary to the four seasons** generate **disordered qi**?
**Ghibu:**
- **Spring needling of collaterals (春刺络脉)** causes **qi to overflow externally (血气外溢)**, leading to **shortness of breath (少气)**.
  *(Annotation: From *Spring needling of collaterals* to *blurring of vision*, the meaning aligns with *Diagnostic Canon’s Final Theory (诊要经终论)*, though phrasing differs. The latter elaborates where this text omits Autumn Equinox needling. This *Long Summer* division for muscle needling likely corresponds to the *Autumn skin* section in the other text.)*
- **Spring needling of muscles (春刺肌肉)** causes **qi to circulate inversely (血气环逆)**, leading to **upward gasping (上气)**.
  *(Annotation: The text omits *Spring needling at Autumn Equinox*.)*
- **Spring needling of tendons and bones (春刺筋骨)** causes **qi to attach internally (血气内着)**, leading to **abdominal distension (腹胀)**.

- **Summer needling of meridians (夏刺经脉)** causes **qi to be exhausted (血气乃竭)**, leading to **indeterminate sweating (解传)**—*indeterminate* means **neither cold nor hot, neither strong nor weak**, hence unnamed.
- **Summer needling of muscles (夏刺肌肉)** causes **qi to retreat internally (血气内却)**, leading to **frequent fear (善恐)**—*却* means **closure**. When **qi is internally blocked**, *yang* does not circulate, hence **frequent fear**.
- **Summer needling of tendons and bones (夏刺筋骨)** causes **qi to reverse upward (血气上逆)**, leading to **frequent anger (善怒)**.

「When **qi reverses upward (血气上逆)**, the **anger qi** responds in kind, hence **frequent anger (善怒)**.
  *(Annotation: The newly corrected text notes: According to the Classic, *Summer needling at Autumn Equinox* is omitted.)*

- **Autumn needling of meridians (秋刺经脉)** causes **qi to reverse upward (血气上逆)**, leading to **frequent forgetfulness (善忘)**.
  When **qi reverses upward**, it accumulates in the **lungs (满於肺中)**, hence **frequent forgetfulness**.

- **Autumn needling of collateral vessels (秋刺络脉)** causes **qi to fail to circulate externally (气不外行)**.
  *(Annotation: The newly corrected text notes: According to another version, it reads *qi fails to nourish externally (血气不行)*; Quan Yuanqi’s version reads *qi does not guard externally (气不卫外)*, matching the *Taoist Canon*.)*
  This leads to **lying without desire to move (卧不欲动)**—due to **excessive vacuity (以虚甚故)**.
  *(Annotation: The newly corrected text notes: According to the Classic, *Autumn needling at Late Summer Equinox* is omitted.)*

- **Autumn needling of tendons and bones (秋刺筋骨)** causes **qi to scatter internally (血气内散)**, leading to **chills and shivering (寒栗)**.
  When **qi scatters internally**, the **central qi weakens (中气虚)**, hence **chills and shivering**.

- **Winter needling of meridians (冬刺经脉)** causes **qi to be entirely depleted (血气皆脱)**, leading to **blurred vision (目不明)**—due to **qi failing to nourish (以血气无所营故也)**.

- **Winter needling of collateral vessels (冬刺络脉)** causes **internal qi to leak externally (内气外泄)**, resulting in **severe numbness (大痹)**.

- **Winter needling of muscles (冬刺肌肉)** causes **yang qi to be exhausted (阳气竭绝)**, leading to **frequent forgetfulness (善忘)**.
  When **yang qi is not robust (阳气不壮)**, it is fully depleted by **Spring (至春而竭)**, hence **frequent forgetfulness**.
  *(Annotation: The newly corrected text notes: According to the Classic, *Winter needling at Autumn Equinox* is omitted.)*

In all these **four seasonal needlings (凡此四时刺者)**, they produce **greatly inverted diseases (大逆之病)**.
  *(Annotation: According to Quan Yuanqi’s version, it reads *the diseases of the Six Canons (六经之病)*.)*
  These must be **avoided (不可不从也)**.
  If **reversed (反之)**, even once, **disordered qi will proliferate (生乱气)**, leading to **excessive diseases (相淫病焉)**.
  *淫* means **without sequence (不次也)**—acting without proper order, like **gradual contamination (浸淫相染)** that generates disease.

Thus, **needling without following the seasonal Canons (刺不知四时之经)** means the **origin of disease follows inversion (病之所生)**.
When **correct qi is internally disordered (正气内乱)** and **interacts with vital essence (与精相薄)**, one must **examine the Nine Signs (必审九候)**.
Only then will **correct qi not be disordered (正气不乱)** and **vital qi not be inverted (精气不转)**!
*不转* means **not inverted (不逆转也)**.

The Emperor said: **"Excellent (善)."**

Needling the **Heart** causes death in **one day**; its **manifestation** is **sighing**.
*The Zhen Yao Jing Zhong Lun* states: *"Needling the Heart leads to encircled death."*
*The Ci Jin Lun* states: *"Death in one day; its manifestation is sighing."*

Needling the **Liver** causes death in **five days**; its **manifestation** is **speech**.
*The Zhen Yao Jing Zhong Lun* omits discussion on this.
*The Ci Jin Lun* states: *"Needling the Liver causes death in five days; its manifestation is speech."*
**Newly corrected:** According to the *Jia Yi Jing*, it reads *"yawn"* instead.

Needling the **Lung** causes death in **three days**; its **manifestation** is **coughing**.
*The Zhen Yao Jing Zhong Lun* states: *"Needling the Lung causes death in five days."*
*The Ci Jin Lun* states: *"Needling the Lung causes death in three days; its manifestation is coughing."*

Needling the **Kidney** causes death in **six days**; its **manifestation** is **swallowing**.
**Newly corrected:** According to the *Jia Yi Jing*, it reads *"three days"* instead.
*The Zhen Yao Jing Zhong Lun* states: *"Needling the Spleen causes death in five days."*
*The Ci Jin Lun* states: *"Needling the Kidney causes death in six days; its manifestation is swallowing."*

Yet these three treatises—all attributed to **Qibo**—differ in their days of death and manifestations, likely due to transmission errors.

If needling **injures the Five Zang**, **wrinkling (皴)** will inevitably lead to death. Its **manifestations** follow the **changes of the respective Zang** to determine death.
*Variable* refers to **changes in qi movement**.

From needling the **Heart** downward, these are all cases of **inversion and compliance**—**redundant phrasing** for emphasis.

**"Discourse on the Transmission of Disease Between Manifestation and Root**
*(Newly corrected: According to Quan Yuanqi’s original text, this appears before the *Discourse on the Skin Department*.)*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"When disease presents with manifestation and root, and needling follows inversion or compliance—how should one proceed?"*

Qibo replied: *"In all needling methods, one must first distinguish yin and yang, then observe their sequential correspondence. Whether inversion or compliance is applied, the relationship between manifestation and root shifts accordingly. Thus, there are cases where the disease lies in the manifestation yet is sought in the root, where it lies in the root yet is sought in the manifestation, where it lies in the root yet is sought in the manifestation, and where it lies in the manifestation yet is treated by first addressing the root.

Therefore, treatment may succeed by targeting the manifestation alone, the root alone, inversion alone, or compliance alone. When one grasps the essence of the disease and understands the broad principle of treatment, both inversion and compliance become applicable, and the method is naturally correct.

Thus, knowing inversion and compliance requires no further questioning. Knowing manifestation and root ensures success in every case. When one’s understanding is not confused by the Dao, and discernment is profound and clear, there is no need to consult others—every application will be correct. Ignorance of manifestation and root is reckless practice. If perception is narrow and shallow, and the Dao remains obscure and profound, actions will often err, leading to many mistakes.

The principles of yin and yang, inversion and compliance, manifestation and root—though seemingly small—embrace the great. To speak of one is to know the harm of a hundred diseases. This is the ultimate precision. To distinguish yin and yang, to know inversion and compliance, to clarify the laws and observe their subtleties—when examining what is raised, it may seem minor, but when tracing its benefits, it becomes vast. Through this clarity, one may speak of one thing and know the harm of a hundred diseases. From the few, one grasps the many; from the shallow, one comprehends the deep. Thus, one may speak of one thing and know a hundred diseases.

To say that the few can encompass the many, and that the shallow can measure the deep—what law is so clear that only the Sage’s Dao could attain this?

Thus, those who study may also speak of one thing and know a hundred diseases.
*Bó* means *great*.

With the shallow, one knows the deep; with the near, one knows the far. Though the Dao of manifestation and root is easy to speak of, few in the world can truly grasp it.

*Treatment contrary to the disease is inversion; treatment in accord with the disease is compliance.*

If disease appears first and inversion follows, treat the root. If inversion appears first and disease follows, treat the root. If cold appears first and disease follows, treat the root. If disease appears first and cold follows, treat the root. If heat appears first and disease follows, treat the root. If heat appears first and *zhòngmǎn* (distension/fullness) follows, treat the manifestation. If disease appears first and diarrhea follows, treat the root. If diarrhea appears first and another disease follows, treat the root—first harmonizing it, then addressing the other disease. If disease appears first and *zhòngmǎn* follows, treat the manifestation. If *zhòngmǎn* appears first and mental agitation follows, treat the root.

Humans have *guest-qi* and *native-qi*.
*(Newly corrected: According to Quan Yuanqi’s original text, this reads *fixed/enduring-qi*.)*

When both small and large intestines are dysfunctional, treat the manifestation. When only the large intestine is dysfunctional, treat the root.

If the root is first diseased and the manifestation follows, examine carefully. If the disease erupts with excess, treat it as *root-to-manifestation*—first the root, then the manifestation. If the disease erupts with deficiency, treat it as *manifestation-to-root*—first the manifestation, then the root.

*Root-to-manifestation* refers to cases where one disease follows another. Because of its excess, one first treats the root, then the manifestation. *Manifestation-to-root* refers to cases where a mild, gradual onset precedes a severe, urgent one. Because of its deficiency, one first treats the manifestation, then the root.

Examine carefully, questioning extensively, and adjust accordingly.
*Questioning* means *many signs*. *Vast* means *few signs*.
*Many* refers to multiple symptoms that are light and easy to discern. *Few* refers to sparse symptoms that are severe and difficult to diagnose.
*Adjust accordingly* means to regulate based on whether manifestation and root are in excess or deficiency—not to arbitrarily apply methods based on personal whim.

When symptoms are *many*, treat them in combination. When symptoms are *vast*, treat them singly.

If small and large intestinal dysfunction precede disease, treat the root.
*Combination* means multiple pulses receiving pathogenic *qi* and converging in disease. *Singular* means a single channel is diseased without other abnormal *qi* interfering.

When combined symptoms are severe, they transmit. When transmission is urgent, death follows.

As for diseases that transmit:
Heart disease begins with heart pain—
*The Zang’s true essence communicates with the heart, hence the heart pains first.*
On the first day, coughing—
*The heart’s fire overcomes metal, transmitting to the lungs. The lungs, in change, manifest as coughing.*
On the third day, hypochondriac pain—
*The lungs’ metal overcomes wood, transmitting to the liver. Because the liver’s *qi* courses along the ribs, it manifests thus.*
On the fifth day, obstruction and stagnation, with body heaviness and pain—
*The liver’s wood overcomes earth, transmitting to the spleen. The spleen’s nature is to settle and harmonize; when wood *qi* assaults it, obstruction and stagnation occur, with body heaviness and pain.*
If this persists for three days, death follows.
*Because the overpowering weakens the attacked, and the four Zang are injured, how could it endure? Thus, death is immediate.*

At the winter *night half* (23:00–01:00) or the summer *day half* (11:00–13:00).
*This refers to the true *zi* and *wu* hours.*
Some say winter and summer differ, but this is incorrect. The division of day and night is clearly evident.

*(Newly corrected: According to the *Língshū Jīng*: "When great *qi* enters the Zang, disease first manifests in the heart, then on the first day transmits to the lungs, on the third day to the liver, on the fifth day to the spleen. If it persists for three days, death follows. Winter at night half, summer at day half."
The *Jia Yi Jing* states: "Disease first manifests in the heart, with heart pain. On the first day, it transmits to the lungs, causing coughing. On the third day, it transmits to the liver, causing hypochondriac pain. On the fifth day, it transmits to the spleen, causing obstruction, stagnation, body heaviness, and pain. If it persists for three days, death follows. Winter at night half, summer at day half."
The *Su Wèn* elaborates on the disease, the *Língshū* on the Zang, while the *Jia Yi Jing* combines both *Su Wèn* and *Língshū*, detailing both disease progression and Zang transmission.)"

The *Língshū* states: "When the lungs are diseased, there is wheezing and coughing, for the **Zàngzhēn** (藏真, *true essence of the Zang*) is higher than the lungs and governs respiration, hence the wheezing and coughing. On the third day, the hypochondriac region becomes distended and painful, as the lungs transmit the disease to the liver. On the first day, the body feels heavy and painful, as the liver transmits the disease to the spleen. On the fifth day, there is distension, and the disease transmits itself to the **Fǔ** (府, *Fu organs*). If it persists for ten days, death follows. In winter, it enters [the body] by day; in summer, it exits by day.

At the midpoint of **Mèngdōng** (孟冬, *early winter*), the sun sets at the **Shēn** (申) hour, **8 kè** (刻) and **2 fēn** (分) of time. At the midpoint of **Zhòngdōng** (仲冬, *mid-winter*), the sun sets at the **Shēn** hour, **7 kè** and **3 fēn** of time. At the midpoint of **Jìdōng** (季冬, *late winter*), the sun sets at the **Shēn** hour, equal to that of **Mèngyuè** (孟月, *early month*).

At the midpoint of **Mèngxià** (孟夏, *early summer*), the sun rises at the **Yín** (寅) hour, **8 kè** and **1 fēn** of time. At the midpoint of **Zhòngxià** (仲夏, *mid-summer*), the sun rises at the **Yín** (寅) hour, **7 kè** and **3 fēn** of time. At the midpoint of **Jìxià** (季夏, *late summer*), the sun rises at the **Yín** hour, equal to that of **Mèngyuè** (孟月, *early month*) as well.

When the liver is diseased, there is dizziness of the head and eyes, and distension in the hypochondriac region, for the **Zàngzhēn** (藏真, *true essence of the Zang*) disperses through the liver, and its pulse connects internally with the eyes and hypochondrium, hence such symptoms. On the third day, the body feels heavy and painful, as the liver transmits the disease to the lungs. On the fifth day, there is distension, and the disease transmits itself to the **Fǔ** (府, *Fu organs*)."

The sun sets at the **Shēn** (申) hour, **8 kè** and **2 fēn** of time. At the midpoint of **Zhòngdōng** (仲冬, *mid-winter*), the sun sets at the **Shēn** hour, **7 kè** and **3 fēn** of time. At the midpoint of **Jìdōng** (季冬, *late winter*), the sun sets at the **Shēn** hour, equal to that of **Mèngyuè** (孟月, *early month*) as well.

When the liver is diseased, there is dizziness of the head and eyes, and distension in the hypochondriac region, for the **Zàngzhēn** (藏真, *true essence of the Zang*) disperses through the liver, and its pulse connects internally with the eyes and hypochondrium, hence such symptoms.

On the third day, the **yào** (腰, *lumbar region*), **jǐ** (脊, *spine*), and **shǎo fù** (少腹, *lower abdomen*) ache, and the **jīng** (经, *meridians*) feel sour—this is called the stomach transmitting the disease to the **shèn** (肾, *kidneys*). For its pulse arises at the foot, follows the **duān** (端, *extremity*) internally, emerges at the **xīn** (胭, *inner ankle*), ascends the inner thigh to the **hòu kàng** (后康, *posterior knee crease*), pierces the spine, and connects with the kidneys, linking to the **pángguāng** (膀胱, *urinary bladder*), hence such symptoms. The lumbar region is the **Fǔ** (府, *Fu organ*) of the kidneys, so there is lumbar pain. If the pain persists for three days, death follows.

In winter, the sun sets early; the newly revised text states: according to the *Jiāyǐ Jīng* (甲乙经, *Canon of the Jia and Yi*), it should be **day mid** (日中, *midday*). In summer, the sun sets early as well. The time of setting early or late follows the winter method. Early setting refers to setting before the usual meal time, which is the **Chǎo** (卯) hour. When the **pí** (脾, *spleen*) is diseased, there is body pain and heaviness, for the **Zàngzhēn** (藏真, *true essence of the Zang*) permeates the spleen, and the spleen governs the muscles, hence such symptoms. On the first day, there is distension, and the disease transmits itself to the **Fǔ** (府, *Fu organs*). On the second day, the lower abdomen, lumbar region, and spine ache, and the **jīng** (经, *meridians*) feel sour—this is the stomach transmitting the disease to the kidneys. On the third day, the back feels fatty (or swollen), the **jīn** (筋, *tendons*) ache, and urination is blocked; the disease transmits itself to the **Fǔ** (府, *Fu organs*) and the **tāi** (胎, *fetus*). If this persists for ten days, death follows.

In winter, the sun sets at **Shēn** hour, **25 kè** after **Rén** (人, *person*) hour. In summer, the sun sets at **Yín** hour, **25 kè** after **Mèngyuè** (孟月, *early month*). When the kidneys are diseased, the lower abdomen, lumbar region, and spine ache, and the **Fǔ** (腑, *Fu organs*) feel sour, for the **Zàngzhēn** (藏真, *true essence of the Zang*) descends to the kidneys, hence such symptoms.

「On the third day, the back and fetus suffer tendon pain, and urination is blocked; the disease transmits itself to the **Fu** (腑, *Fu organs*).

○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Línggū Jīng* (《灵枢经》), "the fetus" refers to the **Pángguāng** (膀胱, *bladder*), meaning the disease transmits itself to the **Fu** (腑) and the **Pángguāng** (膀胱) as well.

On the third day, the abdomen distends, and the **Pángguāng** (膀胱, *bladder*) transmits the disease to the **Xiǎocháng** (小肠, *Small Intestine*).
○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Jiǎyǐ Jīng* (《甲乙经》), it reads: "On the third day, it ascends to the heart, causing heart distension."

On the third day, both sides of the ribs and lateral branches ache; the **Fu** (腑) transmits the disease to the **Zàng** (藏, *Zang organs*).
○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Línggū Jīng* (《灵枢经》), it reads: "On the third day, it is the Small Intestine; on the third day, it ascends to the heart." Now it states that both sides of the ribs and lateral branches ache, meaning the **Fu** (腑) of the Small Intestine transmits the disease to the heart, causing pain.

If this persists for three days, death follows.

In winter, the **Dàchén** (大晨, *great dawn*) occurs; in summer, the **Yànbǔ** (晏哺, *late nursing*) occurs.
**Dàchén** refers to the time **9 kè** after **Yín** (寅, *tiger*) hour, when the light is at its brightest.
**Yànbǔ** refers to the time **9 kè** after **Shēn** (申, *monkey*) hour, when the light is fading toward dusk.

When the stomach is diseased, causing distension and fullness, it is because its **mài** (脉, *pulse/meridian*) courses through the abdomen, hence such symptoms.

On the fifth day, the lower abdomen and lumbar spine ache, the **Fu** (腑) feel sour, and the stomach transmits the disease to the **kidney** (肾). On the third day, the back’s fatty tissues and sinews ache, and urination is obstructed, as the **bladder** (膀胱) transmits the disease to the **Fu** (腑) and the **embryo** (胎) as well. On the fifth day, the body feels heavy, for the **bladder** (膀胱) and **water Fu** (水府) transmit the disease to the **spleen** (脾).

The newly annotated text states: According to the *Lingshu Jing* (《灵枢经》) and the *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》), each describes the fifth day as transmitting to the heart. This means the bladder transmits to the heart, causing the body to feel heavy due to mutual opposition. Now, Wang’s statement that it transmits to the spleen is incorrect.

If this persists for six days, death follows. In winter, it occurs after midnight; in summer, it occurs at **day drip** (日跌, *late afternoon*). Midnight after refers to **8 kè** after **Zǐ** (子, *rat*) hour, when **Chǒu** (丑, *ox*) hour begins. **Day drip** refers to **8 kè** after **Wǔ** (午, *horse*) hour, before **Yǔ** (酉, *rooster*) hour. **Drip** is pronounced as *yǎn* (晏), with the initial *yù* (徒) and the rhyme *jié* (结). When the bladder is diseased and urination is obstructed, it is because the bladder is the **Fu** (府) of **jīn-yè** (津液, *body fluids*), hence such symptoms.

On the fifth day, the lower abdomen distends, and the lumbar spine aches with sourness in the **Fu** (腑), as it naturally returns to the **Zàng** (藏, *solid organ*). On the first day, the abdomen distends, and the **kidney** (肾) again transmits the disease to the small intestine. On the first day, the body aches, as the small intestine transmits the disease to the spleen.

The newly annotated text states: According to the *Lingshu Jing* (《灵枢经》), the text reads: "On the first day, it ascends to the heart. This is the **Fu** (府) transmitting to the **Zàng** (藏)." The *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》) reads: "On the second day, it does not cease, death follows." In winter, it occurs at **cock’s crow** (鸡呜, *early morning*); in summer, it occurs at **late nursing** (下哺, *afternoon*). **Cock’s crow** refers to the division of **Chǒu** (丑, *ox*) hour at dawn. **Late nursing** refers to **5 kè** after **Shēn** (申, *monkey*) hour. All diseases follow this sequential transmission pattern (#24), and those that do will have a fixed period of death, making acupuncture treatment unfeasible.

When the **Zàng** (藏, *solid organs*) transmit diseases sequentially, some cases involve gradual transmission, while others are abrupt. Gradual cases may lead to death after one, two, or three years, or after three or six months; abrupt cases may lead to death within one, two, three, or four days, or even five or six days, such as in this instance.

Examining the transmission laws of this disease, they align with the **Five Phases** (五行) **qi** (气). By reviewing the number of days, one can discern the underlying principle. According to the **Five Phases** system, when the **unconquering** (不胜) **qi** transmits to the **conquering** (所胜) organ—such as fire transmitting to metal (金) on the first day, metal transmitting to wood (木) on the second day, wood transmitting to earth (土) on the third day, earth transmitting to water (水) on the fourth day, and water transmitting to fire (火) on the fifth day—then the transmission follows the **Five Phases** **qi** of the **three yin and three yang** (三阴三阳).

The *Yùjī Zhēncáng Lùn* (《玉机真藏论》) states: The **Zàng** (藏, *solid organs*) are interconnected, and their transmission follows a specific sequence. If left untreated, death may occur after three or six months, or within three or six days, as the disease transmits and reaches its critical point.

Although this is the case, one should still carefully observe the symptoms and count the days when diagnosing the disease to fully understand its progression. When the disease stops at one **Zàng** (藏), the newly annotated text states: The *Jia-Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》) does not have the character **止** (*stop*). When it reaches the third or fourth **Zàng** (藏), acupuncture treatment may be feasible.

When the disease stops at one **Zàng** (藏), it means that after passing through the previous **Zàng** (藏), it no longer transmits further. This would be the case when wood transmits to earth, earth transmits to water, water transmits to fire, fire transmits to metal, and metal transmits to wood, all while stopping after each transmission.

When it reaches the third or fourth **Zàng** (藏), it means the disease has progressed to the third or fourth **Zàng** (藏) in sequence. When it reaches the third **Zàng** (藏), it is the **unconquering** (不胜) **qi** of its own phase. When it reaches the fourth **Zàng** (藏), it is the **qi** of the **parental** (父母) organ that it generates. If the **qi** is unconquering, it cannot cause harm; regarding the organ it generates, there is no parent-child conflict, and the **qi** flows harmoniously, hence acupuncture treatment is possible.

**The Great Treatise on the Celestial Primordium**

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"The Celestial Five Phases govern the Five Positions, giving rise to cold, heat, dryness, dampness, and wind. The human Five Viscera transform the Five Qi, giving rise to joy, anger, thought, worry, and fear. 'Govern' means to oversee. 'Transform' means to generate and change.*

*The vital essence of Heaven is pervasive without bounds. Though their manifestations differ, their correspondences are unified.*

**New Annotation:** *According to the *Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang*, the emotions are joy, anger, sorrow, worry, and fear. The two treatises differ because 'thought' pertains to the Spleen, which all Four Viscera rely upon for completion, and 'sorrow' overcomes anger—thus the two treatises complement each other.*

*The Treatise states that the Five Movements succeed one another in governance, and their terminal days complete a cycle, returning anew. This I have already understood. Now I wish to hear how they harmonize with the conditions of the Three Yin and Three Yang.*

**Annotation:** *The 'Treatise' refers to the *Treatise on the Six Nodal Phases and Viscera*. 'Movements' refers to the Five Phases corresponding to Heaven’s Five Movements, each completing a cycle of 365 days as a standard. Thus, it is said that their terminal days complete a cycle, returning anew. Since six and five do not yet harmonize in their numerical correspondence, I ask this.*

Ghostly Yu Qiu knelt and bowed twice in reply: *"Your question is profound! The Five Movements of Yin and Yang are the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the fundamental order of all things, the origin of transformation, the source of life and death, and the repository of divine mystery—how could one not master them?*

**Annotation:** *Dao refers to the principle of generation and transformation. 'Fundamental order' refers to the principles governing growth, transformation, formation, storage, and concealment. 'Origin' means that life and death arise from these. The Five Movements of Yin and Yang govern all things without exception. Why, then, does creation not reach its utmost, and why are they the primordial source of all generation and transformation? It is because they are the repository of divine mystery.*

*Yet their coalescence and dispersal are unfathomable, and their generation and transformation are boundless—not because the Five Movements are inadequate, but because their operations are profound.*

**New Annotation:** *The detailed explanation of 'Yin and Yang as the repository of divine mystery' aligns with the *Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang*, though the commentaries differ.*

*Thus, when things are born, it is called 'transformation'; when they reach their limit, it is called 'change'; when Yin and Yang are unfathomable, it is called 'divine'; when divine operations are boundless, it is called 'sage.' This is the Dao of transformation, change, sagehood, and divinity.*

**Annotation:** *Transformation refers to the application of change. Change refers to dispersal and alteration. Divine refers to the absence of limits. Sage refers to the absence of measurable thought. The application of Qi brings forth life; its dispersal brings forth limits; its boundless nature is called divine; its immeasurability is called sage. Through transformation and change, no thing can escape the Five Movements of Yin and Yang. Through sagehood and divinity, no marvel can transcend the profound principles of the cosmos.*

*Profound indeed are their wondrous operations, beyond all description.*

**New Annotation:** *According to the *Treatise on the Six Subtle Principles*, it is said: 'The birth of things arises from transformation; their limits arise from change. The interplay of transformation and change determines success and failure.' Again, the *Treatise on the Five Constant Regulations* states: 'Qi begins and generates transformation; Qi disperses and forms shape; Qi spreads and nurtures; Qi concludes and changes form—its effects are unified.'*

*The operations of transformation and change are vast:*
- *In Heaven, they are the Mysterious (玄).*
**Annotation:** *Mysterious refers to the distant and profound. The Dao of Heaven is distant and profound, its transformations boundless. The Classic says: 'The Dao of Heaven is distant; the Dao of humanity is near.'*
- *In humanity, they are the Way.*
**Annotation:** *Way refers to the principle of wondrous operation. The Classic unfolds regulations and transformations; without the Way, they cannot be complete.*
- *On Earth, they are transformation.*
**Annotation:** *Transformation refers to generation. It is the source of all things. Without the nurturing Qi of Earth, their forms and substances would not be complete. Transformation generates the Five Flavors—metals, stones, grasses, and trees—roots, leaves, flowers, and fruits: sour, bitter, sweet, bland, and salty, all arising from transformative Qi in their proper seasons.*

*The Way generates wisdom. Wisdom comprehends wondrous operations, arising solely from the Way.*

*The Mysterious generates the Divine. The Mysterious is distant and profound, thus it generates the Divine. The operations of the Divine, when encountering the Mysterious, harmonize with all things, completing transformations without fail.*

*The Divine, in Heaven, is Wind—*
**Annotation:** *Wind is the beginning of instruction, Heaven’s decree, Heaven’s command.*

*—in Earth, is Wood; the transformation of the Eastern direction.*

*—in Heaven, is Heat—*
**Annotation:** *It corresponds to Fire in its function.*

*—in Earth, is Fire; the transformation of the Southern direction.*

*—in Heaven, is Dampness—*
**Annotation:** *It corresponds to Earth in its function.*

*—in Earth, is Earth; the transformation of the Central direction.*

*—in Heaven, is Dryness—*
**Annotation:** *It corresponds to Metal in its function.*

*—in Earth, is Metal; the transformation of the Western direction.*

*—in Heaven, is Cold—*
**Annotation:** *It corresponds to Water in its function.*

*—in Earth, is Water; the transformation of the Northern direction.*

*The operations of the Divine manifest in these Five Transformations:*
- *Wood is generated by Wind,*
- *Fire is ignited by Heat,*
- *Metal is refined by Dryness,*
- *Water is sustained by Cold,*
- *Earth is nourished by Dampness—*
*for these are their initial conditions for establishment.*

*Though initially established through these, they ultimately disperse and decay through the same. Is this unique to the Five Phases? All things that arise from their conditions will likewise disperse through them.*

**New Annotation:** *The detailed explanation from 'In Heaven, it is the Mysterious' onward aligns with the *Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* and the *Treatise on the Five Movements*, though the commentaries differ.*

*Thus, in Heaven, it is Qi; on Earth, it takes form. Qi—Wind, Heat, Dampness, Dryness, and Cold—senses with form—Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water—and together they generate all things. This is the grand principle of creation and transformation.*

*Yet Heaven and Earth are the upper and lower bounds of all things. Heaven covers, Earth supports; above and below interact, and all things transform and generate without omission. Thus, all things spontaneously generate, grow, transform, complete, fill, empty, renew, and change.*

Now, what is this **transformation**? It refers to the **Qi** of life reaching its peak and then renewing itself through **creation and transformation**.

Confucius said: *"It bends and completes all things without omission."*

**Left and right** are the **paths** of **Yin and Yang**; Heaven has the **six Qi** to govern below, and Earth has the **Five Movements** to pay homage above. The **current year’s cycle** is the **upper**, ruling over Heaven. The **inheriting year’s cycle** is the **lower**, ruling over Earth. When a cycle does not align with the year, the **two Qi** reside on the **right**, and the **Northern Movement** turns them; the **two Qi** reside on the **left**, and the **Southern Movement** turns them. The **movements of Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire** are governed by the **Northern** aspect, yet **left** and **right** are constantly reversed—so the **left** follows the **Southern Movement**, while the **right** follows the **Northern Movement**, and they invert.

**New Annotation:** The detailed examination of **left and right** aligns with the *Treatise on the Five Movements*, though the interpretations differ.

**Water and Fire** are the **signs** of **Yin and Yang**; **signs** mean **truth** and **verification**, while **omens** mean **precedence**. Through the **cold and heat** of **Water and Fire**, the **truth** and **precedence** of **Yin and Yang** are made manifest. **Metal and Wood** are the **end and beginning** of **generation and transformation**. Wood governs **emergence** and corresponds to **Spring**, which marks the **beginning** of **life and transformation**. Metal governs **contraction and gathering** and corresponds to **Autumn**, which marks the **completion** of **harvest and fruition**. As **end and beginning** never cease, their **transformation** is ever in motion—thus, all things endure through **generation, growth, transformation, completion, contraction, and storage**.

**New Annotation:** Referring to the *Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang*, it states: *"Heaven and Earth are the upper and lower bounds of all things; Yin and Yang are the male and female of blood and Qi; Left and Right are the paths of Yin and Yang; Water and Fire are the signs of Yin and Yang; Yin and Yang are the originators of all things."* This aligns closely with the present discourse.

**Qi** varies in abundance, and **form** fluctuates in **prosperity and decline**. Above and below **summon each other**, revealing **deficiency and excess** with clarity. **Qi** varies in abundance refers to the **three degrees** of Heaven’s **Yin and Yang**, differing in rank. **Form** fluctuates in **prosperity and decline** refers to the **Five Movements**’ **Qi**, which may be **too excessive or insufficient**. The **Heavenly Cycle** completes in **six periods**,
while the **Earthly Cycle** completes in **five years**—
**six periods** refer to the division of **six Qi**,
**five standards** refer to the division of **five stations**.

Since **one station** corresponds to **one year**,
and **one Qi** governs **one year**,
then **five years** complete one **Earthly Cycle**,
and **six years** complete one **Heavenly Cycle**.

**Completion** means exhausting all **Heavenly Qi**,
**Cycle** means traversing all **Earthly stations**.
The reason Earth has **six stations** but only **five** are spoken of
is that **Heavenly Qi** does not descend upon **Minister Fire**.

**Minister Fire** governs **illumination**,
**Relative Fire** governs **position**.
Though **Minister Fire** stands to the right of **Relative Fire**,
its name is established in the **Sovereign’s station**,
yet no **yearly Qi** is assigned to it—
thus, **Heaven’s six Qi** do not pair with their corresponding Qi in motion.
**Minister Fire’s** governance **holds its station**,
receiving **Heaven’s command** to propagate the **Fire’s decree**.

Because its name is received from Heaven,
it is called **"Minister Fire by name"**.
Because it **holds its station** and **receives command**,
it is called **"Relative Fire by position."**

When **five and six** combine,
**seven hundred twenty Qi** form one **Great Cycle**—
thirty years, **one thousand four hundred forty Qi**—
sixty years, completing one **full revolution**,
without excess or deficiency—
all this is evident.

The **calendar’s method**: one **Qi** spans **fifteen days**,
and when multiplied accordingly,
**seven hundred twenty Qi** accumulate to **thirty years**,
**one thousand four hundred forty Qi** to **sixty years**.

*"When there is excess, it proceeds forward;*
*when deficient, it follows behind.*
*When deficient, it proceeds forward;*
*when in excess, it follows behind."*
Thus, within **sixty years**,
no excess or deficiency remains—
all this is evident.

**Essence** means **the pivotal mechanism**.

Ghostly Yu Qu replied:
*"Your question is **radiant**!
Your **Dao is clear**!
Like the **drum’s response to the striker**,
or the **echo’s response to sound**."

I have heard:
*"In **Jia-Ji years**#7, the **Earth Phase** governs;
In **Yi-Geng years**, the **Metal Phase** governs;
In **Bing-Xin years**, the **Water Phase** governs;
In **Ding-Ren years**, the **Wood Phase** governs;
In **Wu-Gui years**, the **Fire Phase** governs."*

At the **beginning of Heaven and Earth’s division**,
when **Yin and Yang** first separated,
**Heaven** distributed **five Qi**,
**Earth** arranged the **five Phases**,
the **five Phases** fixed their stations,
governing the **four directions**,
the **five Qi** dispersed their branches
through the **ten Heavenly Stems**#8.

At that time:
**Yellow Qi**#9 dominated **Jia-Ji**,
**White Qi** dominated **Yi-Geng**,
**Black Qi** dominated **Bing-Xin**,
**Green Qi** dominated **Ding-Ren**,
**Red Qi** dominated **Wu-Gui**.

Thus, **Jia-Ji years** correspond to the **Earth Phase**’s reign,
**Yi-Geng years** correspond to the **Metal Phase**’s reign,
**Bing-Xin years** correspond to the **Water Phase**’s reign,
**Ding-Ren years** correspond to the **Wood Phase**’s reign,
**Wu-Gui years** correspond to the **Fire Phase**’s reign.

In the **Great Ancient Era**, the **Sage** observed the **Qi** and recorded the **Heavenly Mandate**#10,
while the **Worthy**#11 reverently preserved it to mark the **Heavenly Primordial Qi**#12.
The lower discourse on **textual meanings** is fully complete.

**Newly corrected text** states:
*"In examining the reigns, there are **excessive**, **deficient**, and **balanced Qi**—
**Jia-Geng and Bing-Ren years**#13 govern **excessive**,
**Yi-Xin, Ding-Gui, and Wu-Ji years**#14 govern **deficient**;
this is the **Great Principle**.
The method of **balanced Qi** varies, as detailed in other texts."*

The **Emperor** asked:
*"How do the **three Yin** and **three Yang** combine in their reign?"*

**Gui-Yu Qu** replied:
*"In **Zi-Mu years**#15, the **Lesser Yin** (**少阴**, *Shǎo Yīn*)#16 appears above.
In **Chou-Wei years**#17, the **Greater Yin** (**太阴**, *Tài Yīn*)#18 appears above.
In **Yin-Shen years**#19, the **Lesser Yang** (**少阳**, *Shǎo Yáng*)#20 appears above.
In **Mao-You years**#21, the **Yang Brightness** (**阳明**, *Yáng Míng*)#22 appears above.
In **Chen-Xu years**#23, the **Greater Yang** (**太阳**, *Tài Yáng*)#24 appears above.
In **Xi-Hai years**#25, the **Jue Yin** (**厥阴**, *Jué Yīn*)#26 appears above.
The **Lesser Yin** is called the **beginning**,
and the **Jue Yin** is called the **conclusion**.
**Beginning** refers to the **uppermost**,
**conclusion** refers to the **end of three Jia and six Jia**#27.

**Newly corrected text** states:
*"In detail, **Mu-Wei-Shen-You-Xu-Hai years**#28 are **true transformations**#29,
which govern the **realized** aspects of **Qi’s transformations**#30.
**Zi-Chou-Yin-Mao-Chen-Xi years**#31 are **counter transformations**#32,
which govern the **virtual** aspects of **Qi’s transformations**#33.
This is their **Great Principle**.*

Above **Jue Yin**, the **Wind Qi**#34 of **One**#35 governs;
above **Lesser Yin**, the **dual Heat Qi**#36 governs.
Above **Greater Yin**, the **Bell Qi**#37 generates **One**;
above **Lesser Yang**, the **mutual Fire**#38 governs;
above **Yang Brightness**, the **dry Qi**#39 governs;
above **Greater Yang**, the **cold Qi**#40 governs.
This is called the **root**—
thus, it is the **Six Primordial Qi**#41.

The **three Yin** and **three Yang** are the **beginning**,
while **cold, heat, dryness, wind, fire, and dampness**#42 govern the **root**,
hence the term **"root"**.
The **Heavenly True Primordial Qi**#43 divides into **six transformations**#44,
to govern the **Kun Primordial Qi**#45’s generative functions.
Examining their **applications**, the **six transformations** differ,
but tracing their **origins**, they are all the **Heavenly True Primordial Qi**#46—
thus, they are called the **Six Primordial Qi**#47.

**Newly corrected text** states:
*"According to another version, **Six Primordial Qi** (*六元*) is rendered as **Heavenly Primordial Qi** (*天元*)."*

The **Emperor** said:
*"Illuminating is the **Dao**!
Clear is the discourse!
I request you inscribe it upon **jade tablets**,
store it in the **golden chamber**#48,
and title it **‘Record of the Heavenly Primordial Qi’**#49.

---
**Huangdi Neijing Suwen: Supplementary Commentary, Volume Thirty-Eight** ends.
**Huangdi Neijing Suwen: Supplementary Commentary, Volume Thirty-Nine** begins.
