**The Great Treatise on the Five Movements (Wǔ Yùn Xíng Dà Lùn) Pien**

The Yellow Emperor sat upon the **Clear Hall**—*明堂* (Míngtáng), the **Grand Official’s Chamber**—*宫* (Gōng), establishing the **Heavenly Principles** and surveying the **Eight Extremes**—*八极* (Bā Jí), the limits of the eight directions. He examined and established the **Five Constants**—*五常* (Wǔ Cháng), the **Five Qi** that traverse the space between Heaven and Earth.

In solemn repose, he awaited the **Heavenly Harmony** of the **True Dao-Qi**. He summoned the **Heavenly Master** and asked him:

*"The Treatise states that the movements of Heaven and Earth, their stillness and activity, are governed by the **Divine Manifestations**—*神明* (Shénmíng). The ascent and descent of Yin and Yang reveal the signs of cold and heat. The newly revised text* clarifies this by detailing the Treatise’s discussion in *The Great Treatise on Yin-Yang Correspondences* and *The Great Treatise on Qi’s Transformations*, where it says: ‘The reciprocal course of Yin and Yang reveals the signs of cold and heat.’*

*I learned the principles of the Five Movements from my Master, whose teachings primarily correct the seasonal dominion of each of the Five Qi. The first year of the **Six Jia**—*六甲* (Liù Jiǎ)—determines the movement, and I have expanded upon this.*

**Ghost-Howling Qū** said: *"Earth governs Jia and Ji, Metal governs Yi and Geng, Water governs Bing and Xin, Wood governs Ding and Ren, and Fire governs Wu and Gui. Above the **Child-Midday** branches—*子午* (Zǐ Wǔ)—**Lesser Yin** presides; above the **Ox-Hen** branches—*丑未* (Chǒu Wèi)—**Greater Yin** presides; above the **Tiger-Ape** branches—*寅申* (Yín Shēn)—**Lesser Yang** presides; above the **Rabbit-Rooster** branches—*卯酉* (Mǎo Yǒu)—**Yang Brightness** presides; above the **Dragon-Dog** branches—*辰戌* (Chén Xū)—**Greater Yang** presides; and above the **Snake-Pig** branches—*巳亥* (Wèi Hài)—**Jué Yin** presides.*

*Why does this not align with Yin and Yang? The **Six Jia**—*六甲* (Liù Jiǎ)—refers to the initial year of the **Six Jia Cycle**, which is the year of Jiazi.*

**Qī Bó** replied: *"This is elucidating the **Dao**—*道* (Dào). This is the Yin and Yang of Heaven and Earth."*

*The sages of antiquity, gazing upward at Heaven’s manifestations, regulated Yin and Yang. Though the principles of Yin and Yang are not obscure, people fail to grasp the **Fundamental Origins**—*宗元* (Zōng Yuán)—and lose sight of their **Primordial Source**—*本始* (Běnshǐ). Thus, myriad doubts and disputes arise. The Yellow Emperor, fearing that profound truths and the **True Dao** might be falsely dismissed or neglected, and moved by compassion for the common folk, questioned the Heavenly Master thus:*

*The Heavenly Master understood that the **Dao** emanates from the **True**—*真* (Zhēn)—and was not speaking falsely, so he responded to the Yellow Emperor:*

*‘This is elucidating the **Dao**. This is the Yin and Yang of Heaven and Earth.’*

*The **Yin-Yang Laws** state: ‘Jia and Wei combine, Yi and Geng combine, Bing and Xin combine, Ding and Ren combine, Wu and Gui combine.’ This reflects the sages’ principle of observing Heaven’s manifestations. Otherwise, the ten **Heavenly Stems** would each occupy a distinct direction, and their interactions would be sparse and unclear.*

*Ah, how profound and distant!* **The common people go through their daily lives without knowing this.**

Thus, *The Supreme Scripture of Establishing Speech* (《Tài Shàng Lì Yán》) says:

*"My words are very easy to know,
Very easy to practice;
Yet none under Heaven can know them,
None can practice them.
This is their nature."*

○The newly corrected edition states:
*"Examine the **Heavenly Stems** of Jia and Geng—
Geng is the **Yin** of Jia,
Jia is the **Yang** of Geng.
In broad terms, this is **Yin** and **Yang**;
In narrow terms, this is husband and wife—
A matter of **Yang** and **Yin**.
I follow this principle as well.*

*"The countable **Heavenly Stems** are the **Yin-Yang** of humanity,
Yet their combinations are what can be counted.
**Yin-Yang**, when counted, can reach ten;
When extended, they can reach a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand.
But **Heavenly** **Yin-Yang**—
They are not counted by numbers,
But by **symbols** is what is meant.
Though their indications are vast,
Their understanding is shallow,
For they see only the source,
And **drums and bells** are not distant.

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear of their origins."*

Qibo replied: *"How clear your inquiry is!
I have examined the *Scripture of the Primordial Heavenly Elements* (《Tàishǐ Tiān Yuán Cè》), and found that
**Dan** **Heaven’s** **qi** flows through **Niu** and **Wèi** in the **Wù** division;
**Zhuó** **Heaven’s** **qi**, flows through **Xīn** and **Tǎi** in the **Jǐ** division;
**Cāng** **Heaven’s** **qi**, flows through **Wēi**, **Shì**, **Liǔ**, and **Guǐ**;
**Sù** **Heaven’s** **qi**, flows through **Kàng**, **Shì**, **Xù**, and **Bì**;
**Xuán** **Heaven’s** **qi**, flows through **Zhāng**, **Yì**, **Lóu**, and **Wèi**.

The **Wù-Jǐ** division—
**Kuí** and **Bì** walls, **Jiǎo** and **Wèi** corners—
are the **gateways** of Heaven and Earth.
**Wù** belongs to **Kàn** (乾, *Heaven*), **Jǐ** belongs to **Sūn** (巽, *Wind*).
*The Scripture of the Retreating Heavenly Stems* (《Dùn Jiǎ Jīng》) says:
‘Six **Wù** form the **Heavenly Gate**,
Six **Jǐ** form the **Earthly Portal**,
Morning and evening, observe the **rain**—
with **west-north** and **east-south**.
This principle is derived from here.
**Rain** is the **use** of **Earth**,
And **moist qi** generates it,
Thus this observation is made.

The origins of **divination** and the **Dao**—
They must not be left unclear.

The Emperor said: *"Well spoken.*
*Discussions on Heaven and Earth—
They are the **up-down** of all things,
**Left-right** are the **paths of Yin-Yang**—
I do not yet understand their meaning.*
*The discussions refer to the *Record of the Heavenly Elements* (《Tiān Yuán Jì》) and the *Discourse on Yin-Yang Correspondences and Symbols* (《Yīn-Yáng Yìng-Xiàng》).*

Qibo replied:
*"The **up-down** refers to the **Yin-Yang** seen in the **year’s** **positions** above and below.
**Left-right** are the **routes of the six divisions**—
When **Yin** is seen above,
Left is **Lesser Yin**, right is **Greater Yang**;
When **Lesser Yin** is seen above,
Left is **Greater Yin**, right is **Yin**;
When **Greater Yin** is seen above,
Left is **Lesser Yang**, right is **Lesser Yin**;
When **Lesser Yang** is seen above,
Left is **Yang Brightness**, right is **Greater Yin**;
When **Yang Brightness** is seen above,
Left is **Greater Yang**, right is **Lesser Yang**;
When **Greater Yang** is seen above,
Left is **Lesser Yin**, right is **Greater Yin**.

This is what is meant by **facing north** and naming their **positions**—
It is the perspective of **facing north**.
Above refers to **south**, below refers to **north**,
Left refers to **west**, right refers to **east**.
Though the **up-down** differ, the **left-right** are distinct.

When **above** and **below** interact,
**Cold** and **Heat** alternate,
**Qi** harmonizes when they meet,
But **disease** arises when they do not.
**Wood** and **Fire** interacting,
**Metal** and **Water** interacting,
**Water** and **Wood** interacting,
**Fire** and **Earth** interacting,
**Earth** and **Metal** interacting—
These are **harmonious** encounters.

**Wood** and **Earth** interacting,
**Earth** and **Water** interacting,
**Water** and **Fire** interacting,
**Fire** and **Metal** interacting,
**Metal** and **Wood** interacting—
These are **disharmonious** encounters.

When **above** interacts with **below**, it is **orderly**;
When **below** interacts with **above**, it is **inverted**.
This is also where **stagnation** breeds **disease**—
**Earth** interacting with **Relative Fire** (相火), the **Fire** of **Wood’s** **Master** (君火).

The Emperor said: *"How can **disease** arise when **qi** harmonizes?"*

Qibo replied: *"It is when **below** interacts with **above**, out of proper **position**.
When the six **positions** interact,
Suppose **Earth** interacts with **Fire**,
**Fire** with **Wood**,
**Wood** with **Water**,
**Water** with **Metal**,
**Metal** with **Earth**—
All are cases where **below** interacts with **above**, out of proper **position**.

The principle of **parent-child**—
The **child** is **below**, the **parent** is **above**,
For the **child** to interact with the **parent**—
Is this not **inverted**?"

The Emperor said: *"How about **movement** and **stillness**?"*
*He meant the **left-right** movements of Heaven and Earth.*

Qibo replied:
*"The **above** moves to the **right**,
The **below** moves to the **left**,
**Left-right** cycles through the **Heavenly Circuit**,
And **residual qi** then **reconvenes**.
**Above** is **Heaven**, **below** is **Earth**.
**Heavenly Circuit** means **Heaven** cycles through **Earth’s** **Five Phases** positions.

**Heaven** descends the **Six Qi**,
**Earth** distributes the **Five Phases**,
**Heaven** moves **orderly** and **Earth** turns **eastward**,
After **Wood’s** **revolution**, **Heaven’s** **qi** always **residual**,
The **residual qi** does not **add** to the **Master Fire**,
But **retreats** one step to **interact** with the **Relative Fire** above,
Thus, every five **years**, when the cycle is complete,
It **retreats** one **position** and **shifts right**,
Hence the saying: **‘Left-right cycles through the Heavenly Circuit, residual qi reconvenes.’**

**Reconvenes** means **meets** or **unites**—
It speaks of **Heaven’s** and **Earth’s** **Dao**:
When five **years** have passed,
The **residual qi** shifts to **interact**,
And **reunites** with the **Five Phases’** **seated positions**,
Thus forming the **year’s laws**.

**Heavenly Circuit** refers to **Heaven’s** cycle through **Earth’s** positions,
Not the **Six Qi** of the **Heavenly Circuit**.

The Emperor said: *"I have heard **Guǐyú Qū** say:
‘**Responding to Earth** is **stillness**.
Yet now you speak of **below** moving to the **left**,
I do not understand your meaning—
I wish to hear how this **generates**."*

The interpretations differ.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *Guǐtū Qū*’s words, *"responding to Earth is stillness"*—this appears in *The Great Treatise on Heaven’s Essence* (*Tiān Yuán Jì Dà Lùn*).

**Qíbó** said: *"The movements and stabilities of Heaven and Earth, the shifts and returns of the Five Phases—even Guǐyú Qū could only grasp their superficial patterns, yet still could not fully illuminate them. If one cannot fully illuminate, there is no need to seek the #2 [path]."*

The functions of transformation and change—Heaven displays its symbols, Earth forms its shapes; the Seven Luminaries weave through the void, the Five Phases adhere to Earth. Earth is what bears the forms and kinds of life’s generation. The void is what arranges the refined *qi* that responds to Heaven. The movement of form and essence is like that of roots and branches. Gazing upward at its symbols, though distant, can be known. Observing the clustered revolutions of the Five Stars reveals the clear logic of Earth’s leftward motion.

*Lì* means "to adhere." No formed thing exists without depending on another to remain whole.

The Emperor said: *"Is Earth, then, truly ‘below’? Does its ceaseless turning make it ‘below’? Or is it ‘not’?"*

**Qíbó** replied: *"Earth is beneath humanity, yet within the boundless void. Though humanity’s dwelling may be called ‘below,’ in terms of ultimate truth, it is but one thing within the void’s expanse. The *Yijing* says: ‘Kūn is vast, bearing all things; its virtue harmonizes without limit.’ This is what is meant."*

The Emperor said: *"Is it then ‘soaring’?"*

The Emperor said: *"If the boundless void is unrestricted, how does the Earth’s body soar and remain fixed?"*
**Féng**—pronounced as in *"fú bīng"* (扶冰切). *(Note: "Ài" for "ài" in "obstruct" [碍].)*

Qíbó replied: *"The Great Qi sustains it."* The Great Qi refers to the **Zàohuà qi**—the transformative qi that upholds the boundless void. Thus, the void does not collapse, and Earth endures while Heaven lasts, because the Zàohuà qi sustains them. When this qi transforms and shifts, failing to uphold, the very vessel of the void decays.

Like falling leaves drifting in the air—descending not swiftly—it is because they ride the qi, so their descent lacks haste. All things with form, dwelling above the Earth, are sustained by the **shēnghuà qi**. Yet their vessels differ in size, and their decay varies in speed. When the qi no longer sustains them, great and small alike perish.

Dryness dries, heat steams, wind stirs, dampness moistens, cold hardens, and fire warms. Thus, cold winds rise from below, dry heat lingers above, damp qi lingers within, and fire wanders between them. Cold and heat penetrate sixfold, making the void fertile and life flourish.

Within the Earth’s body, six penetrations exist:
1. Dryness,
2. Heat,
3. Wind,
4. Dampness,
5. Cold,
6. Fire.

From dryness arises the **dry nature**; from heat, the **steaming nature**; from wind, the **moving nature**; from dampness, the **moist nature**; from cold, the **hard nature**; from fire, the **warm nature**—these are the **Six Qi of Heaven**.

Thus, when dryness prevails, the Earth grows dry;
when heat prevails, the Earth grows hot;
when wind prevails, the Earth trembles;
when dampness prevails, the Earth becomes muddy;
when cold prevails, the Earth cracks;
when fire prevails, the Earth solidifies.

The Emperor said: *"How does one observe the qi of Heaven and Earth?"*

Qíbó replied: *"The shifts of Heaven and Earth’s qi—when one qi overcomes another—do not manifest in pulse diagnosis."* For balanced qi and its reversals are observed through **formal signs**, not pulse alone. The *Pulse Method* states: *"The changes of Heaven and Earth cannot be known through pulse."* This is what is meant.

Heaven and Earth operate through qi, not fixed position, so they cannot be discerned solely by pulse.

The Emperor said: *"How then does one inquire about qi?"*

Qíbó replied: *"Observe its presence in the left and right [sides]."* Divide the four regions—left and right *cùn* and *chǐ*—and note whether the qi corresponds or fails to respond, whether it is excessive or deficient.

The Emperor said: *"How does one determine its regularity?"*

Qíbó replied: *"Conforming to the qi brings harmony; defying it brings illness."* That is, when it should be **deep but is not**, or **superficial but is not**, or **rough but is not**, or **slack but is not**, or **tight but is not**, or **large but is not**—such deviations indicate illness.

*(New annotation: According to the *Zhìzhēn Yàodà Lùn*, when the **Juéyīn qi** arrives, the pulse is **tight**; when the **Shàoyīn qi** arrives, it is **slack and curved**; when the **Tàiyīn qi** arrives, it is **slack and deep**; when the **Shàoyáng qi** arrives, it is **large and superficial**; when the **Yángmíng qi** arrives, it is **short and rough**; when the **Tàiyáng qi** arrives, it is **large and long**. If the qi arrives harmoniously, it is balanced; if excessively so, it is illness; if reversed, it is illness; if it arrives when it should not, it is illness; if it arrives prematurely, it is illness; if yin and yang are inverted, it is perilous. If the qi does not occupy its proper position, it is illness—appearing in another position. If it shifts positions, it is illness—such as when the left *cùn* shows the right’s slackness, or the right shows the left’s pulse, due to disordered qi. If it abandons its position, it is perilous—already appearing in another region, where the original organ is assaulted by hostile qi, making illness grave. If the *cùn* and *chǐ* reverse, it is death—occurring in the years of *zi*, *wǔ*, *mǎo*, and *yǒu*. "Reverse" means when the year’s yin should appear in the *cùn* pulse but instead appears in the *chǐ*, or when the year’s yang should appear in the *chǐ* pulse but instead appears in the *cùn*. If both *cùn* and *chǐ* reverse, it is called reversal. If only one reverses—either *cùn* or *chǐ*—it is not a true reversal but a failure to conform to the qi. If yin and yang intersect, it is death—occurring in the years of *yín*, *shēn*, *hài*, *sì*, *chǒu*, *wèi*, *chén*, and *xū*. "Intersect" means when the year’s yin should appear in the right pulse but instead appears in the left, or when the year’s yang should appear in the left pulse but instead appears in the right. If only one side shows this—left or right—it is not a true intersection but a failure to conform to the qi. First, establish the year to know its qi; then observe whether the left and right pulses correspond. Only then can one speak of life or death’s order.*

The *Classics* state that the seasonal qi is complete. *(New annotation: This is detailed in the *Liùyuán Zhèngjì Dàlùn*.)*

The Emperor said: *"How do cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire interact in humans? How do they generate and transform all things?"*
**"Merge"** means inner and outer correspondence.
**"Generate"** means receiving transformation to produce life.
**"Transform"** means establishing all phenomena.

Qíbó replied: *"Wind first arises from the **shù** direction."* **Shù** is the beginning of the day, and wind is the start of instruction—Heaven’s decree to issue commands, hence wind originates from the **shù** direction.

When shadows fade and mountains darken, blue dust swirls together—this is the wind of **cliffs and valleys**. Yellow and white dust linger at dusk, the sky like a wall, with only the heavens visible—this is the wind of **rivers and marshes**. If yellow, black, and white dust descend, it is the **violent wind of mountains and wetlands**. Wind nourishes wood: as yang ascends, wind stirs, and grasses and trees flourish—thus, it is said that wind generates wood.

This is the harmonious qi’s transformation. If the wind qi acts excessively, it scatters and destroys, reaching extremes where trees are uprooted and grasses withered.

When the cycle aligns with the years of *dīngmǎo*, *dīngchǒu*, *dīnghài*, *dīngyǒu*, *dīngwèi*, or *dīngsì*, then the wind’s transformation is insufficient.

If the cycle aligns with the years of *rénshēn*, *rénwǔ*, *rénchén*, *rényín*, *rénzǐ*, or *rénxū*, then the wind’s transformation is excessive for all things.

○The newly corrected text states: Examining Wang’s annotation on the surplus and deficiency of *dīng* and *rén* cycles, some mistakenly take *dīngmǎo*, *dīnghài*, *dīngsì*, *rénshēn*, and *rényín*—five years—as the *Tiānfú* (Heaven’s Omen), aligning with the *Tiānfú* and *zhèngsuì* (rectified years), not distinguishing surplus or deficiency. This is said to be the balanced *mùyùn* (Wood cycle), and Wang’s annotation is thus incorrect—this is ignorance of the Great Principle.

Further refinement is sought, yet even excluding these five years does not exhaust the matter. The same applies to the cycles of Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water below.

Wood generates sourness.
All things with a sour taste originate from the transformation of Wood qi.

Sourness generates the liver.
The sour taste enters the stomach and nourishes the liver’s storage.

The liver generates sinews.
The sour taste enters the liver, where its essence spreads and forms sinews and membranes.

Sinews generate the heart.
When the nourishing qi of sourness has fully nourished the sinews and membranes, its essence flows onward and enters the heart.

In Heaven, this corresponds to the **Mysterious**—that is, the **Obscure and Profound**.

The **Obscure** reaches its end, and the **Bundle** [方] turns white.
At the **Beginning** [初] of **Tiger** [寅], the Heavenly hue reverses to black,
and the **Great Void** [太虚] converges—
the **Obscure** [玄] symbol in Heaven is thus visible.

○The newly corrected text states: In the seven sentences of *"Heaven's Obscure generates the transformative qi"* [天为玄至化生气七句],
it universally describes the Great Principle of the Six *Qi* and Five *Xing* [五行] in their generative transformations,
not exclusive to the **Bundle** [方].
Yet the Wang commentary says *"Obscure"* [玄] refers to the end of **Obscure** [丑] and the beginning of **Tiger** [寅],
when the Heavenly hue turns black—
this interpretation is limited only to the **Bundle** [方], excluding other directions,
and thus fails to grasp the full meaning.

In humans, this is the **Dao** [道].
The **Dao** of rectification is the governance of **nourishment** [生养].
On Earth, it is **transformation** [化].
**Transformation** [化] is the act of **generation** [生化].
Only after **transformation** [化] does all life emerge,
for all things are born from the **transformative qi** [化气].

**Transformation** [化] generates the **Five Flavors** [五味].
Metals, jade, soils, and stones,
grasses, trees, vegetables, and fruits,
roots, stems, branches, and leaves,
blossoms, husks, kernels, and seeds—
all sentient and unsentient alike,
are produced by Earth’s **transformation** [化].

The **Dao** [道] generates **wisdom** [智].
**Wisdom** [智] is **right knowledge** [正知] and **far-reaching deliberation** [虑远].
Right knowledge prevents doubt in affairs,
far-reaching deliberation avoids peril.
When the **Dao** [道] governs, its principles align with **wisdom** [智].
The *Ling Shu Jing* [《灵枢经》] says:
*"To deliberate and act upon matters is called wisdom."*

The **Obscure** [玄] generates **spirit** [神].
**Spirit** [神] operates without fixed form,
deep and subtle, beyond measure.
It manifests in visible yet hidden ways,
and few can predict its movements.
Thus within the **Obscure and Profound** [玄冥],
**spirit** [神明] dwells concealed yet unseen—
this is the **Obscure** generating **spirit** [神明].

**Transformation** [化] generates **qi** [气].
Flitting, wandering, and branching movements,
scales, shells, fur, feathers, and hair—
the five varied transformations,
internally linked to **spirit** [神机],
though encompassed by the **Five Flavors** [五味],
their inherent natures differ,
hence it is also said: **Transformation** generates **qi** [气].

These seven preceding sentences
universally describe the Great Principle of the Six *Qi* and Five *Xing* in their generative transformations,
not exclusive to the **Bundle** [方].
○The newly corrected text states:
According to the *"Great Treatise on the Interchange of Yin and Yang"* [《阴阳应象大论》]
and the *"Great Treatise on the Heavenly Elements"* [《天元纪大论》],
there is no sentence on **Transformation** generating **qi** [化生气].

**Spirit** [神] in Heaven is **Wind** [风].
It stirs and disrupts, splitting and dispersing—
these are the **transformations** of **Wind** [风之化].
It shakes, pulls, and uproots—
these are the **functions** of **Wind** [风之用].
When **Minor Yin** [厥阴] is above,
**Wind** transforms in Heaven;
when **Minor Yin** is below,
**Wind** courses upon Earth.

On Earth, it is **Wood** [木].
Long, short, curved, or straight—
these are the **forms** of **Wood** [木之体].
Raising stems and activating mechanisms—
these are the **functions** of **Wood** [木之用].
In **form** [体], it is **sinews** [筋].
Tendons, ligaments, and networks—
these are the **forms** of **sinews** [筋之体],
flexible yet resilient—
these are the **functions** of **sinews** [筋之用].
In **qi** [气], it is **gentleness** [柔].
When **Wood**’s **transformative qi** [化] spreads and **Wind**’s **transformative qi** courses,
things assume a **gentle** yet **intertwined** nature.

In **storage** [藏], it is the **liver** [肝].
The liver has two **lobes** [布叶],
one small, resembling the **splitting bark** [甲拆] of **Wood** [木].
Each has branching networks,
traversing the **abdomen** [豚游中],
to propagate **Wood**’s **yang-harmonizing qi** [阳和之气].
It is the **residence of the soul** [魂之官].
It functions as the **general’s office** [将军之官], from which **strategy** [谋虑] emerges.
When **Wood**’s **transformative qi** [化] is excessive in the **Ding year** [丁岁],
the liver’s **storage** and **networks** [经络] first succumb to **evil** [邪] and manifest **disease** [病].
The **gallbladder** [胆府] is the same.

Its **nature** [性] is **warmth** [暄].
**Warmth** [暄] is **gentleness** [温], the **nature** of **Wood** [木].
Its **virtue** [德] is **harmony** [和].
It spreads **harmonious qi** [和气] across all things—
this is the **virtue** of **Wood** [木之德].
○The newly corrected text states:
According to the *"Great Treatise on the Interchange of Qi"* [《气交变大论》],
its **virtue** is to spread **harmony** [敷和].

Its **function** [用] is **movement** [动].
**Wind** stirs and thus **moves** [动],
without **Wind**, all things remain still.
○The newly corrected text states:
According to the **function** of **Wood** being **movement** [动],
the **excessive** **Fire** [火太过] also manifests as **movement** [动],
since **Wood** and **Fire** govern **violent** and **rapid** actions,
hence both are **movement** [动].

Its **color** [色] is **bluish-green** [苍].
Among all formed things,
when they undergo **Wood**’s **transformation** [化],
their external hues appear faintly **bluish-green** [薄青之色].
Now in the **Bundle**’s [束方] Earth,
grasses and trees above display **bluish-green** [苍].
In the **Ding year** [丁岁],
**bluish-green** things also show **white** and **yellow**,
their colors impure.

Its **transformation** [化] is **luxuriance** [荣].
**Luxuriance** [荣] is **beautiful color** [美色].
Among the four seasons,
when things display **blossoms** [华] and **luxuriance** [荣],
their hues are fresh and bright—
these are all generated by **Wood**’s **transformation** [化].
○The newly corrected text states:
According to the *"Great Treatise on the Interchange of Qi"* [《气交变大论》],
its **transformation** generates **luxuriance** [化生荣].

Its **creature** [虫] is **hair** [毛].
When all things emerge,
hair appears like **fur upon skin** [在皮].
Its **governance** [政] is **dispersion** [散].
It disperses **generative qi** [生气] across all things.
○The newly corrected text states:
According to the *"Great Treatise on the Interchange of Qi"* [《气交变大论》],
its **governance** is **relaxation and contraction** [舒卷].
In detail:
**Wood**’s **governance** is **dispersion** [散],
**Wood**’s **balanced governance** is **relaxation and dispersion** [发散],
**Wood**’s **excessive governance** is **dispersion** [散],
**Earth**’s **insufficient qi** is **dispersion** [散],
**Metal**’s **function** is **scattering and falling** [散落],
**Wood**’s **disaster** is **scattering and falling** [散落].
Thus there are six variations of **dispersion** [散],
yet only two meanings:
One is **dispersion** as **relaxation and spreading** [发散之散], which is **Wood**’s **qi** [气].
Two is **dispersion** as **scattering and falling** [散落之散], which is **Metal**’s **qi** [气] in action.

Its **command** [令] is **propagation and dispersion** [宣发].
The **yang-harmonizing qi** [阳和之气]
relaxes and then disperses.

Its **transformation** is **crushing and pulling** [摧拉]—
**Crushing** [摧] is the completion of skill [技成者也].
○*Newly corrected:* According to *Treatise on the Exchange of Qi*, its **transformation** is **vibration and emission** [振发].

Its **blue-green** turns to **falling** [陨]—
**Falling** [陨] means **plummeting** [坠].
When violent winds arise, grasses are uprooted and trees topple.
○*Newly corrected:* According to *Treatise on the Exchange of Qi*, its **disaster** is **scattering and falling** [散落].
(*Blue-green*, pronounced *shè-jǐng*).

Its **flavor** is **sour**—
All things that transform and change into sour flavors
are the **Wood qi**’s [气] **successes and failures** [成败].
Now, in the wilds of the southern regions,
sour tastes abound.

Its **will** is **anger**—
**Anger** is a **straightforward cry** [直声].
Anger is used to **awe** [威] things.
Anger harms the **liver**—
All things, when pushed to their **extreme**, inevitably harm themselves.
Anger arises from the **liver**, yet it **returns to harm the liver** [反伤肝藏].
**Sorrow** [忧] overcomes **anger**—
When sorrow arises, anger ceases, confirming its victory.
○*Newly corrected:* In detail, the **Five Wills**—**sorrow** [悲] should be **grief** [忧], for grief harms the **mind** [意], while sorrow harms the **soul** [魂], hence it is said that sorrow overcomes anger.

**Wind** harms the **liver**—
Just as wind **snaps wood** [折木],
wind is born from **Wood**, yet it **snaps it in return**,
its **extreme use** leading to decline.
○*Newly corrected:* According to *Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang*, wind harms the **sinews** [筋].
**Dryness** overcomes **wind**—
Wind originates from **Wood**, while **dryness** is the **transformation of Metal**;
wind’s excess is checked by **dryness**, and when the **liver** is excessive, it is treated with **cold**—
**cold** clears and directs, the **Metal qi** in action.

**Sour** harms the **sinews**—
**Sour** drains the **liver qi** [写肝气];
when drained excessively, it harms its **qi**.
*The Spirit Pivot* says:
*"Sour travels to the sinews—
when sinews are diseased, avoid excessive sour foods."*
This is why.
**Traveling to the sinews** [走筋] means **rapidly propagating its qi** [宣行其气速疾].
Qi, blood, flesh, and bone are interrelated.
○*Newly corrected:* In detail, the annotation states:
This is from *Plain Questions: Illuminating the Five Qi*, not *The Spirit Pivot*.
According to *The Canon of the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches*, this is from *Plain Questions*;
Wang’s annotation mistakenly attributes it to *The Spirit Pivot*.

**Bitter** overcomes **sour**—
**Bitter** is the **Metal flavor**, thus it overcomes **Wood’s sour**;
sour’s excess is countered by **bitter**.

The **south** generates **heat**—
The product of **excessive yang**.
This is the **Minister Fire**’s and **Sovereign Fire**’s governance.
The **Great Void** grows dim, like **fine dust**,
mountains and rivers all **glow**—
the **heat qi** in action.
The **Great Light** is obscured, its hue like **cinnabar**,
a **stifling heat**’s essence.
If **crimson clouds** surge violently,
leaves accumulate in layers,
swelling then contracting—
the **heat** of **cliffs and valleys**.

**Heat** generates **fire**—
The **extreme heat qi**, where **fire’s circulation** is **flourishing and bright**,
thus it is said that **heat generates fire**.
**Fire** is the **transformation of excessive yang**.

When **heat qi** applies its **transformation**,
it becomes **flaming heat and stifling warmth**;
its **extreme transformation** leads to **burning, scorching, melting, and dissolving**.
When the **celestial stems** **Geng** (癸) and **Yi** (乙) align with **Earthly Branches** **You** (酉), **Wei** (未), **Si** (巳), **Mao** (卯), **Chou** (丑), or **Hai** (亥),
then **heat transformation** is **insufficient**.
If they align with **Wu** (戊) and **Chen** (辰), **Le** (寅), **Zi** (子), **Xu** (戌), **Shen** (申), or **Wu** (午),
then **heat transformation** is **excessive**.

**Fire** has **Sovereign Fire** and **Minister Fire**,
thus it is said **heat generates fire**, and again, **fire**.
**Fire** generates **bitter**—
All **bitter** flavors originate from **fire’s transformation**.
Sweet things, when scorched by fire, turn **charred and bitter**—
bitter arises from **fire’s transformation**, a clear sign.

**Bitter** generates the **heart**—
Bitter substances enter the **stomach** and transform into the **heart**,
thus in **Geng** (癸) years, **bitter transformation** is **scant**,
while in **Xu** (戌) years, it is **abundant**.

The **heart** generates **blood**—
Once **bitter** has transformed into the **heart**,
its **spread** generates **blood vessels**.
**Blood** generates the **spleen**—
After **bitter** has **nourished the blood**,
it flows and transforms, **nourishing the spleen**.

Its manifestation in **Heaven** is **heat**—
Also the **transformation of the divine qi**.

The **summer heat** and **oppressive warmth** are the **transformation of heat**—
**Blazing and boiling** are the **functions of heat**.

When the year belongs to **Shao Yin** and **Shao Yang** above,
then **heat transforms in Heaven**;
when below,
then **heat spreads upon the Earth**.

On Earth, it becomes **fire**—
**Radiant and luminous**, the **substance of fire**.
**Flickering and scorching**, the **function of fire**.

In the body, it becomes the **pulse**—
**Circulating blood and qi**, the **substance of the vessels**.
**Obstruction or release, emptiness or fullness**, the **function of the vessels**.

The **collateral vessels** are the same.

In **qi**, it becomes **breath**—
**Breath**, the **lengthening** [of life].

In the **viscera**, it becomes the **heart**.
The **heart** takes the form of an **unopened lotus**, the **celestial true qi** within—
with **nine hollows** to guide the **celestial true qi**,
the **abode of the spirit**.

It is the **sovereign’s organ**, whence **divine wisdom** emerges.
In **Geng** years, the **heart** and **channels** receive **evil** and fall ill,
as does the **Small Intestine palace**.

Its **nature** is **summer heat**—
**Summer heat**, the **heat** of the **heart’s qi-nature**.

Its **virtue** is **clarity**—
**Manifest and luminous**; the **new annotation** states:
*"According to the* **Great Treatise on Qi Exchange***, its virtue is **manifest and clear**."*

Its **function** is **restlessness**—
**Fire’s nature is restless**, ever **unsettled**.

Its **color** is **red**—
All **transformed things** borne by **fire’s transformation**
bear the **crimson and vermilion hues**;
today, in the **Southern lands**, even **grasses and trees** bear **reddish tints**.
In **Geng** years, **red things** also bear **black and white**.

Its **transformation** is **luxuriance**—
**Luxuriance**, the **proliferation and flourishing**; the **new annotation** states:
*"According to the* **Great Treatise on Qi Exchange***, its transformation is **proliferant and luxuriant**."*

Its **insects and feathers**—
**Varying in length**, mirroring **fire’s form**.

Its **governance** is **clarity**—
**Illuminating and manifest**, with **no concealment**, the **governance of fire**.
The **new annotation** states:
*"According to the* **Great Treatise on Qi Exchange***, its **rectification is luminous**."*

Again, it is noted:
*"Fire’s governance is clarity, water’s qi is clarity—
though both are called ‘clarity,’ they differ:
Fire’s clarity shines **externally**, water’s clarity shines **internally**;
though the name is the same, their essence is distinct."*

Its **decree** is **oppressive heat**—
**Oppressive**, meaning **abundant**; **heat**, meaning **warmth**—
speaking of **abundant heat**, like **steaming**.
The **new annotation** states:
*"The detailed commentary says ‘oppressive’ means ‘abundant,’ but this is unclear.
According to Wang Bing’s annotation on the* **Great Treatise on the Five Constant Governances***, it should be understood as:
‘Oppressive’ means **stifling and stagnant**, not free-flowing.**
This is the correct interpretation."

Its **change** is **flaming and scorching**,

The heat is **extreme**, blazing and radiant—
scorching stone, melting gold—
the **ultimate transformation** of Fire.

○New annotation states:
According to the *Great Treatise on Qi Exchange*, its change is **"consuming and scorching."**

Its **greenish glow** is **brilliant**,
**Overturning** mountains and rivers,
**Spreading** to houses and dwellings—
the **disaster** of Fire.

○New annotation states:
According to the *Great Treatise on Qi Exchange*, its disaster is **"overturning and entangling."**

Its **taste is bitter**—
when things transform under Fire’s influence and bear **bitterness**,
all such **bitter flavors** arise from Fire’s **dispersal and combination**.
Now, in the southern wilds, many creatures are **bitter**.

Its **emotion is joy**.
Joy is **delight and pleasure**, harmonizing the mind.
Yet **excessive joy harms the heart**—
for though joy **emanates from the heart**, it **in turn harms it**,
just as **wind snaps wood**.
When **excessive**, the **qi is exhausted**, hence the **injury** appears.

**Fear conquers joy**;
when **fear dominates**, all **delight and pleasure vanish**—
the principle of conquering joy is evident when **seen with the eyes of the Dao**.
Fear is the **qi of Water**.

Heat **injures qi**—
when the **heavens grow hot**, the **qi lies dormant and unseen**;
when **humans grow hot**, the **qi becomes rapid and gasping**.
The way heat **injures qi** is **verifiable in logic**.
This refers to **extreme heat**; the **qi of lesser heat** still **nurtures all things**.

The *Great Treatise on Yin-Yang Correspondences* states:
**"Robust Fire disperses qi; meager Fire generates qi."**
This is its meaning.

**Cold conquers heat**;
when **cold prevails**, heat **retreats**,
when **yin flourishes**, yang **declines**—
to **subdue heat with cold** is to **seek victory**.

**Bitterness injures qi**—
its harm is **much like this**.
Bitterness **injures qi** because of its **dryness**.
If **heat is added**, the injury is **even greater**.
How is this proven?
**Drinking alcohol causes shortness of breath**,
and **excess causes gasping**—this is **undeniable**.
If **bitter-cold substances** are consumed **excessively over time**,
they **further inflame Fire**, also **injuring qi**.
Temporarily treating with **prescriptions** aligns with **meager Fire**,
thus **restoring qi**.

○New annotation states:
This treatise outlines **three categories of injury**:
The **East** says: **Wind harms the liver**, sourness harms **sinews**;
The **Center** says: **Dampness harms flesh**, sweetness harms the **spleen**;
The **West** says: **Aromatic pungency harms skin and hair**—these are **self-inflicted injuries**.
The **South** says: **Heat harms qi**, bitterness harms **qi**;
The **North** says: **Cold harms blood**, saltiness harms **blood**—these are **injuries to what one conquers**.
The **West** says: **Heat harms skin and hair**—this is **injury from what conquers one**.
Thus, the **five directions’ injuries** follow **three patterns**;
if referring to *The Great Essentials*, all are said to be **self-inflicted**.

**Saltiness conquers bitterness**.
Alcohol **dissolves with salt**—**nature’s logic is clear**.
Fire’s **bitter dominance** is **checked by Water’s saltiness**.

The **Center generates dampness**—
the **Center** is **Earth**; high mountains hold **damp soil**,
springs rise from the earth, waters **originate in mountains**,
clouds form in **rocky valleys**—this is its **manifestation**.
**Innate nature** is **internal and latent**;
when **activated**, it **becomes functional**—
then **rain descends, clouds surge**,
and the **Center generates dampness**—
this is **undeniably true**.
Thus, the **seasonal records** note **soil moisture and maritime heat in the sixth month**—
this is what is meant.

*(Dampness, pronounced "rǔ.")*

**Dampness generates Earth.**
Dampness *qi* is internally latent within Earth;
Earth’s substance is thereby complete.
When dampness is present, Earth is born;
when dryness prevails, Earth dies.
Death brings decline to all things,
life fosters growth and flourishing—
this is the transformation of dampness *qi*.

When dampness *qi* exerts its influence,
Earth takes form while clouds surge and rain descends.
At its extreme, it causes sudden collapse—**landslides**.

When the **Celestial Stem-Branch combinations** of *jǐyǐ* (己巳), *jǐmǎo* (己卯), *jǐhòu* (己丑), *jǐhài* (己亥), *jǐyǒu* (己酉), or *jǐwèi* (己未) dominate,
then dampness transformation is insufficient.
When *jiǎzǐ* (甲子), *jiǎxū* (甲戌), *jiǎshēn* (甲申), *jiǎwǔ* (甲午), *jiǎchén* (甲辰), or *jiǎyín* (甲寅) dominate,
then dampness transformation is excessive.

**Earth generates sweetness.**
Sweetness in things originates from Earth’s transformative power.
Sweetness nourishes the **Spleen**—
sweet substances first enter the **Spleen** before the **Stomach**,
so in **Celestial Stem-Branch combinations of *jǐ*** (己), sweetness is diminished,
while in **combinations of *jiǎ*** (甲), sweetness is abundant.

The **Spleen generates flesh**—
sweetness entering the **Spleen**,
its *qi* spreads and nourishes,
producing fat and muscle.

**Flesh nourishes the Lungs**—
after sweetness *qi* has nourished the flesh,
it flows and transforms,
fostering the **Lungs**—
this is its generative function.

In the **Heavenly realm**, dampness is **divine transformation**—
soft, moist, and heavy, its **marvelous influence**.
Dust and clouds gather, rain descends—
this is dampness’s **manifestation**.
When the **Great Yin** (太阴) is above,
dampness transforms in the **Heavenly realm**;
when below,
dampness transforms on the **Earth**.

On Earth, dampness is **Earth**—
gentle, steady, and tranquil,
its form shifts with gathering and dispersing,
giving rise to all things—
this is Earth’s **substance**.
It contains filth and conceals impurity,
quiet and yielding to the people—
the **root of transformation**,
this is Earth’s **virtue**.

*(New annotation: It is noted that "quiet and yielding to the people" is Earth’s virtue. The phrase "yielding to the people" may be a typographical error.)*

In **physical form**, dampness is **flesh**—
enveloping sinews and bones,
its *qi* emanates between them—
this is flesh’s **function**.
When its density is irregular,
the **interior and exterior** are obstructed—
this is flesh’s **disorder**.

In **energetic essence**, dampness is **fullness**—
Earth’s *qi* in transformation
fills all phenomena.

In **the body’s storage**, dampness is the **Spleen**—
its shape resembles a **horse’s hoof**,
enclosing the **Stomach’s precincts**,
mirroring Earth’s form.
The **meridian networks’ *qi****
converge and circulate within,
nurturing the **True Spirit**—
the **abode of intent**.
It governs the **granary’s vigilance**,
from which transformed substances emerge.

When **Celestial Stem-Branch combinations of *jǐ*** (己) dominate,
the **Spleen** and **meridians** suffer **pathogenic influence**, manifesting as **illness**.

*(New annotation: Examining the four storage organs—Liver, Heart, Lungs, Kidneys—
each is annotated as a "palace" (府).

　　**Water in Wood’s season (水居木位)**, **Wood in the Sovereign’s season (木居君位)**—
　　**such cases are harmonious (如是者为相得)**.

　　Again, **Wood in Water’s season (木居水位)**, **Water in Metal’s season (水居金位)**,
　　**Metal in Earth’s season (金居土位)**, **Earth in Fire’s season (土居火位)**,
　　**Fire in Wood’s season (火居木位)**—
　　though **such cases seem harmonious (如是者虽为相得)**,
　　they ultimately **violate the child’s subservience to the parent’s position (终以子僭居父母之位)**,
　　**as the lower overcomes the higher (下陵上)**, still **counted as slight perversion (犹为小逆也)**.

　　**Wood in Metal or Earth’s season (木居金土位)**, **Fire in Metal or Water’s season (火居金水位)**,
　　**Earth in Water or Wood’s season (土居水木位)**, **Metal in Fire or Wood’s season (金居火木位)**,
　　**Water in Fire or Earth’s season (水居火土位)**—
　　**such cases are disharmonious (如是者为不相得)**, thus the disease is **severe (故病甚也)**.
　　**First establish the cyclical movements and the Heavenly Dominating Qi (运气及司天之气)**,
　　then **the Qi’s harmonious or disharmonious placement can be discerned (则气之所在相得与不相得可知矣)**.

　　The Emperor said: **How does one govern the seasons (主岁何如)?**
　　Gui Bo replied:
　　**When the Qi are excessive (气有余)**, they **restrain their own season (制己所胜)** and **insult the season they do not overcome (侮所不胜)**;
　　**when they are insufficient (其不及)**, the **season that overcomes them insults and rides them (己所不胜侮而乘之)**,
　　while **their own season is light and insults them (己所胜轻而侮之)**.
　　**Excessive Wood (木余)** restrains Earth, **neglects Metal (轻忽於金)**,
　　**as Metal Qi does not contend (以金气不争)**, so **Wood relies on its excess to bully and insult (故木恃其余而欺侮也)**.
　　Again, **when Wood is deficient and Metal is excessive (木少金胜)**,
　　**Earth in turn insults Wood (土反侮木)**,
　　**as Wood does not reach its full measure (以木不及)**,
　　so **Earth presumptuously overpowers it (故土妄凌之也)**.
　　○**Newly corrected annotation (新校正云)** states:
　　**The Four Seasons converge (四气卒同).**
　　**Insult (侮)** means **to scorn and overlook (侮慢而凌忽之)**.
　　**Insult invites perversity (侮反受邪)**,
　　either **because of one’s own strength (己强盛)** or **encountering another’s decline (遇彼衰微)**,
　　**without measuring the weak (不度卑弱)**, arrogantly **riding and overpowering (妄行凌忽)**.
　　Though **one insults to seek victory (虽侮而求胜)**, the **result is ultimately perverse (故终叉受邪)**.
　　**Insult while receiving perversity (侮而受邪)** arises from **lack of reverence (寡於畏)**.
　　**Receiving perversity (受邪)** refers to **receiving the Qi that overcomes one’s own season (各谓受己不胜之邪)****.
　　However, **when one’s own season is strong externally but depleted internally (外强中乾)**,
　　**perverse Qi is strong, while the orthodox is weak (邪盛真弱)**,
　　**lacking reverence (寡於敬畏)**, thus **inviting perversity (由是纳邪)**,
　　hence it is said: **lack of reverence invites perversity (故日寡於畏也)**.

　　○**Newly corrected annotation (新校正云)** states:
　　According to the *Treatise on the Six Cycles and Hidden Symbols (六节藏象论)*:
　　**Arrival before its due time (未至而至)** is **excess (太过)**,
　　thus **it weakens the season it does not overcome (薄所不胜)** and **rides the season it should overcome (而乘所胜)**,
　　and this is called **profligate Qi (气淫)**.
　　**Failure to arrive on time (至而不至)** is **deficiency (不及)**,
　　thus **the season that overcomes it acts presumptuously (所胜妄行)**,
　　**while the season that generates it suffers disease (所生受病)** and **the season it does not overcome weakens it (所不胜而薄之)**,
　　and this is called **constricted Qi (气迫)**.
　　This is the **meaning of the above (即此之义也)**.

　　The Emperor said: **Good (善).**»

**Huangdi Neijing Suwen: Supplementary Commentary, Volume Forty**
*Annotated by Tang Taipu Ling Qixuanzi Wang Bing, with corrections by Song Guanglu Guyi Lin Yi et al., and revised by Song Shoushu Luntian Lang Sun Zhao.*

**Lun on the Profound Essence of the Six Subtle Qi**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"Ah, how profound is the Dao of Heaven! Like welcoming floating clouds, or gazing into the abyss—gazing into the abyss, one may yet measure its depths, but welcoming the floating clouds, none can fathom their limits. The abyss lies still and stagnant yet clears with purity, so its depths may be measured; the floating clouds drift and scatter, merging and dispersing, so none can reach their bounds. The symbols of the Azure Sky, like scales in the depths, may be observed; yet the Dao of transformation and change is like the clouds—its departures and arrivals are unfathomable. The Six Qi are profound and subtle; their role in transformation should be likened to this metaphor."*

*The newly corrected text notes: This passage overlaps with the *Treatise on the Five Excesses*.*

The Master has repeatedly spoken of reverently following the Dao of Heaven. I have heard and stored these words, yet my heart doubts their meaning—I do not understand their intent. I wish the Master would fully express his meaning, so that his teachings may endure forever, never fading or ceasing. Might I then truly hear the Dao of Heaven? It is the Dao of transformation and generation.

Qibo knelt twice, bowing his head, and replied:
*"Ah, how clear is your inquiry into the Dao of Heaven! This follows the order of Heaven, the seasons of flourishing and decline."*

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"I wish to hear how the sixfold cycles of Heaven’s Dao bring about flourishing and decline."*

*The sixfold cycles were already mentioned in prior discourse; the Celestial Master had not yet fully expounded their meaning, hence the repeated question.*

Qibo said:
*"Above and below have their ranks; left and right have their order. Above and below refer to the two Qi governing Heaven and Earth. The remaining four Qi are positioned to the left and right of the year. Thus:
- To the right of Minor Yang, the Yang-Ming Qi governs;
- To the right of Yang-Ming, the Taiyang Qi governs;
- To the right of Taiyang, the Jueyin Qi governs;
- To the right of Jueyin, the Shaoyin Qi governs;
- To the right of Shaoyin, the Taiyin Qi governs;
- To the right of Taiyin, the Minor Yang Qi governs again.

This is what is called the *standard* of the Qi—like facing south in anticipation."* [*Standard* here means *terminal point*. The Sage faces south while standing, observing the arrival of the Qi.]

*"Thus it is said: ‘Following Heaven’s order, the seasons of flourishing and decline—shifting light to determine position, standing upright in anticipation.’ Shifting light refers to the sun’s movement. Determining position means facing south to observe the Qi, standing upright to observe the year, counting the arrival of the Qi so that they may be anticipated.

- Above Minor Yang, the Fire Qi governs; within it, Jueyin appears.
- Above Yang-Ming, the Dryness Qi governs; within it, Taiyin appears.
- Above Taiyang, the Cold Qi governs; within it, Shaoyin appears.
- Above Jueyin, the Wind Qi governs; within it, Minor Yang appears.
- Above Shaoyin, the Heat Qi governs; within it, Taiyang appears.
- Above Taiyin, the Dampness Qi governs; within it, Yang-Ming appears.

This is called the *root*. Below the root, within it appears; below what appears, the *standard* of the Qi lies. The root refers to the Original Qi. When the Qi diverges to become sovereign, the text’s meaning is clear."*

*The newly corrected text notes: The annotation ‘the text’s meaning is clear’ likely contains an error.*

*"Root and standard differ; the Qi’s responses manifest distinct phenomena. The root pertains to the elemental response; the standard marks the onset of disease. When disease arises, one seeks the standard to apply treatment; to seek the root, one examines the fundamental. Root and standard differ, yet within lies the comprehensive method."*

*The newly corrected text notes: The *Treatise on the Most Authentic Essentials* states: ‘The Six Qi’s roots and standards differ. Some Qi follow the root, some follow both root and standard, and some follow neither. Minor Yang and Taiyin follow the root; Shaoyin and Taiyang follow both root and standard; Yang-Ming and Jueyin follow neither, instead relying on the central Qi. Thus, those that follow the root generate transformation from the root; those that follow both root and standard exhibit transformations of root and standard; those that follow the central Qi transform through the central Qi.’*

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"Why do some Qi arrive when they should, some fail to arrive when they should, and some arrive in excess when they should?"*

*All refer to Heaven’s Six Qi. The first Qi arises fifteen days before the Vernal Equinox. The remaining five terminal Qi arrive sequentially, each governing sixty days plus eighty-seven and a half *ke* (a *ke* is 1/100 of a day).*

Qibo said:
*"When a Qi arrives as it should, it is harmonious; when it arrives but does not fully manifest, the incoming Qi is insufficient; when it arrives before its time, the incoming Qi is in excess. When the season arrives and the Qi arrives, this is the response of balance—such is the year of equilibrium.

For instance, in a *jiazi* year, if the Qi is in excess, it arrives before the *guihai* year’s designated time. In a *yichou* year, if the Qi is deficient, it arrives late during the *jiazi* year’s designated time. Thus it is said: ‘The incoming Qi is insufficient’ or ‘the incoming Qi is in excess.’"*

The initial arrival of the Six Qi follows its proper timing. If the annual Qi is in excess, all Six Qi arrive before their designated time; if the annual Qi is insufficient, all Six Qi arrive late. Arriving early or late, each deviation is thirteen days, and this is their response.

○The *Xin Jiao Zheng* states: According to *The Golden Chamber Essentials* (《金匮要略》), there are cases where a Qi arrives before its time, where it arrives but does not fully manifest, where it arrives but does not depart, and where it arrives with excessive force. After the Winter Solstice, in a *jiazi* year, the minor Yang Qi arises at midnight—when the minor Yin Qi’s time should have just begun, and the Yang Qi begins to generate. The heavens thus receive warmth and mildness, even though the *jiazi* year has not yet arrived; this is the case of "arriving before its time."

When the *jiazi* year arrives but the heavens are not yet warm and mild, this is "arriving but not fully manifesting." When the *jiazi* year arrives but the heavens remain intensely cold without abating, this is "arriving but not departing." When the *jiazi* year arrives but the heavens grow warm like mid-summer, this is "arriving with excessive force." These are also manifestations of the Qi’s response.

The Emperor said: *"What does 'arriving but not fully manifesting' or 'arriving before its time' mean?"*

It means the Qi is either in excess or insufficient for the year, responding with late or early arrival when it should come.

Qibo said: *"When the Qi responds as it should, it is harmonious; otherwise, it is contrary. Contrary responses give rise to change, and change leads to illness. Arriving at the proper time is harmonious, while failing to do so is contrary. The transforming Qi of Heaven and Earth is ceaseless, without obstruction. If a Qi arrives when it should not, or fails to arrive when it should, this disrupts the natural order of the transforming Qi. When the natural order is disrupted, the Qi becomes erratic, and this erratic Qi unsettles the blood, resulting in illness. When the Qi of Heaven and Earth varies and loses its regularity, all things fall ill."*

The Emperor said: *"Well said."* He then asked: *"Please explain how the Six Qi respond in terms of the Earth’s geography and their seasonal positions."*

Qibo said:
*"To the right of the *Xianming* (显明) is the position of the Sovereign Fire (君火); to the right of the Sovereign Fire, one step backward, is the position of the Ministerial Fire (相火). When the sun rises, this is called *Xianming*—the Earth Qi at the *mao* hour (卯) marks the onset of Spring. After sixty days and a fraction from the Spring Equinox, when the Dipper (斗) aligns with *mao* (卯) and reaches *si* (巳), this is the position of the Sovereign Fire. From when the Dipper aligns with *si* (巳) until the midpoint of *wei* (未), the threefold division of the Qi belongs to the Ministerial Fire, known as the minor Yang (少阳). The Sovereign Fire’s position is the minor Yin (少阴), the division of heat. When the celestial degree reaches this point, warmth and mildness prevail, and though it resides in the division of heat, it does not extend to scorching summer—this is the Sovereign Fire’s virtue.

If the minor Yang (少阳) occupies its position, it becomes usurping and rebellious, with excessive heat arriving early, causing epidemics (疠). If the minor Yang (少阳) is in its proper place, the heat is intense but arrives at its due time, while the dampness spreads late. If the *Yangming* (阳明) occupies its position, it results in untimely warmth and coolness. If the *Taiyang* (太阳) occupies its position, it brings alternating cold rain and heat. If the *Jueyin* (厥阴) occupies its position, it generates wind and dampness, and rain breeds winged insects (羽虫). If the minor Yin (少阴) occupies its position, it causes widespread pestilence (疫) in the world, for it has obtained its position and the Sovereign Fire’s command spreads unchecked. If the *Taiyin* (太阴) occupies its position, it brings seasonal rains (时雨).

Fire has two positions, so the Sovereign Fire is taken as the beginning of the Six Qi. The Ministerial Fire governs thirty days before and after the Summer Solstice, the division of the minor Yang (少阳), where Fire resides. When the celestial degree reaches this point, scorching heat prevails. If the minor Yang (少阳) occupies its position, it results in sudden heat, withering grass and drying rivers, extreme scorching, and dampness spreading late. If the *Yangming* (阳明) occupies its position, it brings frost-like Qi and premature outbreaks. If the *Taiyang* (太阳) occupies its position, it results in alternating cold and heat, with hot and cold Qi contending, producing hail and ice. If the *Jueyin* (厥阴) occupies its position, it generates intense wind and heat, and rain breeds winged insects (羽虫). If the minor Yin (少阴) occupies its position, it results in great heat and extreme scorching. If the *Taiyin* (太阴) occupies its position, it brings clouds, rain, thunder, and lightning.

*Retreat* (退) refers to facing south and viewing the position to the right of the current one. One step forward or backward is sixty days and a fraction of eighty-seven and a half *ke*. The remaining Qi follow the same principle.

One step further backward, the Earth Qi (土气) governs it—the division of rain (雨). This occurs sixty days and a fraction before the Autumn Equinox, when the Dipper aligns with *wei* (未) and reaches the midpoint of *you* (酉), the fourth division of the Qi. When the celestial degree reaches this point, clouds and rain prevail, and dampness ascends. If the minor Yang (少阳) occupies its position, it results in boiling heat, clouds, rain, thunder, and hail. If the *Yangming* (阳明) occupies its position, it brings clear rain, mist, and dew. If the *Taiyang* (太阳) occupies its position, it results in cold rain that harms things. If the *Jueyin* (厥阴) occupies its position, it generates violent wind and rain, destroying and pulling things apart, and rain breeds winged insects (保虫). If the minor Yin (少阴) occupies its position, it results in alternating cold and heat, with floating clouds over mountains and lakes, sudden rain and dampness ascending. If the *Taiyin* (太阴) occupies its position, it brings prolonged heavy rains (霪霪). (霪, pronounced *yin* as in 淫.)"

«Then another step forward, the *metal qi* (金气) takes charge;
　　This is the division of dryness (燥), occurring sixty days before the Autumnal Equinox (秋分), when the *Lüshou* (六元) reaches its fullest manifestation. From the moment the *Big Dipper* (斗建) aligns with *You* (酉) until *Hai* (亥), it is the fifth *qi* (气). When the celestial degree reaches this point, all things become parched (燥). If the minor Yang (少阳) occupies its position, it brings temperate and refreshing dryness (温清更正), and all things flourish (荣). If the *Yangming* (阳明) occupies its position, it results in severe frost and a sharp, piercing dryness (大冻燥疾). If the *Taiyang* (太阳) occupies its position, it brings early cold (早寒). If the *Jueyin* (厥阴) occupies its position, it unleashes great gusts of cold wind (冻风大行), and rain breeds *shell-scaled insects* (介虫). If the minor Yin (少阴) occupies its position, it results in autumn dampness (秋湿), with heat-related illnesses (热病) becoming prevalent. If the *Taiyin* (太阴) occupies its position, it brings timely rains (时雨) and lingering dampness (况阴).

Then another step forward, the *water qi* (水气) takes charge;
　　This is the division of cold (寒), occurring thirty days before and after the Winter Solstice (冬至). From the moment the *Big Dipper* (斗建) aligns with *Hai* (亥) until *Chou* (丑), it is the sixth *qi* (气). When the celestial degree reaches this point, cold *qi* (寒气) prevails greatly. If the minor Yang (少阳) occupies its position, it brings winter warmth (冬温), with *cold-dwelling insects* (垫虫) not hiding and flowing waters not freezing (流水不冰). If the *Yangming* (阳明) occupies its position, it results in a piercing dry cold (燥寒劲切). If the *Taiyang* (太阳) occupies its position, it brings intense cold (大寒凝冽). If the *Jueyin* (厥阴) occupies its position, it results in cold winds that sweep and scatter (寒风飘扬), and rain breeds *scaled insects* (鳞虫). If the minor Yin (少阴) occupies its position, it brings forth *cold-dwelling insects* (垫虫) and flowing waters that do not freeze (流水不冰). If the *Taiyin* (太阴) occupies its position, it results in lingering dampness and cold snow (凝阴寒雪), with the earth’s *qi* (地气) becoming moist.

Then another step forward, the *wood qi* (木气) takes charge;
　　This is the division of wind (风), occurring sixty days before the Vernal Equinox (春分). From the moment the *Big Dipper* (斗建) aligns with *Chou* (丑) until *Mao* (卯), it is the first *qi* (气). When the celestial degree reaches this point, wind *qi* (风气) begins to move, marking the start of the divine commands (神明号令) of Heaven and Earth and the deployment of Heaven’s agents (天之使). If the minor Yang (少阳) occupies its position, it brings the onset of warm epidemics (温疫至). If the *Yangming* (阳明) occupies its position, it results in clear winds (清风), mist and dew (雾露) in a hazy state (朦昧). If the *Taiyang* (太阳) occupies its position, it brings a fierce, biting cold wind (寒风切烈), with frost, snow, and water all frozen. If the *Jueyin* (厥阴) occupies its position, it unleashes great winds that flourish (大风发荣), and rain breeds *hairy insects* (毛虫). If the minor Yin (少阴) occupies its position, it results in scorching winds that harm people (热风伤人), with seasonal *qi* (时气) circulating freely. If the *Taiyin* (太阴) occupies its position, it brings wind and rain (风雨), with lingering dampness (凝阴) refusing to disperse.

Then another step forward, the *Jūn Huǒ* (君火) takes charge;
　　This is the division of heat (热), returning to the Vernal Equinox (春分) as its beginning. From the moment the *Big Dipper* (斗建) aligns with *Mao* (卯) until *Si* (巳), it is the second *qi* (气). These six positions collectively govern the entire year, comprising 360 days (六六三百六十日), 480 *kè* (刻, a unit of time) (六八四百八十刻), and 42 *kè* (六七四十二刻), with the remaining half-*kè* divided into three, approximating a total of 365 degrees (约终三百六十五度). The surplus can be further refined as needed.

Beneath the *Jūn Huǒ* (君火), the *water qi* (水气) receives it; when heat is excessive and water receives it, it manifests as flexible and tenuous growth (条蔓柔弱), and as the nurturing and overflowing of yin moisture (妻润衍溢), making the water symbol (水象) visible.

○*Newly corrected text* states: According to the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪大论), when the minor Yang (少阳) arrives, it generates fire (火生), culminating in steamy surges (蒸涛). Thus, the meaning of *water qi* receiving it (水气承之) is evident. It further states: When the minor Yang (少阳) arrives, it brings *flagging winds* (标#7风) that overturn and scorch, with frost congealing. This too is the *water qi* receiving it (下承之水气).

Beneath the *water qi* (水气), the *earth qi* (土气) receives it; when cold is severe, things harden (物坚), water freezes and flows cease (流涸), and the earth symbol (土象) then appears, making its reception (承下) clear.

○*Newly corrected text* states: According to the commentary on the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪大论), when the *Taiyang* (太阳) arrives, it brings cold snow, ice, hail, and white mist (寒雪冰雹白埃). This too is the *earth qi* receiving it (土气承之).

Beneath the *earth qi* (土气), the *wind qi* (风气) receives it; after fierce winds (疾风), timely rains (时雨) begin to fall. Thus, dampness is dispersed by wind (湿为风吹), transforming into rain (化而为雨).

○*Newly corrected text* states: According to the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪大论), when the *Taiyin* (太阴) arrives, it generates dampness (湿生), culminating in pouring rain (注雨). Thus, beneath the *earth qi* (土位之下), the *wind qi* (风气) receives it and becomes rain (而为雨). It further states: When the *Taiyin* (太阴) arrives, it brings thunderous downpours (雷霆骤注) and violent gusts of wind (烈风). This too is the *wind qi* receiving it (风承之义).

Beneath the *wind qi* (风气), the *metal qi* (金气) receives it; when wind stirs and *qi* clears, all things become dry (万物皆燥), with *metal qi* receiving the *wood qi* (金承木下), its symbol (其象) manifesting plainly.

○*Newly corrected text* states: According to the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪大论), when the *Jueyin* (厥阴) arrives, it generates wind (风生), culminating in austerity (肃). Thus, the meaning of *metal qi* receiving it (金承之义) is evident. It further states: When the *Jueyin* (厥阴) arrives, it brings *howling winds* (飘怒) and severe frost (大冻). This too is the *metal qi* receiving it (亦金承之义).

Beneath the *metal qi* (金气), the *fire qi* (火气) receives it; when metal is refined and heat is generated (锻金生热), fire flows from metal (火流金), ascending upon fire’s position (乘火之上), its course (理) being without deviation (无妄).

○*Newly corrected text* states: According to the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪大论), when the *Yangming* (阳明) arrives, it brings *dispersing warmth* (散落温). This too is the fire ascending upon it (火乘之义).

Beneath the *Jūn Huǒ* (君火), *yin essence* (阴精) receives it. In the position of *Jūn Huǒ*, extreme heat does not prevail (大热不行), for *yin essence* restrains and receives it below (盖为阴精制承其下). All instances where the *qi* of the conquered element (所胜之气) receives beneath (乘於下者), temper their excessive manifestations (折其标盛). This is the grand framework of Heaven and Earth’s creation (天地造化之大体).

○*Newly corrected text* states: According to the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪大论), when the minor Yin (少阴) arrives, it generates heat (热生), but in the middle, it turns cold (中为寒). Thus, the meaning of *yin essence* receiving it (阴承之义) is clear. It further states: When the minor Yin (少阴) arrives, it brings *great warmth and cold* (大暄寒). This too is its meaning (亦其义也).

Furthermore, according to the *Six Elements and Their Proper Sequence* (六元正纪), it states: When water rises, it brings hail and snow (水发而雹雪); when earth rises, it brings *scattering winds* (飘骤); when wood rises, it brings destruction and breaking (毁折); when metal rises, it brings clarity and brightness (清明); when fire rises, it brings *pervasive haze* (熏昧). What *qi* causes these phenomena?

It is said: *Qi* has varying degrees of intensity (多少), and its manifestations differ in subtlety (微甚). The subtle align with their own element (微者当其气), while the intense combine with the element beneath them (甚者兼其下), revealing what *qi* below is being influenced (征其下气而见可知).

The Emperor asked: What does this mean?
Qi Bo replied: When an element is in excess (亢), it brings harm (则害); when it receives (承), it restrains (乃制), and restraint leads to transformation and generation (制则生化). External manifestations reflect the degree of excess or deficiency (外列盛衰). Excess causes defeat and disorder (害则败乱), while transformation and generation lead to great illness (生化大病). Excess (亢) is the surpassing of limits (过极), and things abhor their extremes (物恶其极).

The Emperor asked: How does excess and deficiency manifest?
Qi Bo replied: If it is not in its proper position (非其位), it becomes perverse (则邪); if it is in its proper position (当其位), it becomes correct (则正). When perverse, its effects are extreme (邪则变甚); when correct, its effects are subtle (正则微).

The Emperor asked: What is meant by "in its proper position" (当位)?

Qi Bo replied:
When the **Wood phase** governs the **Mao** hour, the **Fire phase** governs the **Wu** hour, the **Earth phase** governs all four seasons, the **Metal phase** governs the **You** hour, and the **Water phase** governs the **Zi** hour—this is what is called the **"Sui Hui"** (yearly conjunction), where the **qi** is balanced. Neither excessive nor deficient, this is called **"Ping Yun"** (balanced phase) governing the year. In a balanced year, all things flourish in harmony with the pulses, all in perfect accord without deviation.

*(New annotation: Specifically, when the Wood phase governs Mao, it refers to the Ding-Mao year. When the Fire phase governs Wu, it refers to the Wu-Wu year. When the Earth phase governs all four seasons, it refers to the Jia-Chen, Jia-Xu, Ji-Chou, and Ji-Wei years. When the Metal phase governs You, it refers to the Yi-You year. When the Water phase governs Zi, it refers to the Bing-Zi year. Among these, Wu-Wu, Ji-Chou, Ji-Wei, and Yi-You are also part of the **Tai Tianfu** (Great Heavenly Correspondence).)*

The Emperor asked: What if it is not in its proper position?
Qi Bo replied: The year does not align with the **Hui** (conjunction). It does not meet with its native **ben chen** (root hour).

The Emperor asked: In the Earth phase year, the **Tai Yin** (Greater Yin) appears above; in the Fire phase year, both **Shao Yang** (Lesser Yang) and **Shao Yin** (Lesser Yin) appear above—both being Fire **qi**; in the Metal phase year, **Yang Ming** (Bright Yang) appears above; in the Wood phase year, **Jue Yin** (Dripping Yin) appears above; in the Water phase year, **Tai Yang** (Greater Yang) appears above—how so?

Qi Bo replied: The **Heavenly conjunction** is when the **Heavenly qi** meets with the **Yun qi** (phase **qi**). *(New annotation: Specifically, in the Earth phase year, Tai Yin appears above—Ji-Chou and Ji-Wei. In the Fire phase year, Shao Yang appears above—Wu-Yin and Wu-Shen; Shao Yin appears above—Wu-Zi and Wu-Wu. In the Metal phase year, Yang Ming appears above—Yi-Mao and Yi-You. In the Wood phase year, Jue Yin appears above—Ding-Si and Ding-Hai. In the Water phase year, Tai Yang appears above—Bing-Chen and Bing-Xu. Among these, Ji-You, Ji-Wei, Wu-Wu, and Yi-You are also part of the Tai Tianfu.)*

According to the *Liu Yuan Zheng Ji Da Lun* (Great Treatise on the Six Elements' True Sequence), there are three cases of **Tai Guo** (excess) aligning with Heavenly transformations and three cases of **Bu Ji** (deficiency) aligning with Heavenly transformations: Wu-Zi and Wu-Wu, where **Tai Zheng** (excessive征) ascends to Shao Yin; Wu-Yin and Wu-Shen, where **Tai Zheng** ascends to Shao Yang; Bing-Chen and Bing-Xu, where **Tai Yu** (excessive羽) ascends to Tai Yang—these are three cases. Ding-Si and Ding-Hai, where **Shao Jiao** (deficient角) ascends to Jue Yin; Yi-Mao and Yi-You, where **Shao Shang** (deficient商) ascends to Yang Ming; Ji-Chou and Ji-Wei, where **Shao Guan** (deficient官) ascends to Tai Yin—these are three cases. Those ascending are either **Tai Guo** or **Bu Ji**, all called **Tianfu** (Heavenly Correspondence). Hence, the *Tian Yuan Ce* (Heavenly Elemental Register) refers to them as **Tianfu**.

What is the **Sui Hui** of the **Tianfu** like?
Qi Bo replied: The **Tai Tianfu** conjunction is what is called **"San He"** (Three Harmonies)—the first being **Tian Hui** (Heavenly Conjunction), the second **Sui Hui** (Yearly Conjunction), and the third **Yun Hui** (Phase Conjunction). The *Tian Yuan Ji Da Lun* (Great Treatise on Heavenly Elemental Sequences) states: *"San He"* is the principle of governance. This is what is meant.

*(New annotation: The details of Tai Tianfu are fully elaborated in the annotations of the *Tian Yuan Ji Da Lun*.)*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"How do their dignities and humilities differ?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"The **Tianfu** (Heavenly Correspondence) governs as the law; the **Suiwei** (Yearly Position) acts as the decree; and the **Tai Tianfu** (Great Heavenly Correspondence) signifies the noble person.
To govern as the law is like the **Xiangfu** (Minister of War); to act as the decree is like the **Fangbo** (Regional Commanders); and the noble person is like the sovereign ruler.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"What if one is struck by evil?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"If struck by the **Tianfu** (Heavenly Correspondence), the disease progresses swiftly and is perilous. The **Tianfu** and **Guanren** (Official Person) together form the standard of governance, yet when evil arises, it disrupts this alignment, causing swift and perilous illness.
If struck by the **Suiwei** (Yearly Position), the disease advances slowly but persists. The **Fangbo** (Regional Commander) lacks the authority to enforce swift punishment, so the harm is merely prolonged.
If struck by the **Gui Ren** (Noble Person), the disease erupts violently and leads to death. The noble person’s virtue cannot be violated, so the illness strikes violently and results in death.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"How do the shifts in their positions manifest?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"When a subject assumes the sovereign’s position, it is in harmony; when the sovereign assumes a subject’s position, it is contrary. Contrary brings illness near and harm swift; harmony brings illness distant and harm slight. This is what is called the **Two Fires** (of governance).
The **Xianghuo** (Ministerial Fire) resides within the **Junhuo** (Sovereign Fire), meaning the subject’s position is within the sovereign’s position—thus, it is contrary. The **Junhuo** (Sovereign Fire) residing within the **Xianghuo** (Ministerial Fire) means the sovereign’s position is within the subject’s position, with the sovereign overseeing the subject—thus, it is in harmony. 'Distant' refers to the inner chambers being far, 'near' refers to the inner chambers being close."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Good. I wish to hear about their progression—how does it proceed?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"The progression is measured in degrees: sixty degrees with a remainder, the remainder being eighty-seven and a half **ke** (刻) plus five-tenths of a **ke**. Thus, twenty-four such steps accumulate to a hundred **ke**, completing a day. This refers to the surplus of Heaven’s degrees.
When speaking of the degrees of the **Zhou Tian** (Complete Heavenly Cycle), it is three hundred sixty-five degrees plus one-fourth of a degree. Twenty-four steps equal four years, and one-fourth of a degree is twenty-five **ke**. When the accumulated **ke** of four years reaches a hundred, it forms one day. Here, 'degree' means one day.
The Yellow Emperor said: *"How do the Six Qi (氣) correspond to the changes of the Five Phases (行)?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"Positions have beginnings and endings; **qi** has phases of initial and mid. Their interactions differ above and below, and their inquiry varies accordingly. Positions refer to ranks; **qi** refers to Heaven’s **qi**. The **qi** and positions shift in relation to each other, so at the **qi**’s initial phase, Heaven’s influence prevails, and at its mid-phase, Earth’s influence dominates. When Earth dominates, the **qi** flows upon Earth; when Heaven prevails, the **qi** ascends to Heaven. Both the initial and mid-phases are divided by the Heavenly Steps, with each phase measuring thirty days plus forty-three and three-fourths **ke**."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"How does one seek them?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"The **qi** of Heaven begins at **Jia** (甲), and the **qi** of Earth begins at **Zi** (子). When **Zi** and **Jia** align, it is called **Sui Li** (Yearly Establishment); if one carefully observes the time, the **qi** can be anticipated accordingly. When **Zi** and **Jia** align, it is the **Jia Zi** (甲子) Year. If one carefully observes the early and late moments of the **Shui Ke** (Water Mark), then all Six **Qi** can be anticipated.
The Yellow Emperor said: *"I wish to hear about the year—how do the Six Qi begin and end, early and late?"*
Qi Bo replied: *"Your question is clear! In the **Jia Zi** (甲子) Year, the initial **qi**, Heaven’s degree begins at the **Shui Xia** (Water Mark) minus one **ke**, rising at **Ping Ming** (平明, dawn) during the first **ke** of **Yin Sheng** (寅初, the first hour of the Tiger), in the southern **Geng** (艮) direction. *(Annotation: In the years of **Wu Chen** (戊辰), **Ren Shen** (壬申), **Bing Zi** (丙子), **Geng Chen** (庚辰), **Jia Shen** (甲申), **Ji Zi** (己子), **Ren Chen** (壬辰), **Bing Shen** (丙申), **Geng Zi** (庚子), **Jia Chen** (甲辰), **Wu Shen** (戊申), **Kun Zi** (癸子), **Bing Chen** (丙辰), and **Geng Shen** (庚申), the **qi** of these years align similarly. This is the **Chen Shen Zi** (辰申子) Yearly Conjunction of **qi**, and the *Yin Yang Fa* (Doctrine of Yin and Yang) regards this as **San He** (Three Harmonies).)*
It ends at eighty-seven and a half **ke**; at the midpoint of **Zi Zheng** (子正, the hour of the Rat), which is the halfway point of the night. Twelve and a half **ke** beyond, it enters the initial phase of the second **qi**, and all remaining **ke** are similarly included.
The second **qi** begins at eighty-seven and six-tenths **ke**, in the southern **Geng** (艮) direction of **Zi Zheng** (子正). It ends at seventy-five **ke**, four **ke** after **Xu** (戌, the Dog). Twenty-five **ke** beyond, it enters the initial phase of the next three **qi** in sequence.
The third **qi** begins at seventy-six **ke**, at the first **ke** of **Hai Sheng** (亥初, the first hour of the Pig). It ends at sixty-two and a half **ke**, at the midpoint of **You Zheng** (酉正, the hour of the Rooster). Thirty-seven and a half **ke** beyond, it enters the following phase.
The fourth **qi** begins at sixty-two and six-tenths **ke**, in the northern **Geng** (艮) direction of **You Zheng** (酉正). It ends at fifty **ke**, four **ke** after **Wei** (未, the Sheep). Fifty **ke** beyond, it enters the following phase.
The fifth **qi** begins at fifty-one **ke**, at the first **ke** of **Shen Sheng** (申初, the first hour of the Monkey). It ends at thirty-seven and a half **ke**, at the midpoint of **Wu Zheng** (午正, the hour of the Horse), which is the halfway point of the day. Sixty-two and a half **ke** beyond, it enters the following phase.

The sixth **qi** begins at thirty-seven and six-tenths **ke**, in the southern **Geng** (艮) direction of **Wu Zheng** (午正). It ends at twenty-five **ke**, four **ke** after **Chen Zheng** (辰正, the hour of the Dragon). Seventy-five **ke** beyond, it enters the following phase. *(This is what is called **Chu Liu** (初六), Heaven’s degree.)* The degrees of Heaven and Earth converge in the twenty-four **qi**, forming a grand assembly and alignment; thus, this day is named the **Chu Liu Tian Shu** (初六天數, initial sixth Heavenly degree).

In the **Yi Chou** (乙丑) Year, the initial **qi**, Heaven’s degree begins at twenty-six **ke**, at the first **ke** of **Si Sheng** (巳初, the first hour of the Snake). *(Annotation: In the years of **Ji Si** (己巳), **Gui You** (癸酉), **Ding Chou** (丁丑), **Xin Si** (辛巳), **Yi You** (乙酉), **Ji Chou** (己丑), **Gui Si** (癸巳), **Ding You** (丁酉), **Xin Chou** (辛丑), **Yi Si** (乙巳), **Ji You** (己酉), **Kun Chou** (癸丑), **Ding Si** (丁巳), and **Xin You** (辛酉), the **qi** align similarly. This is the **Si You Chou** (巳酉丑) Yearly Conjunction of **qi**.)*
It ends at twelve and a half **ke**, at the midpoint of **Mao Zheng** (卯正, the hour of the Hare). The second **qi** begins at twelve and six-tenths **ke**, in the southern **Geng** (艮) direction of **Mao Zheng** (卯正). It ends at **Shui Xia** (水下, the Water Mark) plus one hundred **ke**, four **ke** after **Chou** (丑, the Ox).
The third **qi** begins at one **ke**, again at the first **ke** of **Yin Sheng** (寅初, the first hour of the Tiger). It ends at eighty-seven and a half **ke**, at the midpoint of **Zi Zheng** (子正, the hour of the Rat). The fourth **qi** begins at eighty-seven and six-tenths **ke**, in the eastern **Geng** (艮) direction of **Zi Zheng** (子正). It ends at seventy-five **ke**, four **ke** after **Xu** (戌, the Dog).
The fifth **qi** begins at seventy-six **ke**,

The sixth **qi** begins at one **ke**, at the first **ke** of **Hai Chu** (亥初, the first hour of the Pig).
It ends at sixty-two and a half **ke**, at the midpoint of **You Zheng** (酉正, the hour of the Rooster).

The sixth **qi** begins at sixty-two and six-tenths **ke**,
in the northern **You** (酉) direction of **You Zheng** (酉正).
It ends at fifty **ke**, four **ke** after **Wei** (未, the Sheep).

The so-called "six-two" (六二) is the **Heavenly Number** (天之数).
One-six (一六) is the initial six (初六),
and two-six (二六) is the second six (六二), which follows in order.

In the year **Bing Yin** (丙寅), the first **qi**,
the **Heavenly Number** begins at fifty-one **ke**,
at the first **ke** of **Shen Chu** (申初, the first hour of the Monkey).
