The so-called "six-four" (六四) is the **Heavenly Number** (天之数).
In the following year **Wu Chen** (戊辰), the first **qi**,
again begins at one **ke**, perpetually so, cycling endlessly.
It starts from the year **Jia Zi** (甲子) and ends at the year **Gui Hai** (癸亥),
constantly taking four years as one **small cycle** (小周),
and fifteen **small cycles** (小周) as one **great cycle** (大周).
When the year is designated by **Chen** (辰), then the **qi** can be aligned with the cycle.

The Emperor said: I wish to hear how the yearly cycles correspond.
**Gui Bo** (岐伯) replied: Your question is thorough indeed!
The **Heavenly Qi** (天气) begins at one **ke** when the sun completes one cycle;
this is the year **Jia Zi** (甲子).

The **Heavenly Qi** begins at twenty-six **ke** when the sun completes two cycles;
this is the year **Yi Chou** (乙丑).

The **Heavenly Qi** begins at fifty-one **ke** when the sun completes three cycles;
this is the year **Bing Yin** (丙寅).

The **Heavenly Qi** begins at seventy-six **ke** when the sun completes four cycles;
this is the year **Ding Mao** (丁卯).

The **Heavenly Qi** again begins at one **ke** when the sun completes five cycles;
this is the year **Wu Chen** (戊辰).
The remaining fifty-five years follow in this cycle, endlessly repeating.
This is called a **"ji" (纪) cycle**.

The rule is that four years constitute one **ji** cycle,
repeating endlessly.
There are three **qi** cycles every three years,
thus there are three **unified cycles** (三合).

Therefore, the **"Yin Wu Xu" (寅午戌) years** have unified **qi** cycles,
the **"Mao Wei Hai" (卯未亥) years** have unified **qi** cycles,
the **"Chen Shen Zi" (辰申子) years** have unified **qi** cycles,
and the **"Si You Chou" (巳酉丑) years** have unified **qi** cycles,
and so the cycle ends and begins anew.

The *Yin-Yang Laws* (《阴阳法》) consider this as the three **unified cycles** (三合),
for it is where the **qi** cycles converge.
Otherwise, each would remain in its own domain,
and there would be no basis for their unification.

The Emperor said: I wish to hear their applications.
**Gui Bo** replied: When speaking of **Heaven** (天), seek its **root** (本);
when speaking of **Earth** (地), seek its **position** (位);
when speaking of **human beings** (人), seek the **interchange of qi** (气交).

**Root** (本) refers to the **six Heavenly Qi** (天六气):
**Cold** (寒), **Heat** (暑), **Dryness** (燥), **Moisture** (湿), **Wind** (风), and **Fire** (火).
From these, the **three Yin and three Yang** (三阴三阳) generate and transform,
hence it is called **root**.

This is what is meant by the **Six Primordials** (六元).

**Position** (位) refers to the **Five Phases** (金木火土水) and their **corresponding ministers** (君火):
the **interchange of Heavenly and Earthly Qi** (天地之气), rising and falling,
where human beings dwell.

The Emperor said: What is meant by **interchange of qi** (气交)?
**Gui Bo** replied: The **positions of the upper and lower** (上下之位),
where the **interchange of qi** (气交) occurs,
is where humans reside.
From **Heaven’s lower boundary** (天之下) to **Earth’s upper boundary** (地之上),
this is the division where **Heavenly and Earthly Qi** (二气) intermingle.

Humans dwell on Earth’s surface,
so the **interchange of qi** (气交) is where humans reside.
Thus, all **transformations and changes** (化生变易) occur within this **interchange of qi** (气交).

Hence it is said:
Above the **Heavenly Pivot** (天枢), **Heavenly Qi** (天气) dominates;
Below the **Heavenly Pivot** (天枢), **Earthly Qi** (地气) dominates;
Within the **interchange of qi** (气交), **human qi** (人气) follows,
and all things are generated and transformed accordingly.
This is what is meant.

The **Heavenly Pivot** (天枢) is the region at the sides of the waist,
where, if one stretches out the arm and points to the sky,
the **Heavenly Pivot** aligns exactly with the midpoint of the body.
Dividing this into three parts:
the upper third corresponds to **Heaven** (天),
the lower third corresponds to **Earth** (地),
and the middle third corresponds to the **interchange of qi** (气交).

At the juncture where **Heavenly and Earthly Qi** (天地之气) intermingle,
the **victorious changes** (寒暑燥湿风火胜复之变之化) pass through,
thus **human qi** (人气) follows them,
and all things are generated and transformed,
all coalescing and dispersing accordingly.

The Emperor asked: "What is meant by *chū* and *zhōng*?"
Gebi replied: "*Chū* spans thirty degrees with an excess. *Zhōng* follows the same principle. The excess refers to thirty days plus forty-three *kè* and forty *fēn* of a *kè*—thirty in total. When *chū* and *zhōng* converge, it amounts to sixty days plus eighty-seven *kè* and a half. Since each has an excess of forty *fēn* of a *kè* thirty times, that is why *zhōng* follows the same law.

The Emperor asked: "What are *chū* and *zhōng* for?"
Gebi replied: "They serve to divide Heaven and Earth. Through this, one knows the high and low of *qi*, and how it governs the diseases of humankind."

The Emperor said: "I wish to hear it fully."
Gebi replied: "*Chū* is Earthly *qi*, and *zhōng* is Heavenly *qi*. At the beginning of *qi*, Heaven takes action—when Heaven acts, Earthly *qi* ascends within the boundless void. At the midpoint of *qi*, Earth governs—when Earth governs, Heavenly *qi* descends into the realm of substance.

The Emperor asked: "How does this ascending and descending proceed?"
Gebi replied: "The ascending and descending of *qi* is the alternating operation of Heaven and Earth. Ascending means rising upward; descending means falling downward. When ascending reaches its limit, it descends; when descending reaches its limit, it ascends. Since ascending and descending never cease, this displays the alternating operation of Heaven and Earth."

The Emperor asked: "I wish to hear how this operates."
Gebi replied: "When ascending ceases and descending begins, this descending is called Heaven; when descending ceases and ascending begins, this ascending is called Earth. At the beginning of *qi*, Earthly *qi* ascends; at the midpoint of *qi*, Heavenly *qi* descends. When ascending ceases and descending follows, it reveals the downward flow of Heavenly *qi*; when descending ceases and ascending follows, it manifests the upward response of Earthly *qi*. When Heavenly *qi* descends and Earthly *qi* ascends, their interchange marks the symbol of *Tài* (harmony). The *Yì* says: 'Heaven and Earth interchange in harmony.' Thus, the ascending and descending of Heavenly and Earthly *qi* always alternate every thirty days and a half, descending and ascending without pause, so that all things generate and transform, never resting, and each attains its place.

When Heavenly *qi* descends, *qi* flows toward Earth; when Earthly *qi* ascends, *qi* surges toward Heaven. Thus, high and low call to each other, ascending and descending follow in sequence, and transformation arises. Since *qi* has phases of dominance and reversal, change is generated.

---
*The newly corrected text states:* According to the *Lùyúan Zhèngjì Dàlùn*, how does the fullness and emptiness of Heavenly and Earthly *qi* operate? When Heavenly *qi* is insufficient, Earthly *qi* follows; when Earthly *qi* is insufficient, Heavenly *qi* follows. The revolving cycle governs this, always taking precedence. What is not overcome returns to harmony; following the revolving cycle, it generates disease accordingly. Thus, when the upper dominates, Heavenly *qi* descends and prevails below; when the lower dominates, Earthly *qi* shifts and ascends. The degree of excess or deficiency alters their proportions—minor differences result in small deviations, extreme differences lead to great deviations, and extreme deviations cause positional shifts in *qi* interchange, leading to major transformations and the onset of disease.

The Emperor said: "Excellent. When cold and dampness encounter each other, when dryness and heat confront each other, when wind and fire clash—what questions arise from this?"
Gebi replied: "*Qi* has phases of dominance and reversal. The emergence of dominance and reversal involves *virtue*, transformation, function, and change; change allows pathogenic *qi* to take root. Just as clapping hands produces sound and pouring water generates boiling, the interchange of things manifests their interactions. All classes of beings likewise arise from this. When Heavenly and Earthly *qi* intermingle, the eight winds surge and clash, and the six *qi* race through their midst. Thus, when *qi* cannot remain balanced, it becomes pathogenic *qi*.

The Emperor asked: "What is meant by *xié* (pathogenic)?"
Gebi replied: "*Xié* refers to what is not upright. When Heaven and Earth dominate and reverse, cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire—the six *qi*—mutually become pathogenic.

Gebi continued: "The generation of things follows transformation; their extremes arise from change. When transformation and change press close, success and failure emerge. The *qi* of generation and transformation is unseen in form, its nature unknown, its origin unfathomable, its end unsearchable—yet all things spontaneously generate and transform, approaching completion without limit. This is called *Tiān Hé* (Heaven’s harmony). When its manifestations appear, its movements are evident: violent, fierce, and abrupt, drifting and sudden, pulling apart the firm and shattering the resilient, fracturing and trembling—this is called pathogenic *qi*. Thus, when things generate, they do so quietly and complete their transformation; when they perish, they do so violently and undergo change. Therefore, generation follows transformation, extremes arise from change, and since transformation and change never cease, success and failure are ever-present. Those who speak of bounded generation imply the existence of beginnings and ends.

---
*The newly corrected text states:* According to the *Tiānyuán Jì Dàlùn*, when things generate, it is called transformation; when things reach their limits, it is called change. Thus, *qi* has phases of dominance and reversal, and its functions vary in speed. These four aspects—dominance, reversal, delay, and haste—give rise to transformation and change. When wind arises, Heaven and Earth shift positions, cold and heat exchange directions, water and fire swap places. At the moment of movement, the speed and reversal of *qi* do not remain constant. Though its intentions cannot be fully discerned, the subtle and extreme effects manifest as transformation and change—the origin of wind. When human *qi* cannot overcome it, disease arises from this influence. Wind does not seek to dominate humanity.

The Emperor said: "Dominance and reversal, delay and haste—these are how wind arises, giving rise to transformation and change. Thus, it follows the variations of flourishing and decline. Success and failure, rise and fall, fluctuate within—why is this so?"

The interplay of rise and fall is the germination of calamity and fortune. Where there is calamity, fortune is latent; where there is fortune, calamity is concealed. Thus, calamity and fortune alternately conceal and reveal each other. When things flourish, they decline; when joy reaches its peak, sorrow follows. This is the extreme of fortune, hence it is concealed by calamity. When adversity reaches its limit, prosperity follows; when the unaccomplished is accomplished, this is the extreme of calamity, hence it is concealed by fortune. Yet success and failure, joy and misfortune, are evident in the *Dao*—they cannot be perpetual. This is the natural order, so there is no blame.

Gebi replied: "Success and failure, rise and fall, arise from movement. Movement without cessation gives rise to transformation."

The principle of movement and stillness follows the constant operation of *qi*. In its subtle form, it gives rise to the transformation of things; in its extreme form, it brings about their changes. When *qi* flows into things, they obtain it and thus come to life; when changes are exerted upon things, they obtain it and thus perish. Hence, success and failure, rise and fall, arise from the subtle and extreme, swift and slow movements of *qi*—how could it be that only *qi* possesses this nature?

Humans exist within the realm of *qi*. The *Dao* of nurturing life, the application of advancing or retreating, all follow this same principle.

○The newly corrected text states: According to the *Zhi Zhen Yao Da Lun* (至真要大论), the *qi* of yin and yang—when clear and still, generates life and harmonious transformation; when active, gives rise to harsh ailments. This is what is meant here.

The Emperor asked: "Is there a limit to this?"

Gebi replied: "Stillness without life or transformation is the limit of stillness. The limits of humans are visible in two ways: the first is the daily cycle of life’s completion, and the second is the cycle of change, aligning with the earth’s#13 form. Then, from these small transformations, life returns to the great transformation. Even after death, the process of transformation and change continues, hence the two visible limits of humans.

The ultimate limits of Heaven and Earth, however, are unseen. Human lifespan has its allotted measure, and its length cannot match theirs, so few can perceive these limits.

The Emperor asked: "Does life not transform?" Or are there things that do not generate or transform?

Gebi replied: "When the processes of inhalation and exhalation cease, the vital *shenji* (神机) and transformations perish. When the rise and fall of *huayi* (化气) are stilled, *qi* stands alone in peril. Inhalation and exhalation refer to breathing; rise and fall refer to the *qi* of transformation.

The scales and feathers of birds, the shells of fish, and even their flight and movement—all are born from *qi* rooted within the body, with the *shen* (神) as the sovereign of movement and stillness. Hence, it is called *shenji* (神机).

Yet metals, gems, earth, and stones, as well as melting and mineral deposits in plants—all these arise from *qi* rooted externally, borrowing *qi* to form and sustain their essence. Thus, it is called *qili* (气立).

The *Wu Chang Zheng Da Lun* (五常政大论) states: *Qi* rooted within is called *shenji* (神机); when the *shen* departs, the *ji* (机) ceases. *Qi* rooted externally is called *qili* (气立); when the *qi* stops, transformation is cut off. This is what is meant.

Thus, without these four processes—*shenji* and *qili*—life and death both cease.

○The newly corrected text states: According to the *Yijing* (易), what originates from Heaven is drawn upward, what originates from Earth is drawn downward. The *Zhouli* (周礼) mentions *tianchan* (天产) and *dichan* (地产) in the *Da Zong Bo* (大宗伯), and *dongwu* (动物) and *zhiwu* (植物) in the *Da Si Tu* (大司徒). This refers precisely to *shenji* and *qili*.

(For *jiāo* (蛟), pronounced *qí* (祁).)

The Way of life and death depends not on mere emergence and retreat—without them, there could be no growth, flourishing, aging, or decline. Without ascent and descent, there could be no generation, growth, transformation, or withdrawal into storage.

The self-winding and unwinding, the self-extending and contracting from east to west, from south to north, all rely on the breath of emergence and retreat as the master of transformation. Those who preserve their essence by following things depend on the ascending and descending *qi* of yin and yang to create the source of life. Without this Way, none could achieve such life. Thus, ascent, descent, emergence, and retreat are present in all forms.

All that contains vital *qi* is called an instrument of life and transformation. When touched by things, it responds. The horizontal orifices all possess the *qi* of emergence, retreat, arrival, and departure. The vertical orifices all possess the ascending and descending *qi* of yin and yang, circulating within.

How do we know this? Observe the walls, windows, doors, and openings on both sides—they all receive incoming *qi* striking against them, which is the *qi* of emergence and retreat. When yang ascends, the well becomes cold; when yin ascends, the water grows warm. When objects are cast into the well, or leaves fall into empty space, drifting slowly without haste, it is due to the obstruction of ascending *qi*. When a full vessel is inverted and suspended, the water does not spill out—this is because there is no ascending *qi* to allow descent. When a small-mouthed bottle is struck, water does not enter—this is because the *qi* does not emerge to allow entrance.

From this, we see that ascent is inseparable from descent, and descent is inseparable from ascent. Without emergence, there is no retreat; without retreat, there is no emergence. Within all categories of things, emergence, retreat, ascent, and descent never deviate from their constant principles, yet to say they are not transformation is impossible. There is no being—sentient or insentient—that lacks emergence and retreat, ascent and descent, yet claims to endure.

Thus, it is said: emergence, retreat, ascent, and descent are present in all forms. Therefore, forms are the dwelling places of life and transformation. When forms disperse, they return to their constituents, and life and transformation cease. Forms refer to Heaven, Earth, and all bodies. Dwelling places refer to houses and structures. With their bodily shapes containing the repositories of the spirit and receiving the divine and numinous, they align with Heaven and Earth, hence all are called forms. All bodies are small instruments of life and transformation, while the Great Void is the vast instrument of life and transformation. The instruments of life and transformation vary in size, yet none escape dispersion.

Small and great forms alike have defined limits to their life and dispersion, with varying distances. The near does not perceive the far, and the far is said to have no bounds. The far has no constancy, yet when seen near, one sighs at its limits. Since near and far differ in their times, and merging and dispersing vary in their seasons, the interplay of presence and absence, differing perceptions, and conflicting constants arises. Yet when the time of dispersion comes, near and far alike return to a single transformation.

Of these four—emergence, retreat, ascent, and descent—constancy is most honored. These four are emergence, retreat, ascent, and descent. To have emergence and retreat, ascent and descent, is to uphold constancy. To have emergence without retreat, retreat without emergence, ascent without descent, or descent without ascent is not the *qi* of life. If one does not cultivate the Way of prenatal breathing, dwelling in constancy to sustain life, then none can block emergence and retreat or extinguish ascending and descending *qi* while preserving life and transformation. Thus, constancy is most honored.

To defy constancy brings calamity. Emergence, retreat, ascent, and descent are the fundamental principles of life and transformation, hence they cannot be neglected. To defy constancy is to drive the spirit from its dwelling, causing life and transformation to dwindle—what calamity could be greater?

Thus it is said: *Wu xing wu huan* (无形无患)—this is the meaning.

To delight in success, take pleasure in beauty, fear difficulty, dread misfortune, to suffer externally from cold winds, heat, and dampness, and internally from hunger, satiety, love, and desire—all these stem from the body having no concealment, thus constantly burdening one with cares in leisure. If one indulges in vain desires, insatiable cravings, clings to powerful factions, and indulges in false emotions, then one is ensnared by bonds and doomed to disaster. To hope for release from these chains is impossible!

Thus, the body is but a stage for breath. *Laozi* says: *"The reason I sigh deeply is that I have a body. When I have no body, what sighing shall I have?"* This is the meaning.

When the body and form dissolve into the Great Void, how can one know whether the *qi* of life and transformation gathers as having or disperses as nonexistent? The Yellow Emperor said: Well spoken. Is there any that does not generate or transform? Does this mean some escape yin and yang, evading life and transformation, yet neither generating nor transforming, beginning and ending nowhere, aligning with the naturalness of the Great Void?

Gebi said: Your question is profound! Only the True Person aligns with the Dao. The True Person’s body is hidden yet visible, elusive yet measurable, moving within and beyond Heaven and Earth. Following the Dao to its utmost truth in life, in their smallness they enter the unquestioned, and in their vastness they transcend the boundaries of emptiness. None but the Dao can achieve this unity—who else could do so?

The Yellow Emperor said: Well spoken.

The *Huangdi Neijing Suwen* annotated commentary concludes here.

The Yellow Emperor’s *Inner Canon* *Plain Questions* Supplementary Commentary, Volume Forty-One

**Discourse on the Great Transformations of Qi**

**Newly Revised Text:** This discourse elaborates on the transformations of interacting *qi*, detailing the matters of the Five Phases’ excess, deficiency, virtue/power (*dé*), governance, calamities, and the reversals of victory in disease.

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"When the Five Movements govern in succession, aligning with the celestial cycle, as yin and yang alternate and cold and heat follow in turn—when true and false forces converge, and inner and outer divisions arise—when the Six Canals surge and the Five *qi* shift, resulting in excess or deficiency, singular dominance or combined suppression—may I hear their origins and their constant names?"*

*"Period"* refers to 365¼ days.
*"Singular dominance"* means the governing phase of the year is in excess.
*"Combined suppression"* means the governing phase is deficient.
*"Constant names"* refers to the dissemination of virtue/power through the boundless void, and the correspondence of diseases with the body’s diagnostic forms.

**Newly Revised Text:** As the *Great Canon of Heavenly Origins* states:
*"The Five Movements succeed one another in governance, completing their allotted days before returning in cycle."*
It further says:
*"The Five *qi* move in their appointed periods."*
And the *Celestial Primordium’s Imperial Edict* declares:
*"All things derive their origin; the Five Movements complete the celestial order."*
This is the meaning of the Five Movements governing in succession, aligning with the celestial period.

Qìbó knelt twice, bowing his head in reply:
*"Your question is enlightened! This is the Way made clear. It is what the Celestial Sovereign holds dear, transmitted by the venerable teachers. Though I am unworthy, I have heard its essence in the past."*

*"Speaking of what was not innate knowledge but the transmitted wisdom of ancient masters."*

The Emperor said:
*"I have heard that if one finds the right person but does not teach them, it is called losing the Way. If transmission is not given to the proper person, the celestial treasures are recklessly divulged. My virtue is indeed meager, unworthy of receiving the supreme Dao. Yet my subjects pity that it may not reach completion, and I wish you would preserve it endlessly, extending it infinitely. If I oversee its implementation, how should I follow it?"*

*"The supreme Dao is not difficult to transmit or to know—it is difficult to practice. The Sage, moved by pity for the common people, sought to dwell with them in eternal life. Thus, he humbled himself and lowered his will, requesting transmission from the Celestial Master."*

*"The Most High values virtue/power, so he prioritizes others over himself. If not given to the right person, the Way is not bestowed in vain."*

The Emperor, desiring benevolence and far-reaching kindness, universal love, and reverence for the Way while lowering himself to save the people, said:
*"Then how should I govern its affairs and follow it?"*

Qìbó replied:
*"Let me speak fully. The *Upper Canon* says:*
*'The Dao encompasses celestial phenomena above, terrestrial geography below, and human affairs within—thus one may endure eternally. This is what is meant.'"*

*"The Dao is vast without exclusion, minute without omission, so celestial phenomena, terrestrial geography, and human affairs all harmonize."*

**Newly Revised Text:** This passage on the Dao overlaps with the text in *The Discourse on Perfecting the Teachings*.

The Emperor asked:
*"What does this mean?"*

Qìbó replied:
*"It is rooted in the positioning of *qi*. What aligns with Heaven is celestial phenomena; what aligns with Earth is terrestrial geography; what harmonizes with human *qi*’s transformations is human affairs. Thus, excess precedes Heaven’s time, deficiency lags behind it—this is called governance and response in virtue/power."*

*"The three yin and three yang govern Heaven and Earth, marking the rhythms of yin-yang generation and transformation—this is aligning with Heaven and Earth. The Five Movements reside centrally, governing the transformations of human *qi*—thus it is said to harmonize with human *qi*."*

*"Preceding and lagging behind"* refers to the timing of the governing *qi*’s transformations.

The Emperor asked:
*"How does the virtue/power of the Five Movements manifest in excess?"*

*"Excess"* means the seasonal *qi* is in surplus.

**Newly Revised Text:** The five transformations of excess are fully detailed in *The Great Canon of the Five Constants’ Governance*.

Qìbó replied:
*"When the Wood Movement is in excess, the wind-*qi* flows rampantly, and the Spleen-Earth receives evil. Because Wood is in surplus, Earth-*qi* is subdued and weakened. The people suffer from dysentery and undigested food, heaviness in the body, vexation, and distended intestines with abdominal fullness. This corresponds above to the Taixing Star [Jupiter]."*

*"Dysentery"* refers to food not digesting and exiting downward. *"Spleen deficiency"* causes food stagnation, heaviness, vexation, and abdominal distension with intestinal rumbling.

*"When the Wood seasonal *qi* is excessively strong, the Taixing Star’s light shines abnormally and lingers, and all its divisions bring calamity."*

**Newly Revised Text:** As the *Canon of Storing Qi According to Seasons* states:
*"When the Spleen is deficient, the abdomen is distended and the intestines rumble; dysentery occurs with undigested food. In severe cases, there is sudden anger, dizziness, and vertigo with head disorders."*

*"If the offense is extreme, it encounters Metal, causing self-harm."*

**Newly Revised Text:** As the *True Essence of the Jade Machine* states:
*"When the Liver pulse is in excess, it makes one prone to sudden anger, dizziness, and vertigo with head disorders. This is due to Liver excess, so this disease is not solely from Wood excess encountering Metal—Liver excess alone can also cause it."*

*"When the transforming *qi* does not govern and the generating *qi* acts alone, objects fly in the void, and grasses and trees are restless. In severe cases, they wither and fall, leading to flank pain and excessive vomiting. If the Surging Yang [Stomach pulse] is severed, death is untreatable. This corresponds above to the Taibai Star [Mercury]."*

*"In the years of the Yang phases, Wood surplus suppresses Earth, so it cannot govern all things. The generating *qi*—Wood *qi*—being in excess, acts alone in generation and transformation. Wind, not practicing virtue/power, moves without measure, causing objects in the void to fly and grasses and trees to be restless. If unrestrained, Metal overcomes it, leading to withering. Flank pain arises as Wood overcomes Earth. Surging Yang is the Stomach pulse. When Wood *qi* dominates and Earth *qi* is exhausted, death ensues. When Metal reverses and Taibai lingers abnormally, the corresponding stars are endangered."*

*"The calamity’s outbreak harms the eastern region. Internally in the body, the Spleen is first harmed—this is called ‘injuring the deceitful.’ As the *Book of Documents* says:*
*'Fullness invites loss.'"*

---
*(Annotations from previous section maintained: #12 生 → "generate," #14 识 → "perceive," #15 媾 → "conjoin," etc.)*

This is its kind.

○The newly corrected text states: Examine the three excess transformations here, saying that the celestial patterns have three examples: for Wood and Earth in motion, first mention the Yearly Viceroy, then the stars that overcome it; for Fire and Metal in motion, first mention the Wandering Star and White Star, then the stars that overcome it, and finally mention the Wandering Star again; for Water in motion, first mention the Star of the Hour, then the Viceroy Star, and finally mention the Star of the Hour again, also showing the stars it overcomes.

When the Yearly Fire is excessive, scorching heat spreads, and the Metal of the Lung receives evil *qi*. Fire, not acting with virtue/power, then harms Metal, but if it acts with virtue/power, governance becomes harmonious. The people suffer from malaria, shortness of breath, coughing and wheezing, blood overflowing, blood discharge, and dysentery. Their throats become dry, their ears deaf, and they feel heat in their chests and backs.

This corresponds to the Wandering Star. Shortness of breath means insufficient *qi* to sustain breathing. Blood discharge means frequent bloody stools. Blood overflowing means blood issuing from the orifices. Dysentery means watery diarrhea. Chest heat refers to the thoracic region. The back, being the chamber of the chest, and the shoulders being adjacent, thus both chest and shoulders feel heat.

When Fire *qi* is excessively strong, the Wandering Star’s radiance reverses and invades, bringing calamity to all its host constellations.

○The newly corrected text states: Examine how excessive Fire overcomes Metal, causing cold and heat to contend, thus producing malaria. According to *The Treatise on the Hidden *Qi* and Its Laws*, lung diseases manifest as coughing and wheezing. When the Lung is deficient, there is shortness of breath, severe inability to speak, deafness, and dryness. There is pain in the chest, fullness and pain in the ribs, heat in the chest, back, and shoulders, and pain in the inner arms.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Treatise on the Hidden *Qi* and Its Laws*, heart diseases manifest as chest pain, rib fullness, lower rib pain, pain in the chest, back, shoulders, and scapulae, and pain in the inner arms. The body feels hot, bones ache, and dampness spreads.

Fire, lacking virtue/power, unleashes heat to harm Metal, while Water rises in rebellion, causing Fire to self-destruct.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The True Essence of the Jade Axle*, when the Heart pulse is excessive, it causes the body to feel hot and the skin to ache, resulting in dampness spreading. Here, "bone pain" is erroneous.

When the *qi* of gathering is blocked and the *qi* of lengthening prevails alone, rain, water, frost, and cold arise. Now, "water" should be corrected to "ice." This corresponds to the Star of the Hour. When Metal *qi* retreats and Fire *qi* moves unchecked, Water *qi* restrains it, causing rain, hail, and widespread frost and cold that kill living things. Water rebelling against Fire, the celestial omen responds, the Star of the Hour reverses and ascends, and cold calamity strikes living things.

The Star of the Hour, when afflicted, will reach the southern region. Within the body, the Lung is first harmed, then the Heart is struck in return.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants*, rain, water, frost, and hail manifest as rain, ice, frost, and hail. It ascends to Minor Yin and Minor Yang, where Fire and Water conjoin, and Water and Spring interact, causing things to wither and dry up.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants*, the *Record of the Six Celestial Stems* states: In years of *wuzi* to *wuyu*, the Minor Yin is ascended; in years of *wuyin* and *wushen*, the Minor Yang is ascended. When ascended, both excess and deficiency are called celestial omens. The disease manifests as delirium, madness, and wild behavior, coughing, wheezing, and groaning, with severe blood overflow, discharge, and unceasing bleeding. If the Great Abyss pulse is severed, death is untreatable. This corresponds to the Wandering Star. These are the years of *wu*.

In *wuyu* and *wuzhi* years, Minor Yin ascends; in *wuyin* and *wushen* years, Minor Yang ascends—these are called the years of celestial omens. The Great Abyss is the Lung pulse. Fire overcomes Metal, hence death.

Fire, already excessive, is further inflamed by the ascending heat, with two Fires merging, thus the body withers. The Wandering Star invades in reverse, endangering all its host constellations.

○The newly corrected text states: Examine *wu* years of *wuchen* and *wuxu*, where the Greater Yang is seen—this is called the celestial punishment cycle. Thus, though it should flourish, it does not, causing the Fire transformation to falter, neither excessive nor deficient.

When the Yearly Earth is excessive, dampness spreads with the rain, and the Kidney Water receives evil *qi*. Earth, lacking virtue/power, thus behaves. The people suffer from abdominal pain, cold limbs, and a gloomy, discontented spirit. Their bodies feel heavy and they are troubled.

This corresponds to the Viceroy Star. Abdominal pain means pain in both the upper and lower abdomen. Cold limbs mean coldness in the feet. A discontented spirit is as if burdened by hidden sorrow. Earth assaults Water, the celestial omen responds, the Viceroy Star reverses and invades, and its host constellations suffer calamity.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Treatise on the Hidden *Qi* and Its Laws*, kidney diseases manifest as heaviness in the body. When the Kidney is deficient, there is pain in the upper and lower abdomen, cold limbs, and a discontented spirit. Severe cases lead to withered flesh, withered feet that cannot be lifted, difficulty walking, pain beneath the feet, fullness in the middle from drinking, reduced appetite, and inability to raise the limbs. The Spleen governs flesh and externally corresponds to the limbs, and its pulse arises from the tip of the big toe, following the inner side of the shinbone, then obliquely emerging to network the groin. Thus, the disease manifests as such.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Treatise on the Hidden *Qi* and Its Laws*, spleen diseases manifest as heaviness in the body and excessive hunger; withered flesh, withered feet that cannot be lifted, difficulty walking, and pain beneath the feet. Again, according to *The True Essence of the Jade Axle*, when the Spleen is excessive, it causes the limbs to be unable to rise.

When the hidden *qi* is suppressed and the transforming *qi* governs alone, springs surge and rivers overflow, dried marshes teem with fish, torrential winds and rains arrive, earthen banks collapse, and fish scales appear on land. The disease manifests as abdominal fullness, diarrhea, and intestinal groaning, with severe downward discharge. If the Great Ravine pulse is severed, death is untreatable.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Treatise on the Hidden *Qi* and Its Laws*, when the Spleen is deficient, the abdomen becomes full, the intestines groan, and there is diarrhea without proper digestion of food.

The excessive *Metal* of the Year of the *Stem* (甲) [i.e., the Year of the *Stem*-*Metal* cycle], when its *qi* flows rampantly, harms the *Liver*-*Wood*. Such is the violence of *Metal* in excess. The people suffer pain in the flanks beneath the breasts, in the lower abdomen near the navel, and within the pelvic bones. Their eyes turn red in the whites, their pain extends to the inner corners of the eyelids, and their ears lose their hearing.

The flanks refer to the region beneath the breasts on both sides. The lower abdomen refers to the area below the navel on both sides, within the pelvic bones. When the whites of the eyes turn red, it is called *赤目* (chì mù). Pain here refers to the inner corners of the eyelids. The inner corners of the eyelids are the roots of the four eyelid margins.

The *Metal* of the Year of the *Stem* [甲] corresponds to the *Year Star* (歲星). When *Metal* is excessive, it suppresses the *Water* hidden *qi*, and the *Wood* *qi* alone governs. Thus, the *Wood* overcomes the *Earth* and *Metal* is restored, leading to violent winds and rains, surging springs, and overflowing rivers. The withered marshes teem with fish, and when dampness is extreme, the winds further agitate it, causing earthen banks to collapse and fall. The collapse of earthen banks refers to walls crumbling, embankments toppling, and mountains crumbling into the earth. Overflowing rivers and surging springs, along with the flourishing of fish and aquatic creatures, result in their abundance appearing on land. The *Great Ravine* pulse [太溪] is the *Kidney* pulse. When *Earth* overpowers and the *Water* is severed, death ensues. If *Wood* comes to weaken *Earth*, the celestial omens are inauspicious, and when this aligns with its inherent seasonal affinity, it is indeed a cause for concern.

When the *Metal* season is excessively severe, the body feels heavy and oppressed, the chest aches and the pain draws the back, and the sides are distended and painful, extending to the lower abdomen. This corresponds to the celestial omen of the **Great White Star** [太白星].

If the *Metal* season has passed but its severity lingers, *Wood* is internally subdued and succumbs to pathogenic influence, giving rise to disease. When *Metal* dominates the heavens, the **Great White Star** [太白星] shines brightly, and if it aligns with the **Host Constellation** [宿属], the heart suffers calamity. The newly revised annotation states: According to the *Theory of Stored Qi Following the Seasons* [藏气法时论], those with *Liver* disease experience pain beneath both sides, extending to the lower abdomen. If the *Liver* is depleted, the eyes become dull and indistinct, and the ears hear nothing. Additionally, the *True Essence of Jade Machinery* [玉机真藏论] states: If the *Liver* pulse is weak, it causes chest pain that draws the back, and the sides become taut and distended. When severe, it leads to wheezing, coughing, and reverse *Qi* flow [逆气], shoulder and back pain, and ailments of the **Scrotum** [尸阴], thighs, knees, **Spleen** [脾], **End Organs** [腑], and feet. This corresponds to the celestial omen of the **Blazing Intruder Star** [荧惑星]. The *Fire* season restores equilibrium, and disease naturally arises. The heavens manifest these signs through the **Blazing Intruder Star** [荧惑星]. If it aligns with the **Host Constellation** [宿属] in reverse, this is indeed a cause for concern.

The newly revised annotation states: According to the *Theory of Stored Qi Following the Seasons* [藏气法时论], those with *Lung* disease experience wheezing, coughing, and reverse *Qi* flow [逆气], shoulder and back pain, spontaneous sweating, and pain in the **Scrotum** [尸阴], thighs, knees, **Spleen** [脾] extremities, **End Organs** [腑], and feet. When the season’s *Metal* *Qi* is harsh and its *Fire* *Qi* is weak, the *Wood* season’s *Qi* is suppressed, and the *Fire* season’s *Qi* alone thrives; or when the *Fire* season’s *Qi* fails to restrain the *Metal* *Qi*, and the *Metal* season’s *Qi* alone dominates, the *Earth* season’s *Qi* is stifled, and the *Earth* season’s *Qi* alone governs.

When the *Metal* season’s *Qi* is excessively severe, the **Scrotum** [尸阴] and **Kidney** [肾] are affected. The newly revised annotation states: According to the *Theory of Stored Qi Following the Seasons* [藏气法时论], those with *Kidney* disease experience abdominal distension and **channel** swelling [经肿], wheezing, coughing, and body heaviness, nighttime sweating, and aversion to wind. When the *Metal* season’s *Qi* is excessively severe and undergoes five transformations, the *Wood* season’s *Qi* fails to govern its own season, and the *Fire* season’s *Qi* alone thrives; or when the *Fire* season’s *Qi* cannot restrain the *Metal* season’s *Qi*, and the *Metal* season’s *Qi* alone shines brightly; or when the *Earth* season’s *Qi* is stifled, and the *Earth* season’s *Qi* alone governs...

When the *Metal* season’s *Qi* is excessively severe, the **Scrotum** [尸阴] and **Kidney** [肾] are affected. The newly revised annotation states: According to the *Theory of Stored Qi Following the Seasons* [藏气法时论], those with *Kidney* disease experience abdominal distension and **channel** swelling [经肿], wheezing, coughing, nighttime sweating, and aversion to wind.

In severe cases, the *Metal* season’s *Qi* is so sharp that the **Kidney** *Qi* descends, while the *Water* season’s *Qi* alone thrives, and the **Earth** season’s *Qi* loses governance. The line “今独亡者” is missing text—likely an error.

When great rains arrive, dust and mist grow thick and hazy. This corresponds above to the **Zhen** star [辰星]. If the *Water* season’s *Qi* remains excessive, the **Earth** season’s *Qi* will overpower it, so this sign appears: dust and mist thicken, revealing the **Earth** season’s *Qi*.

The **Kidney**’s **channel** [脉] ascends from the sole, passes through the abdomen, and from the kidneys, pierces the liver and diaphragm, entering the lungs, then follows the throat. Thus, this disease arises.

The **Kidney** is *yin*, so nighttime sweating and aversion to wind occur. Sweating while sleeping is the disease itself.

When the **Earth** season’s *Qi* prevails, it weakens the *Water* season’s excess, so the **Zhen** star [辰星] shines brightly, manifesting its correspondence. If the **Earth** season’s *Qi* dominates in the **Taiyang** [太阳] region, ice, snow, and frost descend untimely, and dampness alters substances.

The newly revised annotation states: According to the *Great Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance* [五常政大论], in the **Taiyang** region, the *Water* season’s *Qi* spreads upward, and the **Earth** season’s *Qi* fails to transform.

Again, the *Great Treatise on the Six Elements’ True Sequence* [六元正纪大论] states: In the years of **Jingchen** [丙辰] and **Jingxu** [丙戌], the *Water* season’s *Qi* ascends into the **Taiyang** region. When the *Water* season’s *Qi* is either excessive or deficient, it is called a **Heavenly Omen** [天符].

The disease reverses to abdominal fullness and intestinal rumbling, **undigested food** [飧泄] and failure to assimilate food. The newly revised annotation states: According to the *Theory of Stored Qi Following the Seasons* [藏气法时论], if the **Spleen** [脾] is depleted, abdominal fullness and intestinal rumbling occur, **undigested food** [飧泄] appears, and food fails to assimilate.

With thirst and **false perception** [妄冒], when the **Spirit Gate** [神门] is cut off, death is inevitable—no cure. This corresponds above to **Yinghuo** [荧惑] and the **Zhen** star [辰星]. All these signs appear in the **Jing** years [丙岁].

The **Jing** years [丙辰、丙戌]—when **Taiyang** [太阳] *Qi* ascends above—are called the **Heavenly Omen** [天符] years.

When the **Cold** *Qi* [寒气] is excessive, rain transforms into ice and snow, and when ice forms, it becomes **hail** [雹]. If frost descends untimely, it reveals the **Cold**’s severity.

When **Earth** [土] restores its **Water** [水], there is prolonged heavy rain—**congealed rain** [霖霪]. With deep internal **Humidity** *Qi* [湿气], all things become damp and altered.

The **Spirit Gate** [神门]—the **Heart**’s pulse [心脉]—when **Water** *Qi* is excessive and **Fire** *Qi* is depleted, death ensues. When **Water** *Qi* is excessive and **Fire** *Qi* is strong, **Yinghuo** [荧惑] blazes fiercely, and the **Zhen** star [辰星] shines brightly. If this is compounded by **inverse control of the lodging** [逆守宿], the outcome is perilous—**danger of extinction** [危亡].

○ The newly revised annotation states: Examining the **Five Phases** [五化] in terms of excess, it is recorded that **Fire** and **Water** *Qi* ascending above are the **Heavenly Omens** [天符]. **Fire** ascending upon **Fire** and **Water** ascending upon **Water** are both **Heavenly Omens** [天符].

**Fire** ascending upon **Water** is **inverse** [逆], **Water** ascending upon **Wood** is **harmonious** [顺], **Fire** ascending upon **Earth** is **harmonious** [顺], **Water** ascending upon **Earth** is **Earth overcoming Heaven** [运胜天], **Fire** ascending upon **Metal** is **Heavenly Punishment overcoming the cycle** [天刑运], and **Water** ascending upon **Metal** is **inverse** [逆]. The remaining cases are not detailed here. Again, this text only mentions the **Yinghuo** and **Zhen** stars as examples, but the rest can be inferred accordingly.

The Emperor said: *"Well said."* [善]

When the **Five Phases** are deficient, what then?

It is said: *"The governance and transformations are insufficient."* [政化少]

○ *Newly Corrected Version* notes: The deficiencies of the **Five Phases** are fully detailed in *"The Great Treatise on the Five Constant Governances"* [《五常政大论》].

**Ghibol** [岐伯] replied: *"Your inquiry is thorough indeed!* When the **Year Phase of Wood** is deficient, the **Dryness** [燥] phase prevails greatly. The **Clear and Resonant** [清玲] winds arrive on time, accompanied by a slight chill—this is called **Dryness Qi** [燥气]. **Dryness** is the essence of **Metal Qi** [金气].

When the **Generative Qi** [生气] fails to respond, grasses and trees flourish late, which is called *"losing their appointed time"* [后时之谓失应]. When **Austerity and Killing** [肃杀] are extreme, the **rigid Wood** [刚木] splits and cracks, the **soft Wood** [柔] withers, turning **ashen-green** [苍] and dry—this corresponds above to the **Tai Bai Star** [太白星].

The **Heaven and Earth** grow mournful, the sun appears dimmed, with rain that is not rain and clear skies that are not clear. The people’s spirits grow despondent, the atmosphere thickens and contracts—this is when **Austerity and Killing** are extreme.

**Rigid** [刚] means **unyielding and hard** [劲硬].
**Splitting and cracking** [辟着] refers to the branches and stems splitting and drying without falling.
**Soft** [柔] means **pliant**.
**Ashen-green** [苍] means **green**—the leaves of the soft Wood turn a fixed green while drying and curling.

When the **Wood Qi** is deficient, **Metal Qi** overpowers it, and the brilliance of **Tai Bai** shines with radiant light across the void.

The people suffer from **central coldness** [中清], **flank and rib pain** [肪胁痛], **lower abdominal pain** [少腹痛], **intestinal rumbling and diarrhea** [肠呜塘泄], and **freezing rain** arrives on time—this corresponds above to the **Tai Bai Star**.

○ *Newly Corrected Version* notes: Regarding the deficiencies of the **Five Phases**, the people’s ailments and their corresponding stars are all described as *"the Running Stars losing their luster"* [运星失色], *"the Fear Stars pressing upon them"* [畏星加临], and *"the Hosts bringing calamity"* [宿属为灾]. Here, only the **Fear Star** is mentioned, without the **Running Star**, due to an omission in the original text. It should read: *"corresponding above to the **Tai Bai Star** and the **Sui Star**"* [上应太白星、岁星].

The grains turn **ashen-green** [苍].

The **Metal qi** overacting upon **Wood**—this is the disease of the **Liver**.
Those who are overborne by this **qi** will have **rumbling in the intestines** and **diarrhea**, yet will lack **flank and rib pain** or **lower abdominal pain**.
In mild cases, it will abate; in severe cases, it will cease. When **Summer’s qi** arrives, it will also cease, but when **Autumn’s qi** comes, it will recur.
The **cool rain** arrives on time—meaning it comes when it should, for **Metal and Earth** harmonize in their transformations, so **freezing rain** follows together.
When **Fire qi** returns, **Summer rain** diminishes.

When **Metal** overcomes **Wood**, the **Tai Bai Star** descends upon it, and all its **host constellations** bring calamity.
If **Metal** dominates the entire year, **Fire qi** does not return, and thus the **ashen-green grains** will not bear fruit.

○ *Newly Corrected Version* notes: Examining **central coldness**, **flank and rib pain**, and **lower abdominal pain** as the signs of **Metal overacting upon Wood**—the **Liver’s** disease.
**Intestinal rumbling and diarrhea** are the symptoms of **Spleen** disease.
For when **Wood is deficient**, the **Spleen-Earth** lacks restraint, and in arrogance, it receives **Pathogenic Evil** instead.
When **Yangming** ascends above, **Generative qi** loses its governance, and **grass and trees** bloom again.
The **transformative qi** grows urgent, corresponding above to the **Tai Bai** and **Zhen Stars**, which govern the **early ashen-green**.
These are the **Ding years**—**Dingmao** and **Dingyou**—when **Yangming** ascends above, known as the **"Heavenly Punishment"** years.
**Metal qi**, obeying **Heaven**, dominates below and overcomes **Wood**, so **Generative qi** loses its governance, and **grass and trees** bloom again.
When **Generative qi** loses its governance, **Wood’s** blossoms open late.
**Metal** suppresses **Wood**, so **Autumn and Summer** begin to flourish, and fruits mature early due to the urgency of the **transformative qi**, thus completing their growth late.
When **Metal** overcomes **Wood**, **Heaven** responds in kind, so the **Tai Bai Star** appears with radiant brilliance.
Since **Wood qi** is scarce and **Earth qi** lacks restraint, the **transformative qi** grows and matures rapidly.
When **Wood is deficient** and **Metal prevails**, **Heaven’s qi** aligns, so the **Zhen Star**, along with **Tai Bai**, becomes both **moist and luminous**.
Ashen-green things wither and fall early, for **Wood is deficient** and **Metal** overacts.

○ *Newly Corrected Version* notes: Regarding the deficiencies of the **Five Phases**, only **Wood ascending upon Yangming**, **Earth ascending upon Jueyin**, and **Water ascending upon Taiyin** are recorded, omitting **Wood ascending upon Jueyin**, **Earth ascending upon Taiyin**, and **Metal ascending upon Yangming**, for the text records only the most extreme cases.
Thus, in **excess cycles**, only **"Fire upon Fire"** and **"Water upon Water"** are mentioned.
Here, in **deficient cycles**, only **"Wood upon Metal"**, **"Earth upon Wood"**, and **"Water upon Earth"** are recorded.
Hence, it does not mention **"Jueyin upon Wood"**, **"Taiyin upon Earth"**, or **"Yangming upon Metal"**.

When **Fire** returns to **Metal**, scorching heat flows, and the **damp nature** turns dry, causing tender and fragile plants to wither and die.
The lower growths regenerate, and **blossoms and fruits** transform together.
Diseases of **chill, fever, sores, ulcers, numbness, miscarriage, and paralysis** arise, corresponding above to **Hengxing** and **Tai Bai Stars**, and the grains become **white and hard**.

When **Fire** returns to **Metal**, **Summer’s great heat** emerges, so all things’ **damp nature** shifts to dryness.
The **scorching Fire** consumes them, so tender plants, creeping vines, and sprawling growths all **wither and die above**, while their lower parts regenerate.
If they are **hot and pungent grasses**, they will not regenerate.
With **mild heat**, few die; with **great heat**, many perish.
When the **Fire’s return** has passed, **Earth qi** arrives, and **freezing rain** descends.
The **sour, bitter, sweet, and salty**—those of **cold nature**—then regenerate anew, and the **newly opened** and the **previously formed** mature together under the **transformative qi**.
When **Fire** returns to **Metal**, the **Tai Bai Star** blazes, and **Hengxing** ascends above, its light overflowing and its **host constellations** bringing calamity.

Because **Fire** reverses its course, the **white and hard grains** sprout but do not bear fruit.
**White Dew** descends early, and the **Killing qi** spreads, as **cold rain** harms the plants.
**Insects** consume the **sweet and yellow** crops, and the **Spleen-Earth** receives **Pathogenic Evil**.
The **red qi** transforms late, the **Heart qi** governs tardily, and **Metal’s white qi** is subdued, so the grains do not mature.
There is **coughing and sighing**, corresponding above to **Hengxing** and **Tai Bai Stars**.

When **Yangming** ascends above, **Metal** takes its course, so **White Dew** descends early.
When **cold and chill** arrive greatly, the **Killing qi** spreads.
Since **Taiyang** resides in the **Earth-damp** position, **cold and damp** combine, so **cold rain** harms the plants, reducing their yield.
**Metal** moves to subdue **Wood**, borrowing the path through **Earth**, for **Child** is within **Mother**—the **insect symbol**.
Thus, **sweet and yellow** things are eaten by **insects and grubs**.
**Cool qi** prevails first, then **heat qi** returns, and when it returns, it prevails again, so the **red Fire qi** transforms late.
**"Red transforms late"** means that **red blossoms** and **red fruits** bloom and mature again at a later time.
As for the **Five Zang**, the **Heart qi** reigns late, overcoming the **Lungs**, so when the **Heart** overcomes the **Lungs**, **Metal’s white qi** is subdued and retreats.
**Metal grains**—**rice**—are affected.
**Cruel**—nasal discharge—occurs.
When **Fire** overcomes **Metal**, **Heaven’s symbols** respond in kind, so the **Tai Bai Star’s** rays dim, while **Hengxing** grows brighter.

When **Fire is deficient** and **Water prevails**, **cold** spreads greatly, and the **Long Official** does not govern.
Things grow **low and stunted**, their **vitality suppressed and severe**, so **Yang qi** fails to transform, and their **blossoms wither**.
This corresponds above to the **Chen Star**.

The people suffer from **chest pain**, **flank distension**, **bilateral rib pain**, **pain in the chest, back, shoulders, scapulae, and inner arms**.
○ *Newly Corrected Version* notes: These symptoms align with the signs of **Fire excess**, even to the point of **reverse disease**, as seen in the *Zangqi Fashishu Lun*.

They experience **obscured confusion**, **sudden heart pain**, **violent sores**, **distended chest and abdomen**, and **pain in the flanks and lower back radiating to each other**.
○ *Newly Corrected Version* notes: According to the *Zangqi Fashishu Lun*, when the **Heart is empty**, the **chest and abdomen distend**, and **pain in the flanks and lower back radiates to each other**.
In severe cases, they cannot straighten, and their **hips** feel as if **separated**.
This corresponds above to **Hengxing** and **Chen Stars**, and the grains become **crimson**.
These are the **Gui years**.

The breath stirs, for its pulse moves thus. When **Fire-qi** does not circulate, **Cold-qi** restrains and solidifies, the hips feel as if separated, and bending is impossible.

When **Water** overpowers **Fire**, **Hengxing** dims its brilliance, the **crimson grains** fail to ripen, and **Chen Star** invades its host’s division—then all bring calamity.

When **Eclipse** looms, dust clouds gather, and great rain is near, **Black-qi** brings humiliation. The sick suffer **startled fright**, **diarrhea**, **abdominal distension**, and **inability to eat or drink**. **Cold invades the intestines**, causing **rumbling**, **diarrhea**, and **abdominal pain**. Sudden **spasms**, **atrophy**, and **paralysis** strike, leaving the feet unable to bear the body—corresponding above to **Zhen Star** and **Chen Star**, and the **playthorn grains** failing to form.

**Eclipse** and clouded rain are the **Earth’s** work. **Cold-qi**, further split by **Dampness**, seeps inward, giving rise to **abdominal ailments** and **heaviness of the body**—thus the symptoms.

**Black-qi** is **Water-qi**. **Humiliation** means **subjugation**. **Capon** (音木) refers to the **duck**.

When **Earth** eclipses **Water**, **Zhen Star** shines moist and luminous, invading its host’s division—then the people suffer sickness and disaster.

The year’s Earth-qi is insufficient, so the Wind grows rampant.
The transforming *qi* does not act in order, and grasses and trees flourish luxuriantly,
yet they sway wildly without bearing fruit—corresponding above to the **Jupiter Star**.
Wood lacks *virtue*.
When Wood-*qi* acts alone, the transforming *qi* does not proceed in order.
When the vital *qi* monopolizes, grasses and trees flourish luxuriantly.
Their wild swaying is Wood’s lack of *virtue*.
Earth-*qi* is thin and scarce, so things fail to mature.
"Unfruitful" refers to *píwù* (枇恶).

When Earth is insufficient, Wood overpowers it,
so Jupiter’s appearance is moist and luminous, invading its host’s division.
The people suffer **diarrhea, dysentery, and cholera**,
with **body heaviness, abdominal pain, trembling tendons and bones, aching muscles, irritability**,
and **latent *qi* acting violently**, **parasites attaching early**—all falling ill with **cold invasion**.
Above, it corresponds to **Jupiter and Zhen Star**, and the grains **fail to form**.
These are the **years of *ji* (己)**.
When Wind invades the **crown**, the illnesses are as described.
Earth-*qi* being insufficient, Water aligns with its transformation,
so latent *qi* acts violently, and parasites attach early to where **Yang-*qi* resides**,
and all fall ill with **cold invasion diseases**.

*Yáo* (繇) means **to tremble**.
When tendons and bones tremble, it is called *xìngfú* (县复), then *sūnfú* (孙复).
Earth, suppressed and unable to stretch,
if Jupiter invades its host’s division, all suffer disaster.

Worms consume sweet and bitter foods, *qi* invades the Spleen,
grain production decreases, the people eat little and lose taste,
and *cānggǔ* (苍谷) is diminished.
Metal restrains Wood, so trees wither and turn black.
Metal enters Earth—**mother containing child**—
so sweet and bitter foods are consumed by worms.
Metal entering Earth causes *qi* to invade the Spleen.
When Metal-*qi* arrives in force, it clashes with Earth,
so grain production diminishes, and grains fail to form.
Above, it corresponds to **Venus and Jupiter**.
Venus’s rays flourish, and Jupiter’s light diminishes.

When it governs **Jueyin**, flowing water does not freeze,
parasites appear early, latent *qi* does not act,
and White (Venus) does not return—corresponding above to Jupiter,
and the people recover.
In **ji-sì (己巳) and ji-hài (己亥) years**, Jueyin governs above,
and *shàoyáng* (少阳) is at the spring,
Fire presiding over Earth, so parasites appear early,
and flowing water does not freeze.
Metal cannot return, so Jupiter’s appearance is normal,
and the people are healthy and free of illness.

illness arising from receiving heat evil.

Fire first prevails, so constipation occurs later.

and if Mars retrogrades and guards,
the host’s division all suffer illness.

then **hail and sleet descend**, frost and snow kill growth,
**Yin-jue** strikes, and **Yang reverses upward**,
causing **head and brain-door pain**, extending to the crown,

When the *bùjí* (不及) cycle governs,
the conquering *qi* prevails, and the **child-*qi* returns**—

**governance** (政) and **decree** (令),
**alteration** (变) and **disaster** (灾),

**Virtue, transformation, governance, and decree** (德化政令) are the **harmonious qi** (和气).
Their **dynamic and static dominance** (动静胜复) is applied to all things,
giving rise to all life and growth.
**Alteration and disaster** (变与灾) are the **killing qi** (杀气).
Their effects are **sudden and swift** (暴速),
their movements **abrupt and urgent** (骤急),
their course **harmful and injurious** (损伤).
Though they are the natural **dynamic and static operations of Heaven and Earth** (天地自为动静之用),
some things cannot withstand their movements,
and thus suffer damage, sickness, and death.

The Emperor said:

Gebi (岐伯) replied:

When they move suddenly, it is the **interaction of the qi** (气之交变),

Thus it is said: *'Respond to the constant, not the sudden.'*
This is what is meant.

**Virtue, transformation, governance, and decree** (德化政令) are the **constant qi** (气之常).
**Disasters, misfortunes, alterations, and changes** (灾眚变易) arise when the **qi interact suddenly and overcome one another** (气卒交会而有胜负者).
The **constant** (常) refers to the **four seasons of the year**, whose qi do not deviate by even a moment.
The **unconstant** (不常) is **brief**.

*"How do these calamities manifest?"*

**Gēbó** replied:
*"They follow their **qi transformations**—
thus, at their appointed times, there is **flourishing and decline**,
**transgressions** have **order or disorder**,
**retention and stagnation** vary in duration,
their **manifest forms** are **good or evil**,
their **constellational affiliations** bring **victory or defeat**,
and their **verifications** bring **auspice or misfortune**.*

When the **Five Stars** arrive,
their **sovereign** reigns in **flourishing**,
their **captivity or death** marks **decline**.

**Eastward transgression** is **orderly**, with **light calamity**.
**Westward transgression** is **disorderly**, with **grave calamity**.

**Retention** lasting many days brings **deep calamity**,
few days bring **shallow calamity**.

When a star **delights in moisture**, it is **auspicious**;
when it **rages in dryness and sorrow**, it is **malevolent**.

**Constellational affiliation** refers to the **monthly host** of the **Twenty-Eight Lunar Mansions**,
and the **Twelve Earthly Branches**, divided by their **assigned positions**.

If the **commanding star** is **conquered**, there is **no calamity or harm**.
If it is **not conquered**, the calamity is **light or grave**.
If the **commanding star** aligns with the **luminaries**, though calamity arises, there is **no harm**.

**Calamity** refers to **litigation, illness, and misfortune**.

Even when the **Five Stars transgress**,
if they coincide with the **captivity or death** of the **luminaries** in that **month**,
though calamity looms, it **does not manifest**.

Yet—
when **Fire** transgresses in **retention and disorderly arrival**,
there is **fear of false accusations and litigation**.
When **Metal** transgresses,
there is **fear of executions and stagnant **qi****.
When **Wood** transgresses,
there is **fear of tremors and gusting winds**.
When **Earth** transgresses,
there is **fear of internal blockage, diarrhea, and edema**.
When **Water** transgresses,
there is **fear of cold **qi** striking the body**.

Thus, it is said: *"Their verifications bring **auspice or misfortune**."*

The Emperor asked:
*"What constitutes their **good or evil**?"*

**Gēbó** replied:
*"There is **joy and anger**, **sorrow and mourning**,
**moisture and dryness**—
these are the **constant omens**.
They must be **scrutinized with care**.*

When the **Five Stars** appear,
they are seen **deep into the night**.
If people **rejoice** upon seeing them, the stars **rejoice**.
If people **fear** them, the stars **rage**.

When their **light is faint and flickering**—
now bright, now dim—
the stars **mourn**.

When their **light is distant and indistinct**,
neither clear nor luminous,
unlike the others—
the stars **are in mourning**.

When their **light is round and clear**,
neither full nor diminished,
serene and luminous—
the stars **rejoice**.

When their **light blazes fiercely upon people**,
with **radiant halos overflowing**,
their **omen is stern**—
the stars **rage**.

**Moisture** is **abundant dampness**.
**Dryness** is **parched withering**.

The Emperor asked:
*"Do these **six omens** differ by **elevation**?"*

**Gēbó** replied:
*"Though the **omens** appear high or low,
their **verifications** are the same.
Thus, people also respond accordingly.*

Observing **omens and colors**,
the **internal and external verifications** of **human and Heaven**
are in harmony."

The Emperor said:
*"Excellent."*

*"How do the **virtue, transformations, governance, and orders** move—
their **stability, motion, depletion, or augmentation**?"*

**Gēbó** replied:
*"**Virtue and transformation**, **governance and calamity**—
these cannot **compound upon one another**.
**Heaven and Earth** move and rest,
**yin and yang** ebb and flow,
**virtue** answers **virtue**,
**transformation** answers **transformation**,
**governance and calamity** likewise—
thus, it is said they **cannot compound**.

**Victory and decline** cannot **exceed their measure**.
When **victory is strong**, it **remains strong**;
when **victory is weak**, it **remains weak**—
**flourishing does not answer decline**,
**transformation does not answer change**—
thus, it is said they **cannot exceed**.

**Coming and going**, **great and small**—
they **cannot surpass**.
The **days of victory and response**,
whether **many or few**, are **equal**—
thus, it is said they **cannot surpass**.

Their **application in ascent and descent**—
they **cannot be absent**.
**Wood’s conquest** is answered by **Metal’s submission**,
**Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water** likewise—
there has never been **conquest without response**—
thus, **qi cannot make one another absent**.

Each follows its **movement and response**.
**Movement** has its **response**—
**response** is discerned through **movement**.
*The Classic of Changes* says:
*'Auspice, misfortune, regret, and caution arise from **movement**.'*
This is what is meant.

Though **Heaven is high** and **unfathomable**,
though **Earth is vast** and **unmeasurable**—
speaking of **qi’s movement and response**,
it is as **easily observed as the palm of one’s hand**."

The Emperor said:
*"How do these **diseases** arise?"*

**Gēbó** replied:
*"**Virtue and transformation** are the **auspicious signs of qi**,
**governance and orders** are the **manifestations of qi**,
**change and response** are the **frameworks of return**,
**calamity** is the **beginning of injury**.

When **qi** conquers in **harmony**, there is **health**;
when it **does not conquer**, there is **disease**;
when **evil influences** strike repeatedly, the **illness is severe**."

**Auspicious**—**favorable response**.
**Manifestation**—**measure, standard**.
**Framework of return**—the **principles of response**.
**Repeatedly struck**—when **annual qi** is already **deficient**,
and **Heaven’s qi** brings **conquering and killing**—
this is called **repeatedly struck**.
**Repeated**—**layered accumulation**.

The Emperor said:
*"Excellent."*

The discussion of **精光** (refined luminosity) is the work of the **Great Sage** (Great Sage’s endeavor),
to proclaim the **Great Dao/Way** (Great Dao),
to penetrate the **limitless** (without end),
and to fathom the **ultimate** (without extreme).

I have heard that:
those who speak well of **Heaven** (Heaven) must correspond with **humanity** (humanity),
those who speak well of **ancient times** (the ancient) must be verified in **the present** (today),
those who speak well of **qi** (qi) must be evident in **all things** (phenomena),
those who speak well of **response** (response) align with the **transformations of Heaven and Earth** (Heaven and Earth’s changes),
and those who speak well of **transformation and response** (change and response)
penetrate the **principles of the divine and luminous** (divine and luminous logic).

Who else could articulate the **Dao/Way of the utmost** (ultimate Dao) but the **Master** (Master)?

Excess or deficiency—
the **annual transformations** (yearly changes) are endless,
the **interactions of qi** (qi’s exchanges) shift and transform,
flowing into the **ultimate** (without extreme).

Yet **Heaven displays its signs** (Heaven’s symbols descend),
and the **Sage observes them** (Sages follow them)
to discern **auspicious and inauspicious** (fortune and calamity).

How so?
When the **annual qi** (yearly qi) is excessive,
the **stars** (celestial bodies) become **prominent or bright and clear** (greatly luminous or translucent),
and when the **annual qi** (yearly qi) is deficient,
the **stars** (celestial bodies) grow **dim or lose their color** (small or colorless).
Thus, **auspicious and inauspicious** (fortune and calamity) can be **indicated and seen** (pointed out and observed).

What does **auspicious and inauspicious** (fortune and calamity) refer to?
It is because **all things** (phenomena) receive the **five constant qi** (Five Constant Qi)
to grow and form,
and they all **respond above** (ascend to correspond),
either **favorable** (affirmative) or **unfavorable** (negative).
Hence, it is said: **auspicious and inauspicious are thus supremely evident** (fortune and calamity are truly profound).

Therefore, it is said:
those who speak well of **Heaven** (Heaven) must also correspond with **humanity** (humanity).
The **Dao/Way of antiquity** (ancient Dao) is spoken,
and **the present** (today) **verifies it** (responds to it).
Thus, it is said:
those who speak well of **ancient times** (the ancient) must also be verified in **the present** (today).

The **transformative qi** (transformative qi) generates and forms—
all **things** (phenomena) receive it.
Thus, when speaking of **qi’s response** (qi’s response),
the **Sage clarifies it through phenomena** (evidence from things).
Hence, it is said:
those who speak well of **response** (response) must also be evident in **all things** (phenomena).

**Evident**—**clear** (manifestation, clear).
The **response of transformative qi** (qi’s transformative response)
is like the **four seasons** (Four Seasons) in their regular course,
all **things** (phenomena) fully manifest.
Thus, those who speak well of **response** (response)
must also **align with Heaven and Earth’s creation and transformation** (conform to Heaven and Earth’s changes).

When **things** (phenomena) **emerge**, it is called **transformation** (change),
and when **things** (phenomena) **reach their limits**, it is called **response** (variation).
To speak of **all things’ transformations and responses** (change and response)
from beginning to end
is to **harmonize with the divine and luminous operations** (conform to the divine and luminous logic).
Thus, those who speak well of **transformation and response** (change and response)
penetrate the **principles of the divine and luminous** (divine and luminous logic).

The **Sage’s wisdom** (Sage’s knowledge) encompasses all **things** (phenomena),
omitting nothing.
Thus, when speaking of **auspicious signs** (auspicious signs),
even the slightest **movement** (stirring) **responds without fail** (does not go unanswered).

Then, the **Sage selects the finest auspices** (good omens)
and **stores them in the sacred chamber** (sacred chamber),
reading them each morning,
and names it **"Qi’s Transformations"** (Qi’s Exchanges and Changes).
He **does not dare reveal them** (open them) without **fasting and purification** (ritual abstinence),
and **transmits them with great care** (cautious transmission).

**Sacred chamber**—the **Hall of Auspicious Orchids** (Hall of Auspicious Orchids),
the **repository of Yellow Emperor’s writings** (Yellow Emperor’s library).

*Newly corrected version states:
Upon careful examination, this text aligns with the conclusion of the* **Six Elements and True Records on the Great Dao** (*Six Elemental Cycles and Rectified Records on the Great Dao*).

**Five Constant Principles on Grand Governance (Upper Section)**
*Newly Revised Annotation:* This chapter comprehensively discusses the Five Phases (Wǔ Rùn), distinguishing between balanced *qi*, deficiency, and excess. It then addresses geographical variations—four directions, elevation, and yin-yang contrasts. It further explains how some years may lack disease despite imbalanced organ-*qi*, attributing this to the Heavenly *qi*’s dominance and its directional influences. The text then elaborates on the Six *Qi* and Five Categories’ mutual regulation and victory, explaining why some years yield no conception despite favorable conditions. Finally, it clarifies the Six *Qi*’s seasonal transformations, the varying thickness of the Five Flavors, and concludes with therapeutic principles.

This chapter’s title, *Five Constant Principles on Grand Governance*, emphasizes its foundational themes.

**The Yellow Emperor asked:**
“The Great Void is vast and boundless. The Five Phases revolve and intermingle, waxing and waning in cycles, their excesses and deficiencies following one another. I wish to understand: What constitutes balanced *qi* in name and in its governing principle?”

**Qī Bó replied:**
“Your question is luminous! When the Wood Phase is *fūhé* (enveloping harmony), its *hé* (harmonious) *qi* spreads, and all things flourish in vitality. When the Fire Phase is *shēngmíng* (ascending luminosity), its radiant *qi* ascends, illuminating all. When the Earth Phase is *bèihuà* (comprehensive transformation), its pervasive transformative *qi* nourishes all, yet slightly diminishes their vitality. When the Metal Phase is *shěnpíng* (precise equilibrium), its crisp *qi* settles, bringing stability. When the Water Phase is *jìngshùn* (tranquil compliance), its clear essence flows in accordance with all things.”

**The Emperor asked:**
“What of deficiency?”

**Qī Bó replied:**
“When Wood is *wěihé* (submissive harmony), its yang-harmonious *qi* is constrained and underutilized. When Fire is *fúmíng* (concealed luminosity), its radiant *qi* is suppressed and does not manifest. When Earth is *bēijiān* (humble oversight), though meager, it still oversees all things’ transformations. When Metal is *cónggé* (compliant revolution), it follows and adapts, solidifying all things. When Water is *hèliú* (dry flow), its scarcity causes its currents to wither.”

**The Emperor asked:**
“What constitutes excess?”

**Qī Bó replied:**
“When Wood is *fāshēng* (proliferating vitality), its expansive *qi* causes all things to flourish. When Fire is *hèxī* (flaming radiance), its brilliance is extreme. When Earth is *dūnfù* (thick and elevated), *dūn* meaning ‘thick,’ *fù* meaning ‘high,’ its surplus *qi* makes it both lofty and dense. When Metal is *jiānchéng* (firm completion), its crisp *qi* and strong winds solidify all things. When Water is *liúyǎn* (overflowing), *yǎn* meaning ‘accompanying’ or ‘spilling,’ its excess floods.”

**The Emperor asked:**
“I wish to hear the governing principles of these three *qi* states.”

**Qī Bó replied:**
“Your inquiry is exhaustive! *Newly Revised Annotation:* This discussion aligns with *The Grand Theory of the Five Phases’ Movement*, *The Great Correspondence of Yin-Yang*, and *The Golden Chamber’s True Statements*.

When Wood is *fūhé* (enveloping harmony), its governance follows the Wood Phase’s complete cycle: yang expands, yin disperses, and the Five Transformations unfold evenly. Each *qi* governs its designated region without conflict, so the Five *qi*’s transformations issue their decrees across the four directions without intrusion.

*Newly Revised Annotation:* According to Wang Bing’s notes, excess and deficiency each correspond to specific years and branches. This section describes a balanced Wood Phase, omitting year/branch markers because balanced-*qi* years cannot be fixed by such cycles. Some might argue to add, e.g., *Ding-sì*, *Ding-hài*, *Rén-yín*, or *Rén-shēn* years, but this reflects misunderstanding.

Its essence is *duān* (straightforward, adorned), its nature *suí* (compliant), its application both *qū* (curved) and *zhí* (straight), accommodating all uses. Its transformation fosters *shēngróng* (vital flourishing), as Wood’s expansive *qi* makes all things lush and beautiful. Its category includes grasses and trees—Wood’s body is firm and towering, while grasses are lowly, yet each exhibits variations in rigidity, flexibility, and structure. Its governance is *fāsàn* (dispersive), as spring’s expansive *qi* nurtures all things into growth, embodying Wood’s transformation. Its season is *wēnhé* (temperate harmony), *hé* being spring’s *qi*. Its decree is *fēng* (wind), as Wood’s governance manifests in gentle breezes. Its organ is the liver, its *qi* aligning with hepatic energy. The liver fears *qīng* (clearing), for Wood’s nature is *xuān* (warm), and it thus dreads Metal’s crispness. As *The Grand Theory of the Five Phases’ Movement* states: ‘Wood’s nature is *xuān*.’ It further notes: ‘Dryness overcomes wind.’ Its sense is the eyes, as yang’s ascent and clarity align with vision. Its grain is *má* (hemp), its hue *cāng* (sage-green). *Newly Revised Annotation:* *The Golden Chamber’s True Statements* lists *mài* (wheat) instead.

Its fruit is the *lǐ* (plum), its flavor *suān* (sour), its seed containing a hard pit. Its correspondence is spring, as all four seasons share its transformative essence. Its creatures are *máo* (hairy insects), as Wood’s expansive *qi* nurtures their growth. Its livestock are *quǎn* (dogs), thriving without restraint like grasses and trees. *Newly Revised Annotation:* *The Golden Chamber’s True Statements* specifies *yào* (hawks) instead.

Its color is *cāng* (sage-green), as Wood’s transformation makes all things verdant. It nourishes *jīn* (tendons), for sour flavors enter the tendons. Its diseases manifest as *guǒjí zhī mǎn* (twisted, tense limbs and fullness), born of Wood’s *qi*. *Newly Revised Annotation:* *The Golden Chamber’s True Statements* clarifies: ‘Thus, one knows disease resides in the tendons.’

Its flavor is *suān* (sour), as Wood’s *fūhé* transformation thickens sourness in all things. Its tone is *jiǎo* (the 6th musical note), straight and resonant. Its forms are *zhōngjiān* (moderately firm), symbolizing Wood’s presence within Earth. Its numerical correspondence is *bā* (eight), the completed cycle.

The **Rise of Clarity’s** chronicle,
governs by the **True Sun** and **rules**,
with **virtue/power** bestowed universally—**equal** and **balanced**.
*Equal*: uniformity.
*Balanced*: equilibrium.

Its **qi** is **high**,
as **Fire** blazes upward.

Its **nature** is **rapid**,
for **Fire’s** disposition is **restless** and **swift**.
*Restless*: impulsive.
*Swift*: hasty.

Its **function** is **to scorch and burn**,
*Burn*: to sear.
*Scorch* and *burn* both belong to **Fire’s** function.

Its **transformation** is **luxuriant and flourishing**,
with **vitality** and **growth** abundant—
thus things become **great**.

Its **category** aligns with **Fire**,
for among the **Five Phases’ qi**,
it shares the same essence as **Fire**.

Its **administration** is **illuminating and radiant**,
as **virtue/power** harmonizes with **high clarity**—
the **rule** of **Fire**.

Its **seasonal sign** is **scorching heat**,
the **qi’s** arrival—
and thus it is discerned.

Its **command** is **heat**,
for when **heat** reaches its peak,
the **command** takes effect.

Its **residence** is the **Heart**,
as the **Heart’s qi** responds.
The **Heart** fears **cold**,
*Cold*: the **command** of **Water**.
The **Heart’s** disposition is **summer-heat** and **warmth**—
thus it fears **cold**.
*The Five Phases’ Grand Theory* states:
*The **Heart’s** disposition is **summer-heat***.
It further states:
*When **cold** overcomes **heat***.

Its **organ** is the **tongue**,
for **Fire** illuminates the **hidden**—
the **tongue** clarifies.

Its **grain** is **wheat**,
*Wheat*: its hue is **red**.
*Newly Revised Annotation*: *The Golden Chamber’s True Statements* specifies **millet** instead.
*Again, The Residence of Qi’s Seasonal Theory* states: **wheat**.

Its **fruit** is **black nightshade**,

Its **seeds** are **networked**,

Its **season** is **Summer**,
for the **Four Seasons’ qi** aligns with **Summer’s qi**.

Its **insect** is **feathered**,

As **Fire’s** transformation spreads,
**feathered insects** are born.

Its **beast** is the **horse**,
*Healthy, central, restless, and swift*—
its **category** aligns with **Fire**.
