Its **color** is **red**,
*Red*: hue matching and **bright**.

Its **nourishment** is **blood**,
its **ailment** is **nevus** or **moles**,
*Fire’s* nature is **dynamic**—hence the disease.

Its **flavor** is **bitter**,

then **things** bear **pure bitter tastes**.

Its **sound** is **sheng** (as in *yún* 允),
*resonant and harmonious—beautiful in accord.*

Its **form** is **veins**,
*within, many **vessel-like tendrils** abound—*
this is **Fire’s** transformation.

Its **number** is **seven**,
*the **perfected number**.*

In full measure of its transformations,
**qi** aligns with **Heaven’s** seasonal cycles,
**virtue/power** flows through the **Four Seasons’ governance**,
*the Five Transformations* are **fully realized**.
*Earth’s* **virtue/power** is **static**,
supporting the **Four Directions**,
*augmenting the governance of Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire*.
*Earth’s* **qi** is **thick**,
responding to **Heaven’s** harmonious seasonal cycles,
to **generate, flourish, harvest, and store**,
*completing the cycle and returning anew*—
thus the **Five Transformations** are **fully realized**.

Its **qi** is **balanced**,
*Earth’s* **nature** is **level and upright**.

Its **nature** is **yielding**,
*responding to all things in order,*
transforming them **fully and smoothly**.

Its **application** is **high and low**,
*the world’s **Earth**—both high and low—*
all **respond to its use**.

Its **transformation** is **abundant and full**,
*abundant and full for all things—*
none but **Earth’s** transformation can achieve this.

Its **category** is **Earth**,
*the Five Phases’ transformations—*
**Earth’s** category is the same.

Its **governance** is **tranquility and stability**,
*Earth’s substance is thick,*
**Earth’s virtue/power** is **static**—
thus its **governance** and **transformation** are likewise.

Its **seasonal sign** is **steamy heat**,
*Steamy*: **dampness**.
*Heat*: **warmth**.

Its **season** is **Dampness**,
*As **Dampness’** transformation never ceases,*
then **Earth’s** season is **prolonged**.
*Long Summer*: the **Summer of Nurturing**,
*the sixth month’s **qi** aligns with it*.
*Newly Revised Annotation*: *According to Wang’s annotation in The Residence of Qi’s Seasonal Theory, **Summer** is the **mother of Earth**; Earth flourishes in the **center**, and by its **growth** it governs, hence **Long Summer**. Again, in his annotation of The Six Divisions and Residence of Symbols, **Long Summer** refers to the sixth month. Its **insect** is **□** (blank),

The newly corrected text states: According to *The Golden Cabinet True Speech Discourse*, when disease is at the root of the tongue, it is known that the disease lies in the **flesh**.

Its **flavor** is **sweet**,
*abundant in **transformative qi**, thus things are sweet and rich.*

*great and heavy.*

Examining the **leveling principle**,
*it **withdraws without contention**, **slays without transgression**—*

*Transgression refers to **punishment** against things.*

*Withdrawing without contention, slaying without transgression—*

Its **qi** is **pure**,

Its **nature** is **rigid**,

Its **storage** is the **lung**,

Its **mastery** is the **nose**,

Its **grain** is **rice**,
*White in color.*

**Reported to the One**—

All **directions**—

**End** (he-tuan).

**Passing through official (官) with Five Phases’ qi scarce**,

**Riding the lonely and perilous**,

**not summoned yet arriving**,

**resentment and calamity self-invited**—

If **wood is weak** and **metal’s qi rides upon it**,
**violent and sudden**—

**Wood harmed by metal**, **fire retaliates**,
**metal harmed by fire**, then **disaster strikes**.

Thus—
**punishment severe, retaliation severe**;
**punishment slight, retaliation slight**—
**qi’s** constant movement,
naturally so.
The **Five Phases’ principles**,
all **alternate thus**.

**The record of generation**—

**Instructing**—ancient **陈 (chen)**.

**Wood’s sole dominion**,

○*New Annotation*: According to the *Grand Treatise on the Interaction of Qi (气交变大论)*, when **Greater Yang (太阳)** prevails above,
**rain, ice, snow, and frost descend untimely (不时降)**, and **moist qi (湿气)** alters **substances (物)**.
It does not say **"above invades (上征)"**, for **the course (运)** prevails over it.
When **Water’s course (水运)** overreaches (政过),
**the transforming qi (化气)** surges greatly (大举),
and **dusty and moist qi (埃昏气)** intermingles (气交),
**heavy rains descend in due season (大雨时降)**,
while **evil (邪)** harms the **kidneys (肾)**.
Frequent violent cold (暴寒数举) is called **overreaching (政过)**.
When **Fire (火)** is suppressed by **Water’s excess (水凌)**,
**Earth (土)** comes to **avenge and retaliate (仇复)**,
hence **Heaven and Earth grow dim (昏翳)**,
**Earth and Water’s qi (土水气)** intermingles (气交),
**heavy rains descend (斯降)**,
and **evil (邪)** harms the **kidneys (肾)**.

Thus it is said:
**"If it does not maintain its virtue (不恒其德)**, then its **prevailing force (所胜)** returns to **avenge (来复)**.
**If it governs its principle (政恒其理)**, then its **prevailing force (所胜)** harmonizes and transforms (同化)**—**
this is what is meant.

**"Not overreaching (不怛)"** means **relying on its own excess (恃已有余)**,
**invading and suppressing (凌犯)** what it cannot prevail over (不胜).
**"Overreaching (怛)"** means **restraining its natural transformation (守常之化)**,
so that its **威刑 (power and authority)** does not run rampant (不肆威刑).
Thus, the **qi of self-restraint (克己之气)**,
each year **harmonizes and governs (同治化)** the **course (运)**.

○*New Annotation*: Detailed discussion of **overreaching (太过)** is found in the *Grand Treatise on the Interaction of Qi (气交变大论)*.

**The Grand Treatise on the Five Constant Principles (五常政大论篇下)**

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"Why does the sky not suffice in the west and north? It brings cold on the left and frost on the right.
Why does the earth not satisfy in the east and south? It brings heat on the right and warmth on the left.
What is the reason for this?"*

The face turns **perverse (巽)**, and speech follows.

Qibo replied:
*"The differences in the **Dao/Way (理)** of **yin-yang qi (阴阳之气)** and the high-low nature of the earth are due to variations in scale.
High and low refer to the **terrain (地形)**.
Scale refers to the varying abundance of **yin-yang qi (阴阳之气)**.

Now, the central plains’ terrain is high in the west and north and low in the east and south.
The west is cool, the north is cold, the east is warm, and the south is hot—
the transformations of **qi (气)** follow this pattern.

The east and south are **yang (阳)**.
**Yang (阳)** **essence (精)** descends to the lower regions,
so the right side is hot and the left side is warm.
When **yang (阳)** **essence (精)** descends,
the **qi (气)** of the earth is tempered and harmonized below.

**Yang qi (阳气)** arises in the east and flourishes in the south,
so the east is warm and the south is hot—
the abundance or scarcity of **qi (气)** is now clear.

The west and north are **yin (阴)**.
**Yin (阴)** **essence (精)** ascends to the upper regions,
so the left side is cold and the right side is cool.
When **yin (阴)** **essence (精)** ascends,
the **qi (气)** of the earth is tempered and harmonized above.

**Yin qi (阴气)** arises in the west and flourishes in the north,
so the west is frostbitten and the north is cold.
When the **sovereign (君)** faces **perverse (巽)** and speaks,
the **minister (臣)** faces **dry (乾)** and responds."*

○*New Annotation*: The detailed explanation of the **insufficiency of the sky and earth (天地不足)** and **yin-yang (阴阳)** is also found within the *Grand Treatise on Yin-Yang Correspondence and Symbolism (阴阳应象大论)*.

Thus, the earth has high and low regions,
and the **qi (气)** has variations of warmth and cold—
high regions are cold, and low regions are hot.

○*New Annotation*: According to the *Grand Treatise on the Six Cosmic Elements (六元正纪大论)*:
*"In the highest lands, the **qi (气)** of winter remains constant,
and in the lowest lands, the **qi (气)** of spring remains constant."*

Therefore, those who dwell in extreme coldness develop **distension (胀)**,
and those who dwell in extreme warmth develop **ulcers (疮)**.
Descending (to lower regions) relieves **distension (胀)**,
and sweating (to cool) relieves **ulcers (疮)**—
this is the **principle of prevailing force (胜理)** in opening and closing.
It is merely a variation in scale.

The west and north, the east and south—
these are the larger divisions.

If we verify this through **climatic conditions (气候)**,
the central plains’ terrain shows that dwelling in high regions brings cold,
while dwelling in low regions brings heat.

Observe it empirically:
High mountains are rich in snow,
flat plains are abundant in rain,
high mountains are cold,
flat plains are hot—
then the distinction between high and low regions and their cold and hot **qi (气)** becomes evident.

Within the **central lands (中华之地)**,
the high and low regions are divided into three parts:
the first extends from **Han (汉)** and **Shu (蜀)**, **Jiangnan (江南)**, to the sea;
the second extends from **Han (汉)** north to **Pingyao County (平遥县)**;
the third extends from **Pingyao’s northern mountains (平遥北山)** north to the **northern frontier seas (蕃界北海)**.

Thus, the southern division is of great heat,
the middle division is of cold and heat in equal measure,
and the northern division is of great cold.
Outside these southern and northern divisions,
the extremes of cold and heat are even more pronounced.
In the division of great heat, the cold is slight,
and in the division of great cold, the heat is slight.

However, ascending to the very peaks of the highest mountains,
the southern and northern faces exhibit stark contrasts in cold and heat—
their **flourishing and withering (荣枯)** differ greatly.

Again, the east-west high-low distinctions are threefold:
the first extends from **Yiyuan County (沂源县)** west to **Shazhou (沙州)**;
the second extends from **Kaifeng County (开封县)** west to **Fenyuan County (汾源县)**;
the third extends from **Kaifeng County (开封县)** east to the **Canghai Sea (沧海)**.

Thus, the eastern division is of great warmth,
the middle division is of warmth and coolness in equal measure,
and the western division is of great coolness.
In the division of great warmth, the cold is two-fifths of its presence,
and in the division of great coolness, the heat is two-fifths of its presence.
Outside the divisions of warmth and coolness,
the extremes of warmth and frost are even more pronounced—
transforming into **great blazing heat (大暄)** and **great cold (大寒)**.

Approximately, the divisions are as such.

Yet, within the **nine divisions of land (九分之地)**,
the cold reaches its extreme in the **eastern north (束北)**,
and the heat reaches its extreme in the **western south (西南)**.

Within these nine divisions,
there are still high and low regions—
high regions are damp,
and low regions are dry—
these are minor variations within a single division.

If we speak broadly,
there are two major distinctions in high and low regions:
First, the central plains’ terrain is high in the west and north,
and low in the east and south.
Second, the **qi (气)** of **yin-yang (阴阳)** varies in abundance—
thus, the differences in **surface warmth and coolness (表温凉)** arise.

Now, if we verify this through **climatic conditions (气候)**,
we observe that **spring qi (春气)** travels westward,
**autumn qi (秋气)** travels eastward,
**winter qi (冬气)** travels southward,
and **summer qi (夏气)** travels northward.

If we measure against the middle division,
from **Kaifeng (开封)** to **Fenyuan (汾源)**,
the **climatic seasons (气侯)** align precisely with the **calendrical seasons (历侯)**.

If we measure against the eastward division,
from **Kaifeng (开封)** to the **Canghai Sea (沧海)**,
every hundred *li*,
**autumn qi (秋气)** arrives a day later,
and **spring qi (春气)** emerges a day earlier.

If we measure against the westward division,
from **Fenyuan County (汾源县)** west to the **frontier gravelly lands (蕃界碛石)**,
for those facing **southward (南向)** or **west-north to east-south (西北束南)**,
every forty *li*,
**spring qi (春气)** emerges a day later,
and **autumn qi (秋气)** arrives a day earlier;
for those facing **northward (北向)** or **east-north to west-south (束北西南)**,
every fifteen *li*,
**spring qi (春气)** emerges a day later,
and **autumn qi (秋气)** arrives a day earlier.

If we measure against the **southward division (南行)**,
for rivers facing **northward (北向)** or **east-north to west-south (束北西南)**,
every five hundred *li*,

○**yang qi (阳气)** travels a day later,
and **yin qi (阴气)** travels a day earlier;
for rivers facing **southward (南向)** or **east-south to west-north (束南西北)**,
every fifteen *li*,
the **heat qi (热气)** arrives a day earlier,
and the **cold qi (寒气)** arrives a day later;
in broad, flat regions,
every fifty *li*,
**yang qi (阳气)** emerges a day earlier,
and **cold qi (寒气)** arrives a day later.

If we measure against the **northward division (北行)**,
for rivers facing **southward (南向)** or **east-south to west-north (束南西北)**,
every twenty-five *li*,
**yang qi (阳气)** travels a day later,
and **yin qi (阴气)** travels a day earlier;
for rivers facing **northward (北向)** or **east-north to west-south (束北西南)**,
every fifteen *li*,
the **cold qi (寒气)** arrives a day earlier,
and the **heat qi (热气)** arrives a day later;
in broad, flat regions,
every twenty *li*,
**heat qi (热气)** travels a day later,
and **cold qi (寒气)** arrives a day earlier.

「In general, this holds true. However, in elevated and steep regions, the **winter qi (冬气)** persists, while in lowlands and plains, the **summer qi (夏气)** lingers. By observing snow melting and grass flourishing, one may discern their nature.

Yet, the earth’s terrain inherently possesses rivers shaped like bows (**弓形川**), snakes (**蛇形川**), and moons (**月形川**). Since the land’s contours vary, the **vitality and decay (生杀荣枯)**—though the earth may be the same—are governed by differing **heavenly forces (天异)**.

Among these, there are regions facing **the *li* direction (离向)**, **the *bing* direction (丙向)**, **the *xun* direction (巽向)**, **the *yi* direction (乙向)**, or **the *shen* direction (震向)**, where **spring qi (春气)** arrives early and **autumn qi (秋气)** comes late, the difference being fifteen days. Conversely, in regions facing **the *ding* direction (丁向)**, **the *kun* direction (坤向)**, **the *geng* direction (庚向)**, **the *dui* direction (兑向)**, **the *xing* direction (辛向)**, **the *qian* direction (乾向)**, **the *kan* direction (坎向)**, or **the *gen* direction (艮向)**, **autumn qi (秋气)** arrives early and **spring qi (春气)** comes late, the difference being twenty days. These are the so-called **mountainous regions (带山之地)**; by carefully examining their orientation and aspect, one may understand their climate.

In **cool and cold regions (寒凉之地)**, the pores are mostly closed and rarely open. When closed, **yang qi (阳气)** does not disperse, making the region naturally cool, and thus the abdomen swells with distension (**腹铃胀**).

In **humid and hot regions (湿热之地)**, the pores are mostly open and rarely closed. When open, **yang qi (阳气)** disperses freely, making the region naturally warm, and thus the skin erupts with sores (**皮铃疮**).

If one **leaches (下之)**, the **central qi (中气)** is not left behind, and thus the distension ceases. If one **induces sweating (汗之)**, **yang qi (阳气)** leaks outward, and thus the sores abate.

The **Emperor (帝)** asked: *How does this relate to longevity and premature death?*
In discussing the **virtue/power (德)** of the land and its inhabitants’ longevity or early demise (**寿夭**), **Ghibber (岐伯)** replied:

*The longevity of those nourished by **yin essence (阴精)**, while those diminished by **yang essence (阳精)** die young. The **yin essence (阴精)**-nourished are found in highlands; the **yang essence (阳精)**-depleted dwell in lowlands. In **yin-dominant (阴方)** regions, **yang qi (阳)** does not wastefully leak out, and **cold qi (寒气)** holds firm externally. Thus, **evil influences (邪)** rarely penetrate, and the **true vital energy (正气)** remains steadfastly guarded, so longevity is prolonged.

In **yang-dominant (阳方)** regions, **yang qi (阳气)** is exhausted and disperses without restraint. **Wind and dampness (风湿)** frequently invade, and the **true vital energy (真气)** is depleted, so death comes early.

Examining this in practice, within the **Central Plains (中原)**, those in the **western-northern (西北)** regions tend toward longevity, while those in the **eastern-southern (东南)** regions die young. Even within these, there are slight variations—this is the great disparity in longevity and early death (**寿夭之大异**), which the **master of the four directions (方者)** must carefully assess.

The **Emperor (帝)** said: *Well spoken.*
Then he asked: *For those who fall ill, how should they be treated?*
**Ghibber (岐伯)** replied:

*In the **western-northern (西北)** regions, where **yang qi (阳气)** is dispersed and the climate is cool, one should treat with cooling and dispersing methods. In the **eastern-southern (东南)** regions, where **yang qi (阳气)** is constrained and the climate is warm, one should treat with warming and consolidating methods. This is what is called **“same disease, different treatment (同病异治)**.”

The people of the **western-northern (西方北方)** regions have dense, tightly closed pores (**皮肤闭胜理密**), and all consume **hot foods (食热)**, so treatments should prioritize **dispersion and cooling (宜散宜寒)**. The people of the **eastern-southern (东方南方)** regions have loose, open pores (**皮肤疏**), and all consume **cold foods (食冷)**, so treatments should prioritize **consolidation and warmth (宜收宜温)**.

**Dispersion (散)** refers to **warm bathing (温浴)**, ensuring the **internal and external channels (中外)** are unobstructed. **Consolidation (收)** refers to **warming the center (温中)** without inducing sweating (**不解表**)—this aligns with the natural **qi (气)** of the region.

Yet today’s common practices reverse this. Following them in treatment only worsens the condition.

The newly annotated text states: *The principles of treatment by direction are also detailed in the **“Discourse on Varying Laws and Regional Appropriateness (异法方宜论)”**. Thus it is said: In **cool and cold regions (气寒气凉)**, treat with **cooling and cold methods (寒凉)**, using **hot water immersion (行水渍之)**. In **warm and hot regions (气温气热)**, treat with **warming and hot methods (温热)**, strengthening the **internal defense (内守)**. One must harmonize with the region’s **qi (气)** to achieve balance (**平**), otherwise the effects are counterfeit.

**Leaching (下之)** with cold methods in **cold regions (寒方)** or inducing sweating with hot methods in **hot regions (热方)**, warming with **warm methods (温方)** in **warm regions (温方)**, and cooling with **cooling methods (凉方)** in **cooling regions (凉方)**—these are the **correct principles (正法)**, the **harmonization of qi (同气)**.

**Hot water immersion (行水渍之)** refers to **steeping in hot water (汤浸渍)**. **Balance (平)** means **adjusting to equilibrium (平调)**.

If in the **western-northern (西方北方)** regions there are **cold diseases (冷病)**, one must use **hot methods (热方)** or **warm methods (温方)** to eliminate them. If in the **eastern-southern (东方南方)** regions there are **heat ailments (热疾)**, one must use **cooling methods (凉方)** or **cold methods (寒方)** to treat them. Then one reverses the **correct principles (上正法)** to achieve the desired effect (**取之**).

The **Emperor (帝)** said: *Well spoken.*

*Why does a single region (州) have years where people do not fall ill, yet the **stored qi (藏气)** remains unused?*
**Ghibber (岐伯)** replied:

*The **heavenly qi (天气)** governs this, as the **qi (气)** has a source it follows. **Follow (从)**** means it adheres to external forces rather than being reserved for private, internal application.

The **Emperor (帝)** said: *I wish to hear the full explanation.*

**Ghibber (岐伯)** replied:

*In years when **Minor Yang (少阳)** presides over Heaven, **fire qi (火气)** descends upon the earth, while **lung qi (肺气)** ascends in response. **White Dew (白起)** signals the **metal qi (金)**’s usage, and vegetation turns green. When **fire (火)** manifests in **bright brilliance (墦炳)**, the **metal qi (革金)** is consumed, and the **Great Heat (大暑)** season progresses. Then **coughing (咳)**, **sneezing (嚏)**, **nasal congestion (欤趣)**, **stuffy nose (鼻窒)**, **daytime sores (日疡)**, and **cold-heat swelling (寒热驸肿)** occur—these are the seasonal patterns of the **years of the *yin* and *shen* stems (寅申之岁候)**.

**Presides (司)** means it **controls from above (御於下)**.
**Ascends (从)** means it **responds from below (从事於上)**.
**Manifests (起)** means its **value surpasses the market (价高於市)**.»

**Use** means the implementation of punishments and decrees—**presiding, ascending, emerging, and use** share the same principle.

**Revolution (革)** refers to hides and leather, also to transformation and renewal. **Metal (金)** pertains to vessels and tools. **Exhaustion (耗)** means expenditure and consumption. When **fire qi (火气)** blazes upward, **daily sores (日疮)** appear—**sores (疮)** being lesions on the body, **ulcers (疡)** those on the head. **Cold-heat (寒热)**—first cold, then hot—indicates **malaria (疟疾)**. The **lung (肺)**, harmed by heat, calls for **water (水)** to counter it; water pooling in the lungs causes **swelling (驸肿)**, a firm, unyielding distension—this arises from **Heaven’s qi (天气)**.

When **at its proper time (当其时)**, **lumbar victory pain (反腰胜痛)** and **movement discomfort (动转不便)** occur. These are the seasonal patterns of the **years of the *chǒu* and *wèi* stems (丑未之歲候)**.

**Water’s transformation (水变)** means **sweet springs turn salty (甘泉变咸)**. **Mist (埃)** is **earthly fog (土雾)**. **Unbounded (冒)** means **no distant separation (不分远)**. **Clouds and rain (云雨)** are **earth’s transformation (土化)**. **Yak (雅)** refers to **buttock flesh (臀肉)**—these ailments arise from **Heaven’s qi (天氣)**.

**Reverse peristalsis (厥逆)**.

The **Yellow Emperor** asked: *"In years when pregnancy fails or gestation is incomplete, and treatment does not fully restore health, what forces of **Dao/Way** cause this?"*

**Gebi** replied: *"The six **qi** and five elemental phases interact through mutual conquest and regulation. When aligned, they flourish; when opposed, they decline—this is the eternal **Dao/Way** of Heaven and Earth, the constant principle of generation and transformation.

Thus, when **Juéyin** governs above, **hairy insects** are still, **feathered insects** thrive, and **armored insects** fail to develop*—these are the years of the *chǒu* and *wèi* stems: *yǐ-sì, dīng-sì, jǐ-sì, xīn-sì, guǐ-sì, yǐ-hài, dīng-hài, jǐ-hài, xīn-hài, guǐ-hài*. **Stillness** means **silence**. It also means **retreat**, not acting prematurely. **Feathered insects**, being **fire-insects**, share **Earth’s** nature. Since **fire subdues metal**, armored insects fail to develop*—referring to white-shelled insects bearing little fruit.

When **in the springs**, **hairy insects** thrive, **preserved insects** diminish, and **feathered insects** fail to develop. **Earth-qi** subdues **Earth**, depleting **yellow preserved insects**, and when the year aligns with **Wood**, this effect is even greater. **Feathered insects** fail to develop due to **Shao-yang’s** self-restraint—these are the years of the five *yín* and five *shēn* stems.

When **Shao-yin** governs above, **feathered insects** are still, **armored insects** thrive, and **hairy insects** fail to develop*—these are the years of the *zǐ* and *wǔ* stems: *jiǎ-zǐ, bǐng-zǐ, wǔ-zǐ, gēng-zǐ, rén-zǐ, jiǎ-wǔ, bǐng-wǔ, wǔ-wǔ, gēng-wǔ, rén-wǔ*. **Stillness** refers to **barbarian birds, swallows, and magpies**—in these years, black-haired insects bear little fruit.

When **in the springs**, **feathered insects** thrive, **armored insects** diminish and fail to develop. **Earth-qi** subdues **Metal**, so white-armored insects fail to develop, and when the year aligns with **Fire**, this effect is even more severe—these are the years of the five *mǎo* and five *yǒu* stems.

When **Tài-yin** governs above, **preserved insects** are still, **scaled insects** thrive, and **feathered insects** fail to develop*—these are the years of the *chǒu* and *wèi* stems: *yǐ-chǒu, dīng-chǒu, jǐ-chǒu, xīn-chǒu, guǐ-chǒu, yǐ-wèi, dīng-wèi, jǐ-wèi, xīn-wèi, guǐ-wèi*. **Preserved insects** include **humans and toads**. **Feathered insects** refer to **green-blue creatures**—parrots, mandarin ducks, and other green-blue feathered beings. When the year aligns with **Metal**, this effect is even more severe.

When **in the springs**, **preserved insects** thrive, **scaled insects** fail to develop*—**Earth-qi** subdues **Water**, so black-scaled insects fail to develop, and when the year aligns with **Earth**, this effect is even more severe—these are the years of the five *chén* and five *xū* stems.

When **Shao-yang** governs above, **feathered insects** are still, **hairy insects** thrive, and **preserved insects** fail to develop*—these are the years of the *yín* and *shēn* stems: *jiǎ-yín, bǐng-yín, wǔ-yín, gēng-yín, rén-yín, jiǎ-shēn, bǐng-shēn, wǔ-shēn, gēng-shēn, rén-shēn*. **Preserved insects** refer to **green-blue creatures**. **Feathered insects** refer to **black-feathered birds**—barbarian swallows and magpies. When **in the springs**, **feathered insects** thrive, **armored insects** diminish, and **hairy insects** fail to develop. **Earth-qi** subdues **Metal**, so white-armored insects diminish, and when the year aligns with **Fire**, this effect is even greater. **Hairy insects** fail to develop due to **Heaven’s** restraint—these are the years of the five *sì* and five *hài* stems.

When **Yángmíng** governs above, **armored insects** are still, **feathered insects** thrive, and **armored insects** fail to develop*—these are the years of the *mǎo* and *yǒu* stems: *yǐ-mǎo, dīng-mǎo, jǐ-mǎo, xīn-mǎo, guǐ-mǎo, yǐ-yǒu, dīng-yǒu, jǐ-yǒu, xīn-yǒu, guǐ-yǒu*. **Feathered insects**, being **fire-insects**, flourish. **Armored insects** refer to **red-shelled creatures**. Red-armored insects fail to develop due to **Heaven’s** restraint. When **in the springs**, **armored insects** thrive, **hairy insects** diminish, and **feathered insects** fail to develop. **Earth-qi** subdues **Wood**, so black-haired insects diminish, and when the year aligns with **Metal**, this effect is even more severe—these are the years of the five *zǐ* and five *wǔ* stems.

**Feathered insects** failing to develop aligns with **Shao-yin’s** earlier pattern.

When **Tàiyáng** governs above, **scaled insects** are still, and **preserved insects** thrive*—these are the years of the *chén* and *xū* stems: *jiǎ-chén, bǐng-chén, wǔ-chén, gēng-chén, rén-chén, bǐng-xū, jiǎ-xū, wǔ-xū, gēng-xū, rén-xū*. **Preserved insects** thrive due to **Earth-qi’s** influence. **Scaled insects** are still—referring to **yellow-scaled creatures** failing to act. In these years, thunder is rarely heard, as **Heaven’s qi** suppresses it.

When **in the springs**, **scaled insects** diminish, and **preserved insects** fail to develop. **Heaven’s qi** conquers, depleting **yellow and black-scaled insects**—these are the years of the five *chǒu* and five *wèi* stems.

In years where the **running cycle** fails to develop:
- Aligning with **Wood**, **preserved insects** fail to develop.
- Aligning with **Fire**, **armored insects** fail to develop.
- Aligning with **Earth**, **scaled insects** fail to develop.
- Aligning with **Metal**, **hairy insects** fail to develop.

In the **running cycle** of **Water**, **winged insects** fail to develop.
When this occurs, it is the same as the above years—all are diminished in their ability to nurture.

These are the cases where **the running cycle** aligns with **the Five Qi**—when it aligns with their victorious phase, and further encounters **Heaven’s resonance** and **yearly conjunctions**, then **ten out of every hundred** will fail to fully develop, and **one or two** will succeed.

Thus, **the Five Qi** have their own dominion, yet are subject to suppression; **the yearly stems** establish their own patterns, yet are also subject to suppression. **Earth-qi** suppresses its own victorious phase, while **Heaven’s qi** suppresses the victorious phase of others. **Heaven** suppresses **color**, **Earth** suppresses **form**. When **Heaven’s qi** follows its own phase without suppression, it is said to suppress **color**; when **Earth-qi** follows its own victorious phase, it is said to suppress **form**. Hence, it is also stated: **"Heaven suppresses color, Earth suppresses form."**

Therefore, between **Heaven** and **Earth**, the **Five Categories** of birth and transformation—each suppressing, each transforming, each generating, each being suppressed—vary in their flourishing and decline according to the **Five Qi’s** natural tendencies. When conditions are favorable, they thrive. Thus, there are cases of **conception and gestation failing to bear fruit**, and **governance not being complete**—these are the **norms of the Five Qi**.

Between **Heaven** and **Earth**, all things that are born are encompassed by these **Five Categories**. The Five are: **hairy, winged, preserved, scaled, and armored insects**. Hence it is said:

*"Hairy insects* number **three hundred and sixty**, with the **unicorn** as their sovereign.
*Winged insects* number **three hundred and sixty**, with the **phoenix** as their sovereign.
*Preserved insects* number **three hundred and sixty**, with **humans** as their sovereign.
*Scaled insects* number **three hundred and sixty**, with the **dragon** as their sovereign.
*Armored insects* number **three hundred and sixty**, with the **tortoise** as their sovereign.

All creatures, whether **near or distant, divergent or unified, crawling or flying, breathing or gestating**, great or small, high or low, **green, yellow, red, white, or black**—those whose bodies are clad in **hair, feathers, scales, or armor**—are collectively referred to as **insects**. Those lacking all four of these attributes are called **preserved insects**.

Near these **five creatures**, all exhibit **conception, gestation, damp generation, or transformation**. According to human governance, these are spoken of as the **central roots**. The **root of vital breath** lies within the **central core of their forms**. *Central* refers to **roots**.

Those not belonging to these **Five Categories** rely entirely on external conditions for their birth and transformation. Remove these conditions, and the **vital breath** will vanish. The **roots dependent on the external** are also five:
The **Five Flavors** and **Five Colors**.

However, the **Five Phases**—**Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water**—all derive their forms from external substances and **color-transformations**, thereby enabling birth and transformation. Once external conditions are removed, **vital breath** is severed and lost. Thus, all are **rooted externally**.

**Newly corrected annotation** states: In the detailed notes, the phrase *color-transformations* should be rendered as *already formed*.

Therefore, the distinctions in birth and transformation involve the **Five Qi, Five Flavors, Five Colors, Five Categories, and Five Appropriateness**. Yet among these **twenty-five** aspects, all are **central roots** or **external conditions**.

The **Five Qi** are: **stimulating, scorching, fragrant, putrid, and decaying**.
The **Five Flavors** are: **sour, bitter, sweet, pungent, and salty**.
The **Five Colors** are: **green, yellow, red, white, and black**.
The **Five Categories** are twofold: the first are **hairy, winged, preserved, scaled, and armored insects**; the second are **dry, damp, fluid, firm, and soft**.

All these, within the myriad things, have their own **natural correspondences**. The **Emperor** asked: *"What does this mean?"*

Qiébò said:

*"What takes root within is called **spiritual mechanism** (*shénjī*). When the spirit departs, the mechanism ceases. What takes root without is called **established qi** (*qìlì*). When the qi stops, transformation ends.

All things with form—those rooted within have their origin bound to Heaven, and their movements are subtle and ethereal. Their actions are governed by the interplay of spiritual qi and mechanism, so their operations remain imperceptible to the myriad things. Thus, when the spirit departs, the pathways of mechanism and action are extinguished. Those rooted without have their origin bound to Earth, so their growth, transformation, maturation, and storage all arise from the established qi of creation. Thus, their emergence is also imperceptible to the myriad things. Therefore, when the qi ceases, the pathways of generation and transformation are utterly extinguished.

As for wood, fire, earth, metal, and water—whether dry, damp, fluid, firm, or yielding—their inherent natures remain unchanging. Yet when external influences depart, when vital qi withdraws, and when the roots of transformation are severed, their constant forms, natures, and colors all undergo slight variations day by day."*

The *New Annotation* states: *"As the *Six Microcosmic Principles Great Treatise* says: When the processes of ingress and egress fail, spiritual mechanism and transformation perish. When ascent and descent falter, established qi becomes solitary and precarious. Without ingress and egress, there can be no growth, flourishing, aging, or decline. Without ascent and descent, there can be no generation, transformation, maturation, or storage. Thus, each has its governing principles, its victories, its origins, and its completion. Both internal and external roots follow this pattern. Hence it is said: Without knowing the years’ influence and the similarities and differences in qi, one cannot speak of generation and transformation."*

The *New Annotation* further states: *"As the *Six Nodal Cycles and Symbols Treatise* says: Without knowing the years’ influence, the ebb and flow of qi, and the rise of emptiness and fullness, one cannot be a skilled practitioner."*

The Emperor asked: *"Qi initiates generation and transformation, disperses to form shape, spreads to nurture, and concludes when form alters—its essence is singular. 'Initiate' refers to the first stirrings of motion. 'Disperse' means to flow through things. 'Spread' means to transform into structured form. 'Conclude' refers to the extreme of storage and maturation. Thus, motion initiates generation and transformation, dispersion forms shape, spreading achieves structure, and conclusion brings about all changes in phenomena. Observing this in practice: Between Heaven and Earth, among all formed things, life begins soft and weak, while death is firm and strong. Such transformations in life and death, in form and substance—this is what is meant by the conclusion of qi."*

The *New Annotation* states: *"As the *Grand Record of the Heavenly Stem* says: The emergence of things is called transformation; their culmination is called change. Again, the *Six Microcosmic Principles Great Treatise* says: Things generate through transformation; things reach their limit through change. Change and transformation intermingle, giving rise to success and failure. Yet the Five Flavors, though they sustain life, vary in their capacity for transformation—some generate more, some less; some mature swiftly, some slowly. Why is this so?"*

Qiébò replied: *"It is the influence of Earth’s qi. Heaven does not generate; Earth does not nourish. Though Heaven and Earth are indifferent to generation and transformation, the qi of generation and transformation inherently differs. Why? Because within Earth’s substance lie the Six Ingresses. Since qi varies, there is generation and transformation, non-generation and non-transformation, scant generation and transformation, and abundant generation and transformation. Thus, between Heaven and Earth, there are some things that generate and transform, some that do not, some that generate and transform sparingly, and some that do so extensively—each follows the divisions of its qi, its affinities and aversions, its similarities and differences."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear this principle."*

Qiébò said: *"Cold, heat, dryness, and dampness each transform differently. If one understands how these four qi differ, the transformations of warmth and coolness become clear.

When *Shao-Yang* is in the *Quan*, cold poisons do not arise. Its flavor is pungent, its treatment involves bitter and sour, and its grains are *cāngdān* (barley and millet). This is the *Yǐ-Hài* year’s transformation. Poisons are all manifestations of the violent and excessive qi of the Five Phases. Now, fire is within Earth, its qi being pure heat. Cold poisons, whose qi differs from Earth’s, thus generate differently, resulting in scant life. Fire restrains metal qi, so pungent flavors do not transform. *Shao-Yang*’s qi ascends to nourish *Jué-Yin*, hence the year’s transformation involves bitter and sour flavors. *Shao-Yang* governs the year harmoniously, with wood and fire succeeding one another, so there is no conflicting qi. Bitter and *dān* (millet) arise from Earth’s qi, while sour and *cāng* (barley) arise from Heaven’s qi. All other transformations involve ascending and descending victories and restraints, hence they all have conflicting qi.

When *Yang-Ming* is in the *Quan*, damp poisons do not arise. Its flavor is sour, its qi damp. The *New Annotation* states: *In the six cases of 'in the Quan,' only the years of Yang-Ming and Tai-Yin specify 'its qi is damp' and 'its qi is hot,' as dampness and dryness do not yet reveal cold or warm qi, hence the repetition of 'its qi.'* Its treatment involves pungent, bitter, and sweet, and its grains are *dān* (millet) and *sù* (rice). This is the *Zǐ-Wǔ* year’s transformation. Dryness is within Earth, its qi cool and clear, so damp and warm poisons generate and transform sparingly. Metal and wood restrain each other, so sour flavors transform little. *Yang-Ming*’s qi ascends to nourish *Shào-Yin*, hence the year’s transformation involves pungent and bitter flavors. Pungent and *sù* (rice) arise from Earth’s qi. Bitter and *dān* (millet) arise from Heaven’s qi. Sweet is conflicting qi. Thus, to resolve the victories and restraints of metal and fire, it also treats with sweetness.

When *Tai-Yang* is in the *Quan*, heat poisons do not arise. Its flavor is bitter, its treatment involves bland and salty, and its grains are *gǔ* (millet) and *zū* (barley). This is the *Chǒu-Wèi* year’s transformation. Cold within Earth differs from heat in transformation, so the year’s things do not generate heat poisons. Wood overcomes fire, hence the flavor should be bitter. *Tai-Yang*’s qi ascends to nourish *Tài-Yin*, hence its transformation generates bland and salty flavors."*

「When *Tài-Yin* (Earth’s *Yin*) **qi** ascends to nourish Heaven, its **qi** is distant yet lofty, so the transformation of sweetness is subtle and becomes bland. Hence, bland is also a type of sweet, belonging to its category. Bland subtlety is Heaven’s transformation. Salty and millet are Earth’s transformation. Subtlety is yellow in hue. *○ Newly corrected:* The detailed annotation states: *"Its flavor should be bitter"* is an error; it should read *"bitter is not transformed,"* a scribal mistake in transmission.

When *Gù-Yīn* (Minor *Yin*) is in the *Quan* (Spring), cold poisons do not arise. Its flavor is sweet, its treatment involves sour and bitter, and its grains are *cāng* (sprouted barley) and *chì* (red millet). This is the *Chǒu-Wèi* (Year of the Pig) and *Shēn-Yǒu* (Year of the Rooster) transformation. Earth’s warmth differs in nature from cold, so its medicinal substances rarely generate cold poisons. Wood overcomes Earth, hence sweetness is minimally transformed. *Gù-Yīn*’s **qi** ascends to harmonize with *Shào-Yáng* (Minor *Yang*), and since the harmonized **qi** lacks conflicting elements, its transformation involves sour and bitter flavors. Sour and sprouted barley are Earth’s transformation. Bitter and red millet are Heaven’s transformation. As there is no conflicting **qi** of victory or restraint, sweetness is not used to resolve the transformations. Its **qi** is singular, its flavor is true. In the years when *Gù-Yīn* and *Shào-Yáng* are in the *Quan*, their **qi** transformations are singular and pure.

However, in other years, the **qi** of Heaven and Earth both have conflicting forces of victory and restraint, so they all involve sweetness and sweet flavors in their transformations to mitigate the excesses and suppressions. The remaining bitter, sour, and salty flavors differ in their transformations, hence the distinctions between Heaven and Earth. Medicinal substances with pungent and sweet flavors are more prevalent.

Thus it is said: To supplement Heaven and Earth, follow their **qi**; to treat them, counter their **qi**; adjust according to the predominance of cold and heat in their locations. Heaven refers to *Sī-Tiān* (the governing Heavenly phase), Earth refers to the *Quan* (Spring). When the **qi** of governing Heaven or Earth is excessive, counter its flavor to treat it. When the **qi** of governing Heaven or Earth is deficient, follow its flavor to harmonize it. *From* means *follow*.

Hence it is said: *Upper* and *lower* supplementation, *inner* and *outer* treatment, are all used to seek out excesses. Those who can withstand poisons should be treated with strong medicine; those who cannot should be treated with mild medicine. This is the principle.

*Upper* supplementation refers to using medicine to subdue excessive **qi** in Heaven, restraining it without following its nature, which may lead to vomiting. *Lower* supplementation refers to using rapid-acting medicine to expel lower ailments; if the attack does not remove the disease, then induce purgation. *Inner* supplementation refers to dietary and internal medicinal treatment, carefully adjusting for cold and heat. *Outer* supplementation refers to applying medicinal poultices to regulate the **qi** of the affected area.

If cold is present but heat should be treated, apply cooling medicine; if heat is present but cold should be treated, apply warming medicine. If upper **qi** is excessive, induce vomiting to relieve it; if lower **qi** is excessive, induce purgation to deplete it—this is the way to seek out the **qi**’s excess.

The strength of medicine refers to the thickness or thinness of its flavors. *○ Newly corrected:* According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* (Canon of A and B), those with thick stomachs, black complexion, large bones, and abundant flesh all withstand poisons. The thin and frail-stomached cannot withstand poisons. Additionally, the *Yì-Fǎ Fāng-Yí Lùn* (Treatise on Appropriate Prescriptions for Diverse Regions) states: The people of the Western regions live in elevated dwellings and are exposed to much wind. Their water and soil are harsh, they wear coarse, unrefined clothing, and consume rich, fatty foods. Thus, pathogenic influences cannot harm their physical forms, and their diseases arise internally, so their treatments should use strong, poisonous medicines.

For diseases with reversed **qi**:
- If the disease is in the upper body, treat with lower supplementation;
- If the disease is in the lower body, treat with upper supplementation;
- If the disease is in the middle, treat with adjacent supplementation.

*Lower* supplementation refers to cold being reversed in the lower body, while heat attacks from above. If warmth is not beneficial for the lower body and **qi** is excessive in the upper body, then warm the lower body to regulate it. *Upper* supplementation refers to cold accumulating in the lower body, and warming not removing it, with insufficient *Yang* hidden within. Then supplement its *Yang*. *Adjacent* supplementation refers to **qi** converging on the left side, so applying medicine to the right side to harmonize it; if **qi** converges on the right side, then apply medicine to the left. Adjust according to the cold or heat of the disease.

These seven methods ensure that the disease has no escape, and when applied correctly, they strike the mark—this is the art of perfect treatment.

To treat heat with cold, apply cooling medicine; to treat cold with heat, apply warming medicine; to treat warmth with clarity, apply cooling medicine; to treat clarity with warmth, apply heating medicine. **Qi** has rigid and yielding natures, symptoms have light and heavy manifestations, prescriptions have large and small applications, and adjustments involve cold and warm treatments.»

When the disease is **qi**-replete and robust, one follows its nature to treat it; when it is slight and yielding, one counteracts its nature to subdue it. If the **qi** is divergent, the governing *zang*-organ cannot contain it; if the strength is doubled, attack it decisively with #23. This is the method of decoctions and drinks in regulating **qi**.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Treatise on the Most True and Great Principles*, "Heat is treated with cold, cold with heat; the *zang*-organ’s pathology is suppressed while the root cause is addressed first. Though their beginnings may align, their ends diverge, yet they can break accumulations, dissolve hardness, harmonize **qi**, and resolve the disease. Thus, the methods of purging, emesis, supplementation, and drainage apply equally to both new and chronic ailments. Measure the **qi**’s excess or deficiency and act accordingly—duration of illness does not alter the principle.

The Emperor asked: *"If a disease lies within but is neither solid nor fixed, now gathering, now dispersing, how should it be treated?"*

Gebi replied: *"Your question is profound! For those without accumulation, seek the affected *zang*-organ. If it is deficient, supplement it. Follow the disease’s location and prescribe organ-specific supplementation. Use medicine to guide it, and food to reinforce it. Feed with non-toxic medicines, administer decoctions in sequence to drive it out completely. Harmonize internally and externally with water and decoctions, and the disease will fully resolve. When inner and outer harmony is achieved, **qi** flows unimpeded, and the condition naturally dissipates, with true **qi** restoring balance."*

The Emperor asked: *"Are there guidelines for toxic and non-toxic medicines?"*

Gebi replied: *"Illnesses vary in duration, prescriptions in scale, and medicines in toxicity—these must always be measured. Great-toxicity medicines treat disease, removing six-tenths of its strength; inferior-grade toxic medicines are the most poisonous. Moderate-toxicity medicines remove seven-tenths; middle-grade medicines rank below the inferior. Mild-toxicity medicines remove eight-tenths; superior-grade toxic medicines are the least poisonous. Non-toxic medicines remove nine-tenths. Superior, middle, and inferior non-toxic medicines are all called *hu*#25. Grains, meats, fruits, and vegetables—use them for nourishment without excess, lest they harm the true **qi**. Great-toxicity medicines are fierce in nature, causing much harm; mild-toxicity medicines are gentle, causing little. Moderate-toxicity medicines lie between great and mild in effect, and their harm is thus discernible. Therefore, adhere strictly to the prescribed limits and await further signs.

Yet even non-toxic medicines, though mild, if taken excessively or for too long, may cause **qi** to become imbalanced—either overabundant or depleted. Prolonged use weakens the *zang*-organs, leaving them exhausted and unable to endure further strain. Hence, the rule: remove nine-tenths and stop. Once the prescribed dose is complete, nourish with the five grains, five meats, five fruits, and five vegetables suited to the *zang*-organs. If residual disease remains, combine medicine and diet as needed.

○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Treatise on the Laws of Organ Qi*, ‘Toxic medicines attack pathogens; grains nourish, fruits assist, livestock benefit, and vegetables fill. If the disease persists, repeat the method. The method refers to the four prior prescriptions. If the disease remains, apply the treatment again, adjusting toxicity as needed without overuse. One must first consider seasonal **qi**, never countering the natural harmony. The six seasonal **qi** govern in turn, with their influence manifesting in the front (south) or back (north). Know where each of the six **qi** resides, and observe how they correspond to the pulse at the wrist, cubit, and inch positions. When *Taiyin* dominates, the pulse is deep; when *Shaoyin* dominates, it is hooked; when *Jueyin* dominates, it is taut. When *Taiyang* dominates, the pulse is large and long; when *Yangming* dominates, it is short and rough; when *Shaoyang* dominates, it is large and floating. These six pulses are the *tianhe* (heavenly harmony). If one fails to recognize them, one calls them merely ‘cold’ or ‘heat.’ Attacking cold to induce heat, or heat to induce cold, without pulse transformation, will generate disease—either heat or cold—while the original condition persists. To seek balance is impossible. Thus, premature death arises from such errors.

Do not over-replete the replete, nor over-deplete the deficient, lest you bring calamity upon others. Failing to discern deficiency and excess, attacking only, will worsen the replete and deplete the deficient. A myriad of diseases will thus intensify, true **qi** will dwindle, and the illness will advance, bringing suffering and untimely death—an inescapable tragedy! Avoid inviting pathogens and losing the true **qi**; this is the path to longevity. Attacking the deficient as if it were excess is to invite pathogens. Ignoring an organ’s deficiency is to lose the true **qi**. Once **qi** is extinguished#27, death follows inevitably."

The Emperor asked: *"For chronic illnesses where **qi** remains unstable, the disease departs but leaves the body emaciated—how should this be treated?"* (Here, *from* means ‘in accordance with’.)

Gebi replied: *"Your question is enlightened! A sage’s inquiry. Transformation cannot be forced, nor time defied. To usurp the Master Carpenter’s craft harms even his hands—how much more so to counter natural transformation with human force? Growth, decline, storage, and concealment each follow the seasons’ rhythms. Even the most skilled cannot alter their timing; this is beyond human power. Thus, the rise, fall, order, and chaos of all things depend on their season. If humans were to claim control over such forces, defying nature and the seasons, they would be deluded.

The meridians must flow freely, and **qi** must follow its course. Restore deficiencies to align with others, nourish and harmonize, and in stillness await the right time. Guard the **qi** carefully, preventing imbalance, and vitality will flourish. This is the way of the sage-king. Hence, *The Great Overview* states: ‘Do not counter transformation, do not defy the seasons. Nourish and harmonize, and await restoration.’"*

This is what is meant.

The Yellow Emperor said, *"Excellent. The *Great Overview* is the essential teaching of the Highest Antiquity. It draws upon the core principles of antiquity to illuminate that the Dao of seasons and transformation cannot be defied, nor can human force substitute for it."*
