**Volume 44 of *Huangdi Neijing Suwen* (Supplementary Commentary)**
Annotated by Tang *Taipu Ling* Xī Xuānzǐ Wáng Bīng, revised by Song *Guànglùqīng* Zhí Mìguān Lín Yì et al., and corrected by Song *Shǒushùshàngshū* *Túntiánláng* Sūn Zhào. Errors have been rectified.

**Chapter 44: *Lùyuán Zhèngjì Dàlùn* (Upper Section)**

The Yellow Emperor asked:
*"The Six Transformations and Six Changes—how their excesses and corrections alternate, and the sequential order of sweet, bitter, sour, salty, and bland—these I understand. Yet the transformations of the Five Movements sometimes align with the Five *Qi*, sometimes oppose the Heavenly *Qi*, sometimes align with Heavenly *Qi* while opposing Earthly *Qi*, sometimes align with Earthly *Qi* while opposing Heavenly *Qi*, sometimes harmonize, and sometimes do not. I do not yet grasp their principles. I wish to comprehend Heaven’s cycles, follow Earth’s patterns, regulate their movements, and harmonize their transformations—so that above and below unite in virtue, none overstep their order, and Heaven and Earth ascend and descend without failing their due. When the Five Movements circulate freely, let no policy contradict them. How should one adjust their proper flavors, whether in alignment or opposition?"*

*"When *qi* is alike, it is called alignment; when *qi* differs, it is called opposition. Victory and suppression constitute non-harmony, while generation constitutes harmony. The Heavenly and Earthly *qi* alternate in excess, victory, and correction—each has its governing principles and methods. To balance and regulate *qi*’s nature, one must not violate the inherent *qi* of Heaven and Earth, thus attaining purity, tranquility, and harmony."*

Qibo bowed twice, kneeling, and replied:
*"Illuminating indeed is your question! This is the fundamental order of Heaven and Earth, the source of all transformations. Who but a sage-emperor could exhaust its ultimate truths? Though I am unworthy, I shall expound its Dao, ensuring it endures without fading, enduring yet unchanging. *Qi* follows cycles, akin to Heaven and Earth—excess and deficiency are its constant sequence. If one does not speak of fixed, eternal laws, then over time, it will shift. As ages drift from the sage, how else shall it be clarified?"*

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"I wish you would expound it systematically, following its categories, dividing its governing sectors, distinguishing its primary overseers, revealing its *qi* cycles, and clarifying its proper transformations. May I hear this?*

*"Governing sectors" refers to the division of the Six *Qi*’s dominions.
*"Primary overseers"* refers to the correspondence of the Five *Qi*’s movements in their appointed positions.
*"Qi cycles"* refers to the regular sequence of Heaven and Earth’s Five Movements in their cyclical operations.
*"Proper transformations"* refers to the seasonal *qi*’s appropriate flavors—sour, bitter, sweet, salty, bland—and their cold, cool, warm, and hot natures."

Qibo said:
*"First, establish the year’s configuration to clarify its *qi*. The sequential movements of Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth, and the transformations of cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire as they govern—then Heaven’s Dao becomes visible, and human *qi* can be regulated. The unfolding and contracting of yin and yang, when near, leave no confusion. Of the *qi* that can be counted, let me now exhaustively speak."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"How does the governance of the Great Yang [Taiyang] proceed?"*

Qibo replied: *"It is the governance of the *chén-wèi* [辰戌] sequence. The Great Yang, Great Angle [太角], Great Yin [太阴], *Rén-chén* [壬辰], *Rén-wèi* [壬戌]—its *qi* governs wind, its transformations are clamor, tumult, and disruption. Its variations are trembling, collapse, and uprooting. Its diseases are dizziness, falling, and blindness of the eyes.

The Great Angle: *Initial Zheng* [初正], *Minor Zheng* [少征], *Great Official* [太官], *Minor Shang* [少商], *Great Feather* [太羽]—*terminal*.

The Great Yang, Great Zheng [太征], Great Yin [太阴], *Wù-chén* [戊辰], *Wù-wèi* [戊戌]—*Zheng* and *Initial Zheng* coincide. Its *qi* governs heat, its transformations are sultry warmth, oppressive heat, and steaming. Its variations are blazing, boiling, and seething. Its diseases are heat stagnation.

The Great Zheng: *Minor Official* [少宫], *Great Shang* [太商], *Minor Feather* [少羽]—*terminal*, *Minor Angle* [少角]—*initial*.

The Great Yang, Great Official [太宫], Great Yin [太阴], *Jiǎ-chén* [甲辰]—*Yearly Assembly* [岁会] aligning with *Heaven’s Sympathy* [天符]; *Jiǎ-wèi* [甲戌]—*Yearly Assembly* aligning with *Heaven’s Sympathy*. Its *qi* governs *yin* dust, its transformations are gentle, moist, and abundant. Its variations are trembling, startling, gusting, and sudden. Its diseases are dampness, with heaviness below.

The Great Official: *Minor Shang* [少商], *Great Feather* [太羽]—*terminal*, *Great Angle* [太角]—*initial*, *Minor Zheng* [少征].

The Great Yang, Great Shang [太商], Great Yin [太阴], *Gēng-chén* [庚辰], *Gēng-wèi* [庚戌]. Its *qi* governs coolness, its transformations are mist, dew, and briskness. Its variations are stern, withering, and decay. Its diseases are dryness, with back dimness and chest fullness.

The Great Shang: *Minor Feather* [少羽]—*terminal*, *Minor Angle* [少角]—*initial*, *Great Zheng* [太征], *Minor Official* [少宫].

The Great Yang, Great Feather [太羽]. Its *qi* governs cold, its transformations are congealing, bleak, and piercing. Its variations are ice, snow, frost, and hail. Its diseases are severe cold lingering in valleys.

The Great Feather—*terminal*, *Great Angle* [太角]—*initial*, *Minor Zheng* [少征], *Great Official* [太官], *Minor Shang* [少商].

All these are the governance of the Great Yang’s *Heavenly Stem* [司天], where the *qi* and transformations unfold in advance of the seasons. The six stages of *qi*—generation, growth, transformation, completion, withdrawal, and storage—all align with the *Heavenly Stem* in their due order. Other years follow this *Heavenly Stem* sequence as well.

When the *Heavenly Stem* is austere, the *Earthly Branch* is tranquil. Cold descends upon the void, and *yang qi* does not prevail. Water and Earth harmonize in virtue, corresponding above to the *Chen* and *Zhen* stars.

Its grains are black and yellow. Its governance is austere, its decrees measured. When cold governance is severe, without *yang* brilliance, fire awaits its time. If cold is extreme, fire stagnates, awaiting the four seasons before erupting in sudden heat.

When the *Minor Yang* [少阳] governs in moderation, timely rains cease, and excessive dampness disperses, returning to the Great Yin. Clouds gather toward the North Pole—the *Rain Palace*—and dampness spreads. Dew nourishes all things, cold descends from above, and thunder stirs below. Cold and damp *qi* persist at the *qi* exchange.

The year’s great changes are thus.

The people suffer from cold and dampness, with muscles atrophying, feet withering and failing to contract, and blood oozing and overflowing.

At the first *qi*, the *Earthly Branch* shifts, and warmth becomes great—*fearful of fire’s onset*. Grass blooms early, the people grow restless, and warm diseases arise: fever, headache, vomiting, and muscular sores. Red patches appear—this is *skin’s victory* over sores, occurring beneath the skin.

At the second *qi*, great cold returns, the people grow bleak, grass encounters cold, and fire *qi* is suppressed. The people suffer from *qi* stagnation and abdominal fullness, and cold begins.

The *qi* of cold and dampness, having descended, reverses to the *Earthly Branch* of the year, thus the *qi* of cold begins to approach the people.

The third *qi*: the *Heavenly Stem* is spread, the *qi* of cold moves, and rain descends. The people suffer from cold, yet their inner warmth surges, causing paralysis and carbuncles to flow downward. Their hearts grow hot and oppressed, and if left untreated, they die. When cold reverses to heat, this defies the natural order—heat arising from the heart endangers the spirit (*shen*). If not urgently aided, the spirit (*shen*) will wither and perish, hence those treated survive, while the untreated die.

The fourth *qi*: the *Way* of wind and dampness contend. Wind transforms into rain, and thus it grows, changes, and matures. The people suffer from great heat and weak *qi*, with atrophied muscles and withered feet, and their fluids flow downward in red and white.

The fifth *qi*: the *yang* energy revives and transforms, grass grows, and thus it changes and matures. The people find relief. The great fire presides, so all things flourish and expand.

The final *qi*: the *Earthly Branch* aligns, dampness is released, and *yin* congeals in the boundless void (*Tai Xu*). Dust obscures the fields, and the people grow bleak and weary. Cold winds arrive, and those who resist will perish in childbirth.

Thus, the year requires austerity to dryness, warmth, and moderation.

**Correction Note:** *"Thus, the year requires austerity to dryness, warmth, and moderation"* should be placed under *"Avoid the empty evils to stabilize its proper order"* (避虚邪以安其正), as the text here is misplaced. The *Way* must be bent to release its stagnation, and first, its transformative source must be nourished.

**Transformative Source** (*Hua Yuan*): This refers to the ninth month, when one draws upon its energy to supplement the heart’s fire.

**Correction Note:** *"When water’s energy is about to prevail, one must first, in the ninth month, draw upon its transformative source to replenish the kidney’s essence."* Water’s reign is in the tenth month, so its energy is drawn in the ninth to temper it and thus supplement fire.

To suppress its movement (*qi*), to aid what cannot prevail—
When the *Great Angle* (*Tai Jiao*) year, the *spleen* cannot prevail;
When the *Great Zheng* (*Tai Zheng*) year, the *lung* cannot prevail;
When the *Great Guan* (*Tai Guan*) year, the *kidney* cannot prevail;
When the *Great Shang* (*Tai Shang*) year, the *liver* cannot prevail;
When the *Great Yu* (*Tai Yu*) year, the *heart* cannot prevail.
Such is the year’s proper alignment.

Yet the *Great Yang* (*Tai Yang*) presides over the *Heavenly Stem* for five years, and its general alignment is to first assist the heart, then support the kidney’s *qi*. Do not let its excesses violently overwhelm and generate illness. Consume the year’s grains to preserve its vital essence, avoid the empty evils to stabilize its proper order.

When wood is excessive, the *spleen* falls ill;
When fire is excessive, the *lung* falls ill;
When earth is excessive, the *kidney* falls ill;
When metal is excessive, the *liver* falls ill;
When water is excessive, the *heart* falls ill.
The same holds true when the *Heavenly Stem* and *Earthly Branch* energies are excessive.

**Year’s Grains** (*Sui Gu*): These are yellow and black grains.
**Empty Evils** (*Xu Xie*): These are winds that surge from the *Chong* meridian.

In moderating *qi*—whether similar or different—adjust the proportions.
If aligned with cold and dampness, use drying and warming methods;
If opposed to cold and dampness, use drying and dampness methods.

For the *Great Guan*, *Great Shang*, and *Great Yu* years—aligned with cold and dampness—drying and warming methods are appropriate.
For the *Great Angle* and *Great Zheng* years—opposing cold and dampness—drying and dampness methods are appropriate.

Thus, when aligned, apply more; when opposed, apply less.
More refers to drying and warming;
Less refers to drying and dampness.
The use of cold, cool, warm, and heat must be adjusted according to the year’s *qi*.

If one uses cold in a cold year, cool in a cool year, warm in a warm year, or heat in a hot year, this aligns with the natural order. If one does the opposite, illness arises—this is called *timing* (*shi*).

**Timing** (*shi*) refers to the seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter, as well as the *qi* of the intermediate periods. If aligned, one must avoid it, even if it is the season.

If the six *qi* preside and one uses warming, cooling, or dampness to treat illness, then do not avoid it. For example, in the *Great Yang* (*Tai Yang*) year, if cold is the illness, one may use heat to treat it—then the heat need not be avoided in summer. The same applies to the other *qi*.

Thus, it is said: *"There are instances where one must act contrary to the natural order."*

Food must follow the same principles as medicine.

**Correction Note:** *"The methods of using cold to avoid cold, and the instances where one must act contrary to the natural order, are fully detailed below."*

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

Now, what of the *Yangming* (*Bright Yang*) year’s alignment?

Guanzi replied: *"It follows the *Earthly Branch* of *Mao* (卯) and *You* (酉)."*

In the *Yangming* year,
**Minor Angle** (*Shao Jiao*) and **Minor Yin** (*Shao Yan*)—cooling and drying prevail, aligning with warmth and suppression.
**Minor Zheng** (*Shao Zheng*)—cooling and drying prevail, aligning with warmth and suppression.

**Correction Note:** *"The *Heavenly Stem* of *Yangming* aligns with the *Earthly Branch* of *Mao* and *You*, and its *qi* is wind, cooling, and drying. When the energy is insufficient, it is said to combine with the suppressed and drying *qi*. Wind is the *qi* of the year; cooling is the prevailing *qi*; and warmth is the suppressed *qi*. The rest of the minor *qi* are all the same.*

**Minor Angle** (*Shao Jiao*) begins—**Great Zheng** (*Tai Zheng*)—**Minor Guan** (*Shao Guan*)—**Great Shang** (*Tai Shang*)—**Minor Yu** (*Shao Yu*) ends.

In the *Yangming* year,
**Minor Zheng** (*Shao Zheng*) and **Minor Yin** (*Shao Yan*)—cold and rain prevail, aligning with warmth and suppression.
**Minor Guan** (*Shao Guan*)—**Great Shang** (*Tai Shang*)—**Minor Yu** (*Shao Yu*) ends—**Minor Angle** (*Shao Jiao*) begins—**Great Zheng** (*Tai Zheng*).

In the *Yangming* year,
**Minor Guan** (*Shao Guan*) and **Minor Yin** (*Shao Yan*)—wind and coolness prevail, aligning with warmth and suppression.
**Minor Guan** (*Shao Guan*)—**Great Shang** (*Tai Shang*)—**Minor Yu** (*Shao Yu*) ends—**Minor Angle** (*Shao Jiao*) begins—**Great Zheng** (*Tai Zheng*).

In the *Yangming* year,
**Minor Shang** (*Shao Shang*) and **Minor Yin** (*Shao Yan*)—cold and heat prevail, aligning with warmth and suppression.
**Minor Shang** (*Shao Shang*)—**Great Guan** (*Tai Guan*)—**Minor Yu** (*Shao Yu*) ends—**Minor Angle** (*Shao Jiao*) begins—**Great Zheng** (*Tai Zheng*).

**Correction Note:** *"According to the *Great Treatise on the Five Constant Regulations*, it states: 'The *Earthly Branch* of *Wei* (委) and *He* (和) aligns with the *Heavenly Stem* of *Shang* (商), and the *Earthly Branch* of *Shang* aligns with the *Heavenly Stem* of *Shang*.' In the *Earthly Branch* of *Ren* (丁) and *You* (酉), the year’s *qi* is wind, cooling, and drying. When the energy is insufficient, it is said to combine with the suppressed and drying *qi*."*

**Correction Note:** *"According to the *Great Treatise on the Heavenly Elements*, it states: 'Three alignments form the regulation.' Also, the *Great Treatise on the Six Minor Essences* states: 'Heavenly alignment and year’s *qi* are called *Great Heavenly Alignment* (*Tai Tian Fu*).'"**

**Wang Bing says:** This is called the *Three Harmonies*—first, *Heavenly Harmony*; second, *Yearly Harmony*; third, *Running Harmony*. Some say that in this year, the *Three Harmonies* are all *Great Heavenly Harmony* (*Tai Tian Fu*), and thus should not also be called *Yearly Harmony*—this is utterly incorrect. *Yearly Harmony* is indeed *Yearly Harmony*, and the name *Yearly Harmony* cannot be discarded.

Some say, *"Why do not the years of *Jǐ Chǒu* (己丑), *Jǐ Wèi* (己未), and *Wù Wǔ* (戊午) speak of *Yearly Harmony* but only mention *Great Heavenly Harmony*?"* This is like citing one corner without considering the other three—if one is known, the other three are implied. To omit it would mean *Great Heavenly Harmony* alone, not *Yearly Harmony*. Thus, it cannot be discarded.

Its *running qi* is freezing and hot, cold and warm.
**Minor Shang**, **Great Zhui** (羽终), **Great Jing** (角初), **Minor Zheng** (征), **Great Gong** (宫)
**Yangming**, **Minor Shang**, **Minor Yin**—rain and wind prevail, and the excess and return are the same, aligning with **Minor Gong**.

**Xīn Jiāozhèng says:** According to the *Great Treatise on the Five Constant Regulations*, when the *Five Movements* are insufficient, apart from the regular *Jing*, *Shang*, and *Gong*, in the years *Guǐ Chǒu* (癸丑) and *Guǐ Wèi* (癸未), it should say *"Minor Zheng and Minor Zhui are the same."* In *Jǐ Mǎo* (己卯) and *Jǐ Yǒu* (己酉), *"Minor Gong and Minor Jing are the same."* In *Yǐ Chǒu* (乙丑) and *Yǐ Wèi* (乙未), *"Minor Shang and Minor Zheng are the same."* In *Xīn Mǎo* (辛卯), *Xīn Yǒu* (辛酉), *Xīn Sì* (辛巳), and *Xīn Hài* (辛亥), *"Minor Zhui and Minor Gong are the same."* This makes ten years in total.

Now, this treatise alone speaks of *"Minor Gong being the same"* because *Guǐ Chǒu*, *Guǐ Wèi*, and *Chǒu Wèi* are Earth, so it does not additionally say *"Minor Zhui is the same."* *Jǐ Mǎo* and *Jǐ Yǒu* are Metal, so it does not additionally say *"Minor Jing is the same."* *Xīn Sì* and *Xīn Hài* are Wood, so it does not additionally say *"Minor Gong is the same."* *Yǐ Chǒu* and *Yǐ Wèi*—later, the *Great Yang* is Water—so it does not additionally say *"Minor Zheng is the same."* Apart from these eight years, only *Xīn Yǒu* (辛酉) and *Xīn Mǎo* (辛卯) are years where *"Minor Zhui and Minor Gong are the same."*

**Xīn Yǒu, Xīn Mǎo**—its *running qi* is cold and rainy, windy.
**Minor Zhui** (终), **Minor Jing** (角初), **Great Zheng**, **Minor Gong**, **Great Shang**

All this pertains to the governance of *Yangming* ruling Heaven, with *qi* transformations running in accordance with the *Post-Heaven*. The six stages of *qi*—generation, growth, transformation, and completion—all movements of affairs, both dynamic and static, respond to the *Post-Heaven* timing. The remaining years share the same *Minor* alignment.

Heavenly *qi* is urgent, Earthly *qi* is clear; *Yang* dominates its mandate, scorching heat prevails, things dry and harden, pure winds bring order, and wind-dryness spreads through *qi* exchanges. With excessive *Yang* and deficient *Yin*, clouds rush toward the *Rain Bureau*, and dampness spreads. The *Rain Bureau* is where *Tai Yin* resides.

When dryness reaches its extreme, it transforms into dew—this is the division of the *Three Qi*. Its grains are white *Dān* (丹), born from the true *qi* of Heaven and Earth.

As for *interval grains* (*jiàn gǔ*), those marked *"Great"*—such as the *Great Jing*, *Shang*, etc.—refer to the transformations of *qi* mentioned earlier. Since they arise from *qi* transformations, they are called *interval grains*.

○ **Xīn Jiāozhèng says:** According to the *Mysterious Pearl* (*Xuán Zhū*), what are *year grains* and *interval grains*? These are the grains found in the spring (*zài quán*), and those found beside the spring on either side are also called *year grains*. Those that govern Heaven and the *running qi* while transforming are named *interval grains*. There is another kind of *interval grain*—when Earthly transformations are insufficient, it counteracts its conquered element to produce them, hence the name *interval grain*. This is also the transformation of perverse *qi*, called *convergent transformation grains*, also named *interval grains*. This differs from Wang’s annotation.

Its disasters consume white *jiǎ* (甲) and feathered creatures (*pín yǔ*), white-colored insects, and feathered species multiply and decline in abundance, while armored creatures (*jiǎ bīng*) bring calamity, depleting all things. Metal and Fire combine in virtue, corresponding above to *Tai Bai* (Tai White) and *Xīnghuò* (Mars). When seen as large and bright, its governance is strict, its mandate sudden. Hibernating creatures appear, flowing water does not freeze.

The people suffer from coughing, throat blockage, alternating cold and heat, sudden shivering, *liàn* (癃, urinary retention) and *shì* (閟, urinary difficulty), with cold first and then heat, strong and violent. Feathered creatures die, armored creatures suffer. When the onset is sudden, the excess and return of *qi* clash violently, causing great disorder. Metal first prevails, Wood has already suffered harm, hence feathered creatures die. Fire prevails later, Metal cannot resist, hence armored creatures suffer again. When prevailing, it executes its killing—feathered creatures are already gone, the returning *qi* comes later, the strong then rebel—is this not the great disorder of *qi*?

The cold-heat *qi* lingers at the *qi* exchange. In the first stage, Earthly *qi* shifts, *Yin* begins to condense, *qi* becomes austere, water freezes, and cold rain transforms. Its diseases include internal heat and distension, facial and orbital swelling, excessive sleepiness, sighing and restlessness, sneezing and yawning, vomiting, and yellowish or bloody urine, severe enough to cause *lín* (淋, dysuria).

This is the transformation of *Tai Yin*.

○ **Xīn Jiāozhèng says:** Upon closer inspection, when *qi* becomes austere and water freezes, this is not the transformation of *Tai Yin*.

In the second stage, *Yang* spreads, the people relax, and things flourish. Sudden deaths occur—this is because the minister’s position is beneath the sovereign’s.

In the third stage, Heaven’s governance spreads, coolness prevails, dryness and heat combine, and at the extreme of dryness, dew forms. The people suffer from alternating cold and heat—this is *malaria*.

In the fourth stage, cold rain falls, causing sudden collapse, shivering, delirium, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and thirst. It may also cause heart pain, paralysis, swelling, sores, malaria-like cold, and *bone atrophy* (骨痿) with bloody stools.

In the fifth stage, the spring order reverses, grass flourishes, and the people’s *qi* harmonizes.

In the terminal stage, *Yang qi* spreads, the season reverses to warmth, hibernating creatures emerge, flowing water does not freeze, and the people find peace. Its diseases are fevers—this is the sovereign’s transformation.

Thus, one should eat *year grains* to stabilize one’s *qi*, eat *interval grains* to dispel perverse influences. The year’s suitability lies in *salty*, *bitter*, and *pungent* flavors—through sweating, clearing, and dispersing, one stabilizes the *running qi*, preventing it from receiving perverse influences, and relieves stagnant *qi*, nourishing the source of transformation.

The source of transformation—this refers to welcoming and taking it in the sixth month. ○The newly corrected text states: According to the *Jin* sovereign’s seventh month, thus welcoming the *Jin* qi in the sixth month. Adjusting by cold and heat, lightness and heaviness, scarcity and abundance in its governance:

When aligned with heat, it draws more from Heaven’s transformation;
When aligned with clarity, it draws more from Earth’s transformation.
In years of scarce *Jiao* and scarce *Zheng*, when aligned with heat, prescriptions should primarily use Heaven’s clear transformation.
In years of scarce *Guān*, scarce *Shang*, and scarce *Yǔ*, when aligned with clarity, prescriptions should primarily use Earth’s warm transformation.
Fire resides on Earth, hence alignment with clarity yields more Earth’s transformation.
Metal resides in Heaven, hence alignment with heat yields more Heaven’s transformation.

When using coolness, avoid excessive coolness;
When using warmth, avoid excessive warmth;
When using coldness, avoid excessive coldness;
When using mildness, avoid excessive mildness—
Diet should follow the same principle.

If there are anomalies, reverse the approach—
This is the Dao.
Reversing disrupts Heaven and Earth’s order,
Disturbs *Yin* and *Yang*’s rhythms.

The Emperor said: Excellent.
How does the governance of *Shǎo-Yáng* proceed?

Gǐ Bó replied:
It follows the *Yín-Shēn* cycle. *Shǎo-Yáng*’s *Tài-Jiǎo*:
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, "When *Zheng* ascends, its qi reverses."
*Jué-Yīn* aligns with *Rén-Yín* and *Rén-Shēn*—both in Heavenly resonance—
its movement stirs the wind.
○The newly corrected text states: Detailed in the convergence of wind and fire, hence its movement stirs the wind.
*Shǎo-Yīn* governs Heaven, and *Tài-Jiǎo*’s movement aligns accordingly.
Its transformation: *wū-sù* opens and breaks.
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, "Its virtue: *wū-mǐ* opens and breaks."
Its changes: *zhèn-lā* shatter and pluck.
Its diseases: vertigo, limb numbness, and terror.

*Tài-Jiǎo*’s initial phase—*Shǎo-Zheng*—*Tài-Guān*—*Shǎo-Shāng*—*Tài-Yǔ* concludes.

*Shǎo-Yáng*’s *Tài-Zheng*:
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, "When *Zheng* ascends, it collects *Qi* and brings disaster."
*Jué-Yīn*—*Wù-Yín*—*Wù-Shēn*—both in Heavenly resonance—
its movement brings summer.
Its transformation: *xuān-ráo* oppressive and sultry.
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, it reads: *xuān-shǔ* oppressive and sultry.
This change—summer turning to *ráo*—occurs because it governs *Shǎo-Yáng*.
Its changes: blazing heat, boiling turbulence.
Its diseases: upper heat oppression, blood overflow, blood discharge, and heart pain.

*Tài-Zheng*—*Shǎo-Guān*—*Tài-Shāng*—*Shǎo-Yǔ* concludes—*Shǎo-Jiǎo* begins.

*Shǎo-Yáng*’s *Tài-Guān*:
*Jué-Yīn*—*Jiǎ-Yín*—*Jiǎ-Shēn*—both in Heavenly resonance—
its movement brings *yīn* rain.
Its transformation: gentle, moist, and heavy dew.
Its changes: trembling, gusts, and sudden squalls.
Its diseases: body heaviness, *bì-zhòng* (abdominal distension), edema, and dyspepsia.

*Tài-Guān*—*Shǎo-Shāng*—*Tài-Yǔ* concludes—*Shǎo-Jiǎo* begins.

*Shǎo-Yáng*’s *Tài-Shāng*:
*Jué-Yīn*—*Gēng-Yín*—*Gēng-Shēn*—both in Heavenly resonance, aligned with *Zhèng-Shāng*.
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, "In the *Firm and Complete* cycle, when *Zheng* ascends, it aligns with *Zhèng-Shāng*."
Its movement brings frost.
Its transformation: mist and dew, crisp and sharp.
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, it reads: "Mist and dew, *xiāo-yáng* (scattered and uplifted)."
Again, in *Dà-Shāng*’s three movements, two mention *xiāo-yáng*, but here it states *qīng-qiè* (clear and incisive).
Detailed below, as in *Jué-Yīn*, it should correspond to *xiāo-yáng*.
Its changes: stern desolation, withering, and decay.
Its diseases: shoulder, back, and chest afflictions.

*Tài-Shāng*—*Shǎo-Yǔ* concludes—*Shǎo-Jiǎo* begins—*Tài-Yǔ*—*Shǎo-Zheng*.

*Shǎo-Yáng*’s *Tài-Yǔ*:
*Jué-Yīn*—*Bǐng-Yín*—*Bǐng-Shēn*—
its movement brings cold severity.
○The newly corrected text states: Detailed here, this movement should not be called "cold severity," as it aligns with *Tài-Yáng*’s *Tài-Yǔ* movement in the notes.
Its transformation: congealed, grim, cold, and piercing.
○The newly corrected text states: According to *The Grand Treatise on the Five Constants’ Governance*, it reads: "Congealed, grim, cold, and *hán-líng* (freezing desolation)."
Its changes: ice, snow, frost, and hail.
Its diseases: cold, with floating edema.

*Tài-Yǔ* concludes—*Tài-Jiǎo* begins—*Shǎo-Zheng*—*Tài-Guān*—*Shǎo-Shāng*.

In all, the governance of *Shǎo-Yáng*’s Heavenly phase:
Its *Qi* and transformations move in advance of Heaven.
Heaven’s *Qi* is upright.
○The newly corrected text states: Detailed in *Shǎo-Yáng* governing Heaven and *Tài-Yīn* governing Earth, both attaining their uprightness.
Again, *Jué-Yīn* and *Shǎo-Yáng* govern Earth, each stating they attain their uprightness—
speaking of Earth’s role in nurturing flourishing.
The original text may have read "Heaven’s *Qi* ceases," but *Shǎo-Yáng*’s fiery nature is restless and impulsive—
the meaning of "cease" does not fit.
Earth’s *Qi* is disturbed, and wind rises violently—
trees bend, sand flies, flames spread, and *Yin* follows *Yang*’s transformation.
Rain responds in due course.
Fire and wood share virtue, corresponding above to *Míng* (Mars) and *Suì* (Jupiter).
They appear bright and vast.
○The newly corrected text states: Detailed in the Six *Qi*, only *Shǎo-Yáng* and *Jué-Yīn* governing Heaven and Earth harmonize above and below, without mutual conquest.
Thus, fire and wood share virtue.
The other *Qi* all have mutual conquest, hence they are said to "merge virtues."

Its grains are red and blue-green.
Its governance is strict, its decrees disruptive.
Thus, oppressive wind-heat spreads,
clouds and phenomena boil,
*Tài-Yīn* floods horizontally,
cold arrives in due season,
and frost and rain arise together.
The people suffer from cold invasion,
externally manifesting sores and ulcers,
internally causing diarrhea and distension.
Thus, the Sage, encountering this, harmonizes without contention.
The alternating phases bring diseases of cold, heat, malaria, and diarrhea,
deafness, dim vision, vomiting, and spitting.
Upper oppression, skin eruptions, and color changes.

In the initial phase, Earth’s *Qi* shifts,
wind prevails and shakes,
cold departs,
and the season becomes greatly warm.
Grass and trees flourish early.
Cold does not kill, and warm diseases arise.
Its diseases: *Qi* oppression above, blood overflow, red eyes,
coughing, inverted breathing, headache, *xuè-gāng* (blood clots),
flank distension, and skin ulcers in the center—
*Shǎo-Yīn*’s transformation.

In the second phase, fire is oppressed again—
due to *Tài-Yīn*’s division.
White dust rises in all directions,
clouds gather toward the rain chamber,
wind cannot overcome moisture,
rain falls in droplets,
and the people find peace.
Its diseases: upper heat oppression,
coughing, inverted breathing, vomiting,
ulcers in the center,
chest constriction and discomfort,
headache, body heat,
dizziness, delirium, and purulent sores.

In the third phase, Heaven’s governance spreads,
scorching summer arrives,
*Shǎo-Yáng* ascends above,
and rain recedes.

「The people suffer from inner heat—
deafness and blindness, blood overflow,
purulent sores, coughing, and vomiting,
*wǒ-niǔ* (a type of thirst), sneezing and yawning,
sore throat and red eyes,
prone to sudden death.

In the fourth phase, frost arrives—
scorching summer undergoes transformation,
white dew descends,
and the people’s *qi* becomes harmonious and peaceful.
Its diseases: a sense of heaviness throughout the body.

In the fifth phase, the *Yang* recedes,
cold comes, and rain falls.
The *qi* gates close.
*New annotation*: According to Wang’s commentary in *The Doctrine of Vital Breath Communicating with Heaven* (*Shēng-Qì Tōng-Tiān Lùn*): *Qi* gates are the *Xuán-Fǔ* (Mysterious Storehouse).
They serve as the pathways for the release of *Jīng* (Channel), *Fèn* (Vessel), *Róng* (Nutritive), and *Wèi* (Defensive) *qi*.
Thus, they are called *qi* gates.
The rigid trees wither early,
the people avoid cold pathogens,
and the virtuous ones act prudently.

In the final phase, Earth’s *qi* is upright,
wind arrives, and all things revive.
Mists drift and move.
Its diseases: *guān-bì* (a condition of restricted flow), heart pain,
and *Yang* *qi* failing to be contained, resulting in coughing.

Regarding the *qi*’s movement and its unchecked excess,
one must first suppress the oppressed *qi* by taking the *huà-yuán* (Transformation Source).
The *huà-yuán* is the twelve months before the current year—
approach and take from them.
*New annotation*: Examining Wang’s commentary on "taking the *huà-yuán*" and the *Zū* (Assist) commentary on "take":
their meanings vary across four categories:
*Tài-Yáng* (Great Yang) governs Heaven and takes the ninth month,
*Yáng-Míng* (Yang Brightness) governs Heaven and takes the sixth month—
these two are cases of taking the *qi* from Heaven first.
*Shǎo-Yáng* (Lesser Yang) governs Heaven and takes the twelve months before the year,
*Tài-Yīn* (Great Yin) governs Heaven and takes the ninth month—
these two involve taking the *qi* from Earth before its time.
*Shǎo-Yīn* (Lesser Yin) governs Heaven and takes the twelve months before the year,
*Jué-Yīn* (Extreme Yin) governs Heaven and takes the fourth month—
the meaning here remains unclear.
According to the *Xuán-Zhū* (*Mysterious Pearl*) doctrine, it differs:
the months for *Tài-Yáng* and *Yáng-Míng* align with Wang’s commentary,
while *Shǎo-Yáng* and *Shǎo-Yīn* both take the third month,
*Tài-Yīn* takes the fifth month,
and *Jué-Yīn* takes the twelve months before the year.
The *Xuán-Zhū*’s meaning is clear.
Wang’s months may contain errors.

When excess is not restrained, no life flourishes;
when *qi* is not moderated, severe illnesses do not arise.
*Kē* (severe) means *chóng* (excessive).
*New annotation*: This does not mention "food of the year" or "grain of the year,"
as the year’s *qi* is now balanced between Heaven and Earth,
and the upper and lower realms are in harmony,
so no mention is needed.

Thus, the year suits *saltiness*, *pungency*, and *sourness*;
to permeate and release,
to moisten and disperse—
adjust according to the *qi*’s cold or warmth.
For *Tài-Jiǎo* (Great First) and *Tài-Zhēng* (Great Second) years, the *qi* aligns with wind-heat,
so cold therapy should be applied more.
For *Tài-Guān* (Great Second), *Tài-Shāng* (Great Third), and *Tài-Yǔ* (Great Fourth) years,
the *qi* diverges from wind-heat,
so cool therapy should be used to adjust its excess.

Use heat to distance heat,
use warmth to distance warmth,
use cold to distance cold,
use frost to distance frost—
food should follow the same principle;
this is the Dao’s way.
To act contrary is the path to illness.

*Huáng-Dì Nèi-Jīng Sū-Wèn* (Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon – Plain Questions) supplementary annotated text, Volume 44, concludes.

*New annotation*: Original text had "知" (*zhī*, "know"), but corrected according to Gu’s version to "之" (*zhī*, "its/their").」

「In the *Tài-Yuán Zhèng-Jì Dà-Lùn* (Great Treatise on the Regular Cycles of the Six Elements) of the *Huáng-Dì Nèi-Jīng Sū-Wèn* (Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon – Plain Questions),

The Emperor said: **#1** How does the *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) year function?
Gē-Bó replied: It is the cycle of *Chǒu-Wèi* (Earth-Horse and Earth-Sheep).
When *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) aligns with *Shǎo-Jué* (Minor First), and *Tài-Yáng* (Great Sixty-First) adjusts cooling and excess heat—**both** harmonize with the *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister).
**New Correction:** According to the *Wǔ-Cháng Zhèng-Dà-Lùn* (Great Treatise on the Five Constants), the *Wěi-Hé* (Subdued Harmony) cycle has the *Shàng-Guān* (Upper Minister) and *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister) in accord.
In the *Dīng-Chǒu* (Earth-Hen) and *Dīng-Wèi* (Earth-Sheep) years, the *qi* aligns with **wind-cooling** and **heat**.
*Shǎo-Jué* (Minor First) begins, *Tài-Zhēng* (Great Second), *Shǎo-Guān* (Minor Minister), *Tài-Shāng* (Great Third), and *Shǎo-Yǔ* (Minor Fourth) conclude—**then** *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth), *Shǎo-Zhēng* (Minor Second), and *Tài-Yáng* (Great Sixty-First) adjust **cold** and **rain**, harmonizing with the *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister).
**New Correction:** According to the *Wǔ-Cháng Zhèng-Dà-Lùn* (Great Treatise on the Five Constants), the *Bēi-Jiān* (Low Vigilance) cycle has the *Shàng-Guān* (Upper Minister) and *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister) in accord.
In the *Jǐ-Chǒu* (Earth-Dog) and *Jǐ-Wèi* (Earth-Sheep) years, the *qi* aligns with **cold-rain-wind**, harmonizing with the *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister).
*Shǎo-Guān* (Minor Minister), *Tài-Shāng* (Great Third), *Shǎo-Yǔ* (Minor Fourth), and *Shǎo-Jué* (Minor First) conclude—**then** *Tài-Jué* (Great Second) and *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) begin.
When *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) aligns with *Shǎo-Shāng* (Minor Third) and *Tài-Yáng* (Great Sixty-First), the **rain-wind** adjusts excess and harmonizes with the *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister).
**New Correction:** According to the *Wǔ-Cháng Zhèng-Dà-Lùn* (Great Treatise on the Five Constants), the *Hé-Liú* (Drought Flow) cycle has the *Shàng-Guān* (Upper Minister) and *Zhèng-Guān* (Regular Minister) in accord.
Some mistakenly regard these two years as the *Tóng-Suì Huì* (Converging Years of the Same Cycle), equating them to the **level water** phase, and wish to omit the phrase *"harmonizing with the Zhèng-Guān"* (同正官). This is incorrect.
These years hold **two meanings**, and omitting one is highly improper.
In the *Xīn-Chǒu* (Earth-Rat) and *Xīn-Wèi* (Earth-Sheep) years, the *Tóng-Suì Huì* (Converging Years of the Same Cycle) aligns with **cold-rain-wind**.
*Shǎo-Yǔ* (Minor Fourth) concludes, *Shǎo-Jué* (Minor First) begins, *Tài-Zhēng* (Great Second), *Shǎo-Guān* (Minor Minister), and *Tài-Shāng* (Great Third) follow.

**In all**, the *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) governs the **celestial** cycles, while the *qi* transforms and flows through the **post-heaven** (earthly) phases.
All things grow, develop, and mature—**each** is formed by the **post-heaven** *qi* in due season.
When *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) holds sway, the **Yang** *qi* recedes**, while great winds arise.
**New Correction:** Examining the *Tài-Yīn* (Great Sixtieth) cycle, why mention the **great winds**? Because *Jī-Yīn* (Minor First) is the **initial** *qi*, residing in the **wood** position, where **spring** *qi* prevails—**thus** winds come, and it is said that **great winds** arise.
When **celestial** *qi* descends and **terrestrial** *qi* ascends, mist shrouds the plains, and **white dust** (fine particulate) fills the air.
Clouds race toward the **Southern Pole**, and **cold rain** descends repeatedly—**things** mature in the **post-summer** (late summer).
The **Southern Pole** is the **rain domain**; **post-summer** refers to the ten days after the **Establishment of Autumn** (立秋).
The people suffer from **cold-dampness**, with **abdominal distension**, **body heaviness**, **irritability**, **edema**, **epigastric oppression**, **cold spasms**, and **tightness**.
When **cold** and **dampness** combine, **yellow-black turbidity** (hazy *qi*) arises—**as** the *qi* mingles, it corresponds to the **constellations of Zhènxīng** (镇星) and **Chénxīng** (辰星).
They appear **large and distinct**.
Its governance is **stern**, its command **silent**, and its **grains** (nourishment) are **bitter and dark**.
**Regular** *qi* forms and matures all things.
Thus, **cold** condenses above, and **cold** accumulates below—**when cold water** overcomes **fire**, it becomes **hail**, and **Yang** light cannot rectify it, so **killing** *qi* spreads.
**Yellow-black turbidity** is the **killing** *qi*, flowing from the **north** to the **west**, then to the **east** and **south**.
Therefore, if there is **excess**, treatment should be **elevated**; if **deficient**, treatment should be **lowered**.
If excess occurs **later**, treatment should be **delayed**; if deficient **earlier**, treatment should be **prompt**.
If there is **excess earth**, it is the **transformation of the** *qi*—**the people’s** *qi* follows accordingly.
To inquire about **grains**, one must emphasize the **abundance** (of *qi*).
In the **initial** *qi*, the **terrestrial** *qi* shifts—**thus** cold departs, and **spring** *qi* arrives.
**Thus** winds come, **nourishing** and **spreading** all things—**the people’s** *qi* becomes **uninhibited**, while **wind-dampness** intermingle, and **rain** follows.
The people suffer from **blood overflow**, **tightened sinews**, **stiff joints**, and **body heaviness**.

The **half-year** refers to **the day of the *Lì-Qiū* (立秋)**."

The newly revised text states:
*"The exchange of *qi* and its governance is detailed in the year prior to the **Great Cold (Dà Hàn)**. The **half-year** should be **fifteen days before the *Lì-Qiū* (立秋)**, not on the day of *Lì-Qiū* itself.
The **interchange of Heaven and Earth** is governed by **mutual exchange**—when the **yearly cycle** is complete.
**Mutual exchange** refers to **reciprocal correspondence**.

Within the **upper and lower bodies**, there are **two reciprocal correspondences**.
Thus it is said: *‘When the positions are clear, the *qi* and months can be known.’*
This is what is meant by **the *qi***.
Generally, **one *qi*** governs **sixty days with remainder**, and its position is established by numbering.
If the positions are the same as the *qi*, then the **solar terms and midpoints of months** can be determined.

Thus, when speaking of **Heavenly and Earthly *qi***, it is through the **upper and lower bodies**; when speaking of **prevailing alternation (勝復)**, it is through **exchange of *qi***; when speaking of **horizontal circulation (橫運)**, it is through **upper and lower reciprocity**—all are measured by the **solar terms**. By observing **disasters of green-blue**, the **transformations and alternations** can be anticipated.

The Emperor said: *"I govern its affairs and follow its principles, yet if they do not align with the numbers, why is that?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"The application of *qi* has excess or deficiency, and its transformations and governance have flourishing or decline. The decline and flourishing, excess and deficiency—these all follow the same transformations."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear how these transformations are the same."*

Qī Bó replied: *"**Wind and warmth** are the transformations of **Spring**; **heat and dizziness from scorching fire** are the transformations of **Summer**; **prevailing and alternation** are the same; **dryness, clarity, and dew** are the transformations of **Autumn**; **clouds, rain, dimness, and long summer** are the transformations of **Late Summer**; **cold *qi*, frost, snow, and ice** are the transformations of **Winter**. These are the transformations of **Heaven and Earth’s Five Movements and Six *Qi***, alternating in their usual flourishing and decline."*

The Emperor said: *"The Five Movements proceeding in accordance with Heaven’s transformations are called **Heaven’s Correspondence (天符)**—I understand this. I wish to hear what is meant by **Earth’s Correspondence**."*

Qī Bó replied: *"There are three instances of **excess aligning with Heaven’s Correspondence**, and three instances of **deficiency aligning with Heaven’s Correspondence**; there are also three instances of **excess aligning with Earth’s Correspondence**, and three instances of **deficiency aligning with Earth’s Correspondence**—this encompasses **twenty-four years** in total.
Within sixty years, **twenty-four years align with Heaven and Earth’s transformations**, and the rest follow their respective excesses and deficiencies."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear their specifics."*

Qī Bó replied:
*"In **Jia-Chen (甲辰)** and **Jia-Xū (甲戌)**, **Great Palace (太宮)** below **adds to Great Yin (太陰)**;
In **Rén-Yín (壬寅)** and **Rén-Shēn (壬申)**, **Great Horn (太角)** below **adds to Jue Yin (厥陰)**;
In **Gēng-Zǐ (庚子)** and **Gēng-Wǔ (庚午)**, **Great Commerce (太商)** below **adds to Yang Ming (陽明)**—this occurs three times.

In **Guǐ-Sì (癸巳)** and **Guǐ-Hài (癸亥)**, **Lesser Commerce (少征)** below **adds to Shao Yang (少陽)**;
In **Xīn-Chǒu (辛丑)** and **Xīn-Wèi (辛未)**, **Lesser Feather (少羽)** below **adds to Tai Yang (太陽)**;
In **Guǐ-Mǎo (癸卯)** and **Guǐ-Yǒu (癸酉)**, **Lesser Commerce (少征)** below **adds to Shao Yin (少陰)**—this occurs three times.

In **Wù-Zǐ (戊子)** and **Wù-Wǔ (戊午)**, **Great Commerce (太征)** above **temporarily governs Shao Yin (少陰)**;
In **Wù-Yín (戊寅)** and **Wù-Shēn (戊申)**, **Great Commerce (太征)** above **temporarily governs Shao Yang (少陽)**;
In **Bǐng-Chén (丙辰)** and **Bǐng-Xū (丙戌)**, **Great Feather (太羽)** above **temporarily governs Tai Yang (太陽)**—this occurs three times.

In **Dīng-Sì (丁巳)** and **Dīng-Hài (丁亥)**, **Lesser Horn (少角)** above **temporarily governs Jue Yin (厥陰)**;
In **Yǐ-Mǎo (乙卯)** and **Yǐ-Yǒu (乙酉)**, **Lesser Commerce (少商)** above **temporarily governs Yang Ming (陽明)**;
In **Jǐ-Chǒu (己丑)** and **Jǐ-Wèi (己未)**, **Lesser Palace (少宮)** above **temporarily governs Tai Yin (太陰)**—this occurs three times.
**Excluding these twenty-four years**, there is neither addition nor temporary governance."*

The Emperor said: *"What does ‘addition’ mean?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"When **excess aligns with addition**, it corresponds to **Heaven’s Correspondence**; when **deficiency aligns with addition**, it corresponds to **Yearly Assembly (歲會)**."*

The Emperor said: *"What does ‘temporary governance’ mean?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"Whether **excess or deficiency**, they are all called **Heaven’s Correspondence**, but their manifestations vary in degree—**disease forms** range from mild to severe, and **life and death** occur at different times."*

The Emperor said: *"Master, you speak of **using cold to counter excess cold** and **using heat to counter excess heat**—I do not yet understand this. I wish to hear what is meant by **‘countering at a distance’**."*

Qī Bó replied: *"**Heat should not clash with heat**, and **cold should not clash with cold**—conformity brings harmony, while opposition brings illness. One must **revere and avoid** these, as they align with **the seasons and the Six Positions**.
In the **months when the Four Seasons rule**, if **medicines, food, clothing, or thermal properties** align in **heat or cold**, they should all be avoided.
If one **contradicts the Four Seasons** in such alignment, it is like **adding water to water or fire to fire**—**cold diseases** will arise."*

The Emperor said: *"How about **warmth and coolness**? Since they are between **heat and cold**, can they be lightly contravened?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"If the **ruling *qi* is hot**, do not use **hot**—do not contravene;
If the **ruling *qi* is cold**, do not use **cold**—do not contravene;
If the **ruling *qi* is cool**, do not use **cool**—do not contravene;
If the **ruling *qi* is warm**, do not use **warm**—do not contravene;
If the **ruling *qi* aligns with its master**, do not contravene;
If the **ruling *qi* differs from its master**, then **lightly contravene**—this is called **the Four Reverences**, and the people must **heed them carefully**."*

The Emperor said: *"Good. What of those who contravene?"*

Qī Bó replied: *"When the **Heavenly *qi* reverses its season**, one may follow the season’s due course—
if the reversal is extreme, one may still follow the season’s due course.
If the **ruling *qi* overpowers its master**, then contravention is permissible.
When summer’s heat is extreme, one may use **hot to treat hot**,
but if cold *qi* is not extreme, one must not contravene it.
**Balance** should be the standard—
yet one must not overdo it.
When *qi* is balanced, the excess ceases;
when excess occurs, disease arises.
Excess leading to disease is akin to contravention—
this is called **the reversal of perverse *qi**.*

When *qi* moves and overpowers, this is called **perverse *qi**;
when guest *qi* overpowers the host, it must be resisted.
Within the **Six Steps**, when *qi* should be cold but is hot,
should be hot but is cold,
should be warm but is cool,
should be cool but is warm—
this is called **the perverse victory of the Six Steps**.

When winter reverses to warmth,
summer reverses to chill,
autumn reverses to heat,
spring reverses to cool—
this is called **the perverse victory of the Four Seasons**.

When victory occurs, one must reverse its *qi* to restore balance.
Thus it is said:
**Do not betray Heaven’s truth**,
**do not defy the *qi*’s nature**,
**do not aid its excess**,
**do not assist its return**—
this is called **the supreme governance**.

**Heaven’s truth** refers to the fixed due times.
**Aid and assist** both mean to reinforce.
To diligently uphold Heaven’s truth
is the **supreme, wondrous principle**."*

In general, these fixed cycles of **jì** (纪), where **shèngfù** (胜复) and **zhènghuà** (正化) occur, all have constant numbers that must be observed. Thus, those who grasp their essence can summarize them in a single phrase, while those who do not may wander endlessly without conclusion. This is what is meant.

The Emperor said: Good. Does the **qì** (气) of the Five **Yùn** (运) also follow the yearly cycle?
**Fù** (复) means **bào** (报) retaliation. When one **yùn** (运) prevails excessively over another, the latter retaliates in turn.
**Qí** (岐伯) said: When **qì** (气) is suppressed to its extreme, it erupts. It waits for its appointed time to act.
**Dài** (待), referring to the **wǔ** (五) and **chā** (差) divisions of position, means that the excesses arise in the **Chén-Yǐ** (辰巳) phase for great warmth, in the **Shēn-Wèi** (申未) phase for great heat, in the **Xū-Hài** (戌亥) phase for great coolness, and in the **Chǒu-Yín** (丑寅) phase for great coldness. The upper phases trigger the **shèngfù** (胜复) dominance, also awaiting the **qì** (气) to manifest, hence the saying "waits for its appointed time."
*The New Correction states:* The character **qì** (气) after *dài* (待) may be a misprint for *shèng* (胜).

The Emperor said: I beg to ask further about this.
**Qí** (岐伯) said: The **qì** (气) of the Five **Phases** (**wǔcháng** 五常), when too excessive or insufficient, manifests differently. When a year is too excessive, its manifestation is early; when insufficient, its manifestation is late.

The Emperor said: I wish to hear this fully.
**Qí** (岐伯) said: Excessive manifestations are sudden, while insufficient ones are gradual. Sudden excesses lead to severe diseases, while gradual ones result in milder afflictions. This refers to the **qì** (气) of the **Phases** clashing and restraining one another.

The Emperor said: How do these excessive or insufficient manifestations quantify?
**Qí** (岐伯) said: When excessive, the numbers are complete; when insufficient, the numbers are incomplete. Earth is always incomplete.
**Shù** (数), referring to the transformations and movements of the Five **Phases**, are as follows: Water has one, Fire has two, Wood has three, Metal has four, and Earth has five.
**Chéngshù** (成数), meaning complete numbers, are Water six, Fire seven, Wood eight, Metal nine, and Earth five. Hence, Earth is always incomplete.
**Shùshēng** (数生), meaning incomplete numbers, are determined by the relative abundance or scarcity of each **Phase**’s transformations. Thus, the auspicious or inauspicious days of governance, virtue, and **shèngfù** (胜复) are all calculated based on these numbers, including the finest measurements of inches, centimeters, and millimeters. This is the overarching principle for all **Phases**.

The Emperor said: How do these manifestations occur?
**Qí** (岐伯) said: When Earth **qì** (气) is suppressed, it erupts with **Yángǔ** (严谷) thunderous tremors and **Jīnyīng** (震惊) startling disturbances. The **Léiyīn** (雷殷) thunder and **qì** (气) clash, while the sky darkens with **āihūn huánghēi** (埃昏黄黑) dust and murkiness, transforming into **báiqì** (白气) white vapors that rise swiftly and deeply.
**Yù** (郁), meaning suppressed, refers to the extreme intensity of Earth **qì** (气). Hence, even the **tiānqì** (天气) has limits. Though its suppression may rage, it eventually subsides, so even when suppressed, it erupts in fury. Earth’s transformations are blocked, leading to scorching heat without rain, and Wood’s excess surpasses its limits, causing the suppressed Earth to erupt violently.
Earth’s nature is tranquil and static, yet when it moves, thunderous rains descend, and the clashing **qì** (气) of Wood and Earth then **xiūjiě** (休解) subsides and resolves.
The *Yì* (易) says: *"Thunder and rain act, and resolution follows."* This is what is meant.
Though Earth may erupt alone, Wood still restrains it, so only **jīnyīng** (震惊) tremors occur within the **qì** (气) clash, and its voice cannot yet rise far.
Hence the saying: *"Thunder and **yīn** (殷) clash in the **qì** (气)."* **Qì** (气) clash refers to Earth’s **qì** (气) reaching the peaks of the mountains.
The *Shī* (诗) says: *"The thunder is resounding."* This is the thunder and rain generated within the mountains. Earth’s **qì** (气) is suppressed and intense, while the Heavenly Wood restrains it. The plains, where Earth is thin, are perpetually dry and arid, unable to erupt first. The mountains, where Earth is thick, have abundant dampness and deep transformations, so their Earth **qì** (气) erupts first in fury.
Striking rocks sends sparks flying, and torrential waters surge forth. Rivers overflow and spread widely, while fields and pastures are submerged by **tǔjù** (土驹) Earth currents. Swift winds and sudden rains cause the banks to collapse and mountains to transform, with great floods surging horizontally and jagged rocks erupting violently. High peaks and hollow valleys—when rocks are struck, sparks fly first, followed by the rush of torrential waters.

The **Hong**—greatness—when mighty rivers overflow, their currents spreading across the plains, drowning and drifting all within their vast embrace. When the great waters recede, the stones and earth stand precariously, as though herds of **tǔjù** (Earth currents) scatter across the fields.

Speaking of **tǔ** (Earth), it is akin to sand and stone. When its transformative **qì** (化气) spreads, it brings timely rains—beginning to generate, to grow, to transform, and to complete. This is **tǔhuà** (土化), Earth’s transformation. When Earth’s **qì** is restrained, its transformative power fails to spread. At the extreme of decline, there comes renewal; at the extreme of bending, there comes extension. In times of discord, its transformative **qì** arises and spreads across all things, raining in season, nourishing grasses and trees to completion. *Shàn* (善) here means "timely."

When transformative **qì** is scarce and growth **qì** has passed, then all things begin to generate, to grow, to transform, and to complete. These four beginnings reveal that the formation of all things is delayed. Thus, the people suffer from abdominal distension, intestinal rumbling, and frequent bowel movements; in severe cases, they experience heart pain, flank spasms, vomiting, and cholera-like disorders, with drinking leading to diarrhea and edema, heaviness in the body—all signs of **pí rè** (spleen heat).

Then come the **yúnbēn yǔfǔ** (云奔雨府), with clouds surging and mists enveloping the morning sun, while mountains and marshes grow hazy—this is its eruption, governed by the four **qì** (四气). The **yǔfǔ** (雨府) is the domain of **Tài Yīn** (太阴). **Āi** (埃) is a thin, cloud-like vapor—sometimes faint as silk threads rising, sometimes dense as a thin mist. When dense, it appears near; when faint, it appears far. The four **qì** refer to the thirty-one days after the summer solstice until the autumn equinox.

Clouds stretch across the heavens like a crown, drifting and forming, vanishing and reappearing—this is the precursor to **fú** (怫). When clouds stretch across the sky like a mountain’s crown, with rocks and valleys shrouded in thin layers, appearing and disappearing, revealing Earth’s presence, the signs of **fú** are already clear—all observed at dawn. *Fúyóu* (浮游) is observed by gazing before noon.

When **jīn** (Metal) erupts, the sky clears and the earth brightens, the wind sharpens, and great cold descends. Grasses and trees wither in dryness, and the **shāoshāo** (雾雾) mists rise repeatedly as **shāqì** (杀气) arrives, turning plants pale and dry. Metal thus makes its sound. *Dà liáng* (大凉) is the onset of cold. *Jǔ* (举) means "to take effect." *Fúyīn* (浮姻) is dry **qì**. *Shāqì* (杀气) is frost. The true arrival of **shāqì** occurs between the hours of **chǒu** (丑) and **chén** (辰), or at **mǎo** (卯) and **shēn** (申) for prolonged durations. Its arrival is marked by yellow, red, and black hues mingling. Unable to endure the killing **qì**, grasses and trees turn pale and dry. *Cāng* (苍) is a thin greenish hue. Thus, the people suffer from coughing, heart and flank distension drawing toward the lower abdomen, sudden violent pain preventing turning, dry throat, and a sickly, ashen complexion—Metal overcoming Wood.

When mountains and marshes wither and Earth hardens with frost and salt, **fó** (佛) erupts, its **qì** being the fifth. When summer’s **huǒ** (fire) rages excessively and timely rains fail, mountains and marshes dry up, and the Earth’s surface congeals into white, salty frost. The five **qì** span from the autumn equinox to fifty-four days after the winter solstice. Nighttime frost and morning dew bring a mournful sound from the forests—this is **fó**’s omen. When nighttime dew soaks the ground and morning winds howl, this is the sign of Metal’s eruption.

When **shuǐ** (Water) erupts, **yángqì** (阳气) opens, and **yīnqì** (阴气) surges violently, bringing great cold. Rivers and marshes freeze solid, cold clouds congeal into frost and snow. *Hánlíng* (寒零) is white **qì**. Its form resembles mist but does not disperse, falling to the ground like frost and snow, melting in sunlight. In severe cases, yellow and black vapors obscure the sky, mingling with **qì** until frost kills all—Water then reveals its **xiáng** (祥). Yellow and black are also turbid, malevolent **qì**. *Shuǐ* here refers to **qì**. *Xiáng* is great **xiáng**, also meaning springs emerging from flat ground. Thus, the people suffer from cold-induced heart pain, lumbar stiffness, stiff large joints, difficulty bending or stretching, frequent cold limbs, and abdominal fullness from stagnation—Yin overcoming Yang.

The **yang** light fails to govern, and stagnant **yīn** accumulates in emptiness, as white dust dims the sky—then it erupts. Its **qi** precedes and follows the two fires [of the heart and ministerial fire].

The **yīn** essence and water both ascend to receive the fire, so its eruption occurs before and after the sovereign and ministerial fires, just as the morning star follows the sun.

The **Tàixū** (太虚) probes the profound depths—its **qi** resembles scattered hemp fibers, faintly visible yet concealed, black with a faint yellow hue, a precursor to its outburst.

*Shēn xuán* (深玄) refers to its lofty, dark vastness. The **qi** is like dispersed hemp fibers, thin and barely perceptible.

After the *yín* hour and during the *mǎo* hour, or in summer months before the *chén* hour, it may also be observed.

When wood stagnates and erupts, the **Tàixū** fills with dusty haze, disturbing all things, and great winds arrive—roofs lift, beams snap, and wood transforms.

*Hùfā* (屋发) means the upturned *hóngwěn* (鸿吻) tiles rise. *Zhé mù* (折木) refers to great trees being uprooted and snapped, or suspended poles snapping mid-span. *Biàn* (变) means strange, anomalous wood forms arise from the earth.

Thus, the people suffer from stomach and *yuàn* (院) region pain radiating to the heart, upper support of the two flanks, *géyàn* (鬲咽) obstruction, inability to swallow food or drink. In severe cases, they experience ringing in the ears, dizziness, vertigo, and inability to recognize people, often collapsing suddenly in rigidity.

The sinews and bones stiffen and fail to function, and they fall unconscious without awareness.

The **Tàixū** darkens with pallid dust, blending into a single hue with the heavens and mountains.

「Sometimes it appears as a murky hue, with yellow and black *qi* gathering in chaotic layers, when no clouds rise to bring rain—yet the *hùfā* (屋发) disturbance erupts. Its *qi* (气) is erratic and without fixed pattern.

Its *qi* resembles dust or clouds, sometimes yellow and black in oppressive layers, still lingering within the **Tàixū** (太虚) yet distinctly anomalous from the usual. This is its portent.

Endless rivers stagnate, soft leaves turn shadowed, pines groan on high peaks, tigers roar amid mountain crags—these are the omens of its onset.
*Grǎo yǎn* (草偃) means the grass bows without wind. *Róu yè* (柔叶) refers to the white willow leaves. When leaves all reverse their sides without wind, this is called *chéng yīn* (呈阴).
All such signs indicate a mild or severe onset; severe cases erupt swiftly, mild ones slowly.

For mountain *hùfā* (候), one observes the pines and tigers; for cool *hùfā* (候), one watches the ephedra. In autumn and winter, one looks to the osmanthus and cicada leaves for its signs.

When *huǒ yù* (火郁) erupts, the **Tàixū** (太虚) swells with crimson *qi* (气), obscuring the **Dàmíng** (大明).
*Zhǒng yì* (肿翳) means the red *qi* (气). **Dàmíng** (大明) refers to the sun.

The **Tàixū** (太虚) text clarifies: The *zhǒng* (肿) character in the *jīngzhù* (经注) is likely erroneous.

During the *yánhuǒ* (炎火) season, when the **Dàshǔ** (大暑) arrives, the mountains and marshes blaze with flames, timber exudes sap, vast halls emit smoke, the earth rises with frost and salt, still waters grow murky, creeping plants turn withered yellow. The wind stirs confusion in speech, and dampness transforms afterward. The **Tàiyīn** (太阴) and **Tàiyáng** (太阳) dominate above, while cold dampness permeates the **Tàixū** (太虚). The heart’s *huǒ* (火) aligns with the heavens, yet it is suppressed and cannot manifest. When cold dampness prevails, the *huǒ* (火) rises with the seasons, and the yang *qi* (气) and fire’s radiance surge—thus, the mountains and marshes erupt in flames, well water diminishes, false and erroneous speech spreads, and rain arrives past its due time.
*Shīhuà* (湿化) comes afterward, meaning when the yang *qi* (气) is excessive and dominates its season, the *qi* (气) does not contend for primacy, so drought precedes rain.

Thus, the people suffer from *shǎo qì* (少气), sores and ulcers with flaccid swelling, pain in the flanks, abdomen, chest, and back, as well as the face and four limbs. Their anger is stifled, their chest distended, with ulcerated rashes, itching, vomiting, and retching. Paralysis, phlegm, and bone pain arise, and the joints may twitch. Feverish *zhùliè* (注下) malaria and *wēn shì* (温疟) cold malaria occur, with sudden abdominal agony, blood overflowing and pooling, semen becoming scanty. Their eyes turn red, their hearts burn hot—severe cases lead to suffocating haze, oppression, and torment, often resulting in sudden death.

When *huǒ yù* (火郁) rages, the earth and water *qi* (气) resist it, whether as host or guest, and none penetrate deeply—then there is no harm. But if heat overcomes cold, it becomes a force that crushes adversity, and since the heat originates from the heart, the spirit *qi* (神气) is isolated and endangered. If not swiftly treated, the vital essence will be exhausted, and death follows. The fire’s swift action is why sudden death occurs.»

When the day-night water cycle reaches its end, sweat moistens the *Xuànfǔ* [玄府], and then the outbreak occurs—its *qi* [气] manifests in four forms.
*The day-night water cycle* refers to the moment when the twenty-four *shí* [时] divisions of day and night are complete. *Dàwēn* [大温] is the next stage after heat. *Xuànfǔ* [玄府] refers to the void of sweat—when sweat permeates this void, it means the body steams with early heat. At the moment the cycle ends, *yin* [阴] is most potent here, yet there is no cool *qi*—this shows *yin* cannot overcome *yang*, and since heat has already sprouted, it must erupt in fury.

*—New Annotation:* How does the soil and fire together unleash these four *qi*? Fire has two positions: one where water triggers its eruption, and another where great heat emerges in the *shēn-wèi* [申未] hours. Thus, the outbreak of suppressed fire occurs across the four seasons.

When movement reaches its peak, stillness follows; when *yang* reaches its extreme, *yin* returns. The *shī* [湿] order transforms and solidifies. Fire’s fury dries the metal—when *yang* exceeds its limit, it fears fire and seeks refuge in the earth. Earth saves the scorched metal, unleashing gusty winds followed by timely rains, restoring balance to the *qi*. Thus, all things grow, transform, and mature.

Peak strength inevitably reverses; even flourishing cannot endure forever. When flowers bloom and water congeals, when mountains and rivers freeze, when the sun blazes at noon—these are the omens of *fú* [怫] before its arrival. When the sovereign fire reigns, cold descends—thus, when the fire season erupts, it too awaits its time. Only after the signs of *fú* appear does it respond, for all things are observed at their extremes before eruption. Wood’s outbreak has no set time; water follows fire’s lead.

The signs appear first, the eruption follows—thus, the response precedes the outbreak. Things cannot remain perpetually strong; when strength peaks, the *fú-qi* [怫气] arises. Suppression leads to eruption—this is the nature of *qi*. If one carefully observes the timing, illness can be predicted. Missing the season reverses the year, and the Five *qi* [五气] stagnate, halting generation, transformation, and storage. Governance then falters.

If humans lose their proper timing, then prognostications lack precision.

The Emperor asked: *"When water erupts, it brings hail and snow; when earth erupts, it brings gusty winds; when wood erupts, it brings destruction and breaking; when metal erupts, it brings clarity; when fire erupts, it brings smoky darkness. What *qi* causes these phenomena?"*

Gēbó replied: *"The *qi* varies in intensity—mild eruptions align with their own *qi*, while severe ones encompass the *qi* below. By examining the *qi* beneath, the signs become apparent. Each of the Six *qi* has a supporting *qi* beneath it: beneath fire’s position lies water’s *qi*; beneath water’s position lies earth’s *qi*; beneath earth’s position lies wood’s *qi*; beneath wood’s position lies metal’s *qi*; beneath metal’s position lies fire’s *qi*; beneath the sovereign’s position lies *yin* essence. By observing the *qi* below, the patterns emerge.*

*Thus, when an eruption encompasses the *qi* beneath, it differs from its original form."*

The Emperor said: *"Excellent. When the Five *qi* erupt out of their proper season, what does this mean?"* —*"Out of their correct month."*

Gēbó replied: *"This is called *chā* [差]."* —*"It refers to the deviation from the proper seasonal month."*

*—New Annotation:* According to the *Zhìzhēn Yàodà Lùn* [至真要大论], *"When counteracting *qi* arise, their movements are out of season—sometimes arriving late, sometimes early. What is the reason?"*

Gēbó replied: *"The generation and transformation of *qi*, along with their waxing and waning, differ. The applications of cold, heat, warmth, and coolness vary in intensity, governed by the four cardinal directions. Thus, *yang*’s movement begins with warmth and peaks in summer, while *yin*’s movement begins with coolness and peaks in winter. Spring, summer, autumn, and winter each have their own divisions. Hence, the *Dàyào* [大要] states: 'The spring’s warmth becomes summer’s heat; autumn’s fury becomes winter’s rage. Scarcity follows the four directions, and omens converge—its end is visible, its beginning known.'*

*That text discusses the irregularity of counteracting *qi*; this one addresses the Five *qi* erupting out of season. Though their subjects differ—counteracting *qi* and Five eruptions—the meaning of *chā* [差] remains the same."*

The Emperor asked: *"Does this deviation have a fixed measure?"* —*"In days."*

Gēbó replied: *"After the seasons pass, it is thirty days with an excess of eighty-seven *kè* [刻] and a half."* —*"After" refers to the four seasons. The deviation is thirty days plus eighty-seven *kè* and a half, for the *qi* remains intense even after its expected departure.* —*"Degree" refers to days. Now, the seasons have passed.*

*—New Annotation:* The detailed note states that *"eighty-seven kè and a half"* should read *"forty-three kè and forty minutes."*

The Emperor asked: *"When the *qi* arrives early or late, what does this mean?"* —*"When it arrives before its expected time or after."*

Gēbó replied: *"Excessive *qi* arrives early; deficient *qi* arrives late—this is the norm in prognostication."*

The Emperor asked: *"What does it mean when the *qi* arrives precisely on time?"*

Gēbó replied: *"If it is neither excessive nor deficient, it arrives at the proper time. Otherwise, it is an omen of disaster."* —*"On time" refers to the exact day and *kè* [刻] of its expected arrival. Any arrival that deviates from this—whether early or late—is a sign of calamity.*

The Emperor said: *"Excellent. What does it mean when the *qi* transforms out of season?"*

Gēbó replied: *"Excessive *qi* transforms in advance of its time; deficient *qi* transforms after its time. Winter rains, spring coolness, autumn heat, and winter coldness—these are all cases of *qi* reverting to their own dominant phase."*

The Emperor asked: *"The Four Seasons’ *qi*, when they arrive, may be early or late, high or low, left or right. How should one interpret these variations?"*

Gēbó replied: *"Their movement may be contrary or顺顺, their arrival delayed or swift. Thus, excessive *qi* transforms in advance of the natural order, while deficient *qi* transforms after it. When *qi* is in excess, it transforms early; when *qi* is deficient, it transforms late."*

The Emperor asked: *"I wish to understand what is meant by 'its movement.'"*

Gēbó replied: *"Spring *qi* moves westward, summer *qi* moves northward, autumn *qi* moves eastward, and winter *qi* moves southward. Observe how all things grow, flourish, wither, and store themselves accordingly. Thus, spring *qi* begins from below, autumn *qi* begins from above, summer *qi* begins from the center, and winter *qi* begins from the periphery."*

The Emperor asked: *"How does the Dao/Way of the four seasons manifest in the highest or lowest places, and in the left or right? What are the signs of their arrival?"*

Gēbó replied: *"Spring *qi* begins from the left, autumn *qi* begins from the right, winter *qi* begins from behind, and summer *qi* begins from the front. This is the constant Dao/Way of the four seasons’ transformations. By observing things, one may discern this truth clearly.

Thus, in the highest lands, winter *qi* abides, while in the lowest lands, spring *qi* abides. On the peaks of lofty mountains, ice and snow linger even in high summer, and in the murky depths of valleys, grass sprouts in severe winter—these examples suffice to illustrate the principle of their constant presence."*

The Emperor said: *"Well spoken. The *yin* and *yang* of Heaven and Earth are visible to the eye—why then must one ponder the obscure and delve into laws, straining one’s intellect and wearying the heart without gain?"*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"How do the five phases and six *qi* manifest in their transformations? What is the regular sequence of the six phases’ transformations and six variations’ cycles?"*

Gēbó replied: *"The six *qi* follow their regular cycles: each has its transformation, its variation, its dominance, its retreat, its efficacy, and its disorder. Their signs differ according to their season. What does Your Majesty wish to know?"*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear it all."*

Gēbó said: *"Let me expound fully. *Exhaustive* means *complete*."*

When the six *qi* arrive, the following transformations occur:

- Where *gùyīn* (厥阴) arrives, it brings *peaceful equilibrium* (和平), marking the *first* *qi* of the year, the transformation of *wood*.
- Where *shàoyīn* (少阴) arrives, it brings *radiant warmth* (暄), marking the *second* *qi*, the *master fire*.
- Where *tàiyīn* (太阴) arrives, it brings *dusty and damp* (埃褥), marking the *fourth* *qi*, the transformation of *earth*.
- Where *shàoyáng* (少阳) arrives, it brings *scorching heat* (炎暑), marking the *third* *qi*, the *minister fire*.
- Where *yángmíng* (阳明) arrives, it brings *clear and vigorous* (清劲), marking the *fifth* *qi*, the transformation of *metal*.
- Where *tàiyáng* (太阳) arrives, it brings *cold dew* (寒露), marking the *final* *qi* of the year, the transformation of *water*.

This is the constant Dao/Way of seasonal transformations.

The regular signs of the four seasons’ *qi* are as follows:

- When *gùyīn* arrives, it manifests as the *wind palace* (风府), and as *gentle cracks* (莹启)—*gentle* refers to *subtle fissures*, while *cracks* refers to *opening and scattering*.
- When *shàoyīn* arrives, it manifests as the *great fire palace* (大火府), and as *spreading and flourishing*.
- When *tàiyīn* arrives, it manifests as the *rain palace* (雨府), and as *fullness and abundance*—all things receiving *earth*’s transformation become plump and replete. Moreover, the *rain*’s boundary is a verdant green, and its pattern resembles concentric rings, making clear the transformation of *abundance*.
- When *shàoyáng* arrives, it manifests as the *heat palace* (热府), and as *emergence and movement*—those storing heat emerge in motion.
- When *yángmíng* arrives, it manifests as the *office of execution* (司杀府), and as *replenishing and withering*—*replenishing* refers to *replacement* or *change*, while *withering* refers to *substitution* or *succession*.
- When *tàiyáng* arrives, it manifests as the *cold palace* (寒府), and as *return and storage*—all things retreat to storage when cold.

This is the constant Dao/Way of *qi*’s governance.

The transformations of the six *qi* are as follows:

- Where *gùyīn* arrives, it generates *wind* and ends in *stillness*—wind arises from its transformation, hence *wind generated*; *stillness* means *tranquility*.
- Where *shàoyīn* arrives, it generates *heat* and then *cold*—heat arises from its transformation, hence *heat generated*; *yin* essence ascends from above, so the middle phase becomes cold.
- Where *tàiyīn* arrives, it generates *moisture* and ends in *pouring rain*—moisture arises from its transformation, hence *moisture generated*; *tàiyīn* being above, it culminates in *pouring rain*.
- Where *shàoyáng* arrives, it generates *fire* and ends in *steaming and dampness*—fire arises from its transformation, hence *fire generated*; *yang* being above, it culminates in *steaming moisture*.
- Where *yángmíng* arrives, it generates *dryness* and ends in *freezing*—dryness arises from its transformation, hence *dryness generated*; *yin* being above, it culminates in *freezing*.
- Where *tàiyáng* arrives, it generates *cold* and then *warmth*—cold arises from its transformation, hence *cold generated*; *yang* being within, the middle phase becomes warm.

This is the constant Dao/Way of *virtue/power*’s transformations.

The six transformations each govern their respective forms:

- *Wind* generates *hair-like* forms,
- *Heat* generates *feathery* forms,
- *Moisture* generates *protective* forms,
- *Fire* generates *winged* forms,
- *Dryness* generates *shell-like* forms,
- *Cold* generates *scaly* forms.

Each of these six transformations is the *master* seasonal *qi* and the *questionable* *qi* of its year, and their transformations generate their respective forms without fail.

「If not for *virtue/power*’s transformations, there would be no ability to generate changes. (翮, *xié*, pronounced *Hú-gé* cut)

When *guìyīn* (厥阴) arrives, it brings *hair-like* transformations (毛化), affecting beings with hair.
When *shàoyīn* (少阴) arrives, it brings *winged* transformations (羽化), affecting creatures with wings or feathery flight.
When *tàiyīn* (太阴) arrives, it brings *protective* transformations (保化), affecting beings without hair, wings, scales, or shells.
When *shàoyáng* (少阳) arrives, it brings *winged* transformations (羽化), such as thin, luminous wings or insect-like appendages—these are not the *feathers* (翎羽) of birds.
When *yángmíng* (阳明) arrives, it brings *shell-like* transformations (介化), affecting creatures with armored shells.
When *tàiyáng* (太阳) arrives, it brings *scaly* transformations (鳞化), affecting beings with scales.

This is the constant Dao/Way of *virtue/power*’s transformations.

When *guìyīn* arrives, it brings *generative* transformations (生化), *warm* transformations (温化).
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it brings *flourishing* transformations (荣化), *radiant* transformations (暄化).
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it brings *soaking* transformations (濡化), *moist* transformations (湿化).
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it brings *lush* transformations (茂化), *heat* transformations (热化).
When *yángmíng* arrives, it brings *solid* transformations (坚化), *freezing* transformations (冻化).
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it brings *concealing* transformations (藏化), *cold* transformations (寒化).

This is the constant Dao/Way of *virtue/power*’s governance.

When *guìyīn* arrives, it manifests as *whirling fury* (飘怒), great freezing; *whirling fury* (飘怒) is of *Wood* (木). Great freezing is the *Metal qi* (金气) that follows beneath.
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it manifests as *great radiance* (大暄), cold; *great radiance* (大暄) is the *Lord of Fire* (君火). Cold is the *yin essence* (阴精) that follows beneath.
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it manifests as *thunderous downpour* (雷霆骤注), violent winds; *thunderous downpour* (雷霆骤注) is of *Earth* (土). Violent winds are the *Wood qi* (木气) that follows beneath.
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it manifests as *whirling winds and scorching flames* (飘风墦燎), frost congealing; *whirling winds* (飘风) are winds that spin and turn. Frost congealing is the *Water qi* (水气) that follows beneath.
When *yángmíng* arrives, it manifests as *scattering and falling* (散落), warmth; *scattering and falling* (散落) is of *Metal* (金). Warmth is the *Fire qi* (火气) that follows beneath.
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it manifests as *cold snow and hail* (寒雪冰雹), white dust (白埃). Cold snow and hail are of *Water* (水). White dust is the *Earth qi* (土气) that follows beneath.

This is the constant Dao/Way of *qi*’s variations.
Variation refers to the *qi* deviating from its usual state to become extreme.
If extreme variations persist, then the *qi* beneath will also act in conjunction, hence none of these are the original *qi*.

When *guìyīn* arrives, it manifests as *twisting and agitation* (挠动), *welcoming and following* (迎随); these are the nature of *Wind* (風).
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it manifests as *high and bright flames* (高明焰), *perfuming* (熏); flames are *yang* flames. *Perfuming* (熏) is of reddish-yellow hue.
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it manifests as *deep and hidden* (沉阴), white dust (白埃), and *obscured and gloomy* (晦暝); this is darkness and dimness.
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it manifests as *radiance and visibility* (光显), *scarlet clouds* (彤云), and *dullness* (曛); *radiance* (光显) is lightning, flowing light, brightness. *Scarlet* (彤) is red. (The *yin* essence of *shàoyīn* aligns with this.)
When *yángmíng* arrives, it manifests as *smoky dust* (烟埃), frost (霜), *sharp and piercing* (劲切), and *chilling sounds* (凄鸣); this is *killing qi* (杀气).
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it manifests as *rigid and unyielding* (刚固), *sharp and piercing* (坚芒), and *erection* (立); this is *cold* transformations (寒化).

This is the constant Dao/Way of *virtue/power*’s decrees.
When *virtue/power*’s decrees are carried out, all things obey without resistance.

When *guìyīn* arrives, it manifests as *urgent bowel movements* (里急); this is due to *tendons and sinews contracting and shrinking* (筋练缩).
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it manifests as *ulcers and carbuncles* (疡胗), body heat; this is due to *Fire qi* (火气).
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it manifests as *accumulated fluids and blocked respiration* (积饮否隔); this is of *Earth qi* (土气).
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it manifests as *sneezing and vomiting* (嚏呕), *sores and ulcers* (疮疡); this is due to *Fire qi* (火气).
When *yángmíng* arrives, it manifests as *floating and empty* (浮虚); this is a thin swelling that collapses when pressed.
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it manifests as *difficulty in bending and stretching* (屈伸不利).

This is the constant Dao/Way of disease.

When *yin* arrives, it manifests as *branch-like pain* (支痛); *branch* (支) refers to *obstructed pillars* (柱妨).
