When *shàoyīn* arrives, it manifests as *startle and confusion* (惊惑), *aversion to cold* (恶寒), *shivering and trembling* (战栗), *delirium* (谵妄); *delirium* (谵) refers to *speaking incoherently* (乱言), and the *shivering* (栗) should be corrected to *fierce* (慓).
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it manifests as *congestion and fullness* (蓄满).
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it manifests as *restlessness and agitation* (惊躁), *blindness and sudden illness* (瞀昧暴病).
When *yángmíng* arrives, it manifests as *□* (missing character), *damp and cold in the inguinal region* (炕阴股膝), *□□* (missing characters), *afflictions of the lower orifices* (腑足病).
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it manifests as *lumbar pain* (腰痛).

This is the constant Dao/Way of disease.

When *guìyīn* arrives, it manifests as *irritability and harshness* (緛戾).
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it manifests as *melancholy and hallucinations* (悲妄), *bleeding from the nose* (衄), *stained blood* (蔑); *stained* (蔑) also refers to *grease* (脂).
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it also manifests as *strong movement* (行劲).
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it manifests as *mid-abdominal fullness* (中满), *intermittent diarrhea and vomiting* (霍乱吐下).
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it manifests as *throat obstruction* (喉痹), *ear ringing and vomiting* (耳呜呕涌); *涌* (涌) refers to *regurgitation of food* (溢食不下).
When *yángmíng* arrives, it manifests as *rib pain and flaking skin* (胁痛皴揭), *body skin □* (missing character); *皴揭* (皴揭) refers to *flaking and peeling*.
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it manifests as *sleeping perspiration* (寝汗), *spasm* (痉); *sleeping perspiration* (寝汗) refers to *perspiration occurring between the chest and throat* (胸嗌), *neck and armpit* (颈掖) during sleep. Commonly mistakenly called *stealing perspiration* (盗汗). (痉, pronounced *Jù-yǐng* cut.)」

The common manifestations of disease are as follows:

When *juéyīn* arrives, it causes **rib pain and vomiting with diarrhea** (胁痛呕泄); *泄* (泄) refers to **diarrhea** (利).
When *shàoyīn* arrives, it causes **uncontrollable laughter and speech** (语笑).
When *tàiyīn* arrives, it causes **heavy, bloated swelling** (重驸肿); *驸肿* (驸肿) refers to **floating, soft edema that does not recede upon pressure** (肉泛#40, 按之不起).
When *shàoyáng* arrives, it causes **sudden gushing** (暴注), **□ spasm, □ violent death** (□瘛痣暴死).
When *yángmíng* arrives, it causes **□ sneezing** (□嚏).
When *tàiyáng* arrives, it causes **proliferating discharge and restricted movement** (流泄禁止).

These are the common manifestations of disease.

In all twelve such variations, **virtue is repaid with virtue, transformation with transformation, governance with governance, and command with command** (报德以德，报化以化，报政以政，报令以令). The **Dao/Way** ascends when high, descends when low, lags when delayed, precedes when early, centralizes when in the middle, and externalizes when outward—this is the **constant principle of position** (位之常). When the **Dao/Way** responds to virtue and transformation, it refers to the **heavenly-earthly qi** (天地气). When high, low, early, delayed, central, or outward, it refers to the **origins of disease** (生病所). The **yin and yang of the hands** (手之阴阳) are of **high qi** (其气高), while the **yin and yang of the feet** (足之阴阳) are of **low qi** (其气下). The **foot *tàiyáng*** (足太阳) **qi** is located **behind the body** (气在身后), the **foot *yángmíng*** (足阳明) **qi** is located **in front of the body** (气在身前), the **foot *shàoyīn*, *tàiyīn*, and *juéyīn*** (足少阴、太阴#41、厥阴) **qi** are located **within the body** (气在身中), and the **foot *shàoyáng*** (足少阳) **qi** is located **at the body’s sides** (气在身侧). Each follows its own position in speech, and **changes in qi generate disease symptoms** (气变生病象).

Thus, when **wind prevails, it causes movement, unrest** (风胜则动，不宁也).

The newly corrected text states: *"Examine the passage from 'Wind prevails, it causes movement' to 'Humidity prevails, it causes dampness and diarrhea'—it overlaps with the text of *The Grand Treatise on the Correspondence of Yin and Yang* (*阴阳应象大论*), yet the annotations differ.*

When **heat prevails**, it causes **swelling**. Heat prevailing over **qi** manifests as **erythema and purplish discoloration** (丹缥), over **blood** as **abscesses and pus**, and over **flesh and bone** as **hard, fixed swellings** (驸肿), which do not recede upon pressure.

When **dryness prevails**, it causes **dryness**. Dryness on the **exterior** causes **wrinkled, roughened skin**, while dryness on the **interior** causes **exhaustion of essence and blood**. When dryness affects **qi and body fluids**, the flesh becomes dry and the skin adheres to the bones.

When **cold prevails**, it causes **floating**—meaning the affected area rises upon palpation and subsides when released.

When **humidity prevails**, it causes **dampness and diarrhea**; in severe cases, it leads to **water retention and fixed swellings** (驸肿). *Dampness and diarrhea* refers to **fluid regulation**; *fixed swellings* mean the flesh is **distended**, and upon pressure, it sinks and does not rebound. *Water retention* causes **fluid to escape into the skin**.

These changes follow the **location of the qi** in their manifestations.

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear their applications."*

Gebi replied: *"The functions of the six qi each return to what they do not overcome and transform. 'Functions' refers to their **application of transformative qi**.*

Thus, **Tàiyīn’s damp transformation** applies to **Tàiyáng**; **Tàiyáng’s cold transformation** applies to **Shàoyīn**; **Shàoyīn’s heat transformation** applies to **Yángmíng**; **Yángmíng’s dry transformation** applies to **Juéyīn**; **Juéyīn’s wind transformation** applies to **Tàiyīn**. Each governs its position to **diagnose accordingly**."

The Emperor said: *"What if they remain in their proper positions?"*

Gebi replied: *"When they remain in their proper positions, they undergo **constant transformation**."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to know their locations."*

Gebi replied: *"By determining their positions, the corresponding month can be known. Following the qi’s location to establish direction, the six divisions of time and space will show no discrepancy."*

The Emperor said: *"How do the six positions of qi manifest in terms of excess and deficiency?"*

Gebi replied: *"They differ in excess and deficiency. **Excessive qi** arrives **gradually and steadily**, while **deficient qi** is **sudden and fleeting**. Though strong in onset, it cannot endure, hence its **violence and absence**."* (*Absence* means **non-existence**.)

The Emperor said: *"How do the qi of Heaven and Earth manifest in excess and deficiency?"*

Gebi replied: *"When Heaven’s qi is insufficient, Earth’s qi follows; when Earth’s qi is insufficient, Heaven’s qi follows. The **cyclical sequence** (*运*) operates within this, always preceding.*

*Sequence* refers to **Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water**, each governing the year. When Earth’s qi prevails, the **yearly sequence ascends**; when Heaven’s qi prevails, the **yearly sequence descends**. Ascension and descent of the sequence always precede **transformation and decline**.

What is not overcome **returns to harmony**; following the sequence, it generates disease. If it strays from its position, **variation arises**, and variation leads to **disease**.

Thus, when the **upper prevails**, Heaven’s qi descends below; when the **lower prevails**, Earth’s qi ascends above. *Prevails* means **excess**. When the upper is excessive, it **descends of its own accord**; when the lower is excessive, it **ascends of its own accord**. Excess and deficiency shift reciprocally—this is the **constant of qi**."

The newly corrected text states: *"According to *The Grand Treatise on the Six Microcosmic Principles* (*六微旨大论*), it says: 'Ascend until descending, descending until ascending. The descending refers to Heaven; the ascending refers to Earth.' When Heaven’s qi descends, it flows into Earth; when Earth’s qi ascends, it surges into Heaven. Thus, **high and low attract each other**, and **ascension and descent follow**, giving rise to **variation and change**—this is also the principle of ascension and descent.

Excess or deficiency **diverges from its proper measure**. When excessive, the **transformation and decline are pronounced**; when deficient, they are **subdued**. The responses of excess and deficiency vary—**subtle or severe**.

The subtle show **minor discrepancies**; the severe show **major discrepancies**. Severe cases may **displace the position** and **exchange the qi**, leading to **great variation and disease onset**.

*The Essential Treatise* (*大要*) states: *'Severe cases measure five parts; subtle cases measure seven parts—discrepancies are thus visible.'* This is what is meant.

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."* The text states: *'Do not apply heat to heat, nor cold to cold.'* I wish to avoid both **excessive cold and excessive heat**—how should I proceed?"

Gebi replied: *"Your question is thorough! **Inducing sweating** does not apply excessive heat; **purging or wrapping** does not apply excessive cold. Sweating **depletes heat**, so using heat does not **prolong heat**; diarrhea **depletes cold**, so using cold does not **prolong cold**. Both methods ensure the pathogen does not **linger internally**.

Thus, in summer, heat may be applied; in winter, cold may be applied. **Without sweating or purging**, there is no need to fear contraindications—this is **reckless treatment**, forbidden by principle. All such applications are **used only when unavoidable**."*

The newly corrected text states: *"According to *The Grand Treatise on Supreme Truth* (*至真要大论*), it says: 'Inducing sweating does not apply excessive heat; avoid violating **warmth and coolness**.'*

The Emperor said: *"If there is no sweating or purging, yet one violates cold or heat, what happens?"*

Gebi replied: *"Internal **cold and heat pathogens** worsen the disease. **Adding water to water**, **adding fire to fire**—this is sufficient to **generate new illness**, let alone exacerbating the original disease!"*

The Emperor said: *"How does this apply to those without disease?"*

Gebi replied: *"For the **disease-free**, violating prohibitions **can still induce illness**; how much more so for the **already ill**, who seek **light treatment**—is this not difficult?"*

The Emperor said: *"What of those who are **vulnerable to disease**?"*

Gebi replied: *"Avoiding excessive heat leads to **heat onset**; avoiding excessive cold leads to **cold onset**. When cold arrives, it causes **abdominal hardness, distension, urgent pain, and diarrhea**; **loss of appetite after eating**, foul vomiting and diarrhea—these are **cold-induced illnesses**.

When heat arrives, it causes **fever, vomiting, diarrhea, and cholera**; **abscesses, boils, and ulcers**; **lower abdominal distension and urinary difficulties**; **persistent edema**; **nausea, headache, joint pain, and muscle aches**; **bleeding and hematuria**; **dysuria and urinary retention**—these are **heat-induced illnesses**. **Sudden emaciation, aversion to food, disorientation, agitation, madness, and hallucinations**; **seizures, tetany, and convulsions**—these too are **heat-induced illnesses**."

The Emperor said: *"How should they be treated?"*

Qi Bo said: *"The seasons must be followed, and when they are violated, treatment is with their opposites. In spring, cooling is appropriate; in summer, coldness is appropriate; in autumn, warmth is appropriate; in winter, heat is appropriate—these are the suitable treatments for each season, and they must not be disregarded.

Yet when heat is violated, treat with cold; when cold is violated, treat with heat; when spring is violated, use cooling; when autumn is violated, use warmth—this is the principle of overcoming.

When heat is violated, treat with bitter-cold; when cold is violated, treat with sweet-warm; when freezing is violated, treat with pungent-warm; when warmth is violated, treat with acrid-cooling—these too are methods of overcoming.

The Yellow Emperor asked: 'How should pregnant women be treated with poisons?'*

Qi Bo replied: *'If there is a cause, they shall suffer no harm, nor shall the fetus be lost. By 'cause,' I mean cases of severe **abdominal hardness** (大坚症 *dàjiān zhèng*) with lingering symptoms, where the pain is extreme and unbearable—then treat with **accumulation-breaking** and **pain-relieving** medicines. This is called 'not treating' (不救 *bù jiù*), where the **fetal movement ceases** (爻死 *yáo sǐ*) and death is complete. But if one preserves the greater whole—the mother—even if she takes poison, she will not die. If the mother is unharmed, it means the child will not perish either. If the mother is harmed, it means the child will also not survive."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I wish to hear the reasoning behind this. What is meant by 'cause'?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"Great accumulations and great masses—these may be treated, but only by reducing them by more than half; if one exceeds this, death will follow. Reducing them by more than half is insufficient to harm life, so even if the accumulation is vast, the medicine must be stopped at this point. If one oversteps the limit and waits until exhaustion, residual poisonous qi will remain inside, with no disease left to attack. When the poisonous medicine is exhausted, the poison will continue to assault, disrupting the central harmony—thus, exceeding the limit leads to death."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

*"When stagnation is severe, how should it be treated?"*

*"The movements of Heaven and Earth, the Five Phases, and their correspondence to the Dao—there are cases of extreme stagnation and suppression where things do not unfold naturally."*

Qi Bo replied: *"When wood is stagnant, release it; when fire is stagnant, vent it; when earth is stagnant, drain it; when metal is stagnant, disperse it; when water is stagnant, suppress it. Thus, one harmonizes the qi. Release means to induce vomiting, making it flow freely. Vent means to induce sweating, making it disperse. Drain means to purge, preventing obstruction. Disperse means to promote diuresis and relieve the surface, utilizing the small便. Suppress means to restrain and regulate its surging excess. These five methods—when applied, the qi may be balanced and adjusted. If there is excess, suppress it, for it is what is feared—this is called 'writing' (writing off). Excess means extreme excess. In cases of extreme excess, one counteracts with flavors: use salt to counteract the kidneys, sour to counteract the liver, pungent to counteract the lungs, sweet to counteract the spleen, and bitter to counteract the heart. Excess is what is feared, hence 'writing' is called 'fearing.'"*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"What about false conditions?"*

Qi Bo replied: *"If one borrows qi, there are no prohibitions. When the true qi is insufficient, the pathogenic qi sinks and overwhelms it. One may borrow cold, heat, warmth, or freezing to supplement the four true qi—thus, one may treat heat with heat, cold with cold, warmth with warmth, and freezing with coolness. This is called 'the true qi being insufficient while the pathogenic qi prevails.' Pathogenic qi refers to the six external influences that temporarily dominate. True qi refers to the five viscera corresponding to the four seasons, ruling over spring, summer, autumn, and winter."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Profound indeed is the Dao of the sage! The great transformations of Heaven and Earth, the rhythms of their movements, the governance of their seasons, the policies of yin and yang, the commands of cold and heat—who but you could comprehend them? I request that this be stored in the sacred *Linglan Chamber*, to be titled *The Six Elemental Regulations*. It shall not be revealed without ritual purification, and its transmission must be cautious."*

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"The five *qi* converge and diverge in cycles of abundance and deficiency—I understand this. The six *qi* govern in division, overseeing Heaven and Earth. When they arrive, how do they manifest? The five *phases* dominate each year, with some years having more or less, hence the cycles of abundance and deficiency. As the *Great Record of Heaven’s Elements* states: ‘At first, excess proceeds, while deficiency follows; when deficient, excess follows.’ Thus, its meaning is:

Heaven distributes the six *qi*—the first three govern the boundless void, the three *qi* rule Heaven, and the terminal *qi* oversee Earth. Heaven and Earth generate and transform—this is the great order. Hence, it speaks of those governing Heaven and Earth; the remaining four are self-evident.

Qibo bowed twice in response: *"Your question is profound! The great order of Heaven and Earth is the correspondence between human and divine. The transformations of Heaven and Earth move the human and divine in harmony; though inner and outer differ, their correspondence is unified."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear how the luminous above aligns with the obscure below—how does this work?"*

Qibo replied: *"This is the domain of the Dao and the doubt of the skilled practitioner. Without knowing its essence, its dispersion is boundless."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear its Dao."*

Qibo said: *"When *Jueyin* governs Heaven, its transformation is by wind. It stirs and disperses, harmonizing *qi* to give rise to life. All things flourish and wither, transforming and decaying accordingly.

When *Shaoyin* governs Heaven, its transformation is by heat. The scorching steam nurtures growth, so all creatures thrive and flourish.

When *Taiyin* governs Heaven, its transformation is by dampness. Clouds and rain moisten and nourish, generating fluids and essences.

When *Shaoyang* governs Heaven, its transformation is by fire. Blazing and fierce, it melts away cold disasters.

When *Yangming* governs Heaven, its transformation is by dryness. The dryness proceeds, and nothing decays from dampness.

When *Taiyang* governs Heaven, its transformation is by cold—opposing the yang transformations."* [*New Annotation*: The note on "opposing the yang transformations" likely contains an error in the character *yang*. It refers to the diseases arising from the organ governed by the season.]

The liver-wood governs the east, the heart-fire the south, the spleen-earth the center, the lung-metal the west, and the kidney-water the north—these are the fixed positions of the five *zang*. Yet when the six *qi* dominate and the five *phases* arrive, if the *qi* do not harmonize, disease arises; if they harmonize, balance is achieved. Thus, it first speaks of the six *qi*’s dominion, then of the five *zang*’s ailments.

The Emperor asked: *"How does Earth transform?"*

Qibo replied: *"The same principles apply as when governing Heaven—all inquiries into *qi* follow this pattern. The six *qi* have inherent natures, so though their positions shift, their transformations and governance remain consistent."*

The Emperor asked: *"What is meant by ‘questioning the *qi*’?"*

Qibo replied: *"Those governing left and right are called ‘questioning the *qi*.’ The six *qi*’s transformations typically involve two *qi* governing Heaven and Earth, establishing the principles of auspiciousness, misfortune, victory, reversal, guest, and host within the year. The remaining four *qi* reside on the left and right. Thus, the *Great Treatise on Yin-Yang Correspondences* states: ‘Heaven and Earth are the upper and lower of all things; left and right are the pathways of yin and yang.’ This is what is meant.

The *qi* governing is called *substance transformation*—the *jin* cycle’s *qi*, occurring in *Yi-Geng* years. The *jian qi* is called *pure transformation*—when wind arises, strong and lofty, and grasses and trees are clear and resonant; this is the transformation of purity."* [*New Annotation*: The *Yangming* years of *Yi-Hai* are the first *qi*, the *Chen-Xu* years the second *qi*, the *Yin-Shen* years the fourth *qi*, and the *Chou-Wei* years the fifth *qi*.]

When *Taiyang* governs Heaven, it is a *cold transformation*—in *Chen-Xu* years, the atmosphere is stern and rigid, grim and unyielding, embodying the cold transformation. When governing the spring, it is a *salty transformation*—in *Chou-Wei* years, water governs the Earth *qi*, so the transformation follows saltiness.

The governing *qi* is called *dark transformation*—the *water phase*’s *qi*, occurring in *Bing-Xin* years. The *jian qi* is called *concealed transformation*—when yin congeals and things become clear and reserved, embodying the year’s transformation."* [*New Annotation*: In *Zi-Wu* years, *Taiyang* is the first *qi*; in *Yi-Hai* years, the second *qi*; in *Mao-You* years, the fourth *qi*; and in *Yin-Shen* years, the fifth *qi*.]

Thus, those who treat disease must clarify the six transformations’ governance, the five flavors and five colors’ origins, and what each *zang* requires. Only then can one speak of the sequences of abundance, deficiency, and disease.

The Emperor said: *"I know that when *Jueyin* governs the spring, the sour transformation precedes it. How does the wind transformation proceed?"*

Qibo replied: *"Wind moves upon Earth—this is its root. The remaining *qi* follow the same principle."*

「When *Jueyin* is in *Quan* [the source], wind moves upon Earth.
When *Shaoyin* is in *Quan*, heat moves upon Earth.
When *Taiyin* is in *Quan*, dampness moves upon Earth.
When *Shaoyang* is in *Quan*, fire moves upon Earth.
When *Yangming* is in *Quan*, dryness moves upon Earth.
When *Taiyang* is in *Quan*, cold moves upon Earth.
Thus, it is said that the remaining *qi* follow the same principle.

The **root** refers to the original *qi* of the six *qi* [cosmic energies].
That which originates from Heaven is Heaven’s *qi*, that which originates from Earth is Earth’s *qi*.
That which transforms in Heaven becomes Heaven’s *qi*, that which transforms on Earth becomes Earth’s *qi*.
[*New Annotation*: As the *Yijing* [Classic of Changes] states: "That which originates from Heaven is close to the upper [Heaven], that which originates from Earth is close to the lower [Earth]." This is what is meant.]

When Heaven and Earth combine their *qi*, the six *nodes* [phases] divide to give rise to all things.
All things dwell between Heaven and Earth, all being generated and transformed by the six *qi*.
The functions of yin and yang never escape generation and transformation, nor can they avoid being yin or yang.
Thus, it is said: *"Carefully observe the suitable *qi*, and do not miss the mechanisms of disease."* This is what is meant.
[The mechanisms of disease will be fully explained in the following passages.]

The Emperor said: *"What governs the diseases?"* [Referring to the years in which one harvests medicine.]

Qibo replied: *"If one attends to the seasons and gathers all things, there will be no oversight in their governance.
Carefully observe what Heaven and Earth generate and transform, and the flavors of the medicines will align with their respective seasons.
Thus, if a medicine is specialized for a particular seasonal *qi*, the herbs gathered in that year or the next will serve their intended purpose without fail.
[*New Annotation*: Here, *zé* [则] should be read as *yòng* [用].]

The Emperor said: *"What of the things from the previous year?"*

Qibo replied: *"They are the concentrated essence of Heaven and Earth.
The *qi* of concentrated essence, when used, makes medicines rich and potent, aligning with their proper seasonal flavors."*

[*New Annotation*: Here, *xiān suì* [先岁] is likely a misreading and should be *sī suì* [司岁].]

The Emperor said: *"What of those who govern the *qi*?"* [Referring to those who oversee the seasonal *qi* cycles.]

Qibo replied: *"Those who govern the *qi* [seasonal cycles] align with the seasons’ governance, yet there are years of excess or deficiency.
The five *Yùn* [transitions] govern the seasons, with excess or deficiency—compared to the seasonal things, there may be years of scarcity.
In years of excess, medicines are concentrated and potent."*

The Emperor said: *"If not aligned with the seasonal governance, what then?"*

Qibo replied: *"They are dispersed.
If not concentrated, then the *qi* is dispersed, and the things are not pure.
Thus, even if their forms and substances are the same, their efficacy and application differ, so they are not valued equally.

The *qi* and flavors have degrees of strength or weakness, their nature has qualities of agitation or calmness,
their treatment has varying degrees of intensity, and their transformative power has limits of depth and reach.
This is what is meant.

When things do not align with the seasons, what then?"

The Emperor said: *"What does it mean when the seasons govern the *zàng* [organs] and cause harm?"*

Qibo replied: *"When the *qi* that should not dominate prevails, this is the key principle.
For example, wood does not dominate metal, metal does not dominate fire—this is the pattern.
The Emperor said: *"How should one treat this?"*

Qibo replied: *"When the upper [Heavenly] *qi* dominates the lower [Earthly],
the *qi* that should dominate is used to balance it.
When the external [Earthly] *qi* dominates the internal [Heavenly],
the *qi* that should dominate is used to treat it.
[*New Annotation*: When Heaven’s *qi* governs the season, even if there is excess or dominance,
one must balance and regulate it, hence it is called *píng* [平] rather than *zhì* [治].]

The Emperor said: *"Good."* How does one balance the *qi*?"

Qibo replied: *"Balance refers to diagnosing the harmonious *qi* of yin and yang.
Carefully observe where yin and yang reside and regulate accordingly, aiming for balance.
If the disease is straightforward, treat it directly; if it is contrary, treat it oppositely.
Knowing where yin and yang reside allows one to discern whether the pulse at the *cùnkǒu* [wrist] aligns or does not align with the *shíchù* [radial positions].
Not knowing where yin and yang reside means taking alignment for misalignment and opposing for compliance.
Thus, one must examine carefully.

When yin is diseased and yang is not, or when yang is diseased and yin is not,
this is called **straightforward disease**, and one treats it directly—
meaning to treat heat with cold and cold with heat—
when the *yin position* [pulse] already shows signs of *yang caò* [yang excess],
and the *yang position* [pulse] again shows signs of *yin caò* [yin excess],
this is called **contrary disease**, and one treats it oppositely—
meaning to treat cold with cold and heat with heat.
All prescriptions follow this principle, hence it is said: *"If contrary, treat it oppositely."*

The Emperor said: *"Master Qibo spoke of observing where yin and yang reside and regulating accordingly.
The theory states that the pulse at *rényíng* [carotid] aligns with the *cùnkǒu* [wrist],
and if the pulse is measured equal in size, it is called *píng* [balanced].
[*New Annotation*: Here, the theory states that on the day of balance, the pulse is measured at the *cùnkǒu* [wrist],
originating from the *Língshū* [Miraculous Pivot], now taken from the *Jiāyǐ Jīng* [Canon of the A-B Branches], which reads *cùn* [寸].]

The *cùnkǒu* [wrist] governs the center, while *rényíng* [carotid] governs the exterior.
When both align—rising and falling together—
and if measured equal in size, like a taut string,
then in spring and summer, *rényíng* is slightly larger,
and in autumn and winter, *cùnkǒu* is slightly larger.
The pulse that is slightly larger is called *píng* [balanced].

When yin resides, how does the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] appear?
When yin resides, the pulse is deep and does not respond [to pressure],
and if measured equal in size, the symptoms are greatly misaligned—
thus the question is asked to clarify this.»

Qibo replied: *"Observe whether the season faces south or north, and it can be known.

In the **Northern-facing seasons** [winter and autumn], when *Shaoyin* is in *Quan* [the source],
the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] does not respond.
In the years of the *Yùn* [transitions] of wood, fire, metal, and water,
facing north to receive the *qi*, all *qi* in *Quan* [the source] are imperceptible in the pulse,
only the *qi* of its adjacent seasons are visible.
If the *qi* in *Quan* is benign, the pulse will not show it;
if it is harmful, the pulse will reveal it.
Diseases are named according to the *qi* and the guest-host [interactions] of excess or dominance.
The same applies to the *qi* of Heaven.

When *Jueyin* is in *Quan*, the right [pulse] does not respond to the second [season].
This is because *Shaoyin* resides on the right.

When *Taiyin* is in *Quan*, the left [pulse] does not respond.
This is because *Shaoyin* resides on the left.

In the **Southern-facing seasons** [spring and summer], when *Shaoyin* governs Heaven,
the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] does not respond.
In the years of the *Yùn* [transition] of earth,
facing south to issue commands, *Shaoyin* governs Heaven,
and thus the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] of both hands does not respond.»

When **Jueyin** governs Heaven, the right [pulse] does not respond;
when **Taiyin** governs Heaven, the left [pulse] does not respond.
This is also the principle of left and right [correspondence].

All cases where the pulse does not respond,
when reversed in diagnosis, will reveal themselves.
Non-responsive pulses are all [manifestations of] *depressed* pulses;
when the depressed pulse is found below [the wrist],
lift the hand to observe it—
when the hand is inverted, the depressed pulse becomes *floating*,
and the fine pulse becomes *large*.

The Emperor said: How about the *chi* [cubit] pulse?
Giber [Qibo] replied:
In the **Northern-facing seasons** [autumn and winter],
when the *three Yin* [pulses] are below [the wrist],
the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] does not respond;
when the *three Yin* [pulses] are above [the wrist],
the *chi* [cubit] pulse does not respond.
When governing Heaven, [the pulse] is above;
when in *Quan* [the deep layer], [the pulse] is below.
In the **Southern-facing seasons** [spring and summer],
when the *three Yin* [pulses] are in Heaven,
the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] does not respond;
when the *three Yin* [pulses] are in *Quan* [the deep layer],
the *chi* [cubit] pulse does not respond.
The left and right [principles] are the same.

When the *chi* [cubit] pulse does not respond to the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse],
the left and right [pulses] all follow the same principle as the *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse] not responding.
Thus it is said:
*"He who knows the essentials can conclude in a single word;
he who does not know the essentials will ramble endlessly without reaching the point."*
This is what is meant.

The essentials refer to knowing the location of *Yin* and *Yang*.
To know [them] is to apply [diagnosis] without confusion;
to not know [them] is to lose the *chi* [cubit] and *cùnkǒu* [wrist pulse],
and the distinctions of *depressed* and *floating*, *fine* and *large*,
which always shift every three years.
If one seeks to grasp its meaning,
it is like circling a tree to ask about its branches—
even if one grows old with endless questioning,
one will still not know where to go,
let alone comprehend it in months or years!

The Emperor said: Excellent.
When the *qi* of Heaven and Earth is internally **excessive** [淫], how do diseases manifest?

Qibo replied:
In the years when **Jueyin** is in *Quan* [the deep layer],
where the **Wood** element is dominant and **overpowers** [克] the **Spleen** and **Stomach**,
the *qi* of Earth becomes obscured,
and the plains appear dim.
Grasses sprout early.
The people suffer from **shaking chills** [洒洒振寒],
frequent stretching and yawning,
**heart pain** and **flank distension** [支满],
**rib-side constriction** [两胁裹急],
**inability to swallow food** [饮食不下],
**obstruction of the throat** [鬲咽不通],
**nausea upon eating** [食则呕],
**abdominal distension** with **frequent belching** [腹胀善噫],
and when they encounter the **posterior** *qi* [of the season],
they feel **immediate relief**, as if **withered** [衰],
but their bodies are **heavy** [皆重].

These are the years of **Jia-Yin, Bing-Yin, Wu-Yin, Geng-Yin, Ren-Yin, Jia-Shen, Bing-Shen, Wu-Shen, Geng-Shen, and Ren-Shen**.

When the *qi* of Earth is obscured,
it means that at the **boundary of Heaven and Earth** [天围之际],
the *qi* appears **dim** [气色昏暗],
and the **Wood** *qi* [风] spreads across the Earth,
so the plains all exhibit this dimness.
*Dim* refers to **darkness** [暗].
*Rib-side* [胁] refers to the **area beneath the breasts** and **flanks** [两乳之下及腋外].
*Stretching* [伸] refers to the **action of straining muscles and bones** [以欲伸努筋骨].

---
In the years when **Jueyin** is in *Quan* [the deep layer],
where the **Fire** element is dominant and **overpowers** [克] the **Metal** element,
**flames rise over rivers and lakes** [焰浮川泽],
and **Yin** regions appear **unexpectedly bright** [阴处反明].
The people suffer from **constant rumbling in the abdomen** [腹中常呜],
**rising *qi* that assaults the chest** [气上冲胸],
**shortness of breath** that prevents them from standing for long,
**skin pain** with **alternating cold and heat** [寒热皮肤痛],
**eye pain** and **toothache** [目瞑齿痛],
**neck swelling** [项肿],
**chills and fever resembling malaria** [恶寒发热如疟],
**lower abdominal pain** [少腹中痛],
**abdominal distension** [腹大],
**rectal prolapse** [垫虫不藏].

These are the years of **Yi-Mao, Ding-Mao, Ji-Mao, Xin-Mao, Gui-Mao, Yi-You, Ding-You, Ji-You, Xin-You, and Gui-You**.

*Yin* regions refer to the **North** [北方].
*Cannot stand for long* means **weakness in the legs** [足无力].
*Abdominal distension* refers to **insufficient *heart qi*** [心气不足].
This is due to the **interaction between Water and Fire** [金火相薄].

---
In the years when **Taiyin** is in *Quan* [the deep layer],
where the **Earth** element is dominant and **overpowers** [克] the **Taiyang** [Foot Greater Yang],
**grasses flourish early** [草乃早荣],
and the *qi* of **dampness** [湿] is excessive,
**mist veils cliffs and valleys** [埃昏岩谷],
**yellow turns black** [黄反见黑],
reaching the **peak of Yin** [至阴之交].
The people suffer from **fluid accumulation** [饮积],
**heart pain** and **deafness** [心痛耳聋],
**dull and heavy sensations** [浑浑惇惇],
**throat and neck obstruction** [嗑肿喉痹],
**Yin-related blood disorders** [阴病血见],
**lower abdominal pain and swelling** [少腹痛肿],
**inability to urinate** [不得小便],
**diseases that surge upward causing headache** [病冲头痛],
**eyes appearing to fall out** [目似脱],
**neck appearing to be pulled taut** [项似拔],
**waist appearing to be broken** [腰似折],
**organs unable to return to normal** [脏不可以回],
**knees feeling knotted** [胭如结],
**rectum feeling separated** [端如别].

These are the years of **Jia-Chen, Bing-Chen, Wu-Chen, Geng-Chen, Ren-Chen, Jia-Xu, Bing-Xu, Wu-Xu, Geng-Xu, and Ren-Xu**.

Taiyin corresponds to **Earth** [土],
and when its **color** [黄] appears in the **Heavenly center** [天中],
it instead appears in the **northern black regions** [北方黑处].
When **Water** and **Earth** *qi* [colors] merge,
the **season reaches the peak of Yin** [日至阴之交],
and their *qi* and color combine.

*Diseases that surge upward causing headache* refers to **pain behind the brain and between the eyebrows** [脑后眉问痛].
*Bing* [胭] refers to the **back of the knees** [膝后曲脚之中].
*End* [端] refers to the **soft flesh behind the anus** [腑后软肉处].

When the **Shao-Yang** [少阳] is in the **Spring** [泉],
and **Fire** [火] is in excess,
then **flames blaze across the countryside** [焰明郊野],
and **chills and fevers alternate** [寒热更至].

The people suffer from **diarrhea with blood and mucus** [注泄赤白],
**lower abdominal pain** [少腹痛],
**bloody urine** [溺赤],
and in severe cases, **hemorrhoidal bleeding** [血便].
The symptoms align with **Shao-Yin** [少阴].

These are the years of **Yi-Si, Ding-Si, Ji-Si, Xin-Si, Gui-Si, Yi-Hai, Ding-Hai, Ji-Hai, Xin-Hai, and Gui-Hai**.

During the **cold season** [处寒之时],
**heat intensifies the *qi*** [热更其气],
and when the **heat dissipates** [热气既往],
**cold *qi* follows** [寒气后来],
hence the alternation [故云更至也].
The remaining symptoms match those of **Shao-Yin in the Spring**.

When **Yang-Ming** [阳明] is in the **Spring** [泉],
and **Dryness** [燥] is in excess,
then **mist obscures the sky** [雾雾清暝].

The people suffer from **nausea with a bitter taste** [喜呕，呕有苦],
**frequent sighing** [善太息],
**pain in the heart and ribs** [心胁痛] that prevents turning,
and in severe cases, **dry, dusty skin** [嗑乾面尘],
**lack of luster** [身无膏泽],
and **outer edges of the feet feeling hot** [足外反热].

These are the years of **Jia-Zi, Bing-Zi, Wu-Zi, Geng-Zi, Ren-Zi, Jia-Wu, Bing-Wu, Wu-Wu, Geng-Wu, and Ren-Wu**.

**Mist and dew** [露雾] refers to **a hazy, indistinct atmosphere** [露暗不分，似雾也].
**Thin cold** [清] denotes **a light chill** [薄寒也].
It describes **mist rising, obscuring forms, and a faint cold** [言雾起露暗，不辨物形而薄寒也].
**Pain in the heart and ribs** [心胁痛] refers to **pain beside the heart, in the ribcage** [心之傍，胁中痛也].
**Dusty face** [面尘] means **a face appearing as if dusted with dirt** [面上如有触冒尘土之色也].

When **Tai-Yang** [太阳] is in the **Spring** [泉],
and **Cold** [寒] is in excess,
then **the air grows dense and still, with a chilling dread** [凝肃惨栗].

The people suffer from **lower abdominal pain radiating to the testicles** [少腹控睪],
**pulling at the waist and spine** [引腰脊],
**pain shooting upward to the heart** [上冲心痛],
**visible blood** [血见],
and **severe pain with swollen jaw** [隘痛颔肿].

These are the years of **Yi-Chou, Ding-Chou, Ji-Chou, Xin-Chou, Gui-Chou, Yi-Wei, Ding-Wei, Ji-Wei, Xin-Wei, and Gui-Wei**.

**Dense and still** [凝肃] refers to **cold *qi* lingering in the air, motionless** [寒气霭空，凝而不动],
while **chilling dread** [惨栗] signifies **extreme cold** [寒甚也].
**Pulling** [控] means **drawing or dragging** [引也].

The **testicles** [睪] are the **ninth of the Yang organs** [阴九也].
The **jaw** [颌] refers to **the teeth beneath the cheek and upper lip** [颊车前牙之下也].

○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* [《甲乙经》], **deafness with pain and swollen jaw** [哑痛颌肿] is a **disease of the Small Intestine** [小肠病].
Again, **lower abdominal pain drawing upward** [少腹控举], **pulling at the waist and spine** [引腰脊], **and shooting upward to the heart and lungs** [上冲心肺]—when the **pathogenic factor resides in the Small Intestine** [邪在小肠也]—are all symptoms of the same.
Indeed, in years when **Tai-Yang** [太阳] is in the **Spring** [泉], **Water overcomes Fire** [水克火], and thus the diseases manifest as such.

The **Emperor** [帝] said: **"Well spoken"** [善].
How should they be treated?

**Qi-Bo** [岐伯] replied:
When **all *qi* is in the Spring** [诸气在泉], and **Wind excesses internally** [风淫於内],
treat with **pungent-cold** [辛冻], **assist with bitter** [佐以苦],
**use sweet to moderate it** [以甘缓之], **and use pungent to disperse it** [以辛散之];
Wind **naturally favors warmth and abhors cold** [风性喜温而恶清],
so treatment with **cooling** [凉] is to **subdue the pathogenic factor** [是以胜气治之也].
Assist with **bitter**, following **its therapeutic advantage** [随其所利也].
When **bitterness is too harsh** [木苦急], then **use sweet to moderate it** [则以甘缓之].
When **bitterness suppresses excessively** [苦抑], then **use pungent to disperse it** [则以辛散之].

The *Cang-Qi Fa-Shi Lun* [《藏气法时论》] states:
**The Liver suffers from bitter harshness** [肝苦急], so **urgently consume sweet to moderate it** [急食甘以缓之].
**The Liver desires dispersion** [肝欲散], so **urgently consume pungent to disperse it** [急食辛以散之].
This is the principle.

**Consume** [食] is also pronounced **as *si*** [饲], meaning **to eat on the *ji* day** [己日食], **or to feed on other days** [他日饲也].
The **primary method aligns with these flavors** [大法正味如此],
but **all prescriptions** [诸为方者] do not **exhaustively use them** [不铃尽用之],
merely **applying one or two secondary flavors** [但#8一佐二佐],
then **ceasing when the disease is resolved** [病已则止].
The same applies to **all pathogenic factors** [余气皆然].

When **Heat excesses internally** [热淫於内],
treat with **salty-cold** [咸寒], **assist with sweet-bitter** [佐以甘苦],
**use sour to astringe it** [以酸收之], **and use bitter to induce it** [以苦发之];
Heat **naturally abhors cold** [热性恶寒], so **treatment with coldness subdues it** [故治以寒也].
When **Heat is excessively severe** [热之大盛],
and **overwhelms the exterior** [甚於表者],
**use bitter to induce it** [以苦发之];
If the **Heat is not fully resolved** [不尽],
then **apply cold again to suppress it** [复寒制之];
If the **cold suppression is not complete** [寒制不尽],
then **use bitter again to induce it** [复苦发之];
**Finally, use sour to astringe it** [以酸收之].
For **severe cases**, use **two prescriptions** [甚者再方],
for **mild cases**, use **one prescription** [微者一方],
so as to **fully resolve the pathogenic factor** [可使铃已].
When **Heat flares intermittently** [时发时止],
also **use sour to astringe it** [亦以酸收之].

When **Dampness excesses internally** [湿淫於内],
treat with **bitter-warm** [苦热], **assist with sour-mild** [佐以酸淡],
**use bitter to dry it** [以苦燥之], **and use mild to drain it** [以淡泄之];
Dampness **contrasts with dryness** [湿与燥反],
so **treatment with bitter-warm is assisted by sour-mild** [故治以苦热，佐以酸淡也].
Bitter **removes Dampness** [燥除湿], so **use bitter to dry its Dampness** [故以苦燥其湿也].
Mild **facilitates orifices** [淡利窍], so **use mild to permeate and drain** [故以淡渗泄也].

The *Cang-Qi Fa-Shi Lun* [《藏气法时论》] states:
**The Spleen suffers from Dampness** [脾苦湿], so **urgently consume bitter to dry it** [急食苦以燥之].
The *Ling-Shu Jing* [《灵枢经》] states:
**Mildness facilitates orifices** [淡利窍也].
The *Sheng-Qi Tong-Tian Lun* [《生气通天论》] states:
**When flavor is excessively bitter** [味过於苦],
**the Spleen’s *qi* is not nourished** [脾气不濡],
**and the Stomach’s *qi* becomes dense** [胃气乃厚].
This **clarifies bitterness’s drying effect** [明苦燥也].

○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Liu-Yuan Zheng-Ji Da-Lun* [《六元正纪大论》]:
**When subduing the Lower Tai-Yin** [下太阴],
**its transformation is with mild-warm** [其化下甘温].

When **Fire excesses internally** [火淫於内],
treat with **salty-clear** [咸玲], **assist with bitter-pungent** [佐以苦辛],
**use sour to astringe it** [以酸收之], **and use bitter to induce it** [以苦发之];
Fire **greatly agitates the heart and abdomen** [火气大行心腹],
**a product of the Heart’s anger** [心怒之所生也],
**salty flavor is soft and yielding** [咸性柔软],
so **use it to treat the Heart** [故以治之], **and use sour to astringe it** [以酸收之].
The **primary method** [大法] **supports those needing sweating** [侯其须汗者],
**using pungent to assist it** [以辛佐之],
**without relying on bitter flavor to induce sweating** [不叉要资苦味令其汗也].
For **those desiring softness and yielding** [欲柔软者],
**use salty to treat them** [以咸治之].
The *Cang-Qi Fa-Shi Lun* [《藏气法时论》] states:
**The Heart desires softness** [心欲软], so **urgently consume salty to soften it** [急食咸以软之].
**The Heart suffers from sluggishness** [心苦缓], so **urgently consume sour to astringe it** [急食酸以收之].
This is the principle.

When **Dryness excesses internally** [燥淫於内],
treat with **bitter-warm** [苦温], **assist with sour-pungent** [佐以甘辛],
**use bitter to subdue it** [以苦下之];
Warmth **facilitates the cold nature** [温利冻性],
so **use bitter to treat it** [故以苦治之].
**Subdue** [下] means **to guide its therapeutic advantage** [谓利之使不得也].

○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Cang-Qi Fa-Shi Lun* [《藏气法时论》]:
**The Lung suffers from rebellious *qi* rising** [肺苦气上逆], so **urgently consume bitter to drain it** [急食苦以泄之].
**Use pungent to disperse it** [以辛写之], **and use sour to supplement it** [以酸补之].
Again, according to the **following text** [下文], when **Dryness overcomes the Lung in the *Si-Tian* phase** [司天燥淫所胜],
**it is assisted with sour-pungent** [佐以酸辛],
but here it states **sweet-pungent** [此云甘辛者], where **sweet** [甘] may be a **misprint for sour** [字疑当作酸].
The *Tian-Yuan Zheng-Ji Da-Lun* [《天元正纪大论》] states:
**Subdue with sour-heat** [下酸热].
This **differs from the bitter-warm treatment** [与苦温之治又异].
It also states:
**Use sour to astringe it and stabilize the lower** [以酸收之而安其下],
**for severe cases, use bitter to drain it** [甚则以苦泄之].

When **Cold excesses internally** [寒淫於内],
treat with **sweet-warm** [甘热], **assist with bitter-pungent** [佐以苦辛],
**use salty to disperse it** [以咸写之], **use pungent to moisten it** [以辛润之], **and use bitter to solidify it** [以苦坚之].
**Use warmth to treat Cold** [以热治寒] is to **crush and subdue its *qi*** [摧胜],
**to prevent its proliferation** [折其气用],
**and to ensure it does not flourish further** [令不滋繁也].
The **assistance of bitter and pungent** [苦辛之佐] **facilitates their therapeutic function** [通事行之].

○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Cang-Qi Fa-Shi Lun* [《藏气法时论》]:
**The Kidney suffers from Dryness** [肾苦燥], so **urgently consume pungent to moisten it** [急食辛以润之].
**The Kidney desires solidity** [肾欲坚], so **urgently consume bitter to solidify it** [急食苦以坚之].
**Use bitter to supplement it** [用苦补之], **and use salty to disperse it** [咸写之].
The **old annotation** [旧注] **incorrectly cited this under Dampness excessing internally** [引此在湿淫於内之下],
**lacking logical coherence** [无义],
so it is **now moved here** [今移於此].

The **Emperor** [帝] said: **"Well spoken"** [善].
How does **the variation of Heaven’s *qi*** [天气之变] manifest?

Qi Bó said: When the **Jué-Yīn** [厥阴] **controls Heaven** [司天], **excessive Wind** [风淫] **prevails** [所胜], then **the Supreme Void** [太虚] **is obscured by dust and murkiness** [埃昏], and **clouds and phenomena are in turmoil** [云物以扰].
**Cold arises in Spring *qi*** [寒生春气], **flowing waters do not freeze** [流水不冰].
The people suffer from **pain in the stomach cavity** [胃院] **at the center of the chest** [当心而痛], **radiating upward to the two flanks** [上支两胁], **blockage in the throat and epiglottis** [鬲咽不通], **inability to swallow food** [食不下], **stiffness of the tongue’s root** [舌本强], **nausea upon eating** [食则呕], **prolapse of the rectum** [玲泄] **with abdominal distension** [腹胀], **diarrhea alternating with constipation** [泄痕水闭], **intestinal worms failing to emerge** [垫虫不出].
The root of the illness lies in the **Spleen** [脾].
This refers to the years **Yǐ-Sì** [乙巳], **Dīng-Sì** [丁巳], **Jǐ-Sì** [己巳], **Xīn-Sì** [辛巳], **Guǐ-Sì** [癸巳], **Yǐ-Hài** [乙亥], **Dīng-Hài** [丁亥], **Jǐ-Hài** [己亥], **Xīn-Hài** [辛亥], and **Guǐ-Hài** [癸亥].
In these years, **illnesses converge in the center** [民病集於中].
Wind descends from Heaven, so **the Supreme Void is stirred by dust** [故太虚埃起].
Wind moves and scatters, thus **clouds and phenomena are in turmoil** [故云物扰].
**Dust** [埃] refers to **greenish haze** [青尘].
When distant objects cannot be distinguished, it is called **dusty murkiness** [埃昏].
When **Earth** [土] **manifests as illness**, its tendency is **prolapse and diarrhea** [其善泄利].
If **water-related symptoms** [病水] occur, then **urine retention** [小便闭] **prevents its passage** [而不下].
If there is **severe prolapse and diarrhea** [大泄利], then **menstrual flow may also be obstructed or absent** [经水亦多闭绝].
○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* [《甲乙经》]:
**Stiffness of the tongue’s root** [舌本强], **nausea upon eating** [食则呕], **abdominal distension with chronic diarrhea** [腹胀沧泄], **urine retention** [痕水闭]—these are **Spleen diseases** [为脾病].
Furthermore, **stomach diseases** [胃病者] manifest as **abdominal distension with Spleen involvement** [腹脾胀], **pain in the stomach cavity at the center of the chest** [胃院当心而痛], **radiating upward to the two flanks** [上支两胁], **blockage in the throat and epiglottis** [两咽不通], **inability to swallow food or drink** [食饮不下].
Indeed, in the years when **Jué-Yīn controls Heaven** [厥阴司天], **Wood overcomes Earth** [木胜土], so the diseases are as described.
If the **Chōng-Yáng pulse** [冲阳] **fails**, **death is inevitable** [死不治].
The **Chōng-Yáng pulse** [冲阳] is located on the **upper side of the foot** [足附上], where the artery responds to pressure by hand—this is the **stomach’s *qi*** [胃之气].
When the **Chōng-Yáng pulse is faint** [冲阳脉微], **food and drink intake diminishes** [食饮喊少].
If it **fails completely** [绝], **medicines and food cannot enter** [药食不入], and there is **severe diarrhea** [亦下叉]—**a critical condition** [还出].
If **attacked but unable to absorb nourishment** [攻之不入], **if nourished but unable to grow** [养之不生], **pathogenic *qi* strengthens daily** [邪气日强], **while true *qi* is internally exhausted** [真气内绝], then **death is certain** [故其必死], **with no hope of recovery** [不可复].

When the **Shào-Yīn** [少阴] **controls Heaven** [司天], **excessive Heat** [热淫] **prevails** [所胜], then **irritating heat spreads** [怫热至], **Fire executes its function** [火行其], and the people suffer from **chest discomfort and heat** [胸中烦热], **dry throat** [嗑乾], **right flank fullness** [右肚满], **skin lesions** [皮肤], **alternating chills and fever with coughing and wheezing** [寒热咳喘], **imminent heavy rainfall** [大雨且至].
They experience **sputum with blood** [唾血], **bloody diarrhea** [血泄], **frequent sneezing and vomiting** [凯趣嚏呕], **urine color changes** [溺色变].
In severe cases, **ulcers and abscesses** [疮疡] **with localized swelling** [驸肿], **pain in the shoulders, back, arms, and supraclavicular region** [及缺盆中痛], **heartache and lung tension** [心痛肺缜], **abdominal distension and bloating** [腹大满膨], **wheezing and coughing upon distension** [膨而喘咳]—the root of the illness lies in the **Lungs** [肺].
This refers to the years **Jiā-Zǐ** [甲子], **Bǐng-Zǐ** [丙子], **Wù-Zǐ** [戊子], **Gēng-Zǐ** [庚子], **Rén-Zǐ** [壬子], **Jiā-Wǔ** [甲午], **Bǐng-Wǔ** [丙午], **Wù-Wǔ** [戊午], **Gēng-Wǔ** [庚午], and **Rén-Wǔ** [壬午].
**Irritating heat spreads** [怫热至], **for Fire governs its affairs thus** [是火行其政乃尔].
In these years, **illnesses converge on the right side** [民病集於右], **as the Small Intestine communicates with the Heart** [盖以小肠通心故].
The illness originates in the **Lungs** [肺], hence it is said **the root of the illness lies in the Lungs** [病本於肺].
○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* [《甲乙经》]:
**Urine color changes** [溺色变], **pain in the shoulders, back, arms, and supraclavicular region** [肩背臂燸及缺盆中痛], **abdominal distension and bloating with wheezing and coughing** [腹胀满膨膨而喘咳]—these are **Lung diseases** [为肺病].
**Coughing with blood and fever** [轨钮]—these are **Large Intestine diseases** [为大肠病].
Indeed, in the years when **Shào-Yīn controls Heaven** [少阴司天], **Fire overcomes Metal** [火克金], so the diseases are as described.
Furthermore, **Wang’s annotation** [王注] states that **illnesses converge on the right side** [民病集於右], **as the Small Intestine communicates with the Heart** [以小肠通心故].
According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* [《甲乙经》], the **Large Intestine wraps around the spine** [大肠附脊左环], **and the ileum encircles the spine on the right** [回肠附脊右环].
This contradicts the previous statement, so **perhaps it is due to Fire overwhelming Metal, causing Large Intestine disease** [得非火盛克金，而大肠病欤].
If the **Chǐ-Zé pulse** [尺泽] **fails**, **death is inevitable** [死不治].
The **Chǐ-Zé pulse** [尺泽] is located on the **inner side of the elbow** [肘内康大文中], where the artery responds to pressure by hand—this is the **Lung’s *qi*** [肺之气].
When **Fire consumes Metal** [火烁於金], **it receives Heaven’s mandate** [承天之命], **and Metal’s *qi* is internally exhausted** [金气内绝], so **the hexagram is perilous and lost** [故爻危亡].
If the **Chǐ-Zé pulse does not reach** [尺泽不至], **the Lung’s *qi* has already failed** [肺气已绝].
The **Nourishing and Defensive *qi*** [荣卫之气] **lacks a guiding principle** [宣行无主], **and true *qi* is internally depleted** [真气内竭].
Thus, **how can life be sustained?** [生之何有哉].

When the **Tài-Yīn** [太阴] **controls Heaven** [司天], **excessive Dampness** [湿淫] **prevails** [所胜], then **prolonged darkness spreads** [沉阴且布], **rainfall disrupts growth** [雨变], **and there are withered crops** [枯槁] **along with abscesses and localized swelling** [驸肿], **bone pain and *Yīn* paralysis** [骨痛阴痹].
**Yīn paralysis** [阴痹] refers to **areas that cannot be pressed** [按之不得].
The people suffer from **pain in the waist, back, head, and neck** [腰脊头项痛], **occasional dizziness** [时眩], **difficult defecation** [大便难], **unable to disperse *Yīn* *qi*** [阴气不甩], **anorexia despite hunger** [饥不欲食], **coughing up blood** [咳唾则有血], **and a heart that feels suspended** [心如悬].
The root of the illness lies in the **Kidneys** [肾].
This refers to the years **Yǐ-Chǒu** [乙丑], **Dīng-Chǒu** [丁丑], **Jǐ-Chǒu** [己丑], **Xīn-Chǒu** [辛丑], **Guǐ-Chǒu** [癸丑], **Yǐ-Wèi** [乙未], **Dīng-Wèi** [丁未], **Jǐ-Wèi** [己未], **Xīn-Wèi** [辛未], and **Guǐ-Wèi** [癸未].
**Prolonged** [沉] refers to **long-standing** [久].
When **Kidney *qi* is afflicted by pathogens** [肾气受邪], **water lacks the ability to moisten** [水无能润], **and the lower burner becomes parched** [下焦桔涸], hence **difficult defecation** [故大便难].
○The newly corrected version states: According to the *Jia-Yi Jing* [《甲乙经》]:
**Anorexia despite hunger** [饥不用食], **coughing up blood** [咳唾则有血], **and a heart that feels suspended, resembling hunger** [心悬如饥状]—these are **Kidney diseases** [为肾病].
Furthermore, **when pathogens are in the Kidneys** [邪在肾], **there is bone pain and *Yīn* paralysis** [则骨痛阴痹], **where *Yīn* paralysis refers to areas that cannot be pressed** [阴痹者，按之而不得], **abdominal distension and waist pain** [腹胀腰痛], **difficult defecation** [大便难], **stiffness and pain in the shoulders, back, neck, and supraclavicular region** [肩背颈项强痛], **and occasional dizziness** [时眩].
Indeed, in the years when **Tài-Yīn controls Heaven** [太阴司天], **Earth overcomes Water** [土克水], so the diseases are as described.
If the **Tài-Xī pulse** [太溪] **fails**, **death is inevitable** [死不治].
The **Tài-Xī pulse** [太溪] is located on the **inner ankle, behind the heel bone** [足内踝后跟骨上], where the artery responds to pressure by hand—this is the **Kidney’s *qi*** [肾之气].
When **Earth pathogens overcome Water** [土邪胜水], **Kidney *qi* is internally exhausted** [而肾气内绝], **pathogens are severe while righteousness is faint** [邪甚正微], so **no remedy can be applied** [故方无所用矣].

When the **Shào-Yáng** [少阳] **controls Heaven** [司天], **excessive Fire** [火淫] **prevails** [所胜], then **warm *qi* flows freely** [温气流行], **and Metal’s governance is disrupted** [金政不平].
The people suffer from **headaches** [头痛], **fever with chills and malaria** [一发热恶寒而疟], **heat rising to the skin** [热上皮肤哺], **color changes to yellow or red** [色变黄赤], **progression to water-related symptoms** [传而为水], **fullness in the body, face, elbows, and abdomen with upward pressure on breath** [身面肘鸟腹满仰息], **diarrhea with bloody and white mucus** [泄往赤白], **ulcers and abscesses** [疮疡], **coughing up blood** [咳唾血], **and heart distress** [烦心].
In severe cases, **chest heat** [胸中热] **and vomiting** [甚则欤趣]—the root of the illness lies in the **Lungs** [肺].
This refers to the years **Jiā-Yín** [甲寅], **Bǐng-Yín** [丙寅], **Wù-Yín** [戊寅], **Jué-Yín** [决寅], **Rén-Yín** [壬寅], **Jiā-Shēn** [甲申], **Bǐng-Shēn** [丙申], **Wù-Shēn** [戊申], **Gēng-Shēn** [庚申], and **Rén-Shēn** [壬申].

When **Fire** [火] comes to dominate, the **Lung-qi** [金气] is afflicted by **evil** [邪], hence it is said that the **Lung’s regulatory power is disrupted** [金政不平].

Fire blazes above, and the **Lungs** [金肺] suffer from **evil**, causing **internal heat** [客热内翻] to arise, while **Water** [水] cannot provide relief, thus giving rise to all manner of **illnesses** [诸病]. To subdue this **Fire** [制火之客] is the only remedy.

○Newly corrected text states: According to *The Jia-Yi Classic* [按《甲乙经》], when **evil** [邪] is in the **Lungs** [肺], then **skin pain** [皮肤痛] and **alternating chills and fever** [发寒热] occur. Indeed, in the **Lesser Yang** [少阳] years when **Fire** [火] overcomes **Metal** [金], the illness manifests thus.

When the **Celestial Reservoir** [天府] is severed, the **patient dies without remedy** [死不治]. The **Celestial Reservoir** [天府] is located on the **inner side of the upper elbow** [肘复内侧上], three *cun* below the armpit, where the pulse responds to pressure—this is the **Lung’s qi** [肺之气]. When **Fire** [火] is excessive and the **Metal pulse** [金脉] is severed, death ensues.

In **Greater Yang** [阳明] years when **Dryness** [燥] is excessive, **Wood** [木] flourishes late, and **grasses grow late** [草乃晚生], while **tendons and bones internally transform** [筋骨内变]. The people suffer from **left flank pain** [左肚胁痛], **internal cold** [寒清於中], **malaria** [感而疟], **severe shivering** [大冻革候], **coughing** [咳], **abdominal rumbling** [腹中呜], **urinary urgency or incontinence** [注泄], **fright-induced tremors** [惊搪], a condition called **"Wood’s Retarded Growth"** [名木敛生], where **roots wither below** [莞於下] and **leaves scorch above** [草焦上首].

There is **sudden heart-flank pain** [心胁暴痛], making it impossible to turn or lie on one’s side; the **face becomes parched and dusty** [隘乾面尘], the **waist aches** [腰痛], men develop **epilepsy or hernia** [癫疝], women experience **lower abdominal pain** [少腹痛], the **eyes become dim** [目昧], **ulcers form on the temples** [毗疡], **prolonged sores cause paralysis** [疮座瘫], and **parasitic worms appear** [垫虫来见]—the root of the illness lies in the **Liver** [肝].

This refers to the years **Yǐ-Mǎo** [乙卯], **Dīng-Mǎo** [丁卯], **Jǐ-Mǎo** [己卯], **Xīn-Mǎo** [辛卯], **Guǐ-Mǎo** [癸卯], **Yǐ-Yǒu** [乙酉], **Dīng-Yǒu** [丁酉], **Jǐ-Yǒu** [己酉], **Xīn-Yǒu** [辛酉], and **Guǐ-Yǒu** [癸酉].
**Metal** [金] prevails, hence **grasses and trees grow late** [草木晚生荣]. In the human body, this causes **internal tendons and bones to stiffen and fail to function** [筋骨内应而不用].

The **qi of Great Cold** [大冻之气], shifting and altering in its season [变易时侯], then **causes chill and clearness in the human body** [人寒清发於中]. When **internalized**, the **Liver** [肝] is affected by this **cold qi** [寒气], resulting in **intermittent fevers** [疢疟].

The **Large Intestine** [大肠] resides on the right, and **Lung qi** [肺气] communicates with it. Now, when **Lung qi** [肺气] **overacts internally** [内淫], the **Liver**, being on the left, thus **manifests as piercing pain in the left hypochondrium** [左朕胁痛如刺割].

In such years, the people **suffer from spontaneous urination or diarrhea** [自注泄], yet they **do not experience overactive or defeated disorders** [无淫胜之疾].

**Great Cold** [大冻] is the **second stage of Cold** [次寒]. When **Great Cold** [大冻] is **extreme**, **Yang qi** [阳气] does not flow, hence **trees and plants wither and grow late** [木容收敛，草荣悉晚]. As **vital energy** [生气] has already ascended, **Yang** [阳] fails to spread and command, thus **congested vital energy accumulates below** [闭积生气而蓄於下]. In its **human correspondence**, this **settles as painful qi in the lower abdomen** [少腹之内，痛气居之].

Diseases erupt in **mid-summer** [仲夏], while **ulcerative and carbuncle disorders** [疮疡之疾] persist until **autumn** [秋中]. **Convulsive breath** [疮痉之息] arises from the **upper body** [生於上], while **paralytic and swollen breath** [瘫肿之息] originates from the **lower body** [生於下]. Though **ulcers appear red** [疮色虽赤], their **core remains white** [中心正白], a **natural trait of vital energies** [物气之常].

○ **Newly corrected and verified** [新校正云] states:
According to the *Jiǎ-Yǐ Jīng* [《甲乙经》], **waist pain prevents bending or bowing** [腰痛不可以俯仰], **men develop epilepsy or hernia** [丈夫症疝], and **women suffer lower abdominal swelling** [妇人少腹肿]. In severe cases, **the face becomes parched and dusty** [甚则隘乾面尘], marking **Liver illness** [为肝病].
Again, **chest fullness and spontaneous diarrhea** [胸满洞泄] are **Liver illness** [为肝病].
Again, **piercing chest pain** [心胁#10痛] **prevents turning or lying on one’s side** [不能反侧], **eye detachment and temple ulcers** [目脱毗疡#11], **swelling in the supraclavicular fossa** [缺盆中肿痛], **axillary swelling** [掖下肿], **sweating with cold shivers** [马刀挟撄#12汗出振寒], and **intermittent fevers** [疟] are **Gallbladder illness** [为胆病].

This is because **Yangming governs the sky** [阳明司天], and **Metal conquers Wood** [金克木], hence the diseases manifest thus. Again, according to the *Mài Jiě* [《脉解》], the **epilepsy and hernia** [所谓癫疝] and **lower abdominal swelling in women** [妇人少腹肿] attributed to **Juéyīn** [厥阴] are due to **Chén** [辰] (the year). In the **third month** (of the year), **Yin within Yang** [阳中之阴] prevails, and **evil resides in the center** [邪在中], hence **epilepsy, hernia, and lower abdominal swelling** [故日癫疝少腹肿]. (The character **座** [座] is pronounced *zuò*, as in "sister" and "harvest.")

The **Great Surge** [太冲] ceases, and death ensues without remedy.

The **Great Surge** is located two inches posterior to the joint of the big toe on the foot [太冲在足大指本节后二寸], where its pulse beats in response to touch—this is the **Liver’s *qi*** [肝之气也]. When **Metal invades to subdue Wood** [金来伐木], the Liver’s *qi* is internally exhausted, and **True *qi* cannot overcome evil** [真不胜邪], hence death is inevitable.

When **Tàiyáng governs the sky** [太阳司天], **excessive cold** [寒淫] prevails, and **cold *qi* reverses its course** [财寒气反至], causing **water to congeal like ice** [水且冰], and **blood to alter within the body** [血变於中]. This manifests as **paralytic ulcers** [发为瘫疡], with the people suffering from **sudden heart pain** [厥心痛], **hemoptysis and blood in stool** [呕血血泄], **sighing and weeping** [欤钮], **a tendency toward melancholy** [善悲], and **occasional dizziness or collapse** [时眩仆]. The **year’s *yún* of Fire** [运火] blazes fiercely, and **heavy rains bring hail** [雨暴乃雹].

**Chest and abdominal distension** [胸腹满], **palm heat and elbow stiffness** [手热肘孪], **axillary swelling** [掖肿], **a restless, surging heart** [心澹澹大动], **discomfort in the chest, flanks, stomach, and lower abdomen** [胸胁胃院不安], **flushed face and yellow eyes** [面赤目黄], **frequent sighing** [善噫], **dry throat** [啦乾], and in severe cases, **thirst with a desire to drink** [甚则色□#13渴而欲饮], all originate from **disease in the Heart** [病本於心].

This refers to the years **Jiāchén** [甲辰], **Bǐngchén** [丙辰], **Wùchén** [戊辰], **Gēngchén** [庚辰], **Rénchén** [壬辰], **Jiāxū** [甲戌], **Bǐngxū** [丙戌], **Wùxū** [戊戌], **Gēngxū** [庚戌], and **Rénxū** [壬戌].

When **Tàiyáng governs the sky** [太阳司天], **cold *qi* pervades and transforms** [寒气布化], thus **water congeals like ice** [故水且冰], and **blood clots between the skin and flesh** [而血凝皮肤之问], with **Defensive *qi* stagnating and gathering** [卫气结聚], hence the **paralysis** [故为瘫也]. If the **year’s *yún* of Fire** [乘火运] is intense and **fire’s heat blazes fiercely** [而火热#14炎烈], clashing with water, it results in **sudden downpour and hail shaped like half-pearls** [故暴雨半珠形雹也].

The **Heart’s *qi* causes sighing** [心气为噫], hence the frequent sighing [故善噫]. In these years, **diseases converge in the Heart and flanks** [病集於心胁之中], where **Yang *qi* is internally suppressed** [阳气内郁], and **Damp *qi* steams downward** [湿气下蒸]. Thus, **sudden heart pain and hemoptysis** [心厥痛而呕血], **blood in stool and sighing** [血泄轨钮], **flushed face and yellow eyes** [面赤目黄], **frequent sighing** [善噫], **palm heat and elbow stiffness** [手热肘挛], **axillary swelling** [掖肿], and **dry throat** [哑乾] occur. In severe cases, **cold *qi* overpowers Yang** [寒气胜阳], **water’s flow invades Fire** [水行凌火], and **fire’s *qi* is internally suppressed** [火气内郁], hence the **thirst with a desire to drink** [故渴而欲饮].

The disease **first arises in the Heart** [病始心生], due to **Yin’s invasion and aggression** [为阴凌犯], hence it is said that the disease originates from the Heart [故云病本於心].

**Newly corrected version** [○新校正云]:
According to the *Jiā-Yǐ Jīng* [《甲乙经》], **palm heat, elbow stiffness, and axillary swelling** [手热肘挛掖肿], and in severe cases, **chest and flank distension** [甚则胸胁支满], **a restless, surging heart** [心澹澹大动], and **flushed face and yellow eyes** [面赤目黄], are symptoms of **Heart Center illness** [为手心主病].

Again, when **evil resides in the Heart** [邪在心], the people suffer from **heart pain and melancholy** [病心痛善悲], as well as **occasional dizziness or collapse** [时眩仆].

This is because, in the **Tàiyáng governs-the-sky years** [太阳司天之岁], **Water subdues Fire** [水克火], hence the diseases manifest thus.

When the **Spirit Gate** [神门] is severed, death is incurable. The **Spirit Gate** lies at the back of the palm, at the tip of the sharp bone, where the pulse responds to touch—this is the true **Heart qi** [真心气]. When **Water overpowers Fire** [水行胜火], the **Heart qi** is internally severed [心气内绝], and the **Spirit-qi** [神气] has already perished—what need is there to await death? Those skilled in diagnosis thus deem it incurable.

What is meant by **"moving qi"** [动气]? It refers to knowing the **viscera** [藏]. How does one diagnose death through examination? Because all these are the **pulses and moving qi** of the **visceral channels**—thus one discerns the **survival or extinction of the Spirit-organs** [神藏之存亡].

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

How then should one treat it? [i.e., *What remedies may be applied?*]

**Gǐ Bó** replied: When the **celestial governing qi** [司天之气] is **overborne by Wind** [风淫所胜], one **balances it with pungent and cold** [平以辛冻], **assists with bitter and sweet** [佐以苦甘], **moderates with sweetness** [以甘缓之], and **relaxes with sourness** [以酸写之].

When the **Juéyīn qi** [厥阴之气] has not yet reached extreme heat, one **calms it with cool medicines** [故以凉药平之].

Now, the **application of qi** [气之用也]—when **cold accumulates, it becomes chill**; when **warmth accumulates, it becomes heat**. To **reduce heat**, one employs **warmth**; to **reduce chill**, one employs **cold**. To **increase warmth**, one employs **heat**; to **increase cold**, one employs **chill**. If each follows its proper measure, then **chill is chill**, **warmth is warmth**, **heat is heat**, and **coolness is coolness**. The principles of **formularies** [方书] must not be neglected!

Thus, **cold, heat, warmth, and chill**—their **transformation, decline, and dosage**—must be mastered by those skilled in prescriptions. The **residual qi** [余气] follows these same principles.

**Newly corrected version** [○新校正云]:
As the text above states: *"When excess is directed downward, balance it with its conqueror. When excess is directed inward, treat it with its conqueror."* Thus, on **Spring-and-Autumn days** [在泉日], one **treats**; on **Celestial Governing days** [司天日], one **balances**.

When **heat overpowers** [热淫所胜], one **balances with salty and cold** [平以咸寒], **assists with bitter and sweet** [佐以苦甘], and **contracts with sourness** [以酸收之]. When **heat has retreated but intermittently flares**, this is **Heart vacuity** [心虚], with **scattered qi failing to consolidate**—thus one **contracts with sourness**. Though one contracts with sourness, it must also be **augmented with cold** to **root out its source**.

When **heat is excessively severe**, one **disperses it with bitter**. If **shivering follows sweating**, the **evil qi has exhausted**—do not **chill with ice**. If **heat persists after sweating**, the **evil qi remains**—thus one **contracts with sourness**. If **heat recurs**, one **sweats again**. If **heat returns after sweating**, this is **visceral vacuity**—then one may **tonify the Heart**.

The method is thus unified: **All treatments for heat** must not **repeatedly disperse and repeatedly treat**—how much less should one **cycle through four transformations** and reverse them?

When **dampness overpowers** [湿淫所胜], one **balances with bitter and hot** [平以苦热], **assists with sour and pungent** [佐以酸辛], **dries with bitter** [以苦燥之], and **drains with bland** [以淡泄之]. Wherever **dampness lingers**, it manifests as **swelling and fullness**—but if one **eliminates dampness**, the **swelling and fullness will naturally subside**.

For diseases arising from dampness that **do not present swelling or fullness**, the same treatment applies. When **dampness is above**, one **vomits it with bitter**; when **dampness is below**, one **drains it with bitter** and **leaches it with bland**—thus it is **dried**. *"Draining"* refers to **promoting urination** to **facilitate small voiding** as the method.

Though **sourness is hot**, it is used to **promote urination** and **remove latent water**. In treating **dampness diseases**, failure to **induce urination** is **not the correct approach**.

**Newly corrected version** [○新校正云]:
As the text states: *"When dampness invades internally, assist with sour and bland."* Here, **"sour and pungent"** [酸辛]—**"pungent"** likely should be **"bland"** [淡]. When **dampness above is severe and hot**, one treats with **bitter and warm**, assists with **sweet and pungent**, and **stops with sweating** as the principle. If **warmth remains above the waist**, while **fire-qi is suppressed below**, with **dampness and suppression intermingling**, one uses **bitter, warm, sweet, and pungent medicines** to **release the exterior and induce sweating**, thus **relaxing** it. Hence it is said: *"Sweating is the method to eliminate the disease."*

When **fire overpowers** [火淫所胜], one **balances with salty and clear** [平以咸玲], **assists with sweet and bitter** [佐以甘苦], **contracts with sourness** [以酸收之], **disperses with bitter** [以苦发之], and **restores with sourness** [以酸复之]. The same applies to **heat excess** [热淫同]; **heat excess** follows this same principle, **restoring the original qi with sourness**. If one does not **restore the qi**, the **excess qi will leave a void**, **inviting the original disease** [招其本].

When **dryness overpowers** [燥淫所胜], one **balances with bitter and moist** [平以苦湿], **assists with sour and pungent** [佐以酸辛], and **drains with bitter** [以苦下之]. To **subdue dryness’ excess**, one again uses **bitter and moist**—this is the **flavor-nature of Fire**. What requires **draining** should be treated with **bitter**; what requires **tonification** should be treated with **sour**; what requires **relaxation** should be treated with **pungent**. When **clearing is excessive and produces cold**, which **lingers and does not disperse**, one **drains with bitter and moist**. If **qi is in excess**, one **relaxes it with pungent**. All **qi** follows this principle.

**Newly corrected version** [○新校正云]:
As the text above states: *"When dryness invades internally, treat with bitter and warm."* Here, **"bitter and moist"** [苦湿]—**"moist"** should be **"warm"** [温]. The **three instances of "moist"** in the text and annotations should all be **"warm."** Moreover, as the *Lùyùan Zhèngjì Dàlùn* [《六元正纪大论》] states: *"The governance of Tàiyáng, the year requires bitter to dry it."*

When **cold overpowers** [寒淫所胜], one **balances with pungent and hot** [平以辛热], **assists with bitter and sweet** [佐以苦甘], and **relaxes with salty** [以咸写之]. **Dispersing excess** must be **moderate**—do not overdo it.

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."*

If **evil qi reverses and overpowers**, how should one treat it? [*i.e.,* When **a non-conquering qi reverses to become the conquering evil**]

**Gǐ Bó** replied: When **Wind governs the earth** [风司於地], and **clearness reverses to overpower it**, one treats with **sour and warm** [治以酸温], **assists with bitter and sweet** [佐以苦甘], and **balances with pungent** [以辛平之]. When **Juéyīn is at the Spring-and-Autumn position** [厥阴在泉], then **Wind governs the earth**—referring to **Five Tiger years** [五寅岁] and **Five Monkey years** [五申岁].

When **evil qi is excessively strong**, one **first relaxes with sourness** and **assists with bitter and sweet**. When **evil qi retreats**, the **rightful qi is vacuous**, so one **tonifies and balances with pungent**.

When **heat governs the earth** [热司於地], and **cold reverses to overpower it**, one treats with **sweet and hot** [治以甘热], **assists with bitter and pungent** [佐以苦辛], and **balances with salty** [以咸平之]. When **Shàoyīn is at the Spring-and-Autumn position** [少阴在泉], then **heat governs the earth**—referring to **Five Rabbit years** [五卯] and **Five Rooster years** [五酉].

「One first **relaxes the evil qi**, and then **balances the rightful qi**.

When **Dampness governs the earth** [湿司於地], **Heat counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **bitter and cool** [治以苦玲], **assists with salty and sweet** [佐以咸甘], and **balances with bitter** [以苦平之]. When **Tàiyīn is at the Spring-and-Autumn position** [太阴在泉], then **Dampness governs the earth**—referring to **Five Snake years** [五辰岁] and **Five Dog years** [五戌岁] also.

The principle of **tonifying and relaxing** applies similarly to all remaining cases.

When **Fire governs the earth** [火司於地], **Cold counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **sweet and hot** [治以甘热], **assists with bitter and pungent** [佐以苦辛], and **balances with salty** [以咸平之]. When **Shàoyáng is at the Spring-and-Autumn position** [少阳在泉], then **Fire governs the earth**—referring to **Five Horse years** [五巳岁] and **Five Pig years** [五亥岁] also.

When **Dryness governs the earth** [燥司於地], **Heat counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **mild cold** [治以平寒], **assists with bitter and sweet** [佐以苦甘], and **balances with sour** [以酸平之], **harmonizing being most beneficial**. When **Yángmíng is at the Spring-and-Autumn position** [阳明在泉], then **Dryness governs the earth**—referring to **Five Rat years** [五子岁] and **Five Horse years** [五午岁] also. The nature of **Dryness**, while it **abhors Heat**, also **fears Cold**; thus, **cooling and warming in balance** is the most advantageous approach. #19

When **Cold governs the earth** [寒司於地], **Heat counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **salty and cool** [治以咸玲], **assists with sweet and pungent** [佐以甘辛], and **balances with bitter** [以苦平之]. When **Tàiyáng is at the Spring-and-Autumn position** [太阳在泉], then **Cold governs the earth**—referring to **Five Ox years** [五丑岁] and **Five Sheep years** [五未岁] also.

These six methods of **Daoist/Wayist qi** treatment differ from the previous **excessive counteracting** principles. #20
The term **"treat"** [治] refers to **relaxing the counteracting evil qi**.
The term **"assist"** [佐] refers to **what is beneficial and suitable**.
The term **"balance"** [平] refers to **tonifying the already weakened rightful qi**.

The Emperor asked: **"How does one treat when the evil qi governs the Heaven?"**
Qībó replied:
When **Wind transforms in Heaven** [风化於天], **Cold counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **sour and warm** [治以酸温], **assists with sweet and bitter** [佐以甘苦].
This occurs in **Five Horse years** [巳亥岁] and **Five Pig years** [亥].

When **Heat transforms in Heaven** [热化於天], **Cold counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **sweet and warm** [治以甘温], **assists with bitter, sour, and pungent** [佐以苦酸辛].
This occurs in **Five Rat years** [子午岁] and **Five Horse years** [午].

When **Dampness transforms in Heaven** [湿化於天], **Heat counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **bitter and cold** [治以苦寒], **assists with bitter and sour** [佐以苦酸].
This occurs in **Five Ox years** [丑未岁] and **Five Sheep years** [未].

When **Fire transforms in Heaven** [火化於天], **Cold counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **sweet and hot** [治以甘热], **assists with bitter and pungent** [佐以苦辛].
This occurs in **Five Tiger years** [寅申岁] and **Five Monkey years** [申].

When **Dryness transforms in Heaven** [燥化於天], **Heat counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **pungent and cold** [治以辛寒], **assists with sweet and bitter** [佐以甘苦].
This occurs in **Five Rabbit years** [卯酉岁] and **Five Rooster years** [酉].

When **Cold transforms in Heaven** [寒化於天], **Heat counteracts and overpowers it**, one treats with **salty and cool** [治以咸玲], **assists with bitter and pungent** [佐以苦辛].
This occurs in **Five Dragon years** [辰戌岁] and **Five Dog years** [戌].

The Emperor asked: **"How does the counteracting of the Six Qi manifest?"**
Qībó replied: **"First, I shall describe their effects when they are counteracting."**

When **Juéyīn’s counteracting** is excessive,
there is **tinnitus and dizziness** [耳呜头眩], **a desire to vomit with sourness and resentment** [债愤欲吐], **stomach discomfort as if cold** [胃隔如寒], **frequent gusts of wind** [大风数举], **insects fail to thrive** [保虫不滋], **abdominal and flank distension** [肚胁气并], **transformation into Heat** [化而为热], **yellowish-red urine** [小便黄赤], **pain in the stomach region near the heart** [胃院当心而痛], **upper flank discomfort** [上支两胁], **intestinal rumbling and diarrhea** [肠呜飧泄], **lower abdominal pain** [少腹痛], **discharge of red and white** [注下赤白], and in severe cases, **vomiting** [呕吐] and **obstruction of the gullet and throat** [鬲咽不通].
This occurs in **Five Horse years** [五巳岁] and **Five Pig years** [五亥岁].
The area below the heart and above the navel is the **stomach’s domain**.
The **"stomach gullet"** [胃鬲] refers to the upper portion of the stomach region and the lower part of the great gullet, where **Wind-Cold qi** manifests.
**"Qi distension"** [气并] means **one-sided accumulation**.
**"Gullet and throat obstruction"** [鬲咽] means **food and drink enter but are immediately expelled**.

When **Dampness counteracts above**, **Fire-qi stagnates internally**.
When **Dampness counteracts in the middle**, **Cold presses the lower Burner**.
**"Water overflowing the rivers and canals"** [水溢河渠] means **scaled insects leave the water**.
**"Yá"** [雅] refers to **the buttocks**.

If one treats the **Six Prevailings** [胜] without **draining and dispersing** [写遣], then the **prevailing qi will seep inward**, generating **various diseases** [内生诸病].

**First**, there is the **prevailing** [胜]—
