**Tàiyáng** [太阳] **primarily governs** [正司] **at 戌** [xū], its **secondary transformation** [对化] **at 辰** [chén].

The **primary governing and transformation** [正司化令] is **real** [实], while the **secondary governing and transformation** [对司化令] is **void** [虚].
When the **secondary transformation** [对化] prevails and **reversal** [复] occurs, the **primary transformation** [正化] does not retaliate. This note suggests that **reversal** [复] occurs **after** the **prevailing** [胜], but it seems unclear.

**Gēibó** [岐伯] replied: *"Your question is thorough indeed!*

When **Guìyīn** [厥阴] **reverses** [复], the **lower abdomen becomes rigid and distended** [少腹坚满], **wrapped in violent pain** [裹急暴痛], with **upright trees and flying sands** [偃木飞沙]—**wind prevails** [风为木胜], so **earthly nourishment fails** [土不荣]. **Heart pain** [厥心痛] arises, with **sweating, vomiting, and inability to ingest** [汗发呕吐，饮食不入]. If food enters but is **regurgitated** [复出], the **tendons and bones feel light and dizzy** [筋骨掉眩], and **cold seizes** [清厥] occurs. In severe cases, it **invades the spleen** [入脾], causing **food stagnation and vomiting** [食痹而吐].
**Scholarly annotations:**
- *裹* (guǒ) – **encase/wrap** [腹胁之中]
- *偃木飞沙* (yǎn mù fēi shā) – **a violent wind** [风之大]
- *掉* (diào) – **feel light/float** [肉中动]
- *清厥* (qīng jué) – **cold extremities** [手足玲]
- *食痹* (shí bì) – **unbearable food stagnation** [食已心下痛，阴阴然不可名]

If **the Dao/Way of the stomach’s descending flow is obstructed** [胃气逆而不下流], food and drink **cannot enter** [食饮不入], or if they enter but **are expelled again** [入而复出], it is because **the liver overpowers the spleen and stomach** [肝乘脾胃]. If **the Suīng-Dao/Way of the stomach is severed** [冲阳绝], death is **untreatable** [死不治].
**Suīng-Dao/Way** [冲阳] refers to **the stomach’s channel and qi** [胃脉气].

When **Shàoyīn** [少阴] **reverses** [复], **internal heat and suffocation arise** [燠热内作], causing **restlessness, irritability, and sneezing** [烦躁欺嚏], with **lower abdominal twisting pain** [少腹绞痛].
**Fire** [火] **manifests as radiant brilliance** [墦炳], **constricting and drying** [隘燥], **distributing downward** [分注] at times. **Qi moves on the left** [气动於左], **ascends on the right** [上行於右], causing **coughing** [咳], **skin pain** [皮肤痛], **sudden sores and heart pain** [暴疮心痛], **obstructed consciousness** [郁冒不知人], and **sudden chills** [乃洒淅恶寒]. There is **shivering and delirium** [振栗谵妄], **chills followed by heat** [寒已而热], **thirst with desire to drink** [渴而欲饮], **shortness of breath and weakened bones** [少气骨萎], **obstructed intestines** [隔肠不便], **external floating edema** [外为浮肿], and **groaning** [喊噫].
**Dampness** [水] **transforms late** [后化], **flowing water does not freeze** [流水不冰], **heat-qi prevails** [热气大行], and **feathered insects perish** [介虫不福]. **Diseases manifest as food stagnation, sores, and festering** [病痹胎疮疡], **paralysis, gangrene, and hemorrhoids** [瘫疽座痔], and in severe cases, it **invades the lungs** [入肺], causing **coughing and nasal discharge** [咳而鼻渊].

The **fire-heat qi** [火热之气], entering from the **small intestine** [小肠] **at the left of the navel** [从脐下之左], **ascends to the left flank** [上行至左胁], and in severe cases, **ascends to the right** [甚则上行於右] and **invades the lungs** [入肺], hence **qi moves on the left while ascending on the right** [动於左，上行於右], causing **skin pain** [皮肤痛].
**分注** (fēn zhù) – **distributing downward** [大小俱下].
**骨萎** (gǔ wěi) – **weakened bones** [言骨弱无力].
**隔肠** (gé cháng) – **obstructed intestines** [肠如隔绝而不便写], especially when **chills and heat are severe** [寒热甚则然].

Since **Yángmíng** [阳明] **prevails first** [先胜], **dampness transforms late** [赤气后化], and **flowing water does not freeze** [流水不冰]. **Shàoyīn** [少阴] **primarily governs the earth** [本司於地], so in humans, **winter pulses do not congeal** [冬脉不凝].
If **high mountains and deep valleys** [高山穷谷] are **already at their peak** [至高之处], water **should freeze** [亦当冰], but if it **flows freely in the plains** [平下川流], it follows the **classical Dao/Way** [经].

**Fire-qi** [火气] **steams internally** [内蒸], while **metal-qi** [金气] **resists externally** [外拒]. **Internal Yáng-heat** [阳热内郁] **stagnates**, so **prickly heat and sores develop** [故为痱胜疮疡]. If the **prevailing** [胜] is severe, **sores** [疮] also appear.
When **heat is mild** [热少], **prickly heat and sores manifest externally** [外生痱胜]; when **heat is excessive** [热多], **internal paralysis and hemorrhoids form** [内结瘫座]. If **the small intestine has heat** [小肠有热], then **the anus** [户] **externally develops hemorrhoids** [外为痔]. These **reversals of heat** [热之变], all manifest as **diseases on the body’s posterior and lateral sides** [病於身后及外侧].

**Sores, festering, and prickly heat** [疮疡痱胜] **generate in the upper** [上], while **paralysis, gangrene, and hemorrhoids** [瘫疽痉痔] **generate in the lower** [下]. If they **manifest in reverse** [反其处], it is **inverted** [逆].
If **the Dao/Way of the lungs’ descending flow is severed** [天府绝], death is **untreatable** [死不治].
**天府** [Tiānfǔ] refers to **the lung’s channel and qi** [肺脉气].

**Newly annotated text states:** According to the **upper text** [上文], **Shàoyīn** [少阴] **governs the heavens** [司天], and if **heat rampantly prevails** [热淫所胜], **the Chi-Zé** [尺泽] ** Dao/Way is severed** [绝], death is **untreatable** [死不洽].

Shào-yáng [少阳] governs the heavens [司天], and when **fire rampantly prevails** [火淫所胜], **the Chi-Zé [尺泽] Dao/Way is severed** [绝], death is **untreatable** [死不治].

This passage describes **the Shàoyīn [少阴] reversal** [复], where **the lung’s channel and qi [天府, 肺脉气]** is severed [绝], rendering death **untreatable** [死不治]. The **lower text [下文]** speaks of **the Shào-yáng [少阳] reversal** [复], where **the Chi-Zé [尺泽, 肺脉气]** is severed [绝], death is **untreatable** [死不治]. When the text **contradicts in this manner** [相反], it is because **both Chi-Zé [尺泽] and Tiānfǔ [天府]** are **Dao/Way-points** [脉] of the **hand Tài-yīn [太阴]** channel, hence the **reciprocal phrasing** [互文].

In **the Tài-yīn [太阴] reversal** [复], **dampness** [湿] **manifesting as disease** [变] **prevails** [举], causing **the body to feel heavy and distended** [体重中满], **indigestion** [食饮不化], **rising of yīn-qi [阴气]** to the chest, **discomfort in the chest** [胸中不便], **water-related symptoms** [饮] **emerging in the midsection** [发於中], and **coughing with wheezing** [咳喘有声]. **Heavy rainfall occurs in due season** [大雨时行], and **scaly lesions appear on dry land** [鳞见於陆]. **The crown of the head aches severely** [头顶痛重], with **skin flaking and moles** [掉痣] **particularly pronounced** [尤甚], **nausea accompanied by silent retching** [呕而密默], **spitting clear fluids** [唾吐清液], and in severe cases, **penetrating the kidneys** [入肾], leading to **uncontrolled orifices** [窍写无度]. **Dampness reverses internally** [湿气内逆], while **cold qi fails to circulate** [寒气不行], and **Tài-yáng [太阳] qi ascends** [上流], thus generating these **symptoms** [病]. When **the crown of the head aches severely** [头顶痛重], it indicates **excessive flaking and moles on the brain** [脑中掉痣尤甚]. **Cold dampness in the intestines and stomach** [肠胃寒湿] **blocks heat circulation** [热无所行], requiring **scorching of the chest cavity** [灼胸府], hence **chest discomfort** [胸中不便] and **indigestion** [食饮不化]. **Silent retching** [呕而密默] signifies **a desire for stillness** [静定]. **A harsh sensation in the throat** [喉中恶玲] causes **spitting of clear fluids** [唾吐玲水]. If **cold qi shifts its position** [寒气易位], ascending into the **lungs and throat** [肺喉], it obstructs **the breath’s Dao/Way** [息道], resulting in **coughing and wheezing with throat sounds** [咳喘而喉中有声]. **Water stagnates in flat terrain** [水居平泽], so **fish swim in the marketplace** [鱼游於市]. **Head crown and chest pain** [头顶胸痛] may also affect women, causing **additional pain in the brow region** [兼痛於眉问].

In **the Tài-yáng [太阳] reversal** [复], **jué-qi [厥气] ascends** [上行], **water condenses into rain and freezes into ice** [水凝雨冰], and **winged insects die** [羽虫乃死]. **Cold arises in the heart and stomach** [心胃生寒], causing **chest discomfort** [胸中不利], **heart pain and distension** [心痛否满], **headache with melancholy** [头痛善悲], **occasional dizziness and collapse** [时眩仆], **indigestion** [食臧], **waist stiffness turning into pain** [腰雅反痛], **difficulty in bending and stretching** [屈伸不便], **earth cracking and ice solidifying** [地裂冰坚], **and the sun’s Dao/Way failing to treat cold** [阳光不治]. In severe cases, **the lower abdomen contracts the testicles** [少腹控睪], **pulling the waist and spine** [引腰脊], **and ascending to assault the heart** [上冲心], causing **spitting clear water** [唾出清水], **and hiccups** [及为喊噫], which may **penetrate the heart** [入心], leading to **amnesia and melancholy** [善忘善悲]. **Rain-ice** [雨冰] refers to **hail** [雹]. **Cold encountering hail** [寒而遇雹] **is particularly fatal** [死亦其宜]. **Cold transforms into earth** [寒化於地], and its **upper layer is soil**, hence **the earth’s structure cracks** [地体分裂] and **water accumulates into solid ice** [水积冰坚]. If **this condition persists without resolution** [久而不释], it indicates **the sun’s Dao/Way failing to treat cold** [阳光不治] **and the congealing of water** [寒凝之物]. The **Tài-yáng [太阳] reversal** [复] **does not align with its usual pattern** [与不相持], resulting in **upper dampness and lower cold** [上湿下寒], **fire having no place to go** [火无所往], **heart qi suppressed internally** [心气内郁], and **heat arising from this** [热由是生]. **Fire and heat internally congeal** [火热内墦], thus generating these **symptoms** [病].

If **the Shénmén [神门] Dao/Way is severed** [绝], death is **untreatable** [死不治]. **Shénmén [神门]** refers to **the true heart’s channel and qi** [真心脉气].

The **Emperor** [帝] said: **Well done** [善]. How should these **reversed conditions** [复气] be treated? **The Yellow Emperor** [岐伯] replied: In **the Juéyīn [厥阴] reversal** [复], **treat with sour and cold** [治以酸寒], **assist with sweet and pungent** [佐以甘辛], **to drain with sour** [以酸写之], **and moderate with sweet** [以甘缓之]. If **not moderated sufficiently** [不大缓之], **symptoms persist even in summer** [夏犹不已], and **the reversal intensifies** [复重於胜], hence **treat with pungent and cold** [故治以辛寒].

In **the Shàoyīn [少阴] reversal** [复], **treat with salty and cold** [治以咸寒], **assist with bitter and pungent** [佐以苦辛], **to drain with sweet** [以甘写之], **and constrict with sour** [以酸收之], **to stimulate with bitter** [以苦发之], and **to consolidate with salty** [以咸奥之]. If **not induced to sweat profusely** [不大发汗], **treat with cold to attack internally** [以寒攻之], **and persist until mid-autumn** [持至仲秋], **internal heat will congeal and form heart heat** [热内伏结而为心热], resulting in **weakened qi and diminished strength** [少气少力], **and inability to rise** [而不能起].
○**Newly annotated text states:** **Internal heat, if suppressed, returns to the bones** [热伏不散，归於骨].

In **the Tài-yīn [太阴] reversal** [复], **treat with bitter and hot** [治以苦热], **assist with sour and pungent** [佐以酸辛], **to drain with bitter** [以苦写之], **to dry with bitter** [燥之], and **to purge with bitter** [泄之].

「If **dryness and purgation** [燥泄] are not applied, **prolonged illness will lead to body swelling and abdominal distension** [身肿腹满], **stiff joints** [关节不利], **and when it reaches the stage of *Fù-tu* [伏兔] and *Fèi-mǎn* [怫满], internal turmoil ensues** [内作], **manifesting as *Shǔ* [膝] and *Yāo* [腰]—**the inner lateral sides of the knees and waist—**becoming **congested and swollen** [驸肿], **a condition known as *bone-heat disease* [骨热病].**

In **the Shǎo-yáng [少阳] reversal** [复], **treat with salty and resonant** [咸玲] **therapies** [治], **assist with bitter and pungent** [佐以苦辛], **to consolidate with salty** [以咸奥之], **to constrict with sour** [以酸收之], **and to stimulate with pungent and bitter** [辛苦发之].
**Sweating should not stray far from the heat** [发不远热], **nor should one violate the principle of avoiding excessive warmth or cold** [无犯温凉].**

**The Shǎo-yín [少阴] reversal follows the same method** [同法].

If **sweating is not induced to deplete excessive Yang** [不发汗以夺盛阳], **internal heat will pervade the four limbs** [热内淫於四支], **resulting in *Jiě-rán* [解然]—**a fever of indeterminate nature** [不可名也].**
**When heat is not extreme, when cold is not extreme, when strength is not extreme, or when weakness is not extreme**, **it cannot be named or described** [不可以名言], **thus it is called *Jiě-rán* [解然].** **Rudimentary physicians label this as *Guǐ-qì è bìng* [鬼气恶病]—**the malevolent *ghost-qi* disease.**

If **this condition persists unabated** [久久不已], **then bone heat, marrow depletion, and dry teeth ensue** [骨热髓涸齿乾], **thus manifesting as *bone-heat disease* [骨热病].**
**Since sweating depletes Yang**, **there should be no lingering heat** [故无留热]. **Therefore, even if heat-induced illness arises in summer**, **once recovery begins, hot therapies are still used to stimulate sweating** [及差亦用热药以发之].

However, **during spring and autumn**, **even if fire-heat prevails** [纵火热胜], **one must not use hot therapies to induce sweating** [亦不得以热药发汗], **for if sweating does not occur while heat remains intense internally** [汗不发而药热内甚], **it will exacerbate the illness, leading to intermittent fever** [助病为疟], **and offend the *Shén* [神]—**the vital spirits.** **Hence, the admonition: *do not violate warmth and cold* [无犯温凉].**

**In the Shǎo-yín [少阴] reversal**, **the method for heat is the same** [气热，为疗则同], **thus it is stated: *follows the same method as Shǎo-yín* [故云与少阴同法也].**

If **sweating is repeatedly suppressed** [数夺其汗], **then the body fluids will be exhausted and dried up** [津液竭涸], **hence the use of sour to constrict** [以酸收] **and salty to moisten** [以咸润].

In **the Yáng-míng [阳明] reversal** [复], **treat with pungent and warm** [治以辛温], **assist with bitter and sweet** [佐以苦甘], **to purge with bitter** [以苦泄之], **to descend with bitter** [以苦下之], **and to supplement with sour** [以酸补之].
**Purgation refers to permeation and drainage** [泄谓渗泄], **including sweating, urination, and baths** [汗及小便、汤浴皆是也].

**Around the Autumnal Equinox** [秋分前后], **sweating may also be induced** [则亦发之], **and in cases of excess during spring**, **follow the method of the excess** [春有胜则依胜法]. **If the condition does not cease**, **also use decoctions or immersions to harmonize internally and externally** [或不已，亦汤渍和其中外也].

**After an outbreak of anger** [怒复之后], **the *qi* is all depleted** [其气皆虚], **hence supplementing to secure the *qi*** [故补之以安全其气].

**The remaining reversals follow the same treatment principles** [余复治同].

In **the Tài-yáng [太阳] reversal** [复], **treat with salty and hot** [治以咸热], **assist with sweet and pungent** [佐以甘辛], **and to solidify with bitter** [以苦坚之].
**If not solidified**, **internal cold *qi* will transform and fluctuate** [寒气内变], **stopping and restarting, restarting and stopping** [止而复发，发而复止], **dragging on for years** [绵历年岁], **and giving rise to a great cold ailment** [生大寒疾].

**In treating all excess reversals** [治诸胜复], **apply heat to cold conditions** [寒者热之], **cold to heat conditions** [热者寒之], **cooling to excessive warmth** [温者清之], **warming to excessive cooling** [清者温之], **constriction to dispersion** [散者收之], **dispersion to suppression** [抑者散之], **moistening to dryness** [燥者润之], **gentleness to urgency** [急者缓之], **consolidation to fragility** [脆者坚之], **supplementation to depletion** [一哀者补之], **and purgation to excess** [强者写之]. **Each therapy should stabilize the *qi*** [各安其气], **and must be both clear and tranquil** [必清必静], **then the pathogenic *qi* will weaken and depart** [则病气衰去], **returning to its original source** [归其所宗]. **This is the fundamental principle of treatment** [此治之大体也].

**The Tài-yáng [太阳] *qi* is cold**, **the Shǎo-yín [少阴] and Shǎo-yáng [少阳] *qi* are hot**, **the Jué-yín [厥阴] *qi* is warm**, **the Yáng-míng [阳明] *qi* is cooling**, **and the Tài-yīn [太阴] *qi* is damp** [太阴气湿]. **In cases of excess reversal**, **each should be doubled in its respective *qi* to regulate it** [有胜复则各倍其气以调之], **thus restoring balance** [故可使平也].
**宗 [Zōng] means *affiliation* [属].**

If **regulation does not deviate from principle** [调不失理], **then the remaining *qi* will return to its proper domain** [则余之气自归其所属], **and the deficient *qi* will settle in its proper abode** [少之气自安其所居]. **Once the excess reversal has subsided** [胜复衰已], **each should be supplemented and nourished to achieve stability** [则各补养而平定之]. **If the *qi* is clear and the spirit tranquil** [爻清铃静], **and there is no reckless disturbance** [无妄挠之], **then the Six *Qi* will cycle harmoniously** [则六气循环], **and the Five *Shén* [神]—**the vital spirits—**will remain secure** [五神安泰].

If **the seasonal *Qi*’s cold or heat** [运气之寒热] **is treated and balanced** [治之平之], **it will also return to govern the *Tīan* [天] and *Dì* [地] *Qi*** [亦各归司天地气也].

The **Emperor** [帝] said: **Well done** [善].
**The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: Plain Questions—**Supplementary Commentary, **Volume Forty-Seven** [黄帝内经素问补注释文卷之四十七竟].

The **Sovereign** [主] said: **The original reads „*Shēng* [生]**. **The original reads „*Gù* [故]**, corrected according to the **Gu** [顾] version. **The original reads „*Gōng* [工]**. **The original reads „*Sī* [司]**, corrected according to the **Gu** [顾] version. **The original reads „*Jì* [颌]**. **The original reads „*Zài* [在]**, omitted in the original; restored from the **Po** [颇] version. **The original reads „*Biǎo* [表]**. **The original reads „*Zuǒ* [佐]**, corrected according to the **Xian** [显] version. **The original reads „*Lā* [啦]**. **The original reads „*Xiē* [胁]**. **The original reads „*Mù shuō pí tòng* [目说毗痛]**. **The original reads „*Sài* [赛]**. **The original reads „*Shǐ* [始]**, corrected according to the **Po** [颇] version. **The original reads „*Rè* [热]**, omitted in the original; restored from the **Po** [颇] version. **The original reads „*Chéng* [乘]**. **The original reads „*Jié* [结]**. **The original reads „*Tīan* [天]**, corrected according to the **Po** [颇] version. **The original reads „*Shǎn* [损]**. **The original reads „*Zhì* [制]**. **The original reads „*Yín* [淫]**, omitted in the original; restored from the **Gu** [顾] version. **The original reads „*Wèi* [谓]**, corrected according to the **Gu** [顾] version. **The original reads „*Yǐn* [引]**. **The original reads „*Lì* [鬲]**. **The original reads „*Xīn* [辛]**. **The original reads „*Jiě pái* [解俳]**. **The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon: Plain Questions—**Supplementary Commentary, **Volume Forty-Eight** [黄帝内经素问补注释文卷之四十八], **Tang Taipu Ling Qi Xuanzi Wang Bing’s annotations, Song Guanglu Qing Zhishi Ge Lin Yi’s corrections, and Song Shou Shangshu Tun Tian Lang Sun Zhao’s revision of errors** [唐太仆令启玄子王冰次注宋光禄卿直秘阁林亿等校正宋守尚书屯田郎孙兆重改误].

**至真要大论篇下** [至真要大论篇下]:

The **Emperor** [帝] asked: **How does the *Qi* move above and below** [气之上下，何谓也]?

**Qibo** [岐伯] replied: **Above the midpoint of the body, there are three *Qi*** [身半以上，其气三矣], **divided by Heaven** [天之分也], **ruled by the *Tīan* [天] *Qi*** [天气主之]; **below the midpoint of the body, there are three *Qi*** [身半以下，其气三矣], **divided by Earth** [地之分也], **ruled by the *Dì* [地] *Qi*** [地气主之].

**The *Qi* are named according to their domain** [以名命气], **and their domain is determined by the *Qi*** [以气命处], **to speak of their diseases** [而言其病]. **The midpoint is called the *Tīanshū* [天枢]**. **The midpoint of the body is precisely the navel** [身之半，正谓脐中也]. **Some take the waist as the midpoint of the body** [或以腰为身半], **but this is because they consider the center as the essence** [是以居中为义], **exceeding the Heavenly midpoint** [过天中也]. **All people of the Central Plains follow this** [中原之人悉如此矣].

**When extending the arm to point to Heaven and stretching the foot to point to Earth, measuring with a cord** [当伸臂指天，舒足指地，以绳量之], **the midpoint aligns with the navel** [中正当脐也], **hence it is also called *Tīanshū* [天枢]**. **The *Tīanshū* [天枢] is precisely the region two *cùn* [寸] above the navel, corresponding to the two *cùn* [寸] of the body’s measurement** [天枢，正当脐两傍，同身寸之二寸也].

**The three *Qi* above the midpoint** [其气三者]: **for instance, if *Shǎoyīn* [少阴] *Qi* governs Heaven** [假如少阴司天], **then there is *Rè* [热] *Qi* above and the *Tàiyáng* [太阳] *Qi* in the center, making three** [则上有热中有太阳兼之三也]. **This applies to all Six *Qi*** [六气皆然].

**The *Qi* governing Heaven have three domains** [司天者其气三], **and the *Qi* governing Earth have three domains** [司地者其气三], **hence there are three *Qi* above the midpoint of the body and three below** [故身半以上三气，身半以下三气也]. **The *Qi* are named according to their domains** [以名言其气], **their domains are determined by the *Qi*** [以气言其处], **and the diseases caused by the *Qi*’s imbalance of cold and heat are described by their symptoms** [以气处寒热，而言其病之形证也].

**For example, the *Qi* of the Foot *Juéyīn* [厥阴] channel** [则如足厥阴气] **resides within the inner aspect of the foot and thigh, ascending through the lower abdomen and following the ribs** [居足及股经之内侧，上行於少腹循胁]. **The Foot *Yángmíng* [阳明] *Qi*** [足阳明气] **is located above the foot, outside the *Fǔ* [腑], and in front of the thigh, ascending beside the abdomen and navel, following the chest and breasts to the surface** [在足之上，腑之外，股之前，上行腹脐之傍，循胸乳上面]. **The Foot *Tàiyáng* [太阳] *Qi*** [足太阳气] **originates at the eyes, ascends to the forehead and connects with the head, descends to the back of the neck and spine, passes across the waist, and horizontally traverses the *Páishū* [牌枢] and posterior thigh before descending into the *Shǐ* [驸], passing through the *Duǎn* [端], and emerging behind the lateral malleolus of the foot, at the outer side of the little toe** [下项背过腰，横过牌枢股后，下行入驸贯端，出外踝之后，足小指外侧]. **The Foot *Tàiyīn* [太阴] *Qi*** [足太阴气] **follows the inner aspect of the foot and thigh, ascending to the front of the abdomen and ribs** [循足及股经之内侧，上行腹胁之前]. **The Foot *Shǎoyīn* [少阴] *Qi* follows the same path** [足少阴同之]. **The Foot *Shǎoyáng* [少阳] *Qi*** [足少阳气] **follows the outer aspect of the channel, ascending beside the abdomen and ribs, and extending to the cheek, ear, and *Ruìbì* [锐毗], located at the side of the head** [循经外侧，上行腹胁之侧，循颊耳至目锐毗，在首之侧].

**These are the primary domains of the Six *Qi* of the Foot** [此足六气之部主也]. **The Hand *Juéyīn* [厥阴], *Shǎoyīn* [少阴], and *Tàiyīn* [太阴] *Qi*** [手厥阴少阴太阴气] **emanate horizontally from the chest and heart, following the inner aspect of the arm to the tips of the middle, ring, and index fingers** [从心胸横出，循臂内侧，至中指小指大指之端]. **The Hand *Yángmíng* [阳明], *Shǎoyáng* [少阳], and *Tàiyáng* [太阳] *Qi*** [手阳明少阳太阳气] **all originate at the Hand *Biǎo* [表], ascending along the outer aspect of the arm to the shoulder, upper arm, and head** [并起手表，循臂外侧，上肩及甲上头].

**These are the primary domains of the Six *Qi* of the Hand** [此手六气之部主也].

**To diagnose diseases, one must follow the *Qi*’s location and speak accordingly** [欲知病诊，当随气所在以言之]. **For the *Yīn* [阴] aspect, diseases are attributed to cold** [当阴之分，玲病归之], **and for the *Yáng* [阳] aspect, diseases are attributed to heat** [当阳之分，热病归之]. **Hence, when discussing the excess reversal of *Qi*** [故胜复之作], **it first mentions diseases caused by cold and heat** [先言病生寒热者], **which must rely on this principle of *Qi*** [必依此物理也].

**Newly corrected text states** [○新校正云]: **According to the *Lù Wēi Zhì Dà Lùn* [六微旨大论], it is said: **Above the *Tīanshū* [天枢], the *Yáng* [阳] *Qi* governs** [天枢之上，夭气主之], **below the *Tīanshū* [天枢], the *Yīn* [阴] *Qi* governs** [天枢之下，地气主之], **and the realm where the *Qi* intersect is where human *Qi* originates** [气交之分，人气从之]. **Thus, when the upper *Qi* prevails and the lower *Qi* is also diseased, it is named according to Earth** [故上胜而下俱病者，以地名之]; **when the lower *Qi* prevails and the upper *Qi* is also diseased, it is named according to Heaven** [下#1胜而上俱病者，以天名之].

**If one *Qi* prevails while the other cannot yet reverse** [彼气既胜，此未能复], **it is suppressed and cannot flow freely** [抑#2郁不畅], **and has nowhere to go** [而无所行]. **Advancing further, it is hindered by great obstacles** [进则困於伟嫌], **and retreating, it is confined by resentment and blockage** [退则穷於怫塞]. **Hence, when the upper *Qi* prevails to its extreme, the lower *Qi* is also diseased** [故上胜至则下与俱病], **and when the lower *Qi* prevails to its extreme, the upper *Qi* is also diseased** [下胜至则上与俱病].

「When the upper *Qi* prevails and the lower *Qi* is diseased, it is the Earth *Qi* that is congested [上胜下病，地气郁也], hence it is named *Earth Disease* [故从地郁以名地病]. When the lower *Qi* prevails and the upper *Qi* is diseased, it is the Heaven *Qi* that is blocked [下胜上病，天气塞也], hence it is named *Heaven Disease* [故从天塞以名天病].

The principle of naming according to Heaven [夫以天名者] means that one aligns with the Heaven *Qi* as the standard and counters the Earth *Qi* with attack. The principle of naming according to Earth [以地名者], if the Heaven *Qi* is the standard, is acceptable; for instance, when *Yangming* [陽明] governs Heaven and *Shaoyin* [少陰] is in the *Spring* [泉], if the upper *Qi* prevails and the lower *Qi* is also diseased, it arises from resentment in the lower [是怫於下而生也]. When the Heaven *Qi* is truly prevailing, Heaven can be countered [天气正胜，天可逆之], hence aligning with the Heaven *Qi* is akin to purity [故顺天之气，方同清也]. If *Shaoyin* [少陰] or *Shaoyang* [少陽] govern Heaven, the law of upper and lower prevailing follows the same principle [少阴少阳在泉，为火居水位。 阳明司天，为金居火位。 金复其胜，则火主胜之。 火复其胜，则水主胜之].

The *New Corrected Edition* states: According to the *Six Elements Standard Cycle Theory* [《六元正纪大论》], when the upper *Qi* prevails, the Heaven *Qi* descends and the lower is affected; when the lower *Qi* prevails, the Earth *Qi* ascends and the upper is affected [上胜则天气降而下，下胜则地气逆而上，此之谓也]. The so-called "prevailing to its extreme" [胜至] refers to the *reaction Qi* [报气] being subdued but not yet manifesting [报气屈伏而未发也], whereas when the *reaction Qi* manifests [复至], it does not follow the Heaven-Earth divergent naming [不以天地异名], but rather adheres to the principle of the *reaction Qi* [皆如复气为法也]. When the prevailing *Qi* has not yet reacted and disease arises [胜至未复而病生], the Heaven-Earth divergent naming is applied [以天地异名为式]. Once the *reaction Qi* manifests [复气已发], the resulting disease, whether from upper or lower prevailing, all depends on the *reaction Qi* [悉皆依复气为病], and the *Qi* of cold and heat governs it [寒热之主也].

The Emperor said: Are there fixed times for the dynamics of prevailing and reaction [胜复之动]? Is there a necessity in the *Qi* [气有必乎]? Qibo replied: There are fixed positions for time [时有常位], but the *Qi* has no necessity [而气无必也]. Though time has fixed positions, the manifestation and movement of the *Qi* may vary [虽位有常，而发动有无], and it cannot be rigidly determined [不铃定之也].

The Emperor said: I wish to hear its principle [愿闻其道也]. Qibo replied: From the beginning of the *prevailing Qi* [初气] to the end of the third *prevailing Qi* [终三气], the Heaven *Qi* governs [天气主之], and this is the fixed principle of prevailing [胜之常也]. From the fourth *prevailing Qi* [四气] to the end of the sixth *prevailing Qi* [尽终气], the Earth *Qi* governs [地气主之], and this is the fixed principle of reaction [复之常也]. When there is prevailing, there is reaction; when there is no prevailing, there is no reaction [有胜则复，无胜则否].

The Emperor said: Good [善]. What happens when reaction occurs and then prevailing resumes [复已而胜何如]? Qibo replied: When prevailing reaches its extreme [胜至], reaction follows [则复], but there is no fixed number [无常数]. If prevailing is slight [胜微], reaction is also slight [则复微], hence reaction may occur and prevailing resume again [故复已而又胜]. If prevailing is extreme [胜甚], reaction is also extreme [则复甚], hence reaction occurring means there is little chance of prevailing again [故复已则少有再胜者也]. Even if there is prevailing, it follows the principle of slight or extreme reaction [亦随微甚而复之尔]. However, the principle of prevailing and reaction, though without fixed numbers [虽无常数], when they decline [至其衰谢], both prevailing and reaction naturally cease [则胜复皆自止也].

When reaction occurs and then prevailing resumes [复已而胜], if there is no reaction, it becomes harmful [不复则害], and this is the injury of life [此伤生也]. If there is prevailing but no reaction [有胜无复], it means the *reaction Qi* has already declined [复气已衰], and the decline cannot react [衰不能复], indicating that the true Heaven *Qi* has been severely injured [天真之气已伤败甚], and the vital intention is exhausted [而生意尽].

The Emperor said: Why does reaction lead to the recurrence of disease [复而反病何也]? Qibo replied: It is because the *Qi* resides in a position that is not its own [居非其位], and thus they cannot harmonize [不相得也]. When the reaction is excessive against the prevailing [大复其胜], the prevailing *Qi* dominates [则主胜之], hence the recurrence of disease [故反病也]. If the governing *Qi* of a phase [己官观] is exhausted and borrowed from another phase [适於他邦], the governing *Qi*’s strength has declined [己力已衰], and the governing *Qi* cannot dominate [主不相得], resentment follows [怨随其后]. Only when the borrowed *Qi* is convenient [唯便是求] does the prevailing *Qi* reach its extreme and then the governing *Qi* retaliates [故力极而复，主反袭之], leading to the disease recurring from itself [反自病者也]. This is what is called *fire-drying-heat* [所谓火燥热也].

*Shaoyang* [少陽] is *fire* [火], *Yangming* [陽明] is *drying* [燥], and *Shaoyin* [少陰] is *heat* [热]. When *Shaoyin* [少陰] and *Shaoyang* [少陽] are in the *Spring* [泉], it is *fire* residing in the *water* position [为火居水位]. When *Yangming* [陽明] governs Heaven, it is *metal* residing in the *fire* position [为金居火位]. When *metal* reacts against its prevailing [金复其胜], *fire* governs the prevailing [则火主胜之]. When *fire* reacts against its prevailing [火复其胜], *water* governs the prevailing [则水主胜之]. If the remaining *Qi* prevails and reacts, there is no governing *Qi* of prevailing that causes disease [余气胜复，则无主胜之病气也]. Hence, it is said again: this is what is called *fire-drying-heat* [故又日所谓火燥热也].

The Emperor said: How should it be treated [治之奈何]? Qibo replied: When the *Qi* prevails, if it is slight [微者], follow its principle [随之]; if it is extreme [甚者], restrain it [制之]. When the *Qi* reacts, if it is harmonious [和者], balance it [平之]; if it is violent [暴者], subdue it [夺之]. All treatments follow the prevailing *Qi*, ensuring its subjugation [安其屈伏], without regard to its quantity [无问其数], aiming for balance [以平为期], and this is the principle [此其道也].

*Follow* [随] means to follow its principle. *Ensure its subjugation* [安] means to align with the prevailing *Qi* to harmonize it [顺胜气以和之也]. *Restraint* [制] means to suppress. *Balance* [平] means to regulate. *Subdue* [夺] means to suppress the prevailing *Qi* [夺其胜气也]. Treating this follows no fixed number [治此者，不以数之多少], but rather takes the balanced and harmonious *Qi* as the standard [但以气平和为准度尔].

The Emperor said: Good [善]. How does the prevailing and reaction of *guest* and *host Qi* [客主之胜复] proceed? *Guest* refers to the six *Qi* of Heaven [客，谓天之六气]. *Host* refers to the five phases’ positions [主，谓五行之位也]. Since the *Qi* has suitable and unsuitable conditions [气有宜否], each has its own prevailing and reaction [故各有胜复之者].

Qibo replied: The prevailing and reaction of *guest* and *host Qi* [客主之气] may occur without reaction [胜而无复也]. The *guest* and *host Qi* inherently have varying degrees [客主自有多少], and this differs from the fixed principle of prevailing [以其为胜与常胜殊].

The Emperor said: How do they conform or deviate [其逆从何如]? Qibo replied: When the *host Qi* prevails, it deviates [主胜逆]; when the *guest Qi* prevails, it conforms [客胜从], as per the Heavenly principle [天之道也]. The *guest Qi* follows the Heavenly mandate [客承天命], governing its region [部统其方], and the *host Qi* is subordinate [主为之下], naturally it should reverently follow the Heavenly mandate [固宜祗奉天命]. If it does not conform and yet prevails, the Heavenly mandate cannot proceed [不顺而胜，则天命不行], hence it deviates [故为逆也]. When the *guest Qi* prevails over the *host Qi* [客胜於主], it follows the Heavenly mandate and proceeds according to principle [承天而行], hence it conforms [理之道，故为顺也].

The Emperor said: How do they generate disease [其生病何如]? Qibo replied: When *Jueyin* [厥阴] governs Heaven, if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is ringing in the ears and dizziness [耳呜掉眩], severe cases involve coughing [甚则咳]; if the *host Qi* prevails, there is chest and flank pain, and difficulty in speaking [主胜则胸胁痛，舌难以言]. This occurs in the *Five Yi* [五巳] and *Five Hai* [五亥] years [岁也].

When *Shaoyin* [少陰] governs Heaven, if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is sneezing and stiffness in the neck and shoulders [欤嚏颈项强], shoulder and back heat [肩背瞥热], headache, shortness of breath [头痛少气], fever, deafness, and blurred vision [发热，耳聋，目瞑], severe cases involve scrotal swelling and blood overflow [甚则驸肿血溢], as well as sores, coughing, and wheezing [疮疡咳喘]; if the *host Qi* prevails, there is heart heat and restlessness [心热烦躁], severe cases involve flank pain and fullness in the hypochondrium [甚则胁痛支满]. This occurs in the *Five Zi* [五子] and *Five Wu* [五午] years [岁也].

When *Taiyin* [太阴] governs Heaven, if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is scrotal and facial swelling [首面驸肿], and difficulty in breathing [呼吸气喘]; if the *host Qi* prevails, there is fullness in the chest and abdomen [胸腹满], and belching after eating [食已而瞥]. This occurs in the *Five Chou* [五丑] and *Five Wei* [五未] years [岁也].

When *Shaoyang* [少陽] governs Heaven, if the *guest Qi* prevails, it manifests as external *measles* [丹脍外发], or as *measles*-like sores [及为丹嫖疮疡], vomiting, throat obstruction [呕逆喉痹], headache, and constricted swelling [头痛隘肿], deafness, and blood strangulation [耳聋血缢], internally causing *moles* and *herpes* [内为痣症]; if the *host Qi* prevails, there is chest fullness [胸满], coughing with upward gaze and labored breathing [咳仰息], severe cases may involve blood, and the hands are hot [甚而有血，手热]. This occurs in the *Five Yin* [五寅] and *Five Shen* [五申] years [岁也].

When *Yangming* [陽明] governs Heaven, if the *guest Qi* of *clear* [清] reacts internally and the *guest Qi* remains, it causes coughing with a sensation of obstruction [咳钮嗑塞], heat in the *epigastrium* [心鬲中热], incessant coughing, and the emission of white blood [咳不止，而白血出者死], leading to death [死].」

The return [復] refers to returning to one’s original abode [居].
White blood [白血] refers to coughing up pale red blood, resembling flesh or lung tissue.

In the *Five Mao* [五卯] and *Five You* [五酉] years [歲也].

---
The newly corrected annotation states: *"This does not mention guest or host prevalence [客勝主勝], for when Metal occupies the Fire position, there is no logic of guest prevalence, hence it is unsaid."*

When *Taiyang* [太陽] governs the *Dian* [泉],
if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is discomfort in the chest [胸中不利], clear nasal discharge [出清涕], and coughing upon catching cold [感寒則咳];
if the *host Qi* prevails, there is a sensation of obstruction in the throat [喉嗑中呜].

In the *Five Chen* [五辰] and *Five Xu* [五戌] years [歲也].

When *Jueyin* [厥陰] is in the *Dian* [泉],
if the *guest Qi* prevails, the major joints [大關節] are stiff, internally causing *tetany* [痉強], *spasms* [拘痣], and externally causing discomfort [不便];
if the *host Qi* prevails, the tendons and bones become rigid [筋骨縣並], with intermittent lumbar and abdominal pain [腰腹時痛].

The *major joints* [大關節] refer to the lumbar and knee regions [腰膝也].

When *Shaoyin* [少陰] is in the *Dian* [泉],
if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is lumbar pain [腰痛], with ailments affecting the buttocks, thighs, knees, calves, ankles, and feet [尸股膝脏踹腑足病], accompanied by sudden heat and acidity [瞥熱以酸], facial swelling [驸腫], inability to stand for long [不能久立], and altered bowel movements [沒便變];
if the *host Qi* prevails, the *ulcerating Qi* [厥氣] ascends, causing heart pain and fever [心痛發熱], epigastric distress [鬲中], and the onset of various *bi* syndromes [眾痹皆作], manifesting in the flanks [發於肚胁], with *sweat of the spirit* [魄汗不藏] and *four reversals* [四逆] arising.

In the *Five Mao* [五卯] and *Five You* [五酉] years [歲也].

When *Taiyin* [太陰] is in the *Dian* [泉],
if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is leg paralysis and heaviness [足痿下重], irregular bowel movements [便搜不時], dampness invading the lower burner [湿客下焦], manifesting as *dampness* [濡寫] or swelling [及為肿], and diseases of the *hidden and curved regions* [隐曲之疾];
if the *host Qi* prevails, cold *Qi* ascends and causes fullness [寒氣逆滿], with inability to ingest food or drink [食飲不下], and severe cases may develop into *hernia* [甚則為疝].

The *diseases of the hidden and curved regions* [隐曲之疾] refer to ailments in concealed and convoluted areas [隱蔽委曲之處病].

When *Shaoyang* [少陽] is in the *Dian* [泉],
if the *guest Qi* prevails, there is lumbar and abdominal pain with aversion to cold [腰腹痛而反惡寒], and severe cases may involve passing white urine [甚則下白溺白];
if the *host Qi* prevails, heat ascends and invades the heart [熱反上行而客於心], causing heart pain and fever [心痛發熱], and obstruction in the epigastrium with vomiting [格中而呕].
[The symptoms are] the same as for *Shaoyin* [少陰同候].

In the *Five Si* [五巳] and *Five Hai* [五亥] years [歲也].

When *Yangming* [陽明] is in the *Dian* [泉],
if the *guest Qi* prevails, clear *Qi* descends, causing lower abdominal fullness and frequent urination [少腹堅滿而數便寫];
if the *host Qi* prevails, there is lumbar heaviness and abdominal pain [腰重腹痛], cold in the lower abdomen [少腹生寒], and *duck pond syndrome* [下為鴨塘], leading to cold *ulceration* in the intestines [則寒厥於腸], ascending to cause chest oppression [上衝胸中], severe cases involving dyspnea [甚則喘], and inability to stand for long [不能久立].

In the *Five Zi* [五子] and *Five Wu* [五午] years [歲也], *duck* [驚], *duck* [鴨]—meaning like the sound of a duck’s cry [言如鴨之後也].

When *Taiyang* [太陽] is in the *Dian* [泉],
if cold *Qi* remains internally after returning [寒復內余], there is lumbar and buttock pain [腰尸痛], stiffness upon flexion and extension [屈伸不利], and pain in the thighs, calves, and knees [股經足膝中痛].

In the *Five Chou* [五丑] and *Five Wei* [五未] years [歲也].

The newly corrected annotation states: *"This does not mention guest or host prevalence [客主勝], for *Taiyang* resides in the Water position, hence it is unsaid."*

The Emperor said: *"Excellent."* How should one treat these conditions [治之奈何]?

Qì Bó said: *"The excessive must be suppressed, the deficient must be elevated, the overabundant must be reduced, the insufficient must be replenished. Assist with what is beneficial, harmonize with what is suitable. Ensure the balance between guest and host, adjust cold and warmth as needed. When the *Qi* are compatible, treat them oppositely; when incompatible, treat them according to their nature.*

*To suppress the excessive is to control its dominance. To elevate the deficient is to reinforce its weakness. To reduce the overabundant is to temper its sharpness. To replenish the insufficient is to preserve its *Qi*. Though one may control dominance and support weakness, guest and host must still be balanced. If the *Qi* lose their proper place, then contradictions arise, thorns and brambles flourish, each seizing its opportunity, failing to align—thus internal excess and external depletion occur, and the path to danger and failure begins.*

*Compatibility refers to cold, heat, warmth, and coolness, where the *Qi* harmonize among themselves. Incompatibility refers to Water, Fire, Metal, Wood, and Earth, which do not harmonize. When the *Qi* align, one treats them by countering the dominant *Qi*. When they do not align, one treats them by following the non-dominant *Qi*.*

*In treating Fire, whether in excess or deficiency, if one wishes to increase it, use its flavor; if one wishes to reduce it, also use its flavor—whether dominant or not, its *Qi* must be tempered. Why? Because its nature is impulsive and restless. The same applies in treating Heat."*

The Emperor said: *"I understand: treating cold with warmth, treating heat with cold, countering when the *Qi* align, and following when they do not. But I wish to hear about the three categories of Yin and Yang—what are they called?"*

Qì Bó replied: *"The host of the **Wood** position, for reduction use **sour**, for replenishment use **pungent**; the **Wood** position is the sixty-one days before the Spring Equinox, the first of the *Qi*.

The host of the **Fire** position, for reduction use **sweet**, for replenishment use **salty**; the **Jūn Fire** position is the sixty-one days after the Spring Equinox, the second of the *Qi*. The **Xiāng Fire** position is the thirty days before and after the Summer Solstice, the third of the *Qi*. Though the two Fire *Qi* differ in nature, their treatment principles remain unified.

The host of the **Earth** position, for reduction use **bitter**, for replenishment use **sweet**; the **Earth** position is the sixty-one days before the Autumn Equinox, the fourth of the *Qi*.

The host of the **Metal** position, for reduction use **pungent**, for replenishment use **sour**; the **Metal** position is the sixty-one days after the Autumn Equinox, the fifth of the *Qi*.

The host of the **Water** position, for reduction use **salty**, for replenishment use **bitter**; the **Water** position is the thirty days before and after the Winter Solstice, the final of the *Qi*.

For **Yùnyīn** as a guest, replenish with **pungent**, reduce with **sour**, and moderate with **sweet**; for **Shàoyīn** as a guest, replenish with **salty**, reduce with **sweet**, and consolidate with **salty**. *(The newly corrected annotation states: According to the *Zàng Qì Fǎ Shí Lùn* [藏气法时论], for the Heart, use **bitter** to moderate, and if it desires excess, quickly use **sour** to consolidate it. If it desires further change, quickly use **salty** to alter it. The previous statement that "consolidate with **salty**" is incorrect.)*

For **Tàiyīn** as a guest, replenish with **sweet**, reduce with **bitter**, and moderate with **sweet**; for **Shàoyáng** as a guest, replenish with **salty**, reduce with **sweet**, and invigorate with **salty**; for **Yángmíng** as a guest, replenish with **sour**, reduce with **pungent**, and drain with **bitter**; for **Tàiyáng** as a guest, replenish with **bitter**, reduce with **salty**, solidify with **bitter**, and moisten with **pungent**. This opens the pathways of dominance, directs the **Jīn Yè** [津液], and harmonizes the *Qi*.

The guest *Qi* reside in each position for sixty-one days, without fixed abode, following the seasonal shifts. When guest *Qi* dominate, reduce the guest and replenish the host; when host *Qi* dominate, reduce the host and replenish the guest. Treat according to whether the situation calls for moderation or urgency."*

Qi varies in abundance, differing in its applications. **Tàiyīn** is the true yin, **Tàiyáng** is the true yang; the next lesser ones are **Shàoyīn** and **Shàoyáng**, then **Yángmíng**, and finally **Juéyīn**, which is the culmination of yin. This meaning is fully elucidated in the *Língshū Jìrìyuè Lùn* [灵枢系日月论].

The newly revised text states: According to the *Liùyuán Zhèngjì Dàlùn* [六元正纪大论], what is meant by "Qi varies in abundance"? Guǐtū Qū [鬼突区] said: The *Qi* of yin and yang each have varying degrees of abundance, hence the saying "three yin and three yang."

The Emperor asked: What is meant by **Yángmíng**?
Qíbó replied: It is the confluence of the two yangs.
The *Língshū Jìrìyuè Lùn* [灵枢系日月论] states: The month of Chén [辰] is the third month, governing the **Yángmíng** of the left foot; the month of Wèi [巳] is the fourth month, governing the **Yángmíng** of the right foot. The two yangs converge in advance, hence it is called **Yángmíng**.

The Emperor asked: What is meant by **Juéyīn**?
Qíbó replied: It is the complete intersection of the two yins.
The *Língshū Fánrìyuè Lùn* [灵枢繁日月论] states: The month of Xū [戌] is the ninth month, governing the **Yuèyīn** [厌阴] of the right foot; the month of Hài [亥] is the tenth month, governing the **Yuèyīn** of the left foot. The two yins fully intersect, hence it is called **Juéyīn**.

The Emperor said: Qi varies in abundance, diseases fluctuate in severity; the newly revised text states: According to the *Liùyuán Zhèngjì Dàlùn* [六元正纪大论], the body varies in strength. Treatment has its urgency or moderation, prescriptions have their size—great or small. I wish to hear the principles governing these distinctions.

Qíbó replied: Qi has high and low positions, diseases have distant and near origins, symptoms manifest internally or externally, and treatments have varying degrees of weight. One must align the treatment to its intended target—this is the principle. The **Zàng** [藏] and **Fǔ** [府] have high and low positions, diseases and symptoms have superficial or deep layers, and medicinal applications have their own degrees of potency. Adjust the dosage to match the abundance, balance the tension and slackness, and ensure the medicinal *Qi* reaches the site of the disease—this is the way. Do not overdo or underdo it.

The *Dàyào* [大要] states:
- *"Jūn* one, *Chén* two—this is the principle of odd prescriptions;
- *Jūn* two, *Chén* four—this is the principle of even prescriptions;
- *Jūn* two, *Chén* three—this is the principle of odd prescriptions;
- *Jūn* three, *Chén* six—this is the principle of even prescriptions."

Odd refers to ancient single-herb prescriptions; even refers to ancient compound prescriptions. Both single and compound prescriptions vary in size, hence the odd prescriptions state: *Jūn* one, *Chén* two; *Jūn* two, *Chén* three; while the even prescriptions state: *Jūn* two, *Chén* four; *Jūn* three, *Chén* six. Diseases vary in size, *Qi* in distance, and treatments in weight—this is what is meant by "principle."

Thus it is said: For nearby diseases, use odd or even prescriptions; for distant ones, adjust the dosage accordingly. Small dosages are given more frequently; large ones less often. When frequent, administer in sets of nine; when sparse, in sets of two. The volume of decoctions and pills follows this principle as well.

Near and far refer to the positions of the **Zàng** [藏] and **Fǔ** [府]. The heart and lungs are considered near, the liver and kidneys far, while the spleen and stomach reside in between. The three yangs—governing the bladder, gallbladder, and bile—also have near and far distinctions: the upper third of the body is near, the lower third is far.

Some practitioners may perceive distant or subtle patterns, thus combining odd and even principles in their dosages—odd prescriptions with even parts, even prescriptions with odd parts. In such cases, if a disease is near and treated with even principles, administer more frequently; if far and treated with odd principles, administer less frequently. Thus, the lungs receive nine doses, the heart seven, the spleen five, the liver three, and the kidneys one—this is the principle of odd prescriptions.

Hence it is said: Small dosages require more frequent administration; large ones require fewer.

The newly revised text states: Detailed annotations clarify that the "three yangs" and "three intestines" in the original text were likely misrecorded. The yangs have no meaning here, and "three intestines" is also unsatisfactory. The intestines have large and small distinctions, and the term *sāng* [胪] refers to the small intestine. Since the large and small intestines have already been mentioned, it is incorrect to refer to "three intestines." The "three" should be "two."

When odd prescriptions fail, resort to even ones—this is called a "double prescription." When even prescriptions fail, use opposite properties to treat them, as in the principle of "leaping contrary" with cold and hot, warm and cool, to address the disease's *Qi*.

Prescriptions should prefer lightness over excess, gentleness over toxicity, and smallness over largeness. Therefore, if an odd prescription fails, an even one is used; if an even prescription is ineffective, revert to one opposing property to observe the disease's *Qi* and treat accordingly.

Now, heat and cold oppose each other, cold and heat contradict one another. A slight heat may be subdued by cold, and a slight cold may be dissipated by heat. Extreme cold or heat can either clash with a patient's inherent constitution or conflict with opposing *Qi*, causing discord. When their natures are incompatible, they do not harmonize—thus, one hesitates to attack them. If attacked, the disease's *Qi* and the medicinal *Qi* will resist each other, leading to self-generated heat and cold, which will further entrench the disease's fixed and stubborn defenses.

Thus, the Sage reverses the opposing *Qi* to observe its nature, ensuring the body’s *Qi* harmonizes in resonance. Then, he aligns their heat and cold, making what was once divergent now unified—dryness and moisture are subdued, rigidity and strength are weakened, and softness and frailty dissolve of their own accord.

The Yellow Emperor said: "Good. I know that diseases arise from the root. But if a disease originates from the *standard* (manifestation), how should one treat it?"

Qi Bo replied: "A disease that reverses its root will reveal the *standard*; a treatment that reverses the root will uncover the *standard*’s prescription. The *Qi* of Minor Yin and Major Yang are the same in root and *standard*—the remaining four *Qi* follow this principle."

The Yellow Emperor said: "Good. How does one discern the excess of the Six *Qi*?"

Qi Bo replied: "By riding their arrival. When the clear *Qi* comes in abundance, it is the triumph of dryness—the liver, associated with wood, contracts disease from it, which flows into the gallbladder.

When the hot *Qi* comes in abundance, it is the triumph of fire—the lungs, associated with metal and dryness, contract disease from it, which flows into the ileum and large intestine.
*[New annotation: The ileum (回肠) is the large intestine (大肠) in the *Jia Yi Jing* (《甲乙经》).]*

When the cold *Qi* comes in abundance, it is the triumph of water—the heart, associated with fire and heat, contracts disease from it, which flows into the Triple Burner and small intestine.

When the damp *Qi* comes in abundance, it is the triumph of earth—the kidneys, associated with water and cold, contract disease from it, which flows into the bladder.

When the wind *Qi* comes in abundance, it is the triumph of wood—the spleen, associated with earth and dampness, contracts disease from it, which flows into the stomach.

This is what is meant by contracting pathogenic *Qi* and generating disease. When the external *Qi* is rejected and the internal *Qi* is harmed, the inner and outer are displeased, and this leads to the progression of disease—this is called *sensing* (感).

If one rides the year’s deficiency, the pathogenic *Qi* will be severe. When wood is deficient in the year, the external clear *Qi* will prevail. When fire is deficient in the year, the external cold *Qi* will prevail. When earth is deficient in the year, the external wind *Qi* will prevail. When metal is deficient in the year, the external hot *Qi* will prevail. When water is deficient in the year, the external damp *Qi* will prevail. This is the year’s deficiency.

If the seasonal *Qi* is deficient, the external pathogenic *Qi* will prevail and be severe. If one loses the balance of the times, the pathogenic *Qi* will also be severe. When the Six *Qi* govern the body and clash with their assigned positions, they will generate disease, and the internal organs will respond according to what they cannot overcome, making the pathogenic *Qi* even more severe.

If one encounters the moon’s void, the pathogenic *Qi* will also be severe. This refers to the period before the upper crescent and after the lower crescent, when the moon’s orb is empty. If one is repeatedly exposed to pathogenic *Qi*, the disease becomes perilous. When the year’s *Qi* is already deficient and the pathogenic *Qi* arrives in abundance, this is repeated exposure. When the year’s *Qi* is deficient and Heaven’s *Qi* overcomes it, and at this time one is exposed to pathogenic *Qi*, this is also repeated exposure. If the internal *Qi* invites the pathogen and Heaven’s *Qi* does not assist, can the disease not become perilous? If there is an excess of *Qi*, it must return and reverse itself. Heaven and Earth’s *Qi* cannot be without interaction, so there is an excess of *Qi*, which will then return and reverse itself.

The Yellow Emperor said: "How does its pulse manifest upon arrival?"

Qi Bo replied: "When Minor Yin arrives, its pulse is taut—soft and hollow yet slippery, straight and long, this is called taut.
If it is strong and forceful, there is disease. If it is not strong yet faint, there is also disease. If it is not straight and long, there is disease. If it does not correspond to its position, there is disease. If its position cannot manifest tautness, there is also disease.

When Minor Yang arrives, its pulse is hook-shaped—arriving strong and departing weak, like a suspended belt with a hook, this is called hook-shaped.
If it arrives not strong but departs forceful, there is disease. If it arrives strong and departs strong, there is also disease. If it arrives not strong and departs not strong, there is disease. If it is not hook-shaped, there is disease. If it does not correspond to its position, there is disease. If its position cannot manifest hook-shaped, there is also disease.

When Major Yin arrives, its pulse is deep—deep, meaning downward. When pressed, it is obtained; this is the pulse of all downward positions.
If it is excessively deep, there is disease. If it is not deep, there is also disease. If it does not correspond to its position, there is disease. If its position cannot manifest depth, there is also disease.

When Minor Yang arrives, its pulse is large and floating—floating, meaning high. Large, meaning slightly larger than the pulses of other positions.
If it is excessively large and floating, there is disease. If it is floating yet not large, there is also disease. If it is large yet not floating, there is disease. If it is neither large nor floating, there is disease. If it does not correspond to its position, there is disease. If its position cannot manifest large and floating, there is also disease.

When Major Yang arrives, its pulse is short and rough—rough, meaning it does not flow smoothly. Short, meaning it does not travel far.
If it is excessively short, there is disease. If it is excessively rough, there is disease. If it is neither short nor rough, there is disease. If it does not correspond to its position, there is disease. If its position cannot manifest short and rough, there is also disease.

When Major Yang arrives, its pulse is large and long—long, meaning it travels far.
If it is excessively large, there is disease. If it is excessively long, there is disease. If it is long yet not large, there is disease. If it is large yet not long, there is disease. If it does not correspond to its position, there is disease. If its position cannot manifest large and long, there is also disease.

If it arrives and is harmonious, it is balanced. If it is not excessively large, it is a balanced pulse. If it is neither weak nor strong, this is called harmonious.

If it arrives and is excessive, there is disease. A taut pulse resembles a drawn bowstring, a slippery pulse resembles rolling pearls, a deep pulse clings to the bones, a floating pulse rises above the skin, a rough pulse halts and lingers, a short pulse is like millet, a large pulse is like a hatpin, and a long pulse is like a drawn thread—all these are signs of arrival and excessive severity.

If it arrives yet reverses, there is disease. When a taut pulse reverses to rough, when a large pulse reverses to fine, when a deep pulse reverses to floating, when a floating pulse reverses to deep, when a short and rough pulse reverses to long and slippery, when a soft and hollow pulse reverses to strong and solid, when a fine pulse reverses to large, these are all signs where the *Qi* deviates from its natural balance, and disease manifests accordingly.

If it arrives yet does not arrive, there is disease. If the position of the *Qi* has already arrived but the pulse does not respond, this is a sign of disease.

If it arrives before it should, there is disease. By observing the calendar and noting the seasons, one should anticipate the arrival of the Six *Qi*’s positions, as if marking the passage of years like north and south. If the pulse changes and responds prematurely, and the *Qi* sequence has not yet shifted while the pulse already alters, this is an arrival before its time, and thus there is disease.

If the yin and yang are exchanged, it is perilous. If the pulse does not correspond to Heaven’s natural order, and the *Qi* shows signs of crossing and disorder, losing its usual position, and the positions are exchanged—when a yin position shows a yang pulse, or a yang position shows a yin pulse—this is a sign of exchanged positions, and the *Qi* is in peril due to the confusion of the two."

The newly corrected text states:

According to the *Six Microcosmic Principles Great Treatise*, the Emperor asked: *"How can there be cases where the *Qi* arrives when it should, where it arrives when it should not, and where it arrives in excess?*" Ghī Bó replied: *"When it arrives as it should, it is harmonious. When it arrives but does not come fully, the incoming *Qi* is insufficient. When it arrives before its time, the incoming *Qi* is excessive."*

The Emperor asked: *"What of the cases where it arrives but does not come fully, or arrives before its time?"* Ghī Bó replied: *"If it corresponds, it is in accordance; if not, it is contrary. Contrariness gives rise to change, and change gives rise to disease."*

The Emperor asked: *"Please explain its correspondence."* Ghī Bó replied: *"Things manifest their correspondence, and *Qi* and pulse manifest their correspondence. What is meant by ‘pulse correspondence’ is this very pulse correspondence."*

The Emperor asked: *"The Six *Qi*’s roots and branches differ in origin—how so?"* Ghī Bó replied: *"Some *Qi* follow their roots, some follow both roots and branches, and some do not follow roots or branches at all."*

The Emperor said: *"I wish to hear this fully."* Ghī Bó replied: *"Minor Yang and Major Yin follow their roots; Minor Yin and Major Yang follow both roots and branches; Yang Ming and Jue Yin do not follow roots or branches but follow the center. Minor Yang’s root is Fire, and Major Yin’s root is Dampness—their beginning and end are the same, hence they follow their roots. Minor Yin’s root is Heat, its branch is Yin; Major Yang’s root is Cold, its branch is Yang—their beginning and end differ, hence they follow both roots and branches. Yang Ming’s center is Major Yin, and Jue Yin’s center is Minor Yang—their beginning, end, and center differ, hence they do not follow roots or branches but follow the center. Following roots, branches, or the center—all are for the purpose of transformation and generation. Thus, those that follow roots transform and generate from the roots; those that follow roots and branches have transformations from both; those that follow the center transform through the central *Qi*. Transformation refers to the elemental sovereign of *Qi*’s transformation. There are diseases treated by regulating the elemental sovereign’s *Qi* with cold or heat."*

The newly corrected text states:

According to the *Six Microcosmic Principles Great Treatise*, it says:
*"For Minor Yang above, treat with Fire *Qi*; its center reveals Jue Yin. For Yang Ming above, treat with Dryness *Qi*; its center reveals Major Yin. For Major Yang above, treat with Cold *Qi*; its center reveals Minor Yin. For Jue Yin above, treat with Wind *Qi*; its center reveals Minor Yang. For Minor Yin above, treat with Heat *Qi*; its center reveals Major Yang. For Major Yin above, treat with Dampness *Qi*; its center reveals Yang Ming. This is the root. Beneath the root is the center’s manifestation; beneath the manifestation is the *Qi*’s branch. Roots and branches differ, and the *Qi*’s correspondence manifests varied appearances. This is what is meant."*

The Emperor asked: *"If the pulse follows yet the disease is contrary, how should it be diagnosed?"* Ghī Bó replied: *"When the pulse arrives and follows, pressing it yields no resonance—this applies to all Yang pulses. For instance, if the disease is Heat yet the pulse is rapid and pressing it yields no movement, this is due to extreme Cold forcing Yang upward, not Heat."*

The Emperor asked: *"How about the contrary cases of the Yin pulses?"* Ghī Bó replied: *"When the pulse arrives and follows, pressing it yields a strong, resonant beat. If the symptoms indicate Cold yet pressing reveals a pulse that thunders violently beneath the hand, this is due to extreme Heat repelling Yin and generating disease—not Cold."*

Thus, the origins of a hundred diseases may arise from the root, from the branch, from the central *Qi*, or be obtained by taking the root, the branch, the central *Qi*, or both root and branch. There are cases obtained by contrary methods and cases obtained by following methods. Contrary methods are called *Fan Zuò* (反佐). Odd-even methods are called *Cóng Zuò* (从取). Treating Cold diseases with Cold and Heat diseases with Heat is contrary. Following means accordance; contrary means what appears contrary is actually correct. If, for example, extreme Cold forces Yang upward and one treats Heat with Heat, or extreme Heat repels Yin and one treats Cold with Cold—these are called contrary, yet externally they seem contrary while internally they are correct. This is contrary yet truly correct. If, however, extreme Cold forces Yang and one treats with Cold, or extreme Heat repels Yin and one treats with Heat—externally they seem correct, yet internally the *Qi* is contrary. Thus, though the method appears correct, it is contrary.

Hence it is said: *"Knowing roots and branches, applying them without hesitation; understanding contrary and following, acting correctly without question—this is what is meant."* Those who do not understand this are unworthy of speaking of diagnosis and will only confuse the Classics.

Thus, the *Great Overview* states: *"Rough practitioners, pleased with superficial knowledge, assume they understand: ‘Heat has not yet ceased, yet Cold disease begins anew.’ They confuse same-*Qi* with different forms, leading to misdiagnosis and disorder of the Classics."* *Xīxī* (嘻嘻) means delight.

The mind and intention at ease assume they have fully grasped the Dao. The application of the Six *Qi* by the crude and the skilled alike only achieves half the understanding.

The transformations of *Juéyīn* are deemed Cold by the crude, yet they are truly Warm. The transformations of *Tàiyáng* are deemed Hot by the crude, yet they are truly Cold. Here, the errors and reversals cause their learning, knowledge, and application to falter, leaving the skilled only half-versed.

Now, *Tàiyáng* and *Shàoyīn* each possess Cold transformations, yet when measuring their roots and branches in application, they invert. How so? *Tàiyáng*’s root is Cold, its manifestation is Heat; *Shàoyīn*’s root is Heat, its manifestation is Cold—thus their treatments follow likewise. *Juéyīn* and *Yángmíng* also invert in their central *Qi*: *Juéyīn*’s central *Qi* is Heat, *Yángmíng*’s is Dampness—these two *Qi* likewise invert, akin to *Tàiyáng* and *Shàoyīn*. Yet *Tàiyáng* and *Shàoyīn* have roots and branches, differing in application from the other *Qi*, hence it is said: *"Same *Qi*, different forms."*

For a single channel’s roots and branches, since Heat and Cold differ, one must first examine the manifestation, then seek the root. If one discusses *Qi* without exhausting its roots and branches, or diagnoses illness without distinguishing Yin and Yang, though the two *Qi* may share a name, their governance obstructs the proper timing of Cold and Warm, thus the mind confuses true principles, and treatment disrupts the Classics—hence the term *"crude practitioner"* is rightly applied.

The principles of roots and branches are essential yet vast, small yet grand, allowing one to speak of one to know the harm of a hundred diseases. To speak of roots and branches is easy yet must not be neglected; to observe roots and branches allows *Qi* to be harmonized. To clearly know victory and reversal is to set the standard for all people—thus the Dao of Heaven is complete.

Though Heaven and Earth’s transformations may be fully known, how much more so for diagnosing a single person? Yet some remain in darkness, grasping only the essentials of the Classics and holding fast to their foundational laws, yet still they degrade their path, failing to set the standard for all people—how could this be called great?
