**Newly corrected text states:**
According to *"Discourse on Roots and Branches in Disease Transmission,"* there are cases where the disease lies in the manifestation and is sought there, where it lies in the root and is sought there, where it lies in the root yet is sought in the manifestation, and where it lies in the manifestation yet is sought in the root. Thus, treatment may succeed by taking the manifestation, by taking the root, by taking the inverse, or by taking the direct.

Hence, knowing inverse and direct, acting correctly without question—those who know roots and branches will succeed in every case; those who do not are reckless in their actions.

The principles of Yin and Yang, inverse and direct, roots and branches—small yet grand, speaking of one to know a hundred diseases; few yet many, shallow yet profound, allowing one to speak of one to know a hundred. To know the shallow and discern the deep, to observe the near and know the far—this is speaking of roots and branches, easy yet not to be neglected.

Treatment contrary to the principle is inverse; treatment in accordance is direct.

If disease arises first, then inversion follows, treat the root;
If inversion arises first, then disease follows, treat the root;
If Cold arises first, then illness develops, treat the root;
If Heat arises first, then illness develops, treat the root;
If Heat arises first, then abdominal fullness develops, treat the manifestation;
If illness arises first, then diarrhea follows, treat the root;
If diarrhea arises first, then another illness develops, treat the root.
Then adjust the *Qi* and treat the other diseases.

If illness arises first, then abdominal fullness develops, treat the manifestation;
If abdominal fullness arises first, then mental agitation follows, treat the root.

Humans have guest-*Qi* and native-*Qi*.
For minor or major dysfunction, treat the manifestation;
For major dysfunction, treat the root.

When illness erupts with excess, root-to-manifestation: first treat the root, then the manifestation;
When illness erupts with deficiency, manifestation-to-root: first treat the manifestation, then the root.

Examine and inquire thoroughly, then adjust with intention. When symptoms are mild, both examination and inquiry proceed together; when severe, inquiry proceeds alone.

If minor or major dysfunction arises first, then illness follows, treat the root.
This Classic’s discussion of roots and branches is particularly detailed.

The Emperor asked: *"How do the changes of victory and reversal manifest in terms of timing?"*
Gēbó replied: *"The victorious *Qi*, when it arrives, the illness is already present, and the patient is uneasy—then the reversing *Qi* begins to sprout. The unease of the reversing *Qi* appears soon after. The reversing *Qi*, when it arises, exhausts the victorious *Qi* and takes its place, becoming intense. The victorious *Qi* may be slight or severe. The reversing *Qi* may be little or much—victory and reversal in harmony yield harmony; victory and reversal in emptiness yield emptiness—this is Heaven’s constant law."*

The Emperor asked: *"Why do the actions of victory and reversal sometimes move contrary to their proper positions, or arrive late in the season? What is their cause?"*
Gēbó replied: *"The generation and transformation of *Qi* vary in decline and flourishing. The applications of Cold, Heat, Warm, and Freezing differ in their盛衰. These changes occur in the four cardinal directions. Thus, the movement of Yang begins with Warmth and peaks in Heat; the movement of Yin begins with Coolness and peaks in Cold. Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter each differ in their divisions. It is said that the proper *Qi* of Spring’s Warmth lies in the months of *Chén* and *Sì*; Summer’s Heat in *Wèi* and *Shēn*; Autumn’s Cold in *Xū* and *Hài*; Winter’s Cold in *Chǒu* and *Yín*.

Spring begins in mid-Spring, Summer in mid-Summer, Autumn in mid-Autumn, Winter in mid-Winter. Thus, in the month of *Chǒu*, Yin congeals into thick ice beneath the earth; in the month of *Wèi*, Yang blazes with lightning across the sky; in the month of *Xū*, frost clears and kills, hardening all things; in the month of *Chén*, wind stirs gently, and withered trees flourish anew."*

This then is the divergence of *Qi* from its proper divisions, manifest and unobstructed. Yet the *Qi* of Yin and Yang, in its generation, flourishing, contraction, and storage, aligns with the usual laws when examining its transformations and their manifestations in humanity. The four seasons each vary in their daily count, diverging from the norm. Following these variations, one arrives at the true standard.

Thus, the *Da Yao* says:
*"That which is the Warmth of Spring becomes the Heat of Summer;
that which is the Rage of Autumn becomes the Fury of Winter."*

Carefully observing the four cardinal divisions, all omens converge—its end is visible, its beginning known. This is what is meant.

Speaking of the *Qi* in its youth and vigor:
Yang’s youth is Warmth, its vigor is Heat;
Yin’s youth is Rage, its vigor is Fury.
All this refers to the differing *Qi* of youth and vigor, verifying the waxing and waning of their applications. But if one establishes waxing and waning within the four cardinal divisions, then the terminal and initial applications of Yin and Yang become entirely knowable.

The Emperor asked: *"Does this divergence have a fixed number?"*
Gebi replied: *"It varies by thirty degrees—*
*degree meaning day."*

*(New annotation: According to the *Liu Yuan Zheng Ji Da Lun*, it says: "Does this divergence have a fixed number?"—*
*each day thereafter varies by thirty degrees with remainder. This text’s mention of "thirty degrees" is an abbreviation.)*

The Emperor asked: *"How do the pulses correspond?"*
Gebi replied: *"When divergence aligns with the proper law, it departs with the times. The pulse also diverges, following the *Qi*’s response. When the days of divergence are complete, the response to the sovereign *Qi* arrives and then departs."*

The *Mai Yao* states:
*"Spring without depth, Summer without tension,
Winter without roughness, Autumn without frequency—
this is called the Four Obstructions.
The *Qi* of Heaven and Earth is closed, with nowhere to circulate."*

Excessive depth is called disease,
Excessive tension is called disease,
Excessive roughness is called disease,
Excessive frequency is called disease.
But if it corresponds to the harmonious *Qi* of Heaven,
then this is called balanced.

When the form appears excessively so,
it is called *forceful attainment*—
how could such force endure long?
Thus, all excess is disease.

If it appears again on the same day, it is disease;
If it departs before its time, it is disease;
If it lingers after it should have departed, it is disease.
*Param* refers to the convergence of harmonizing *Qi*;
*Fu xian* refers to the reappearance of already decayed or dead *Qi*.
*Qu* refers to the sovereign *Qi* having departed.
If the daily degree has not yet exceeded the divergence,
this is called the Heavenly *Qi* not yet having emerged.
If the daily degree surpasses the divergence,
this is called the Heavenly *Qi* already having departed,
yet the pulse remains—
since it is not in proper response, it is called disease.
This is called *fan*—rebellion.
Summer shows slackness, Autumn shows frequency,
Winter shows slackness, Spring shows roughness—
this is called *fan*, violating Heaven’s command.
How could life endure?

*(New annotation: Referring to the earlier text, "Autumn without frequency is called the Four Obstructions," yet this note says "Autumn shows frequency is called *fan*," meaning the pulse’s divergence occurs only in the central month, and though the degree of divergence is complete, the frequency does not depart—thus, in the late month of Autumn, if the pulse remains frequent, it is called *fan*.)*

Thus, it is said:
*"The *Qi*’s mutual governance is like the scales of a balance,
which must not be unequal.*
Scales refer to a steelyard.
The *Qi* of Heaven and Earth—cold and heat opposing,
warmth and coolness alternating—
is like holding a balance.
If one side is heavy or the other is light,
when the two are equal and unopposed,
then clarity and tranquility generate transformations,
each attaining its proper measure."*

When the *Qi* of Yin and Yang is clear and tranquil,
generation and transformation are orderly;
when it moves, harsh diseases arise—
this is what is meant.
*Dòng* refers to deviations from the usual balanced state,
giving rise to calamities.
*Pó* means excessive.

*(New annotation: According to the *Liu Wei Zhi Da Lun*:
*"Success and failure, rise and fall, arise from movement.
Movement that does not cease becomes transformation."*

The Emperor asked: *"How do the obscure and the luminous manifest?"*
Gebi replied:
*"When the two Yins converge fully, it is called obscure;
when the two Yangs unite in brightness, it is called luminous.
The pairing of obscure and luminous corresponds to the differences in cold and heat.
The two Yins converge fully in *Xū* and *Hài*,
the two Yangs unite in brightness in *Chén* and *Sì*.
The *Ling Shu Xi Ri Yue Lun* states:
*Hài* is the tenth month, the left foot’s *Jué Yin*;
*Xū* is the ninth month, the right foot’s *Jué Yin*.
This is where the two Yins converge fully, hence called *Jué Yin*.
*Chén* is the third month, the left foot’s *Yáng Míng*;
*Sì* is the fourth month, the right foot’s *Yáng Míng*.
This is where the two Yangs unite in front, hence called *Yáng Míng*.
Yet when Yin converges, it is obscure;
when Yang unites, it is luminous—
the symbols of obscure and luminous must follow this.
Cold and heat occupy the southwest and northeast,
obscure and luminous occupy the northwest and southeast.
The pairing of obscure and luminous,
the positions of cold and heat—
truly, these are distinct."*

*(New annotation: According to the *Tai Shi Tian Yuan Ce Wen*:
*"Obscure and luminous having positioned,
cold and heat relax and expand."*

The Emperor asked: *"How do the solstices and equinoxes manifest?"*
Gebi replied:
*"When *Qi* arrives, it is called *zhi*;
when *Qi* divides, it is called *fen*.
At *zhi*, the *Qi* aligns;
at *fen*, the *Qi* diverges—
this is called the proper sequence of Heaven and Earth.
Following the inquiry into obscure and luminous,
this meaning takes form.
Speaking of the winter and summer solstices,
these are the Heavenly and Earthly *Qi* dominating the year at their positions.
The spring and autumn equinoxes
are the initial *Qi* of the four seasons,
each dividing its governance to the left and right of the dominant year.
Thus, at the solstices, the *Qi* aligns;
at the equinoxes, the *Qi* diverges.
What is spoken of as the correspondence of the two solstices and two equinoxes—
this is called the proper sequence of Heaven and Earth’s *Qi*."*

The Emperor said:
*"Master, you have spoken of Spring and Autumn *Qi* beginning in advance,
and Winter and Summer *Qi* beginning later—I understand this.
Yet the Six *Qi* circulate, and their dominance over the year is not constant.
How should their supplementary records be written?
By clarifying the divisions of solstices and equinoxes,
the initial *Qi* of the four seasons begins fifteen days before the *Lì Chūn* and *Lì Qiú*,
and the three *Qi* and six *Qi* begin fifteen days after the *Lì Xià* and *Lì Dōng*,
as the established method."*

The four seasons’ forward and backward sequence thus reveals that within the three *Qi* and six *Qi*, the proper alignment occurs at the solstices. Hence it is said that Spring and Autumn *Qi* begin in advance, while Winter and Summer *Qi* begin later. Yet since the year contains 365 days, each *Qi* shifts anew annually. When new *Qi* arrives, the old departs, and the appropriate times for action differ greatly above and below. Thus, the method of supplementary records must account for their sequence, which is why the question was raised again.

Gebi said:
*"The governing principles above and below follow what is advantageous, and aligning their flavors is the key. The same method applies to both sides."*

*The Great Overview* states:
*"The lesser yang’s governance: first sweet, then salty;
The yangming’s governance: first pungent, then sour;
The greater yang’s governance: first salty, then bitter;
The jueyin’s governance: first sour, then pungent;
The shaoyin’s governance: first sweet, then salty;
The taiyin’s governance: first bitter, then sweet.
Assist with what is beneficial, and supplement with what is generated—this is called attaining the *Qi*.
*Governance* refers to the dominant year.
*Attaining* means realizing its nature and function.
When one attains its nature and function, expansion and contraction follow human intent; failing to do so, movements generate discord, and how can one then hope to drive away evil? It is merely sufficient to exhaust the subtle *Qi* of Heavenly Truth.
Thus, the sequence of flavors—first writing off what is diseased, then supplementing—is as described."*

The Emperor said:
*"Excellent. The hundred diseases arise from wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire, transforming and varying through them. Wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire are the six *Qi* of Heaven. When still and harmonious, they are called transformations; when agitated and varying, they are called variations. Hence it is said that they transform and vary.
The classics state: ‘Excess is written off; deficiency is supplemented.’ I have entrusted this to physicians, yet even they cannot achieve full success. I wish to ensure that essential methods are practiced correctly, with techniques and prescriptions in perfect accord—like removing thorns and cleansing snow—so that skill, artistry, and sanctity may be attained. Needlework is skillful; medicine is sanctified."*

*The New Annotation* states:
*"According to the *Difficult Classic*: ‘To know by observation is called divine; to know by inquiry is called sage; to know by questioning is called skillful; to know by pulse-taking is called artful. To know externally is called sage; to know internally is called divine.’"*

Gebi said:
*"Carefully examine the mechanisms of disease, never missing the appropriate *Qi*—this is what is meant.
Mastering the essential principles means that small actions yield great results, and shallow methods achieve deep effects."*

The Emperor said:
*"I wish to hear how disease mechanisms operate."*

Gebi said:
*"All dizziness and vertigo from wind belong to the liver; wind’s nature is movement, aligning with wood *Qi*.
All contractions and spasms from cold belong to the kidneys; *shōu* means constriction, *yǐn* means urgency. Cold substances contract, aligning with water *Qi*.
All stagnant *Qi* and oppression belong to the lungs; in late autumn, frost descends, and damp *Qi* gathers. When frost arrives, *Qi* grows hot, and excessive heat transforms into *chán*—examining these phenomena reveals their correspondence.
*Jì* means facial distension; *yù* means pressing urgency. *Qi*’s function aligns with metal *Qi*.
All dampness, swelling, and fullness belong to the spleen; thin soil yields shallow water, thick soil yields deep water, level soil is dry, and high soil is damp. Where dampness exists, earth *Qi* aligns.
All heat and *dé* belong to fire; fire’s symbol is evident.
All pain, itching, and sores belong to the heart; when the heart is tranquil, pain is slight; when agitated, pain is severe. A hundred disturbances arise from the heart, and pain, itching, and sores originate there.
All *jué* (inversions), constipation, and diarrhea belong to the lower [orifices]; *lower* refers to the lower burner’s liver and kidney *Qi*.
The kidneys govern the lower burner; the liver governs the gateways and passages. Thus, all *jué*, constipation, and diarrhea belong to the lower burner.
*Jué* means inverted *Qi*; *gù* means inhibited. When *Qi* surges upward or inhibition fails, with unrestrained inflow and outflow, and dryness and dampness fluctuating—all stem from the lower burner’s governance.
All weakness, dyspnea, and vomiting belong to the upper [orifices]; *upper* refers to the upper burner’s heart and lung *Qi*.
Scorching heat is the heart’s *Qi*; receiving heat and transforming it is the lung’s *Qi*. When heat stagnates and ascends, disease belongs to the upper burner."*

*The New Annotation* states:
*"Examining *wěi* (weakness) as a disease, it seems not an upper disorder. Wang’s commentary fails to explain why it belongs to the upper burner, causing later doubt. Now, according to the *Treatise on Weakness*, the five *zàng* cause weakness when lung heat scorches the leaves, manifesting as *wěi-bì*. Hence, it is said to belong to the upper burner. *Wěi* also refers to lung weakness."*

*"All trembling and terror, as if losing one’s spirit, belong to fire; internal heat’s manifestation.
All stiffness and neck rigidity belong to dampness; excessive dampness in the greater yang.
All upward surging inversions belong to fire; fire’s ascending nature.
All abdominal distension and enlargement belong to heat; internal heat stagnation generates lung distension.
All agitation, madness, and recklessness belong to fire; excessive heat in the stomach and the four limbs.
All sudden stiffness belong to wind; internal yang stagnation while external yin circulates.
All diseases with sound—when struck like a drum—belong to heat; meaning they produce sound.
All diseases with *bì* (hardness) and swelling, along with pain, sourness, and fright, belong to fire; excessive heat *Qi*.
All twisting and inversion, with turbid fluids, belong to heat; *fan-lì* means tendon contraction. *Fluids* refers to urine.
All diseases with clear, cold fluids belong to cold; whether excreted above, below, or vomited and urinated out.
All sour vomiting and sudden downward pressure belong to heat. *Sour* refers to sour fluids and *mèi* (phlegm)."

Thus the *Great Overview* states:

*"Diligently guard the disease mechanisms—each belongs to its own category. If present, seek it; if absent, seek it. If excessive, reduce it; if deficient, supplement it. One must first apply the Five Conquests, harmonizing the blood and qi, ensuring their smooth circulation, and attaining equilibrium—this is the principle.*

The wisdom of the Sage is profound, and this reasoning is correct. To seek what is present or absent, to reduce excess or supplement deficiency—this is to exhaust all possibilities.

When extreme cold prevails yet heat does not respond, this indicates *no fire*. When heat arises and then retreats, appearing by day and hiding by night, or emerging at night and ceasing by day, moving with the seasons—this too indicates *no fire*. In such cases, one must *assist the heart*.

When fire-heat is extreme yet cold does not take effect, this indicates *no water*. When heat surges and then subsides, appearing and vanishing abruptly, moving and stopping at irregular times—this too indicates *no water*, and one must *assist the kidney*.

When internal obstruction causes retching and vomiting, preventing food from entering, this indicates *fire*. When illness causes vomiting and food is expelled upon ingestion, this indicates *no fire*. When sudden, rapid diarrhea occurs before food can be digested, this indicates *no water*. When prolonged diarrhea persists without urgency, this indicates *no water*.

Thus, when the heart is excessive, heat is generated; when the kidney is excessive, cold is generated. When the kidney is deficient, cold stirs within; when the heart is deficient, heat is drawn inward. If heat cannot be countered by cold, this indicates *no fire*. If cold cannot be countered by heat, this indicates *no water*.

When cold does not take effect, it is because *water is absent*. When heat does not take effect, it is because *fire is absent*. When heat does not persist, it is because the heart is deficient. When cold does not persist, it is because the kidney is insufficient.

If present, drain it; if absent, supplement it. If deficient, supplement it; if excessive, drain it. Balance the extremes—unblock stagnation, ensure unimpeded circulation above and below, and harmonize the qi and blood. Then cold and heat will naturally balance, and yin and yang will be in harmony.

Thus, some prescriptions treat heat with cold, yet cold causes food refusal; others attack cold with heat, yet heat induces delirium. This arises when qi is not freely circulating—when stagnation prevails.

By observing water and fire, the remaining qi may be understood. Therefore, the saying: *"If present, seek it; if absent, seek it. If excessive, reduce it; if deficient, supplement it."* This is the subtle method to harmonize the qi.

The Five Conquests refer to the cyclical dominance of the Five Phases, applying cold, heat, warmth, chill, and dampness, as well as sour, salty, sweet, bitter, and pungent to overcome them according to their laws.

The Emperor asked: *"How do the five flavors function in terms of yin and yang?"*

Gebi replied: *"Pungent and sweet disperse and ascend as yang; sour and bitter descend and drain as yin; salty also descends and drains as yin; bland permeates and drains as yang. These six—whether contracting, dispersing, moderating, hastening, drying, or moistening, softening, or firming—should be applied according to their benefits to regulate the qi and achieve balance."*

*"Descend" refers to vomiting; "drain" refers to diarrhea. "Permeate and drain" refers to urination—meaning water and fluids descend from the small intestine, separate as essence, seep into the bladder, and are transformed by the bladder’s qi before being excreted as urine.*

*(New annotation: According to the *Theory of Stored Qi and Seasonal Laws*, it states: "Pungent disperses, sour contracts, sweet moderates, bitter firms, and salty transforms." It further states: "Pungent, sour, sweet, bitter, and salty each have their uses—some disperse, some contract, some moderate, some hasten, some firm, some soften. The four seasons and five viscera require treatment according to the appropriate flavor."*

The Emperor asked: *"If the disease does not arise from disharmonized qi, how should it be treated? How do we determine whether to use toxic or non-toxic remedies, and in what order?"*

Gebi replied: *"The nature of diseases has four categories:
1. Those arising from internal formation due to disturbed qi—such as accumulations, masses, nodules, itching, contractions, and chronic pain.
2. Those arising from external formation due to disturbed qi—such as flaccid swelling, sores, scabs, scabies, boils, hemorrhoids, dropsy, floating edema, red eyes, blurred vision, hardness, swelling, and pain.
3. Those arising internally without disturbed qi—such as retained fluids, phlegm, improper diet, hunger, overwork, indigestion, cholera, grief, fear, joy, anger, brooding, and melancholy.
4. Those arising externally without disturbed qi—such as miasmic vapors, malevolent spirits, insects, snakes, witchcraft, ghosts striking, collisions, falls, wind, cold, heat, dampness, cuts, stabs, slashes, beatings, or blows."*

*"Among these four categories, some are cured by treating only the internal, some by treating both internal and external, some by treating only the external, some by treating both. Some require treating the internal first, then the external; others require treating the external first, then the internal. Some demand aggressive toxic methods, while others require gentle, non-toxic adjustment. The methods vary—sometimes heavy, sometimes light; sometimes gradual, sometimes urgent; sometimes contracting, sometimes dispersing; sometimes moistening, sometimes drying; sometimes softening, sometimes firming. Practitioners’ interpretations differ, each favoring their own methods and often misusing remedies without foundation. Hence, I am asked again."*

Gebi replied: *"Whether a remedy is toxic or non-toxic depends on the treatment’s necessity, adjusted by the severity and scale of the disease. A good prescription is one that swiftly resolves stagnation, urgently rescues critical illness, and prevents death. It is not about prioritizing toxicity—whether toxic or non-toxic, the choice depends on the disease’s urgency and scale."*

The Emperor asked: *"Please specify the criteria."*

Gebi replied: *"A small prescription uses one sovereign and two ministers; a medium prescription uses one sovereign, three ministers, and five assistants; a large prescription uses one sovereign, three ministers, and nine assistants."*

The cold is treated with warmth, the hot with cold;
The mild is countered, the severe is followed.
Even the smallest disease, like a great fire,
Encounters grass and is extinguished,
Meets wood and is overturned—
It can be suppressed by dampness,
Or quenched by water.
Thus, its nature and *qi* are countered to subdue and attack it.

The most severe disease, like a dragon’s fire,
Encounters dampness and flames rise,
Meets water and is overturned—
If one does not recognize its nature and attempts to suppress it with water or dampness,
It will only grow brighter, reaching the heavens before exhaustion halts it.
But if one knows its nature,
And acts contrary to its usual course,
Using fire to drive it out,
Then it will self-destruct, its flames extinguished.

Yet "countering" means attacking heat with cold and cold with heat.
"Following" means attacking with cold or heat,
Though following its nature, the methods are not all the same.

Thus, it is said:
*Countering* is *zhèng* treatment,
*Following* is *fǎn* treatment—
Following in small or great measure,
Observing the circumstances.

This is what is meant.

---
The *Shénnóng* says:
Medicines have sovereigns, ministers, assistants, and guides,
To mutually promote and regulate.
When combined, one sovereign, two ministers, three assistants, and five guides are used;
Or one sovereign, two ministers, and nine assistants and guides.

The firm is regulated,
The exogenous is removed,
The exhausted is warmed,
The stagnant is dispersed,
The lingering is attacked,
The dry is moistened,
The urgent is calmed,
The scattered is consolidated,
The deficient is supplemented,
The idle is invigorated,
The startled is pacified,
The upper and lower are harmonized,
Rubbed and bathed,
Thinned and purged,
Opened and released—
All adapted to the circumstances.
Measure the disease and its signs,
And apply accordingly.

The Emperor asked: *"What is meant by countering and following?"*

Gebi replied: *"Countering is zhèng treatment,
Following is fǎn treatment—
Following in small or great measure,
Observing the circumstances."*

He said:
*Countering* is *zhèng* treatment—
Attacking cold with heat and heat with cold.
Though following the disease’s *qi*,
It is still *fǎn* treatment.

*Following in small measure* means one similarity and two differences;
*Following in great measure* means two similarities and three differences.
What is not the same is called *zhì* (regulation).

The Emperor asked: *"What is fǎn treatment?"*

Gebi replied:
*"Heat arises from cold suppression—treat with cold;
Cold arises from heat suppression—treat with heat;
Stagnation arises from stagnation—treat with stagnation;
Obstruction arises from obstruction—treat with obstruction.
Necessarily suppress its root,
And first address its cause—
Though the beginning may be the same,
The end will differ.
It can break accumulations,
Dissolve hardness,
Harmonize the *qi*,
And ensure recovery.

When great cold congeals internally,
Forming scrotal masses and hernias,
Attacking with heat removes cold obstruction and heat stagnation,
But excessive heat causes severe pain.
Using honey-cooked *Aconitum* with warm honey,
Increasing the dose,
After ingestion, it dissipates naturally.
This is Zhang Gong’s method of treating cold with heat.

When fire *qi* surges,
And *Lingzhi* mushrooms are overused,
Heat is suppressed by cold,
Causing vomiting, retching, hoarseness, dry mouth, bitterness,
Aversion to heat and preference for cold—
All agree it is heat,
But treating it as such worsens the condition.
If one opposes their preference, resistance arises;
If one complies with their desire, the disease worsens.
Adjusting cold and heat inversely,
Heat dissipates as cold spreads,
Then hot substances are taken—
After vomiting and hoarseness subside,
The body’s heat emerges,
The disease *qi* gradually recedes,
And retching ceases.
This brings no harm,
And great benefit follows—
Pure wine is consumed,
And the pattern is clear.
This is treating heat with cold.

Those who dislike heat—
All residual *qi* from food that causes life—
Seeing it induces vomiting.
Again, in heat diseases,
Cold attacks fail to penetrate,
For they fear cold’s dominance,
And heat dissipates.
Following its *qi* increases heat,
But cold attacks prevent penetration.
Using fermented soybeans or other cold medicines in warm wine,
Warm wine and cold medicine share no conflict—
Once the wine’s heat is exhausted,
The cold medicine takes effect,
Following ingestion, heat disperses—
This is treating cold with heat.

Or using cold substances,
Harmonized with heat,
Taken as food or medicine,
Heat dissolves and disperses—
This too is treating cold with heat.
Again, consuming hot meats and *mallow* milk,
With pepper, ginger, and tangerine harmonized in heat,
Follows the same principle.

When heat is in the lower burner,
Treatment follows similarly.
For instance, if lower *qi* is deficient,
And the middle burner is congested,
With severe flank distension,
Worsening after meals—
Unskilled practitioners cannot decide:
Dispersing the fullness risks depleting the lower burner,
Supplementing the lower burner worsens middle congestion,
Dispersing *qi* further weakens the lower burner,
Supplementing deficiency exacerbates middle fullness.
Consulting physicians agree:
Without addressing the deficiency,
They attack the fullness—
Medicine enters, causing retching,
But after passing, the condition remains unchanged.
Thus, middle fullness and lower deficiency persist.

Only by gently opening the middle,
And forcefully supplementing the lower,
With small doses aiding congestion,
And large doses promoting flow,
Can the disease be cured—
Middle fullness is removed,
Lower deficiency is resolved.
This is treating stagnation with stagnation.

Again, when great internal heat congeals,
Causing unremitting diarrhea,
Heat should be treated with cold,
But once the stagnation is resolved,
Cold is used to purge—
Stagnation disperses, and diarrhea stops.
This is treating obstruction with obstruction.

Or when great internal heat congeals,
Causing prolonged diarrhea,
Healing only to recur,
Dragging on for years—
Treating with heat stops the cold and halts diarrhea.
This is of the same kind.

Using cold to treat heat,
Cooling as it acts,
Using heat to treat cold,
Warming as it acts—
Though the beginning is the same,
The end differs.
This is what is meant."

「All such cases—
Their disciples merely outline the general signs,
Yet still adhere to the principle of *counter-treatment* [反治].
This is of the same kind.

*The newly corrected text* states:
According to the *Five Constants Governing the Great* [五常政大论]:
To treat heat with cold, let it act with warmth [温而行之],
To treat cold with heat, let it act with coolness [凉而行之].
This is the meaning of treating heat with coldness and cold with heat [热因寒用，寒因热用].

The Emperor said: *Well done.*

For cases where *qi* is regulated and attained—
How should they be treated?

Gui Bo [岐伯] replied:
*Counter* [逆] and *assist* [从],
*Counter* while *assisting*, *assist* while *countering*—
To disperse the *qi* and restore harmony,
This is the Dao [道].

*Counter* means to oppose the disease-*qi* with proper treatment [逆病气以正治].
*Assist* means to follow the disease-*qi* with counter-treatment [从病气而反疗].
Opposing the *qi* to properly treat,
Letting it follow its natural course,
Following the disease to counter its nature,
Letting it attain balance—
Thus, it is called *counter* and *assist* [逆从].

If the *qi* is not dispersed to open its pathways,
It will be affected by cold and heat, leading to manifold changes—
At first, transformations arise in abundance [始生化多端].

The Emperor said: *Well done.*
For diseases affecting the *inner* and *outer* [中外]—
How should they be treated?»

**Qibo replied:**

When disease spreads *from the inner to the outer*,
adjust the inner;
When disease spreads *from the outer to the inner*,
treat the outer;
Each must sever its source.
If disease spreads *from the inner to the outer* and flourishes externally,
first adjust the inner, then treat the outer;
If disease spreads *from the outer to the inner* and flourishes internally,
first treat the outer, then adjust the inner.
All this means: first remove its root cause,
then trim its branches.

When inner and outer diseases do not interact,
treat the primary ailment.
When inner and outer diseases do not interact,
they are separate afflictions.

**The Emperor said:** *Well done.*

*Fire-heat* recurs, aversion to cold with fever,
resembling malaria—
sometimes erupting daily, sometimes every few days—
what is its cause?

**Qibo replied:**
The *victorious countering-qi* [胜复之气] meets at varying intervals,
depending on its abundance or scarcity.
When *yin-qi* predominates and *yang-qi* is weak,
the onset is spaced farther apart;
When *yang-qi* predominates and *yin-qi* is weak,
the onset is closer together.
This is the interplay of *victorious countering-qi*,
the rhythm of waxing and waning—
malaria follows the same principle.

When *yin* and *yang* are balanced,
chills and fevers alternate within a single day.
When *yang* is excessive and *yin* deficient,
fever appears daily without chill.
When *yang* is deficient and *yin* excessive,
fever erupts every other day—
first chill, then heat.

Even with *victorious countering-qi*,
if the *qi* is weak, a single attack may recur after six or seven days—
folks mistakenly call this recovery, only for it to flare again.
Or it may recur every third day, then cease for six or seven,
or erupt every tenth day, then stop after four or five—
all due to the *qi*'s varying strength,
whether it converges or does not converge.

Common folk, seeing no immediate change,
blame malevolent spirits or sudden afflictions,
and for long they pray, flee, or hide—
yet by the time the disease has run its course,
death follows swiftly.
The deceased, wronged in life, now haunt broad roads,
while untimely deaths fill the wilderness.
How tragic—
how could this not bring sorrow?
Customs, once entrenched, resist sudden reform.
No longer can they be altered—
what else can be done?
Alas, alas!

**The Emperor said:**
The theory states: *"Treat cold with heat, treat heat with cold,"*
yet practitioners abandon these principles
and deviate from the Dao.

There are patients with heat—
cool them, and heat persists;
Patients with cold—
warm them, and cold remains.
Both conditions coexist,
new diseases arise—
how should they be treated?
For the treatment fails to subdue the disease,
and instead, the medicine’s cold or heat
gives rise to fresh cold or heat afflictions.

Some cases remit only to relapse,
others worsen while the medicine lingers,
some never abate at all.
If practitioners abandon these principles,
there is no method to renew their approach.
If they follow superficial patterns,
the disease remains unchecked.
If they grasp at symptoms,
they obstruct the true nature of the ailment;
if they treat superficially,
the medicine proves ineffective.
Confused in mind, bewildered in intent,
they find no path to enlightenment.
Unknowing of the Dao,
what reliance can they have?
Diseases arise from the medicine itself—
old and new ailments clash.
How can one hope for recovery?

**Qibo replied:**
For those who grow hot when treated with cold,
draw from *yin*;
For those who grow cold when treated with heat,
draw from *yang*—
this is called *"seeking their affinity."*

It means:
Nurturing *fire*'s source to disperse *yin* obstructions;
Strengthening *water*'s master to restrain *yang* excess—
hence, *"seeking their affinity."*

Crude practitioners, shallow in learning,
attack cold with heat, cold with cold;
Before heat is fully treated, new diseases emerge;
Before cold is fully attacked, heat resurges.
Heat arises while internal cold remains,
cold generates while external heat persists.
To attack cold, they fear heat will not yield;
to treat heat, they dread cold will return.
Advance and retreat clash in battle—
danger is imminent.
How could they know the *zang-fu* sources
hold the keys to cold, heat, warmth, and freezing?

To treat the *heart*, one does not simply apply heat;
to treat the *kidney*, one does not simply apply cold.
But by reinforcing the *heart*'s *yang*,
even cold will disperse;
by fortifying the *kidney*'s *yin*,
heat may yet be contained.
Observe this truth:
Sometimes heat is treated with heat,
cold with cold—
a thousand applications, a thousand cures.
Who understands their intent?
Though their prescriptions are profound,
their reasoning is exhausted.
Alas!
Is death by fate,
or by the practitioner’s ignorance and folly?

**The Emperor said:** *Well done.*

When cold remedies cause heat to return,
or heat remedies cause cold to return—
what is the cause?

**Qibo replied:**
It is due to treating the *sovereign-qi* [王气] excessively,
thus provoking the reaction.

All things have cold or heat,
*qi* has *yin* or *yang*.
When it clashes with the *sovereign-qi*,
it intensifies its nature.

The *liver-qi* is temperate,
the *heart-qi* is scorching,
the *lung-qi* is cool,
the *kidney-qi* is piercing cold,
the *spleen-qi* encompasses all four.
Thus, in spring, treating the *liver* with cold
yet causing warmth to return;
in summer, treating the *heart* with cold
yet causing heat to return;
in autumn, treating the *lung* with warmth
yet causing coolness to return;
in winter, treating the *kidney* with heat
yet causing cold to return—
this is because the *sovereign-qi* was over-supplemented.
When the *sovereign-qi* is over-supplemented,
the *zang*'s inherent cold or heat will naturally intensify.

**The Emperor said:**
What if this occurs without treating the *sovereign-qi*?

**Qibo replied:**
Your question is thorough.
It is due to neglecting the *five flavors*' affinities.

The *five flavors* enter the stomach,
each attacking what it favors:
Sour first enters the *liver*,
bitter first enters the *heart*,
sweet first enters the *spleen*,
pungent first enters the *lung*,
salty first enters the *kidney*.
*(Note: The *Zangfu* affinities are:
Sour enters the *liver*,
pungent enters the *lung*,
bitter enters the *heart*,
salty enters the *kidney*,
sweet enters the *spleen*.)*
This is called *"the five entries."*

With time, they augment the *qi*—
a natural transformation of things.
When *qi* is prolonged, it leads to untimely death.
For what enters the *liver* becomes warmth,
what enters the *heart* becomes heat,
what enters the *lung* becomes cool,
what enters the *kidney* becomes cold,
what enters the *spleen* becomes *ultimate yin*,
encompassing all four *qi*—
each enhances its flavor and strengthens its *qi*,
thus following the inherent nature of its respective *zang*.

Thus, prolonged consumption of *Huánglián* (Coptis) and *Kǔcān* (Sophora) leads to heat—
this is their inherent nature.
All flavors behave likewise.
Yet, human perception is often lax and careless,
unable to discern their subtle transformations with precision.
Hence it is said:
*"With time, they augment the qi—
a natural transformation of things.*
When *qi* grows ever stronger without restraint,
it prolongs life but also leads to the imbalance of the *zang*’s inherent *qi*.
If *qi* becomes imbalanced, it may then be cut off in excess,
and if the *zang* is thus overstrained, sudden death may follow.
Therefore it is said:
*'When qi is prolonged, it leads to untimely death.'*

Hence, the *Zhènglǐ Guānhuà Yàojí* (Collection of Proper Principles for Aligning and Transforming Medicines) states:
*"If medicines lack all five flavors and do not encompass the four qi,
yet are taken for prolonged use,
though they may initially yield benefits,
over time, they will cause sudden death.*
This is what is meant.

If one abstains from grains and only takes medicines,
sudden demise will not occur—
why is this so?
Because there is no flavor of the five grains to aid in their augmentation.
Yet if grains are reintroduced,
death will still come.
The Emperor said: *Good.*

Now, regarding the categorization of sovereign and ministerial herbs—
what does this mean?
Gūibó (Master Gui) replied:
*"The sovereign is the herb that treats the primary disease,
the minister aids the sovereign,
and the assistant harmonizes the ministerial action.
This does not refer to the upper, middle, and lower three grades.
The upper herbs are sovereigns,
the middle herbs are ministers,
the lower herbs are assistants—
this distinction clarifies their varying efficacy and nature.
The method of taking medicines should follow this principle,
and the same applies universally in treating diseases.
The sovereign herb is chosen to address the primary disease,
the ministerial herbs assist the sovereign,
and the assistant herbs fulfill the ministerial function—
all are employed to enhance the therapeutic effect."*

The Emperor asked:
*"What are the three grades?"*
Gūibó replied:
*"They serve to differentiate the medicinal virtues of good and evil.
The three grades—upper, middle, and lower—
are thus named to reflect the distinct Daoist natures and functions of medicines.
*(Note: According to Shénnóng [Divine Farmer], upper herbs are sovereigns, nourishing life to align with Heaven;
middle herbs are ministers, nourishing vitality to align with humanity;
lower herbs are assistants, treating diseases to align with Earth.)*
The Emperor said: *Good.*

Now, regarding diseases of the inner and outer—
how should they be addressed?
*(This question revisits the inner and outer distinctions,
further elaborating on the method of regulating qi,
as the previous inquiry was incomplete.)
The following response should follow the earlier discussion on discerning their attributes.
This is likely an ancient instance of displaced text.*

Gūibó replied:
*"In regulating qi,
one must distinguish yin and yang,
determine whether the disease is of the inner or outer,
and each treatment must adhere to its proper realm.
Diseases of the inner are treated internally,
diseases of the outer are treated externally.
If the imbalance is slight, regulate it;
if it persists, balance it;
if it is severe, suppress it;
if it is extreme, induce sweating to resolve it.
For excesses of cold and heat, temper and chill,
weakening them according to their affinities.
Follow what is advantageous—
diseases have inner and outer distinctions,
treatments have external and internal applications.
Inner diseases are harmonized with internal treatment;
outer diseases are harmonized with external treatment.
If the qi is weak and unbalanced,
use methods to regulate it#67;
if the imbalance is moderate,
use methods to balance it;
if the imbalance is severe and unyielding,
suppress its excess to let it decline.
For instance, if there is a slight excess of cold *qi*,
use warmth to harmonize it;
if there is a great excess of cold *qi*,
use heat to resolve it;
if there is extreme cold *qi*,
then induce downward elimination to suppress it—
if suppression does not suffice,
reverse and bend it;
if bending does not exhaust it,
then seek its affinity to weaken it.

If there is a slight excess of heat *qi*,
use coolness to harmonize it;
if there is a great excess of heat *qi*,
use cold to resolve it;
if there is extreme heat *qi*,
then induce sweating to disperse it—
if dispersion does not suffice,
reverse and restrain it;
if restraint does not suffice,
then seek its affinity to weaken it.

Hence it is said:
*'Induce sweating to resolve it,
use cold and heat, temper and chill—
weakening them according to their affinities,
following what is advantageous.'*
*Sho*, meaning *that which belongs to*.
Adhering meticulously to these principles,
all actions will be successful.
When *qi* and blood are balanced,
longevity is in accordance with Heaven’s decree.

By observing the Dao and acting accordingly,
all endeavors will be precise—
thus one can command herbs and minerals,
summon spirits and deities,
regulate yin and yang,
ward off all ailments,
and preserve *qi* and blood in harmony,
ensuring vitality without depletion or exhaustion.
For when one can freely extend or withdraw,
leave or retain as one wills,
the spirit is inwardly protected,
and life is prolonged with divine vigor.

The Emperor said: *Good.*
Thus concludes the annotated text of the *Huángdì Nèijīng Sūwèn* (Yellow Emperor’s Inner Classic, Plain Questions), Volume 48.

**Newly Translated Text:**

The *Zhuò Zhì Jiào Lùn* (至教论, "Treatise on Supreme Teaching")—newly collated—states: *"According to the Gùběn of Quán Yuánqǐ, this appears in the beginning and end of the Sìshí Bìnglèi Lùn (四时病类论, 'Classification of Seasonal Diseases')."*

The Yellow Emperor sat in the **Míngtáng** (明堂, "Hall of Enlightenment"), summoning Léi Gōng and asking him: *"Do you understand the Dao of medicine?"*
The **Míngtáng**, an office of governance, has eight windows and four gates, its form round above and square below, located in the southern part of the state—thus it is called the **Míngtáng**.
To seek out the people’s afflictions and relieve their hidden suffering was the great sage’s concern, hence the summoning of Léi Gōng to inquire about the means of saving lives.

Léi Gōng replied: *"I can recite, yet barely comprehend; comprehend, yet cannot distinguish; distinguish, yet cannot illuminate; illuminate, yet cannot make manifest.*
This speaks to what I know and understand—only grasping the laws and numbers of the method, yet still unable to penetrate the profound and subtle mysteries of its application."*

**New collation notes:** *"According to Yáng Shàngshàn, practicing the Dao has five stages: recitation, comprehension, distinction, illumination, and manifestation. This suffices to govern officials, yet is insufficient to reach the level of a feudal lord."*

Léi Gōng did not dare exalt his own teachings, yet the difference between a commoner and a noble in healing is vast. He wished to receive the **shù tiān zhī dù** (树天之度, "measuring the celestial order"), harmonizing the four seasons’ yin and yang, distinguishing the stars, constellations, and the luminaries of sun and moon, to manifest the **jīngwèi** (经卫, "Channels and Defensive Qi"), making it ever clearer for future generations.
*"Measuring the celestial order"* refers to its lofty and boundless nature. *"Harmonizing the four seasons’ yin and yang"* means following the sequence of qi. *"Distinguishing the stars, constellations, and the luminaries"* refers to scholars’ differentiation of great and minor illuminations.

**New collation notes:** *"According to the Tàisù (太素), '列' (liè, 'array') is used instead of '别' (bié)."*
He sought to transmit the teachings to Shénnóng, doubting whether they originated with the **Èrhuáng** (二皇, "Two Sovereigns").

The Emperor said: *"Excellent! Do not lose this. All these are the outer and inner correspondences of yin and yang, male and female, above and below, mutually responding. The Daoist who knows the celestial patterns above, the earthly geography below, and human affairs within can endure long and teach the masses without doubt. This medical discourse can be passed down to posterity as a treasure—because it is made manifest."*

Léi Gōng said: *"May I receive this Dao? I will recite, comprehend, and apply it."*

The recitation is also a discourse. The recitation and elucidation are what bring understanding through close comparison.

The Emperor said: *"Have you not heard of the* **Yīnyáng Chuán** *(《阴阳传》)?*
Léi Gōng replied: *"I have not."*

The Emperor said: *"The Three Yangs belong to Heaven’s domain—meaning the Three Yang *qi* in the human body, which move and reside above. The* **Yīnyáng Chuán** *is an ancient text on transformation. Above and below are without constancy; when they converge, disease arises, and the imbalance harms yin and yang. Above and below are without constancy—meaning the *qi* flows irregularly, neither fixed above nor below. When they converge, disease arises—referring to the Three Yangs of the hands and feet merging to cause illness. When the Yangs converge excessively, the vital essence weakens, thus impairing yin and yang’s functions."*

Léi Gōng said: *"The Three Yangs are overwhelming—I beg to hear their resolution."*

The Emperor said: *"When the Three Yangs converge alone, it means all six Yangs have converged—like wind and rain, causing *diān* sickness above and *lòu* disease below. Converged, it refers to the Three Yangs of the hands and the Three Yangs of the feet merging. The Foot *Tàiyáng* vessel arises from the inner canthus, ascending to the forehead and meeting at the crown; its branching path goes from the crown to the upper ear angle, while its direct course enters to network the brain, descends to branch below the nape, follows the shoulder’s inner side along the spine to the waist, then enters to circulate through the loins, connecting to the kidneys and linking with the bladder. The Hand *Tàiyáng* vessel arises from the hand, ascending the arm to meet above the shoulder, entering the supraclavicular fossa to network the heart, descending the throat to the epigastrium, reaching the stomach, and linking with the small intestine. Thus, above it causes *diān* sickness, and below it causes *lòu* disease. *Lòu* refers to blood and pus discharge—what is meant by ‘converged like wind and rain’ is that there is no fixed measure. Hence, the following text states: There is no external standard, no internal regularity; it does not conform to the meridian pathways. Diagnosis finds neither above nor below—it must be recorded and distinguished. When the Three Yangs converge, above and below are without constancy, with no visible signs or *qi* to rely upon, nor a fixed meridian course. The timing of their arrival and the resulting symptoms are irregular, requiring textual records for differentiation."*

Léi Gōng said: *"My treatments are sparse in cure—I only speak of intent."* *(Léi Gōng meant: My treatments rarely achieve full recovery; I only explain the deeper meaning to dispel doubt.)*

The Emperor said: *"The Three Yangs are the utmost Yang. When the Six Yangs converge, they become the most extreme Yang. Accumulating and converging causes terror, with disease arising as violent wind—like a collision of minerals, sealing all nine orifices. The Yang *qi* overflows, causing dryness, hoarseness, and throat obstruction. Accumulating refers to their excessive convergence—when the Six Yangs merge overwhelmingly, the Yang’s frustration becomes unchecked, overflowing endlessly, thus sealing the nine orifices. When they converge with yin, above and below are without constancy, leading to intestinal obstruction. Yin refers to the viscera. Yet when Yang presses upon the viscera, the disease is also irregular in diagnosis. If the disease is below, it causes frequent discharge of red and white. This is when the Three Yangs directly affect the heart—sitting becomes impossible, while lying down relieves the body entirely. The Foot *Tàiyáng* vessel follows the shoulder down to the waist, hence sitting is impossible, but lying outward eases the body. The reason is: rising causes the Yang to surge, so one constantly seeks outward relief. Outward movement balances the meridian *qi*, thus the body feels secure."*

*(The text continues:)* *"How then does one know the world? How does one distinguish yin and yang, respond to the Four Seasons, and harmonize with the Five Phases?"* *(meaning: The knowledge is incomplete.)*

Léi Gōng said: *"..."*

The Emperor did not immediately grant this as profound knowledge, hence the repeated request.

When the disease injures the Five Viscera, the sinews and bones wither away. Your words are unclear and indistinct—this means the world’s rulers have exhausted their learning.

The Yellow Emperor sat in leisure and summoned Léi Gōng, asking:

*"You who have received the arts and recited the classics—if you can survey diverse studies, compare analogies, and harmonize principles, then speak to me of your expertise. The Five Viscera, Six Palaces—the gallbladder, stomach, large and small intestines, spleen sac, and bladder—brain marrow, tears, saliva, weeping, lamentation, and sorrow; the pathways of water—these are all that give rise to life. Yet in treating them, errors persist."*

From the *"Differentiation of the Five Viscera"*:
The Yellow Emperor asked: *"I have heard that some alchemists consider the brain and marrow as viscera, others the intestines and stomach as viscera, and still others as palaces. They contradict one another, each claiming to be correct, yet none know the true principle. I wish to hear their explanation."*

Qíbā said:

*"The brain, marrow, bones, vessels, gallbladder, and female reproductive organ—these six are born of Earth-*qi*. They are stored in the Yin and resemble the Earth, hence they are called ‘strange and hidden palaces,’ for they are stored but not emptied."*

*"The stomach, large intestine, small intestine, Triple Burner, and bladder—these five are born of Heaven-*qi*. Their *qi* resembles Heaven; they are emptied but not stored. They receive the turbid *qi* of the Five Viscera, hence they are called ‘transformation and transmission palaces.’"*

Thus, the ancients who treated diseases considered these distinctions as errors.

You must clarify them—then you may achieve perfect mastery. If you cannot, you will be reviled by the world.

*"If one cannot discern them, even slight actions may harm the living—thus, when people hear such discussions, many harbor resentment and blame. Lěigōng said:

*'安 (ān), meaning ‘how could’ or ‘how much less.’*

*The Yellow Emperor said:

I will then ask what you do not know.*

*'过 (guò) refers to faults, meaning diseases arising from deviations beyond the usual pulse patterns. Toxic medicines attack evil *qi*, while flavors nourish and replenish—your test now reveals whether you know or do not know.*

*Lěigōng said:

*'When the liver is deficient, when the kidneys are deficient, or when the spleen is deficient, all cause heaviness in the body, fatigue, and suppressed resentment. *'Your servant, following the Emperor’s inquiry, speaks of the faults of the Five Viscera and the toxic medicines and decoctions—thus, the question pertains to this very disease.*

*The Emperor said:

*'You are so long in years yet speak so little—it seems I truly question you only to invite my own errors. My inquiry does not align with your response, so I say this to admit my own mistake.*

*'I asked you of the subtle and unseen—why do you reply with the upper and lower chapters?*

*'窈冥 (yǎomíng) refers to what is not outwardly visible, meaning the pulse’s manifestation of form, *qi*, and the circulation of *Nourishing* and *Defensive* *qi*.*

*In the *Eight Correct Principles of Divine Brilliance* (《八正神明论》), Qíbā replied to the Yellow Emperor:

*'To observe the murky and unseen—it means that the pulse’s form, *qi*, and the circulation of *Nourishing* and *Defensive* *qi* do not outwardly manifest, yet the skilled physician alone knows them. By aligning the daily warmth and cold, the lunar waxing and waning, and the seasonal *qi*’s fluctuations, one can harmonize and regulate them. The physician often perceives these changes before they surface externally—thus, it is said: “To observe the murky and unseen.”*

*Hence, the Emperor said: *“I asked you of the subtle and unseen.”*

*Yet, when the liver, kidneys, or spleen are deficient, the intent of the *Pulse Classic*’s upper and lower chapters must be clarified—thus, the Emperor said: *“Why do you reply with the upper and lower chapters?”*

*When the spleen is deficient, its pulse floats like that of the lungs; when the kidneys are deficient, their pulse is slightly floating like that of the spleen; when the liver is deficient, its pulse is hurried and scattered like that of the kidneys. These are all cases where physicians often become confused, but they can be discerned with careful consideration.*

*Why does the spleen’s deficient pulse float like that of the lungs, the kidneys’ deficient pulse slightly float like that of the spleen, and the liver’s deficient pulse hurry and scatter like that of the kidneys?*

*It is because the Three Viscera (liver, kidneys, spleen) are closely related, so their pulse patterns overlap and resemble one another. Thus, physicians become perplexed and make errors in treatment.*

*Even so, one should still proceed with calm and measured deliberation, carefully comparing and categorizing them, and await the Three Viscera’s distinct pulse manifestations.*

*How should one approach this?*

*The spleen’s deficient pulse is floating yet relaxed; the lungs’ deficient pulse is floating yet short; the heart’s deficient pulse is slightly floating yet slippery; the liver’s deficient pulse is hurried and tight yet scattered; the kidneys’ deficient pulse is bounding yet slippery. If one cannot compare and categorize them, confusion and doubt will only deepen.*

*Now, the Three Viscera—spleen (earth), liver (wood), and kidneys (water)—reside in the lower abdomen (鬲下), close to one another. Why question this?*

*Lěigōng said:

*'There is a person now: suffering headache, stiff sinews, heavy bones, faintness, shortness of breath, belching, abdominal fullness, and frequent startling. They do not enjoy lying down—what viscus is this manifestation from?*

*Their pulse is floating yet taut, firm like stone upon pressing. I do not know its resolution—thus, I ask again of the Three Viscera, to discern their comparative patterns.*

*The pulse may be floating, taut, firm like stone—hence, the inquiry is about the Three Viscera’s comparative patterns.*

*The Emperor said:

*'It is a matter of careful consideration and alignment.*

*'He means comparative categorization.*

*'Those of advanced years seek answers in the Six Palaces; the young seek them in the channels; those in their prime seek them in the Five Viscera. Those of advanced years are overburdened by flavors; the young are exhausted by their laborious tasks; those in their prime overindulge internally.*

*'Overindulgence internally consumes and injures *Essential Qi* and *Vital Substance*; exhaustion from labor invites wind pathogens into the channels; overburdening by flavors harms the Six Palaces—thus, their focus differs.*

*'Your words now are all in error.*

*The Eight Winds (八风) agitate and ripen, the Five Viscera decay and erode, and evil *qi* is transmitted and received among them.*

*The pulse that is floating yet taut—this is the kidney’s deficiency. The floating pulse signifies deficiency, while tautness reflects the liver’s *qi*. Because the kidney’s *qi* is insufficient, the pulse manifests as floating and taut.’*

*(苑, read as *hú* *ruǎn* *yuàn* [胡阮切])*

A pulse that is **deep and stony**—this is the kidney’s *qi* settling inward.
*"Stony"* means firm. *"Settling"* refers to the kidney’s *qi* congealing inwardly, adhering and failing to flow.

When one is **timorous and breathless**, this is the Waterway blocked, with *form* and *qi* dwindling and exhausted.
The kidney’s *qi* being insufficient, the Waterway does not flow. The lung’s storage is disrupted, so *form* and *qi* scatter and dissipate.
*"Exhausted"* means depleted.

Coughing and **restless distress**—this is the kidney’s *qi* in reverse.
The kidney’s *qi* settling inward ascends to the mother [organ, i.e., the liver].
One person’s *qi* resides in one organ alone.
If one claims three organs are simultaneously affected, this is not in accordance with the principles.
The Classics do not say this.

**Leigong said:** There was a man whose limbs were **loose and sagging**, with **shortness of breath, coughing, and blood discharge**. A foolish physician diagnosed him as having injured the lung, felt a **floating, large, and taut pulse**, and dared not treat him. A crude practitioner applied **bloodletting with a lancet**, and the illness improved—yet excessive blood was lost. When the bleeding stopped, the body felt light. What was this condition?

**The Emperor replied:** Your abilities are many, yet you failed here! To diagnose lung injury and refuse treatment is **reckless perception**, contrary to the principles. *(Lancet, read as *biǎn* [方念切].)*

By way of analogy, the flight of a wild goose soars to the heavens.
The wild goose’s ascent to the skies comes by chance—
how could it be the work of its fluttering wings alone?
The crude practitioner’s use of the lancet was much the same.

The Sage’s method of treating illness follows principles and measures.
Drawing upon analogies and comparing cases, transforming mysteries unseen,
extending from above to below—why cling to the *jing* alone?
By *jing*, I mean the *jingmai* (vessels), not the *jingfa* (principles).

Now, when the pulse is floating, large, and empty,
this is when the *pì* qi has severed externally,
detaching from the stomach to return to *Yángmíng*.
The *Zú Tàiyīn* collateral branches diverging into the intestines and stomach—
thus, the *pì* qi severs externally, failing to return to the stomach and join *Yángmíng*.

When the two *fires* cannot overcome the three *waters*,
the pulse becomes disordered and irregular.
By *two fires*, I mean the two *yáng* organs—the heart and lungs, which lie above the *ge* (stomach).
By *three waters*, I mean the three *yīn* organs—the liver, spleen, and kidneys, which lie below the *ge*.

Yet when the three *yīn* forces prevail over the two *yáng*,
the *yáng* cannot overcome the *yīn*, so the pulse becomes disordered and irregular.

When the limbs are loose and sagging,
this is when the *pì* essence fails to circulate.
Earth governs the limbs, so their collapse is due to the *pì* essence’s stagnation.

When breathlessness and coughing occur,
this is when *shuǐ* qi converges with *Yángmíng*—
the *shèn* qi reverses into the stomach, causing *shuǐ* qi to merge with *Yángmíng*.

When blood is discharged,
this is when the pulse’s urgency restricts blood’s flow.
By *discharge*, I mean blood spilling out.
Yet when the pulse’s force is rapid and urgent,
blood overflows internally, failing to enter the vessels,
so blood discharge occurs.
Because the pulse races and blood overflows,
it is said that blood has no path to follow.

As for diagnosing this as lung injury—
this is sheer error and delusion.
Without drawing analogies, one’s understanding is dim.
To claim ignorance and yet diagnose lung injury
is but reckless, deluded speech.

For lung injury, the *pì* qi fails to contain itself,
the stomach’s *qi* is unclean,
the vessel *qi* cannot govern,
the true organ is damaged and decaying,
the vessels are severed at their sides,
and the five organs leak and discharge—
if blood is not restrained, vomiting ensues.
These two conditions are not alike.

When lung *qi* is injured, the *pì* externally aids it,
hence the saying, *“pì qi fails to contain itself.”*
When the lung organ is damaged, *qi* does not flow,
and stagnation causes stomach fullness,
hence *“stomach qi is unclean.”*
The lung governs the circulation of *róng* and *wèi*, *yīn* and *yáng*,
so lung injury means the vessels cannot fulfill their function.
By *true organ*, I mean the lung organ itself.
If the lung organ is damaged, the skin and membranes rupture,
the vessels are severed and fail to circulate,
and the five organs’ *qi* overflows and leaks—
if blood is not restrained, blood vomiting occurs.
Why?
The lung governs the nose, corresponding to the stomach.
The mouth and nose are the *qi*’s gateways.
Now, if the lung organ is damaged and stomach *qi* is unclean,
if blood is not restrained, it flows downward into the stomach,
so if not expelled through the nose, it is vomited out.

Yet lung injury and spleen injury—
their outward signs differ, and their roots diverge,
so these two conditions are not alike.
It is like the formlessness of Heaven and the lawlessness of Earth—
black and white are vastly distant.

This was my failing.
Since you knew this, I did not instruct you.
This is the same.

By drawing upon analogies and comparing cases,
the *Cóngróng* method ensures even minor cases are not missed.
The newly corrected text reads: *“According to the *Tàisù*, ‘light’ should be *jing*.”*
This is called the Ultimate Way.

By clearly drawing upon symptoms and measuring analogies,
following the *Cóngróng* principle,
even the most subtle cases will not be overlooked.
Why is this so?
Because the Dao’s utmost subtlety enables it.

*“I have exhausted my understanding,
received the transmission of the vessels,
and must obtain the *Cóngróng* method
to align with the *Cóngróng* text.”*
This confirms the existence of the ancient *Cóngróng*.

The Yellow Emperor sighed:

like meeting floating clouds—
one can measure the depths of the abyss,

This laments the Dao’s unfathomable extent.
*Mǐnmǐn*—its wondrous applications are endless.

so their measure is certain.

so their edge cannot be grasped.

In governing intentions and actions,
there must be principles and measures.
Following the vessels and observing numbers,
adhering to medical practice,
this serves as a guide for all people.
Thus, there are five transgressions and four virtues—
do you know them?

one will respectfully follow the four seasonal virtues.
For *dé* is the Dao’s manifestation,
the essence of life—
thus, it must be revered and followed.

The *Shànggǔ Tiānzhēnlùn* says:

for their virtue was complete and undamaged.”*

and humans rely on it to live.
Life-qi embraces the spirit,
ascending to unite with Heaven.
